headline: Union That Endorsed Edwards Will Back Obama
text: The Transport Workers Union, which represents 140,000 active workers, is expected to announce Friday that it will become the first union that had backed John Edwards to switch its endorsement to Barack Obama, one union adviser said Thursday night. The union, which endorsed Mr. Edwards, last September represents transit workers in New York City, flight attendants at Southwest Airlines and ground crew for American Airlines.

headline: Bush’s Empty Words on Two Troubled Nations
text: Words are cheap. And never cheaper than when humanitarian tragedies are invoked in speeches for dramatic effect or out of a perfunctory sense of obligation with no effective followup.

headline: Sergey Brin’s iPhone Adventure in Davos
text: For a company that is busy building its own cellphone operating system, Google shared a lot of love for the iPhone on its earnings-related conference call today. The most heartwarming story came from Sergey Brin, the company’s co-president, who said that he uses an iPhone himself. He described the value of the My Location feature of Google Maps on the iPhone, which can figure out (more or less) where you are even though the iPhone can’t receive G.P.S. navigational signals.

headline: Pre-Debate Show in Los Angeles
text: LOS ANGELES – It’s almost a wrap.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'Over Her Dead Body'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "Over Her Dead Body," directed by Jeff Lowell.

headline: Harrison Guarantees Better Defense Against Giants
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — The Giants scored the most points against New England this season in a 38-35 loss, but Patriots safety Rodney Harrison isn’t worried about whether his team’s defensive mistakes in that game have been corrected.

headline: Hulk Hogan Has Obama’s Back
text: Should Barack Obama make it to the general election, he’s got his own pseudo-superhero in his corner: “Hollywood” Hulk Hogan.

headline: Live Blogging the L.A. Debate
text: 10:30 p.m. | Wrapup: Everyone is all smiles, especially Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton, and it’s clear why. This, the 17th debate for the Democrats, was by far the most substantive and engrossing and cordial of this long season.

headline: Another Cup
text: That just about says it all, doesn’t it?

headline: Conversation With Los Angeles Mayor
text: The mayor and campaign co-chairman for Hillary Clinton talked to John Harwood about the nomination race and the California economy.

headline: Burress Held Out of Practice for Second Straight Day
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — Giants wide receiver Plaxico Burress missed his second consecutive practice Thursday, this time because of swelling and soreness in his left knee, according to the designated pool reporter at the session.

headline: Seeking Independence
text: Nicaragua and Colombia both claim San Andrés in a bitter territorial dispute. Now, a nonviolent separatist movement is growing increasingly vocal.

headline: CNN Puts Ohio Debates On Schedule
text: LOS ANGELES — See you next time Senator,” a CNN producer remarked to Senator Barack Obama as he walked off the Kodak Theatre stage.

headline: China’s Inflation Hits American Price Tags
text: SHANGHAI  China’s latest export is inflation. After falling for years, prices of Chinese goods sold in the United States have risen for the last eight months.

headline: Carrying a Weight, but Standing Firm
text: When Brian Cashman tells the story of how he became the Yankees’ general manager, he makes his voice squeaky, like a teenager’s, as he tries to sound confident before the principal owner George Steinbrenner.

headline: Monumental Gesture at Renovated Museum
text: A dramatic photograph on the cover of the Oct. 13, 1967, issue of Time magazine shows the sculptor Tony Smith looking purposely diminutive as he is posed gazing up at his most monumental sculpture, “Smoke,” that enveloped the atrium of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington. The sculpture he created that year is 22 feet high, 45 feet long and 33 feet wide.

headline: China Accuses Online Activist of Subversion
text: BEIJING  A prominent Chinese human rights advocate who has been in custody since late December was issued a formal arrest warrant this week on charges of subversion despite calls from prominent Chinese intellectuals and lawyers for his release.

headline: When the Conceptual Was Political
text: In December 1983 the Argentine Conceptual artist Marta Minujin and a group of helpers spent 17 days building a full-scale model of the Parthenon in a public park in Buenos Aires. Except for a metal scaffolding, it was made almost entirely of books wrapped in plastic. All the books had been banned by one of the most oppressive juntas in the country’s history, which was just being dismantled after Argentina’s first democratic election in a decade. “The Parthenon of Books/Homage to Democracy,” as Ms. Minujin’s work was titled, stood for about three weeks. Then the public was allowed to disassemble the piece and keep the books.

headline: Yankees Add Ensberg to the Mix at First Base
text: Morgan Ensberg has played only one game at first base in seven major league seasons, so he does not know how hard it will be to learn that position for the Yankees this spring. But he has a theory.

headline: Small Law Firm’s Big Role in Bundling Mortgages
text: In recent years, as subprime lending proliferated, a small law firm played a big role on Wall Street.

headline: More Than Workout Space
text: GETTING away to a second home usually means leaving routine behind, but when that routine is a workout regimen, many second-home owners like to take it with them.

headline: Artistic Muscle, Flexed for Medicis
text: Michelangelo was a terrible kvetch. His back forever ached; popes were slow with the paychecks; the local food was always an insult, a disgrace. No one worked half as hard as he did, and slacker artists made him nuts. “Draw, Antonio; draw, Antonio; draw and don’t waste time,” he scrawled on a sketch he gave to a lackadaisical young pupil and studio assistant, Antonio Mini, in 1524.

headline: Troubled Bond Insurer Puts on Its Defense
text: On Thursday, MBIA fought back. Under attack from critics who describe the company as effectively insolvent, MBIA, a big and troubled bond insurer, presented a spirited defense in a four-hour conference call with investors and analysts. Its executives did not allow the participants to ask questions directly, accepting only questions submitted in advance.

headline: A Plea for More Federal Dollars to Build America
text: To the Editor:

headline: Solaris and Apes Hill Club
text: Solaris

headline: Florida: F.B.I. Backs Students on Explosives
text: Two Egyptian college students arrested near a Navy weapons station in South Carolina last year were carrying low-grade fireworks, as they claimed, not explosives as charged by federal prosecutors, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has determined. The men, Ahmed Abdellatif Sherif Mohamed, 26, and Youssef Samir Megahed, 21, engineering students at the University of South Florida, were indicted by a Tampa grand jury on charges of transporting explosives. The F.B.I. report was submitted to the court Wednesday by Mr. Megahed’s lawyer as part of a motion seeking bail. It said the items in the car  PVC pipe containing a mixture of sugar, potassium nitrate and cat litter  were ingredients for a “pyrotechnic mixture” that burned but did not explode. Mr. Megahed is a permanent resident of the United States; Mr. Mohamed was on a student visa.

headline: The Verdict: It’s Broken
text: The case of the mismanaged American Indian trust funds is Dickensian both in length  now 11 years before the courts  and inequity. On Wednesday, Judge James Robertson of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia ruled that the Interior Department had “unreasonably delayed” its accounting for billions of dollars owed to American Indian landholders and that the agency “cannot remedy the breach.”

headline: Senator Wants N.F.L. Spying Case Explained
text: The ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee wants N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to explain why the league destroyed evidence related to spying by the New England Patriots.

headline: For His Super Bowl Wager, One Mayor Keeps It Real
text: It’s not so much the NY logo on the Giants’ helmets that gets to James L. Cassella. He can handle that. “I happen to like New York City,” said Mr. Cassella, who is the mayor of East Rutherford, N.J. That’s the small borough where the Giants have played football since well before Eli Manning first drew breath.

headline: Indonesian Chickens, and People, Hard Hit by Bird Flu
text: KONCANG, Indonesia  The rooster started to crow at 3 a.m., and Partoparmin, a farmer in this small hillside village, went into his yard to look. All around him, chickens were lying on the ground, twitching and shaking.

headline: TV Stations Seek Shows to Put Online
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: St. Peter’s A.D. Will Retire
text: Bill Stein, the athletic director for St. Peter’s College in Jersey City, will retire in July after 26 years, the college announced.

headline: Pakistani P.R.
text: You have to hand it to Pervez Musharraf. With all the problems the Pakistani president faces at home, he still found time to spend eight days in Europe last week, assuring world leaders everything is fine in his nuclear-armed state. But everything is not fine, and the cracks in his sunny public-relations facade were not hard to see.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: An Obsessive Love of Prayer
text: Shot over three years in a close-knit Jewish Reconstructionist community in Philadelphia, “Praying With Lior” documents the extraordinary life of Lior Liebling, a rabbi’s son with Down syndrome and an obsessive love of prayer.

headline: Bush Presses Democrats to Pass Stimulus Bill
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush said on Friday that the economy remains basically sound, but that the disappointing report on jobs shows the need for Congress to approve a stimulus package without delay.

headline: Lost Boosts ABC
text: The return of “Lost,” albeit a two-hour repeat of last season’s finale, buoyed ABC’s ratings on Wednesday during a night otherwise dominated by Fox’s “American Idol” and “The Moment of Truth.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the two Fox programs delivered the night’s largest audiences by far, 25.3 million viewers at 8 for “American Idol,” followed by 17.9 million for “The Moment of Truth” at 9. ABC ranked a distant second for the night among adults 18 to 49, with “Wife Swap” at 8 (5.8 million), followed by the “Lost” rerun at 9 (8.5 million), which the network enhanced with on-screen pop-ups to fill in the back story. In total viewers, however, ABC finished third behind Fox and NBC, which benefited from “Deal or No Deal” at 8 (9.8 million) and “Law & Order” at 10 (11.1 million). CBS finished fourth over all with repeats.

headline: Motorola Weighs a Shift in Cellphones
text: Motorola, which in recent years has been unable to capitalize on the success of its popular Razr phone, said Thursday that it was exploring the possibility of selling or spinning off its cellular phone business as a way to make the company more profitable.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,934 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:

headline: O’Brien Allowed to Coach Again
text: Jim O’Brien won an appeal Thursday and can return to the college sidelines after he had been fired by Ohio State as its men’s basketball coach and essentially barred from coaching by the N.C.A.A. for paying a recruit.A year after the initial 2006 ruling found seven rules violations, the N.C.A.A. threw out three of them and part of a fourth because the association’s enforcement staff missed a deadline for filing charges. Any further restrictions on future employment were lifted by Thursday’s ruling by an N.C.A.A. appeals committee.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $6,999,342

headline: Regulators Warn France Against Protecting Bank
text: PARIS  As numerous European banks considered whether to make a bid for Société Générale, reeling from a $7.1 billion trading loss, regulators in Brussels warned the French government Thursday against trying to protect the bank from foreign suitors.

headline: Feminists Find Unity Is Elusive
text: Jessica Valenti, a 29-year-old blogger from Astoria (by way of Williamsburg), and Marcia Pappas, a 57-year-old life coach who owned and ran a hair salon in Albany for most of her career, might be surprised to find how much they had in common if they ran into each other at a party. (Admittedly, it’s hard to imagine what that party would look like).

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the Democratic primary in Florida referred incorrectly to a pledge by the candidates that they would not campaign in the state. They made that pledge to Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina, the four states that had permission to hold early primaries; they did not make that deal with the Democratic National Committee. (Go to Article)

headline: A Home for Your Gear, and a Place to Play With It
text: MICHAEL HUNT was tired of keeping his fishing boat and Mercedes convertible under tarps next to his house in Post Falls, Idaho. His prized recreational vehicle was slowly falling apart after spending a few winters outside. With no room left in his garage, he wasn’t sure what to do.

headline: Robert M. Ball Is Dead at 93; Led Social Security
text: Robert M. Ball, the commissioner of Social Security in the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon administrations, an architect of Medicare and an influential opponent of privatizing Social Security, died Wednesday at his home in Bowie, Md. He was 93.

headline: To Giants, Desert Solitude Is Nothing but a Mirage
text: TEMPE, Ariz.  The man had climbed over a fence, apparently, and made his way quietly along the railroad tracks that border the east side of the practice fields where the Giants are preparing for the Super Bowl.

headline: Stockholm Plans Bergman Street
text: The Stockholm City Council is expected to name a street and adjoining square in honor of Ingmar Bergman, the Swedish master filmmaker who died in July, Agence France-Presse reported. “I would be very surprised if the decision doesn’t go through,” said Mikael Soederlund, a city councilor who backs the proposal. The street and square are near the Royal Dramatic Theater, of which Bergman was the director and where he staged plays by Strindberg, Ibsen, Anouilh, Tennessee Williams and others.

headline: Only G.M. Posts a Gain in January Sales in U.S.
text: DETROIT  General Motors was the only one of the six biggest automakers whose sales in the United States increased last month, according to figures released Friday.

headline: Patriots Get Ready for the Giants and History
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  With the excitement continuing to build for Sunday’s Super Bowl XLII, New England quarterback Tom Brady only heightened the hyperbole Thursday.

headline: Gearing Up for the Big Countdown
text: A DEFINITE contender for the title of Most Precocious Republican in New York City, Marcus Cederqvist, at 37 the baby-faced new executive director of the Board of Elections, is gearing up for his debut as the city’s chief vote counter for Tuesday’s New York presidential primary.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 21 about two music stores in Harlem that are victims of gentrification misstated their relative location. The Harlem Record Shack, on West 125th Street, is southeast  not northwest  of Bobby’s Happy House, which is on Frederick Douglass Boulevard, and is a few hundred feet  not a few hundred yards  away.

headline: China and Alcoa Buy Stake in Rio Tinto
text: BEIJING  The state-owned Aluminum Corporation of China joined Alcoa on Friday in taking a 12 percent stake in Rio Tinto. The Chinese company also said it might buy more shares to derail a hostile takeover attempt by BHP Billiton, a merger that China fears could drive up prices for raw materials even further.

headline: Times Reporter Subpoenaed Over Source for Book
text: WASHINGTON  A federal grand jury has issued a subpoena to a reporter of The New York Times, apparently to try to force him to reveal his confidential sources for a 2006 book on the Central Intelligence Agency, one of the reporter’s lawyers said Thursday.

headline: U.S. Economy Unexpectedly Sheds 17,000 Jobs
text: The economy lost 17,000 jobs in January, the Labor Department reported on Friday, the first monthly decline in four years and the most striking evidence yet that the United States may be slipping into a recession.

headline: Travels With Hemingway: That’s Not All She Wrote
text: It is one of the myths of the profession that inside every journalist there is a great novel struggling to get out. For Ernest Hemingway, the myth became a reality. For Martha Gellhorn, Hemingway’s third wife, the struggle was her life story. In “The Maddening Truth,” a new play being staged by the Keen Company at the Clurman Theater, David Hay makes a case that Gellhorn ultimately won the battle.

headline: Plenty of Porcelain in West Palm Beach
text: Floridians have always had a healthy appetite for fine porcelain, which explains its appearance at the 10-day, 90-dealer art and antiques fair that opens on Friday in West Palm Beach.

headline: Kurds’ Power Wanes as Arab Anger Rises
text: BAGHDAD  As a minority group in Iraq, the Kurds have enjoyed disproportionate influence in the country’s politics since the ouster of Saddam Hussein in 2003. But now their leverage appears to be declining as tensions rise with Iraqi Arabs, raising the specter of another fissure alongside the sectarian divide between Sunnis and Shiites.

headline: In the List of Top-Selling Games, Clear Evidence of a Sea Change
text: Ever since video games decamped from arcades and set up shop in the nation’s living rooms in the 1980s, they have been thought of as a pastime enjoyed mostly alone. The image of the antisocial, sunlight-deprived game geek is enshrined in the popular consciousness as deeply as any stereotype of recent decades.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 1 about the parole of Sara Jane Moore, who tried to assassinate President Gerald R. Ford in 1975, referred incorrectly to her ties to radical leftist groups. She was not involved with the Symbionese Liberation Army.

headline: Former President Shows Calmer Face in Campaign
text: The red-faced, finger-wagging Bill Clinton has left the campaign trail.

headline: Microsoft Bids $44.6 Billion for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Microsoft said Friday that it has made an offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion, or $31 a share, in a mix of cash and stock.

headline: Lawmaker on Long Island Wants Worker Status Verified
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  In the latest move on eastern Long Island to crack down on illegal immigrants, a freshman Suffolk County legislator proposed a bill on Thursday that would require the estimated 15,000 licensed contractors there to verify their workers’ legal status.

headline: A Small-Town Oasis in the High Desert
text: SOUTH of Tucson on Interstate 19, just over the Santa Cruz County line, two rugged mountain ranges vie for your attention: the soaring Santa Rita Mountains to the east, and the smaller, but no less compelling, Tumacacori Mountains to the west.

headline: The No. 6 Train From Pelham Bay Park to Brooklyn Bridge-City Hall
text: This is the last commute in the Next Stop series. Billie Cohen took a different commute around the New York region every week day in January.

headline: New York Candidates Awash in Real Estate Cash
text: The real estate industry, racing to beat strict new limits on campaign contributions, has been flooding New York City candidates with donations for the 2009 campaign at a rate three and four times that in previous election cycles.

headline: Mehdi and Sarah and Adrien and Manu, Coupling Under a Cloud
text: The French director André Téchiné is a master at evoking personality quirks, the unpredictability of relationships and the haphazard way love affairs, friendships and social groups form and dissolve. Many of his films, like “Changing Times” and “Wild Reeds,” portray a multicultural environment in which French and North African characters mingle, sometimes uneasily.

headline: Two Are Sentenced for 1992 Mob Killings
text: Two Ukrainian immigrants convicted in a pair of organized-crime murders in Brooklyn that went unsolved for 14 years were sentenced on Thursday to 25 years to life in prison, prosecutors said.

headline: Voters’ Dark Mood
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rangers Help Valiquette Claim First N.H.L. Shutout
text: PHILADELPHIA  The first goal the Rangers scored against the Flyers on Thursday night seemed like it was drawn from their wish list. They had been playing defense relentlessly, trying to stop their season from sliding out of control, when forward Nigel Dawes skated into the offensive zone with no teammates to help him and no indication that he would alter the course of the game.

headline: Democrats: And Then There Were Two
text: To the Editor:

headline: Second Lawmaker Is Killed as Kenya’s Riots Intensify
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  A second Kenyan opposition lawmaker was shot dead on Thursday, and riots immediately exploded in opposition strongholds, putting the country increasingly on edge.

headline: 8 Banks in Talks to Rescue Bond Insurer
text: Eight major banks are in talks to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, as part of an industrywide rescue being orchestrated by state regulators, people briefed on the negotiations said Friday.

headline: Australia Won’t Punish Lawyer for Leak
text: SYDNEY, Australia  The lawyer for an Australian resident who had been a suspect in connection with the bungled bombings in London and Glasgow last June will not be subject to any disciplinary action for leaking the transcript of the police interview with his client, a state agency reviewing the matter said on Friday.

headline: A Stadium Goes Up, but It Is Missing a Cornerstone
text: The Minnesota Twins are building a ballpark that is expected to open in 2010.

headline: Favor Between Friends Led 2 Officers Into Corruption Case, Court Papers Show
text: Luis M. Batista and Henry Conde: old friends, and New York City police officers. Mr. Batista joined the force in 1997, his friend in 1994.

headline: Doing Their Part to Help Save the Planet, in High Style
text: Jessica Stam, the leonine fashion model with honey-colored hair and outstanding high arches, tried on a very short ivory dress by the label Rodarte. It was described as being made of hemp silk and a “Piña cobweb,” which sounded as if it might be a drink order for Elvira.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about the Democratic primary in Florida referred incorrectly to a pledge by the candidates that they would not campaign in the state. They made that pledge to Iowa, New Hampshire, Nevada and South Carolina, the four states that had permission to hold early primaries; they did not make that deal with the Democratic National Committee.

headline: Nets and New Drug Make Inroads Against Malaria
text: Widespread distribution of mosquito nets and a new medicine sharply reduced malaria deaths in several African countries, World Health Organization researchers reported Thursday.

headline: Bellwether State Fervently Seeks Choice Who Can Win in the Fall
text: ST. LOUIS  They are used to picking the president around here, and more than ever, it seems, they want to extend their winning streak to the primaries.

headline: Public and Private: The Gap in Education
text: To the Editor:

headline: Release of 1950s U.S. Grand Jury Transcripts Is Sought in Rosenberg Atomic Spy Case
text: After half a century of scholarly work, one might have thought that little of the famous spy story of the Rosenbergs could still be left untold. On Thursday, however, a group of historians, led by a government watchdog group, began the process of prying loose the last trove of secret documents remaining in the case.

headline: Suicide Attack in Mosque Kills an Afghan Deputy Governor
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The deputy governor of Helmand Province and five other people were killed by a suicide bomber during afternoon prayers in a mosque in the provincial capital, Afghan officials said. The Taliban claimed responsibility through a spokesman.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about a new production of “Porgy and Bess” by the Zachary Scott Theater Center in Austin, Tex., misspelled the surname of one of the singers whose recording of the work inspired the theater’s producing artistic director, Dave Steakley. She is Cleo Laine, not Lane.

headline: Estrada and Nationals Have Deal
text: Johnny Estrada and the Washington Nationals agreed to a one-year, $1.25 million contract, giving the Nationals an experienced catcher to back up Paul Lo Duca.

headline: Mexican Farmers Protest End of Corn-Import Taxes
text: MEXICO CITY  Tens of thousands of farmers clogged the streets of the capital on Thursday to protest the end of tariffs on corn from the United States, warning that the elimination of trade barriers could drive them out of business and lead more Mexicans to migrate north.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Sunday about the downhill skier Daron Rahlves and his hopes for the skiercross event at the Winter X Games misstated, in some editions, his place in the history of the prestigious Hahnenkamm downhill in Austria. In 2003, he became the second American to win that race, not the first. (Bud Werner was the first, in 1959.)

headline: OPEC Is Expected to Keep Oil Production Unchanged
text: Ignoring calls from the United States and other consuming countries to pump more oil into the global economy, the OPEC oil cartel is expected to keep its output unchanged when the group’s ministers meet in Vienna on Friday.

headline: Burger King Profit Jumps 29 Percent
text: MIAMI (AP)  Burger King Holdings said Thursday that its second-quarter profit jumped 29 percent, helped by strong sales of its Whopper and new Homestyle Melt sandwiches, along with promotions with TV tie-ins.

headline: Buying Low: Minor Leaguer Takes Stock of Himself
text: While the pending trade of Johan Santana to the Mets has shaken up Major League Baseball, a relatively unknown, submarine-throwing farmhand who might never reach the big leagues has also spent the week rattling his sport’s economics.

headline: Skis of a Different Breed
text: To the Editor: “As Natural as Sneezing, But So Much More Fun” (Rituals, Jan. 25) is a fine story on the joys of downhill skiing, but based upon the accompanying photograph I fully expected this to be on the joys of cross-country skiing. Any skier will know that that photo is of cross-country skis and poles, not the far more complicated downhill gear.

headline: For Retired N.F.L. Greats, Checks Are Out of Balance
text: Phoenix

headline: A Good Plan for Traffic Relief
text: Mayor Michael Bloomberg rightly touts congestion pricing as a solution for New York’s traffic gridlock, a boon to the environment and a way to finance improvements to the city’s mass transit system. A commission, appointed by top state and city officials, has now proposed a sensible pricing plan. Important details still must be worked out, and city and state lawmakers must approve a plan before the end of March to qualify for a $354 million federal grant. They must not miss that deadline or this opportunity.

headline: Giants Make Statements of Fashion and Confidence
text: Most of the Giants wore their white jerseys with big, red numerals Thursday morning when they met with the news media for the final time before Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Cradle for Serious Grooving
text: IT’S 7:30 on a weekday evening, and the Josie Robertson Plaza at the heart of Lincoln Center is crowded. Slender teenagers from Juilliard’s ballet program, hair still up in tight “bunhead” knots, dart like gazelles toward the New York State Theater, where City Ballet is about to perform. They cut through the older operagoers flowing toward the Metropolitan Opera House. Film fans stroll diagonally across the plaza, heading to the Walter Reade Theater.

headline: Maybe Never? Love’s Old Bittersweet Song
text: “Maybe Forever,” which explores a failed relationship, might have made a good show for Co-Dependents Anonymous, one audience member observed wryly when the piece opened at Dance Theater Workshop on Wednesday. The 85-minute work is occasionally as tedious as the real thing and the memories that linger. But Meg Stuart, who created the piece with Philipp Gehmacher, has long specialized in teetering productively on the edge of tedium. And while “Maybe Forever” is less ambitious than some of her other work, it suggests why Ms. Stuart, who left New York for Europe in the early 1990s, has a reputation for unfailingly imaginative, provocative avant-garde theater dance.

headline: Amazon to Buy Audiobook Seller for $300 Million
text: Amazon.com, which has been rapidly adding digital downloads to its vast Web store, said on Thursday that it had agreed to buy Audible, the largest online seller of audiobooks.

headline: Wesley Snipes Is Acquitted of Tax Felonies
text: OCALA, Fla.  The actor Wesley Snipes was acquitted of the most serious charges against him on Friday in the most prominent tax prosecution since Leona Helmsley, the billionaire hotelier, was convicted of tax fraud in 1989.

headline: A Green Energy Industry Takes Root in California
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The sun is starting to grow jobs.

headline: Bank Chief May Face Questions
text: PARIS  A senior prosecutor examining the trading scandal at Société Générale recommended Friday that the embattled chief executive, Daniel Bouton, be questioned by judges in connection with accusations he has made about a rogue trader’s role in the bank’s loss of billions of euros.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Well column in Science Times on Tuesday, about statins, misidentified the location of the university where Dr. Beatrice Golomb, who questioned whether they help most users live longer, is an associate professor of medicine. It is the University of California, San Diego  not San Francisco.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: One on One in Debate, Democrats Set Aim at G.O.P.
text: LOS ANGELES  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama met for debate here Thursday, sitting side by side and sharing a night of smiles, friendly eye-catching and gentle banter. Cordial as the encounter was, the candidates did not mask their own divisions, even as they previewed the attacks one of them will ultimately make against a Republican rival.

headline: Coins in the New Realm
text: HOLLYWOOD  Xavier Buck planned to spend $100,000 to bid for domain names, those parcels of virtual Internet real estate, at a live auction here last week.

headline: Senate Democrats’ Stimulus Plan Hits Roadblock
text: WASHINGTON  Backed solidly by the Bush administration, Senate Republicans said on Thursday that they would block a $157 billion economic stimulus package championed by Senate Democrats, who said they would have no choice but to quickly adopt a cheaper, more streamlined plan approved this week by the House.

headline: Home Depot Will Lay Off 500 Workers
text: Home Depot, battered by a downturn in the housing market, is laying off 500 workers at its headquarters in Atlanta, or about 10 percent of its work force there, the company said Thursday.

headline: A Long Illness Compounds Dubious Financial Decisions
text: Agnes and Francisco Santiago are homeowners.

headline: The Rev. Marcial Maciel, 87, Conservative Catholic Leader, Dies
text: ROME  The Rev. Marcial Maciel Degollado, founder of the influential Roman Catholic group the Legionaries of Christ and the most prominent priest disciplined after accusations of sexual abuse, died Wednesday, the group announced Thursday. He was 87.

headline: Aid to Indebted Students
text: To the Editor:

headline: Britney	Spears Woes Inspire Meltdown
text: The Rambert Dance Company, one of Britain’s leading modern-dance troupes, will perform “Meltdown,” a choreographic interpretation of the travails of Britney Spears, in an appearance on Friday as part of its new season at the Southbank Center in London, Agence France-Presse reported. Hubert Essakow, who created the work, set to music by Richard Thomas (“Jerry Springer: The Opera”), said he became interested in Ms. Spears’s problems about a year ago. “I thought this was a really modern-day tragedy, this reversal of fortune,” he told BBC Television. “I saw somebody who had such great hope and was adored by millions of people, then goes down the wrong route.” In an excerpt from “Meltdown” that accompanied the BBC report, the Spears character is seen dancing in an abbreviated pink top, black vinyl hot pants and a pink Stetson while being harried by photographers costumed in menacing black. Eventually she is carried away by dancers dressed as white-coated doctors.

headline: Georgia: Life Sentence in Hiker’s Death
text: A man was sentenced to life in prison, with possibility of parole in 30 years, after pleading guilty to murder in the beating-death of a young woman hiking in the north Georgia mountains. District Attorney Lee Darragh of Dawson County said the murder resulted from a plan by the man, Gary M. Hilton, 61, above, to abduct the woman, Meredith Emerson, 24, in order to steal money using her A.T.M. cards. But Ms. Emerson, whose body was found Jan. 7 near Dawsonville, misled Mr. Hilton, giving him false numbers with the hope that the authorities would be alerted to efforts to gain access to her account, Mr. Darragh said. Mr. Hilton was indicted on one murder count.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: From the Housing Market to the Maternity Ward
text: For the first time in 35 years, America’s total fertility rate  the estimated number of children a woman will have in her lifetime  reached 2.1, the theoretical level required to maintain the country’s population, according to recent data from the National Center for Health Statistics.

headline: Deal Over Randalls Island Sports Fields Is Voided
text: A Manhattan judge voided an agreement between the Bloomberg administration and 20 private schools on Thursday, ruling that the city had improperly given the schools priority in using athletic fields on Randalls Island in exchange for $45 million.

headline: An Alienated Bunch Not Dealing With Loss
text: Why do we like sad plays? Is it because they allow us to confront painful emotions or escape from them? “Deathbed,” a coolly thoughtful and taut meditation by the stylish playwright Mark Schultz, engages this question with an eyebrow raised.

headline: California: Early Report on Plane Crash
text: The pilots of two small planes did not move to avoid each other before colliding last week near Los Angeles, killing five people, investigators said. A preliminary report by the National Transportation Safety Board said a witness saw the planes cruising toward each other for at least five seconds without taking an evasive maneuver. The collision occurred about a mile south of Corona Municipal Airport, which does not have a manned control tower. The report said that a Cessna 150 was headed east on approach to the airport and that a Cessna 172 was traveling north. It did not blame either pilot. The collision on Jan. 20 killed two people in each plane and a person on the ground. A final report is expected by the end of the year.

headline: Bored Stepbrothers, Intrepid Platypus
text: Imagine “Family Guy” with an espionage subplot and a big dose of magical realism, and you have “Phineas and Ferb,” a new animated children’s series whose debut episode will be shown on the Disney Channel on Friday night.

headline: Talk of Independence in a Place Claimed by 2 Nations
text: SAN ANDRÉS, Colombia  Down the road from a neighborhood here called the Hill, where reggae blares out of weathered houses and parishioners sing hymns in English at the First Baptist Church, President Álvaro Uribe recently inaugurated a hospital with a decidedly Colombian name: Amor de Patria.

headline: Electronic Arts Posts Loss, Citing a Revamp
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Electronic Arts, the video game maker, swung to a quarterly loss because of reorganization charges and deferred revenue. But the company largely met Wall Street’s forecasts as it posted solid revenue gains in what was a strong holiday season for the game industry.

headline: Arthur B. Kramer, Playwright’s Brother, Dies at 81
text: Arthur B. Kramer, who built a small New York law firm into an international one and whose tense relationship with his brother Larry Kramer, the playwright and gay rights advocate, helped inspire a benchmark play of the 1980s, died on Saturday. He was 81 and lived in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Britain: People-Smuggling Arrests in Raids
text: After dawn raids on 12 locations in London and one in the British Midlands that resulted in 13 arrests, Scotland Yard officials said they had broken up two Turkish-led gangs engaged in “large-scale human smuggling” into Britain. Police commanders said the gangs charged Chinese migrants up to $42,000 each for journeys that could take up to 18 months, with stopovers at safe houses in Belgium and France, where additional arrests were made. The police said the raids demonstrated a resolve by European governments to curb criminal gangs that run an underground railroad for illegal immigrants along with other rackets that include heroin smuggling and money laundering.

headline: Spreading Joy With a Mobile Disco
text: “I want to see these hills shine and sparkle like disco floors.” So says Vincent (Magnus Aronson), the kooky dreamer hero of the short feature “Build a Ship, Sail to Sadness.”

headline: Digging for Truth in a Life That’s Built Upon a Lie
text: Fundamental issues of ethnic and religious identity and the agony of exile are at the heart of “Live and Become,” an intermittently compelling swatch of recent Israeli history filtered through the experience of an African immigrant.

headline: Winter. Cross-Country Racing. And Not a Ski on the Course.
text: ON a clear, 13-degree December morning at 8,000 feet above sea level, hundreds of snowshoers are assembled around a white plastic tent, preparing to race one another up and down the side of a snow-covered mountain. They are limbering up, sprinting for short distances across the hard-packed snow, turning on G.P.S. watches, cueing up MP3 play lists. They are growing familiar with the apparatus strapped to their feet, which will allow them to climb up icy hills in this part of Beaver Creek, Colo.; bound through aspen-rich trails; and fly down steep mountain pitches coated in thigh-high powder.

headline: Ad Growth Still Strong, Google Says
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said it has seen no effect from a slowing economy on its advertising business, as it reported a 17 percent jump in profit and a 51 percent growth in revenue in the fourth quarter.

headline: Blizzards and Coal Shortages Strain China’s Rail Network
text: BEIJING  After blizzards disrupted coal deliveries, acute electricity shortages across a swath of central and southern China have exposed the fragility of transportation networks in the world’s fastest-growing major economy.

headline: Giuliani Will Return Diminished, but Not Finished, Associates Say
text: WASHINGTON  He left as America’s Mayor. But Rudolph W. Giuliani will return to New York’s business and political arenas as a mere mortal, some of his friends and business associates acknowledge.

headline: Petty Already Rocking Long Before Halftime
text: PHOENIX  The Giants and the New England Patriots will be busy fine-tuning their game plans Sunday when the halftime entertainment, Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers, takes the stage for a 12-minute set.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: A Musical Sermon Steeped in Darkness
text: Maybe the directors of the new-music ensemble Sequitur were feeling mystical rather than merely dour when they assembled the group’s Wednesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall. Four of the five scores were vocal works, and death figured prominently in each text. The fifth, as an instrumental work, might reasonably have been taken as abstract  it is basically a chaconne  except that the composer, Arthur Levering, named it “Furies,” after the mythological goddesses of vengeance.

headline: Jay-Z to Headline Glastonbury?
text: A New York rapper will be one of the headliners at the Glastonbury Festival in England this summer, but Michael Eavis, 72, the dairy farmer who has been organizing the event on his land since 1970, refused to confirm on Thursday that he was referring to Jay-Z, Agence France-Presse reported. “We’re trying to get youngsters to the festival this year,” he said, expressing hope that half of the 137,500 ticket holders would be under 25. “Hopefully the headliner will appeal to them. Traditionally we’ve had a very white lineup, and I’m moving away from that. The Saturday slot is a wonderful hip-hop artist from New York and a bit of a legend, in my view. We need more young people here. I’m trying to address the balance. Otherwise, the festival will die out with the older people.” Nevertheless, a golden-oldie star usually is the Sunday headliner, and Mr. Eavis confirmed that the honor this year would fall to Neil Diamond. This year’s festival on the 800-acre farm runs June 27 through 29.

headline: Microsoft Bids $44.6 Billion for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  In a bold move to counter Google’s online pre-eminence, Microsoft said Friday that it had made an unsolicited offer to buy Yahoo for about $44.6 billion in a mix of cash and stock.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about genital pain in women, misspelled the name of a muscle relaxant said to bring relief in some cases. It is Flexeril, not Flexoril.

headline: Oregon: Deadline for Fish-Run Plan Is Delayed
text: A federal judge in Portland has postponed for a second time a deadline for a plan that meets his standards for balancing operations of Columbia River Basin dams with threatened or endangered fish runs. At a December hearing the judge, James A. Redden of Federal District Court, moved the deadline for a third biological opinion to March 18 from March 1 but threatened unspecified consequences if he rejected it. On Tuesday he extended it to May 5, said Brian Gorman, spokesman for the National Oceanic Atmospheric Administration Fisheries in Seattle. Judge Redden has thrown out two opinions as inadequate and wrote in December that a draft of a third effort looked little better.

headline: Are You Up Yet?
text: It is hardly a revelation that teenagers like to sleep late. But more and more research is showing that this is not just a preference  or even the result of late-night studying or instant messaging  but is rooted in their biological rhythms. All of this would be little more than an interesting observation except that most high schools start so early, and so many teenagers are having a hard time staying awake.

headline: Online Schooling Grows, Setting Off a Debate
text: MILWAUKEE — Weekday mornings, three of Tracie Weldie’s children eat breakfast, make beds and trudge off to public school — in their case, downstairs to their basement in a suburb here, where their mother leads them through math and other lessons outlined by an Internet-based charter school.

headline: Exxon Mobil Profit Sets Record Again
text: By any measure, Exxon Mobil’s performance last year was a blowout.

headline: Star of the Silver Screen and a Political Entourage
text: Among political types, Rudolph W. Giuliani’s failed campaign in Florida will be the subject of endless post-mortems, second-guessing, what-ifs. They will rehash the strategic miscalculations, the exit poll numbers, the single-minded focus on Florida.

headline: Smiles All Around in an Evening of Dueling Niceties
text: They did not ostentatiously shake hands. They let their eyes make nice.

headline: Money for Transit Systems to Increase
text: The public transit systems in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey will be getting a large increase in federal financing to help them better prevent or respond to a terrorist attack, according to government officials.

headline: Across the Universe, Literally
text: NASA will send the Beatles song “Across the Universe” across the universe on Monday, the agency said. At precisely 7 p.m., E.S.T. the song will be beamed by the agency’s Deep Space Network of antennas at the North Star, Polaris, which is 431 light years away. The transmission is to mark the 40th anniversary of the recording of the song, as well as the 50th anniversary of both NASA and its first satellite, Explorer I, and the 45th anniversary of the Deep Space Network, which carries out communications between NASA and its far-flung fleet of spacecraft. In a message to the space agency, Paul McCartney, one of the two remaining Beatles, said, “Send my love to the aliens. All the best, Paul.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fireworks Explosion in Istanbul Kills 22
text: ISTANBUL  An unlicensed fireworks factory here exploded accidentally, leaving at least 22 people dead and at least 100 injured, Turkish officials said Thursday.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the National Briefing column on Tuesday about the confirmation of Ed Schafer as secretary of agriculture misspelled the surname of his predecessor. He is Mike Johanns, not Johans.

headline: Sony Reports 25% Rise in Profit, but Lowers Its Forecast
text: TOKYO  Sony said Thursday that its profit rose more than 25 percent in the final three months of 2007, helped by robust sales of televisions and computer games. But it said strong yen and subprime problems would weigh on demand this year.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: A Guy, His Psychic and a Jealous Ghost
text: For what it is  a romantic comedy about the rivalry between a jealous ghost and a flaky psychic for the love of a veterinarian  “Over Her Dead Body” is not bad. Eva Longoria Parker, as Kate, the ghost, represents the control-freak/ice-queen end of the female comedic spectrum pretty well, while Lake Bell as Ashley, the psychic, is perfectly lovely on the sweet, scatterbrained end. In the middle is Henry the vet, played by the winningly smirky Paul Rudd, and there are sidekicks drawn from the usual storeroom: the kooky sister (Lindsay Sloane) and the gay male best friend (Jason Biggs).

headline: Britain: Lawmaker Suspended Over Son’s Pay
text: The longstanding practice of politicians putting family members on the public payroll came under scrutiny with the censure and 10-day suspension by Parliament of a Conservative member, Derek Conway, left, after he was found to have paid his 22-year-old son nearly $100,000 in public money for work as a parliamentary researcher during three years when he was a full-time college student in Newcastle, 300 miles from London. A House of Commons panel found “no record” of any work by the son. Mr. Conway apologized and said he would not seek re-election. More than 40 other Commons members employ spouses and other family members. Sir Christopher Kelly, chairman of the Committee on Standards in Public Life, urged that Britain consider following the example of the United States Congress in barring lawmakers from employing family members.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Senior Qaeda Commander Is Killed by U.S. Missile
text: WASHINGTON  An American missile strike in Pakistan’s northwestern tribal areas killed a senior commander of Al Qaeda who had been involved in planning attacks on United States and NATO troops in Afghanistan, American officials said Thursday.

headline: Times Co. Swings to Profit
text: The New York Times Company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $53 million on Thursday as revenue dropped, but it continued to fare better than most of its peers across the troubled newspaper industry.

headline: Russia Creates a $32 Billion Sovereign Wealth Fund
text: MOSCOW  Russia has split its oil proceeds into two funds and cleared the way for one to invest in foreign stocks and bonds, officials said Thursday. But actual investments are not expected to begin until fall at the earliest.

headline: State Commission Approves a Plan for Congestion Pricing
text: A state traffic commission voted on Thursday to recommend that New York City charge drivers an $8 daily fee to bring their cars into Manhattan below 60th Street.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Exploring the Neighborhood, on Screen and Off
text: READING

headline: Lone Star Executive Sentenced
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A court here on Friday found Lone Star, the United States private equity fund, and one of its executives guilty of manipulating stock prices, dealing a blow to Lone Star in its intensely monitored legal battle with South Korean prosecutors.

headline: Awakening, Nightly, at 50
text: EARLY in the first act of “Spring Awakening,” the hit Duncan Sheik musical about teenage lust in 19th-century Germany, Kate Burton throws open her blouse, revealing a lacy, low-cut corset, and does a bouncy, hoochie-coochie dance into the face of her young co-star, Gerard Canonico. She looks as if she’s having a lot of fun. (So does he.) But not as much fun as in the last scene, when Ms. Burton  a Serious Thespian herself and the daughter of another, Richard Burton  sings and dances in a buoyant group number.

headline: Women Weigh Use of Clout in Primary
text: In the garden-level kitchen of a Harlem brownstone last Sunday, five women sat around a long wooden table, overshadowed by a large leafy plant in the window, sipping hazelnut coffee and excitedly finishing one another’s sentences as they talked about the presidential candidates as if they were on intimate terms, calling them Hillary and Barack.

headline: McCain Wins Schwarzenegger Endorsement, and Romney Delivers Barb
text: LOS ANGELES  John McCain and Mitt Romney battled across the daunting political landscape of California on Thursday as Mr. McCain basked in the potent endorsement of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and Mr. Romney poured at least $1 million into a statewide television advertising campaign and likened Mr. McCain’s tactics to those of the Nixon era.

headline: Jackson Hole Mountain Resort
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Tenor Cancels Appearances
text: The star tenor Juan Diego Flórez, who has a throat infection caused by a fish bone he swallowed, has been forced to cancel his performances in the Lyric Opera of Chicago production of Rossini’s “Barbiere di Siviglia.” The company said on Thursday that doctors in Parma, Italy, have advised Mr. Flórez, 35, not to perform at least through mid-March. For the 12 scheduled Lyric Opera performances through March 22, he will be replaced in the role of Count Almaviva by John Osborn. Mr. Flórez, left, is next scheduled to sing in his native Peru on March 31 as the Duke in Verdi’s “Rigoletto.” Beginning on April 21, he is to portray Tonio in the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Donizetti’s “Fille du Régiment.” ... A knee injury suffered by the tenor Michael Schade has forced the cancellation of his Lincoln Center “Great Performers” duo recital with the baritone Russell Braun, scheduled for Feb. 10 at the Rose Theater in Frederick P. Rose Hall. It will not be rescheduled.

headline: Eurozone Inflation Rising at Record Pace
text: PARIS  Inflation in the euro zone rose in January at the fastest pace on record, official data showed Thursday, highlighting the difficult task facing the European Central Bank as it seeks to enforce price stability in the face of slowing economic growth.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THEATER

headline: Comrades Speak of Fallen Marine and Ties That Bind
text: CAMP VICTORY, Iraq  As a cold wind swept across much of the Middle East on Thursday, bringing snow to northern Iraq and subfreezing temperatures to Baghdad, about 100 soldiers and marines gathered for a ceremony to rename a small helicopter landing zone on this huge American base in honor of a fallen comrade.

headline: Bond of Brothers in a California Wilderness
text: ONE recent winter night, having just scrubbed out after an emergency C-section, Jonathan Bourne, an anesthesiologist at Mammoth Hospital in Mammoth Lakes, Calif., threw his pack and skis into his brother’s secondhand Suburban and slid into the passenger seat. The plan was to make a routine trek east across one of the largest, darkest volcanoes in North America, the Long Valley Caldera, to the family’s private ski retreat on the eastern edge of California.

headline: Support for Israeli Premier Amid Calls to Resign
text: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, received crucial support from senior ministers of his own Kadima Party on Thursday, and leaders of a public campaign to oust him said they were not immediately planning mass demonstrations. Those developments improved Mr. Olmert’s chances of surviving a formal inquiry that found “grave failings” in the handling of the 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon.

headline: F.D.A. Finds Increase in Suicide Symptoms for Patients Using Seizure Medications
text: Drugs for epilepsy, bipolar illness and mood problems double the risks of suicidal thoughts and behavior, and patients taking them should be watched for sudden behavioral changes, drug regulators have said.

headline: Federal Agents Crackdown on  Super Bowl Fakes
text: MESA, Ariz.  It seemed like a good deal.

headline: Who’s Your Daddy?
text: To the Slate editor in chief, Jacob Weisberg, the presidency of George W. Bush is a plane crash, and he says there is a black box that can help explain just what brought this White House down in flames: a black box “filled with a series of relationships  familial, personal, religious and historical,” most notably the father-son relationship, which “lies at the very core of the second Bush presidency and its spectacular, avoidable flame-out.”

headline: A Haircut, With an Affair and Highlights of Support
text: The Beirut beauty salon where most of “Caramel” takes place is likely to be a familiar type of establishment, even to viewers who have never been to the Lebanese capital. What the shop lacks in sleekness and chic it makes up for in the kind of friendly, sisterly warmth that could be found, for instance, in “Beauty Shop,” the distaff installation in the “Barbershop” franchise.

headline: Defense Says Police Violated Brooklyn Stepfather’s Rights
text: The day that Cesar Rodriguez was charged in the beating death of his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, he was questioned by a series of police officers and prosecutors.

headline: Extreme Cultural Realignment for Randolph and Frye
text: TUALATIN, Ore.  How, exactly, should a person judge a blockbuster trade after a half-season of results?

headline: Pop in 3-D
text: “Every generation throws a hero up the pop charts,” Paul Simon once sang, and in 2008 there’s Miley Cyrus (excuse me, Miley Ray Cyrus)  on television, on the iTunes Top 10 and in theaters with this 3-D artifact of her just concluded tour. Bygone decades had Donny Osmond, Menudo and New Kids on the Block. Today Walt Disney  which also spawned Britney Spears, Justin Timberlake and Christina Aguilera  feeds tweens their pop idols. But don’t call it packaged teenage rebellion. In this movie there are few teenagers and no rebellion, only bouncy inspirational ditties. “I Miss You,” a wholesome ode to Ms. Cyrus’s dead grandfather, is as doleful as it gets.

headline: Sweden Accuses 4 of Copyright Offenses
text: LONDON  Prosecutors in Sweden on Thursday charged four men who are associated with a popular file-sharing Web site called Pirate Bay with facilitating copyright infringement.

headline: Slide, Jump, Fly in Connecticut
text: PEOPLE have been skiing for about 6,000 years, but it’s safe to say that when someone first donned a pair of skis, it wasn’t long before that person had another entertaining thought: I wonder how far I can jump on these things?

headline: South Africa: Zimbabweans’ Shelter Raided
text: The police raided the Central Methodist Mission in central Johannesburg, where hundreds of Zimbabweans had taken refuge, hauling people in pajamas to a police station. Bishop Paul Verryn sheltered about 1,200 people at the church, which has become a haven for Zimbabweans fleeing their country. Police officers could be heard asking people taken from the church for their residency permits. The authorities have been struggling with the influx of migrants. South Africa is believed to have one of the largest communities of Zimbabwean refugees, estimated at three million.

headline: Canada, but Think of Warmth and Wine
text: “They come seeking heat and wine, not igloos,” said Jim Henry, managing broker at MacDonald Real Estate, referring to buyers who choose Osoyoos for a second home. “This may be Canada, but we’re at the northernmost tip of the Sonoran Desert. By May, temperatures are in the mid-80s, and through the summer months, it’s in the 90s almost every day.”

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Gambling Money Is in the Minutiae
text: The best anyone can remember, proposition bets, or the props, as they are known, began with Super Bowl XX in 1986 when the Chicago Bears faced the New England Patriots and the burning question was whether William Perry might score.

headline: Enlisting New Donors, Obama Reaped $32 Million in January
text: As he was winning contests in Iowa and South Carolina, Senator Barack Obama raised $32 million in January for his presidential bid, tapping 170,000 new contributors to rake in nearly double the highest previous one-month total for any candidate in this election cycle.

headline: Winter Storms Hit Northern U.S.
text: Snow, sleet and freezing rain pelted the northern Midwest and northeastern states Friday, closing the Buffalo airport and causing travel delays around the region. Hundreds of flights were canceled Thursday at Chicago’s O’Hare airport, and Friday started with arrival delays averaging two and a half hours, according to federal aviation officials.

headline: Suit Seeks to Block Oil Search Off Alaska
text: A coalition of environmental organizations and Inupiaq native groups filed suit in federal court in Anchorage on Thursday to force the Interior Department to do a new analysis of the environmental consequences of oil and gas exploration in the Chukchi Sea, off northwestern Alaska.

headline: Consumers Slow Spending Pace
text: Consumer spending slowed in December and inflation continued to rise, the government said Thursday, leaving the Federal Reserve less maneuvering room as it ponders policy decisions in the months ahead.

headline: Mets Are Optimistic About Signing Santana
text: A second round of talks with the representatives for Johan Santana left the Mets feeling optimistic about their chances of signing him to a lucrative extension before their 72-hour negotiating window expires at 5 p.m. on Friday.

headline: Sanctioned Killings, and the Very Many That Aren’t
text: “Under Pain of Death,” a show at the Austrian Cultural Forum about capital punishment, approaches its theme with such timidity and indirectness you might conclude that contemporary art is just not equipped to deal with the topic. Buried within it, however, are glimmers of what a more daring show could entail. (For the record, Austria has banned capital punishment.)

headline: China Tries to Reassure U.S. About Its Investing Plans
text: WASHINGTON  The head of China’s $200 billion government investment fund, seeking to reassure Americans nervous about the possibility of foreign takeovers, said Thursday that China would invest mostly in portfolios rather than individual companies  except when a “big fat rabbit” like the investment banker Morgan Stanley came along.

headline: Correction
text: The American Journeys column last Friday, about Cuban culture in Miami, gave incomplete lyrics for a song performed in Spanish by the Cuban singer Albita at a club in Little Havana. The correct lyrics include the preposition “de” three times: “Que culpa tengo yo de estas caderas? Que culpa tengo yo de este sabor? Que culpa tengo yo de haber nacido en Cuba?”

headline: Vermont’s Highways of Snow
text: STEVE RUSHFORD had been riding his snowmobile all morning, and by 11 a.m. both his vehicle and stomach were in need of fuel. But first there was a more pressing issue.

headline: Art in Review
text: HARUN FAROCKI

headline: Berkeley Finds a New Way to Make War Politics Local
text: BERKELEY, Calif.  While the City Council here has little  read, no  sway over foreign policy and distant wars, local parking is a different matter. And so it was that a parking space directly in front of the recruiting station here for the Marine Corps was awarded on Tuesday night to an antiwar group in the hope of running the Marines out of town.

headline: Determined to Beat a Ticket, but Finding Bigger Trouble
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A motorist who received a ticket for driving through a stop sign and then tried to outsmart the system did not count on the traffic commissioner outsmarting him, officials said Thursday.

headline: Britney Spears Is Hospitalized
text: Britney Spears, with a police escort of nearly a dozen motorcycles, two cruisers and two helicopters, was removed by ambulance from her home and taken to U.C.L.A. Medical Center, early on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. Ms. Spears, 26, whose erratic behavior has made her a public spectacle and cost her the custody of her two young sons, was hospitalized to “get help,” said a Los Angeles police officer who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to discuss the matter. Allan Parachini, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Superior Court, said: “The way it works is a law enforcement agency or mental health professional can conclude that someone is a danger to self or others and undertake an involuntary commitment. To extend that for another 14 days there has to be a court hearing.” On Jan. 3, when Ms. Spears refused to return her children to her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, who has custody, the police had paramedics take her from her home to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, where she was released after a day and a half.

headline: In Court Ruling on Floods, More Pain for New Orleans
text: NEW ORLEANS  There is disappointment but little surprise here at a federal judge’s grudgingly absolving the Army Corps of Engineers of liability in the flooding of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Stocks Rally in Defiance of Bad News
text: Thursday had all the ingredients for a bearish day on Wall Street.

headline: In Report, Officers Call for Major Overhaul of NATO
text: BERLIN  With NATO facing the risk of failure in trying to defeat Taliban insurgents in Afghanistan, a group of former senior officers has called for a major overhaul of the alliance, which they say is paralyzed by cumbersome decision-making rules, inequitable financing arrangements and an inability to sustain long-term missions.

headline: The Edwards Effect
text: So John Edwards has dropped out of the race for the presidency. By normal political standards, his campaign fell short.

headline: Like Home-Builder Shares? Look Again
text: The worse the news got, the better the stocks performed.

headline: Footnote
text: Richard Chamberlain and Jan Maxwell will play George and Martha when the Berkshire Theater Festival revives Edward Albee’s “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?” for its 80th-anniversary season, from May 22 through Dec. 30 in Stockbridge, Mass. The schedule also includes works by Beckett, Shaw and Harold Pinter, as well as two new plays.

headline: Washington: Wireless Tracking System for Miners
text: Federal mine-safety regulators said they approved the first wireless tracking system to locate miners trapped underground. The Mine Safety and Health Administration said the technology was developed by Venture Design Services Inc., based in Liberty Lake, Wash., a subsidiary of the Venture Corporation of Singapore. After deadly mine explosions in 2006, Congress passed legislation that year requiring that mine operators adopt wireless communications and electronic tracking systems by June 2009. A January 2006 explosion in West Virginia killed 12 men. In May of that year, five men died in an explosion in a Kentucky mine. In August, nine people died in two cave-ins in Utah.

headline: Ohio: Jeb Magruder Pleads Guilty in Crashes
text: Jeb Stuart Magruder, a Watergate conspirator, pleaded guilty to a traffic charge stemming from two crashes last summer in Columbus that happened as he had a stroke while at the wheel. Mr. Magruder had been charged with failing to maintain proper distance and leaving the scene of an accident, but pleaded guilty to a reduced charge of reckless operation. He was fined $300, placed on a year’s probation and lost his license for a year. He says he has no recollection of the crashes. Mr. Magruder was President Richard M. Nixon’s deputy campaign director, an aide to H. R. Haldeman and deputy communications director at the White House. He spent seven months in prison for his role in covering up the 1972 Watergate break-in.

headline: Views of the City, His and Hers, With Lens and Brush
text: “When I arrived in New York in 1935,” the photographer Rudy Burckhardt recalled near the end of his life, “I was amazed at the difference in scale between the people and the buildings.” Over the course of his career he figured out a way to make the city’s architecture fit the human scale he favored. Faced with the same choice, Burckhardt’s wife of 40 years, the painter Yvonne Jacquette, opted to focus on the city’s skyscrapers.

headline: Tentative Deal to Salvage Real Estate Empire
text: Harry and William Macklowe, the father-and-son team of real estate developers who doubled the size of their holdings in a $7 billion deal last year, have reached a tentative agreement to give their lender control of all seven Manhattan skyscrapers purchased in the deal, according to real estate executives.

headline: Rights Group Says U.S. Is Too Eager to Endorse Suspect Elections
text: WASHINGTON  The advocacy group Human Rights Watch on Thursday said that the Bush administration was giving lip service to the promotion of democracy around the world by endorsing suspect elections while allowing human rights violations in those countries to go unchecked.

headline: Roar of Crowd Is Music to Ears of PGA Tour
text: PHOENIX  The brass at PGA Tour headquarters has long dreamed of the day when its traveling golf show would approach the N.F.L. for size of fan base, television ratings and sheer fan excitement. Although a comparably sized fan base and TV ratings are still a distant dream, golf is  for at least one week, in one sports-crazed Southwestern city  going head-to-head with the N.F.L.’s showcase event and holding its own.

headline: Finding a Tangle of Knots, Untying Them Smoothly
text: The American composer Elliott Carter turns 100 in December, and the sheer wealth of his music being played in celebratory concerts could easily overwhelm admirers who have otherwise waited months and even years for opportunities to hear these pieces. Notably absent from most of these celebratory events are Mr. Carter’s five string quartets.

headline: McCain’s Critics on Right Look Again
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain has long aroused almost unanimous opposition from the leaders of the right. Accusing him of crimes against conservative orthodoxy like voting against a big tax cut and opposing a federal ban on same-sex marriage, conservative activists have agitated for months to thwart his Republican presidential primary campaign.

headline: From Berio, the Dark Fraying Ends of the 1960s
text: Luciano Berio’s Sinfonia may not be as well known as “Pet Sounds,” “Sgt. Pepper’s Lonely Hearts Club Band” or the Simon and Garfunkel songs for “The Graduate.” But in its way this seminal work from the modernist wing of 20th-century contemporary music is equally emblematic of the 1960s.

headline: Budget Cuts Raise Wrath of Principals
text: Principals across New York City turned on their computers Thursday morning to discover that because of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s new budget proposal, their budgets had been slashed overnight by sums ranging from $9,000 to $447,587. And they reacted with unvarnished fury, while frantically scouring for places to cut spending.

headline: Agent Tied to McNamee Is Interviewed
text: WASHINGTON  Jim Murray, a sports agent linked to conversations with the personal trainer Brian McNamee about Roger Clemens and performance-enhancing drugs, spoke Thursday to lawyers for the House oversight committee at a closed-door interview that lasted more than three hours.

headline: Drawn and Quartered
text: Washington

headline: The McCain Transition
text: John McCain is exhausted. He hasn’t had a full-night’s sleep in forever. It took him 10 hours to get to California because of flight trouble. He underperformed in the debate Wednesday night, as his staff understands. He took some shots at Mitt Romney that were gratuitous considering the circumstances, as he privately acknowledges.

headline: Times Co. Posts Profit, but Revenue Declines
text: The New York Times Company reported a fourth-quarter profit of $53 million on Thursday as revenue dropped, but it continued to fare better than most of its peers across the troubled newspaper industry.

headline: McCain and Giuliani Sit on Leno’s Couch
text: Rudolph W. Giuliani teamed up with Senator John McCain in a chummy joint appearance on Jay Leno’s “Tonight Show’’ on Thursday and quickly deflected questions about whether he would ever consider accepting an offer for the vice presidential spot on the Republican ticket.

headline: Microsoft Makes $44.6 Billion Bid for Yahoo
text: Microsoft said Friday that it would offer $44.6 billion for Yahoo, the ailing search giant. The surprise offer of $31 a share represents a 62 percent premium to Thursday’s closing share price. Yahoo shareholders could elect to receive either cash or stock.

headline: Russia Creates a $32 Billion Sovereign Wealth Fund

It’s a terrible way to judge your work — and you always have to remember that the most-emailed article ever was the one about using animal-training techniques on your husband. But the temptation is irresistible.

headline: A Rush to Beat New Rules on Campaign Gifts
text: With an eye toward the next campaign season in New York City when top offices will be up for election, Ray Rivera finds that donations from the real estate industry, traditionally a dependable source of campaign contributions, have soared to three and four times the rate of previous election cycles as part of an effort to beat strict new limits. The surge is driven in large part by a major overhaul in the city’s campaign finance law, which, starting this month, will cap contributions from people who do business with the city at less than a tenth of what is now permissible. That means many developers, brokers, landlords and contractors will be limited to giving $400 to a mayoral candidate, compared with $4,950 now.

headline: Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid: What’s Next
text: After being served with an unsolicited $44.6 billion takeover bid from Microsoft, Yahoo has reacted cautiously. In a press release early Friday, Yahoo said it will “evaluate this proposal carefully and promptly in the context of Yahoo!’s strategic plans and pursue the best course of action to maximize long-term value for shareholders.”

headline: My eHarmony Experiment: Can This Marriage Be Matched?

After visiting the eHarmony Labs for my Findings column on matchmaking, I wondered if its algorithm would match me and my wife of 12 years, Dana. We falsely said we were each divorced (because eHarmony doesn’t offer its service to people already married) and each childless, but otherwise we told the truth.

headline: Unlocking the Republican Ballot
text: Since the advent of the modern primary system in the 1970s, New York Republicans have largely avoided the fractious intraparty battles that have divided their Democratic Party counterparts in election years like 1976, 1980, 1984 and 1992. But the party did so in part by heavily favoring establishment candidates and making it hard for challengers to get on the ballot. In 1996 and 2000, the New York Republican leadership’s efforts to block party insurgents made its arcane rules the focus of national attention — and embarrassment.

The bar, Tonic East on Third Avenue in Murray Hill, was pumped with dance music and the raised voices of young professionals straining to chat. A mosaic of big-screen televisions flashed hockey and basketball games. But the high energy wasn’t for Hillary. Amid the regular Thursday night revelry, in a corner of a second-floor balcony, a small crowd of suit-clad Clinton supporters waited for the candidates to speak.

headline: The Debate: What’s Your Superstition?
text: So, we have a friend who donned his favorite blue Giants shirt on the last Saturday night of 2007, when the Big Blue took the Patriots to the wire, and he’s worn it for every game since as the team made its surprising run to the Super Bowl. Let’s face it: The shirt played a key role. You couldn’t convince our friend otherwise. And so it hasn’t seen a spin cycle or a tumble dry in a month; that would upset the karma. His wife has given up trying. At this writing it’s airing out on the treadmill in his bedroom. It’s back in business Sunday evening, when it faces the ultimate test.

headline: Bill Clinton, Climate and the ‘Instanet’
text: [UPDATE 11/24/08: Sharon Otterman explored the slow-blog movement, which — as I now see — dates from 2006, in our Styles section.] Much of the power of the Web lies in speed and reach. But those same properties are the source of its greatest failing as well: the tendency to spread faulty assertions instantly and widely. Maybe it’s time for a “slow blog” movement, just as there’s now a slow food movement — and even a slow life movement, as described in The Times this week.

headline: Fine Print | South Africa
text: Travel editors get bombarded with glossy imagery every day. No matter the destination — from Qatar to the Caribbean — there’s some attendant glamor shot of a zero-edge pool or a honeymooning couple kicking at shells on the beach at dusk. It’s mind numbing. Then the other day a book passed our desk called South Africa, by a new publishing venture called Well Souled. The volume is a hefty and, yes, glossy 312 pages: images of the country’s people, landscape, architecture, food, fashion, iconography. The founder and editor Mital Shah, a 31-year-old former executive at Vera Wang, says she came across all her subjects solely through word of mouth. “I didn’t cast a wide net. I just let one person lead to the next. And I tried to meet everyone, but I didn’t try to cover everything.” (To document her far-flung network, there’s a “map” of her contacts at the end of the book.) The result is a seductive but not synthetic portrait of a place; we encounter musicians, athletes, and designers, along with children orphaned by AIDS, ordinary citizens, and pinup girls from the pages of 1950s Drum magazine. “I wanted this project to be about being well-traveled but always being soulful about how you travel,” says Shah, who will release books on more countries and who has plans to apply the concept to other media, along with fashion and home design. “We want to offer luxury and culture at the same time — and always be giving back.” To put its money where its passport is Well Souled will give 20 percent of the sales of South Africa to organizations that help AIDS orphans; the same percentage from a book about India will go toward rural education. “It’s a big number, but we wanted to put that stake in the ground.” We’re feeling that. To order a copy, go to www.wellsouled.com.

headline: In Bay Ridge, Shock Over a Pharmacy Owner’s Death
text: Lowen’s Pharmacy, in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, closed early on Thursday evening for a wake for its owner, John Rossi. Mr. Rossi, whose store was under investigation in a wide-ranging steroid probe, was found dead in an office above the business on Monday with two apparently self-inflicted gunshot wounds. Bay Ridge has been buzzing about his death all week. The neighborhood, which stretches from 65th Street to 101st Street along Brooklyn’s eastern shoreline, is fairly big, geographically speaking. But, maybe because of its low-rise buildings and neat front yards, and maybe in part because it is hemmed in by expressways that clearly define its boundaries, Bay Ridge, where I went for this week’s Dispatches feature in the City section, can feel like a small town.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: My Wired Youth
