headline: The New New Thing in Broken Buyouts
text: The deathwatch on the Reddy Ice deal ended Thursday. In anticipation of the Feb. 5 termination date on its deal, Reddy Ice, a maker of packaged ice, announced that it had agreed to terminate its agreement to be acquired by affiliates of GSO Capital Partners. In connection with the termination, GSO agreed to pay Reddy Ice $21 million in cash on Feb. 5 — the self-same termination date. In addition, Reddy Ice agreed to pay up to $4 million of fees and expenses incurred by GSO and its consultants in connection with the failed transaction.

headline: Bush Discusses the Economy
text: CNBC footage of President Bush in Kansas City, Missouri, discussing the state of the economy .

headline: Living in Williamsburg
text: Factories and warehouses converted into residences in South Williamsburg are taking longer to sell, but prices are holding firm.

headline: Yahoo’s New Chairman, No Stranger to a Sale
text: Late on Thursday, Yahoo said that Terry S. Semel, its chairman and former chief executive, was leaving the company. It appointed Roy J. Bostock, another director, to replace him.

headline: Romney’s Potted Plant
text: SAN DIEGO—At least he can still laugh at himself.

headline: Welcome Online, Mr. Mondino
About All Those Endorsements
text: You’ve got to wonder what a guy like Kevin Tynan is thinking. Mr. Tynan is the former chairman of the Broward County Republicans, and on Monday, the day before the critical Florida primary, Rudolph W. Giuliani’s campaign sent out an e-mail trumpeting his endorsement. “Florida needs Rudy and I’m proud to support him,” Mr. Tynan said in his statement, at a moment when it was pretty clear to just about everyone that it was actually Rudy who needed Florida and that he wasn’t going to get it. Thirty-six hours later, predictably enough, the Giuliani campaign shuddered and sank like the Titanic, with its newest passenger, Kevin Tynan, waving from the deck.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Friday, Feb. 1:

headline: Where’s Governor Bill?
text: As the Clinton and Obama campaigns descended on Santa Fe and Albuquerque, one of the most gregarious politicians in the Democratic field -– New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson — was nowhere to be seen.

headline: American Universities Go Global
text: As more and more American universities take their programs overseas, the United States' system of higher education is becoming one of its most valued exports.

headline: Percy and Buckley
text: My colleague Steve Coates has discouraged readers from dragging other Percy novels into the discussion, and it’s a laudable policy. But since there has been some speculation about Percy’s politics, Steve granted me dispensation to note that in the 1970s, Percy’s ardent champions included William F. Buckley, Jr.

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Don’t Pander So Much’
text: Monday, Jan. 28

headline: Missing Out on the Real Excitement
text: I want to be back in Africa, back in Ghana. Not here in Williamsburg, Va., trying to focus on the contours of probable cause with regard to the issuance of warrants and the definition of dependent relative revocation in Trusts and Estates law. Given the choice between my status quo reality and the next chapter of the African Cup of Nations…Fortunately, the rhythmic drum beats, songs and smiles of Ghanaians remain at the front of my consciousness after 10 sometimes hectic days in Accra, Kumasi and Sekondi. Even memories of long, hot bus trips, inhaling dust while walking along side roads and fighting through misinformation concerning transportation and tickets are fond memories. How I wish I were still there, especially with the drama of the quarter-finals, which start Sunday.

headline: It’s the Rudy and John Show
text: Anyone else wondering why Rudolph W. Giuliani continues to tag along on the campaign trail with John McCain, even though Mr. Giuliani dropped out of the race a couple of days ago?

headline: Flickr Users Consider Their Potential Microsoft Overlords
text: The hard-core users of Flickr, the photo-sharing Web site owned by Yahoo, have this to say about a potential Microsoft takeover: “Oh no, not again!”

headline: Importing Chinese inflation?
text: This piece in the NYT on how China’s inflation affects U.S. consumers is interesting. But I think some perspective is called for.

headline: How Super Will Tuesday Be? Bloomberg Predicts…
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who will not be voting in the Democratic presidential primary on Tuesday since he is a political independent, offered a little bit of political analysis on Friday morning about the significance of the Super Tuesday contests. In his weekly radio program on WABC-AM (770), the program’s host, John Gambling, asked the mayor, “Results from Tuesday, will they give you an opportunity to re-evaluate your personal situation?”

headline: Oprah’s Back
text: ALBUQUERQUE – Oprah is on the way.

headline: College Hockey Matchup of the Week: Clark-Who?
text: It’s rare to see a high-profile non-conference series this late in the college hockey season, but when No. 10 Clarkson heads west to take on No. 6 Colorado College this weekend, a bunch of guys you’ve never heard of will take center stage.

headline: Clipboard: There’s Hype and Then There Is Trash Talking
text: The reporters and columnists who cover the teams on a daily basis know there are certain guys to go to in the locker room not only for a more thoughtful response, but a more provocative response. Obviously, Plaxico Burress is one of the players that reporters go to for something more provocative.

headline: Gawkers and Stalkers
text: Our builder, John, mentioned in passing yesterday that when he drove over to our construction site last Sunday to check on a few things, he encountered a group of four women who were doing a self-guided tour.

headline: The Founding Fathers of Perfectville
text: Members of the undefeated 1972 Miami Dolphins wanted to make it clear Friday that they were not rooting against the Patriots in their quest to become the second N.F.L. team to complete an undefeated season. They were, however, rooting for the Giants to win Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Icahn Announces Alternate Directors for Motorola
text: Carl C. Icahn scored a major coup late Thursday when Motorola announced it may spin off its handset unit — what he calls a “long overdue” move. Now the shareholder activist seems intent on solidifying that progress by unveiling his own slate of directors on Friday. And in that list are some familiar, if unexpected, names.

headline: NASA Says, ‘Hello, Universe. Meet the Beatles.’
text: UPDATE Tuesday, Feb. 5In one of those too-wierd-for-fiction coincidences, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the guru who famously introduced the Beatles and the Western world to transcendental meditation, and thus indirectly inspired the mantra-refrain of the song “Across the Universe,” which NASA beamed out into space on Monday, died on Tuesday. He was 91 and had been living in a small town in Holland.

headline: Extreme Takeover
text: Do you Micro-hoo? Technology bloggers are chattering about Microsoft’s proposed purchase of Yahoo! Henry Blodget (yes, that Henry Blodget), writing at Silicon Alley Insider, calls it “a brilliant move by Microsoft — a big premium dangled in front of battered Yahoo shareholders, but a price that would have seemed absurdly low as recently as six months ago.”

headline: Lieberman’s McCain Caravan Hits Stamford
text: Updated, 6:44 p.m. | STAMFORD, Conn. — After traveling to New York City to rouse phone-bank volunteers making calls for Senator John McCain, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman returned to his home state of Connecticut for yet another event to promote Mr. McCain’s White House candidacy. Mr. McCain is scheduled to hold a campaign rally at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., at 1 p.m. on Sunday.

headline: L.A. Times Endorses Obama, McCain
text: The Los Angeles Times, the largest newspaper from the Super Tuesday state with the most delegates, has just endorsed Barack Obama in the Democratic race and John McCain on the Republican side. The paper was one of the co-sponsors of both parties’ California debates this week.

headline: Get Your Fashion Game Face On
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Fitting the Pieces in an Internet Mega-Merger
text: When Microsoft announced its $44.6 billion bid to buy Yahoo on Friday, inquiring minds wanted to know whether or not the deal was likely to go through. But many were also asking a different question: Even if the deal is approved, can these two technology titans work together?

headline: Soft Serve | Ikea’s Prefab Housing, Balenciaga In Space, Uniqlo Vending Machines …
text: Have you lost your manners? Consult the University of Chicago Press’s new re-printing of the 1930’s Oxford etiquette manuals, How to be a Good Husband and How to be a Good Wife. Here’s a pearl from the reference book for women: “Don’t forget that… while face powder may catch a man, baking powder is the stuff to hold him.” … Homemaking requires a home, of course, and now you can buy one — and everything to go inside it — from Ikea (if you live in the UK). The Swedish company’s line of manufactured housing, BoKlok, will likely have you reconsidering the chicness of prefab … Add this one to the ugly file: the Ryugyong Hotel in Pyongyang, North Korea. Esquire has named it the “Worst Building in the History of Mankind.” Ouch! … Balenciaga’s new London flagship is groovy looking for sure, but Ghesquière, et al’s concept — “an intergalactic experience” — brings new meaning to high-concept design … If modernism leaves you cold, just imagine how you’ll feel in a Snow Room, a chilly spa gimmick (relax, it’s ten below zero!) coming soon to a luxury hotel near you… If you’re one of those flip-flops-in-the-shower types, you should read the Transportation Security Administration’s new blog that defends the hygiene of shoe removal airport at security checkpoints, and other matters of homeland security… If your luggage gets lost at Narita International Airport you’ll be grateful for the new Uniqlo t-shirt vending machine in Tokyo. Add that to the list of weird Japanese vending machines… Sorry guys, Soft Serve is out-of-order until Monday.

headline: Making Movies: A Hairy Business
text: No matter what Sean Young says, the Bagger thinks listening to Julian Schnabel talk about making movies is always a significant entertainment, as it was last night when he was on Charilie Rose. As an added bonus, Mr. Schnabel went dramatically south with the zipper on his shirt, offering Charlie and the rest of us a view of what the Washington Post called the “lush jungle” of his chest region.

headline: The Secret Lives of Phone Bank Volunteers
text: When you’re phone-banking, dialing call after call after call to registered Democratic voters for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, “NH” means not home. “LM” is left a message. And “CB” is a callback.

headline: Fake Newspaper Offers Real Apology
text: The Onion’s deadpan photography plays second funny fiddle to its stories, and therein lies a tiny problem that emerged this week: The words are completely made up, but the pictures are very real.

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo, From Rumor to Reality
text: Investors were quick to respond to Microsoft‘s bid to buy Yahoo – they bought up plenty of the Internet company’s stock on Friday, pushing Yahoo’s share up by nearly 50 percent to $28.38 by the end of the day.

headline: Big Test for Rangers to Build Momentum
text: Almost to a man, the Rangers said Thursday night’s victory over Philadelphia — no matter how dominating — will mean little if they cannot follow it with a victory over New Jersey Friday night. It was the first sign that the Rangers truly understand the predicament they have played themselves into, and now they have to show they can do something about it. Playing another Atlantic Division rival right away gives them a perfect opportunity.

headline: 8 Banks in Talks to Rescue Ambac
text: Eight major banks are in talks to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, as part of an industrywide rescue being orchestrated by state regulators, people briefed on the negotiations said Friday.

headline: Vows: Erin and Thomas
text: On their first meeting, Thomas and Erin learned they had attended the same program in Australia.

headline: New York Fashion Week | BCBG
text: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment.

headline: City Room: Out Come the Volunteers
text: Today’s Journal Entries: With no candidates in sight, the surrogates and volunteers are doing the hard work in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Showing his independent streak, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman gave a pep talk to McCain volunteers in Lower Manhattan, then headed to a Republican rally in Stamford. …The Bloomberg true believers are starting to believe he has no intention of running. The mayor does have some Super Tuesday predictions. …The secret lives of campaign phone-bank volunteers. A judge in New Jersey has ruled that absentee voters may cast a new vote if they voted for someone who dropped out …New York City’s Jewish Democrats parse the Clinton-Obama contest …A look back at the legal fights over the Republican ballot that led to this year’s winner-take-all rules in New York …A Latinos for Clinton party, an Obama singles night, and a congressional leader’s spouse goes her own way. …A review of reader comments from the week includes this advice for candidates: “Don’t pander so much.”

headline: McCain Ad: A ‘True Conservative’
text: John McCain’s positions on the environment, campaign finance and immigration, not to mention his willingness to cooperate with Democrats in the Senate, have dogged him on the campaign trail.

headline: YHTMAAAIYP
text: That’s “you have too many acronyms and abbreviations in your paper” — a caution that used to be thrown at people writing about international trade policy, which is full of QRs, ADDs, the MFA, the GATT, etc.. (Not to mention Section 201 versus Section 301, but that’s another matter.)

headline: Some Absentee Voters Will Get New Ballots
text: Voters in New Jersey who cast absentee ballots for a candidate who has dropped out of the presidential race can vote again, a state judge has ruled. The ruling by the judge, Vincent J. Grasso of State Superior Court in Ocean County, dealt specifically with the Ocean County Clerk but has bearing statewide, according to the New Jersey attorney general’s office.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Wayne
text: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment.

headline: Spotting Satellites
text: The Noss 2-3 satellites passing by the Pleiades star cluster, on Sept 28, 2004. On a clear night the cluster can be seen with the naked eye. (Video: Kevin Fetter)

headline: Weekend Political Calendar
text: As New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and 19 other states head into Super Tuesday, a number of campaign events are planned in the region for Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, who will both be in the region on Monday. The only candidate scheduled to make a personal appearance over the weekend is Senator John McCain, who will attend a rally on Sunday in Fairfield, Conn. The campaign of Mitt Romney does not appear to have any local volunteer events scheduled. Following are highlights of the events. Feel free to post event information in the form.HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON

headline: The Game Ball
text: The footballs used for the Super Bowl are crafted by many experienced hands.

headline: Protesters Bounced From Clinton Event
text: SAN DIEGO – As Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton spoke before a huge crowd at San Diego State University just now, two young men in the audience unfolded a hand-painted banner that read “Nepotist Tyrant, Hands Off Iran!” and held up photographs of her – blocking one of her campaign’s “Solutions for America” signs.

headline: Another Celebrity Sports Couple Descends on Arizona
text: PHOENIX — The famous woman stood behind her man, urging him to throw strikes. No, the supermodel Gisele Bundchen did not show up in Tempe, Ariz., Friday to watch her boyfriend, Patriots quarterback Tom Brady, practice.

headline: Bloggingheads: Sexism vs. Racism
text:
Bloggers Megan McArdle of The Atlantic, left, and Garance Franke-Ruta of The Washington Post's The Trail blog discuss the role of race and gender in the Democratic presidential campaign.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 1
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include preparations for Super Tuesday, a harbor seal on the Upper West Side and the newly discovered negatives of photographs taken by Robert Capa, one of the pioneers of modern war photography.

headline: Mets Reach Deal With Santana
text: UPDATE: The Mets reached an agreement with Johan Santana, the dominant left-hander acquired Tuesday from the Minnesota Twins, shortly before 6:30 p.m. Friday, signing him to a contract that would make him the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history.

headline: What Happened When the Lights Went Out
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — One of the best tests of a politician’s pure sense of showmanship is his ability to recover when something goes unexpectedly awry.

headline: Speaking Truth Without Power
text: During the last five years, no movement has had as great an impact on progressive politics as the liberal blogosphere. Built from grassroots anger over Democratic leadership support for the Iraq war in 2002, liberal bloggers have chastised party leaders who backed President Bush, causing many prominent Democrats to reverse — and even recant — their positions on the war. Just as impressively, the blog voices on the left have played a critical role in pushing less visible issues — like electronic voting machines, bankruptcy legislation and telephone companies’ liability in wiretapping programs — into the mainstream.

headline: Friday’s Other Hostile Bid: O’Reilly Pursues CSK
text: While most investors, analysts, reporters and members of the public had focused on the other unsolicited takeover offer on Friday, the biggest gainer of the day was actually CSK Auto, a Western car parts retailer.

headline: Voices From the Region
text: Voters across the region appeared to be undecided just ahead of the primary on Tuesday.

headline: Undecided in New York
text: A John Edwards supporter examines the remaining democratic candidates.

headline: Worst Attack on Baghdad in Months
text: Twin bombings struck two markets in central Baghdad on Friday, killing 65 people and wounding 149.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Rag & Bone
text: Gisele Bündchen at the Rag & Bone show today.

headline: What Would Binx Do?
text: As Sam Tanenhaus’s posting about William F. Buckley Jr. suggests, the Walker Percy Fan Club has a tent of Ringling Brothers dimensions, and that’s no less true of “The Moviegoer” itself. First, check out this Academy of Achievement recommendation for the novel by Peggy Noonan, who says she tried to persuade Ronald Reagan to nominate Percy for a Medal of Freedom in 1984. (Guess who got it instead?)

headline: The Week That Keeps On Going
text: If we tried to capture this week’s worth of news and events and memorable quotes, you would be forced to read (or give up) way too much.

headline: Colorado's Unpredictable Voters
text: Colorado's voters may yield some surprises in the 2008 presidential primaries.

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr (a k a the Carpetbagger) polls New Yorkers about whether it matters if the Oscars are canceled.

headline: Couch Potato Turned Super Bowl Player
text: For New England’s first 13 games this season, Stephen Spach watched from a black leather couch of his rented house in Fresno, Calif.

headline: AppleScript Code for Microsoft Office 2008
text: Very, very tweaky, geeky blog entry today, sorry, but it’s great information that I don’t want to hoard. This one’s just for Mac fans with Office 2008. (I’ll return to more general topics soon, I promise.)

headline: Golden Impala: A Case of Identity Theft
text: 2008 Chevrolet Impala 50th Anniversary Edition.

headline: Bombings in Baghdad Markets
text: Attacks that killed dozens of people at two popular Iraqi pet markets were the bloodiest in six months.

headline: Flying for a Good Cause
text: Danny Ware, a rookie running back out of Georgia, doesn’t figure to see much — if any — action Sunday. After the Giants signed him off the Jets’ practice squad, Ware appeared in one game, playing special teams in the loss to the Patriots in the regular-season finale.

headline: Bombings in Baghdad Markets
text: Attacks that killed dozens of people at two popular Iraqi pet markets were the bloodiest in six months.

headline: Knicks Falter in Randolph’s Return to Portland
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  Seven months after leaving, Zach Randolph returned to his original N.B.A. home Friday night and turned in a vintage performance. He arrived late, shot a lot, scored in bunches and left the Rose Garden with a loss  much as he did for his last few years with the Portland Trail Blazers.

headline: Britney Spears’s Father Is Named Conservator
text: James Spears, the father of Britney Spears, was named her temporary conservator, putting him in control of her welfare a day after she was hospitalized for a psychiatric evaluation, The Associated Press reported. In addition, after a hearing in California Superior Court he was named a conservator, along with the lawyer Andrew Wallete, of the singer’s estate. The court also issued a restraining order against Ms. Spears’s friend and sometime manager, Sam Lutfi, and gave permission to change the locks on her estate and remove anyone there. Ms. Spears, shown above outside a hearing last month regarding visitation rights for her two children, will be under conservatorship at least until Monday, when another hearing will be held.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Monday about Suharto, the former dictator of Indonesia, misstated the number of islands in the Indonesian archipelago that are inhabited. It is about 6,000  not “more than 17,000,” which is the approximate number of islands that make up the country.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 38 of The Times Magazine this weekend about voting patterns among women referred incorrectly to the questions in a Norman Lear Center/Zogby International poll used to help discern those patterns. Respondents were asked to indicate their degree of agreement with certain statements; the questions were not true-or-false or open-ended.

headline: Just Fine as Tackles, but They Can’t Pass
text: “I wanted to get a sense of who you wanted to speak with,” a publicist from Animal Planet said the other day in response to an interview request, “because, um, it’s all puppies.”

headline: Ready With a Song and a Story at 95
text: “Tony Martin? The singer? Used to be married to Cyd Charisse? I thought he was. ...”

headline: Disney Signs Its Chief to a New Five-Year Contract
text: LOS ANGELES  Directors at the Walt Disney Company signed the chief executive, Robert A. Iger, to a new five-year contract on Friday, signaling their confidence in his ability to navigate a turbulent economy and sweeping changes in the media business.

headline: At a Small Ohio Factory, Leather and Laces Mesh
text: ADA, Ohio  The calls come in every year, right before the N.F.L.’s conference championship games, and when they do, Peg Price tries not to laugh.

headline: Jens Quistgaard, 88, a Designer of Popular Tableware, Is Dead
text: Jens Quistgaard, a celebrated Danish industrial designer whose clean-lined and immensely popular pieces for the Dansk brand of tableware helped define the Scandinavian Modern style for postwar Americans, died on Jan. 4 at his home in Vordingborg, Denmark. He was 88.

headline: Evangelical Democrats, Exit Polls and a Matter of Balance
text: If a tree falls in the forest and no one is there to hear it, does it make a sound? If a born-again Christian votes in a Democratic primary and no exit poll records it, does it matter?

headline: Rebels Are Said to Enter Chad’s Capital
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Rebels entered the capital of Chad on Saturday and gun battles erupted around the presidential palace, according to Chadian officials and news reports.

headline: Given Reprieve, N.F.L. Star’s Dogs Find Kindness
text: KANAB, Utah  A quick survey of Georgia, a caramel-colored pit bull mix with cropped ears and soulful brown eyes, offers a road map to a difficult life. Her tongue juts from the left side of her mouth because her jaw, once broken, healed at an awkward angle. Her tail zigzags.

headline: Those First in ‘Chorus Line’ Gain a Continuing Stake
text: The dancers and actors who participated in the 1974 recordings and workshops that were the foundation of “A Chorus Line” have been granted a financial interest in the current Broadway revival, according to a joint statement released on Friday by those artists and the beneficiaries of the estate of Michael Bennett, the musical’s creator and original director.

headline: Bush to Seek Budget Cuts, Except in Child Health
text: WASHINGTON  Dozens of popular health, housing and education programs would be eliminated or sharply reduced under the budget that President Bush plans to announce on Monday. But he would significantly increase spending on the State Children’s Health Insurance Program, the focus of a huge fight with Congress last year.

headline: Two Bombings Wreak Carnage in Iraqi Capital
text: BAGHDAD  Two women strapped with explosives killed dozens of people at Baghdad pet markets on Friday, in the kind of carnage that the Iraqi capital hoped it had left behind.

headline: A Candidate Who Wasn’t, and Now They Believe Him
text: His bosom pals endorsed someone else. Some of those trying to draft him for a run are suddenly less interested. And even the mayor himself, as he continues to insist he will not be a contender for the White House, is for the first time sounding like someone who means it.

headline: Exxon Sets Profit Record: $40.6 Billion Last Year
text: By any measure, Exxon Mobil’s performance last year was a blowout.

headline: Coach Asks to Open Records
text: Rich Rodriguez’s lawyers argued Friday that opening the financial records of West Virginia University’s private fund-raising arm is the only way to determine if his abrupt resignation as coach had harmed the university financially. The filing, part of an official response Friday to the university’s lawsuit, largely restated arguments that Rodriguez’s lawyers had previously made in response to the lawsuit over a $4 million buyout clause in his contract. Rodriguez asked the court to make the fund-raising group, the WVU Foundation, a third party to the lawsuit.

headline: Preparing the Patriots, but Staying Off the Field
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The player who personifies the Patriots spent this week pretending to be a Giant. Troy Brown, who held the team single-season reception record that was surpassed this year by Wes Welker, ran routes for the scout team to help prepare the Patriots’ defense for its Super Bowl matchup Sunday against the Giants.

headline: Yahoo Offer Is Strategy Shift for Microsoft
text: Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft and a global philanthropist, called upon fellow business leaders at the World Economic Forum last week to pursue a kinder form of capitalism.

headline: North Carolina: 6 Die in Plane Crash
text: A twin-engine plane crashed as it tried to land amid low fog at a small airport in Mount Airy, killing all six people on board, officials said. No one on the ground was hurt, said Warren Woodberry, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The King Air C90A took off in Cedartown, Ga., Mr. Woodberry said, and the passengers were on their way to Primland, a hunting and golf resort in Meadows of Dan, Va., about 25 miles north of the Mount Airy airport, said Kelvin Boyette, the airport manager.

headline: Bracing Small Business in a Turbulent Economy
text: THE Bush administration and others have praised small business as the engine of American job creation, but small-company owners are being squeezed by the shaky economy and rising health costs.

headline: French Open Lawsuit
text: The organizers of the French Open filed a lawsuit Friday to prevent online gambling companies from offering bets on the tournament. The complaint, which was filed in courts in Liège, Belgium, and in Paris, seeks injunctions against the companies Betfair, Bwin and Ladbrokes.

headline: Irving Berlin? Broadway? No, City Ballet
text: Bless Susan Stroman and New York City Ballet. With Ms. Stroman’s “Double Feature,” august ballet audiences can indulge in an unaccustomed Broadway-style laugh riot.

headline: Border Traffic Moves Well in First Days of New Rule for Americans’ Re-entry
text: EL PASO  A lot of Americans grumbled, but there were no major delays or disruptions at this bustling border station in the last two days as United States citizens were required for the first time to show a passport or other identity documents to return to the country by land.

headline: ‘Minister of Ideas’ Tries to Put Brazil’s Future in Focus
text: Brasília

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Q&A column in Science Times on Jan.15, about the elements the Sun produces, misidentified the heaviest stable element. It is lead, not iron.

headline: A New Chapter in Ethnic Cleansing
text: It is far too easy to become inured to bad news from Africa, a continent of great promise and peril. Kenya’s rampage of ethnically driven killings that is now five weeks long is especially sickening and attention-grabbing because of how much hope the world had for Kenya’s democracy and economic revival  and how fast the country has descended into madness.

headline: Shooters Are Sought in Israeli Embassy Attack in Mauritania
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Investigators from Mauritania, Israel and the United States were searching for men who opened fire on the Israeli Embassy in the Mauritanian capital early on Friday, and struggling to determine the motive and target of the attack.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some editions last Saturday with a sports article about Jerome Collins, a backup tight end for the Giants, misidentified the player shown hugging running back Brandon Jacobs. It was David Diehl of the Giants, not Collins.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart on Monday omitted one of the 24 states holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday. The West Virginia Republican Party is holding a state convention that day. And an article on Thursday about New York State Republicans’ embrace of Senator John McCain for the presidential nomination after Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped out referred incorrectly to the 21 Republican contests on Tuesday. In addition to the West Virginia convention, there are 15 primaries and five caucuses; not all 21 Republican events are primaries.

headline: Housing Illness Spreading to Rest of Construction
text: A PLUNGE in construction spending threatens to drive the American economy into recession.

headline: If It’s Hit, Strummed or Plucked, It’ll Be Here
text: You make a fortune, love the arts and want to give money away. That usually means building a fancy new orchestra hall, financing an opera season or helping to pay sleek ballet dancers.

headline: Giants Coach Coughlin Focusing on Fun for a Change
text: PHOENIX  Dressed in a dark suit and carrying a casual demeanor, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin made his final public appearance Friday before the Super Bowl, answering questions at the final pre-game news conference.

headline: Berlusconi’s Long Shadow Casts a Chill Over Italian Politics
text: ROME  To Silvia Tomassini, owner of a boutique in Rome’s ancient center, Silvio Berlusconi is “arrogant.” At 71, he’s too old. He endlessly commits “brutta figura,” which loosely means that you can’t take the man anywhere nice.

headline: Spurrier Package Approved
text: South Carolina’s board of trustees approved a tax-deferred retirement package Friday for the football coach Steve Spurrier that would pay him $1 million if he remained with the Gamecocks for the next four seasons. Spurrier makes about $1.75 million a year.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Public Lives column in some editions on Jan. 25, about Judge Margarita López Torres of Surrogate’s Court in Brooklyn, whose legal challenge to the way New York picks its judges was rejected by the United States Supreme Court, referred incorrectly to her background. She was born in Puerto Rico and moved to New York City as a child; she did not immigrate.

headline: McCartney Denies Heart Trouble
text: Paul McCartney called recent reports that he had a heart procedure last year “entirely untrue,” The Associated Press reported. Mr. McCartney, 65, wrote in a letter posted on his Web site (paulmccartney.com) that during a routine medical examination more than a year ago, “there was a minor irregularity which I needed to have tests for and which I have now been assured is completely fine.” Reports that he had had an angioplasty “completely distorted the story,” Mr. McCartney said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Friday about the excitement surrounding this week’s FBR Open golf tournament at the T.P.C. Scottsdale in Arizona misstated the given name of the event’s director. He is Tim Louis, not Phil.

headline: Preventing Diabetes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lone Star Executive Sentenced
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A court here on Friday found the private equity fund Lone Star and one of its executives guilty of manipulating stock prices, dealing a blow to Lone Star in its closely watched legal battle.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Buy Stake in Penney
text: The investor Carl C. Icahn has gone shopping again, this time acquiring shares in the retailer J. C. Penney, people briefed on the matter said Friday. The size of the stake could not be learned.

headline: Motivated by a Tax, Irish Spurn Plastic Bags
text: DUBLIN  There is something missing from this otherwise typical bustling cityscape. There are taxis and buses. There are hip bars and pollution. Every other person is talking into a cellphone. But there are no plastic shopping bags, the ubiquitous symbol of urban life.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Schedule information in Weekend on Friday with a film review of “Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert” misidentified the theaters where the film is playing. As the review noted, it is a 3-D film, and it is being shown in digital 3-D theaters, not on Imax screens.

headline: On a City Campus, Excitement and Uncertainty for Primary
text: For them, it’s almost impossible to remember a time when Hillary Rodham Clinton was not in the White House or the Senate. Sept. 11, 2001, was a third of a lifetime ago.

headline: Divisive Serbian Vote Offers Stark Choice of East and West
text: BELGRADE  As Serbia prepared to choose a president, 25,000 supporters of the nationalist challenger, Tomislav Nikolic, packed a stadium on Thursday where the warm-up performances included a haunting song celebrating Radovan Karadzic, the fugitive Bosnian Serb leader charged with genocide, enthusiastic tributes to Moscow and rousing speeches by former lieutenants of the late Slobodan Milosevic.

headline: A New Orleans Paradox
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wesley Snipes Cleared of Serious Tax Charges
text: OCALA, Fla.  A federal jury returned a mixed verdict against the actor Wesley Snipes on Friday, acquitting him of the most serious tax charges he faced, but convicting him on three of six lesser charges. The case was the most prominent tax prosecution since the billionaire hotelier Leona Helmsley was convicted of tax fraud in 1989.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The On Education column on Jan. 16, about overcrowding at Richmond Hill High School in Queens, described the status of a nearby high school, Franklin K. Lane, incorrectly, and because of an editing error, referred imprecisely to its location. It is scheduled to be phased out over four years; it has not closed. And although Franklin Lane is near the Queens border, it is in Brooklyn, not in Queens.

headline: A Giant Bid That Shows How Tired the Giant Is
text: Oh, how the mighty have fallen.

headline: Alcoa and Chinese Rival Buy 12% Stake in Rio Tinto
text: SHANGHAI  The state-owned giant Aluminum Corporation of China and the Aluminum Corporation of America stunned analysts and investors Friday by buying a minority stake in Rio Tinto, the world’s third largest mining company.

headline: Casey and Red Sox in Accord
text: The free agent Sean Casey reached a preliminary agreement on a one-year, $800,000 contract with the Boston Red Sox, giving them an experienced backup at first base to Kevin Youkilis. Casey hit .296 with four homers for the Detroit Tigers last season.

headline: California: Sewage Spill in San Francisco Bay
text: More than two million gallons of partially treated sewage and storm water were dumped into the San Francisco Bay on Thursday night, and officials in Marin County, north of San Francisco, were trying to determine the extent of environmental damage. According to the county sheriff’s office, the spill occurred at a sewage treatment plant in Mill Valley after a pump, and an alarm system meant to monitor it, both failed after several weeks of near-constant rain. Warning signs were posted at several beaches, and tests were being conducted to determine whether any hazardous sewage escaped. Public health officials were also warning boaters and fishermen to avoid contact with the water near Richardson Bay, near Sausalito. The spill comes three months after a Chinese container ship struck the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge, spilling 58,000 gallons of fuel.

headline: Sex Offender Accused of Raping Boy, 6, in Public Library
text: BOSTON  A convicted sex offender was arrested this week and charged with raping a 6-year-old boy in the New Bedford public library, feet away from his mother, who was working on a computer.

headline: Keeping Our Food Safe
text: To the Editor:

headline: C.I.A. Tells of Changes for Its Internal Inquiries
text: WASHINGTON  After an internal inquiry that put his office under unusual scrutiny, the inspector general of the Central Intelligence Agency has agreed to a series of changes in the way the office conducts its investigations of the agency’s practices, the C.I.A. director confirmed on Thursday in a message to agency employees.

headline: Viewers Find ‘Lost’
text: The premiere of the fourth season of “Lost” delivered 16.1 million viewers on Thursday, Nielsen estimated, lifting ABC to a No. 1 finish on the night, though the audience was down from the 18.8 million who watched last season’s debut. The premiere followed an 8 p.m. show summarizing the series’s complicated back story (13.1 million).Fox and NBC ranked second and third on the night among adults 18 to 49. CBS was fourth in that demographic but managed to finish second in total viewers. And CNN’s broadcast of the debate between Senator Barack Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton drew an average of 8.3 million viewers, the most ever for a primary debate on cable news.

headline: Wall Street Does Its Share to Help Fellow New Yorkers
text: Several analysts from Goldman Sachs and Citigroup delivered an envelope full of cash, checks and change this week to the offices of The New York Times Company Foundation.

headline: Goodell Defends Handling of Patriots’ Spying Case
text: PHOENIX  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Friday that he was willing to meet with Senator Arlen Specter, who Thursday said he would call Mr. Goodell before the Senate Judiciary Committee to explain why the league destroyed the tapes from its investigation into spying by the New England Patriots.

headline: Retrial Begins for Six Accused in Sears Tower Plot
text: MIAMI  The retrial of six construction workers accused of conspiring to join forces with Al Qaeda and blow up the Sears Tower in Chicago began on Friday, seven weeks after the jury in the first trial deadlocked on those defendants and acquitted a seventh.

headline: Eli Stone’s Overleap of Faith
text: You can’t help rooting for Eli Stone, the young corporate attorney who has decided to go to bat for the little guy (after a “Faith”-singing George Michael appears in his living room) in ABC’s new series that bears his name. Unfortunately, on his first try, Mr. Stone  even with Mr. Michael singing backup and the spiritual insights attributed to an inoperable brain aneurysm  chose the wrong cause to champion and sent the wrong message to parents about the safety of vaccines.

headline: Insecticide-Tainted Dumplings From China Sicken 175 in Japan
text: TOKYO  The Japanese government said Friday that at least 175 people had been sickened by insecticide-tainted dumplings from China, prompting supermarkets to pull Chinese-made meat products from their shelves while Tokyo pressed Beijing to improve food safety.

headline: Authors Suit Dismissed
text: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit brought by five authors against Eagle Publishing, the parent company of Regnery Publishing, a Washington-based conservative imprint. The authors had charged that the company deprived them of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company. Judge Ellen Segal Huvelle of United States District Court in Washington ruled on Wednesday that because the authors had contracts with Regnery, not Eagle, and those contracts included binding arbitration clauses, the lawsuit was invalid. “We are very pleased with the judge’s dismissal of the lawsuit,” Marji Ross, president and publisher of Regnery, said. Richard Miniter, one of the authors, said they would file an arbitration case next week.

headline: New Bids Are Sought for Building on Railyards
text: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, seeking a bigger financial stake in the sale of development rights over the West Side railyards, has asked five competing developers to submit a new round of bids. According to documents sent to the developers Monday night, the authority prefers to lease the property, 26 acres overlooking the Hudson River, to the winning bidder for 99 years, rather than to sell it. And in a new request, it is asking for an “equity-type interest” in any project built on the land.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article last Saturday about the growing endowments of college preparatory schools referred incorrectly to the rankings by age of college preparatory schools in the United States. Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., founded in 1781, is the sixth-oldest boarding school, not the third-oldest school over all, including day schools. Older boarding schools are West Nottingham Academy in Colora, Md. (1744); Linden Hall in Lititz, Pa. (1746); the Governor’s Academy in Byfield, Mass. (1763); Salem Academy in Winston-Salem, N.C. (1772); and Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. (1781). Older day schools include the Collegiate School in New York City (1628), Roxbury Latin School in Boston (1645) and Hopkins in New Haven (1660). The article also gave an incomplete name for a boarding school in Wallingford, Conn. It is Choate Rosemary Hall, not just Choate.

headline: Randolph Trade Looks Good for Portland
text: PORTLAND, Ore.  There is little Zach Randolph can do now, short of realigning the stars, space and time, to validate the trade that sent him to New York last June. The Knicks are too disjointed and their defeats too voluminous, for anyone to change impressions at this point.

headline: Closing Income Gap Tops Obama’s Agenda for Economic Change
text: WICHITA, Kan.  Senator Barack Obama says the top priority of the next president should be to create a more lasting and equitable prosperity than achieved by either President Bush in the current decade or even Bill Clinton in the 1990s.

headline: Union Workers Protest Firing by Players Club
text: For several hours every day since Monday, a small picket line has marched outside the Players Club’s landmark Greek Revival town house, which was deeded to the group by one of its famous founders: John Wilkes Booth’s brother Edwin, the leading Shakespearean actor in late-19th-century America.

headline: Massachusetts Accuses Merrill of Fraud
text: The top securities regulator in Massachusetts accused Merrill Lynch on Friday of defrauding the city of Springfield with subprime-linked investments, casting light on how Wall Street banks sold complex mortgage securities that are now plummeting in value as the housing slump deepens.

headline: Spreading Banditry Dilutes Benefits of a Plan for Ethnic Peace in Kenya
text: NANDI HILLS, Kenya  The road from Eldoret to Kericho used to be one of the prettiest drives in Kenya, a ribbon of asphalt threading through lush tea farms, bushy sugar cane and green humpbacked hills. Now it is a gantlet of machete-wielding teenagers, some chewing stalks of sugar cane, others stumbling drunk.

headline: Bullish About the Web
text: ONLINE ADS: WINNERS AND LOSERS

headline: Guantánamo Decision Rebuffs Government
text: A federal appeals court ruled against the Bush administration on Friday in a central case on Guantánamo detainees, declining to reconsider an order that the government has to turn over virtually all its information on many detainees.

headline: Fund Data Show Rivals in G.O.P. Almost Tied
text: Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney each ended 2007 with more than $2 million in cash on hand, $2.9 million for Mr. McCain and $2.4 million for Mr. Romney. But the candidates took entirely different routes to reach almost the same point.

headline: First Job Losses in 4 Years Raise Recession Fears
text: The nation’s employers eliminated 17,000 jobs in January, the government reported Friday, the first decline in the work force in more than four years, and the strongest signal yet that the United States may be in the early stages of a recession.

headline: Opponents of Atlantic Yards Lose an Appellate Ruling
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Friday that a lower court was correct last year in tossing out a lawsuit challenging the Atlantic Yards construction project near Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Attention, Slackers: It’s a Jungle Out There
text: Underachieving even by the standards of stoner comedies, “Strange Wilderness” is so inert that it doesn’t so much unreel on screen as loiter there, giggling at its own outrageousness.

headline: Dodgers and Reliever Agree
text: The Dodgers avoided arbitration with the left-handed reliever Joe Beimel, agreeing Friday to a one-year, $1,925,000 contract. Beimel appeared in a career-high 83 games last season. He was 4-2 with a 3.88 earned run average and a save.

headline: Colombia: Drug Boss Killed in Venezuela
text: Wilber Alirio Varela, a leader of the Norte del Valle drug cartel in Colombia, has been found shot to death in a hotel in Mérida, in Venezuela’s Andean region. He commanded a private army believed responsible for hundreds of killings in and near the Colombian city of Cali. The United States was offering a reward of up to $5 million. Mr. Varela was wanted in connection with exports of cocaine to the United States worth more than $10 billion. The killing in Venezuela comes amid claims that it has become a major shipment point and haven for Colombian drug traffickers.

headline: In the Town Where the Giants Play, a Sense of Being Overlooked
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: A Region Where Many Voters Opt to Cross Party Lines
text: RIFLE, Colo.  Political quirkiness has a long and honored pedigree in the West. Many people come to places like Garfield County, a sprawling rural area here on the western slope of the Rockies, to shed the pigeon holes, labels and other confining encumbrances that they associate with the East and West Coasts and all the big cities between.

headline: Islanders’ Nolan Proves Himself Once Again
text: Hardly a day goes by that Ted Nolan does not open the refrigerator door, just to stare at the shelves stocked with food.

headline: Bank Chief May Face Questions
text: PARIS  A senior prosecutor examining the trading scandal at Société Générale recommended Friday that the bank’s chief executive, Daniel Bouton, be questioned by judges in connection with accusations he has made about a rogue trader’s role in the loss of billions of euros.

headline: English Arts Grants Are Maintained
text: Arts Council England, the government-financed body that provides subsidies to the arts, announced a 9.5 percent budget increase over the next three years and maintained financing of 17 recipients that had been scheduled for cuts, Bloomberg News reported. Those cuts had caused an uproar, drawing hundreds of actors to a protest at the Young Vic Theater last month. Christopher Frayling, chairman of the council, said that 888 arts groups would share £1.3 billion ($2.6 billion) between now and 2011. Another 185 groups, though, will no longer get financing, including the London Mozart Players and the City of London Sinfonia.

headline: A Touch of Royal Pomp From a Flute-Playing King
text: Regal luxury is a concept foreign to New York’s financially troubled early-music world. But the Clarion Music Society and its artistic director, Steven Fox, made a decent show of it at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday evening, offering “Treasures From the Court of Frederick the Great.”

headline: Hamas to Cooperate on Border Closing
text: JERUSALEM  Hamas said on Saturday that it would cooperate with Egypt to close the breached border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip on Sunday.

headline: It’s Official: Santana and Mets Have a Deal
text: It took every bit of their allotted 72 hours, an additional 90 minutes and $137.5 million, but the Mets finally secured the best pitcher in baseball. They reached an agreement with Johan Santana, the dominant left-hander acquired Tuesday from the Minnesota Twins, shortly before 6:30 p.m. Friday, signing him to a contract that would make him the highest-paid pitcher in baseball history.

headline: Clinton’s Gradual Education on Issues of Race
Somalia: Doctors Without Borders Pulls Out
text: The French medical charity Doctors Without Borders said it had withdrawn its 87 foreign employees from Somalia after three of its workers  a Kenyan surgeon, a French logistics expert and a Somali driver  were killed this week in a land mine explosion in the south that it termed “probably premeditated.”

headline: Tie in Arizona
text: J. B. Holmes shot a six-under-par 65 to share the clubhouse lead with Doug LaBelle II at nine-under 133 among the players who finished the second round Friday at the FBR Open in Scottsdale, Ariz. LaBelle shot a 64. A 90-minute frost delay to start the day left 45 golfers on the course when play was halted because of darkness.One of them, Camilo Villegas, was tied for the lead at nine under through 12 holes. Two were at eight under on the course: Bill Haas through 13 holes and Ben Crane through 14. They will complete the round Saturday before the cut is made.

headline: Even on Basketball Court, Focus Is on Football Star
text: VILLANOVA, Pa.  Terrelle Pryor was one of the best basketball players on the court Friday night as his team, Jeannette High School of western Pennsylvania, played Chester High School, a six-time defending district champion. In the first quarter, Pryor drew cheers by finishing a breakaway with a thunderous one-handed slam.

headline: Identifying the Singleton, No Computer Needed
text: Today we are all accustomed to computers generating deals and scoring duplicates. But 40 years ago everything was done by humans. In the early 1960s one of the pioneers in using computers to yield deals and scores was Marty Scheinberg, then of New York and now of Singer Island, Fla. Scheinberg declared the diagramed deal on Jan. 16 in a private team game in Boca Raton, Fla.

headline: G.M.’s Car Sales Rise in an Otherwise Tough Month
text: DETROIT  Automakers got off to a rough start in 2008, as expected, but General Motors served up a surprise on Friday with higher sales in January on strong demand for its new car models.

headline: New Operation to Put Heavily Armed Officers in Subways
text: In the first counterterrorism strategy of its kind in the nation, roving teams of New York City police officers armed with automatic rifles and accompanied by bomb-sniffing dogs will patrol the city’s subway system daily, beginning next month, officials said on Friday.

headline: Progress Toward Ending Writers’ Strike
text: LOS ANGELES  Informal talks between representatives of Hollywood’s striking writers and production companies have eliminated the major roadblocks to a new contract, which could lead to a tentative agreement as early as next week, according to people who were briefed on the situation but requested anonymity because they were not authorized to speak.

headline: 30 Baptist Groups Build a Bridge Toward Unity
text: ATLANTA  The Rev. Bill Shoulta called himself a renegade.

headline: A Symphonic Homage to Manhattan
text: “Manhattan Takes Manhattan” is the slogan of the Manhattan School of Music’s celebration of its 90th anniversary this year. What better way to assert that theme than the premiere of “212,” a symphony in homage to Manhattan by the composer and native New Yorker Robert Sirota? The piece, which takes its title from the borough’s area code, was played impressively on Thursday by the Manhattan School of Music Symphony, with Kenneth Kiesler conducting, at the John C. Borden Auditorium, where it shared a program with Mahler’s Symphony No. 1 in D.

headline: Wisconsin: Nun Jailed for Sexual Abuse
text: A 79-year-old nun was sentenced to one year in a county jail for sexually abusing two teenagers when she was their principal four decades ago in Milwaukee. Sister Norma Giannini avoided a trial by pleading no contest in November to two felony counts of indecent behavior with a child. The two male victims told the authorities they had dozens of sexual encounters with Sister Giannini, including intercourse, while attending St. Patrick’s School in Milwaukee during the 1960s, according to a criminal complaint. Sister Giannini, who lives with other Sisters of Mercy in a Chicago suburb, has been retired from active work for five years because of failing health.

headline: Deal That May Create More, Not Less, Competition
text: In most industries, a merger of two major companies would cause everyone else to panic over a decline in competition.

headline: When Just Handing Over a Ring Won’t Do
text: I LIKE hearing marriage proposal stories, and I like telling about ours. All right, since you asked, my husband-to-be proposed in Paris in the back of a taxi.

headline: Bolivia: Plane Crash-Lands; All Survive
text: A Boeing 727 flown by Lloyd Aéreo Boliviano and carrying 155 passengers crash-landed in a forest clearing near the eastern city of Trinidad after storms turned it away from its destination, Cobija, hundreds of miles away, according to officials and news reports. All on board survived. Photographs showed the plane stripped of at least one wing. It was three miles from the runway in Trinidad. Survivors said it had lost power. The airline has been in and out of bankruptcy in recent years. It now runs a handful of planes on a charter basis.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Blake Avoids Arbitration
text: Third baseman Casey Blake avoided arbitration by agreeing to a one-year, $6.1 million contract with the Cleveland Indians. Blake, who can become a free agent after this season, hit .270 with 18 home runs last season.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the dismissal of the final claim in a lawsuit brought by a violinist against the Seattle Symphony and its music director, Gerard Schwarz, referred imprecisely to members of the orchestra who have said they were targets of vandalism. They are supporters of Mr. Schwarz, who has faced opposition from players, not his opponents.

headline: A Flight Attendant’s Duties
text: To the Editor:

headline: Honoring Jazz Greats, Not Repeating Them
text: Two years ago the pianist Myra Melford, the bassist Mark Dresser and the drummer Matt Wilson joined forces as an experimental collective, Trio M. Though unassumingly named after a shared first initial  they might just as easily have gone with 3M, but apparently that was taken  the ensemble struck a high-minded and often sophisticated tone. “Big Picture” (Cryptogramophone), released last year, was a strong collaborative debut. It also felt ripe with potential.

headline: Ethereal Songs Made More Expansive With an Orchestra’s Multitude of Colors
text: The orchestra slips in almost surreptitiously in “Emily,” the first song on Joanna Newsom’s 2006 album, “Ys,” just as it did at her concert with the Brooklyn Philharmonic on Thursday night. Pizzicato violins joined the plucked strings of Ms. Newsom’s harp, as if they might blend in, but they didn’t stay incognito long. Soon the 30-piece orchestra was doing what her harp cannot: sustaining chords and gliding between notes, creating a cushion of harmony, stirring up extra counterpoint, placing the songs in broader vistas.

headline: Canadian Inquiry Blames Israelis for Deaths in 2006
text: OTTAWA  A Canadian military inquiry’s report released Friday blames Israeli forces for the “tragic and preventable” deaths of a Canadian soldier and three other United Nations observers in Lebanon in July 2006.

headline: Chadian Army Battles Rebels
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Chad’s army waged fierce battles on Friday against rebel troops headed for the country’s capital, Ndjamena, where they are seeking to force the president, Idriss Déby, to share power or step down.

headline: Viktor Schreckengost, Master of Product Design, Dies at 101
text: Viktor Schreckengost, a distinguished yet largely unsung industrial designer who spent most of the 20th century quietly infusing every corner of the United States with his work, from dinnerware for the average home to the prized Art Deco “Jazz” bowls for the White House, died last Saturday while wintering in Tallahassee, Fla. He was 101.

headline: The Milestones of a Squandered Presidency
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parade Returns, and New Orleans’s Heart Rejoices
text: NEW ORLEANS  Amid the riot of purple, gold and green  the flowers, the bunting, the flags, the tinsel, the masks and the wreaths outside the Negrottos’ house on Orleans Avenue near City Park  there is a new addition to the holiday décor: A big banner proclaiming, “Welcome Home Endymion.”

headline: Doctor Missing Since 9/10 Is Declared a Victim of 9/11
text: A doctor who left her home in Lower Manhattan on Sept. 10, 2001, and never returned died in the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center the next morning, a state appellate court in Manhattan has ruled.

headline: As Barriers Fall, a Black Politician Sticks With Clinton
text: ALBANY  Being one of Hillary Rodham Clinton’s most visible black supporters has complicated the life of David A. Paterson, the lieutenant governor of New York.

headline: At 90, Giants Trainer Decides He Will Retire After Sunday’s Game
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  In 1948, the Giants had an opening for a trainer. A young man named John Johnson filled it.

headline: For Just a Few Dollars, a Big TV and Years of Debt
text: First thing Friday morning, before anyone showed up to rent a television for the Super Bowl, Deborah Williams walked in the door of the Rent-A-Center store under the Broadway el in Bushwick, Brooklyn. She was delivering $109 in cash, her February payment for a 27-inch television that she is buying over time.

headline: Coffee and Pregnancy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Eyes on Google, Microsoft Bids $44 Billion for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, was finishing a regularly scheduled company board meeting Thursday night when his assistant interrupted him with an urgent phone call.

headline: In Land of Fútbol, Hoping for Football Fans
text: NOGALES, Mexico  About 180 miles from the site of Super Bowl XLII, through a desert lined with tumbleweeds and cacti, a fence rises with barbed wire coiled across the top.

headline: A Voter’s Guide
text: The Democrats: One minute they’re not even speaking. The next thing you know they’re at Thursday’s debate smiling and whispering in each other’s ear. (Use of the word “agree”: Obama, 7; Clinton, 5.)

headline: Appeal of Challenge to ‘No Child’ Law
text: One month after a three-judge panel of a federal appeals court revived a legal challenge to the federal No Child Left Behind law, Education Secretary Margaret Spellings said she would ask the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, to convene a larger panel to reconsider that ruling. In its 2-to-1 ruling on Jan. 7, the Sixth Circuit said that school districts in Michigan and several other states had been justified in their 2005 suit that argued the law required them to pay for testing and other programs without providing sufficient federal money.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded: $7,239,904

headline: Sober Bartok With a Swirling Finale
text: Big ideas in music gravitate toward big sounds. Well used, a single instrument does even better. Viviane Hagner’s violin recital with the pianist Tatiana Goncharova at the 92nd Street Y on Thursday was mostly Brahms but mainly about Bartok’s Sonata for Solo Violin. It is a singular piece in more ways than one.

headline: A Showdown, but With a Civil Tone
text: To the Editor:

headline: Lagat Outduels Mottram in Wanamaker Mile
text: Craig Mottram’s lead in the Wanamaker Mile lasted all of one lap.

headline: Smart on Crime
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gunman Kills 5 at Store in Chicago Suburb
text: TINLEY PARK, Ill.  The authorities in this suburb southwest of Chicago were engaged in a massive search on Saturday evening for a man they say shot and killed five women inside a clothing store during a robbery attempt that went terribly wrong.

headline: Secrets and Rights
text: President Bush’s excesses in the name of fighting terrorism are legion. To avoid accountability, his administration has repeatedly sought early dismissal of lawsuits that might finally expose government misconduct, brandishing flimsy claims that going forward would put national security secrets at risk.

headline: Israel: Arabs Protest
text: Israeli Arabs staged big protest strikes after a government decision last weekend to drop an inquiry into a 2000 police shooting that killed 13 people as the police were trying to put down riots in favor of the intifada. As many as 20,000 protesters marched in Sakhnin. On Sunday, the Israeli attorney general said there was insufficient evidence to convict officers, in part because the families of the victims would not allow autopsies.

headline: Judge Rules Absentees Can Revote in New Jersey
text: Voters in New Jersey who cast absentee ballots for a candidate who has dropped out of the presidential race can vote again, a judge has ruled.

headline: The Melting Point
text: Los Glaciares National Park,

headline: If an Election Is Close ...
text: If there is one lesson to be drawn from the 2000 elections, it is that recounting votes can be as important as counting them in the first place. It has also become clear in the years since that some of the fanciest new machines fail to offer a secure way to verify votes and a decent paper trail for recounting.

headline: Kennedy Revels in Limelight as He Stumps for Obama
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  “Are you glad to see me, Santa Fe?” Edward M. Kennedy roared.

headline: Obama Wins Endorsement of MoveOn.org
text: LOS ANGELES  As the Democratic presidential rivals dashed into a final weekend of campaigning before the nominating contests here and in 21 other states next Tuesday, Senator Barack Obama collected the endorsement on Friday of a leading antiwar group, MoveOn.org. He said his opposition to the war would make him a stronger general election candidate.

headline: Spice Girls Cancel Part of Their Tour
text: The Spice Girls said Friday that they had canceled concerts planned for China, Australia, South Africa and Argentina, shortening their reunion tour, Agence France-Presse reported. The group pulled out for “family and personal commitments,” a spokesman said, though there have been reports of poor ticket sales. Concerts in Beijing, Shanghai, Hong Kong, Sydney, Cape Town and Buenos Aires are off, and the tour is now set to finish in Toronto on Feb. 26. The Spice Girls, who last toured almost 10 years ago, sold more than 50 million albums worldwide and had nine British No. 1 singles in the 1990s.

headline: Symbols and Signs Amid All the Ideas
text: Via Dance Collaborative expresses a sweetly optimistic belief in group exploration. This four-year-old troupe develops “new work in a collegial, mutually supportive atmosphere,” according to the program notes for its current show at Dance New Amsterdam.

headline: Romney Maps a Strategy for Survival
text: DENVER  After devoting two years and more than $35 million of his money trying to win his party’s nomination for the presidency, Mitt Romney and his advisers face the possibility that his effort could end with the nominating contests on Tuesday.

headline: A World of Malnourished Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: Reasons Vary, but McCain and Romney Compete for the Same Prize
text: CHICAGO  Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney waged a long-distance war on Friday over who was the real Republican as Mr. McCain released his first national television commercial, “True Conservative,” and Mr. Romney’s campaign attacked him for his “straight talk detour” into the favorite causes of the Democratic Party.

headline: It’s Enough to Make Anyone Blink
text: “I want to see the world like everyone else,” the blind violinist Sydney Wells (Jessica Alba) whines at the beginning of “The Eye,” the latest Western deconstruction of a successful Asian horror movie.

headline: Clinton and the Iraq War Amendment
text: WASHINGTON  During Thursday night’s Democratic debate in Los Angeles, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was asked to explain why she had voted against an amendment to the 2002 resolution that authorized the use of force in Iraq.

headline: Lowering the Volume
text: There may be some grown-ups left in the Democratic Party after all.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A chart on Monday omitted one of the 24 states holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday. The West Virginia Republican Party is holding a state convention that day. And an article on Thursday about New York State Republicans’ embrace of Senator John McCain for the presidential nomination after Rudolph W. Giuliani dropped out referred incorrectly to the 21 Republican contests on Tuesday. In addition to the West Virginia convention, there are 15 primaries and five caucuses; not all 21 Republican events are primaries. (Go to Article)

headline: Where the Capitalism Is (Always on Display)
text: A few years ago, when irrational exuberance reigned, opening a handsome museum devoted to the history and celebration of money just a block from the New York Stock Exchange might have seemed somewhat vulgar. In times of enthusiasm and plenty, celebration is superfluous. Why devote reverential attention to something when its powers are so omnipresent that they provide daily fodder for gossip?

headline: If It’s Tuesday, It Must Be Spanish
text: CONVENTIONAL wisdom says it is never too early for children to learn a foreign language. But conventional wisdom predates the days of paying someone to teach your child another tongue.

headline: Rangers Grab Lead and Lundqvist Holds It
text: NEWARK  Late in the first period Friday night, Devils forward Patrik Elias fired two consecutive shots at Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist. The second, which was zipped quickly at Lundqvist from two feet away, was so tantalizing that Elias threw his head back when he heard the thud of the puck against Lundqvist’s pads.

headline: 8 Banks Discuss Aid for Bond Insurer
text: Eight major banks are in talks to bolster the Ambac Financial Group, the troubled bond insurance company, as part of an industrywide rescue being orchestrated by state regulators, people briefed on the negotiations said Friday.

headline: Houston Prosecutor Admits He Deleted E-Mail Messages
text: HOUSTON  The embattled Harris County district attorney admitted before a federal judge here Friday that in violation of two subpoenas and a court order, he deleted as many as 3,500 e-mail messages sought in a civil rights lawsuit. He said he thought the messages were available on backup files.

headline: Utility Stocks No Longer Such a Haven

headline: Woods Leads in Dubai
text: Tiger Woods managed it all  the wind blowing, the sand swirling and the photographers clicking.He shot a one-under-par 71 Friday, making birdies on two of the last three holes, for a one-stroke lead halfway through the Dubai Desert Classic. Woods was at eight-under 136. He also won in Dubai in 2006. Damien McGrane, who is ranked 319th and has never won as a professional, shot a 69 and was a stroke behind. He will be paired with Woods in the third round Saturday at Emirates Golf Club.Wind gusts reaching 30 miles an hour shook the bunkers and desert terrain. Sand flew in faces and created a haze masking many of the skyscrapers usually seen towering over the course. Woods wore sunglasses but said he was still “chewing sand all day.”The defending champion, Henrik Stenson of Sweden, shot a 70 and was two strokes behind. He shared third place with Thomas Levet of France, who had a 71.

headline: State Court Recognizes Gay Marriages From Elsewhere
text: A New York appellate court ruled Friday that valid out-of-state marriages of same-sex couples must be legally recognized in New York, just as the law recognizes those of heterosexual couples solemnized elsewhere. Lawyers for both sides said the ruling applied to all public and private employers in the state.

headline: The Dollar’s Long Fade
text: DOLLAR’S FUTURE The dollar may gain a bit against other currencies in 2008, Bloomberg Markets reports, but its long-term prospects are bleak. The days when the dollar was strong  both in terms of purchasing power and prestige  may be past.

headline: Hong Kong Toymaker Discusses the Costs of Doing Business in China
text: Francis Choi is the chairman and chief executive of the Early Light Industrial Toy Company in Hong Kong, one of the biggest toy manufacturers in Asia. The company produces goods for some of the world's biggest toy companies, including Mattel. In an e-mail response this week to questions about the rising costs of doing business in China, he said that he expected toy prices to increase as much as 15 percent this year, but that companies like Early Light would make higher-value toys to continue to grow. He outlined the problems facing the toy industry and other companies that manufacture products in China, where costs are rising dramatically.

headline: Federal spending mythology
text: One thing I’ve written about a number of times, but becomes especially worth emphasizing now that John McCain is the presumptive Republican nominee, is the myth of runaway federal spending under the Bush administration. McCain has said on a number of occasions that he doesn’t know much about economics — although, straight-talker that he is, he has also denied having ever said such a thing. But one thing he thinks he knows is that the Bush administration has been spending like a drunken sailor. Has it?

Women, African Americans and Hispanics are among the most strategically important and closely scrutinized demographic groups in a campaign where two historic first candidates are going head to head, especially in a city where blacks comprise one quarter of the population and women make up 60 percent of registered Democrats.

headline: Giuliani Is Coming Home, for McCain
text: Updated, 11:38 p.m. | There was an awkward moment on Wednesday when former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who was abandoning his presidential bid and endorsing Senator John McCain of Arizona, told Mr. McCain: “I’m going to campaign with John McCain as much as he wants — or not, depending on if I’m in trouble or not at that particular point.” Mr. McCain smiled, uncomfortably. Evidently the McCain campaign has concluded that Mr. Giuliani is more of an asset than a liability, if their frequent joint appearances are any indication.Now comes word that the former mayor is heading home to help his ally. Mr. McCain told reporters in Birmingham, Ala., today that Mr. Giuliani will be campaigning with him on Monday and Tuesday in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. McCain is scheduled to speak at Sacred Heart University in Fairfield, Conn., at 1 p.m. on Sunday.

headline: Correction: 8 Decades, 7 Iraqi Flags
text: Because of an editing error, a chart last Sunday on the history of Iraq’s national flag misstated the year in which the reign of Iraq’s first 20th-century king ended. The British-backed monarch, King Faisal I, ruled until 1933, when he died, not until 1958. (It was his grandson King Faisal II who was deposed in a 1958 military coup that ended the monarchy.)

headline: The Suburb That Resisted Condos

Mr. Burns also recalls the day that Mitchell Berenson, a local developer, came before the Town Board with what was then considered an audacious proposal to build 117 town-house condominiums within New Castle, in the hamlet of Chappaqua.

headline: They Might Be Losers
text: WHEN New Yorkers reminisce about our beloved hometown sports team that couldn’t quite win it all, we’re usually talking about the Brooklyn Dodgers. From 1941 through 1953, the Dodgers reached the World Series five times but always lost to the hated Yankees. During that same 13 years, they finished two games shy of a National League pennant three times and lost a tiebreaker playoff game on Bobby Thomson’s home run for New York’s baseball Giants in 1951.

headline: Back-Room Choices
text: This Tuesday was designed to be the day when it all gets decided for Democrats and Republicans, the moment when more than 20 states weigh in at once on the chaotic presidential campaigns. In the Democratic field, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama are each hoping to pile up a decisive number of delegates and end in one night what has been a protracted and increasingly unkind competition. If the Democratic voters defy the designs of the party, though, and neither candidate can achieve a clear verdict, the battle will then enter a rare and little-understood phase: the scramble for superdelegates. These are the roughly 800 Democratic Party insiders  elected officials, state chairmen, national committee members  who will make up about a fifth of the total delegate count at the convention and who can vote for any candidate they want, regardless of what the voters in primaries and caucuses have said. Superdelegates were invented by the Democrats after the 1980 election in the expectation that in any future close nomination race, they would line up behind the establishment candidate and head off the possibility of a ruinous floor fight at the convention.

headline: Memories of Dusty, Newport and ‘Odelay’
text: Shelby Lynne

headline: Log On. Tune Out.
text: One of the oldest and soundest rules in intellectual life is “never get in a parsing contest with a skunk.” It is a principle that the lively, intelligent, combative cultural critic Lee Siegel forgot in autumn 2006, when he gave in to the temptation to respond to comments about him posted on his blog at The New Republic’s Web site. Some of the comments were anonymous and abusive  featuring allegations of chromosomal deficiencies and pedophilia  and Siegel replied under the pseudonym “sprezzatura,” praising his own work and denouncing his critics (“You couldn’t tie Siegel’s shoelaces”). When it emerged that Siegel was sprezzatura, he was pilloried in the blogosphere, suspended by The New Republic and, “in good American fashion,” he writes, rewarded with the opportunity “to write the book on Web culture that I’d long wanted to write.”

headline: For Once, Gaffney Is Going Somewhere His Father Did Not
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Jabar Gaffney’s life has been about tracing his father’s footsteps, but last week he found himself in new territory. By making it to the Super Bowl with the New England Patriots, Gaffney, a sixth-year receiver, has gone one giant step further than his father, Derrick, did in eight seasons as a receiver with the Jets.

headline: Small and Sexy
text: WALKING along Adelphi Street in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, you could almost miss The Hideout, and not just because the former parking garage doesn’t have a sign. No Jimmy Choo-shilling boutiques or coolly antiseptic hotels indicate to scene-seekers that behind those black curtains and nondescript doors is a sexy little lounge offering $14 cocktails  not to mention bottle service.

headline: My Servant
text: Some years ago, I was looking for an apartment in Delhi. I had just moved to India, and everything about it was frenzied and raw. Every place I saw was either too pricey or noisy or prone to attack by flying cockroaches the size of small birds.

headline: Monk and Green Selected for N.F.L.’s Hall

headline: The Greenback Is Losing Global Appeal
text: THE dollar used to be the universal tourist currency, accepted almost anywhere, from the streets of Hanoi to the plains of Africa. But the continued slide of the dollar against other currencies has led the greenback to be shunned in unexpected places, creating new problems for American travelers and pushing prices higher.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A Calendar listing last Sunday misstated the location of a performance by the bass vocalist Kevin Maynor on Feb. 3 at Adelphi University in Garden City. It is at the Ruth S. Harley University Center Ballroom, not Blodgett Hall.

headline: Two Personalities: One for Game Day, One for Every Other Day
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Phnom Penh, Cambodia: Bliss
text: To thrive in the tropics you need cotton.

headline: 8-Year Clinton Veteran (and Yes, He’s Just 21)
text: DAVID HELFENBEIN said he would love to talk about the many years he has worked for Hillary Rodham Clinton. But his political instincts are finely honed, and he wouldn’t chat until he got permission from the campaign.

headline: There Will Be Blood
