headline: Lenders Who Sold and Left
text: THE Federal Bureau of Investigation said last week that it had opened criminal investigations into 14 companies that played a part in the mortgage boom and bust. While it did not identify the companies on its dance card, the F.B.I. said they included mortgage brokers, lenders, and the Wall Street banks that packaged and sold the securities. Investigators are looking for accounting fraud and possible insider trading at the companies, an F.B.I. spokesman said.

headline: Last Exit
text: Brooklyn isn’t Greenwich Village, but many writers  established and ascendant  are concentrated in a handful of low-rise neighborhoods there. In “Brooklyn Was Mine,” a collection of essays edited by Chris Knutsen and Valerie Steiker, some of the borough’s writers ruminate on arrival and domestic survival in this emerging haute bohemia. The jealous ownership implied by the word “mine” suggests that (à la Walt Whitman) to live in Brooklyn is both to claim possession of a milieu and to be possessed by it. The contributors make the place more sought after and, by a handy symbiosis, the place makes them cool.

headline: Letters: The Education of Ben Bernanke
text: Roger Lowenstein’s article (Jan. 20) was extremely informative about the evolution of Ben Bernanke’s philosophical and scientific approach to Fed policy. Lowenstein says that when Bernanke took over as Fed chairman, he “knew more about central banking than any economist alive.” A troubling contradiction arises, however, when Lowenstein asserts that, although Bernanke “knew the experience of the 1930s in his sleep, he was, in truth, unfamiliar with the exotic mortgage instruments that were failing now.”

headline: Lost Innocence, Now Appearing in the Economy
text: Economic events in January, it turns out, were enough to crack the composure of some usual glass-is-half-full types.

headline: Brothers in Arms Outdo the Mannings
text: The Manning brothers have nothing on the half brothers Hernández.

headline: No Body Left Untoned Preparing for Carnival
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  It was the last rehearsal of the Vila Isabel samba school at the famed Sambadrome, and Natalia Guimarães, Miss Brazil 2007, wondered if she was truly ready for Carnival.

headline: It’s No Easy Task to Fire a Super
text: TEACHERS have tenure. Justices of the United States Supreme Court have lifetime appointments.

headline: Letters
text: English and Only English?

headline: Making It Mellow and Keeping It Green
text: OAHU, Hawaii

headline: His City, Lost and Found
text: I RECENTLY went into Manhattan with a friend to visit her younger brother’s new apartment on 52nd Street and the East River. The brother, Ariel, had just graduated from college and had been hired by a prestigious financial firm in Midtown. His two roommates had followed the same path, and so, apparently, had everyone else who lived on their long, fluorescent-lit hallway on the 32nd floor.

headline: In Rome, Finding an Ideal Rental
text: ROME

headline: The F.D.A. in Crisis: It Needs More Money and Talent
text: The Food and Drug Administration is supposed to be Americans’ main line of defense against tainted food, drugs, medical devices and other products  in a world abounding with tainted goods. So it was especially chilling last week to hear the agency’s former chief counsel, Peter Barton Hutt, tell a Congressional panel that the F.D.A. was “barely hanging on by its fingertips.”

headline: Gun Battles in Chad’s Capital as Rebel Forces Storm In
text: DAKAR, Senegal  A rebel army swarmed the capital of Chad on Saturday, and gun battles erupted around the presidential palace, according to Chadian and Western officials, in an attack that raised the specter of deeper chaos in one the most war-scarred and fragile regions of the world.

headline: Correction: Number of Rooms Can’t Meet Surging Demand
text: An article on Jan. 20 about rising hotel rates around the world misstated the number of rooms in New York City in a comparison with those in India. The city has about 74,000 hotel rooms  not 100,000, which is the estimated total for India.

headline: Leaving Las Vegas
text: Charles Bock, the son of Las Vegas pawnbrokers, spent much of his childhood behind the counter of his parents’ shop, staring out at desperate adults as they hocked their most precious possessions in hopes of restoring their luck. “From the back of the store,” he recalls on his Web site, “I’d watch as the customers exploded and called my parents dirty Jews and cursed at them and threatened them at the top of their lungs. It’s impossible in situations like that not to feel for everybody involved  to be horrified, sure, but more than that, to be saddened by the spectacle, to want so much more than that out of life for everyone.”

headline: Beneath the Bay, a Mystery and Maybe Worse
text: A HALF-CENTURY ago, an ammunition barge broke loose from the U.S.S. Bennington, an aircraft carrier anchored a mile offshore in Gravesend Bay. The barge drifted over to Rockaway Point, but somewhere along the way it overturned, scattering 15,000 live antiaircraft shells, each as long as a man’s leg, onto the sea floor.

headline: Patriots and Giants Hope to Cap Their Quests With a Win
text: PHOENIX  The New England Patriots’ path to perfection, it turns out, began at their most imperfect moment.

headline: A Reporter Finds Drama in Iraqis’ Heartbreak
text: ONE of the more poignant moments in “Betrayed,” George Packer’s play about a group of Iraqi translators that opens Wednesday at the Culture Project in SoHo, is presented by Intisar, an idealistic young woman employed by the American Embassy in Baghdad.

headline: Solar and Relatively Affordable?
text: The “In the Region” article in Long Island and Manhattan copies last Sunday, about energy-efficient modular homes, misstated the height restrictions on trucks, which deliver the modules to building sites. While these limits vary according to state, none are lower than 13 feet 6 inches. The maximum is not 13 feet.

headline: 3 Cheers for the Home Team! (But, Uh, Which One Is It?)
text: Milford

headline: My Wired Youth
text: Last month, a PBS documentary called “Growing Up Online” revealed that kids today create false Internet identities, contend with cyberbullies and visit Web sites that promote anorexia. To my surprise, I felt defensive: the scare phrase “growing up online” recalled nothing so much as my own shady adolescence 25 years ago, when, because of a quirk of early communications technology, a small group of New Hampshire girls, including me, came of age on a primitive computer network  the Internet before the Internet.

headline: Home Is Where Harmony Is
text: DURING her apartment hunt, Catherine Brophy carried with her the essential tool of her trade  a loupan, the traditional feng shui compass.

headline: Presidential Race Dividing Some Top State Democrats
text: TRENTON

headline: Still a Warehouse Wonderland
text: WHEN Julia Warr, Martin Brierley and their three children moved to Brooklyn from London two and a half years ago, they settled in Cobble Hill, largely because of the local elementary school, Public School 29. So it was with some chagrin that they found out not long ago, on a visit to a friend’s place, that they were smitten with the friend’s neighborhood on the south side of Williamsburg.

In a breathtaking spree that lasted little more than a week, the Patriots signed linebacker Adalius Thomas, tight end Kyle Brady and running back Sammy Morris, and traded for receiver Wes Welker. Later, they added receiver Donte’ Stallworth and, on draft weekend, stunned the league by trading for Randy Moss, who took a pay cut because he wanted to join the Patriots. The team insisted that was not unusual.

headline: Bang the Drums Softly
text: MODELS do not as a rule make a lot of noise, being paid to suggest secret realms of sensuality without making a sound. As for making a joyful (or other) sound unto the heavens, well, isn’t that what all those rock-star husbands are for?

headline: Breadless Baking
text: When you pass through the Prussian-blue door of the Blue Bakery, the first aroma you’ll notice is likely to be coffee, not bread. That’s because the Blue Bakery brews plenty of joe, as well as half a dozen types of latte, but doesn’t bake any bread.

headline: The Civic Poet
text: Robert Pinsky has been writing outstanding poems for more than 30 years  “Gulf Music” is his seventh collection  but you’re more likely to know him for his poetry advocacy than for his own examples of the art. Given Pinsky’s public profile, this is more than understandable; he has served as a highly visible poet laureate of the United States for an unprecedented three terms, founded the acclaimed Favorite Poem Project (and edited or co-edited several resulting anthologies, including “Americans’ Favorite Poems” and “An Invitation to Poetry”), fashioned an eloquent translation of Dante’s “Inferno,” written a regular “Poet’s Choice” column for The Washington Post, moderated a “Meta-Free-Phor-All” on “The Colbert Report” and read one of his poems during a cameo appearance on “The Simpsons.” (No token haiku, either! A real live longish poem!) No other living American poet  no other living American, probably  has done so much to put poetry before the public eye.

headline: Playing It Safe in Las Vegas
text: LAS VEGAS

headline: Where the Twain Meet
text: Sunset Park is home to two distinct culinary districts. Eighth Avenue is known as the Chinatown of Brooklyn, while Fifth Avenue has a trove of Mexican restaurants. Whether you’re celebrating the Chinese New Year, which starts Thursday, or craving a taco, this neighborhood is worth exploring.

headline: Evangelicals a Liberal Can Love
text: At a New York or Los Angeles cocktail party, few would dare make a pejorative comment about Barack Obama’s race or Hillary Clinton’s sex. Yet it would be easy to get away with deriding Mike Huckabee’s religious faith.

headline: A Store Where Profit Comes Not in Dollars
text: AT a small high-end children’s clothing and toy store on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, shirts for infants go for as much as $40 and sweaters for toddlers to first graders cost $40 to $70. But many parents in the area are well off and accustomed to paying those prices, according to the store’s operator, Marjorie Stern.

headline: Will 6 Be a Lucky Number for Halston?
text: NEVER have so many people gone to a mountain. Tomorrow, at the Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea, Marco Zanini will present his first collection for Halston. Mr. Zanini, 35, is the sixth designer to put his name behind Halston, which has had at least eight owners in the 35 years since Roy Halston Frowick sold his own name to Norton Simon. That’s a lot of believers.

headline: Childhood, Interrupted
text: When poets or novelists write the story of their youth, the plot turns in a circle: they tell the story of the making of the mind of the writer who wrote the book. But this means that, while the writer’s memoir involves remembrance and return, it also involves development and departure. The story is about getting away from the past as well as going back to it.

headline: Correction: Hip-Hop’s Newest Faces: Indie, Fierce and Female
text: An article last Sunday about female rappers misidentified the member of the hip-hop duo Yo Majesty who married and then divorced a male Christian missionary. She is LaShunda Flowers  not Jewel Baynham, the other rapper.

headline: Letters: Kilimanjaro Memories
text: To the Editor: I was dismayed to learn from your article on Kilimanjaro, "On Africa’s Roof, Still Crowned With Snow" (Jan. 20), that a veritable ants-trail of tourists climb “my” mountain each year. When I climbed it in 1961, my group met only three other parties in five days, and our guide refused to take us beyond Leopard Point on the rim of the crater around to the actual summit, then still called Kaiser-Wilhelm-Spitze, because the snow was too deep and dangerous!

headline: Ex-Prosecutors Question Handling of Spying Case
text: PHOENIX  When the N.F.L. investigated spying charges against the New England Patriots, it asked for evidence gathered by the New England Patriots.

text: Antonia McGowan Phillips and Peter Bertram Hoagland Hommeyer were married on Saturday evening at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. Andrew C. Mead, the church’s rector, performed the ceremony.

headline: In Summer, Hitting the Books, Not Just the Beach
text: WHEN Jeremy Grant of Roslyn, N.Y., was 16, he decided not to return for another summer of sleep-away camp, opting instead for a precollege program at U.C.L.A. In the mornings he took courses in SAT prep and public speaking; in the afternoons he hopped on a van to the beach, a museum, or a TV game show.

headline: Lucy Demerjian, Joseph Flynn
text: Dr. Lucy Elizabeth Demerjian and Joseph Daniel Flynn were married on Saturday at St. Margaret of Antioch Church in Pearl River, N.Y. Msgr. John J. O’Keefe, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Correction: For Strikers, the Agony of Spare Time
text: An article and picture caption last week about the ways that striking writers are filling their time misidentified the location in California of a Bob’s Big Boy where an anonymous celebrity benefactor has offered to pick up the tab for any card-carrying writer. The restaurant is in Burbank, Calif., not Toluca Lake.
The season opener, a 38-14 victory over the Jets, made it clear that Robert K. Kraft need not have waited. Tom Brady completed 22 of 28 passes, 9 of them for 183 yards to Moss.

headline: Beaten Down, and Not Only by Nature
text: The “Living In” article last Sunday, about Far Rockaway, Queens, referred incorrectly to the affordability of Ocean Park Apartments. The complex is now part of the federal low-income housing tax credit program, so its apartments will stay affordable for 40 more years. It has not lost its affordable units.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 38 of The Times Magazine this weekend about voting patterns among women refers incorrectly to the questions in a Norman Lear Center/Zogby International poll used to help discern those patterns. Respondents were asked to indicate their degree of agreement with certain statements; the questions were not true-or-false or open-ended. (Go to Article)

headline: Offering New Roles to Wounded Marines
text: SAN DIEGO  Two marines enter the Iraqi village and take aim.

headline: Obama Seldom Asks His Pollster to Play the Role of an Oracle
text: AS a key pollster for Senator Barack Obama’s presidential campaign, Joel Benenson has a job that would typically make him one of the most sought-after voices in the candidate’s inner circle. But that status depends on who the candidate is.

headline: As Knicks Fall Again on Road, Robinson Loses in Hometown
text: SEATTLE  It took Nate Robinson two years to make it back to his hometown, to play in front of his friends and relatives and to strut through the arena the way he once did here in high school and college.

headline: Working to Resettle Iraqi Allies at Risk
text: Three groups trying to help Iraqi employees and contractors are Human Rights First (humanrightsfirst.org), which does legal work for Iraqi refugees; Refugees International (refugeesinternational.org), the main advocacy group on the issue; and the List Project (thelistproject.org), a nonprofit group that has collected the names of more than 1,000 Iraqis who worked for American agencies in Iraq and are now trying to move to the United States.

headline: Eureka! It Really Takes Years of Hard Work
text: WE’VE all heard the tales of the apple falling on Newton’s head and Archimedes leaping naked from his bath shrieking “Eureka!” Many of us have even heard that eBay was created by a guy who realized that he could help his fiancée sell Pez dispensers online.

headline: Here Come the Babies. There Go the Jackhammers.
text: JACOB GOLDSTEIN, the longtime chairman of Community Board 9 and the unofficial mayor of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was driving his little red Ford Contour through the neighborhood the other day, honking at acquaintances. Several times on every block, he braked and gestured at a newly risen, salmon-colored apartment building, or a plywood fence protecting a construction site.

headline: Correction: When Icons Die Young
text: An article last Sunday about the ways in which successive generations have mourned the deaths of young celebrities referred imprecisely to those saddened by the death of the actor James Dean in 1955. Those who mourned, in general, were young people whose generation had not been given a name; they were not baby boomers. (A generally accepted definition of the baby boom generation dates its start to 1946, meaning many baby boomers were not yet born at the time of his death or would have been too young to appreciate its significance.)

headline: The Party Animal Either Plays Well or Fights Well
text: SOMETIMES the simplest of arguments can reveal the deepest of divisions. Take the dispute between Senator Barack Obama and the Clintons over the legacy of Ronald Reagan. The episode began in Reno, Nev., you will recall, when Mr. Obama told an editorial board that Mr. Reagan was a president of ideas who had moved the country’s politics. His ideas weren’t necessarily good ideas, as Mr. Obama framed it, but they were transformative.

headline: Letters: A Breckenridge Problem
text: To the Editor: Your 36 Hours column on Breckenridge, Colo. (Jan. 20), reminded me of my stay there a few years ago.

headline: Dibs on a Junker
text: Dibs on a Junker

headline: A Fine Romance, My Friend, This Is
text: IT might be Kate Hudson, or maybe Mandy Moore, or possibly Rachel Weisz, Lindsay Lohan or a Jennifer. (Lopez? Aniston? Garner?) But if it’s February, you can be pretty sure that some pretty, plucky actress will be traipsing around some glamorous and photogenic American city (or its Canadian double) in search of the dimple-chinned fellow who embodies her one true love.

headline: Boomtown Builds Its Future on the Business of Sports
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Jeff Feagles, the punter for the Giants, grew up in the Phoenix area and remembers the suburb of Glendale as “out in the boonies,” a farming town northwest of the city that was “really, really far away” and filled with cotton fields.

headline: Perfect Would Not Mean Most Dominant
text: If the New England Patriots complete an unprecedented 19-0 sweep of the regular schedule and the Super Bowl XLII playoffs Sunday night, they will deserve to be hailed as the best one-season team in N.F.L. history. But as a dynasty, the House of Belichick will still trail the Vince Lombardi Packers of the ’60s and the Chuck Noll Steelers of the ’70s.

headline: Beyond the Point Spread: Super Bowl Science
text: FARMINGDALE

headline: Where Money Doesn’t Talk
text: ON the corner of Fulton Street and Bedford Avenue stands the red-brick building that houses Rent-a-Center, a national chain store that tempts low-income, credit-challenged customers with a range of slightly worn couch sets, scuffed refrigerators and consumer electronics, among which television sets were a prime attraction last week.

headline: For Jewish Voters in New York, ‘Almost an Embarrassment of Riches’
text: The notion that New York’s Jewish electorate can be easily characterized has long been debated. But the looming primary election on Tuesday is raising new speculation about how strongly Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will appeal to Jewish Democrats.

headline: Santana Deal Took Intense Negotiating
text: It was nearing 5 p.m. on Friday, when the Mets’ 72-hour window to sign the star left-hander Johan Santana was to expire, and they had improved what had been their take-it-or-leave-it proposal. But that was not good enough for Santana, and he said so  in person. At the Mets’ request, he had flown to New York from his home in Florida, and he was sitting in a room with his agent, Peter Greenberg, and the Mets’ senior executive vice president, Jeff Wilpon, when he rejected it.

headline: The Fixer
text: AS a child growing up in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Robert Holt Jr. thought that the mysterious gray machines rolled into his school for Election Day looked like coffins. Now, as one of 21 repairmen in the place where Brooklyn’s voting machines are fixed, he has developed a certain amount of affection for the hulking contraptions.

headline: Patriots Deny Another Accusation of Taping
text: PHOENIX  The N.F.L. investigated rumors last year that the New England Patriots had videotaped the final walk-through by the St. Louis Rams before the 2002 Super Bowl and found no evidence that the taping had occurred, the league said Saturday. The Patriots told the N.F.L. that the rumor was not true and on Saturday denied a report in The Boston Herald that quoted an unnamed source saying the taping had occurred.

headline: Delta Gets Help in Bolstering Its Wine List
text: Delta is getting serious about wine. The airline recently brought on board the wine educator and author Andrea Robinson, one of 15 women in the world who have been awarded a master sommelier diploma by the Court of Master Sommeliers, to reconfigure its wine list for its BusinessElite international service starting this month. Later this year, Ms. Robinson will also make wine selections for its international coach and domestic first and coach classes.

headline: Patricia Whitby and David Irwin
text: Patricia Dawn Whitby and David Horandt Irwin were married Saturday at their home in Deephaven, Minn. The Rev. Timothy Johnson, a Lutheran minister, officiated. On Feb. 14, a second ceremony is to be performed by the Rev. Charles Vere Nicoll at St. Bartholomew’s Anglican Church in Gustavia, St. Bart’s.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
Rock Around the Block
text: ROCK music’s past and its present live side by side in New York, though the line that splits the two is porous. When it closed in 2006, CBGB, on the Bowery — to many the birthplace of punk — seeped into the past. And when the ’80s rock group Duran Duran played the Hammerstein Ballroom last June, you might say they seeped back into the present, however briefly.

headline: Other People’s Money
text: Eight years ago, American liberalism split sharply in two over the Clinton economic record. The larger, more moderate faction deemed the departing administration to have done an exemplary job  or at least a credible effort with a weak political hand  shepherding economic growth and social justice. But a smaller, more populist faction recoiled at policies that sat comfortably with corporate America and allowed the very rich to pull farther away from the middle class. Ultimately, that populist critique became the basis of Ralph Nader’s 2000 presidential campaign, which polled in the mid- to high single digits before settling at a lower, but still decisive, 2.74 percent of the vote.

headline: To Pull a Thorn From the Side of the Planet
text: SANTA CRUZ, Calif.

headline: For Many Jets Fans, Super Sunday in Name Only
text: Not since Joe Namath made good on his guarantee to beat the Baltimore Colts in 1969 have the Jets been back to the Super Bowl. The players continually change, so the wait may be harder on longtime Jets fans who have endured two victories in three Super Bowl appearances by the rival Giants.

headline: Letters: Consumer Man
text: I could relate to Paul Mecurio’s Lives column (Jan. 13). I was “consumer woman” before my daughter changed my life.

headline: Perfection Is Afterthought, Perfect Examples Say
text: PHOENIX  The 18-0 New England Patriots take the field Sunday for Super Bowl XLII seeking perfection and a place in sports history. But those who have already tread the path to a flawless sports achievement say that finding perfection and fame will be the farthest thing from the Patriots’ minds.

headline: Candidates Scrambling in States About to Vote
text: MINNEAPOLIS  The presidential campaign played to new audiences on Saturday as the leading Democratic and Republican candidates fanned out across the nation, drawing distinctions with their rivals and making urgent appeals to voters in delegate-rich or politically symbolic states.

headline: In Praise of the Decisive C.E.O.
text: DURING this season of economic alarm and political choice, “Judgment” (Portfolio, $26.95), by Noel M. Tichy and Warren G. Bennis, could not be more timely. Americans live in a democracy, cherish checks and balances, and remain skeptical of concentrated power. But many also seem to hope for a savior-leader  whether in the form of a United States president, a Fed chairman or a corporate titan.

headline: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
text: FORGET the issues.

headline: A ‘Bold’ Step to Capture an Elusive Gas Falters
text: CAPTURING heat-trapping emissions from coal-fired power plants is on nearly every climate expert’s menu for a planet whose inhabitants all want a plugged-in lifestyle.

headline: Voting Will Reflect Republican Retirements
text: CHICAGO  Voters in Illinois on Tuesday will begin the process of filling three Republican seats in the House of Representatives that are up for grabs, just one state’s slice of a broader pattern of Republican retirements across the nation.

headline: Amo, Amas, Amuse
text: Not only does Latin train the mind; it also polishes the manners. So you might think from the tone of rueful apology that Harry Mount sometimes adopts in “Carpe Diem,” his chatty Latin primer: “The annoying thing is that there’s no real way round needing to know adjectives,” he writes, before hitting the reader with some “pretty relentless” tables of declensions. It’s hard to imagine anyone ambivalent about adjectives tackling a book on Latin, but if one does, he’ll be reassured.

headline: Correction:  No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate
text: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Jan. 20 about airport parking misstated the number of airports served by AirportParkingReservations.com, which allows travelers to reserve parking spots through the Web site. It is more than 65, not 200. (The service does offer reservations at more than 200 lots at those airports.)

headline: Candidates Feel the Lure of Celebrity Cash
text: They make their fortunes engineering the world’s biggest deals or making hearts swoon in movie houses and concert halls. But inside their storied prewar East Side town houses and palatial downtown lofts, members of the city’s power elite are grappling with the same question as the rest of the nation: Who should next occupy the White House?
The Patriots returned to form in the playoffs, routinely dispatching the Jaguars and the Chargers.

headline: Trim and Ready to Rumble
text: TESTED 2008 Lamborghini Gallardo Superleggera.

headline: Feisty Flyers Get Better and Meaner
text: Last season, the Philadelphia Flyers finished last in the N.H.L. with the worst record in their 40-year history. But this season, they have been first among the turnaround teams.

headline: Asian Horror Films: Who’s Inspiring Whom?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Passengers on Amtrak Are Stranded in Mountains
text: SAN FRANCISCO (AP)  Dozens of passengers were stranded on a train in the Sierra Nevada on Saturday after a large snowplow fell through the tracks and blocked the railroad, officials said.

headline: Yahoo Sale Could Be Bad for Minnows
text: SAN FRANCISCO  FOR decades, Silicon Valley has been the land of eternal optimism and high anxiety, traits that pitch into overdrive anytime a seismic business event washes across the corporate and entrepreneurial landscape here  like, for example, Microsoft’s blockbuster $45 billion bid for Yahoo on Friday.

headline: What Money Can Buy: Help With Achieving a Self-Sufficient Life
text: Every day, Neediest Cases articles offer glimpses into the lives of New York’s poor. Often, the subjects have recently survived a crisis  or are still in one  and their futures seem uncertain at best. Revisiting three cases from the 2005-6 campaign shows how timely assistance, and the continuing support of the seven agencies that are the beneficiaries of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, have turned lives around.

headline: Up Front
text: Like Susan Sontag, Katie Roiphe is no stranger to polemic. Her first book, “The Morning After: Sex, Fear, and Feminism on Campus,” a critique of the gender wars, was published in 1993, when she was in her early 20s. It drew both intense criticism and comparisons to Mary McCarthy. Roiphe  her mother is the novelist Anne Roiphe  most recently wrote “Uncommon Arrangements,” about literary marriages in early-20th-century London.

headline: All Eyes Are Focused on Beijing Olympics
text: This is only February, and six months remain before the Beijing Olympics, but many elite track and field athletes are already establishing their Olympic credentials or trying and not succeeding.

headline: A Track in the Snow
text: A couple of weeks ago, when the snow was at its deepest, I walked up the hill in the middle pasture after chores. By that time in the afternoon, I am often trudging through my thoughts, barely noticing anything around me. Part of the pleasure of chores is that they happen in the same light every day, though the hour changes as the days lengthen and contract. No matter what I’m doing, I am propelled outside by the falling light, which means that I’m often doing chores mid-paragraph. I imagine that the animals are mid-paragraph too, for we are all just going about our business together.

headline: Betting on Cuisine to Marginalize Crime
text: Usually, it is the harsh yellow of the crime scene tape that catches the eye, its cold, crisp snap in the wind a universally understood sign of recent unpleasantness.

headline: Great Literature? Depends Whodunit
text: IN a British court recently, an author said, in effect, that glue-sniffing had made her write a thriller. The author, Joan Brady, is a 68-year-old American who has lived in England for the last several decades and in 1993 became the first woman to win the Whitbread book prize. She received a £115,000 out-of-court settlement after arguing that fumes from the glue and solvents used in the Conker shoe factory next door to her home in Totnes had poisoned the air and made her sick. She suffered nerve damage, she said, and a loss of concentration that caused her to abandon the literary novel she was working on, “Cool Wind From the Future,” and instead crank out a potboiler called “Bleedout.”

headline: 1972 Dolphins: Undefeated on Field, Undeterred Off It
text: MIAMI  Dick Anderson made $38,000 as a Pro Bowl strong safety for the Dolphins in 1972, but that was only part of his income. He started an insurance agency five years earlier and would sometimes return calls to clients before or after practices.

headline: The Headlock That Won for the Giants
text: MOM crushed indoor horseplay. If my brother Rory and I started in, Mom yelled once. If we continued wrestling, she’d throw things. If we kept it up, she’d hurl us into the hallway outside our apartment in Yorkville and not let us back in till she felt like it. How much time we spent there depended on her mood and the neighbors’ complaints.

headline: My Birthday Wish: Not Burdening Our Children
text: IT’S official. As of today, at 6 a.m., I am a half-century old. Special thanks go to my mom for bringing me into the world back in 1958 and for looking after me all these years. But she doesn’t need to worry about me anymore. My welfare now falls within the mission statement of AARP.

headline: Franco’s Monuments: Healing War Wounds
text: To the Editor:

headline: J. B. Smoove: True to Character
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Foundation in the Classics
text: IN the contemporary landscape of architecture, someone like Richard Sammons doesn’t get lionized by the fledgling and impressionable (and constantly blogging) designerati. That might be because his firm, Fairfax & Sammons, which he owns with his wife, Anne Fairfax, specializes in traditional architecture.

headline: Sunnis Say Law Opening Jobs to Ex-Baathists Would Do More Harm Than Good
text: BAGHDAD  Top Sunni politicians say they are trying to stop final approval of legislation that they now believe would hurt Sunnis’ chances of holding government jobs, rather than helping them get more posts in the Shiite-led government.

headline: Yes, a Giant Can Sprint
text: FOR investors, the idea that a German industrial giant could also be a nimble stock market star might seem far-fetched, if not outright delusional. Indeed, the very concept of anything nimble and industrial might seem an oxymoron, whether Teutonic or American.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THIS REPUBLIC OF SUFFERING: Death and the American Civil War, by Drew Gilpin Faust. (Knopf, $27.95.) The lasting but little-understood impact of the war’s immense loss of life is the subject of this extraordinary account by Faust, who is president of Harvard.

headline: Soap Opera
text: Just as one “Ring Cycle” may be enough for some operagoers, one book recounting the Wagner family saga probably suffices for many readers. Certainly, by now, the most distasteful aspects of the story  the family’s association with German nationalism, anti-Semitism and, eventually, the Führer himself  are well known. Yet, with some archives still under lock and key, more dark secrets can be expected to emerge.

headline: A Statesman Without Borders
text: Bernard Kouchner, the foreign minister of France, has urged his country’s ambassadors to engage in ‘diplomacy in motion.’ Kouchner, who established the organization Médecins Sans Frontières 37 years ago; has had four or five careers since then; has often polled as the most popular politician in France; has written a dozen or so books; and once contemplated running for president of France, is himself the chief practitioner of this aerobic statecraft. So it was that at 6 a.m. on New Year’s Day, he and a few staff members gathered in the courtyard of the Quai d’Orsay, the headquarters of the foreign ministry, to drive to the airport for an overnight trip to Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan. The goal, Kouchner explained, was to “bear witness to the solidarity” of the French people with the family of the former prime minister Benazir Bhutto, murdered the week before, and with democratic forces in Pakistan.

headline: A Clearer Picture on Voter ID
text: THIS is a major election year. Unfortunately, our two major political parties  Democratic and Republican  continue to disagree on some of the rules that apply to the administration of our elections. This divide is perhaps most contentious when the issue becomes one of whether voters should present photo identification to vote.

headline: On the Trail of an Urban Nomad
text: THAT’S not the phone book that Keira Naughton has to recite at the beginning of “Hunting and Gathering,” but it’s pretty close.

headline: The Lemur
text: Chapter 4: Alison

headline: Who Pays the Most Taxes?
text: A TAX collector’s tour of Manhattan might rightfully begin in front of the neo-Georgian town house on East 63rd Street with stately stone pillars and a bowed brick front, a large flagpole protruding from a fourth-floor terrace. Once a private club and later a Catholic school, it is now the home of Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire who made his fortune buying up troubled companies.

headline: Waiting for It
text: For writers, few steps in the publishing process are as strange as the state of suspended animation between submitting a manuscript and seeing the book appear in stores. The sudden change in cabin pressure from writing to waiting can be jarring  and can last a very long time. “It comes as a huge shock when it happens the first time,” said the Irish writer Colm Toibin, whose first novel, “The South,” appeared in 1990, a year and a half after he turned it in. “It was all slow and strange.”

headline: Beyond the Point Spread: Super Bowl Science
text: “TELL me, why do they use Roman numerals to count the Super Bowls  like, Super Bowl X-L-I-I instead of just saying 42  why is that?” said John Sanford, 61, sitting Tuesday afternoon at the J Two Lounge, a bar in a strip mall in Farmingdale, N.Y.

headline: Running Through the Cholesterol Maze
text: To the Editor:

headline: Real Estate Investing, Made Easier Online
text: IT wasn’t long ago that finding commercial property, especially for the neophyte investor, meant traveling by car or plane to various sites  with measuring tools, notepads and camera in tow  then pounding the pavement to inspect comparable places, vet tenants or peruse town hall documents. Newspapers and trade publications were also routinely scoured.

headline: Clean Look
text: Tide

Philadelphia showed the Patriots unexpected defenses and provided a blueprint for beating them: pressure Tom Brady and run the ball. Although the Eagles lost, they were the first of two opponents to give the Patriots a scare.

headline: An Open and Shut Marriage
text: AT an upscale pub in our small Northwestern town, one of the mothers seated around our table made an indissoluble confession: she told us she had been having a very serious crush on a man who was not her husband. She said the crush bothered her. Besides making her feel guilty, it also made her unsure of the status of her marriage. As she spoke, red blotches formed around her neck.

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption last Sunday in the Evening Hours column misspelled the surname of a guest at the Quadrille Ball of the Germanistic Society of America on Jan. 19. She is Julia Yale, not Gale.

headline: A Budget Package for Seeing Iceland
text: If you’ve been wanting to see the fjords, waterfalls and hot springs of Iceland, but have been daunted by the cost  even more expensive than Britain  then check out a self-driven itinerary called Iceland on a Budget. The nine-day trip, which was put together by the travel company Iceland Experience (www.iceland-experience.com; click on Independent Tours), includes a rental car, lodging in guesthouses with shared baths and daily breakfasts.

headline: Sean Yseult and Chris Lee
text: IF there is one law of social physics in New Orleans, it is that after first meeting someone, you will cross paths again within weeks. It was this certainty that gave hope to the rock musicians Sean Yseult and Chris Lee.

headline: He Got His Workshop, She Got Her Privacy
text: WHEN Alan and Helene Ferris decided 16 years ago to move from their longtime home in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., they had some strict requirements.

headline: In Miami, the Beach Party Moves Indoors
text: THE art and cocktail bacchanal known as Art Basel Miami Beach was still three months away, but that didn’t stop a hundred artists and their hangers-on from cramming into a raw and unoccupied restaurant in Miami’s Design District last fall. Glasses of Red Bull and vodka flowed freely. A noise band, armed with electric guitars and homemade synthesizers, jammed so loudly that it seemed to disturb the entire neighborhood. A gang of fresh-faced artists in tight T-shirts and worn-out jeans suspended a six-foot-long digital timer from the ceiling that counted down the milliseconds left in the party.

headline: Rebecca Adamus and Kaustuv Basu
text: Rebecca Paige Adamus and Kaustuv Basu are to be married Sunday at the Crowne Plaza resort in Melbourne, Fla. The Rev. Francis X. Metzbower, a Roman Catholic priest, is to officiate at a nondenominational ceremony.

headline: A Tale of the Velvet Rope
text: IN early February every winter, Bryant Park becomes a tangle of pulsing white tents and the buzzing apparatus that provides them with heat and light so that the glories of Fashion Week, which this year began on Friday, can go on display.

headline: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
text: FORGET the issues.

headline: Detox for the Camera. Doctor’s Order!
text: ON the first episode of the VH1 reality series “Celebrity Rehab With Dr. Drew,” Jeff Conaway arrives for in-patient treatment at the Pasadena Recovery Center in California slumped over in the passenger seat of a car, caressing an open bottle of Dom Pérignon. The actor, who starred in the television show “Taxi” and the movie “Grease,” describes himself as “loaded,” for which he blames people who, the night before, accused him of being an addict.

headline: Trying to Clear Fog From Pension Plans
text: NEW pension rules being phased in this year may make some employees curious about the financial health of their pension plans  but it’s still hard to get enough information to make an intelligent judgment.

headline: True Believers Rally Campaign Troops
text: MOST likely, you’ve never heard of them.

headline: Preconceptions Defied
text: NO one in my family had gone to college. My mom finished high school. My father was a pipe fitter who completed 10th grade. He injured his back and shoulders on the job and retired on disability. They had saved a small amount for my college education. I thought I would go to a state university or junior college to stretch out the money.

headline: Coaches Will Have Extra Time on Their Hands
text: PHOENIX  At halftime of a regular-season game, teams have 12 minutes to get to the locker room, use the restroom, get a drink or a bite to eat, get an injury checked, make game-plan adjustments, collect thoughts, hear a quick motivational speech and run back to the field.

headline: Under Wintry Skies, a City Revealed
text: CALL it the travel equivalent of contrarian investing: Prague, a famously beautiful city in spring, summer and fall, can yield big dividends for travelers in the winter off-season. Teeming crowds? Gone. Prices? Much lower. Overbooked hotels? Not for now. Picturesque spires and cobblestone lanes? With a gentle dusting of snow, perhaps even more so.

headline: A Water Park With a View
text: Last Friday, a water park with 362,080 gallons’ worth of rapids, waves and pools had its official opening on the grounds of El Conquistador Resort and Golden Door Spa in Puerto Rico (www.elconresort.com).

headline: Long Island’s Political Leaders Regroup as Landscape Shifts
text: UNTIL last Wednesday, Long Island’s political leaders had declared this to be Hillary and Rudy country. But with Rudolph W. Giuliani’s departure from the campaign last week and now a one-on-one contest between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama, the political landscape is shifting as voters head to the polls on Tuesday.

headline: Google Assails Microsoft’s Bid for Yahoo
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Google said Sunday that Microsoft’s proposed $44.6 billion takeover of Yahoo could pose a number of potential threats to competition that need to be examined by policymakers around the world.

headline: Argentina Rises, Minus Its Swagger
text: RIO DE JANEIRO

headline: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
text: FAIRFIELD

headline: The Magic of the Alimar, Airlifting Paris to New York
text: Q I am intrigued with the apartment building on the northwest corner of 105th Street and West End Avenue. It looks as if it should be in Paris. Any enlightenment would be appreciated. ... Robert Trenta, Manhattan

headline: Kill the Cats, but Keep the Career
text: FOR sketch comedy fans the ’90s were nothing short of a renaissance, thanks in no small part to the pioneering efforts of Michael Showalter. While troupes like Kids in the Hall, from Toronto, and Upright Citizens Brigade, from Chicago, hit pay dirt with their own acclaimed television shows, amassing legions of fans along the way, “The State” on MTV, adapted from the New York University improv group of the same name, was probably the period’s most groundbreaking.

headline: A Frail Economy Raises Pressure on Iran’s Rulers
text: TEHRAN  In one of the coldest winters Iranians have experienced in recent memory, the government is failing to provide natural gas to tens of thousands of people across the country, leaving some for days or even weeks with no heat at all. Here in the capital, rolling blackouts every night for a month have left people without electricity, and heat, for hours at a time.

headline: How Are the Bees of Winter? Doing Fine, Sticking Together
text: An article last Sunday about bees in winter misstated the position held by Howland Blackiston. He is a former president of the Back Yard Beekeepers Association and a member of its advisory board. (David Blocher of Redding is the group’s current president.)

headline: In the Ruins of Ice Dams, Splendor
text: IT is at the edges of a house that damage often creeps in  the rotted sills, the cracked stone steps, the crumbled bricks of the chimney. In winter, though, you are most likely to find it at the edge of the roof. That was where we found it last winter, coming in as ruin so often does, quietly, without announcing itself, escaping our notice until the wreckage was nearly complete. In this case, we noticed not a torrent of water but streaks on the wall, the more subtle stains and drips that proved once again that Abstract Expressionism is winter’s given art form.

headline: The Changing Room
text: THE FIRST TIME I walked into an N.F.L. locker room  the locker room of the New York Giants, as it happens  I was shocked by how little effort went into making me feel as if I didn’t belong. I’d grown used to baseball locker rooms, where the players’ edginess made outsiders feel instantly unwelcome and rendered useful human interaction all but impossible. In their private sanctums, baseball players behave as if someone might walk in at any moment and ask them to leave; they’re a bit like starving dogs who have just stumbled upon a slab of raw meat. Not all of them, of course  the effect is atmospheric, produced by the sum of the personalities. Give 25 professional baseball players a place to call their own and they give it a forbidding name: clubhouse. If you aren’t a member, you don’t belong.

headline: Robin Rosenthal and Richard Rothfeld
text: Robin Marci Rosenthal, the daughter of Sandra Rosenthal and the stepdaughter of Charles Rosenthal of Woodbury, N.Y., was married in the Bahamas on Saturday to Richard Z. Rothfeld, the son of Harriet Rothfeld and Eric A. Rothfeld of New York. Melvin Grant, a justice of the peace and marriage officer for the Bahamas, officiated at the One & Only Ocean Club on Paradise Island, at a ceremony led by Rabbi Yaakov Nerenberg.

headline: A Head Start on Head Start
text: BRENTWOOD, N.Y.

headline: A Lengthy Journey, Nowhere Near Over
text: THOUGH the chemistry of any happy relationship is hard to define, there are tangible elements behind the success of the diminutive Chinese conductor Xian Zhang at the New York Philharmonic and elsewhere. Her incisive gestures elicit vivid performances from musicians who have seen it all, and her passionate musicality reflects the boundless energy that has propelled her improbable journey from a small town in China to the Philharmonic, where, as associate conductor, she is a rising star.

headline: Seller Beware
text: Seller Beware

headline: A Wild Ramble, Near the Golden Gate
text: MARIN COUNTY, just north of San Francisco, cradles wealthy bedroom communities in picturesque bays. But nearly half of the county’s 520 square miles is protected open space — bucolic and wild, its tiny towns separated by forested mountains.

headline: A Miracle Indeed
text: If William Gibson’s 1959 play “The Miracle Worker” were a made-for-television after-school special, it would probably end with a postscript, suitably accompanied by swelling strings, informing viewers just why Helen Keller became such a household name during the first half of the 20th century.

headline: Belmondo, Bond and Now Kerviel
text: France has always had a soft spot for the lawbreaker, from Jean Valjean in “Les Misérables” to Jean-Paul Belmondo in “Breathless.” Now Jérôme Kerviel, the trader who cost Société Générale more than $7 billion, has attracted a fan club of his own.

headline: Radio Days
text: COLER-GOLDWATER, a public long-term care hospital on Roosevelt Island, is a world unto itself. There are chapels for the faithful, a Subway fast-food restaurant, smoking lounges and a small gift store that sells items like soda, chips and stuffed animals.

headline: Home Prices Start to Dip, Recalling ’90s Slump
text: For homeowners in the metropolitan area, all of the talk in the past year about a real estate collapse may have sounded as foreign as a Bollywood musical.

headline: For Ruby Dee at 83, Acclaim and Performances
text: A MONTH of awards ceremonies began triumphantly last Sunday for Ruby Dee, who won the Screen Actors Guild’s Award for best supporting actress for her role in the Denzel Washington film “American Gangster.”

headline: Chug-a-Lug Contest: A High Profile Comes at a High Price
text: Long Beach, Calif.

headline: Where Soldiers Slept, a Cultural Enclave Rises
text: BY 9 p.m. — early according to the neighborhood’s standards — a lively crowd had already gathered in the courtyard of Metelkova City, a compound of former military barracks in the heart of Ljubljana, the capital of Slovenia. Variously attired as neo-Goths and punk rockers, many in the crowd were nursing cigarettes and drinks as they stood amid the sculptures and murals, waiting for the evening’s activities to begin.

headline: In Football and Politics, Connecticut Is Betwixt and Between
text: WOODBURY, Conn.

headline: Coming to America
text: It is hard to imagine where American culture would be today without the contributions of Hitler and Stalin  that is, without the thousands of creatively gifted refugees who fled these murderers. A good many cultural historians and writers have explored this meaty subject from different angles since Anthony Heilbut’s 1983 landmark, “Exiled in Paradise” (still the best book on the topic). And now, in “Artists in Exile,” Joseph Horowitz has taken a crack at it.

headline: An Older Woman Bursts Into a Bedroom ...
text: Elizabeth Ashley can do almost no wrong. Michael Wilson, Hartford Stage’s artistic director, has directed her before, and things have gone well. So I am going to have to blame the material for the disappointment that is their latest collaboration. That is “Zerline’s Tale,” the stolid one-act drama in which Ms. Ashley is currently starring.

headline: The House That Whimsy Built
text: AT Seventh Avenue and Second Street, on a prime corner in the heart of Park Slope, stands an abandoned brownstone whose state of disrepair has been a source of local speculation for years.

headline: As Primary Nears, Voters Critique Field
text: NEVER mind that the race for the presidential nomination in both parties was still as rich and compelling  not to mention wide open  as it has been in memory. Never mind that the field of candidates was deep and diverse and that voters interviewed here in Union County would be called upon to cast their lot for one of them earlier in the race than ever before.

headline: Nuclear Leaks and Response Tested Obama in Senate
text: When residents in Illinois voiced outrage two years ago upon learning that the Exelon Corporation had not disclosed radioactive leaks at one of its nuclear plants, the state’s freshman senator, Barack Obama, took up their cause.

The first half of the season seemed part showcase for the Patriots’ new offensive threats and part puzzle: why would this team bother to cheat? The Patriots pulverized their opponents, winning games by pinball margins: 38-7, 34-13, 48-27  against the Cowboys, the best the National Football Conference had to offer then  52-7, 56-10. Only the Colts, their most talented opponent, gave the Patriots a game before falling, 24-20.

headline: Hamas and Egypt to Work on Sealing Gaza Border
text: JERUSALEM  Hamas said Saturday that it would cooperate with Egypt to close the breached border between Egypt and the Gaza Strip on Sunday.

headline: New Jersey Guidelines Allow Unaffiliated Voters to Participate in Primaries
text: Even though the majority of New Jersey’s registered voters are not affiliated with any political party, state election guidelines allow them to participate in the presidential primaries on Tuesday.

headline: A Tenant Wants a Lease for More Than One Year
text: Q I have had a rent-stabilized lease since 1989. It is now up for renewal, and the landlord is offering to extend it for only a year. I would prefer to have a two-year or even a three-year lease. Isn’t the landlord required to offer a multiyear lease?

headline: Congresswoman Collapses at a Clinton Rally
text: United States Representative Nita M. Lowey, Democrat of Westchester, collapsed on Saturday afternoon during a campaign rally for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in White Plains. Ms. Lowey, who was conscious and joked that she had gotten “too excited,” was taken away on a stretcher to a hospital.

headline: Placing Family First Hasn’t Held Children’s Author Back
text: TRUMBULL

headline: The F.D.A. in Crisis: Another Danger Made in China
text: The F.D.A.  and American consumers  got another warning last week about the need for vigilant monitoring of imported drugs from the developing world, especially from China. The contamination of a drug used to treat Chinese leukemia patients should also raise alarms at multinational pharmaceutical companies that plan to outsource manufacturing to China.

headline: Number of Homes Using Wood-Fired Boilers and Wood Stoves Rises
text: FOR three decades, Robin Norton of Bethany, Conn., heated her 2,000-square-foot home the way many people do: by burning oil. In 2004, though, fed up with the $1,200 annual bill, Ms. Norton, an emergency medical technician, switched to a wood-fired boiler.

headline: A Strong Week for Stocks After Fed Cuts
text: Buoyed by another Federal Reserve interest-rate cut and by Microsoft’s $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo, the broad stock market rose last week and the Nasdaq composite index had a weekly gain for the first time in 2008.

headline: This Year, Full Dance Cards for Local Politicians
text: EVERY four years, Connecticut residents swallow their pride and acknowledge a political truism: in the presidential primary season, their state plays a wallflower. While the suitors flirt with the popular kids from Iowa and New Hampshire, those from the Nutmeg State must content themselves with an occasional nod, a few sporadic phone calls, maybe a fund-raiser or two.

headline: A 17-Year-Old’s Breakthrough Victory
text: We may be ready for a changing of the guard.

headline: The Many Benefits of a Children’s Museum
text: To the Editor:

headline: Still Trying to Bring Their Fallen Heroes Home
text: The military telegram arrived in Peekskill, N.Y., on a springlike day in February 1945. The parents put it down unopened, falling to their knees to pray. Three of their five sons were pilots fighting overseas, and they were afraid to learn which of their boys was dead.

headline: From Irrelevance to Influence
text: With the wash comes the election.

headline: Thrust Into Leading Role, Crawford Is Showing Strain
text: SEATTLE  On his best nights, Jamal Crawford is the one who takes the biggest shots, makes deficits disappear and makes the Knicks (if ever so briefly) believe anything is possible. Pressure hardly affects him, and neither do the occasional shooting jags.

headline: My Bloody Valentine
text: The premise of Eli Gottlieb’s second novel, “Now You See Him,” is irresistible to anyone even slightly acquainted with the frustrations of writer’s block. A celebrated short story writer “up against the limitations of his gift,” becomes slowly unhinged, gets a gun and shoots his ex-girlfriend (also a writer, now quite successful) “between her green eyes.” He then kills himself, leaving behind a “fatal valentine” of literary ravings.

headline: Special Delivery for Golfers on the Go
text: Attention golfers: now there’s a new alternative to lugging your clubs through the airport: www.golfclubsaway.com is a new online rental service that delivers top brand clubs, like Callaway and Nike, directly to your hotel. The company charges $35 or $45 a day, depending on the brand, to deliver a bag of clubs, which includes a sleeve of golf balls and golf tees. Renters may also pay a fee of $10 to customize their bag by mixing and matching clubs.

headline: Copenhagen: Danhostel Copenhagen City
text: THE BASICS

headline: A New Year of Apricots
text: Pacific Rim sweet riesling is a fine match for Szechuan cuisine on the Chinese New Year, which starts Thursday.

headline: Erin Conroy, Thomas Welling Jr.
text: Erin Elizabeth Conroy, a daughter of Mary Conroy and James Conroy of Newtown, Pa., was married on Saturday to Thomas John Welling Jr., a son of Helen Welling and Mr. Welling Sr. of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Carleton P. Jones, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

headline: Letters: Art in the Age of Franchising
text: Virginia Heffernan’s column (The Medium, Jan. 20) suggests that the critically acclaimed “Friday Night Lights” receives poor ratings because the series doesn’t lend itself to franchising, but she’s confusing cause and effect. Great ratings lead to spinoff properties, they don’t follow them; if the show were a hit, NBC would certainly look for ways to capitalize on that.

headline: A Farce of Many Parts (and Darting Otello Look-Alikes)
text: Jim Poulos and Catia Ojeda make such a cute young couple in Ken Ludwig’s farce “Lend Me a Tenor” that you really want things to work out for them. As the mild-mannered Max, an unappreciated opera underling, and the super-pretty Maggie, his reluctant girlfriend (she thinks she loves him, but she doesn’t hear bells), they give real heart to the John W. Engeman Theater production, which is itself as cute as a button.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Can’t Stop Looking Over His Shoulder
text: WHEN Martin J. Sullivan, now 53, took over the world’s largest insurer, the American International Group, three years ago, the company was the target of multiple criminal and civil investigations and its books were in such disarray that its auditors refused to endorse them. During Mr. Sullivan’s first 18 months on the job, A.I.G.’s bottom line was successively pounded by three huge hurricanes and a South Asian earthquake. Then came an equally costly disaster, though one of human origin: the subprime credit market meltdown.

headline: 36 Hours in Cairo
text: CAIRO is third world and first world, Islamic world and pharaonic world, a teeming city that jars all the senses, all at once. There are thousands of years of history in this city of 18 million people, and that history can be seen in the people themselves: the modern-day ful seller peddling his stewed beans from a decorated cart, the felucca captain guiding his sailboat through the murky Nile, the young man riding a bicycle through traffic with a ladder-sized tray of bread balanced on his head. Come prepared: a scarf for women to enter mosques; packets of tissues for bathroom stops; small bills for tips; and if you like to drink, a bottle or two of wine from the duty-free airport shop. Cairo has a lot to offer, but a good bottle of wine is not included.

headline: Pentagon Seeks Record Level in 2009 Budget
text: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the public focus on more than $600 billion already approved in supplemental budgets to pay for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and for counterterrorism operations, the Bush administration has with little notice reached a landmark in military spending.

headline: From the World of Brew Pubs, Earthly Beers With Heavenly Tastes
text: FARMINGDALE

headline: Events in Westchester County
text: Film

headline: In-Verse Thinking
text: As the poet laureate of the United States, what are you doing to increase the public’s interest in poetry at a time when cultural alarmists insist that reading is on its way out? Poetry doesn’t need much promotion. It is doing quite well in this country. I gave a reading the other night in Concord, N.H., with two former poet laureates  Donald Hall and Maxine Kumin and 740 people came. That’s a lot of people!

headline: The Bishop’s Report
text: Can a novel that features cannibalism, amputations, burning at the stake and the devouring of children by wolves be a comedy? Tackling the gruesome and the grotesque with gleeful abandon, “The Voyage of the Short Serpent” is an eccentric, slightly maddened and often brutally funny tale of a colony of Roman Catholics marooned in medieval Greenland by the encroachment of a new ice age. Much has been made in France of the fact that its author, Bernard du Boucheron, was 76 years old when “Voyage,” his first novel, was published, and there’s something oddly triumphal about the way the narrative takes direct aim at death  which, despite its omnipresence (the bodies pile up rapidly) is never entirely conceded to.

headline: Giving the People What They Want
text: An article on Jan. 20 about Jack W. Batman, executive producer of the White Plains Performing Arts Center, referred incorrectly to the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck and the Westchester Broadway Theater in Elmsford. They are not the only other professional theaters in Westchester. (Others include the Hudson Stage Company in Briarcliff Manor, the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls, Blueberry Pond Theater Ensemble in Ossining, Axial Theater in Yorktown Heights and the Mighty Theater in Peekskill.)

headline: Correction
text: A review on Jan. 13 about “They Knew They Were Right: The Rise of the Neocons” repeated the book’s erroneous date for a view about World War II once expressed by Irving Kristol, who later became a founder of neoconservatism. It was in 1943, when Kristol was 23, that he published an article referring to a “near hysterical insistence upon the pressing military danger” posed by the Axis powers; it was not “as late as 1944,” when he was 24.

headline: Listening to the Jobs Report
text: The most pressing data in the latest jobs report is this: The number of people who were unemployed for six months or more as of January was 1.38 million.

headline: Toughest Moves in Dance: The Last Ones
text: THE British choreographer Antony Tudor once asked Martha Graham if she wanted to be remembered as a dancer or as a choreographer. When Graham chose dancer, he responded, “I pity you.”

headline: C’mon. Would You Cross This Director?
text: WHEN a recording at the Laura Pels Theater recently had Kathleen Turner asking audience members to turn off their cellphones, her mix of sex, gravel and good breeding actually made people turn off their phones. Ms. Turner is making her New York directing debut with a revival of Beth Henley’s Pulitzer Prize-winning play, “Crimes of the Heart.” The Off Broadway production, which opens on Feb. 14, ran last year at the Williamstown Theater Festival, with Ms. Turner directing and with much the same cast.

text: SALT LAKE CITY  Most of the time, this city succeeds in projecting the secular, cosmopolitan image that its leaders and residents have polished over the years: the ski capital, the economic engine, the desert metropolis of wide streets and mountain vistas.

headline: Correction: Built for the Earth and the Pocketbook
text: A Square Feet article last Sunday about energy-efficient modular homes misstated the height restrictions on trucks, which deliver the modules to building sites. While these limits vary according to state, none are lower than 13 feet 6 inches. The maximum is not 13 feet.

headline: Giants Hope a Moral Victory Can Lead to a Real One
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The term moral victory is not exclusive to sports. It has been used to describe everything from Al Gore’s disputed defeat in the presidential election of 2000 to the battle at the Alamo in 1836.

headline: Must a Landlord’s Fee Apply to All Tenants?
text: Q My wife and I live in a rental building. In the summer, we are charged an extra fee for each air-conditioning unit. We recently discovered that this fee was introduced a few years ago and that tenants who had lived here before then are not charged. Is it legal for the landlord to charge some tenants but not others?

headline: Elsewhere’s Children
text: As someone whose subway rides tend to resemble scenes from an “Evil Dead” movie, in which I am Bruce Campbell dodging zombies who have had all traces of their humanity sucked out of them by a sinister book  not the “Necronomicon,” but “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows”  I sometimes wonder how any self-respecting author of speculative fiction can find fulfillment in writing novels for young readers. I suppose J. K. Rowling could give me 1.12 billion reasons in favor of it: get your formula just right and you can enjoy worldwide sales, film and television options, vibrating-toy-broom licensing fees, Chinese-language bootlegs of your work, a kind of limited immortality (L. Frank Baum who?) and  finally  genuine grown-up readers. But where’s the artistic satisfaction? Where’s the dignity?

Wall Street is worried that the economy is headed for its first recession in six years, so it’s only natural that investors are a little spooked.

headline: The Tax Bills of New York’s Rich
text: A TAX collector’s tour of Manhattan might rightfully begin in front of the neo-Georgian town house on East 63rd Street with stately stone pillars and a bowed brick front, a large flagpole protruding from a fourth-floor terrace. Once a private club and later a Catholic school, it is now the home of Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire who made his fortune buying up troubled companies.

headline: Azinger Aims for a Ryder Cup Victory
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Clad in a black leather jacket over a collarless shirt, oozing a relaxed casual chic, the United States Ryder Cup captain Paul Azinger again shook up the status quo for September’s Ryder Cup by sending a clear message to the European team earlier this week.

headline: Much About History
text: I’m a history professor  my period is 1500-1800  with an M.A. student who wants to pursue a doctorate. While she is smart and capable, she is very religious, subscribing to the “young earth” theory that the world is only 6,000 years old. I am to work with her for a year and then recommend her to Ph.D. programs. Must I do so if I find her views incongruent with those of historians?  NAME WITHHELD, CALIFORNIA

headline: Hairdressers and Clients, and the Roles They Play
text: It would be all too easy to simply dismiss “And Her Hair Went With Her,” Zina Camblin’s new play at the New Jersey Repertory Company, as the flawed, if mildly diverting, trifle that it ultimately proves to be. Doing so, however, would mean failing to recognize the extraordinary promise of Ms. Camblin, who clearly embodies what Nina Simone and Weldon Irvine were celebrating when they wrote the song “To Be Young, Gifted and Black” nearly 40 years ago.

headline: High Cost of Superfund

headline: Nonfiction Chronicle
text: A VIEW OF THE OCEAN, by Jan de Hartog. (Pantheon, $17.95.) In this slim memoir, Hartog, a noted novelist and playwright who died in 2002, sketches his mother: she’s the girl beneath the flowering cherry, the piously forbearing housewife and the white-haired “mischievous saint,” attested doer of good works in Japanese prison camp and Dutch retirement home alike. But at its heart, “A View of the Ocean” is an unsparing account of her death. De Hartog was a sort of northern European Hemingway: a best-selling novelist and legitimate hero of the Dutch resistance before he turned 30. But for all his physical and moral courage, he couldn’t bear nursing his mother in the last weeks of her life. He breaks down in the attempt  and the simple rhythm of his prose turns to a howl. In particular, he’s undone by the stench of her cancerous breath: “It defeated everything in me that wanted to help, to love, to succor.” This is painful to read, but that pain is necessary to understand why de Hartog  though a lifelong skeptic  turns to prayer, and to believe in the religious revelation that follows. The ending suggests he will convert to Quakerism. In fact, he did, adamantly, and went on to write several well-regarded novels about that faith.

headline: Designing Woman
text: It can be hard, 25 years after it was first published, to appreciate the impact of the psychologist Carol Gilligan’s book “In a Different Voice.” Its argument that women and men make moral decisions differently  women emphasize relationships, while men focus on justice  now sounds familiar, even if its implications are still controversial. Although some scholars criticized (and continue to criticize) its findings, politicians, parents and teachers began to re-evaluate how they treated young boys and girls. Gilligan was named to the first professorship in gender studies at Harvard. Jane Fonda credits the book with changing her life. Many other women would agree.

headline: Events on Long Island
text: FILM

headline: Letters: Airport Parking
text: To the Editor: I read, with interest, your Practical Traveler column "No Room at the Lot and Late at the Gate" (Jan. 20), about the lack of parking at airports around the nation. One suggestion: Airports should consider offering valet parking at airports. This would be a help to those who miscalculate and are in a rush to park their cars but can’t find spots, and to travelers who are not taking advantage of other long-term parking options. Valet parking could ease anxiety among travelers and generate some additional revenue for airport operations.

headline: Letters: A Cutting Tradition
text: The seven images that accompany Sara Corbett’s article (Jan. 20) depict a culturally sanctioned practice in Indonesia of female genital mutilation. Aside from the single photo of the child in severe pain, the pictures show female attendants preparing to deform young girls in an environment of care and concern, mothers trying to soothe their fearful daughters and, finally, the face of a serene-looking child, who has apparently recovered from her acute pain and is accepting of her mutilation.

headline: Mourning the Medicine Man
text: LOWEN’S PHARMACY, at the corner of Bay Ridge Avenue and Third Avenue in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, since 1953, was open for business last week, with a Valentine’s Day display in the window next to an old newspaper article, blown up to poster size, hailing the store as a “beacon of service.” With the text was a picture of John Rossi, the store’s gray-haired owner, wearing glasses and a serious look, and filling a prescription.

headline: Ruling Allows Legal Status for Partners of Same Sex
text: PORTLAND, Ore. (AP)  A state law allowing same-sex couples to register as domestic partners took effect Friday after a federal judge ruled the state’s process of disqualifying petition signatures was consistent enough to be valid.

headline: The Archaeology of Hunger
text: In late November 2006, a San Francisco couple with two young children made a wrong turn and found themselves snowbound in their car in the Oregon wilderness, where they stayed for more than a week. The parents lived on berries, the babies on breast milk. (The father, James Kim, died of hypothermia while trying to get help.) A year later, Frederick Dominguez, of Paradise, Calif., and his three adolescent children went into the woods looking for a Christmas tree and lost track of their car; they slept in a culvert and made a “HELP” sign from sticks. After three days, they were rescued, more or less unharmed. These grim situations attracted relentless media attention: family plus snow plus stranded equals human-interest story nonpareil.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE VIEW FROM CASTLE ROCK: Stories, by Alice Munro. (Vintage International, $14.95.) Munro (right) based her 12th collection of stories on family records extending back to their origin in the Scottish lowlands. “They were not memoirs but they were closer to my own life than the other stories I had written,” she explains in a foreword. “You could say that such stories pay more attention to the truth of a life than fiction usually does. But not enough to swear on.” In the book’s second half, Munro moves toward the present and her typical themes: class, domesticity, sexual desire and the tensions between ambition and loyalty, duty and dreaming. Our reviewer, A. O. Scott, said Munro is incapable of writing a sentence that is “sloppy, dishonest, unnecessary or dull.” Another story collection  his first  comes from Colm Toibin, the author of five novels, including “The Master.” All nine of the tales in MOTHERS AND SONS: Stories (Scribner, $14) contain a mother and son, but rarely are they together. Instead, Toibin is interested in people in hiding from themselves and their feelings, and in the relationship between the watcher and the watched. Writing in the Book Review, Pico Iyer found that “Toibin’s craft is immaculate,” and that the stories are “beautiful and echoing,” but warned that despite its title, “this is not ... a collection to share with your loved ones on the second Sunday in May.”

headline: Ask Not What J.F.K. Can Do for Obama
text: BEFORE John F. Kennedy was a president, a legend, a myth and a poltergeist stalking America’s 2008 campaign, he was an upstart contender seen as a risky bet for the Democratic nomination in 1960.

headline: Without Metaphor
text: One can’t say Susan Sontag died a particularly private death. She once declared she wouldn’t tell her readers “what it is really like to emigrate to the kingdom of the ill and live there,” but it seems other people were determined to do it for her. The latest glimpse we have of her sickbed is “Swimming in a Sea of Death,” David Rieff’s intelligent, disordered account of his mother’s final illness.

headline: Mellow and Groovy and Fighting Crime
text: YOUTHFUL-LOOKING, telegenic cops head undercover, infiltrating schools and their peers’ hangouts to bust the bad guys. Mention that plot, and the first response will be “21 Jump Street,” the ’80s drama that gave the world Johnny Depp. But the founding father of that premise was “The Mod Squad,” the ABC series from the late ’60s and early ’70s in which three young counterculture delinquents sought to redeem themselves by joining the police force.

headline: Hello, Neighbor
text: Anyone who caught Hugo Chávez’s act at the United Nations in September 2006  in which Chávez, the president of Venezuela, compared George W. Bush to Satan  might infer that relations between Latin America and the United States have gone to hell. But Chávez’s extreme theatrics mask the real problem. Our mostly Spanish-speaking neighbors have reason to suspect that except for occasional military and economic interventions, American leaders don’t pay them much mind, let alone give them the respect they’ve earned.

headline: Morality Studies
text: Imagine that you are standing next to a railway track and you see a runaway trolley, with nobody on board, heading toward a group of five people down the track. The only way to save these people is to throw a switch that will divert the train to another track. This will save the five, but unfortunately will kill another person standing on the second track. Now imagine the same runaway trolley and the same five people, but this time you are standing on a bridge above the track, next to a very large stranger. The only way to stop the trolley is to shove the man off the bridge and into the trolley’s path, killing him but saving the five. (It won’t help to jump yourself; you’re too small to stop the trolley.) What is interesting is that both situations present the option of saving five by killing one, but most people respond to them differently. Most believe that you would be right to throw the switch, yet wrong to push the man. But why do we think this? And are we right to do so?

headline: Lovin’ Spoonfuls
text: If you have ever tried passing through customs at Newark with a partly wrapped Burgundian salami in your luggage or have found yourself stuck in traffic outside a 72,000-person stadium while the biggest football game of the year is about to start, then you know that five minutes can seem like an eternity. Making pudding, on the other hand, is a different kind of exercise in stretching time  a pleasant one. The five minutes spent in front of a stove, dragging a wooden spatula across the pan to ward off scorched spots and looking for that subtle thickening that seizes the custard just before all-out lumps break out, are elastic, meditative, (ideally) unbothered  a reminder that sometimes the comfort of a comfort food has less to do with eating than it does with cooking.

headline: Swiss Sausage Fans Fret Over How to Save Their Skin
text: BERN, Switzerland  Amid the news of global warming and huge losses at UBS, the country’s largest bank, the Swiss were confronted this winter with an even more dire report: the possible extinction of cervelas, the national sausage.

headline: Carnal Market
text: Daniel McGinn, a reporter for Newsweek, is not the first person to draw, as if on architectural graph paper bordered in leopard print, an explicit link between sex and real estate. Indeed, “Sex and Real Estate” was the title of a 2000 book by the prolific Harvard professor Marjorie Garber, who likened the American upper middle class’s then still novel fascination with pursuing and perfecting their dream domiciles to “yuppie pornography.” She compared buying and selling a house to “dating,” open houses to “cruising opportunities,” real estate agents to “matchmakers,” second homes to love affairs and house-trading to spouse-swapping.

headline: Ignoring the Right to Remain Silent
text: Lucy Stickler is doing something strange. Why is she stealing those blank prescription-pad pages? She has already tricked several local pharmacies into filling a single prescription of hers nine times in one day. Well, Lucy (Jennifer Harmon) has her reasons.

headline: Inside the List
text: THE EDGAR FACTOR I: For crime fiction readers looking to expand their reach beyond the boldface names that crowd this page, the annual Edgar Award nominee list is a gift: an essential, against-the-grain reading guide. The writers on its lists tend not to be well known (yet) to American audiences. Here are the 2008 Edgar nominees for best novel: “Christine Falls,” by Benjamin Black (a k a John Banville); “Priest,” by Ken Bruen; “The Yiddish Policemen’s Union,” by Michael Chabon; “Soul Patch,” by Reed Farrel Coleman; and “Down River,” by John Hart. The Edgar nominees for best first novel are: “Missing Witness,” by Gordon Campbell; “In the Woods,” by Tana French; “Snitch Jacket,” by Christopher Goffard; “Head Games,” by Craig McDonald; and “Pyres,” by Derek Nikitas. None of these novels have made the Times list except Chabon’s, which appeared here for six weeks. But there’s always next time. Cut this paragraph out and amble to your local bookstore.

headline: The Red Zone Factor

Although that does not appear to be good news for the Giants, how the defense plays in those red zone opportunities just might end up being the decisive factor.
