headline: Is Capturing CO2 a Pipe Dream?
text: [UPDATE 5/29: Matt Wald has just written the latest story in our Energy Challenge series — a sobering update on the lack of progress in the United States (and elsewhere) on pursuing ways to affordably capture and store carbon dioxide from coal-burning power plants. It’s a technology that’s on everybody’s wish list — from environmental groups to coal companies. But full-scale tests are years away, and nobody yet knows whether it can be done anywhere near the necessary scale in a world with tens of billions of tons of such emissions each year already, and much more to come.]

headline: Coming Attractions: ‘August: Osage County’
text: Expect a few more posts on “The Moviegoer” before the lights come up and everyone floods out of the theater. But while you’re still in your seats, here’s a brief announcement: next up is “August: Osage County,” by Tracy Letts. It’s a brand new work, a three-act play about a large family in total crisis. In his Times review, the theater critic Charles Isherwood called it “flat-out, no asterisks and without qualifications, the most exciting new American play Broadway has seen in years.” And we’ve put together a great panel to discuss it: the playwright Marsha Norman, the novelist Eliza Minot, and the Times’s Frank Rich, who was the paper’s chief theater critic before becoming an Op-Ed columnist. We’ll start in on February 18, and I’ll be moderating the discussion.

headline: A Milestone for Literary Chess Institution
text: The Serbian publication Sahovski Informator (Chess Informant) recently marked 42 years of operation with its 100th volume. Appearing three times a year (twice a year over most of its run), Informant provides hundreds of deeply annotated games, as well as combinations and endings. To render the commentary internationally understandable, the editors invented a language of symbols to evaluate moves and positions (e.g., “+=” means white has a slight advantage) still in wide usage today. The chess community is particularly grateful for the openings classification system known as ECO codes, after its five-volume work “Encyclopedia of Chess Openings.”

headline: Dissent Over an Endorsement at a Major Black Church
text: Updated, 11:15 p.m. | The Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, the pastor at Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and one of New York’s most influential clergymen, endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton two weeks ago, on the eve of the holiday marking the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s birthday. Speaking to the congregation that day, Mrs. Clinton paraphrased Frederick Douglass, the 19th-century black abolitionist, telling the congregation: “Right has no sex and truth has no color.” But at the church this morning, there was little agreement on who would be the best candidate to carry the Democratic flag into the general election in November.

headline: A Race to Knock on Doors Before the Super Bowl Starts
text: JERSEY CITY – The dozen or so Obama faithful who gathered here just after noon on Sunday were up against the clock. They had hundreds of doors to knock on and only five hours to do it.

headline: Talking With Man of the Year Finalists
text: In an N.F.L. season pocked, in part, by bad news – Michael Vick and dogfighting, Bill Belichick and the spying controversy – you don’t hear much about guys like the Walter Payton N.F.L. Man of the Year finalists.

headline: Fewer Want Bill Clinton Back in the White House
text: The negative coverage of Bill Clinton over the past couple of weeks seems to have hurt his standing with the public. A new survey finds that fewer voters these days like the idea of the former president being back in the White House.

headline: Obama’s Super Bowl Ad: ‘Join’
text: WILMINGTON, Del. – While Senator Barack Obama watches the Super Bowl tonight at home in Chicago, television viewers in 24 states will be able to watch him.

headline: Google’s Microsoft Fixation
text: Google just released a statement on Microsoft’s bid to acquire Yahoo. David Drummond, Google’s general counsel, wrote that the prospective deal “raises troubling questions.” He goes on to outline the points in what may turn into an antitrust challenge were the deal to be consummated.

headline: ‘Latino Caravan’ for Clinton Drives Through Upper Manhattan
text: A group of Hispanic politicians, led by Miguel Martinez, a Dominican-American city councilman, drove cars in a caravan through heavily Hispanic sections of Upper Manhattan this morning in an effort to drum up support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The Latino Caravan, as it was billed in Mrs. Clinton’s campaign literature, made its way from 155th Street and Broadway, in Washington Heights, to 215th Street and 10th Avenue, in Inwood, where it ended with a small rally.

headline: Time of Your Life
text: Inside the quiet Sheraton Wild Horse Pass Resort on Saturday night, as parties swirled around the Phoenix area and a Playboy soiree raged about a mile away, Giants Coach Tom Coughlin addressed his team.

headline: At Columbus Circle, ‘Experience’ Vs. ‘Change’
text: At Columbus Circle around 3 p.m. this afternoon, about 100 supporters of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton stood just a few dozen feet from about 10 volunteers for Senator Barack Obama. One passer-by quipped, “I think you guys should have a cat fight.”

headline: The Super Bowl Telecast
text: To read live commentary on Fox’s Super Bowl telecast — announcers, sideline reporters, promos and attendant hoo-hah — click on “read more” and refresh periodically. Times TV and media critic Virginia Heffernan, of the Times blog The Medium, and occasional Times sports blogger Jeff Z. Klein bring you their impressions, LIVE, as those impressions occur to them.

headline: Romney Reaches Out to Some Fellow Named Brady
text: CHICAGO—Mitt Romney would never be mistaken for a rabid sports fan.

headline: Maria Shriver Backs Obama
text: Score another Kennedy for the Barack Obama campaign.

headline: A House Divided; This Half Is for Clinton
text: Representative Charles B. Rangel, Harlem’s leading politician, visited three Manhattan churches today to stump for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. He was joined at one of them by David N. Dinkins, who was New York City’s first black mayor. But the appearances, intended to bolster Mrs. Clinton’s standing among black and Latino voters, highlighted the extent to which many New Yorkers — even members of the same family — are torn between Mrs. Clinton and her rival for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Foreign Affairs! Mystery!
text: Just left the Diane von Furstenberg show in the Bryant Park tents, where I ran into Hamish Bowles, Michael Roberts and a regular on the blog–whose identity shall remain secret in keeping with DVF’s spies-and-gals-in-the-Berlin-fog theme! Von Furstenberg loves an historical theme to sell contemporary clothes. Lots of layers here, to a vague 1940s slant. In fact, I kept thinking during the show that if I put that black polo sweater I have over that ruffled cream Blass blouse that’s been lurking in the back of my closet for ages, and fish around for a slim skirt, I’d have the look. Also intriguing was the fluffy hair–a mirror image, I thought, of DVF in the Warhold portrait years.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Chuck Bass In a.a.
text: (Jason Frank Rothenberg)

headline: ‘Eligible for Pre-Boarding on Air Force One’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Hey, did you all see Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton last night at the big debate? You see them sitting side by side, staring at the camera. Didn’t they look like one of those bad local eyewitness news teams?

headline: ‘My Forefathers Died to Vote’
text: Supporters of Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton targeted houses of worship on Sunday morning as they waged a final push to get voters to support their candidate on Tuesday, when New York holds its Democratic and Republican presidential primaries. “We’re not looking for the reverends to endorse,” said one Obama volunteer, Giovanna Judge, 42, of Staten Island. “We just want the parishioners to know what’s going on.”

headline: Comedy Stop: Super Tuesday? It’s All About the Name
text: Well, Super Tuesday is finally upon us, and it must be comforting to Democrats in their 22 primary states to know that their votes will, you know, count. As you’re no doubt aware, Florida and Michigan, also known as “the bad boys of statedom,” moved their primaries ahead of Feb. 5 to gain influence and campaign dollars. Tragically, they were punished by the Democratic National Committee by having their delegates denied seats at the party’s national convention. (Even more tragically, they lost the chance to sample D.N.C. chairman Howard Dean’s homemade ice cream in either of its two flavors, Facial Pink and Grassroot.) But all this could have been avoided if Michigan and Florida hadn’t miscalculated the real reason that Super Tuesday carries so much clout: its cool name.

headline: All You Need Is Hate
text: I have been thinking about writing this column for some time, but I have hesitated because of a fear that it would advance the agenda that is its target. That is the agenda of Hillary Clinton-hating.

headline: For Once, Ads Take a Backseat
text: This is likely to be deemed one of those Super Bowl years when the action on the field surpassed the best efforts of Madison Avenue to excite, entertain, amaze and amuse.

headline: New York Men's Wear Collections
text: Photos from the Band of Outsiders, Duckie Brown, Patrik & Ervell, Robert Geller, Shipley & Halmos and Tim Hamilton collections.

headline: Sound Bites on a Plane
text: This weekend has brought new tension to the campaign planes of Senator Hillary Clinton and Senator Barack Obama. Each aircraft was the scene of a standoff between press and campaign aides over what is reportable by traveling reporters at 30,000 feet.

headline: Game Over: Giants 17, Patriots 14
text: Post your wisdom below, check out what others are saying, and review the live commentary from the Super Bowl.

headline: ‘One Down,’ One to Go
text: ST. PAUL, Minn. – Arms stretched above her head in full victory pose, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was cheering along with a roomful of Giants fans on Sunday night as Eli Manning & Co. made their final drive to win Super Bowl XLII.

headline: Clinton’s Post-Game Show
text: ABOARD THE CLINTON PRESS PLANE – Before taking off to New York late Sunday night, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hailed the New York football Giants and made a few quips about Senator Barack Obama and the people of Massachusetts, who vote on Feb. 5.

headline: Super Bowl Watching With Romney
text: NASHVILLE—Somehow it became me versus the Governor.

headline: Clemens’s Lawyers Not Worried About What Pettitte Will Say
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens arrives here for his own Super Tuesday this week, a showdown with his former trainer in closed-door testimony to Congressional lawyers.

headline: Fed Cup Matches Rained Out
text: Steady rain washed out matches at the Fed Cup quarterfinal between Germany and the United States in San Diego, forcing organizers to try again Monday. The best-of-five series was tied, 1-1. The winner will move on to face defending champion Russia, which reached the semifinals by beating Israel. China and Spain also reached the semifinals.

headline: Ghana and Ivory Coast Win
text: Host Ghana and Ivory Coast reached the African Cup of Nations semifinals, staying on course to meet in the final next Sunday. Ghana beat Nigeria, 2-1, and Ivory Coast routed Guinea, 5-0.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 22 about the evacuation of a Brooklyn building that is home to artists, writers and photographers referred imprecisely to the type of zoning, based on information from city officials, for the building at 475 Kent Avenue in Williamsburg. It is now zoned for residential use, not exclusively commercial use. However, until the owner obtains the necessary certificates of occupancy, city officials said, it can be used only for commercial purposes.

headline: Cold Chinese Grow Angry Over Lack of Preparation
text: SHANGHAI  For two weeks running, much of this country, long known for its capacity for mass mobilization, has been tied in knots by a series of major snowstorms.

headline: Some Campuses Decide Tobacco Company Money Is ‘Tainted’
text: Officials at the University of Texas business school in Austin became uneasy when they realized that a reliable donor to student activities  the parent company of the tobacco maker Philip Morris  wanted a more prominent role in sponsoring events, and more interaction with students.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Ascendia Brands, Hamilton, N.J., named two agencies to handle assignments for brands like Baby Magic, Binaca, Calgon, the Healing Garden and Mr. Bubble, which the company acquired in 2005 and 2007. Hillman & Partners, New York, will handle advertising, with spending estimated at $10 million during the next 12 to 18 months, and Corbin & Associates, New York, will handle public relations.

headline: Microsoft Adds Research Lab in East as Others Cut Back
text: SAN FRANCISCO  As other high-tech companies cut back on their research labs, Microsoft continues to increase its ranks of free-rein thinkers.

headline: Nine-Piece Band Animates a Six-Part Jazz Album
text: The album Marcus Roberts recreated from start to finish at the Allen Room over the weekend is 18 years old, but its mannerisms don’t come from any particular era. The key to “Deep in the Shed,” that record of six concisely written pieces in blues form, is its natural shuffling of elements from jazz’s entire life.

headline: Leno’s Art of Late-Show Maintenance
text: How does he do it?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Tuesday about the dropping of charges against some of the 32 young people arrested on their way to a wake in Brooklyn misstated the number who were formally charged. Twenty-six of the youths were charged, not all 32 (six were juveniles; their arrests were reviewed, but they were released). The headline and article also misstated the total number of charges dropped so far. The dismissal of charges against 10 of the defendants this month raises the total to 16, not 22.

headline: Even as the Candidates Make Nice, the TV Crew Hopes for a Fight
text: LOS ANGELES  A serious discussion on pressing national issues may be good for the country. But it isn’t necessarily good television.

headline: Bronx: Store Employee Critically Shot
text: A 22-year-old employee of a Bronx clothing store was in critical condition at St. Barnabas Hospital on Sunday after being shot while working in the store, the police said. The worker, whom the police declined to identify, was shot at 5:45 p.m. on Friday by a man who entered Urban Terrain, at 2467 Grand Concourse in the Fordham neighborhood, and became unruly. After he was told to leave, the man shot the store employee and fled before police officers, who had received a 911 call, arrived. There were no arrests by Sunday.

headline: Ready to Take Advantage When the Bidding Goes Awry
text: We tend to concentrate on deals that have been cleverly played or defended, but in the real world everyone makes mistakes. When an opponent does something wrong, you must be ready to benefit.

headline: Going for Every Last Vote in Upper Manhattan
text: With megaphones, telephones and hundreds of pounds of fliers, pamphlets, stickers, posters and buttons, volunteers for Senators Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama turned a warm winter Sunday into a battle for Upper Manhattan two days before the nation’s biggest day of presidential nominating contests.

headline: For Giants Fans, the Celebration Is Only Beginning
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Griffin Ferrara woke up Sunday morning and groaned.

headline: Michelle, Maria, Caroline and Oprah on the Hustings in California
text: Los Angeles

headline: Brydon Takes Super-G
text: Emily Brydon of Canada won a super-G for her first World Cup victory, while Lindsey Vonn just missed a top-three finish in St. Moritz, Switzerland. Vonn, who missed the podium by 0.01, is second in the World Cup standings, 89 points behind Nicole Hosp.

headline: Safety Messages That Sound Like Silence
text: As he passed through Grand Central Terminal last month, Dr. David Berman, a commuter from Westport, Conn., usually perked up when he heard the voice of Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC anchor, echoing through the main hall over the public announcement system.

headline: Mad Magazine Uses Pulitzer Winners to Tweak Bush
text: The “usual gang of idiots,” as the editorial staff of Mad magazine lovingly describes itself, produces cultural and political parody every month. For the next issue, however, the gang has recruited some very special help.

headline: Sutton Earns 800th Victory
text: Eddie Sutton became the fifth N.C.A.A. Division I coach to win 800 games as San Francisco came back from a 19-point second-half deficit to beat host Pepperdine, 85-82, on Saturday. Sutton joined a group that also includes Bob Knight, Dean Smith, Adolph Rupp and Jim Phelan. He trails only Knight among active coaches.

headline: For Celebrities, Ads Made Abroad Shed Some Stigma
text: It is no secret that celebrities have earned big paychecks doing commercials for Japanese and European markets, but now that Robert De Niro is soulfully shilling for American Express and Nicole Kidman stars in artfully shot ads for Chanel No. 5  both seen in the United States  celebrities seem to have relaxed about their commercial work.

headline: Miley Cyrus’s Music Is Music to Disney’s Ears
text: Pulling in an estimated $29 million in its debut, the 3D film “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour” (distributed by Disney), right, ran away from the competition to capture the No. 1 ranking at North American box offices over the weekend. With $13 million on its opening weekend, the horror film “The Eye” (Lionsgate and Paramount Vantage), starring Jessica Alba as a blind violinist, took second place, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported. The romantic comedy “27 Dresses” (Fox) drew $8.4 million to hold on to third place for a second consecutive week. Fourth place and $7.4 million went to last week’s seventh-place finisher, “Juno” (Fox Searchlight), lifting this little film’s nine-week total to $110.2 million. Last week’s No. 1 film, the spoof “Meet the Spartans” (Fox), lost 61 percent of its audience, attracting only $7.1 million and sank to fifth place.

headline: Davis Wins 1,500 Meters
text: Shani Davis won the 1,500-meter race in Baselga di Pinè, Italy, at a speedskating World Cup event. Davis finished in 1:46.85, ahead of Simon Kuipers, the World Cup leader, and Mark Tuitert.

headline: Parker Fuels Tennessee
text: Candace Parker dunked for the seventh time in her career and scored 20 points to help No. 2 Tennessee overcome a sluggish first half in a 79-51 victory against visiting Kentucky.

headline: Crossroads of a Million Private Lives
text: The “American Experience” documentary “Grand Central” is such an entertaining wallow for New York PBS viewers that it’s disconcerting to note that it was produced, as World Series champions are these days, in Boston, by the public television station WGBH. Think of it as a peace offering.

headline: Footnotes
text: The revival of “The Country Girl,” the backstage drama by Clifford Odets, has found its Broadway home: the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater. The play, directed by Mike Nichols and starring Morgan Freeman, Frances McDormand and Peter Gallagher, opens in previews on April 3 and officially on April 27. ... James Gandolfini, who played Tony Soprano on “The Sopranos” on HBO, will join Jesse L. Martin in “Sexual Healing,” a film about the last years of the singer Marvin Gaye, Variety reported. Mr. Gandolfini will portray Freddy Cousaert, the promoter who guided Gaye (Mr. Martin) through the recording of “Midnight Love,” his biggest-selling album.

headline: Rangers Rally After Trailing by 3
text: MONTREAL  Late in the second period Sunday afternoon, the Bell Centre ice was littered with gloves and sticks and helmets, with Rangers and Canadiens players locked in sets of skirmishes. A capacity crowd of 21,273 shook the building with a roar.

headline: U.N.C. Wins, but Loses Lawson
text: Tyler Hansbrough had 22 points and a career-high 21 rebounds and No. 4 North Carolina beat host Florida State, 84-73, in overtime Sunday. The Tar Heels lost their starting point guard, Ty Lawson, four minutes into the game when he sprained his left ankle.

headline: Male Circumcision No Aid to Women in Study
text: BOSTON  A number of studies showing that circumcision among men reduces their risk of infection from the AIDS virus has raised the hope that the procedure would also benefit their female sexual partners.

headline: Swarming Giants Stifle the Brady-to-Moss Connection
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  There was a glitch in the Patriots’ high-speed connection Sunday night. Because of increased traffic in the backfield, Tom Brady to Randy Moss was not working.

headline: The Stubborn Voice of a Troubadour
text: Tom Petty was not an obvious choice for halftime entertainment at Super Bowl XLII. His most recent album, “Highway Companion,” came out in 2006, and he is by no means a staple of pop radio or MTV. Petty, 57, is yet another of the mature performers chosen for the Super Bowl halftime since Janet Jackson’s wardrobe malfunction in 2004.

headline: Extreme Makeover, Champions Edition
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: U.S. Says It Accidentally Killed 9 Iraqi Civilians
text: BAGHDAD  American forces said Sunday that they had accidentally killed nine Iraqi civilians and wounded three in a strike aimed at militants of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia south of Baghdad, acknowledging what appeared to be one of the deadliest cases of mistaken identity in recent weeks.

headline: A Lebanese Diva, Performing in Syria, Creates Drama in More Ways Than One
text: DAMASCUS, Syria  From the moment she stepped onstage here at the Dar al Assad opera house on Monday night, the red-haired woman in the pale green gown set off a wild storm of applause. Fayrouz, the great Lebanese diva, had returned to Damascus for the first time in three decades.

headline: Endowments Widen a Higher Education Gap
text: Allan T. Demaree, a retired executive editor of Fortune magazine, gladly makes donations to Princeton University, his alma mater, even though he knows it has become one of the wealthiest educational institutions in the world. His son, who also went to Princeton, points to its endowment of $15.8 billion, and will not give it a penny.

headline: It’s Splitsville for Rupert and Hillary
text: Honeymoons don’t last forever. Just ask Hillary Clinton and Rupert Murdoch.

headline: In Election of Change, TV Gives Voice to Insiders
text: On Sunday mornings, the choice is between Captain of the Debate Club Tim Russert and George Stephanopoulos, high school’s most diligent lab partner.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Jan. 24, about the novel “All Shall Be Well; and All Shall Be Well; and All Manner of Things Shall Be Well,” by Tod Wodicka, misidentified the fictional “Star Trek” language one of the characters learns. It is Klingon, not Vulcan.

headline: Earl L. Butz, Secretary Felled by Racial Remark, Is Dead at 98
text: Earl L. Butz, who orchestrated a major change in federal farm policy as secretary of agriculture during the 1970s but came to be remembered more for a vulgar racial comment that brought about his resignation during the 1976 presidential election race, died Saturday in Washington. Mr. Butz, who lived in West Lafayette, Ind., was 98.

headline: Tax Scheme Is Blamed for Damage to Artifacts
text: WASHINGTON  Recent raids on museums in Southern California have stirred much questioning in the art world about why three federal agencies would devote four years to investigating what seems to be low-level smuggling and penny-ante tax fraud.

headline: Tragicomic Tale of the 9/11 Report
text: Journalists like to talk about the back story, the story behind the story. The back story can be nothing more than vaguely sourced gossip traded among pundits and politicos before they go on talk shows. But sometimes the back story is the real, whole truth, a tale of conniving or official blundering that the headlines can only hint at. Journalists often conceal the whole truth because they need to protect their sources.

headline: Confident Burress Emerges Victorious, Just as He Predicted He Would
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Plaxico Burress strode to the podium with an infant on his arm and his significant other standing by his side. He wore a championship hat and T-shirt, his eye black smeared across his face.

headline: Inspired by Obama, Filmmaker Takes on Politics
text: At 3 o’clock one morning last February, Jordan Thomas, a 37-year-old actor-turned-filmmaker, woke up in his Brooklyn apartment and headed for the computer. Inspired by Barack Obama’s star-making speech at the 2004 Democratic National Convention, Mr. Thomas had been paying close attention to the Illinois senator, and was now eager to catch the online announcement about how to join his presidential effort.

headline: One Survivor in Shooting at Illinois Mall
text: TINLEY PARK, Ill.  The police confirmed Sunday that one woman survived an apparent robbery gone wrong at a suburban Chicago shopping center that left five others dead.

headline: A Formula for Success, but Not for Innovation
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: In Health Debate, Clinton Remains Vague on Penalties
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton inched closer Sunday to explaining how she would enforce her proposal that everyone have health insurance, but declined to specify  as she has throughout the campaign  how she would penalize those who refuse.

headline: As if Mardi Gras Weren’t Enough
text: NEW ORLEANS (AP) Wide receiver Plaxico Burress was probably not the only one shouting “Throw me something, mister” on Sunday night.

headline: Leak on Cross-Border Chases From Iraq
text: WASHINGTON  American military forces in Iraq were authorized to pursue former members of Saddam Hussein’s government and terrorists across Iraq’s borders into Iran and Syria, according to a classified 2005 document that has been made public by an independent Web site.

headline: Natural Gas Project Planned in Australia
text: The Queensland Gas Company, an Australian producer of natural gas from coal seams, and the BG Group of Britain plan to invest about 8 billion Australian dollars ($7.2 billion) in an export project in northeastern Australia to tap rising demand for the fuel.

headline: Peter Staudhammer, 73, Aerospace Engineer, Is Dead
text: Peter Staudhammer, a wide-ranging aerospace engineer and executive who helped design instruments and engines used by NASA in landings on Mars and the Moon, died on Jan. 14 at his home in La Quinta, Calif. He was 73.

headline: A Battle of the Moguls Over IAC
text: Like Hollywood stars stuck in a rut, Barry Diller and John C. Malone are always cast in the same contrasting roles. Mr. Diller, 65, lives a razzle-dazzle life of extravagance and celebrity. If he isn’t flying off to Capri with his wife, the socialite and fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg, he is running his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp, from a sculptured $133 million tower designed by Frank Gehry on the Hudson River.

headline: Is Obama a Mac and Clinton a PC?
text: STYLES make fights  or so goes the boxing cliché. In 2008, they make presidential campaigns, too.

headline: Israeli Defense Minister to Stay in Olmert Coalition
text: JERUSALEM  Ehud Barak, Israel’s defense minister and the leader of the Labor Party, announced Sunday that he would remain in the government, stabilizing Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s coalition despite last week’s harsh report on the political and military leaders’ handling of the Lebanon war in 2006.

headline: Empty Olympic Promises
text: Six months out from the 2008 Olympics, China has jailed another inconvenient dissident. Hu Jia was dragged from his home by state police agents, and last week he was formally charged with inciting subversion. To earn the right to host the Games, China promised to improve its human rights record. Instead, it appears determined to silence anyone who dares to tell the truth about its abuses.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Critic’s Choice column on Tuesday, about new DVDs, including one of the 1961 movie “El Cid,” referred incorrectly to the membership in the Communist Party U.S.A. of Ben Barzman, one of the writers of the screenplay of “El Cid.” He resigned from the party in 1949; he was not still a member when he rewrote the script.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the Nielsen estimates of viewers of various television programs on Sunday night misidentified the show that was on Fox at 8:30 and drew an estimated 7.5 million viewers. It was a repeat of “The Simpsons,” not “King of the Hill.”

headline: It’s the Economy Again, and Some See Similarities to 1992
text: WASHINGTON  An economic downturn at election time almost always spells disaster for the political party that holds the White House. But the slowdown this year could add an especially cruel twist for the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: ESPN to Offer Sports Events on the Web Free to Some
text: ESPN, the dominant channel for sports programming, will announce this week that Web users on college campuses and military bases  anyone in the .edu or .mil domain  will be able to access live programming on its Web site, ESPN360, without charge.

headline: Google Works to Torpedo Microsoft Bid for Yahoo
text: Standing between a marriage of Microsoft and Yahoo may be the technology behemoth that has continually outsmarted them: Google.

headline: St. Peter’s Tops Manhattan
text: Todd Sowell had 19 points and 13 rebounds to lead St. Peter’s to a 78-68 victory against visiting Manhattan.

headline: The Cold War as Ancient History
text: BERLIN

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Tuesday, and in some editions last Monday, about Gordon B. Hinckley, the president and prophet of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, misidentified the town where Joseph Smith, the founder of the church, was killed by an anti-Mormon mob and misstated the year the event occurred. He was killed in Carthage, Ill.  not Nauvoo, Ill., where he had earlier been detained, and the year was 1844, not 1843.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A music review on Jan. 18 about the jazz singer Mark Murphy, at Birdland, misidentified the writer of a song he performed, “What a Way to Go.” June Tonkin wrote it, not Mr. Murphy.

headline: Miller Wins Super-Combined
text: Bode Miller clinched his third super-combined World Cup title with a victory Sunday after Jean-Baptiste Grange failed to finish the second leg in Val d’Isère, France. Grange’s misstep gave Miller the win in the discipline standings before Miller finished first with a combined time of 2 minutes 18.45 seconds. Miller won his fifth World Cup event of the season and increased his lead in the overall World Cup standings.

headline: G.M.’s Global Strategy: A Brand for Every Place
text: LONDON  In Britain, you can buy a Vauxhall, a Chevrolet, a Saab, a Cadillac or a Hummer. On the Continent, you can trade in the Vauxhall for an Opel. In China, perhaps you’d prefer a Buick, in Dubai a GMC. How about a Holden? Well, you’ll have to travel to Australia or New Zealand. But they are all General Motors brands.

headline: McCain Looks Confident; Tighter Democratic Race
text: Senator John McCain, buoyed by new polls and endorsements, appeared in an increasingly commanding position on Sunday as he headed toward coast-to-coast contests that could effectively hand him the Republican presidential nomination, party officials said. In a display of confidence, Mr. McCain campaigned in the backyard of his chief rival, Mitt Romney.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $7,239,904

headline: Partying On
text: Coming to the aid of one’s party has been given a freshly cynical meaning by the House ethics committee.

headline: BHP Weighs Options in Rio Tinto Bid
text: BEIJING  The world’s biggest mining company, BHP Billiton, must decide by Wednesday if it will proceed with a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group, after China intervened with a strategic investment that could sharply increase the price of what would be one of the biggest mergers in corporate history.

headline: Strike May End Soon, but Writers May Confront a Hostile Hollywood
text: LOS ANGELES  As movie and television writers deliberate whether to end a strike that is about to enter its fourth month, they will also have to grapple with a sober realization: the work world to which they return may be even less friendly than the one they left behind.

headline: Saving Bolshoi Theater
text: Emergency construction needed to spare the historic Bolshoi Theater in Moscow from collapse has delayed its restoration for a year, and it is not scheduled to reopen until November 2009, Reuters reported. Its facade crumbling, its walls and columns marred by 17 vertical cracks and its foundation shifting dangerously, the building was found by engineers last year to be more than 75 percent unstable. The restoration that was to have cost $610 million when the theater was closed in July 2005 will cost $730 million, said Mikhail Shvydkoi, director of the Russian Federal Culture Agency. “We are now planning to open on Nov. 1, 2009, with the opera ‘Ruslan and Lyudmila,’ ” he said. Founded in 1776 by Catherine the Great, the Bolshoi has been in its current building since 1825.

headline: A Tiny Staff, Tracking People Across the Globe
text: WASHINGTON  It has an editorial staff of one and annual advertising revenues of less than $2,000. It charges its subscribers nothing and pays most contributors the same. Mapping the settlement of Latino poultry workers is its idea of a sexy piece.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A picture caption in some editions on Thursday with an article about the death of a construction worker, Jose Palacios, who fell 12 stories from a collapsing scaffold in Brooklyn, misstated, in some copies, the relationship between Mr. Palacios and Jasmine Solas, who said he came to the United States from Mexico to find work. He was her uncle, not her cousin.

headline: Best Ad? Bowl Fans and TiVo Clash
text: The most-cited measure of a Super Bowl ad’s performance is the “Ad Meter,” a 20-year-old metric created by USA Today. Every year, the newspaper asks a panel of volunteers to watch the ads while twiddling dials to reflect their reactions; last year, the 238 panelists anointed a Bud Light spot, featuring beer-thieving crabs, as the year’s top Super Bowl ad.

headline: ‘Survivor’ Winner Loses
text: Richard Hatch, winner of $1 million in the first “Survivor” competition on CBS, has lost an appeal of his tax-evasion conviction, The Associated Press reported. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston rejected an argument by Michael Minns, Mr. Hatch’s lawyer, that Judge Ernest Torres of Federal District Court improperly prevented Mr. Hatch, above right, from describing a deal he says was offered by producers of “Survivor” to pay his income taxes in return for his silence about employees of the show smuggling food to other contestants. In its 52-page decision, the court wrote, “The failure of Hatch to present any evidence of such conversations when invited by the court strongly suggested that no actual promises were made.” Mr. Hatch, 46, is serving four years and three months in a federal prison in West Virginia. He was convicted by a jury and sentenced by Judge Torres, who said he had lied repeatedly on the witness stand.

headline: Scarlett Gets Her Rhett
text: Darius Danesh, below, a Glasgow-born actor, singer and songwriter who achieved fame on the British television show “Pop Idol,” has been chosen to portray Rhett Butler opposite Jill Paice’s Scarlett O’Hara in the Trevor Nunn production of “Gone With the Wind,” opening in previews on April 4 at the New London Theater in London. Ms. Paice was seen as Laura Fairlie in London and on Broadway in Mr. Nunn’s production of “The Woman in White.”

headline: Private Schools Cry ‘Unfair’ Over a Grade
text: Report cards are in, and the grades are not good: New York City private schools have given The New York Sun an F.

headline: Late and Lame on Warming
text: Even allowing for the low expectations we bring to any lame-duck president’s final State of the Union address, President Bush’s brief discussion of climate change seemed especially disconnected from reality: from the seriousness and urgency of the problem and from his own responsibility for obstructing progress.

headline: Addenda:  Accounts, People
text: Accounts

headline: Barak to Remain in Israeli Coalition Government
text: JERUSALEM — Ehud Barak, Israel’s defense minister and the leader of the Labor Party, announced Sunday that he would remain in the government, stabilizing Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s coalition despite last week’s harsh report on the political and military leaders’ handling of the Lebanon war in 2006.

headline: All the Percussion That’s Fit to Pound
text: The ensemble So Percussion is gradually making its way through the ranks of composers most revered by percussionists. The group has devoted multiple concerts to the music of Steve Reich; it has also paid due attention to John Cage, seen by many as the father of modern percussion music. On Friday night at Miller Theater, in a Composer Portrait concert, So Percussion played works by George Crumb, completing a sort of holy trinity of percussion composers that Jason Treuting, a member of the ensemble, cited during an onstage conversation with Mr. Crumb.

headline: Campaign Conflicts Are Not Over Core Goals, but How to Get There
text: WASHINGTON  Although the surviving presidential candidates furiously attack one another over the details of their tax, health and Iraq proposals, there is more consensus in the parties these days than disagreement.

headline: Stories of Life, With Passion in Common
text: CityDance Ensemble has made a name for itself in Washington, where it is one of the leading modern-dance troupes. On Friday night at the Joyce SoHo, where the company was making its New York City debut, it presented an impressively varied program of work by nine choreographers, including Doug Varone and Jane Dudley.

headline: A Severed Car Grille? It’s Super Bowl Ad Time
text: WINK-WINK, nudge-nudge.

headline: A German Comic Book on Holocaust History
text: German schools will begin distribution this week of a comic book intended to teach children about the Nazi era and the Holocaust, Reuters reported. Although German schools already make a strong effort to educate pupils about Nazism, racist violence remains a problem, and a revival of the German Jewish population  now the world’s fastest growing  has brought a resurgence of anti-Semitism. Created by the Dutch cartoonist Eric Heuvel, the 61-page comic book, titled “The Search,” tells the story of Esther, a fictional Jewish survivor of the Holocaust. For six months the comic book will complement work sheets in history classes in secondary schools in Berlin, and then the project may spread nationwide. Melina Feingold, a spokeswoman for the Anne Frank Center in Berlin, which is backing the project, expressed hope that the comic book would reach the children who are least interested in schoolwork.

headline: K.G.B.-Trained Hungarian Has NATO Role
text: BERLIN  The new chief of the Hungarian secret services, who spent six years at the K.G.B.’s academy in Moscow during the 1980s, in January became the chairman of NATO’s intelligence committee, a rotating post that is held for a year.

headline: Dyspepsia on the Right
text: The prospect of John McCain as the likely Republican presidential nominee has produced a squall of anger on the right. Normally reserved columnists and usually ebullient talk-radio hosts vie to express their disgust with McCain, and their disdain for the Republicans who are about to nominate him. The conservative movement as a whole appears disgruntled and dyspeptic.

headline: Still Rudderless in Gotham
text: Theatergoers are probably not supposed to like Bess, the youngest and bossiest character in Brooke Berman’s “Hunting and Gathering,” as much as I did. In Ms. Berman’s slim and winsome comedy of urban nomads in search of stability, which opened on Sunday night at 59E59 Theaters, it’s the three older people who are presumably meant to capture your heart.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills Tuesday.

headline: Spurs Sign Stoudamire
text: San Antonio bolstered its backcourt, signing point guard Damon Stoudamire. He negotiated a buyout with Memphis last week after falling behind two young players in the rotation.

headline: Bush Seeks Budget of $3.1 Trillion
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush submitted a federal budget of $3.1 trillion on Monday, declaring that the spending plan would keep the United States safe and prosperous and, despite its record size, would adhere to his principle of letting Americans keep as much of their own money as possible.

headline: Is Nothing Secure? Not Romance, Real Estate or Big Bird?
text: “Apartment 3A,” a play by Jeff Daniels being presented at the Beckett Theater, affords us the opportunity to ponder whether it is more tedious to listen to people talking about God or talking about sex. Both subjects are discussed at length in this modest romantic comedy that recalls early Neil Simon sprinkled with metaphysics.

headline: Democrats’ Long Battle May Benefit Republicans
text: The good news for the 2008 presidential candidates is that only hours remain in their torturous march across the Super Tuesday battlefield.

headline: Producers Guild Honors ‘No Country’
text: “No Country for Old Men,” already honored by the Directors Guild of America, received another major honor when it was selected best feature film by the Producers Guild of America on Saturday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. Directed by Joel and Ethan Coen (starring Josh Brolin, above), this latter-day western has been nominated for eight Academy Awards. The producers named “Ratatouille” the best animated film and gave honors for episodic television comedy to NBC’s “30 Rock” and for drama to HBO’s “Sopranos.”

headline: France Said to Suggest New Controls for Its Banks
text: PARIS  A French government report to be released Monday calls for tighter risk-control measures at Société Générale and a broad review of the rules at other French banks in response to huge losses from a trading scandal, French officials with direct knowledge of the findings said on Sunday.

headline: Obama, Cultivating California Spirit, Eases Clinton’s Grip on State
text: LOS ANGELES  In the iconography of American politics, California more than anyplace is where candidates, in Mario M. Cuomo’s words, “campaign in poetry.” Odes to the state’s embrace of youth, change and possibility linger in Democratic presidential lore.

headline: Specter Appears on TV and Plans Follow-Up
text: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, the ranking Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, made the national news media rounds on the morning of the Super Bowl. First, he went on ESPN. Later, he went on CNN.

headline: Spitzer’s Budget Plans, and the Iffy Real Estate Deals Behind Them
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s budget, specifically his ambitious plan to encourage moderately priced housing, is predicated on raising $900 million by selling two parcels of land to the north and south of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

headline: Manhattan: Man Dies in Subway
text: An unidentified man was killed early Sunday by a northbound N train at the subway station at 49th Street and Seventh Avenue, the authorities said. According to Marisa Baldeo, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the emergency brakes were activated as the train was leaving the station about 5:40 a.m., and the motorman saw the man’s body on the tracks. Both the transportation authority and the police said the exact cause of death was not known. The police said that no criminal act was suspected. A man who said he was a witness, Karriem Torres, said the victim had been running to catch the train and climbed between two cars. He slipped under the train as it began to move and he screamed, Mr. Torres said, adding that by the time the train stopped, the man had been crushed.

headline: Candidates Make Final Push Before Tuesday Vote
text: The presidential candidates from both parties campaigned frenetically on Monday, making their final pushes with a series of rallies and blitzes of television commercials for a final bout of November-style campaigning before more than 20 states vote in Tuesday’s virtual national primary.

headline: Before Offense Rallies, Defense Handles Brady
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  In the days leading to Super Bowl XLII, the Giants’ defensive leaders, especially the veteran end Michael Strahan, grew impatient with all the talk about New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady.

headline: Drama in Stories Written in Sounds
text: Ever since he became the Brooklyn Philharmonic’s music director in 2005, Michael Christie has been intent on restoring the thematic programming  and with it, the feeling that the orchestra’s concerts were events  that was the philharmonic’s calling card through the 1990s.

headline: Internet-Era Magazine Is Revived to Look at the Future
text: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the signature publications of the first dot-com boom is being reincarnated.

headline: Manning Keeps Cool, and Keeps a Drive Alive
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  After winning the Most Valuable Player award in Super Bowl XLII for leading the Giants to a 17-14 victory over the New England Patriots, quarterback Eli Manning seemed as composed as he did on the field when he brought his team from behind twice in the fourth quarter with drives that ended in touchdown passes.

headline: Northern Rock’s Troubles Demoralize Its Hometown
text: NEWCASTLE, England  From his office in the outskirts of this city in the northeast of England, Robin Ashby, a public relations executive and shareholder in the troubled British lender Northern Rock, can see a large construction site where Northern Rock is building the latest extension to its headquarters.

headline: Apartments for Rent: Loopy Hollywood Types O.K.
text: If you have just about lost your tolerance for portrayals of Los Angeles involving the oversexed and underappreciated, the dippy, the dopey, the hollow and the holistic, “Welcome to the Captain” may not merely tax your immune system, it could also send you to the nearest virologist.

headline: Great Firewall of China Faces Online Rebels
text: WUHAN, China  As an 18-year-old student with an interest in the Internet, Zhu Nan had been itching to say something about the country’s pervasive online censorship system, widely known here as the Great Firewall.

headline: In Democratic Families, Politics Makes for Estranged Bedfellows
text: Maria Shriver woke up Sunday morning and decided to surprise the audience at a rally for Senator Barack Obama in Los Angeles, materializing alongside Oprah Winfrey and telling the crowd she was there because she sought “an America that’s about unity.”

headline: ‘Everybody’s a Giants Fan Tonight’
text: The Super Bowl celebrations Sunday night were like New Year’s Eve all over again.

headline: Giants Stun Patriots in Super Bowl XLII
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  The Giants were not even supposed to be here, taking an unlikely playoff path through the behemoths of their conference and regarded, once they alighted on Super Bowl XLII, as little more than charming foils for the New England Patriots’ assault on immortality.

headline: Support for Clinton, Driven by Respect
text: On a cold, drizzly night in Bushwick last week, dozens of people had packed themselves into a storefront office, awaiting the arrival of Assemblyman Vito J. Lopez, leader of the Brooklyn Democratic Party.

headline: Marches Show Disgust With a Colombian Rebel Group
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched here and in other cities around Colombia on Monday to protest the abductions and killings carried out by the country's largest rebel group.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,936 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Sunday:

headline: Waiting (and Waiting) for a Big Rap Moment
text: NASHVILLE  He calls himself All $tar, and he has what most rappers dream of: a devoted fan base, a strong regional reputation and a big-time record deal. His major-label debut, “Street Ball” (Cash Money/Universal), is one of the year’s most eagerly anticipated Southern hip-hop albums.

headline: Clinton, Obama, Insurance
text: The principal policy division between Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama involves health care. It’s a division that can seem technical and obscure  and I’ve read many assertions that only the most wonkish care about the fine print of their proposals.

headline: As the Giants’ Defense Holds Tough, the Patriots’ Crumbles
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  After Eli Manning’s 13-yard touchdown pass, which was to be the difference in the Super Bowl on Sunday night, Patriots Coach Bill Belichick turned his back and walked slowly down his team’s sideline.

headline: Pro-West Incumbent Wins Serbia’s Presidential Runoff
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  Boris Tadic, Serbia’s pro-Western incumbent, won the presidential runoff election Sunday in a closely contested race that was seen as having the potential to determine whether this poor Balkan nation would turn toward the West or revert to the nationalism and isolationism of the past.

headline: Proposed Military Spending Is Highest Since WWII
text: WASHINGTON  As Congress and the public focus on more than $600 billion already approved in supplemental budgets to pay for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan and for counterterrorism operations, the Bush administration has with little notice approached a landmark in military spending.

headline: Cut Undersea Cables Raise Questions of Safety
text: NEW DELHI  Four undersea communication cables have been cut in the last week, raising questions about the safety of the network that handles most of the world’s Internet and telephone traffic.

headline: Fighting Rages for Second Day in Chad’s Capital
text: CASABLANCA, Morocco  Fighting raged for a second day in the capital of Chad on Sunday, with the government making an all-out attempt to beat back rebels who had overrun the capital on Saturday, Chadian officials said. The country’s president, Idriss Déby, remained defiant in the presidential palace and directed counterattacks, the officials said.

headline: To Be Young Again, and in a Shrunken Suit
text: All men are little boys when it comes to toggle coats. Grown-up men, even balding men, can sometimes be found in department stores fondling the horn buttons, looking at them the way they might a red sports car or Gisele Bündchen, as the outerwear antidote to a midlife crisis.

headline: New CDs
text: K. D. LANG “Watershed” (Nonesuch)

headline: Once Again, Hobbs Causes Trouble for Manning
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Giants quarterback Eli Manning singled out Ellis Hobbs, the New England Patriots’ 5-foot-9 cornerback, during a crucial drive in the second quarter Sunday in Super Bowl XLII. His first attempt was successful. His second attempt was a disaster.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 21 about Julio Angarita, a Brooklyn man who fell behind on his rent because of depression and surgery and received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, misspelled the surname of a social worker who helped him, misstated the nature of that help and misidentified her employer. The worker is Carla Betancourt, not Bentancourt, and she works for the Fifth Avenue Committee, a nonprofit community development group, not the Community Service Society. Ms. Betancourt helped Mr. Angarita document his financial need, but she did not secure rent money for him. (That service was provided by another social worker, Kim Lerner, of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.)

headline: Investigation Into Bruno Broadens
text: Federal authorities have widened their investigation of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, issuing subpoenas to pension funds affiliated with union locals in and around the senator’s Albany-area district, people with knowledge of the investigation said.

headline: Suitor Ends Bid for Northern Rock
text: LONDON  Olivant Advisers, one of two possible suitors for Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, dropped out of the bidding on Monday, saying it failed to come up with an offer that would satisfy both it and the government.

headline: Begging Bush’s Pardon
text: Washington

headline: Backroom Politics Is Brought to the People, and the People Step In
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn.

headline: Adweek Gets Extreme Makeover in New Campaign
text: A playful campaign for a leading trade publication for the advertising industry has a serious purpose, promoting what may be the most significant changes since its founding 30 years ago.

headline: Manhattan: Congresswoman Recovering
text: A “minor coronary incident” caused United States Representative Nita M. Lowey, left, to collapse at a campaign rally for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in White Plains on Saturday, according to Ms. Lowey’s spokesman, Matthew Dennis. In a statement, he said on Sunday that Ms. Lowey, 70, a Democrat who represents parts of Westchester and Rockland Counties, was expected to fully recover but would remain at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia hospital in Manhattan for a few days. Ms. Lowey collapsed after introducing Kerry Kennedy, the human-rights activist and daughter of Robert F. Kennedy, at the rally but remained alert as medics carried her away by stretcher.

headline: Take the Game, Leave the ‘Idol’
text: By the time Eli Manning kneeled down on the final play of the Giants’ 17-14 Super Bowl win Sunday night, the memory of Ryan Seacrest in the pregame show was nearly gone. His most welcome words: “Seacrest out,” or something like that, as the “American Idol” host bid adieu.

headline: Another Difficulty for a Microsoft-Yahoo Marriage: Recruiting
text: The crowds of engineering students stood as many as six deep at the recruitment table Google set up at a job fair at Stanford last fall. Facebook’s representatives faced a similarly thick crowd clamoring for a few minutes of their time.

headline: A Small Patriots Receiver Ends Up Being the Biggest Target of All
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  As the clock ticked down in the fourth quarter, when the Patriots needed a reception, quarterback Tom Brady scanned the field for the little guy with the No. 83 jersey streaked with red paint.

headline: Knicks’ Winless Trip Instills a Measure of Confidence
text: After a long and winding trip that began with faint hope and ended with a string of defeats, the Knicks find themselves buried deeper in the standings and up to their ears in finely honed rhetoric.

headline: A Young Generation, Eager to Tackle Problems
text: To the Editor:

headline:
Making Most of 2nd Chance,
Giants Seize Patriots’ Day
text: GLENDALE, Ariz.  Plaxico Burress had caught what became the winning touchdown pass, but all the anticipation born of improbability had to remain corked for 35 more seconds.

headline: Prototypically American, Atypically Challenging
text: A friend of mine once asked Pierre Boulez why he had taken up the music of Elliott Carter and done so much to make it an international presence. Mr. Boulez, a French composer and conductor, had an interesting answer: “Because he sounded so American.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
That’s Crain’s New York, as Distinct From Craig’s
text: Name-squatting on the Internet has been around for years, but one public relations firm has found a novel use for it in promoting a nascent awards and networking program.

headline: Baby Essentials Succeed Where Pet Food Failed
text: IT sounds like a recipe from the Internet’s cookbook for business disasters. Sell bulky commodity items at prices low enough to compete with grocery stores, and ship them for free to consumers.

headline: Anne Frank Musical Denounced by Relative
text: Anne Frank’s last living relative has voiced his disapproval of plans for a Spanish musical based on her renowned diary, Agence France-Presse reported. Buddy Elias, Frank’s  82-year-old cousin, who is chairman of the Anne Frank-Fonds, a Swiss-based charitable organization that holds the copyright to “The Diary of a Young Girl,” said: “We are very much against it. The Holocaust is not a theme to be made into a musical.” He said that the foundation had not opposed earlier film, theater and television adaptations because they were considered “realistic.” He noted, however, that the foundation had no recourse against the musical because it does not quote from the diary. Rafael Alvero, the director and developer of “The Diary of Anne Frank: A Song to Life,” scheduled to open on Feb. 28 at the Calderón Theater in Madrid, insisted that the show was “very faithful” to the diary. He had support from the Anne Frank Foundation, which operates the museum in the building where the Frank family and others hid, and said the show would spread a message of tolerance. Mr. Alvero also pointed to musicals like “Les Misérables” and “Jesus Christ Superstar” that have dealt with serious subjects. “I do not think we have trivialized this story in any way,” he said.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about Thursday night’s Democratic debate between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama quoted incorrectly from an e-mail message sent by a 38-year-old woman in South Carolina. In asking Mrs. Clinton how she represented change, the woman noted that she had never had the opportunity to vote in a presidential election in which a Bush or Clinton was not on the ticket; she did not say that she had only voted for a Bush or Clinton. (Go to Article)

headline: Change of Teams Changes Everything for Hixon
text: CHANDLER, Ariz.  Until a little more than a month ago, Giants wide receiver Domenik Hixon was known as the other player involved in the collision that caused the spinal cord injury of Buffalo Bills tight end Kevin Everett.

headline: Former Warlord in Standoff With Police at Kabul Home
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Dozens of armed police officers laid siege on Sunday to the house of a powerful ethnic Uzbek leader, Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, in the diplomatic district of the capital, Kabul’s police chief said. The action came after about 50 of General Dostum’s followers attacked and briefly abducted a political rival Saturday night.

headline: Newark: Off-Duty Officer Fatally Shoots Man
text: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a man on Sunday who was thought to have gone by mistake to the home where the officer was staying, and then pointed a gun at the officer, the Essex County prosecutor’s office said. The shooting occurred about 5:30 a.m., after a vehicle with four occupants pulled up in front of the house, on North 12th Street, and two of the four went to the front door. “Apparently, the suspects were mistakenly searching the wrong residence for someone they were going after,” said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the prosecutor. The officer, whose name was not released, was getting ready for work at the house, which belongs to a friend or relative, when he heard the banging and answered the door, taking his service pistol with him, Mr. Loriquet said. One of the men at the door, Khalif Cousar, 29, of East Orange, pointed a loaded handgun at the officer, who fired three times, killing Mr. Cousar, Mr. Loriquet said. No one else was injured. The three suspects were being questioned on Sunday. Mr. Loriquet said that after a preliminary investigation, it appeared the shooting was justified. Compiled by Denise Fuhs

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about Thursday night’s Democratic debate between Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama quoted incorrectly from an e-mail message sent by a 38-year-old woman in South Carolina. In asking Mrs. Clinton how she represented change, the woman noted that she had never had the opportunity to vote in a presidential election in which a Bush or Clinton was not on the ticket; she did not say that she had only voted for a Bush or Clinton.

headline: Is the Faith-Based Initiative Working?
text: To the Editor:

headline: No Longer the Insurgent, McCain Courts Wary Party
text: BOSTON  He says he is not enough of a masochist to listen to Rush Limbaugh. He jokes at a Republican dinner about a looming foreign policy crisis: “I have a four-hour speech on the North Korean nuclear buildup that I know you’ve been waiting for.” And he still treats the media as his No. 1 constituency, plying them with nonstop talk and stories, like one about a date from his Navy days who cleaned her nails with a switchblade.

headline: What About Bill?
text: The fact that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to deploy Bill Clinton in California in advance of tomorrow’s most important primary is evidence enough that her campaign considers the former president a major asset  at least there and at least for now.

headline: As Candidates Scramble for Delegates, Connecticut Primary Gains Spotlight
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  On Tuesday, voters in 22 states will cast their ballots for a Democratic presidential candidate. Nearly 1,700 delegates are on the line, including hundreds in big states like California, New York and New Jersey.

headline: Helping to Keep Homelessness at Bay as Foreclosures Hit More Families
text: Staff Sgt. Sandra Rolon spent more than a year in Kuwait, managing food service operations at a military base as part of the 408th Personnel Service Battalion in the U.S. Army Reserve. She thought of her time there in 2004 as a way both to serve her country and to pursue a more personal goal: buying a home.

headline: Local Culture: Hong Kong’s Brushstrokes of Spring
text: My favorite part of Chinese New Year (February 7th, mark those calendars!) is the anticipatory build-up, the two weeks before the actual holiday. The shopping malls and buildings decorate their public spaces splendiforously, with inflatable lanterns as huge as Macy’s Thanksgiving Day balloons. The supermarkets, Wellcome and Park and Shop, start programming endless loops of Cantonese opera Muzak to get shoppers into the mood. My building caretaker, Mrs. Wong, pulls down the tattered Christmas tinsel and re-decorates the walls of the lobby with a red-and-gold extravaganza of fai cheun.

headline: A Super Sunday of Campaigning
text: The candidates raced to get their messages out to voters, even as many Americans turned their attention to football.

headline: Money: Then and Now
text: The 2008 presidential race has featured an early field of candidates in both parties, and a monumental block of early primaries. Those factors have produced an unprecedented level of fund-raising and spending in the year leading up to the election. President Bush, the only Republican candidate in 2004, was able to spend conservatively through 2003. A competitive field of Democratic candidates was reflected in earlier fund-raising and more aggressive spending through early 2003. Increased receipts may also be partly due to contribution limit increases. In 2004, individuals could give a candidate up to $2,000 in the primary; for 2008, the limit is $2,300.

headline: Democrats’ Long Battle May Benefit Republicans
text: The good news for the 2008 presidential candidates is that only hours remain in their torturous march across the Super Tuesday battlefield.

headline: Tears in the Beanpot
text: Along just in time to serve as therapy for distraught New England Patriots fans is Boston’s fabled Beanpot tournament

headline: Enough of What We Think, What Do You Think?
text: It’s time to get a little interactive here at Slap Shot.

headline: The Control Room
text: Behind the Scenes at the Democratic Debate in Los Angeles

headline: Monday: New York Fashion Week
text: Selections from the runways around New York.

headline: What, They Funny?
text: Mad magazine asked Pulitzer Prize-winning editorial cartoonists to draw on the theme of “Why George W. Bush Is in Favor of Global Warming.” Watch the slide show.

headline: ‘She Never Ate at Fatburger’
text: More of your “late night” comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: Super Bowl Ad Special
text: Among the funnier ads during the Super Bowl was Will Ferrell’s spot for Bud Light, as Jackie Moon from the forthcoming sports spoof “Semi-Pro.” What makes Moon moon over Bud Light? “A magical blend of barley, hops and delicious alcohol”:

headline: Who Gets the Credit?
text: This is more uplifting than writing: Who Gets the Blame?

headline: Pigging Out
text: Poke the pastry porker: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Google Works to Foil Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
text: Standing between a marriage of Microsoft and Yahoo may be the technology behemoth that has continually outsmarted them: Google.

headline: China’s Sinochem Buys Soco’s Yemen Field
text: Chinese state-owned oil trader Sinochem has bought Soco International‘s stake in a Yemen oil field for $465 million, the London-based oil explorer said on Monday.

headline: Judge Allows Additional Arguments in Suit Against Enron Bankers
text: A federal judge in Houston on Friday left open a sliver of hope for Enron investors suing big banks over their alleged roles in defrauding investors in the energy company’s collapse.

headline: RBC Chief Takes Home Smaller Slice of the Pie
text: Like many of his counterparts in the United States, Gordon Nixon, the Royal Bank of Canada‘s chief executive, took home a smaller bonus last year, but also exercised options worth 29 million Canadian dollars, the bank said Friday.

headline: Microsoft-Yahoo Media Roundup
text: The weekend was rife with media speculation about Microsoft‘s Yahoo bid and how it could play out. The San Francisco Chronicle wondered about the fates of “dozens” of overlapping Internet services at the two Web giants, and Reuters suggested that a combined Microsoft and Yahoo would be a “Noah’s Ark of a Web company” — one with two of everything. Vindu Goel, writing in the San Jose Mercury News, suggested that integration could be such a distraction that it works in favor of archrival Google.

headline: A.I.G. Chief Can’t Stop Looking Over His Shoulder
text: When Martin J. Sullivan, now 53, took over the world’s largest insurer, the American International Group, three years ago, the company was the target of multiple criminal and civil investigations and its books were in such disarray that its auditors refused to endorse them.

headline: V.C.s Ride D-Wave in $17 Million Round
text: D-Wave Systems of Vancouver has received $17 million to see if it’s possible to compute complex equations by studying the behavior of molecules. International Investment and Underwriting of Dublin led the round, which was the third round of funding for the company.

headline: China’s Sovereign Wealth Fund Said to Eye Stake in Fortescue
text: In China’s latest move to secure iron ore supplies, the country’s $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, the China Investment Corporation, and a coal mining company, the China Shenhua Group are reportedly in talks to take a sizable stake in Fortescue Metals, a major Australian iron ore producer.

headline: Yahoo Sale Could Be Bad for Minnows
text: For decades, Silicon Valley has been the land of eternal optimism and high anxiety, traits that pitch into overdrive anytime a seismic business event washes across the corporate and entrepreneurial landscape here – like, for example, Microsoft‘s blockbuster $45 billion bid for Yahoo on Friday.

headline: BHP May Need to Match Chinalco Bid for Rio
text: BHP Billiton, the world’s largest mining company, must raise its $127 billion bid for the Rio Tinto Group to at least match the price Aluminum Corporation of China paid for its stake, Bloomberg News reported citing investors and analysts.

headline: Icahn Is Said to Buy Stake in Penney
text: The investor Carl C. Icahn has gone shopping again, this time acquiring shares in the retailer J.C. Penney, according to press reports. While the exact size of his stake in the retailer is unknown, The Wall Street Journal said that Penney is now among Mr. Icahn’s five largest holdings, which could place it in the hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Bids Due for Northern Rock
text: Investors in the troubled British lender Northern Rock are expecting bids Monday from Richard Branson’s Virgin Group and an investment firm, Olivant Advisers. But, according to The Times of London and others, they shouldn’t be expecting a higher offer from Mr. Branson, despite warnings from two hedge fund shareholders that the current proposed offer is unsatisfactory.

headline: How Google Could Keep Yahoo From Microsoft
text: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, is offering Yahoo — and, it seems, anyone else — whatever help he can to make sure Yahoo isn’t swallowed by Microsoft.

headline: Massachusetts Accuses Merrill of Fraud

headline: Happiness at Work: Does it Matter?
text: Today’s guest post is written by Gretchen Rubin, who writes the popular blog, The Happiness Project. Ms. Rubin is also working on a book of the same title, which will be a memoir of the year she spent testing every principle, tip, theory and scientific study about happiness she could find, whether from Aristotle, St. Therese, Martin Seligman or Oprah. Prior to her foray into the world of happiness, Ms. Rubin had an impressive career as a lawyer, including clerking for a Supreme Court justice, Sandra Day O’Connor. She is also the author of three books, Power Money Fame Sex: A User’s Guide, Forty Ways to Look at JFK and Forty Ways to Look at Winston Churchill.

headline: Malone and Diller: 2 Deal-Makers, 2 Different Styles

If he isn’t flying off to Capri with his wife, the socialite and fashion designer Diane von Furstenberg, he is running his company, IAC/InterActiveCorp, from a sculptured $133 million tower designed by Frank Gehry on the Hudson River.

headline: Now That’s a Super Duper Bowl, New York
text: The New York papers, not surprisingly, provide heavy coverage of the Giants’ improbable 17-14 victory in the Super Bowl, which denied the New England Patriots (and their quarterback with the supermodel girlfriend, Tom Brady) a chance at historic perfection and gave the New York team its first Super Bowl championship since 1991. The New York Post praises them as “Supermen!” while The Daily News blares “Champs” on their front covers. Giants quarterback Eli Manning, arguably played more like Brady than Brady himself, and was awarded the most valuable player award only a year after his older brother, Peyton Manning, won it while leading the Indianapolis Colts to the championship.The newspapers dissect the heart-stopping game (the lead switched three times during the final quarter). The Patriots defense crumbled in the fourth quarter, which proved telling given that the Giants’ aggressive defense shut down what was perhaps the best offense in the history of football. While the Giants were universally deemed the underdog, Plaxico Burress, who caught the game-winning touchdown, exhibited prescience in his pre-game prediction of a low-scoring game with a small margin of victory in favor of the Giants (off by the winning margin, off by the exact score, but close enough that everyone is praising him). The Giants had walked away with a sense of confidence and strategy after their 38-35 loss to the Patriots in December, feeling perhaps they knew how to beat the undefeated Patriots.

headline: McCain Plans Two Days of Campaigning Here

Mr. McCain, who is scheduled to lead a rally at his New Jersey campaign headquarters in Hamilton, N.J., at noon today, will hold a 3 p.m. news conference at Grand Central Terminal. Then at 7 a.m. Tuesday, Mr. McCain is scheduled to appear with former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for a rally at Rockefeller Center Plaza. The candidates for the Democratic nomination are also in the New York region today.

headline: The End of Something
text: There’s been talk here about what “The Moviegoer” generated. But I think it’s also worth considering how it represents the end of something. As we’ve seen, Aunt Emily — standing in for William Alexander Percy — stands for the end of the Southern Way, for a certain noblesse oblige that had already been swept aside by history by the time the book was written, and which Percy can only salute in passing. And Binx himself represents a certain kind of self-conscious Southern protagonist who isn’t quite an anti-hero but is self-conscious, well aware of his limitations and foibles — if he doesn’t in fact revel in them. He’s wounded and he knows it and he loves himself for it — he’s a noble Confederate junior officer ill-equipped for life in the squalid Union, and proud of it. He too has been swept away by the tides of progress — and Percy’s later fiction, from the perfectly-titled “The Last Gentleman” on, bears witness to his noble, doomed trajectory.

headline: A Love Poem to New Orleans
text: I hate to turn every discussion of “The Moviegoer” into a discussion about New Orleans. It minimizes Walker Percy to perceive him as purely a Southern writer, or someone who just happened to write the greatest book about the city. But I can’t resist pointing out in this final posting just how much of a love poem this book is to New Orleans, which could use one just about right now. “The streetlights make golden spaces inside the wet leaves of the live oaks,” he writes, describing a parade night Uptown. “A south wind carries the smell of coffee from the Tchoupitoulas docks.” Here’s Percy on nightfall in Gentilly: “The sky is a deep bright ocean full of light and life. A mare’s tail of cirrus cloud stands in high from the Gulf. High above the Lake a broken vee of ibises points for the marshes; they go suddenly white as they fly into the tilting salient of sunlight.”

headline: Troubles in Ireland
