headline: Murdoch Boasts: ‘Greatest Day Ever In The History Of Our Network’
text: Rupert Murdoch, the chief executive of the News Corporation, took what would seem to be a well-deserved victory lap today, one day after the Super Bowl delivered record ratings for Fox.

headline: Cupcakes for Candidates
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Nooooooo!!!
text: Via Duncan Black, Clinton’s people think this might go to the convention.

headline: Hollweg Is Suspended, and Rangers Are Unapologetic for Tough Game
text: The N.H.L. handed down an automatic one-game suspension for Rangers’ forward Ryan Hollweg, whose five-minute boarding penalty against Montreal forward Sergei Kostitsyn follows another five-minute major against Edmonton earlier this month. That means he will sit out Tuesday’s game against Los Angeles at Madison Square Garden.

headline: What About Bill?
text: In her Web column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes, “As long as the audience is Democrats, the Clinton camp firmly sees Mr. Clinton as more of a help than a hindrance. But if Mrs. Clinton goes on to win the Democratic nomination, you may see her campaign rethink how it uses Mr. Clinton as it appeals to a broader audience. Depending on what happens, Mrs. Clinton may even find herself considering a ‘Bill’ speech, not unlike Mitt Romney’s ‘Mormon’ speech or J.F.K.’s ‘Catholic’ speech.

headline: Ignore His Wife, Please
text: Well, as much as Bill Clinton enjoys the limelight, he might be glad to have one of the other candidates’ spouses in hot water for a change. On today’s “Good Morning America,” Michelle Obama said she’d have to “think about” whether she would actively support Hillary Clinton should Barack Obama go down to defeat in the primary campaign.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Thakoon
text: The Fashion Telex: In which the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file almost-real-time dispatches from the show of the moment.

headline: Recipe: Asian Chicken Salad
text: This chicken salad has only one thing — chicken — in common with the familiar variety. Here, grilled or broiled chicken is combined with a super-flavorful dressing based on soy sauce, peanut or sesame butter, spices and cucumber for crunch.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Halston
text: (Getty Images for IMG)

headline: At Long Last, the Dinkins Papers Are Ready
text: The official archives of David N. Dinkins, New York’s first African American mayor, are complete, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is announcing this evening at a reception honoring Black History Month at Gracie Mansion.

headline: Clinton Leading Among the Unpledged
text: Updated | Feb. 4 Heading into Tuesday’s nominating contests, many of the unpledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention are still undecided, but more who have made up their minds are expressing support for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton than for Senator Barack Obama, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.

headline: Romney Ad Ties McCain to Clinton
text: Mitt Romney, trailing John McCain in the latest polls, has put out a last-minute negative ad ahead of Super Tuesday.

headline: When Super Tuesday Wasn’t Decisive: 1988
text: If the contest between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination stretches past Super Tuesday, with a state-by-state battle for delegates that lasts well into the spring, election historians and political analysts might do well to look back at 1988, when a large field of contenders sought the Democratic presidential nomination, leading to a protracted battle for delegates that lasted for months.

headline: Why Conservatives Don’t Like McCain
text: In my job as associate editor at The Weekly Standard, I must get half a dozen e-mails a day from conservative readers who say they will never vote for John McCain for president. Conservative talk radio hosts and bloggers raise the idea that they will not support Senator McCain if he is the Republican nominee in the fall — even if that means a Clinton Restoration. When Senator McCain speaks at this year’s Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in a couple of weeks, it’s likely he’ll be booed in person, just as he was booed in absentia last year. Loudly.

headline: The Worst Super Bowl Ad
text: My vote for the most repellent Super Bowl commercial wasn’t the disgorged heart on the keyboard, the vomiting baby, or the fat guy with the jumper cables on his nipples.

headline: A Romney Son Takes His Pitch to Campus
text: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J. – Looking as youthful as the Monmouth University college students to whom he spoke, Craig Romney, son of Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney was unfailingly polite as he vouched for his father’s character Monday afternoon.

headline: ‘House’ Enjoys The Post-Bowl Time Slot
text: The minutes immediately following the Super Bowl are some of the most valuable on television. With nearly 100 million viewers watching, broadcast networks have used the time slot has been used to debut new shows and prop up existing franchises.

headline: Find Polling Places, and Share Voting Stories
text: And now it’s up to the voters.

headline: Better Late . . .
text: Now they tell us.

text: Fashion insiders reveal how to survive New York Fashion Week -- if you can get in.

text: Cavemen return to the modern world of advertising

headline: One Day to Go
text: On the eve of Tuesday’s nominating contests, candidates tried to reach as many voters as possible, all over the country.

headline: Knight’s Complicated Legacy
text: Bob Knight abruptly resigned as Texas Tech’s coach on Monday, a move that seemingly brings to an end the career of the winningest men’s basketball coach in Division I history.

headline: Solar City to Rise in Persian Gulf; Why Not Arizona?
text: The push to find ways to build not just buildings, but communities — even small cities — with low environmental impacts is under way, although mainly outside the United States, it seems. Ever since I stumbled onto the fascinating Web site www.inhabitat.com, I’ve been assembling a list of large-scale projects designed for negligible fossil-fuel use and emissions of greenhouse gases, access to mass transit, and other environmental and social attributes.

headline: Bloggingheads: McCain on Virtue
text:
Matt Welch, author of a book on John McCain, discusses Mr. McCain's values system with blogger Will Wilkinson.
Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Hollywood Hopes For Strike Settlement Soon
text: “From the picket lines to ballrooms filled with stars, Hollywood on Monday hoped for a deal to end a 3-month-old clash between striking writers and studios amid reports they could reach an agreement this week,” Reuters reports.

headline: Super Tuesday: Hallmark Channel Televises Hour-Long Clinton Commercial
text: Using an hour of prime time on the Hallmark Channel Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton hosted a national town hall on Monday, hours before primary elections in more than 20 states.

headline: Spectrum Auction: A New Bidder Emerges For the C Block
text: It’s not over.

headline: An Estate With Mustique
text: At the very least, an estate for sale on the private island of Mustique ranks high on the cool meter.

headline: Child or Caveman?
text: Nearly everyone has witnessed the toddler meltdown — that moment in a store, restaurant or airplane when a once-happy child loses it. He screams, cries and flails as his embarrassed parents desperately try to calm him.

headline: For the Moment | Hana Soukupova
text: This week’s guest blogger is the 22-year-old supermodel Hana Soukupova, who has been treading catwalks since she was 13. Soukupova is the face of Gucci Envy, she appears in the current Gap campaign, and she has closed shows for such designers as Valentino, John Galliano, Dior, Celine, Gucci, Michael Kors, Roberto Cavalli, Alexander McQueen, Calvin Klein, Donna Karen and Zac Posen. But at The Moment, we love her for her sharp eye, which is why we slipped a digital camera into her handbag and asked her to cover Fashion Week through the lens of a model.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Proenza Schouler
text: (Getty Images for IMG)

headline: New York Central
text: Whenever I go to some black-tie affair at the Waldorf, I leave thinking of my father, Eugene Horyn, an ex-newspaperman. I can’t help it. He loved all that big-city stuff, and I don’t take any of it for granted even when my shoes feel too small. I went to the Waldorf tonight because Bill Cunningham was being honored, among others, by the Citizens Committee for New York, and the Times took two tables.

headline: Creating Those Hallmark Moments
text: SAN FRANCISCO –- Never mind the Kennedy dynasty. The Clinton family offered Hallmark moments to millions of voters across the nation Monday night during a 90-minute town hall meeting simultaneously streamed over the Web and on cable TV.

headline: Plenty of Reaction to Knight’s Resignation
text: As news of the retirement of Texas Tech Coach Bobby Knight spread throughout college basketball, there has been an outpouring of reaction. Here’s a sampling of what people around the game think about Knight and his legacy.

headline: Zombies and Scrabble Knock-Offs to Invade MySpace
text: MySpace is about to join Facebook, Bebo, Meebo and so many other stars in the Web 2.0 firmament in opening up its platform and giving developers a set of tools with which to build applications that can run, and make money, on its site.

headline: Dickensian Happenings for a Child of the ’60s
text: Peter Carey’s novels  from the Booker Prize winners “Oscar and Lucinda” and “True History of the Kelly Gang” through recent ones like “My Life as a Fake” and “Theft”  tend to feature improbable undertakings, sudden reversals of fortune and elaborately manufactured or forged identities. Most of his characters inhabit a boldly colored limbo land somewhere on the great fiction map between Dickens’s world of improbable coincidences and the old-fashioned world of the picaresque, where odd happenings and even odder people are strung together willy-nilly into rollicking, improvisatory tales.

headline: Footnotes
text: Sylvester Stallone, below, who has achieved new popularity in “Rambo,” has signed an agreement to direct and star in two more action films for the same producers, Reuters reported. Last year “Rocky Balboa,” the sixth of Mr. Stallone’s “Rocky” films, grossed $70 million and cost an estimated $24 million. ... The seventh annual Tribeca Film Festival will take place from April 23 to May 4. Tickets will be priced at $15 for evening and weekend screenings and $8 for daytime weekday and late night screenings. Some screenings, with panel discussions, will be priced at $25; and ticket packages, will also be available. Information: tribecafilmfestival.org.

headline: Anna Netrebko Is Expecting
text: The soprano Anna Netrebko,  pregnant and engaged, has withdrawn from this summer’s Salzburg Festival, Agence France-Presse reported. She was scheduled to sing at the festival opposite the tenor Rolando Villazón in Gounod’s “Romeo and Juliet.” Ms. Netrebko, 36, a Russian-born Austrian citizen (right, with her finacé, the Uruguayan-born baritone Erwin Schrott, 35), is in Vienna, filming Puccini’s “Bohème” with Mr. Villazón as her leading man. She also was to sing in Massenet’s “Manon,” opening on April 4 at the Vienna State Opera, The Associated Press reported. Her manager, Jeffrey Vanderveen, said she “will keep her engagements as long as her doctors permit it.” Helga Rabl-Stadler, president of the Salzburg Festival, said: “The nicest reason for a cancellation is a child. Anna will receive the most beautiful bouquet of flowers from us.” The Metropolitan Opera said Ms. Netrebko has withdrawn from 10 performances of its revival of “Lucia di Lammermoor,” beginning Oct. 3, but said her seven performances in Massenet’s “Manon” in December and January remained undecided.

headline: Will the Capital of Change Choose Change or Experience?
text: San Francisco

headline: Saying Baseball Is in Turmoil? Don’t Be So Sure
text: Maybe it’s a cultural thing. Maybe something is lost in the transition.

headline: As a Japanese Island Grows Less Remote, a Wildcat Grows More Endangered
text: IRIOMOTE ISLAND, Japan  The Iriomote wildcat is said to have roamed this small, subtropical island in the East China Sea for 200,000 years, but proved so elusive that it was not discovered until 1967. To this day, many islanders have never seen the wildcat, and some even stubbornly deny its existence.

headline: Sexually Transmitted Diseases Common in Australian Aborigines, Report Shows
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Sexually transmitted diseases have spread so widely in some Aboriginal communities that mass treatment without individual testing, even for children as young as 10, is the only way to fight the problem, according to a medical paper published Monday.

headline: Nostrums: Aspirin May Reduce Risk of Colon Cancer
text: Aspirin may help reduce the risk of colon cancer, a new study suggests, when taken in large doses over long periods of time.

headline: The Associated Press Delegate Count
text: The Associated Press count of delegates includes projections based on non-binding votes for candidate preference, such as in the Iowa caucuses. On the Democratic side, the A.P. count also includes a tally of unpledged superdelegates that the news organization has independently surveyed.

headline: Obama Wins Georgia in Night’s 1st Prize
text: Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is projected to easily defeat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Georgia, the first of 21 Democratic Super Tuesday contests to be decided, capitalizing on large margins among young and African-American voters.

headline: Amgen Sells Drug Rights and Unit in Japan
text: The chief executive of Amgen said Monday that the company’s decision to sell Japanese distribution rights to many of the drugs in its pipeline was not solely a response to financial pressures caused by the decline in sales of Amgen’s flagship anemia drugs.

headline: Primary Day
text: NEW YORK

headline: Greene to Retire
text: Maurice Greene, the former Olympic and world champion in the 100 meters, announced Monday that he was retiring. He cited nagging injuries for his decision. “It’s a little sad for me but it’s happy at the same time because I’ve had a great career,” Greene, 33, said. “For the last couple of years, I’ve had nagging injuries that have stopped my training. So I think it’s better to just call it quits.”Greene was the top sprinter of the late 1990s and early 2000s. He set a then world record for the 100 meters in 1999 (9.79 seconds) and won the 100 at the Sydney Games in 2000. He still holds the indoor 60-meter world record at 6.39 seconds.

headline: Candidates Blitz States as Big Day Looms
text: The presidential candidates from both parties campaigned frenetically on Monday, making their final pushes with a series of rallies and blitzes of television commercials for a last bout of November-style campaigning before more than 20 states vote in Tuesday’s virtual national primary.

headline: North Carolina: Missing Hiker’s Body Found
text: A body found in western North Carolina is a missing hiker believed to be a victim of the man who pleaded guilty in a Georgia killing, a sheriff said. The skeletal remains found Saturday by a hunter in Macon County were identified as belonging to John Bryant, who disappeared in October with his wife, Irene, while they were hiking in the Pisgah National Forest, Sheriff David Mahoney of Transylvania County said. Irene Bryant’s body was found near a hiking trail in November. Sheriff Mahoney has said he believes the person responsible for their deaths is Gary M. Hilton, 61, who pleaded guilty last week to murdering a hiker in Georgia. After that plea, Mr. Hilton was immediately sentenced to life in prison with the possibility of parole after 30 years.

headline: Time Runs Out for an Afghan Held by the U.S.
text: KABUL, Afghanistan  Abdul Razzaq Hekmati was regarded here as a war hero, famous for his resistance to the Russian occupation in the 1980s and later for a daring prison break he organized for three opponents of the Taliban government in 1999.

headline: U.N. Urges Outside Help for Chad
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council adopted a statement on Monday condemning attacks by rebels seeking to overthrow the government of Chad and urging other countries to help stop the violence.

headline: Texas: F.B.I. Joins Case of Child Found in Trash Bin
text: Nearly five years after the emaciated body of a little boy was found in a trash bin in Houston, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has joined the case, releasing an autopsy photograph and a sketch, left, of the child’s face and increasing the reward for information to $25,000. The victim was possibly Hispanic, between 3 and 6 years old, with a surgical scar on his neck suggesting possible hospitalization and two scars on his abdomen, the F.B.I. said. He was wearing a disposable diaper and was wrapped in a gray blanket inside a red-and-white checkered plastic bag. The cause of death was malnutrition and dehydration, but the autopsy found no signs of other abuse or injuries, the F.B.I. said. The public appeal was born of desperation, Andrew R. Bland III, the bureau’s special agent in charge of the Houston Division, acknowledged. “Quite frankly,” he said, “this is a cold case.”

headline: Joshua Lederberg, 82, a Nobel Winner, Dies
text: Joshua Lederberg, one of the 20th century’s leading scientists, whose work in bacterial genetics had vast medical implications and led to his receiving a Nobel Prize in 1958, died on Saturday. He was 82 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

headline: Suitor Ends Bid for Northern Rock
text: LONDON  Olivant Advisers, one of two possible suitors for Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, dropped out of the bidding on Monday, saying it had failed to devise an offer that would satisfy both it and the government.

headline: Study Finds Prior Trauma Raised Children’s 9/11 Risk
text: Preschoolers who witnessed the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center or saw its victims were at high risk of developing lingering emotional and behavior problems if  but only if  they had had a previous frightening experience, like seeing a parent fall ill, researchers are reporting Tuesday.

headline: Relatives Say Victims of Illinois Shooting Were First Bound
text: TINLEY PARK, Ill.  Relatives of the only survivor of a weekend shooting here that left five women dead inside a clothing store told a Kentucky newspaper that all of the women inside the shop had been bound and then shot in the back of their heads.

headline: New DVDs
text: SHADOWS OF FORGOTTEN ANCESTORS

headline: A Trader’s Secrets, a Bank’s Missteps
text: PARIS  The first e-mail message arrived in Société Générale’s offices on Nov. 7. The surveillance office at Eurex, one of Europe’s biggest exchanges, alerted a compliance officer at the bank that for seven months a trader named Jérôme Kerviel had engaged in not just one but “several transactions” that had raised red flags.

headline: Human Viruses Cause Respiratory Outbreaks in Ivory Coast Chimps
text: Wild populations of chimpanzees and other great apes are in trouble in many areas, mostly because of hunting and loss of habitat. Conservationists know that other activities, like research and ecological tourism, can help by suppressing poaching and providing an alternative source of income for local people.

headline: Selling Us Ice in the Winter
text: Here is how nutty fashion can make you. Racing home from the Bryant Park tents on Sunday, intent on tuning in to the Super Bowl, this reporter clicked the remote just in time to see Tom Brady being sacked by Michael Strahan, and the first thought that came to mind was not, “The Giants might actually win this thing.” It was, “Those uniforms look just like Martin Margiela’s collection for fall.”

headline: McCain Leads the Field, but Shuns Talk of Victory
text: Senator John McCain has been an edgy front-runner in recent days, pumped up by crowds and in near disbelief about national polls showing him racing ahead of Mitt Romney, but still visibly jumpy that something could go terribly wrong. And he would know.

headline: Bold Prints and Shoulders Above the Rest
text: You can’t blame the fine mess that designers served up on Sunday on their rushing home to watch the Super Bowl. They’ve been working on their fall collections for weeks. So let’s blame Brancusi. He did it. And while we’re at it, don’t even mention Bobby Kennedy. What in the name of Butterick does he have to do with a dress in 2008?

headline: New York
text: In New York City and the counties of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland, Orange, Putnam and Erie, the polls open at 6 a.m. and close at 9 p.m. In all other counties, the polls open at noon and close at 9 p.m. Three polling places in New York City  45 Wall Street, 90 Trinity Place and 31 Chambers Street  will be affected by the ticker-tape parade for the New York Giants. The Board of Elections said the polls would remain open, and the police will assist voters entering polling places.Voters who experience problems in New York City can call 212-VOTE-NYC or 866-VOTE-NYC. Outside New York City, voters can call their county Board of Elections or the State Board of Elections at (518) 474-1953.

headline: An Altar Beyond Olympus for a Deity Predating Zeus
text: PHILADELPHIA  Before Zeus hurled his first thunderbolt from Olympus, the pre-Greek people occupying the land presumably paid homage and offered sacrifices to their own gods and goddesses, whose nature and identities are unknown to scholars today.

headline: Banking Stem Cells (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Meet the New Mitt Romney, the Anti-Insider Populist
text: ATLANTA  Mitt Romney is leading a citizen revolution, or at least that is what he has been telling people these last few days as he has tries to right his bid for the Republican nomination.

headline: BHP Weighs Options in Rio Tinto Bid
text: BEIJING  The world’s biggest mining company, BHP Billiton, must decide by Wednesday whether it will proceed with a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group, after China intervened with a strategic investment that could sharply increase the price of what would be one of the biggest mergers in corporate history.

headline: Europe’s Central Banker Engineers His Economics
text: FRANKFURT  The day after the Federal Reserve’s emergency interest rate cut two weeks ago, Jean-Claude Trichet went before the European Parliament to deliver perhaps the most eagerly awaited speech of his four years as president of the European Central Bank.

headline: Longer Drug Regimen Found to Help Babies Avoid H.I.V.
text: BOSTON  Over recent years, giving an antiretroviral drug to a woman infected with the AIDS virus in labor and to her baby at birth has reduced the risk of transmitting the virus to the baby.

headline: Pursuing Synthetic Life, Dazzled by Reality
text: When scientists announced on Jan. 24 that they had reconstituted the complete set of genes for a microbe using just a few bottles of chemicals, the feat was hailed as a kind of shining Nike moment in the field of synthetic biology, the attempt to piece together living organisms from inert scratch.

headline: Intelligence Chief Cites Qaeda Threat to U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  Michael McConnell, the director of national intelligence, said on Tuesday that Al Qaeda is improving its ability to attack within the United States by recruiting and training new operatives. At the same time, he said, a terrorist group in Iraq that claims allegiance to Al Qaeda is beginning to send militants to other countries.

headline: Satellite Spotters Glimpse Secrets, and Tell Them
text: When the government announced last month that a top-secret spy satellite would, in the next few months, come falling out of the sky, American officials said there was little risk to people because satellites fall out of orbit fairly frequently and much of the planet is covered by oceans.

headline: Processing of Iraqi Refugees Remains Slow, U.S. Says
text: WASHINGTON  Last year the Bush administration vowed to find a way to accelerate the processing of immigrant visas and the granting of refugee status so that Iraqis who worked for the American Embassy in Baghdad could immigrate to the United States. But a State Department update on the issue on Monday showed that a gap remains between words and action.

headline: In Single File, Berio’s Menagerie on Parade
text: The New York Philharmonic is paying a great deal of attention this season to the Italian avant-garde composer Luciano Berio, who died in 2003. Last week Lorin Maazel delivered a commanding account of “Sinfonia,” a tumultuous 1969 work for orchestra with amplified voices. Still ahead are performances of Berio’s “Folk Songs” (in March) and “Rendering” (in May).

headline: A Coach’s About-Face Transforms a Team
text: Glendale, Ariz.

headline: Symptoms: Metabolic Syndrome Is Tied to Diet Soda
text: Researchers have found a correlation between drinking diet soda and metabolic syndrome  the collection of risk factors for cardiovascular disease and diabetes that include abdominal obesity, high cholesterol and blood glucose levels, and elevated blood pressure.

headline: Car-Free, Solar City in Gulf Could Set a New Standard for Green Design
text: In an ever more crowded world facing environmental limits, the push is on to create entire communities with reduced needs for energy, water, land and other resources.

headline: Barry Morse, Who Played the Dogged Detective in ‘The Fugitive,’ Is Dead at 89
text: Barry Morse, famous for his portrayal of the cold-hearted detective who relentlessly pursues the wrongly convicted Richard Kimble for four seasons in “The Fugitive,” one of the biggest TV hits of the 1960s, died Saturday in London. He was 89.

headline: Webb to Run in New York
text: Alan Webb, the American record-holder in the mile, will run his first race of the year March 15 in the Central Park Challenge, the New York Road Runners announced. The race will also serve as the United States 8-kilometer men’s championship. The Road Runners said a women’s 8K (4.97 miles) invitational race for top American and international runners would precede the men’s race. The total prize money will be at least $70,000, plus $10,000 to anyone who establishes a United States 8K record.

headline: A Chronic Case of Make-Believe
text: Here is an idea I came up with in the too-short turnaround between Super Sunday and Super Tuesday: Let's re-deploy and mix and match all the sports and political pundits and see if anyone can tell the difference. The ability to be flagrantly wrong, after all, is a skill set that ought to travel particularly well to new and unfamiliar territory.

headline: Comments Could Draw Sanctions
text: Formula One’s governing body, FIA, said the racial abuse aimed at Lewis Hamilton, Formula One’s first black driver, during testing in Barcelona, Spain, over the weekend could result in sanctions.Under FIA’s statutes, punishment can include removing races from the Grand Prix calendar. The Spanish Grand Prix is April 27 in Barcelona, and the European GP at Valencia, Spain, is Aug. 24.Formula One said it could take legal action against the spectators involved in the taunts.

headline: Bush’s Final Budget Hints at Tough Choices Ahead
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s final budget, a $3 trillion plan offered Monday that would continue his tax cuts and sharply reduce domestic spending, has little chance of surviving in a Democratic Congress. But the problems it lays out will survive and grow, presenting tough choices for the next administration.

headline: Britain: Prison for 5 Who Helped Failed London Bombers
text: Five men were convicted by a suburban London court of assisting in the failed terrorist attack on London’s transportation system on July 21, 2005, which sought to repeat the attacks that on July 7 that killed 52 people. The five  all Muslim immigrants from Africa between 25 and 30  were sentenced to prison terms from 7 to 17 years for providing safe houses, passports, clothing and food after bombs planted in three subway stations and on a bus failed to explode. The two given the longest sentences, 12 and 17 years, were found guilty of knowing about the plot in advance. The court found that one lived above the “bomb factory” and helped dump incriminating evidence, including empty bottles of hydrogen peroxide, used in making the bombs, in bins outside his apartment complex. The judge, Paul Worsley, said laws setting the maximum sentences he imposed were “woefully inadequate for the enormity” of the plot. Four bomb-carriers in the failed attack were sentenced to life last year.

headline: A Heartfelt Appeal for a Graceful Exit
text: After reading the Personal Health column on Nov. 27 on preventing geriatric suicide, Gloria C. Phares, a 93-year-old retired teacher in Missouri, wrote:

headline: States Prepare for Tests of Changes to Voting System
text: After California ordered a switch to paper ballots from touch-screen voting machines for Tuesday’s primary, election officials in the sprawling, 7,200-square-mile Riverside County had to decide the best way to pick up the ballots so they could be centrally counted on time: helicopter or truck?

headline: They Might Be Champions: One Last Drive of Conviction
text: PHOENIX  The Giants stood 83 yards from the lead, trailing an unbeaten team by 4 points with only 2 minutes 39 seconds left in Super Bowl XLII. Defensive players paced the sideline shouting one-word directions: Believe.

headline: Correction
text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 26 about Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at the French bank Société Générale, misstated the number of workers dismissed in connection with the scandal. Only one of the employees mentioned  Luc François, global head of equities and derivatives activities  will leave or move to another position as a result of the investigation. Two other employees, Marc Breillout and Grégoire Varenne, left for reasons unrelated to the scandal and a third, Christophe Mianné, remains at Société Générale  they were not dismissed as a result of the Kerviel inquiry.

headline: The Claim: Menstrual Cycles Can Synchronize Over Time
text: THE FACTS

headline: Ukraine Joins the W.T.O.
text: MOSCOW  Ukraine joined the World Trade Organization on Tuesday after 14 years of negotiations, a milestone for the former Soviet state that helps clear the way for a valuable free trade agreement with the European Union.

headline: Their Status Preserved, Dolphins Breathe Easy
text: MIAMI  Some members of the 1972 Miami Dolphins say they have been described as grumpy old men a little too often for openly rooting against the New England Patriots to join them in completing an unbeaten season. So after the Patriots lost to the Giants on Sunday in Super Bowl XLII, Manny Fernandez decided to be as grumpy as he wanted to be.

headline: Tar Heels Pull Away From Duke in Game and A.C.C.
text: DURHAM, N.C.  The stakes are often high and the emotions always intense when Duke and North Carolina renew their rivalry on the basketball court. And that usually makes for a classic showdown between the teams, whether the men or the women are playing.

headline: Study Suggests That, Unlike in the ’70s, Energy Lessons Will Last
text: The oil shocks of the 1970s produced a flurry of attention to alternative sources of energy, but it faded once prices dropped in the mid-1980s. Now, with oil prices again high and climate change moving up the list of public concerns, interest in alternative energy is once again at fever pitch.

headline: Turkish Planes Strike Iraqi Kurdistan
text: BAGHDAD  Turkish warplanes bombed villages in Iraqi Kurdistan on Monday as the Kurds came under pressure on several fronts. Representatives in Parliament discussed the Kurdish share of the budget, and the Turkmen, a minority group primarily in northern Iraq, declared that they would no longer support efforts to hold a referendum on whether the city of Kirkuk should join the Kurdistan region.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A front-page Inside summary on Saturday about Exxon Mobil’s record $40.6 billion in net income misstated, in some editions, the period that the profit covered. It was for the year, not for the quarter.

headline: Physicists Hope U.S. Budget Will Mean an End to Research Cuts
text: Under President Bush’s proposed federal budget announced on Monday, research in the physical sciences would receive a hefty boost.

headline: Facing Far Bigger Crowds, Obama Strikes a New Note
text: HARTFORD  These days, Senator Barack Obama leads his own applause.

headline: Thousands Flee Fighting in Chad’s Capital
text: NDJAMENA, Chad  Shelling and small arms fire erupted here in this capital on Monday, the third day of fighting between government troops and rebel forces, as thousands of residents fled the city in fear, the United Nations said.

headline: Google and Microsoft Take Up Battle Stations
text: WASHINGTON  It could be payback time.

headline: What Were You Expecting, Mr. Milquetoast, a Plot?
text: O.K., so you represent nothing, speak directly to the audience and have dispensed with plot, character and the rest of those phony conventions of the theater. I get it. And I also see that as a member of the audience, I am in the cross-fire. The subject is me. But here’s my question for the long line of young performers who take turns blowing the minds of any square from the 1960s who just arrived downtown from a time machine: Why are you so adorable?

headline: Bob Knight Resigns as Coach of Texas Tech
text: Bob Knight, who won more games than any men’s coach in major college basketball history, unexpectedly resigned from Texas Tech on Monday.

headline: Principles of Fair Lending
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Jersey
text: Polls open at 6 a.m. and close at 8 p.m. Voters with problems can call 1-877-NJVOTER.

headline: Boston Scientific Posts Loss, but Sales Beat Expectations
text: With a lift from the falling dollar and better-than-expected sales in several divisions, Boston Scientific has delivered a pleasant earnings surprise to its long-suffering shareholders.

headline: Exuberant Beethoven, Mild-Mannered Baroque
text: Women in high office are becoming such a nonissue that listeners could visit Xian Zhang conducting the Orchestra of St. Luke’s on Sunday afternoon and just listen. Being female and Chinese in the classical music business are helpful in getting yourself noticed, but careers are built  and this one is building fast  on substance. Ms. Zhang has it.

headline: Many Democrats Still Wavering on a Choice
text: Voters jumping and hollering in stadiums and town squares in last-minute rallies intended not to convince anyone but to fire up the true believers. Thousands of people standing in snaking lines in Connecticut, hoping to register to vote or change their party affiliations.

headline: A Victory for Same-Sex Marriage
text: In a decision at once common-sensical and profound, a New York State appeals court ruled Friday that same-sex marriages validly performed in other jurisdictions are entitled to recognition in New York. It was common sense because it simply accorded same-sex marriages the same legal status as other marriages. It was profound because of the way it could transform the lives of gay people.

headline: An Imperfectly Good Question: What to Do Now?
text: PHOENIX  At the end, the sheen of dominance the New England Patriots had acquired during their spectacular regular season was replaced by the vacant stares of the shocked. Last year, when the Patriots lost to the Colts in the final moments of the American Football Conference championship game, they were devastated, but the loss spurred them to an off-season personnel blitzkrieg and a perfect regular season.

headline: Bush Presents Budget That Would Increase Deficit
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush sent Congress a $3.1 trillion budget on Monday that would increase military spending and curb the growth of Medicare and Medicaid but raise the federal deficit by nearly $250 billion, a major setback for a president who is trying to restore his credentials as a fiscal conservative.

headline: Learning Online
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marvel. Wonder. Bliss.
text: PHOENIX -- Perhaps it was inevitable, given the stakes and the presence of thousands of Giants and Patriots fans side by side, that some of the energy in the 64,000-seat University of Phoenix Stadium would funnel into the intense Boston-New York sports rivalry. Chants of "18-1" increased Sunday night as the Giants' Super Bowl upset became secure, a mockery reminiscent of the "1918" chant Yankee fans inflicted for so many year on their Red Sox counterparts. There were predictable retorts: "Yankees Stink", or its equivalent. When they played "New York, New York" over the loudspeaker after the award presentation, it must have reminded New Englanders of the swagger that accompanied so many Yankee victories over the years.

headline: Where Victory Is Routine, Surprise of Giants’ Comeback Sweetens Super Bowl Triumph
text: In this town, a sports championship usually consists of the Yankees winning in October. Which is to say, another year to hang on the stadium walls, another ticker-tape parade.

headline: Clemens Answers Panel’s Questions
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens, one of baseball’s most dominant pitchers, emerged from an almost five-hour deposition before Congress on Tuesday afternoon repeating his denials of ever using steroids or human-growth hormone and thanking Congressional investigators for the chance to say so under oath.

headline: ... and There’s More
text: In The Times today, Harvey Araton writes about the remodeled and softer Tom Coughlin; David Picker visits Montclair High School in New Jersey, the school attended by Giants hero David Tyree, who made only five catches in the regular season but the biggest one of the Super Bowl; and Judy Battista examines the blockbuster 2004 trade for Eli Manning -- looks like that worked out well.

headline: Philadelphia Sues HUD, Citing Threat of Losing Aid
text: The director of the Philadelphia Housing Authority has accused the federal housing secretary of ordering the city to turn over a $2 million property to a politically connected developer, then threatening to withhold millions of dollars in federal aid after his directive was refused, according to a federal lawsuit filed by the city.

headline: Mired in Crisis, Italy Veers Toward Elections
text: ROME  Italy seemed headed toward elections after the Senate president said Monday that he could not find enough support in Parliament to form a temporary government that would fix the nation’s flawed electoral law.

headline: Pettitte Remains Quiet After Giving Deposition
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens is set to give congressional investigators a sworn deposition about performance-enhancing drugs Tuesday, after Andy Pettitte talked with them for two and a half hours Monday.

headline: Judge Reinstates Rules on Sonar, Criticizing Bush’s Waiver for Navy
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A federal judge in California on Monday reinstated a series of provisions meant to protect whales from high-powered sonar during military exercises in the Pacific Ocean.

headline: A Place With Some History
text: Not long ago, historic hotels were often a little frayed at the edges, spurned for fresher alternatives like the trendy boutique hotels.

headline: The Pursuit of Perfection as a Futile and Worthy Quest
text: For a new evening of work, the choreographer Colleen Thomas, who usually collaborates with Bill Young, struck out on her own to produce a pair of dances vastly different in tone but similar in their adherence to binding structure and exacting details. The approach is less pedantic than it sounds. In “Winning You With Words (this is how we fall),” the more original of the two, Ms. Thomas attacks notions of perfection, yet what remains long after the echo of language subsides is the way she uses bodies like punctuation.

headline: Super Sunday: And the Giants Decide It!
text: To the Editor:

headline: Taking the Steps
text: In separate races Tuesday, 160 men and 64 women will sprint from the lobby of the Empire State Building to the 86th-floor observation deck in the 31st annual Empire State Building Run-Up, covering 1,576 steps along the way. “I run it just for fun,” said Suzy Walsham, a world-class runner in the 800 and 1,500 meters who won last year’s women’s race. “But it’s not that much fun while I’m running it. But once you get to the top, it’s an amazing view.”Thomas Dold, a 23-year-old economics student from Germany, is the defending men’s champion.

headline: Connecticut Sees Surge of Voters for Primary
text: NEW HAVEN  Seth Poole, a guidance counselor who lives in this Democratic-leaning city, never thought much about his voter-registration status: unaffiliated.

headline: Wikipedia Islam Entry Is Criticized
text: An article about the Prophet Muhammad in the English-language Wikipedia has become the subject of an online protest in the last few weeks because of its representations of Muhammad, taken from medieval manuscripts.

headline: Some Symbols and Signs Amid an Ocean of Ideas
text: Via Dance Collaborative expresses a sweetly optimistic belief in group exploration. This four-year-old troupe develops “new work in a collegial, mutually supportive atmosphere,” according to the program notes for its current show at Dance New Amsterdam.

headline: Egypt and Cameroon Reach Semifinals
text: Stephane M’Bia and Cameroon needed extra time to beat Tunisia, 3-2, and reach the semifinals at the African Cup of Nations in Kumasi, Ghana.Defending champion Egypt also advanced, beating Angola, 2-1. Cameroon will face host Ghana and Egypt will play Ivory Coast in Thursday’s semifinals.

headline: The Cooper Concerns
text: I’m not a Hillary-hater. She’s been an outstanding senator. She hung tough on Iraq through the dark days of 2005. In this campaign, she has soldiered on bravely even though she has most of the elected Democrats, news media and the educated class rooting against her.

headline: Granderson Gets 5-Year Deal
text: The Detroit Tigers and Curtis Granderson agreed to a five-year, $30.25 million contract that includes a club option for 2013 that could make the deal worth up to $43.25 million.Granderson, 26, had a breakout season last year, hitting .302 with 23 home runs and 74 runs batted in.

headline: Buzz at Garden Is for the Giants
text: It started off as a quiet night at Madison Square Garden on Monday. One of the worst teams in the Eastern Conference, the Knicks, returned home after five consecutive losses to play one of the worst teams in the Western Conference, the Los Angeles Clippers. There was not much for the fans to get excited about.

headline: Ground Squirrels Chew Snakeskins to Mask Their Scent
text: Here’s an odd animal behavior for you: the California ground squirrel chews on the molted skins of one of its main predators, the rattlesnake, and applies the scent to its body by licking itself all over.

headline: Feel Like a Fraud? At Times, Maybe You Should
text: Stare into a mirror long enough and it’s hard not to wonder whether that’s a mask staring back, and if so, who’s really behind it.

headline: On the West Coast, a Distinguished Company Avoids Showing Any Gray
text: SAN FRANCISCO  For most ballet companies that survive past their first 50 years, some degree of artistic recession proves inevitable. With San Francisco Ballet alone, the third quarter-century has brought a higher artistic eminence than before.

headline: Bolshoi Director May Take Job at City Ballet
text: Alexei Ratmansky, the artistic director of the Bolshoi Ballet, has confirmed that he is leaving the Bolshoi and is in negotiations with New York City Ballet to become its resident choreographer. He would replace Christopher Wheeldon, who is leaving at the end of this month.

headline: Kenya: South African Bows Out of Mediation
text: Cyril Ramaphosa, a South African businessman who led the African National Congress’s negotiations to end apartheid in his country in the 1990s, withdrew as a mediator in crisis talks in Kenya after the government of President Mwai Kibaki said he would not be impartial because he had had business dealings with the top opposition leader, Raila Odinga. Mr. Ramaphosa denied that. He arrived in Nairobi on Friday to help Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general, broker talks between Kenya’s opposing politicians. Talks continued without him. The sides pledged to help people return to their homes and to provide food and shelter for those displaced by the ethnic violence that broke out after with the Dec. 27 presidential election. The government also lifted a monthlong ban on live television broadcasts.

headline: Food Politics, Half-Baked
text: LAST month the Food and Drug Administration gave the green light to food made from cloned cows, pigs and goats, with the agency’s top food-safety expert, Dr. Stephen Sundlof, declaring, “It is beyond our imagination to even have a theory for why the food is unsafe.” Opponents of biotechnology immediately let out a collective groan of disapproval  among them Jerry Greenfield of Ben & Jerry’s ice cream (who has called cloning “just weird”). Cloning, after all, will now join genetically modified crops as yet another threat to organic agriculture. I, too, let out a groan, but for a different reason.

headline: A Medical Mystery Unfolds in Minnesota
text: AUSTIN, Minn.  If you have to come down with a strange disease, this town of 23,000 on the wide-open prairie in southeastern Minnesota is a pretty good place to be. The Mayo Clinic, famous for diagnosing exotic ailments, owns the local medical center and shares some staff with it. Mayo itself is just 40 miles east in Rochester. And when it comes to investigating mysterious outbreaks, Minnesota has one of the strongest health departments and best-equipped laboratories in the country.

headline: Teacher Held in Forgery of Time-Off Requests
text: A daughter of Lynne F. Stewart, the defense lawyer convicted of aiding terrorism by smuggling messages out of prison for a client, was arrested on Monday on charges of forgery and falsifying documents she submitted to take time off from her teaching job, some of it during her mother’s trial and sentencing.

headline: Government Help for Small-Business Owners (No Joke)
text: For years, a good way to guarantee a laugh was to walk into a room of small business owners and announce, “I’m from the government and I am here to help you.”

headline: Once a Prisoner of Her Body, Now Stronger After Battling Adversity
text: Janay Ryals lay facedown on the carpeted floor of her apartment in the dark of night, having fallen out of bed while sleeping. She told her outstretched arms to push her upright. They did not listen. She told her feet to get her off the ground. They did not respond.

headline: Trade for Manning Looks Fine Now
text: PHOENIX  As the Giants’ final drive began Sunday night, with a championship and history hanging in the balance, Ernie Accorsi had just one thought: “If he is what we thought he was, he has to do it now.”

headline: Disease Fighter Turns Plane Aisle Into a Gym
text: AS an infectious diseases specialist, I travel to Johannesburg, South Africa, and Lilongwe, Malawi, four times a year for various projects related to my work with the human immunodeficiency virus or, as we all know it, H.I.V.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article last Tuesday about the current dominance of Boston’s professional football, basketball and baseball teams misstated the chances of any city with only one franchise in each of those sports winning championships in the same season. It is 1 in 2,000, not 1 in 29,000.

headline: China: Rails and Main Road Reopen
text: China’s main north-south highway, the Zhuhai-Beijing Expressway, reopened and was expected to ease the logjams that have stranded millions of bus and rail passengers after a series of exceptional snowstorms. Rail service was slowly returning to normal. About 80 trains left southern Guangzhou on Sunday with 210,000 passengers aboard, said the state-run newspaper The Southern Metropolis Daily. But a river of new travelers trying to get home for the Lunar New Year holiday this week flowed into the city on Monday, and the area around the main train station was still packed with people.

headline: Iran Launches Rocket to Commemorate New Space Center
text: TEHRAN  Iran fired a research rocket into space on Monday to mark the opening of its space center, a move that was immediately condemned by the United States.

headline: Sixteen Seconds That Saved the Game
text: The Giants’ winning drive Sunday was kept alive by a dramatic pass play. They faced third-and-5 from their 44-yard line with 1 minute 15 seconds left and the Patriots leading, 14-10.

headline: Correction:  For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column on Monday about Coach Eddie Sutton’s 800th career college basketball victory referred incorrectly to his accomplishment. He became the fifth, not the fourth, N.C.A.A. Division I coach to reach the milestone. (As the report noted, the group also includes Bob Knight, Dean Smith, Adolph Rupp and Jim Phelan.)

headline: An Extended Run for Hannah Montana
text: America’s tweens are going to get more of what they love. Disney Studios has decided to extend the run of “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour,” the 3-D movie that sold an estimated $29 million in tickets over the weekend, Variety reported. The run of the concert film, originally scheduled for one week, will be extended market by market, said Chuck Viane, Disney’s president for distribution. In some cities it may play two more weeks; in others only one. The film stars Miley Cyrus, the daughter of the country music singer Billy Ray Cyrus. She stars on the Disney Channel in the series “Hannah Montana,” for two years the top-rated cable show among children 6 to 14. In “Hannah Montana” Ms. Cyrus plays a teenager who lives a secret life at night as a pop star.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about Senator John McCain and Mitt Romney waging a war of words over who is the real Republican misidentified the founder of Forbes magazine. It was B.C. Forbes, not his son Malcolm Forbes. (Malcolm’s son Steve endorsed Mr. McCain on Friday.)

headline: Mysterious Leak Provides a Hint of Lost Manhattan
text: Cities absorb history  all kinds of histories. Personal history, commercial history, political history, even geological history combine to form the fabric of the contemporary city.

headline: A Convict and Medical School (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Not So Super Sunday for Fox's Rivals
text: On a night in which Fox’s Super Bowl coverage won a resounding victory in the ratings, ABC, CBS and NBC struggled to attract even meager audiences during prime time. CBS fared best, finishing a very distant runner-up thanks in part to the strength of “60 Minutes,” which drew 5 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen’s estimate. This veteran news magazine followed a news special on the National Guard at 7 p.m., “CBS Reports” (3.3 million), while repeats of CBS’s “Shark” and “Cold Case” attracted 4.2 million and 6.1 million viewers, respectively, at 9 and 10 p.m. ABC, in third place for the night, outpaced CBS in the important demographic of adults 18 to 49, getting a boost later in the night from the 2004 movie with Ben Stiller and Robert De Niro, “Meet the Fockers,” which averaged 4.1 million viewers from 9 to 11. NBC ranked fourth over all with four repeat hours of “The Biggest Loser,” which averaged 2.3 million viewers.

headline: In His Own Words
text: In Boston:

headline: Issues Start Rush to Vote by Hispanics
text: Spurred by the widespread crackdown on illegal immigration and by the contentious tone of the national immigration debate, Latinos are gearing up for Tuesday’s voting with an eye toward making Hispanics a decisive voting bloc nationwide in November.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture credit on Monday with an article about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s position on health care carried an incorrect credit. The photograph of Mrs. Clinton was by Todd Heisler of The New York Times, not by Damon Winter.

headline: In Some Circles of Friends, the Big Game Is Tuesday
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  At the Barney’s Beanery here, bartenders have assigned a brand of beer to each presidential candidate, inviting patrons to vote with their lips. In Leonia, N.J., a group of friends who have been gathering since 1980 to eat dinner and watch returns on election night will celebrate their first Super Tuesday meal over a nice tablecloth.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Critics’ Choice column on Monday, about new CDs, misidentified the vocalist who sings with Matthew Caws on the song “The Film Did Not Go Round” on the new album by Nada Surf, “Lucky.” She is Lianne Smith  not Coralie Clément, who also performs on the album.

headline: Lame-Duck Budget
text: President Bush’s 2009 budget is a grim guided tour through his misplaced priorities, failed fiscal policies and the disastrous legacy that he will leave for the next president. And even that requires you to accept the White House’s optimistic accounting, which seven years of experience tells us would be foolish in the extreme.

headline: With Hockey Market Stagnant, Nike Seeks to Sell Equipment Unit
text: OTTAWA  It was just a little swoosh. But when Nike added its logo to gear by Bauer, a longtime Canadian maker of hockey equipment, “there was resistance,” said Terry Bovair, owner of the Fontaine Source for Sports in Peterborough, Ontario. “Some people did not buy the product.”

headline: Winds of Change
text: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Coping With Loss and Grief (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toyota Profit Increases 7.5 %
text: TOKYO  The Toyota Motor Corporation reported on Tuesday that its profit rose 7.5 percent in the October-to-December quarter as its strategy of shifting its focus to emerging markets from the United States appears to be paying off.

headline: Japan: Princess Becomes Fair Game
text: A 13-dish Mexican dinner in her honor. Then shark fin soup at a top Chinese restaurant. Next, a French meal featuring black truffles. Princess Masako, the wife of Crown Prince Naruhito, has been eating well, and being criticized in the tabloid press for violating the standards of imperial austerity as the economy shows signs of faltering. The lavish private outings have also prompted the tabloids to ask why the 44-year-old Harvard-educated princess, in whom depression was diagnosed four years ago, is still opting out of most of her official public duties.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the presidential candidates’ stances on health care, taxes and other issues misstated the cap on income subject to the Social Security tax. It is now $102,000  not $97,500, the cap for 2007.

headline: The Player’s Lair
text: Michael Lewis, a regular contributor to Play, has set foot in many baseball clubhouses, where he felt as though the players' edginess made an outsider feel unwelcome. But as he writes in The New York Times Magazine this week, his first experience in an N.F.L. locker room -- that of the New York Giants, actually -- was an entirely different experience:

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Jan. 25 about Jérôme Kerviel, the rogue trader at the French bank Société Générale, misstated the number of workers dismissed in connection with the scandal. Only one of the employees mentioned  Luc François, global head of equities and derivatives activities  will leave or move to another position as a result of the investigation. Two other employees, Marc Breillout and Grégoire Varenne, left for reasons unrelated to the scandal and a third, Christophe Mianné, remains at Société Générale  they were not dismissed as a result of the Kerviel inquiry. (Go to Article)

headline: States Prepare for Tests of Changes to Voting System
text: As voters in 23 states head to polls or caucuses today to pick their party’s presidential candidate, local election officials around the country are bracing for a long, exhausting night and an array of unpredictable factors that might prevent some states from reporting final tallies until early Wednesday morning. Although no one is predicting serious problems, many voting officials acknowledge that they could happen.

headline: For Marketing, the Most Valuable Player Might Be YouTube
text: SOME religions believe in an afterlife. Others do not. On Madison Avenue after the Super Bowl, most everyone is a believer.

headline: In Brazil, Anger Over European Ban of Beef Imports
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil  A decision by the European Union to ban Brazilian beef imports is “unjustifiable and arbitrary” and could result in shortages and higher prices for European consumers, officials and agricultural specialists say.

headline: Bird’s-Eye View
text: Q. Why do birds sit on telephone or power wires? What did they do before there were wires?

headline: Americans Claim Fed Cup Victories
text: Shaking off nerves, the 22-year-old United States Fed Cup rookie Ashley Harkleroad rallied from a 4-1 deficit in the second set to beat Germany’s Sabine Lisicki, 6-4, 7-5, in San Diego to clinch the quarterfinal match.Harkleroad’s victory followed Lindsay Davenport’s 6-1, 6-2 victory against 19-year-old Julia Goerges in reverse singles, sending the United States into a World Group semifinal road match against Russia, the defending Fed Cup champion, in April.The United States finished 4-1 against Germany after Davenport and Lisa Raymond won the doubles, 6-2, 6-0, over Tatjana Malek and Anna-Lena Groenefeld.

headline: France: Parliament Set to Ratify European Treaty
text: Both houses of Parliament met in joint session at the Palace of Versailles and approved a revision of the constitution necessary for ratification of the new, simplified European Union treaty. The vote paved the way for parliamentary ratification of the treaty on Thursday. France’s rejection of a proposed European Union constitution in a 2005 popular referendum paralyzed the union. The constitution has since been streamlined and renamed a treaty, and is being put before member nations. President Nicolas Sarkozy decided that this time Parliament would vote on the charter, diminishing the risk of rejection.

headline: In Her Own Words
text: In Worcester, Mass.:

headline: Rock Memorabilia Raises Questions
text: From a house in the center of Edinburgh a mystery has emerged, in the form of a gold Elvis Presley record, a framed signed picture of him and a framed piece of paper with lyrics to Don McLean’s hit song “American Pie,” apparently written by McLean, the BBC reported. The police said the items, recovered during a search, may have been stolen. A spokesman said: “The value of the items is not known, but they look genuine. And if they have been stolen, then we hope that the original owner will recognize them and contact us.”

headline: Daschle Uses Senate Ties to Blaze Path for Obama
text: WASHINGTON  When Senator Edward M. Kennedy was ready to deliver his endorsement of Senator Barack Obama, Mr. Kennedy did not call Obama headquarters. He got in touch with Tom Daschle, the former Senate Democratic leader who had quietly been serving as the liaison between Mr. Obama and fellow senators.

headline: Economy Fitful, Americans Start to Pay as They Go
text: For more than half a century, Americans have proved staggeringly resourceful at finding new ways to spend money.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Go to Work, See a Parade and Don’t Forget to Vote
text: Except for religion, few things arouse as much emotion as politics and sports. Tuesday, New Yorkers will be able to indulge in both.

headline: Boston Scientific Posts Loss, but Sales Beat Expectations
text: With a lift from the falling dollar and better-than-expected sales in several divisions, Boston Scientific delivered a pleasant earnings surprise to its long-suffering shareholders Monday.

headline: Memo Pad: United Adds a Checked-Bag Fee
text: UNITED ADDS A CHECKED-BAG FEE Saying that it was offering customers a “new, simplified checked-bag policy,” United Airlines said that it would charge $25 to check a second bag, starting May 5, for customers who travel domestically on advance purchase nonrefundable fares. The vast majority of coach passengers buy such fares, as opposed to the more expensive, fully refundable walk-up fares. United said the fee would generate more than $100 million a year “in cost savings and new revenue.” Most competitors allow coach passengers to check a second bag without charge. United’s fee policy also applies to travel to and from Canada; San Juan, P.R.; and St. Thomas, V.I., for tickets purchased starting this week. Passengers with Premier status or higher in United’s Mileage Plus frequent-flier program and those with Silver status or higher in the Star Alliance program will be exempt from the fee.

headline: Stanzas of Sin With a 21st-Century Spin
text: Neither political corruption nor the cardinal sins have gone out of fashion since “The Roman de Fauvel,” a satirical poem denouncing ruling institutions in France, was written in the early 14th century. But some of the work’s references would mean little to modern audiences.

headline: McC, Hil, Bam, et al.: Everyone Needs a Nom de Tab
text: There are all sorts of reasons to presume that Senator John McCain will do exceedingly well in New York’s Republican primary on Tuesday. Here’s one that does not get the attention it deserves: He has been cut down to size by headline writers for the city’s major tabloid newspapers. This is a plus for him.

headline: Former Executive Named to Lead Mormon Church
text: An 80-year-old former advertising and publishing executive, Thomas S. Monson, was named on Monday to be the 16th president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, one week after the death of the previous president, Gordon B. Hinckley.

headline: Dow Off 370 Points on Weak Business Survey
text: Stocks plummeted on Wall Street on Tuesday after a business survey provided another strong signal that the United States may be in the early stages of a recession. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 370 points.

headline: Mrs. Clinton Has Support in Stronghold of Obama
text: Idealism used to be the hallmark of young voters, and many of Yale’s undergraduates appear to be supporting the fresh-faced candidate, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois.

headline: In His Own Words
text: At the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J.:

headline: With an Unexpected Layoff Comes a New Sense of Political Urgency
text: HAMILTON, N.J.  This election just got very personal for Tom Mahoney.

headline: Mystery Solved: This Hummingbird Chirps With Its Tail
text: When a male Anna’s hummingbird swoops down over a female in an acrobatic mating display, it emits a loud and quick chirp, closely corresponding in tone to the highest C on a piano. For years, the source of the sound has been the subject of debate. Is it a vocal sound, or something else?

headline: Utilities Turn From Coal to Gas, Raising Risk of Price Increase
text: WASHINGTON  Stymied in their plans to build coal-burning power plants, American utilities are turning to natural gas to meet expected growth in demand, risking a new upward spiral in the price of that fuel.

headline: Florida Insurers Defend Increases in Home Rates
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  Facing accusations that they have been gouging customers, executives from one of Florida’s largest homeowners’ insurance companies told a special State Senate committee on Monday that they had been forced to raise rates to offset losses and prepare for the possibility of more frequent hurricanes in the future.

headline: City Fosters Arts for Elderly
text: To encourage participation by people older than 60 in New York City’s arts offerings, a $1 million partnership between cultural organizations and centers for the elderly was announced yesterday by the city’s Department for the Aging, the Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York City Council. About 60 arts organizations will team up with more than 150 centers for the elderly in all five boroughs to provide a variety of programs, like jewelry design, storytelling, circus arts, horticulture, blues cabaret, creative writing, intergenerational theater and cinema. By 2030 one-fifth of the city’s population will be over 60, outnumbering school-age children, city officials said.

headline: McCain Shops for Votes With Stop at Grand Central
text: There is much about Grand Central Terminal that puts one in mind of an earlier New York: the Oyster Bar, the racket stringing kiosk, the watch repair counter that sells striped grosgrain watchbands, proximity to the Yale Club and Paul Stuart, and the fact that commuters boarding the Metro-North trains for points in Westchester and Fairfield Counties can buy beer and cocktails from carts at the base of the platforms.

headline: Obama Receives Cheers in the Meadowlands
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Daniel Levine could barely contain himself. He paced the floor of the Izod Center waiting for Senator Barack Obama’s appearance on Monday morning. He spoke about being “part of something amazing” and “magical,” and how a person like Senator Obama “only comes along every 40 years.”

headline: A Corporate View of Mafia Tactics: Protesting, Lobbying and Citing Upton Sinclair
text: Smithfield Foods, which raises, kills and processes more pigs than any company on earth, does not like some of the things a union has been saying about conditions at its giant slaughterhouse in Tar Heel, N.C., where 4,650 people work and 32,000 hogs die every day.

headline: Turkish Jets Bomb Northern Iraq
text: ISTANBUL  Turkish fighter jets bombed targets in northern Iraq on Monday, the Turkish military said, the fifth major strike against Kurdish rebels this year.

headline: Montclair Celebrates One of Its Own
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  The day after he helped the Giants win the Super Bowl by pinning a ball against his helmet, David Tyree was everywhere at Montclair High School even as he was on a plane flying home from Arizona with the rest of his jubilant teammates.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund-Raising Totals
text: Previously recorded $7,320,514

headline: California: Stranded Skiers Rescued
text: Two skiers missing for two days near Lake Tahoe after a winter storm were rescued after they burrowed into snow caves and huddled together for warmth, the authorities said. The men, described as expert skiers, were spotted by the crew of a Placer County Sheriff’s Department helicopter about seven miles from the Alpine Meadows ski resort, just west of Lake Tahoe. The men, Patrick Frost, 35, and Christopher Gerwig, 32, both of San Francisco, were picked up near Hell Hole Reservoir and taken to Sutter Auburn Faith Hospital, where a spokeswoman said they had suffered “really minor, minor” frostbite.

headline: TV Audience Sets N.F.L. Record
text: The Giants’ 17-14 upset of New England in Super Bowl XLII Sunday night was the most-watched N.F.L. championship game ever, seen by an average of 97.5 million viewers, beating the previous record of 94.1 million for Dallas’s victory over Pittsburgh in 1996.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Schedule information in Weekend on Friday with a theater review of “The Maddening Truth,” at the Clurman Theater, misstated the date of the final performance. It is Feb. 23, not Feb. 17.

headline: New Mojo in New York?
text: Before Super Bowl XLII, professional teams in the Boston area had a run of great success, especially compared to -- and against -- New York teams. Do you think that the Giants victory over the Patriots is a sign of changing fortunes for the two cities, or just an aberration?

headline: Marches Show Disgust With a Colombian Rebel Group
text: BOGOTÁ, Colombia  Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched here and in other cities around Colombia on Monday to protest the abductions and killings carried out by the country’s largest rebel group.

headline: Reid Tries to Pressure G.O.P. for $159 Billion Stimulus Bill
text: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats tried to pressure Republicans on Monday to vote for a $159 billion economic stimulus plan, including $1 billion in additional subsidies for home energy, instead of a cheaper, more streamlined package approved by the House last week.

headline: City Seeking Tougher Rules for High-Rise Construction
text: The city’s Buildings Department, moving to shore up safety on construction sites after a worker fell 42 stories to his death last month, proposed new regulations on Monday that would require general contractors and concrete operators to register with the city.

headline: Regimens: An Herbal Extract Eases Symptoms of Heart Failure
text: In a review of 14 studies, researchers have found that the herbal supplement hawthorn extract is effective in treating symptoms of chronic heart failure.

headline: Quantum Teleporting, Yes; the Rest Is Movie Magic
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In a battle waged with popcorn, floodlights, chalk and star power, science and art squared off at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology one night last month.

headline: Oscar Nominees Urged to Attend Ceremony
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Sid Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and chief defender of its strike-threatened Oscar show, took the gloves off on Monday. Well, one glove anyway.

headline: Virginia: Police to Drop Obscenity Charge
text: The police in Virginia Beach plan to drop a misdemeanor obscenity charge filed against the manager of an Abercrombie & Fitch clothing store that displayed two photos of scantily clad men and a woman, a city attorney said. The police said they confiscated the photos from the Lynnhaven Mall store on Saturday after some customers complained and Abercrombie management did not heed warnings to remove the images of three shirtless young men, with one man’s upper buttocks showing, and of a woman whose breast was mostly exposed. Deputy City Attorney Mark Stiles said the photos might technically meet the nudity portion of city code. But he said it would be difficult to meet the other standards of the law: that the display had to appeal to prurient interests, lack redeeming artistic merit and be offensive to prevailing community standards.

headline: In Brooklyn, Police Work Is Undone by Scandal
text: On a winter day in 2005, an undercover officer noticed two young men loitering on a street corner in Gravesend, Brooklyn. Something about their behavior caught his eye. He approached the men, gave one of them $19 and was handed two bags of crack cocaine by the other. After he left, other officers moved in and arrested them.

headline: Suicide Biker Kills 6 in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A suicide bomber on a motorbike packed with explosives destroyed a military bus carrying doctors in the Pakistan military headquarters city of Rawalpindi on Monday, and officials said at least six people had been killed, including a high-ranking army physician.

headline: Bush Aide and Democrats Clash Over Budget
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush’s budget chief and Senate Democrats clashed in a more or less friendly way on Tuesday, as the administrator defended Mr. Bush’s low-tax philosophy and Democrats said the president was saddling American children with debt they will still be paying when they are grandparents.

headline: Basking in the Sun Though Wary of a Storm
text: NASHVILLE  It had rained hard through Sheryl Crow’s last day of rehearsals with her band as she prepared for her two sold-out shows at the Fillmore at Irving Plaza on Wednesday and Thursday. They were practicing in a converted barn  with carpets on the wall and guitars in overhead racks  at what’s called the Hit Farm in the credits to “Detours” (A&M), the rambunctious and vulnerable album she will release on Tuesday.

headline:
Clinton and McCain Win in California;
Obama Stays Close as G.O.P. Rivals Lag
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton won primaries in New York, New Jersey and Arizona and captured the biggest prize of all, California, while Senator Barack Obama strung together nearly a dozen victories from Georgia to Idaho as the two Democratic candidates were locked in an intense struggle for convention delegates on Tuesday.

headline: A Special One
text: The Giants 17-14 victory on Sunday was an instant classic, a history-making game that sports fans will place alongside the greatest N.F.L. dramas of all time. We can't get enough of it, and that's why we put together this special edition of the newsletter. Enjoy, and see you on Thursday.

headline: Britney Spears's Hearings Continue
text: As Britney Spears remained in a psychiatric ward in Los Angeles, court hearings on Monday dealt with the custody of her two small children and with the conservatorship of Ms. Spears and her estate that were granted last week to her father, James, and her lawyer, Andrew Wallete, The Associated Press reported. The news agency also reported that a person close to Ms. Spears said her stay had been extended for two weeks under a California law that allows patients to be kept for medical treatment if found to be gravely disabled or a danger to themselves or others. The closed-door custody hearing, involving Ms. Spears’s lawyers, conservators and her ex-husband, Kevin Federline, was continued until Feb. 19.

headline: BP Misses Estimates and Plans More Job Cuts
text: LONDON  BP, the British oil giant, announced on Tuesday that it would cut an additional 5,000 jobs by the middle of next year, part of plan by the chief executive, Anthony B. Hayward, to slim management and make the company more efficient.

headline: New Food Formula: Tastes Fine, Kills Worms
text: Kraft Foods, the conglomerate built on macaroni and cheese, is working on a new and unusual product line  food that is not only tasty, but kills intestinal worms.

headline: For Clinton the Speaker, the Smaller the Better
text: When Hillary Rodham Clinton speaks to large audiences, be it a rally with several thousand students or a fund-raiser with well-heeled donors, she often sounds more like a senator than a presidential candidate  delivering wonky recitations of her policy positions instead of a raise-the-roof stemwinder.

headline: Former Banker Convicted of Insider Trading
text: A former Credit Suisse banker accused of leaking confidential information about several major deals, including the $45 billion buyout of TXU, as part of a $7.5 million insider trading scheme was convicted Monday in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Lively Collaboration Evokes Mozart’s Spirit
text: Mozart’s youthful “Turkish” Violin Concerto (No. 5 in A) is distinguished by the unusual entrance of the soloist in the first movement. Instead of diving in with a sprightly, virtuosic statement, the violinist halts the jaunty orchestral introduction and abruptly shifts the mood with a lyrical, pensive aria that unfurls over the suddenly subdued orchestra.

headline: Suicide Attack in Israel Kills One
text: DIMONA, Israel  A Palestinian suicide bomber who may have sneaked into Israel from the Egyptian Sinai blew himself up at a shopping center in this southern desert town on Monday, killing an Israeli woman and wounding 11 other Israelis, emergency services officials said.

headline: Coping With the Caveman in the Crib
text: If there is such a person as a “baby whisperer,” it is the pediatrician Dr. Harvey Karp, whose uncanny ability to quiet crying babies became the best-selling book “The Happiest Baby on the Block.”

headline: Famous Black Lives Through DNA’s Prism
text: “African-American Lives 2,” a four-part series on PBS that begins on Wednesday night, belies its sleepy name with the poetry of history, the magic of science and the allure of the family trees of Morgan Freeman, Chris Rock, Tina Turner, Don Cheadle, Tom Joyner and Maya Angelou.

headline: Dartmouth President to Resign
text: James Wright, the president of Dartmouth College, will step down in June 2009, the college announced. Mr. Wright, 68, has been Dartmouth president for 10 years and a member of the college’s faculty since 1969. A professor of history, he also served as dean of the faculty and provost. During his tenure, the number of black and Latino students increased at Dartmouth, as did the number of undergraduates from low-income households.

headline: Rutgers Center Looks to Add More Offense
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Kia Vaughn and Brittany Ray were walking through the airport in Pittsburgh on Saturday, toward a flight home after a tough victory, when a man noticed they were from the Rutgers women’s basketball team.

headline: Sixteen Seconds That Saved the Game

headline: Taxes with a Greenish Hue
text: Last week I wrote about Ireland’s plastic bag tax, enacted in 2002, which now requires consumers to pay 22 euro cents at the cash register for every plastic bag they take out of the store. It has cut down on plastic bag use in that country by well over 90 percent. Consumers I spoke with – not at all green types – said the “plas tax” had helped cure them of a bad habit. Retailers, at first resistant, now love it, too: They no longer have to buy and store millions of plastic bags. Revenue from the tax is used for environmental enforcement and cleanup.

headline: Discussing Microsoft’s Yahoo Bid
text: Upon its announcement Friday at 6:30 a.m., Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion bid for Yahoo quickly became Topic A in the tech and media circles. But with so many intricacies in the deal, there’s a lot to dissect and digest.
