headline: Ecolab Gobbles Up Ecovation
text: Ecolab, a provider of cleaning products and services, said on Monday it would acquire Ecovation, a company that provides technology used to increase efficiency in food and beverage production, for $210 million.

headline: F.C.C. Green-Lights AT&T’s $2.5 Billion Deal for Aloha Spectrum
text: AT&T has won government approval to buy wireless airwaves from Aloha Partners, a privately held partnership, for $2.5 billion. The Federal Communications Commission on Monday announced approval of AT&T’s acquisition of the spectrum, saying the move would serve the public interest.

headline: Sun-Times Media Weighs Selling Itself
text: The Sun-Times Media Group, the parent company of The Chicago Sun-Times, said Monday that it was considering a sale of the company and its assets. The company said its directors were also looking at other alternatives to increase shareholder value, including joint ventures or strategic partnerships.

headline: Ringleader Recharges With $6 Million
text: Ringleader Digital on Monday became the latest in a string of companies in the embryonic mobile advertising market to announce that it has attracted venture capital funding.

headline: Visa Eyes October Deadline for I.P.O.
text: Visa, the world’s largest credit-card network, said on Monday there is a 95 percent chance it will complete its initial public offering by Oct. 10, Reuters reported citing a quarterly filing.

headline: Citadel Move Rekindles I.P.O. Chatter
text: The Citadel Investment Group, the powerful investment firm run by Kenneth C. Griffin, has split its hedge-fund business from an options market-making unit in what Bloomberg News said “may be a prelude to a public offering.”

headline: Are Deals Getting More Pushback?
text: There are lots of reasons for the recent lull in merger activity. One of the less-obvious ones might be increased skepticism from boards, hedge funds and proxy advisory firms about the benefits of such deals, Compliance Week suggests.

headline: Teneros Adds $84.5 Million

headline: Dorel Bikes Off With Cannondale

headline: Freescale Buys SigmaTel for $110 Million
text: A private equity-backed chipmaker, Freescale Semiconductor, agreed Monday to buy SigmaTel for $110 million to broaden its multimedia business.

headline: 2 Deal Veterans Start Activist Hedge Fund
text: Guy Wyser-Pratte, the New York-based arbitrageur, has teamed up with one of the co-founders of Knight Vinke Asset Management to start an activist hedge fund to target underperforming European companies, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Icahn Pushes for Merger of Railcar Makers

headline: Suitor Ends Bid for Northern Rock
text: Olivant Advisers, one of two possible suitors for Northern Rock, the troubled British mortgage lender, dropped out of the bidding on Monday, saying it had failed to devise an offer that would satisfy both it and the government.

headline: Corporate Express: No Takeover Talks With Staples
text: Shares of Corporate Express, the world’s biggest distributor of office supplies, rose sharply Tuesday in Amsterdam after De Telegraaf said the company is in early-stage talks to be bought by Staples. But the stock eased after Corporate Express said “such discussions are not taking place.”

headline: BHP Weighs Options in Rio Tinto Bid
text: The world’s biggest mining company, BHP Billiton, must decide by Wednesday whether it will proceed with a bid for a rival, the Rio Tinto Group, after China intervened with a strategic investment that could sharply increase the price of what would be one of the biggest mergers in corporate history.

headline: Primary Morning in Chappaqua, With the Clintons
text: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — Primary day in Chappaqua. It feels like Transylvania with a thick soupy fog hugging the ground. There’s a winter display at Hillary Rodham Clinton’s polling place at Grafflin Elementary School that says “Let It Snow,” surrounded by snowmen. It has the doleful air of one of those global warming winter days, but the mild weather is something of a blessing for the Clinton faithful, about 30 or so who show up with their blue Hillary signs to greet the candidate when she arrives to vote shortly before 8 a.m. The Clintons show up — Hillary in a brown suit, Bill in blue, Chelsea in a dark coat — to enthusiastic applause and are greeted by Evan Norris, a retired doctor turned volunteer firefighter who has been taking pictures of the assembled cameras waiting to take pictures of the Clintons.

headline: Super Surprise?
text: While the Republicans make extensive use of “winner-take-all” systems in their nominating process, the Democrats rely exclusively on the more leveling “proportional representation” system. This means that the most likely outcome tonight is for a clear frontrunner to emerge on the G.O.P. side, and a much more muddied picture on the Democratic side. Most observers forecast a “a long-term slog” for the Democrats, or maybe even a “back room choice” at the Democratic convention.Perhaps … but perhaps not. Though a split result and a prolonged contest are likely for the Democrats, there are at least three ways in which either Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton could establish real dominance in the race today. They are:

headline: In Africa, the Goal Is the Thing
text: KUMASI, Ghana — African soccer fans love goals. This may seem self-evident — who doesn’t love goals? But Africans have a unique desire to see joyful, attacking soccer that leads to bunches of goals. And they dread a scoreless affair. Nil-nil, even if it is a good result for the team’s involved, is “very, very bad,” said Ato Mohamed, a former centerback with local club Olympics, after we watched Tunisia’s goalless draw with Angola.

headline: Benediction
text: I have thoroughly enjoyed the past two weeks with “The Moviegoer,” our panelists and our readers. What a privilege to spend quality time with such a great work of art and with people who have such diverse insights into it. My single greatest impression as we near the end of our exchange is the staggering richness of theme that Percy was able to cram into little more than 200 pages and the multitude of ways in which it is possible to approach the novel, picking and choosing, and leaving some of its aspects on the back burner.

headline: The Featherweights
text: I’m glad we have a show in New York that’s generating some debate—Halston, of course. There’s nothing in my review tomorrow about Jil Sander, though I did wonder if the tulle-veiled tweed and embroidered skirts, etc. at Herrera and Oscar started with Raf Simons’ transparency collection for spring. I think the only point of comparison between Sander and Halston is that both designers had to clean house a bit with their brands, find the main points. (I hate that dreaded word DNA; I expect to find bodies.) After two or three seasons of establishing a line and his tailoring, as well as the great dresses, Simons has felt free to do more with Jil. I suspect Marco Zanini will do the same thing. The guy is smart, and not affected by the side-show dramas. And look at all the boxy, flaring and embellished jackets we’ve seen on the runways this week—the oversized grunge plaid at Preen, the A-line shapes at Herrera, the tweed numbers at Oscar. And who does a super-simple, sharp-shouldered, one-button jacket with a slim skirt (on Freja) and makes it look new? Mister Zanini. That was my favorite look in the show. It’s all about knowing what to eliminate. I agree with Marco about the 70s context thing, though I looked at it differently in the review. Halson was not about the furnishings; he was about the architecture: line and cut, and color for visual impact and warmth. So what was Liza M. doing in the front row? Why do the new owners feel they have to sell Halston by telling the history? It’s such an old approach.

headline: What I Ate Last Night Department …
text: … Or, do Brussels sprouts and plantains make sense together? I’m not big on fusion food, at least when it’s contrived, but I’m huge on spontaneity, and this sure counts for that. The “recipe” is based on what was sitting in the refrigerator and on the counter, along with my new and profound love for poblanos and my belief that garlic helps almost everything. It works: you have different textures, the odd sweetness of the plantains and the grassiness of the Brussels sprouts, and the mild but distinctive heat of the poblanos. I may never make it again, but I enjoyed it.

headline: Monitors Report Array of Voting Problems in the City
text: Reports of sporadic voting problems have been coming in since the early morning in New York City, but the complaints seem to have increased in volume and seriousness. Election observers and voters are now describing a variety of concerns: longtime voters finding themselves left off registration rolls even though they have not moved or changed their party status; mechanical failures involving the lever used to activate the Democratic or Republican race between each vote; and poorly trained election workers who had trouble helping voters to use the emergency ballots and affidavit ballots that must be made available if voting equipment fails or if voters are incorrectly left off the registration rolls.

Soukupova is the face of Gucci Envy, she appears in the current Gap campaign, and she has closed shows for such designers as Valentino, John Galliano, Dior, Celine, Gucci, Michael Kors, Roberto Cavalli, Alexander McQueen, Calvin Klein, Donna Karen and Zac Posen. headline: A Mutant Obsession
text: This week I’m introducing the first article in what will be an occasional series about mutation. And yes, I admit it: I’m obsessed with mutation (which is why I’ve already alluded to it in a couple of earlier articles). The reason is that mutations to DNA form the raw material for evolution. It’s wondrous to think that mutations, accumulated over billions of years through the action of natural selection and the other forces of evolution, have produced such diverse life forms as vampire squid, coconut palms, death cap mushrooms, giant Gippsland earthworms, Etruscan pygmy shrews, E. coli — and us.
