text: To the Editor:

headline: The Unending Allure of the Free Lunch
text: With usura hath no man a house of good stone

headline: A Fairer System: Tax the Annoying
text: IT’S tax season and an election year, so again our thoughts have turned to change.

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE BEAUTIFUL THINGS THAT HEAVEN BEARS, by Dinaw Mengestu. (Riverhead, $14.) This first novel of hope and loss concerns an Ethiopian immigrant who owns a failing grocery store in a gentrifying neighborhood. He lives in two cities  the Washington where he struggles to survive and the Addis Ababa of memory. His pain is offset by the friendship of fellow immigrants and that of a white woman who moves with her young daughter into the house next door. Our reviewer, Rob Nixon, praised Mengestu’s “watchful honesty and egalitarian tenderness” and added, “This is a great African novel, a great Washington novel and a great American novel.”

headline: Warning: Fast Driving May Lead to More Trading
Alicia Svenson and Matthew Friese
text: Alicia Lindall Svenson and Matthew Bach Friese were married Saturday evening at the Explorers Club in New York. Justice Richard F. Braun of the State Supreme Court in New York officiated.

headline: Bhutto’s Widower Rallies Party
text: THATTA, Pakistan  Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, opened her party’s election campaign on Saturday with a huge rally in her home province, Sindh, in a bid to sweep the party into power on her legacy and her martyrdom.

headline: Tell the T.S.A. (and Don’t Hold Back)
text: “Ever since you started X-raying our shoes, I’ve been forced to carry all my plastic explosives in my pants, which I find most inconvenient.”

headline: Arts Developers, Now Hear This
text: IT seems a talent peculiar to artists: the ability to locate real estate ripe for transformation, imbue it with a little panache, and price oneself out.

headline: Who’s in Charge Here? Need You Ask?
text: ALTHOUGH I know better  I really do  when I have the impulse to adopt a new pet, I picture only love and fulfillment. I forget the work; I play down the mess. Think of those cat food commercials where a woman is curled up reading in the company of a sleek, purring, contented creature, and you’ll see straight into my fantasy life.

headline: Pebble Beach’s 18th Hole Is a Perfect Intersection of Golf and Nature
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Every year at this time, the familiar coastline comes into view. Beamed into millions of living rooms and dens are the scenic assortment of aerials, ground-level looks from worm cams, slo-mo and super-slo-mo beauty shots of players and celebrities great and small strolling the golf course on the cliffs at Pebble Beach. To see it all unfold each February is a ritual as familiar as opening the family photo album.

headline: Recalling the Maharishi and Carville’s Killer Ad
text: WITH his high-pitched giggle and his gentle ways, Maharishi Mahesh Yogi is not someone you would expect to be used as a blunt-force weapon in a political campaign.

headline: Turkey’s Parliament Lifts Scarf Ban
text: ISTANBUL  Parliament took a major step on Saturday toward lifting a ban against women’s head scarves at universities, setting the stage for a final showdown with Turkey’s secular elite over where Islam fits in the building of an open society.

headline: Inside the List
text: KING’S KINDLING: Stephen King is, famously, no admirer of the cellphone. But when it comes to other fripperies, like electronic books, he’s long been an early adapter. His novella “Riding the Bullet” (2000) was first published in e-book form. That same year he also self-published “The Plant”  an ultimately uncompleted serial novel  online, and even adopted an honor system payment plan, predating Radiohead’s stab at this by seven years. The lastest gleam in King’s eye is Kindle, Amazon’s fledgling e-book reader. “I’ve argued all my life that the story means more than the delivery systems involved (and that includes the writer),” King wrote recently in Entertainment Weekly, praising the device. Among other things, he likes that Kindle allows him to increase a book’s type size. His conclusion: “My definition of Kindle: a gadget with stories hiding inside it. What’s wrong with that?” King’s new novel, “Duma Key,” enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 1. As it happens, “Duma Key” is also  as this issue goes to press  No. 1 on Kindle’s own most-downloaded list.

headline: The Job Interview, Starring Your Avatar
text: AS far as job interviews go, my recent meeting with Sandy Gould was anything but ordinary.

headline: Insurance Appraisals: High-Tech Protection
text: GONE are the days when buying homeowner’s insurance meant telling your local insurance broker how much you paid for your house and then tacking on a buffer for inflation.

headline: Willie’s World
text: If the agents at Guantánamo Bay ever run out of interrogation techniques, they might consider forcing their prisoners to spend hours reading aloud to one another from the memoirs of American politicians. It’s a dreadful genre, mainly because any politician who is still alive and coherent  and this would include at least two-thirds of the United States Congress  is too concerned about his own place in history to be a very reliable chronicler of it.

headline: A View of Pueblo Life From the Inside
text: AT about 8:30 at night, an artillery-like barrage of fireworks shattered the silence, followed by the oompah of a tuba and the beating of drums. My curiosity aroused, I left the simple wooden cabin in which I was staying and went into the darkness to investigate. I found a slow-moving parade of perhaps 200 people shuffling down the streets of the Mexican village of Santa Ana del Valle, some 20 miles east of the city of Oaxaca. Indigenous Zapotec faces, from the newborn to the elderly, glowed in the flickering light of the candles many carried, along with bouquets of poinsettias, roses, or gladiolus.

headline: Letters: A Cutting Tradition
text: Female circumcision is neither mandated nor recommended in Islam (Sara Corbett, Jan. 20). Your photo gallery shows a particular practice in a particular ethnic group. Culture, not religion, dictates much of what Muslim and non-Muslim people do worldwide. The distinction is essential to make in these times when Islam and Muslims are under the microscope.

headline: Child of the Revolution
text: When circumstances throw a child into the company of a stranger, do you wish for that stranger to be male or female? What would the child prefer? In Harry Mulisch’s novel “The Assault,” a young Dutch boy is separated from his parents at the end of World War II, after members of the underground assassinate a collaborator outside the family home. Alone and afraid, he is taken to a police station and pushed into a dark cell. “All about him he could feel the presence of the man who must be in there somewhere.” When a voice in the blackness says, “Why are you here?” relief washes over him. Why? Because it is “the gentle voice of a woman. Suddenly it was as if a great danger had been averted.” As the woman pulls him close to console him, the boy smells sweat and something strangely sweet  perfume, he thinks. But it’s blood. The woman who comforts him is one of the assassins, a “terrorist” in the words of the soldiers who imprisoned her. Her actions led to the death of the boy’s parents, but he doesn’t know that, nor does she. Still, as she holds him, he hears “her heart pound, really much too hard for someone who was just comforting someone else.” Years later, he sobs when he learns she has died: “She was resurrected together with all she had meant to him, hidden there in the darkness.”

headline: Other School Districts Offered State Intervention
text: THE state bailed out the financially and academically troubled Roosevelt school district, with $14 million. But Long Island’s representative on the State Board of Regents said that Roosevelt was not the only district on the Island where the state should intervene.

headline: Good News: Bad News Arrives Quickly
text: IT has not been a great year so far for Enfield High School. Beyond the two snow days the school district has racked up, students at the high school, in northwestern Connecticut, received an unexpected extension on their holiday break when a pipe burst on Jan. 1, letting water pour in for hours before the break was discovered. The school was closed for three days, reopened, then shut down again the next week, when the main electrical box caught fire, possibly as a result of the flooding.

headline: John Myers, 96, World War II Test Pilot, Is Dead
text: John W. Myers, a leading civilian test pilot in World War II, who helped develop the first American fighter plane designed specifically for night combat, died on Jan. 31 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 96.

headline: Clean Power or Dirty Coal?
text: Opposition to new coal-fired power plants built without new technology  that is, without the capacity to capture greenhouse gas emissions  is rising on both Wall Street and Main Street. Citizen opposition has led companies to cancel some high-profile projects, including a proposed plant near the Florida Everglades. Pressure from environmental organizations has persuaded major banks to begin weighing the risks of global warming when deciding whether to finance new plants.

headline: Learning From Britney’s Troubles
text: THE involuntary hospitalization of Britney Spears last week brought back memories. Ten years ago, when I was 15, I was a high school dropout and heroin addict, living in the back of a dealer’s van. My mom first noticed red flags at 14: rapid weight loss, self-mutilation, coming home high, irregularly showering. The therapist she had me see, as well as my school counselor, believed that, cutting aside, my actions were typical teenage behavior. The first time I ran away, though, my mother formed her own conclusions, and got a 5150 issued  California code for the involuntary 72-hour psychiatric hold that Ms. Spears was under, before she left the hospital on Wednesday.

headline: A Peruvian Place That Aims High
text: UPSCALE Peruvian?

headline: Now, Feed the Data to the Subprimeoscope
text: AS a nation, the central question we face just now  even more than, “Can I still exchange this dreck for something I might actually wear?”  is whether our economy is entering a recession (“recession,” of course, being technically defined as two consecutive quarters in which office managers keep warning everyone to stop using FedEx for personal mail).

headline: Going Global With Concerns on Health Costs
text: The United States has long been an unusual study in medical care, with employers assuming much of the cost. Now, though, as the employers say “enough,” calls are deepening for the government to take on more of that role through nationalized health care.

headline: When Women Rule
text: While no woman has been president of the United States  yet  the world does have several thousand years’ worth of experience with female leaders. And I have to acknowledge it: Their historical record puts men’s to shame.

headline: Whose Responsibility Is a Terrace Door?
text: Q At a recent shareholders’ meeting of my co-op, the board said that a terrace is the co-op’s responsibility but that the door leading to it is the responsibility of the shareholder. Is this true?

headline: Two of Yesterday’s Stars Face Off With Gusto
text: In chess, as in life, the elders deserve a little respect. The game’s legends may not regularly face the rigors of tournament play, but they can still put on a good show.

headline: A Little Jewel Box of a Shoe Store
text: THE shoe designer Israel Miller built an unusual series of stores in the 1920s and 1930s, none more remarkable than his arresting little gem, rebuilt in 1926 at the northeast corner of Broadway and 46th Street.

headline: In Reversal, Courts Uphold Local Immigration Laws
text: After groups challenging state and local laws cracking down on illegal immigration won a series of high-profile legal victories last year, the tide has shifted as federal judges recently handed down several equally significant decisions upholding those laws.

headline: Wedding-Bell Grille
text: Wedding-Bell Grille

headline: Next Up for the Democrats: Civil War
text: WHAT if a presidential candidate held what she billed as “the largest, most interactive town hall in political history” on national television, and no one noticed?

headline: Bollywood Princess, Hollywood Hopeful
text: Mumbai

headline: Endless Task: Keeping Unions Clean
text: For more than a decade, federal officials and court-appointed monitors have strained to clean up two New York-area unions, representing cement truck drivers and construction laborers, that prosecutors say were long under Mafia control.

headline: The Lemur
text: Chapter 5: Sweet Guys

headline: Up Front
text: This week’s issue of the Book Review ranges over American politics but not, we hope, in a familiar way. While some of the books reviewed relate, directly or obliquely, to the presidential election and address many of its most divisive issues  race, gender, religion and war  others touch realms where politics meets the imagination and the present confronts the past.

headline: Correction
text: An entry on the fiction best-seller list last Sunday for “Plum Lucky,” by Janet Evanovich, misidentified the character who finds a bag of cash. She is Stephanie’s grandmother, not her mother

headline: Girardi Is Leaving a Lot Behind
text: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla.  Joe Girardi had tears in his eyes, tears that have been building for months, even years, and tears that were close to covering his face. But Girardi, the manager of the Yankees, stared upward, plowed through his thoughts and kept the tears from escaping. He held them back, for now, anyway.

headline: In Tavel, Paying Homage to the Rosé of Kings
text: TAVEL, a town of 1,600 perched at the edge of the Languedoc, on the brink of Provence, is the veritable cradle of French rosé. A staple of the ancient papal court in nearby Avignon and a favorite of Louis XIV and Philippe le Bel (earning it the dual sobriquets Rosé of Kings and King of Rosés), Tavel was the first rosé to be designated AOC (Appellation d’Origine Contrôlée). The appellation has stayed true to its roots; to be called a Tavel, it must be a rosé.

headline: Suzanne Kopp, Michael Moskow
text: Suzanne M. Kopp and Michael H. Moskow were married on Saturday at the Kohl Children’s Museum in Glenview, Ill. Rabbi Samuel N. Gordon officiated.

headline: In Vino Veritas
text: Why are videos of drunken people so compelling?

headline: Pathfinders
text: The South, as its great historian C. Vann Woodward once noted, developed into the United States’ “most distinctive region.” Among its distinctions  bound up with but outlasting its peculiar institution of chattel slavery  were white Southerners’ preoccupations with human limitations, guilt and evil. Not for them the optimistic creed or “dream of perfection” associated with their Northern brethren. In that sense, Woodward argued, the South’s outlook was “a thoroughly un-American one.”

headline: Because They Said So
text: Even by the dismal standards of what passes for a national debate on intelligence and civil liberties, last week was a really bad week.

headline: The Time of Their Lives
text: Campaigning against a president who refused to respond to the growing opposition to a cruel, dishonest war, the charismatic young candidate insisted: “What we need in the United States is not division. What we need in the United States is not hatred. What we need in the United States is ... love and wisdom and compassion toward one another.” That wasn’t last week  it was April 1968, and two months later Robert Kennedy was dead. Opposition to the war continued and broadened after the election of Richard Nixon that fall, but one of the engines of the antiwar movement, Students for a Democratic Society, largely disbanded after a split in 1969; the next year its leaders, gripped by revolutionary fantasies, went underground.

headline: Nods to the Old Country in a Modern Space
text: IN 2004, Ermenegildo Zegna, the men’s luxury clothing and accessories brand, opened a new United States flagship store at 663 Fifth Avenue, between 52nd and 53rd Streets. The Zegna family, the sole owner of the company, would eventually decide that it needed something that better told the story of the business, now 98 years old, and went back to the drawing board.

headline: Taking the Bite Out of a New Mexico Winter
text: TAOS is at its moodiest and most beautiful in winter. It’s the time of the silver gray mesa, of ominous clouds, of crackling cedar logs in kiva fireplaces, of snow clouds billowing in across the plain, of the smoke of house fires leaning in lines from the pueblo rooftops. The adobe architecture seems so well suited to winter, both physically and spiritually. It offers the kind of haven from the cold no other building material can.

headline: Legos for the Grown-Ups
text: THE social event of the season in Locust Point, a quiet enclave of tidy family homes along the East Bronx waterfront, took place just over a week ago when a crane lifted two 18-ton halves of a prefabricated house off flatbed trailers and stacked them like Legos on an empty lot.

headline: Rumor Has It ...
text: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: From One Cuckoo’s Nest to Another
text: “IT’S funny to realize, but in my relatively short life I have lived through six or seven different social and cultural systems,” the filmmaker Milos Forman said. “First the Democratic Republic of Czechoslovakia, then the limited democracy before World War II, then the Nazi regime. After the Nazi regime there was a kind of democracy again for three years, then came the Stalinist regime, then the reformed Communist regime, and now I am living in a free country.”

headline: Letters: How It’s Couched
text: Daphne Merkin’s interesting essay (Jan. 27) suggests that nowadays “the tweaking of serotonin and dopamine levels is considered more effective than examining the wrong turns of the psyche” and that “psychotherapy... has always required a degree of blind faith.” Popular notions, these, but clinicians familiar with the research of the past 30 years believe otherwise. Well-controlled studies of cognitive-behavioral and other types of psychotherapy have shown them to be as effective as medication for certain kinds of psychological problems, like panic attacks. Indeed, for some disorders, cognitive-behavioral therapy may have longer-lasting effects than medication. Experienced psychiatrists know that both psychotherapy and medication have their proper place and often work best when combined.

headline: Breaking Through
text: In 2005, at the Sundance Film Festival, a star was born, but almost no one noticed. Well, actually, a few studio executives who saw “Hard Candy” raved about the performance of the unknown Ellen Page  she played an avenging, psychopathic 14-year-old who entices and then violently tortures a would-be pedophile. But the movie was so relentlessly disturbing (at one point, Page’s character ties her enemy down and slowly begins to castrate him) that when “Hard Candy” was released the following year, no one went to see it. What the audience missed then is what they later found in “Juno”  the birth of a different sort of actress. Unlike her glamour-girl peers who double as tabloid superstars, Page, who is now 20, is a tomboy  her on-screen persona is sharp, clear-eyed, determined and self-consciously original. In “Hard Candy,” she managed to be adorable and persuasive while wielding a large knife; in 2007, that same spirit and charm animated “Juno,” a kind of fairy tale about a pregnant 16-year-old who decides to have the baby and give it to the couple (in the end, half the couple) she chooses. In “Juno,” the lack of realism  no one questions Juno’s decision  and the lack of politics are trumped by the overwhelming appeal of Page’s acting. She is so alive on screen  so unique, so ingratiating  that she makes the character, and the entire film, believable.

headline: The Vanishing Establishment
text: A LITTLE more than 40 years ago, the journalist Richard H. Rovere set off in search of that indistinct tangle of power and influence known as the American Establishment. After months of investigation, Mr. Rovere, in an essay published in 1961, unmasked the establishment’s members  the directors of the Council on Foreign Relations, the chairman of Chase Manhattan Bank, the head of the Ford Foundation, and so on  and offered a working definition: “A more or less closed and self-sustaining institution that holds a preponderance of power in our more or less open society.”

headline: When Pink Pigeons Soared in the Sky
text: AT the Rosebank Deli on Tompkins Avenue, in an unhurried Staten Island neighborhood near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the colors on the awning are the red, white and green of the Italian flag, and on the window, there is the green of a poster advertising homemade meatballs. On Tuesday afternoon, four gray-haired men sat as they often do at a wooden table drinking their coffee out of foam cups.

headline: Man Bites Insect
text: David Gracer eats bugs. Not any old crushed, oozy, sidewalk kind of bug, but insects selected just like any other food  for sustenance and taste. He eats them sautéed, filleted and roasted. And he thinks you should eat them, too.

headline: Who Killed the Courtesan?
text: Henry II, the Plantagenet king who occupies the English throne in Ariana Franklin’s captivating medieval mysteries, proved himself a wise and just (if headstrong) monarch in “Mistress of the Art of Death,” so intellectually enlightened and free of religious superstition that he entrusted a sensitive murder case to Adelia Aguilar, a woman brought up as a free-thinker and schooled in Italy to perform autopsies. In THE SERPENT’S TALE (Putnam, $25.95), which continues this exciting series, the focus is on Henry’s contentious queen, Eleanor of Aquitaine, whose agile mind, strong will and vibrant personality make her a formidable adversary for her royal spouse.

headline: Holiday Show That’s Rockin’ Round the Clock
text: An article on Dec. 16 about Jon Solomon, who is the host of a 24-hour holiday radio show for WPRB-FM at Princeton University, referred incorrectly to Mr. Solomon’s coverage of men’s basketball at the university. He reports for a Web site, princetonbasketball.com, not the radio station.

headline: Terror Threat From Pakistan Said to Expand
text: This article was reported by Elaine Sciolino, Victoria Burnett and Eric Schmitt and written by Ms. Sciolino.

headline: Little Children
text: Thirty-five years after Roe v. Wade, the pro-life movement faces a new challenge: biotechnology. The first human biotech issue, embryonic stem-cell research, looks like an easy call. Stem cells could save millions of lives. And the entity we currently sacrifice to get them  a sacrifice that may soon be unnecessary  is a tiny, undeveloped ball of cells. The question, like the embryo, seems a no-brainer.

headline: The Republican Reformation
text: Washington

headline: Pushing Paper Out the Door
text: CHRIS UHLIK’S children can be found in their home computer lab almost every morning. Nicole is writing a story about her two lizards. Tony is playing an interactive spelling game, while Andy is learning multiplication tables. Even 5-year-old Joceline is clicking away at a storybook game.

headline: Backing for a Behemoth
text: The Posting article last Sunday about Sky View Parc, a new mixed-use development in Flushing, Queens, misstated the area to be used for retail space. It will be 800,000 square feet, not 80,000.

headline: Marrakesh, Morocco: Les Borjs de la Kasbah
text: THE BASICS

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A Calendar listing last Sunday about an exhibition of drawings and prints at the Fairfield Public Library misspelled the surname of the artist. He is James Reed, not Reid.

headline: Republicans Weighing the Benefits of Bush’s Embrace
text: WASHINGTON  With President Bush’s job approval ratings hovering around 30 percent and four-fifths of Americans believing the country is on the wrong track, some Republicans say the best thing he could do this election season would be to simply stay out of the way.

headline: Chinese Hockey Players Make Islanders’ Ice Theirs, for a Period
text: UNIONDALE

headline: Queens Lives Up to Its Billing
text: FOR Patrick Haggerty, Queens was absolutely the place to be. He was convinced of it.

headline: Fresh From Broadway, Souls (and Sex) for Sale
text: There are four hustlers onstage at TheaterWorks in Hartford, but only one of them is in the business of peddling sex. The other three characters in Douglas Carter Beane’s satirical comedy about Hollywood, “The Little Dog Laughed,” cheerfully sell their souls instead.

headline: Left Wing and a Prayer
text: The leadership of the Democratic Party, to its misfortune, has tended to confuse the religious right with religion, period. As a result, they can now look back at a long campaign of successful efforts to alienate white Christians, who make up two-thirds of the American electorate.

headline: We’re Friends, Right?
text: IN classic buddy movies like “Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid,” a mismatched pair of friends learn to transcend their differences and forge a lasting, loyal friendship.

headline: Redskins Hire Zorn as Coach
text: The Washington Redskins hired Jim Zorn as their coach Saturday night, a surprise ending to a monthlong search for a replacement for Joe Gibbs.“I’ve always dreamed of being a head coach with a franchise rich in tradition like the Redskins,” Zorn said in a team news release. “As a player who had to fight Redskins teams at R.F.K. as well as at our home field, I know about the history of this franchise as well as the passion of its fans. I won’t let you down.”The Redskins said Zorn, 54, agreed to a five-year contract.Zorn, a former Seattle quarterback, has been the Seahawks’ quarterbacks coach for the last seven years. The Redskins hired him to be their offensive coordinator Jan. 26 while continuing their search for a head coach. Zorn replaces Gibbs, who resigned Jan. 8.

headline: Joint Chiefs Chairman and Musharraf Discuss Terror Threat
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. Mike Mullen, speaking after meeting top military officials here on Saturday, said Pakistan faced an escalating terrorist threat that could affect the United States, but he also underscored the limitations of what Washington could do about it.

headline: U.S. Universities Rush to Set Up Outposts Abroad
text: When John Sexton, the president of New York University, first met Omar Saif Ghobash, an investor trying to entice him to open a branch campus in the United Arab Emirates, Mr. Sexton was not sure what to make of the proposal  so he asked for a $50 million gift.

headline: Brothers in Arms
text: Mahammed Farooqi, a 49-year-old Pakistani news addict, was snoring through the story of his generation.

headline: Will Disney Keep Us Amused?
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  VISIT Disney’s California Adventure  a 55-acre theme park next door to the fabled progenitor of the modern amusement Mecca, Disneyland  and you will find a noisy reminder of what happens when a company loses its focus and cuts corners.

headline: 36 Hours in Napa Valley
text: STRIKING waves of mustard flower. Rolling fields of budding vines. No traffic. You might need to pack an umbrella and an extra sweater, but winter is a surprisingly beautiful time to visit the Napa Valley of California. A misty and painterly moodiness sweeps over the 30-mile-long region this time of year, scattering the crowds, sharpening the colors and infusing the oak-scented tasting rooms with coziness. Daytime temperatures hover as high as the 50s, and though the season brings rain, it encourages an air of reflection perfectly suited to those big California reds.

headline: How Long Is a Tenant Entitled to Insider Price?
text: Q I live in a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment on the Upper West Side that was once rented by my mother. In the early ’80s, when the building went co-op, she was offered an insider’s price of $165,000 to buy it. She declined. Do I have any right to buy at a lower price?

headline: Lawsuit May Force Ex-U.S.C. Star to Talk
text: New Orleans Saints running back Reggie Bush has faced continual accusations since April 2006 that he and his family took as much as $300,000 in cash and goods while he attended the University of Southern California.

headline: From Bush, Foe of Earmarks, Similar Items
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush often denounces the propensity of Congress to earmark money for pet projects. But in his new budget, Mr. Bush has requested money for thousands of similar projects.

headline: Beyond Bush
text: An author who has published a book extolling George W. Bush as a leader of heroic proportions faces a challenge in deciding what to write next. Given the current state of popular opinion, he might understandably wish to choose a different subject altogether. Or he might simply dig in and argue that Bush will one day be recognized as a great statesman unappreciated in his time. Or, more interestingly, he might decide to pull back from his earlier posture of admiration, take a serious look at what has gone wrong over the past seven years of Republican stewardship, and offer suggestions for how the party and the American conservative movement in general might attempt to recover.

headline: In a House, You Can Make All the Noise You Want
text: FOR the West Village sippy-cup set, it marked the passing of an era when Hali Lee and Peter von Ziegesar moved from that neighborhood across the river to Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: No Tool Left Behind
text: WHEN Ford asked owners of its trucks and vans which work-related problems drove them nuts, forgetting to bring crucial tools to a job was high on the list. At the Chicago Auto Show, Ford demonstrated a radio frequency identification system designed to let owners of its 2009 F-150 and E-Series trucks know if they had every tool on their checklist when they set out.

headline: Cowboys Hire Herring
text: The Dallas Cowboys have hired Reggie Herring as linebackers coach. The hiring comes a little more than a month after Herring, the former Arkansas interim coach, was named the defensive coordinator at Texas A&M. Herring filled the last of the positions that opened in Dallas after Tony Sparano became the Dolphins’ new coach and hired three Cowboys assistants for his staff.

headline: Father and Sons
text: My aging father needs a kidney transplant. A brother and I are willing donors, but I am a perfect blood match while he is only an acceptable match. The hospital says either will do for the next round of testing, but it prefers the perfect blood match. We could flip a coin, a fair way to choose between us, but our dad could get the second-best kidney. Whose needs take precedence?  NAME WITHHELD

headline: Letters: What Happened in Vegas Stayed in His Novel
text: In his otherwise excellent profile (Jan. 27), Charles McGrath observes that Charles Bock is a “little old to be a first novelist” at age 38. Good thing Henry Miller, Anaïs Nin, Joseph Conrad, George Eliot, Stephen Carter, Julia Glass and the nonagenarian writer Millard Kaufman, to name a few, didn’t think they were all washed up when they turned 38.

headline: Letter: Galápagos Islands
text: To the Editor: Regarding "Can Darwin’s Lab Survive Success?" (Jan. 27): You could not have picked a more appropriate setting to begin the Green Traveler series on travel and the environment than my native Ecuador’s Galápagos Islands. These truly enchanted islands, which were the inspiration and the basis for Darwin’s theories, are one of the ultimate destinations for nature lovers and eco-tourists and one of the most treasured, fragile and endangered ecosystems on our planet.

headline: Citing 15-Year Delay, Suit Seeks Action on Rebuilt Wrecks
text: WHEN President Bush signed a bill that would keep millions of vehicles seriously damaged in crashes  and potentially dangerous  from being repaired and sold to unsuspecting buyers, consumer advocates were thrilled.

headline: Yahoo Expected to Reject Microsoft’s Takeover Bid
text: Yahoo’s board plans to reject Microsoft’s $44.6 billion hostile bid in a letter on Monday, saying the offer undervalues Yahoo, people involved in the discussions said Saturday.

headline: Recession Hint Sends Stocks Down Sharply
text: Buffeted by concerns about a weakening economy, the stock market fell last week after two weeks of gains.

headline: Indulge, Charitably
text: If pastries are part of your Valentine’s Day plans this year, you might consider buying ones that not only taste good, but do good: All the proceeds from Connie’s Bakery and General Store in Mount Kisco go to local charities.

headline: Matchmaker, You Have Until Thursday
text: JON BRANSDON left his date on Wednesday night with a glass of scotch in one hand and a scorecard in the other.

headline: Berlin: Weinerei
text: With artists and other creative types slowly being priced out of the adjacent Berlin neighborhoods of Prenzlauer Berg and Mitte, places like the weinerein (wine bars) owned by Jürgen Stumpf are welcome holdouts. These wine bars — all based on an honor system — have a charming, if maybe a bit naïve, faith in mankind’s honesty. For the price of 1 euro (about $1.50), you rent yourself a glass and get to sample as many of the wines as you want. At the end of the night you throw some bills or coins into a big jar, the amount based on what you think is fair.

headline: New Rules Ease the Sting of Mortgages
text: REACTING to the troubles in the nation’s housing and mortgage markets, Congress enacted measures late last year that will give tax breaks to some beleaguered home buyers.

headline: In an Era of Glitz, a Witness With Panache
text: “THE ABOLAFIA FILES,” as Oscar Abolafia describes his celebrity photographs, are kept in file cabinets in a narrow, dim hallway in his small prewar apartment on West 98th Street.

text: “Most writers,” the writer F. Scott Fitzgerald once wrote, “look like writers whether they want to or not. It is hard to say why.”

text: SOME of the most expensive and historic mansions on the Upper East Side pay no taxes at all, and the number is growing. These are, of course, the properties picked up over the years by foreign governments, at a time when prices were far lower than they are today.

headline: Mashups Are Breaking the Mold at Microsoft
text: REDMOND, Wash.  TUCKED away in a building on this forested corporate campus, John Montgomery and his team of 17 programmers might be more at home in Silicon Valley than at Microsoft.

text: AS a suburban environmentalist, Mike Tidwell, 45, of Takoma Park, Md., always felt like a walking contradiction.

text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

headline: For a Book About Peace, a Dose of Trouble
text: KAREEM ABDUL-JABBAR, the 7-foot-2 basketball legend, seemed a fitting subject for a children’s coloring book about tolerance in the age of the war on terror. Mr. Abdul-Jabbar is a Muslim, and he has a distinctly Arabic name. With his status as a celebrity athlete, he seemed a perfect illustration of the principle that people defy stereotypes.

headline: Dan H. Laurence, 87, Bibliographer and George Bernard Shaw Scholar, Is Dead
text: Dan H. Laurence, a noted scholar, editor and bibliographer who devoted nearly every waking moment of his professional life to compiling the voluminous works of George Bernard Shaw, died on Tuesday at his home in San Antonio. He was 87.

headline: Proposal in Texas for a Public-Private Toll Road System Raises an Outcry
text: ROBSTOWN, Tex.  Leon Little’s farm here near Corpus Christi would not be seized for Texas’s proposed $184-billion-plus superhighway project for 5 or 10 years, if ever.

headline: Correction: Seeking a Path in Democracy’s Dead End
text: A map last Sunday with an article about the decline of democracy in Central Asia and the Caucasus misidentified a lake in eastern Kazakhstan. It is Lake Balkhash  not Lake Baykal, which is in Siberia.

headline: When Horizontal Meets Vertical
text: ISLANDIA

headline: Death March
text: No matter how serious a disease may be, devising a cure or treatment or ways of prevention is only half the battle. The other half can be more mysterious. Throughout the world, people who should know better eat, drink or have sex in needlessly risky ways, or ignore medical danger signs until it is too late. These, the willful ignorers, are what interest the South African journalist Jonny Steinberg about the gravest medical crisis his country has experienced: AIDS. More than one out of every eight South Africans is H.I.V. positive, Steinberg reports; every day roughly 800 South Africans die of AIDS and more than 1,000 additional people are infected. A recent survey found that in the previous month, the average South African was more than twice as likely to have been to a funeral as to a wedding.

headline: Selling on eBay? Keep Eye on Gains
text: EBAY and other Web sites have transformed the neighborhood garage sale into a never-ending global auction, vastly expanding the number of potential buyers. The market for a Mickey Mantle rookie baseball card is no longer limited to the kids on the block  nor is the price determined by what those kids are able to pay.

headline: Indian Discontent Fuels Malaysia’s Rising Tensions
text: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  Malaysian Indian Casket, a shop on the outskirts of this modern and cosmopolitan city, sells coffins in all sizes: standard coffins clutter the entrance, child-size boxes are stacked high on the shelves and extra-large models, those for the tallest of the deceased, are stored in the back.

headline: Alexandra Certilman, David Kay
text: Alexandra Beth Certilman was married on Saturday evening to David Victor Kay. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

headline: That Other East End Artists’ Colony
text: STONY BROOK

headline: Atop Vietnamese Noodle Shop, War’s Course Shifted
text: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam  The pho bo, Vietnam’s traditional beef noodle soup, is tasty at the Pho Binh restaurant, but in truth no better than at other places here. The broth is hearty, the noodles are chewy, the small slices of beef tender even if the accompanying pieces of lime and chili pepper looked a bit tired. The price is right: 22,000 dong, or about $1.30.

headline: Long Before Legos, Wood Was Nice and Did Suffice
text: SOMETIMES one great idea is all you get. Take Friedrich Froebel, who, back in the 1830s, convinced that children’s education started too late, founded a play school for younger children (in Blankenburg, Prussia). He named it kindergarten.

headline: Sacred Chow
text: One morning, we heard a shriek from the kitchen. Our cook, Saratbhai, came racing to get my mother to view the evidence: my sister’s handprint in the curd dish and a line of white plops all the way to the bedroom we shared.

headline: Close Indian Point? It Could Be Costly
text: CLOSING the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan could have dire consequences for the county’s economy, according to a new report by the Westchester Business Alliance, a coalition of regional groups.

headline: Singh Shares Lead, and Mickelson Misses Cut After an 11
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Even as Vijay Singh roared into a tie for the lead with Dudley Hart at nine under par, restoring some sense of order in the AT&T Pebble Beach Pro-Am on Saturday, Phil Mickelson went the other way by missing the cut here for the first time in six years.

headline: Meet David Wright, the Real Mr. Met
text: When Brian Schneider was traded to the Mets from the Washington Nationals in November, his first phone call came from the Nationals’ general manager, Jim Bowden. Then he heard from Omar Minaya, the Mets’ general manager. Almost immediately after he hung up with Minaya, his cellphone buzzed again. It was a text message from one of his new teammates. “It’s D-Wright,” the message began.

headline: Don’t Like Taxes? Consider the Alternative
text: EVERY year at tax time, someone is sure to remind us of Benjamin Franklin’s maxim that nothing is certain but death and taxes. The statement happens to be true, but associating taxes with death adds only to the gloom of the moment. My goal here is to remove some of that gloom.

headline: Myanmar Junta Calls for Vote
text: BANGKOK  Myanmar’s military government on Saturday announced a timetable for what it calls its “roadmap to democracy,” scheduling a referendum on a proposed constitution for May and elections for 2010.

headline: Postpartisan
text: “G.O.P. Doubts, Fears ‘Post-Partisan’ Obama” went a Washington Post headline as this election year began. A week before, the Times columnist David Brooks told ABC’s George Stephanopoulos about “the post partisan independence of John McCain.” A week later, Times reporters noted how Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York “has spent months laying out his vision for a post-partisan approach to politics that would take the best from left and right.”

headline: In Dentist’s Death, Clues Line Up After a Big Break
text: A homemade silencer found lying in some leaves. Bingo.

headline: Obama Scores Convincing Wins in Three States
text: Senator Barack Obama won decisive victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Washington, Louisiana and Nebraska on Saturday, giving him an impressive sweep going into a month when the Democratic nominating contests are expected to favor him.

headline: The First Ache
text: Twenty-five years ago, when Kanwaljeet Anand was a medical resident in a neonatal intensive care unit, his tiny patients, many of them preterm infants, were often wheeled out of the ward and into an operating room. He soon learned what to expect on their return. The babies came back in terrible shape: their skin was gray, their breathing shallow, their pulses weak. Anand spent hours stabilizing their vital signs, increasing their oxygen supply and administering insulin to balance their blood sugar.

headline: Europeans Are From Venus
text: At the time of the World Cup the summer before last, there was a nice cartoon in the papers by Oliphant, with two panels. One showed “Soccer as seen by Americans,” a group of dainty chaps prancing lightly across the grass with purses dangling from their limp wrists, and the other, “American football as seen by Europeans,” a heap of brutally moronic humanoids using severed limbs to batter each others’ brains out.

headline: Cape Town Townships
text: To the Editor: I’ve been to Cape Town twice, and the highlight of each trip was two days spent touring the townships. They were the most memorable of all of Cape Town’s extraordinary sights and experiences but were omitted from your 36 Hours (Jan. 27) itinerary.

headline: A League of Their Own
text: AVERAGE apartment sale prices in Manhattan soared last month to the highest levels ever, showing the tenacity and power of the luxury market.

headline: Events in New Jersey

headline: Letters: Minorities for Money?
text: I disagree with the Ethicist’s advice (Jan. 27) regarding financial incentives for hiring minority candidates. While he is correct that presenting a diversity of backgrounds and viewpoints is an important part of any university’s mission, the financial incentives as described are unethical and possibly illegal. The university’s acceptance of a job application is an implied promise that the candidate will be assessed based on her qualifications for the position, not the interviewer’s potential financial gains.

headline: A Walk on the Wild Side, and Then Some
text: Among the many outrageous works in “Person of the Crowd: The Contemporary Art of Flânerie,” at the Neuberger Museum of Art, is a photograph of Marina Abramovic, “the grandmother of performance art.” It is one of a series documenting a performance in which she traded places for four hours with a Dutch prostitute to mark the opening of her 1975 show at a gallery in Amsterdam. The work is called “Role Exchange,” and in many ways typifies the loopy experimentation of the era, when artists knew no boundaries.

headline: Some Killings Don’t Get Solved
text: LONDON

headline: High End and Front Rank
text: Bedell Cellars’ first vintage of Musée (Museum) and second of Gallery symbolize its commitment to art, both on walls and in bottles.

headline: Coyotes Are Yowling Confidence
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  It has been easy for the Phoenix Coyotes to exceed expectations because they were expected by most of the hockey world to finish last in the N.H.L. this season.

headline: Rustic, Cozy and Casual
text: WILD HARVEST, a new restaurant that opened in Glen Cove in mid-December, has a name that makes clear the connection with its four-year-old sibling, Wild Honey in Oyster Bay; both are owned by Tina and Rob O’Brien and Zane Smith, who is also the chef.

headline: ‘Idol’ to Be a Theme on Cruises
text: If you think you’ll need an “American Idol” fix while the show is on hiatus next fall, here’s an idea: take a cruise. Royal Caribbean International has announced that it will offer five cruises with an “American Idol” theme Nov. 19 through Dec. 21 aboard its newest ship, the Independence of the Seas.

headline: A More Intimate Grand Bazaar
text: FORGET the Grand Bazaar. If you want to return from Istanbul with truly memorable souvenirs, head over to the winding streets of Cukurcuma, the city’s funky antiques district, where you can get anything from camel saddles to decorative brass faucets from defunct Turkish baths.

headline: Look Who’s Getting Rolled Out of the Bar
text: THESE days little children are brought along to places that would have been considered inappropriate a generation ago: four-star restaurants, cocktail parties, rock concerts. But for all the sniping from adults who resent this territorial invasion, the onslaught shows no sign of letting up. In fact, one of its latest flash points is the local bar.

headline: NATO’s Leader Says the Alliance Remains Unified on Troops for Afghan Mission
text: MUNICH  NATO is not devolving into a two-tier alliance of those who fight and those who will not, the alliance’s secretary general said Saturday at an international security conference.

headline: Vonn Ties American Mark
text: Lindsey Vonn won her ninth career World Cup downhill Saturday in Sestriere, Italy, matching the American record set by Picabo Street and Daron Rahlves.The victory propelled Vonn back to the top of the overall World Cup standings, 3 points ahead of Nicole Hosp of Austria. “It’s awesome,” Vonn said. “I was superpsyched about that, and I still have more this season, so hopefully I can get another one under my belt.”Vonn used a much straighter line than the other skiers to cover the 1.84-mile Kandahar Banchetta course in 1 minute 38.86 seconds. It is the same downhill course the men used at the 2006 Turin Olympics.

headline: Andrea Linett and Michael Waring
text: Andrea Lee Linett and Michael Simon Waring were married on Saturday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan. Judge Joseph E. Gubbay of Brooklyn Criminal Court officiated.

headline: Washingtonians
text: Former Senator Bob Dole once said the most dangerous place in Washington “is between Chuck Schumer and a television camera,” as Dana Milbank reminds us in his new book. Today, things are worse. Now there is also the retired diplomat Joe Wilson (Milbank quotes The New Republic: “Do not let yourself get between him and a camera, a lectern or a buffet, or you will likely be trampled”), the pundit Larry Sabato (a former governor of Virginia, Milbank writes, “postulated that ‘the shortest distance between two points is Larry Sabato and a TV camera’ ”) and many others. They belong to “the Gang of 500,” as Mark Halperin, formerly of ABC News, describes (in Milbank’s words) “the lawmakers, strategists, journalists and officials who, collectively, define the social order of Potomac Land.” And they are the focus of “Homo Politicus.”

headline: In Mexico: A Bus of Women's Own
text: Mexico City has created "Women Only" buses in response to complaints of sexual harassment on public transportation.

headline: ‘His Illegal Self’

There were plenty of pictures of his mom. There she was with short blond hair, her eyes so white against her tan. And that was her also, with black hair, not even a sister to the blonde girl, although maybe they shared a kind of bright attention.

text: Sometimes in government the most dramatic and noble events come disguised as endless meetings, what might be called the banality of goodness.

text: Aired Friday night on CBS: It’s Fashion Week in New York City. And everybody in New York gets into Fashion Week. As a matter of fact, Hillary Clinton today was wearing her strapless pantsuit.

headline: Avoiding the Deep End
text: TAX season is never pleasant, but this one could have been much worse for many taxpayers. An estimated 20 million Americans were spared additional tax burdens by the Tax Increase Prevention Act of 2007, known less formally as "the A.M.T. patch," signed by President Bush on Dec. 26. The change means that they will escape the alternative minimum tax, though it is still expected to snare more than 4 million other taxpayers.

headline: Can We Uninvent Suburbia?
text: There’s a fine story in our Sunday Styles section today by Alex Williams examining the environmental costs of suburban life, which evolved around the highway system, cheap oil, and the automobile and now typically consumes several times more energy per person (and thus fossil fuels) than urban living. There’s all that driving. There are the chugging mowers and fertilizers and pesticides used to keep all those lawns lovely. Lighting, heating and cooling those ballooning homes consumes vast amounts of energy compared to a city apartment — or a house half a century ago.

headline: Income and consumption inequality
text: So Cox and Alm have a piece in today’s Times arguing that consumption inequality is much less than income inequality, so nothing to worry about.

text: Fresh off two shutout victories at Philadelphia, Rangers backup goalie Steve Valiquette will start for the second straight day as the Rangers play at Washington Sunday afternoon. It gives a rare weekend off to starter Henrik Lundqvist, who has played a bit lately like he needs it.

text: Oscar Abolafia worked for Time, People and Life as a celebrity photographer in the 1960s. Here are some of his images.

headline: Obama Edges Out a Clinton — For a Grammy
text: Barack Obama, not known for his singing prowess, nevertheless picked up a Grammy Award Sunday for the spoken-word recording of his most recent book, “The Audacity of Hope.”

headline: Down the Rabbit Hole With Chronic Daily Headache
text: When he plunged Alice down the rabbit hole, the author Lewis Carroll was armed with a powerful tool from his own inner life to make his heroine’s journey all the weirder: migraines. He certainly took advantage of the vision distortions that accompanied his particular spells to make Alice feel as clumsy and disoriented as possible in her far-from-wonderful “wonderland.”

headline: Ask Dana Hadan a Question
text: Dana Hadan, a business student enrolled at the Carnegie Mellon campus in Qatar, is fielding questions on what it’s like being a student at an overseas branch of an American university.

headline: A Shocked Crowd in Buffalo
text: A gruesome accident sent Richard Zednik off the ice bleeding profusely at the Florida-at-Buffalo game Sunday. People sat in stunned silence at the sold-out HSBC Center. Zednik had been cut on the neck by the skate of Florida teammate Olli Jokinen.

headline: Spain Horror Story Redux
text: Another expat couple is facing heavy fines and the possible demolition of their home in Spain, after the local government declared it illegal.

headline: On to Virginia
text: Sixty-three Republican delegates and 83 Democratic delegates are up for grabs at the Virginia primary on Tuesday. Recent polling shows Senator John McCain with a two-to-one advantage over former Gov. Mike Huckabee, and Senator Barack Obama with a strong lead over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. The poll was conducted Thursday and Friday by Mason-Dixon Polling and Research and included 400 likely Democratic primary voters and 400 likely Republican primary voters.

headline: A Calumny a Day To Keep Hillary Away
text: The responses to my column on Hillary Clinton-hating have been both voluminous (the largest number in the brief history of “Think Again”) and fascinating. The majority of posters agreed with the characterization of the attacks on Senator Clinton as vicious and irrational, but in not a few posts the repudiation of Hillary-hatred is followed by more of the same. Lisa (No. 17) nicely exemplifies the pattern. She begins by saying “I agree that there is a rabid nature in the manner in which numerous conservative groups attack Hillary Clinton,”, but in the very next sentence she declares that “most of Hillary’s reputation is well earned” and then she spends nine paragraphs being rabid. A significant minority of posters skipped the ritual disavowal of hatred and went straight to the task of adding to it.

headline: As Voting Pattern Emerges, So Does Need to Break It
text: Senator Barack Obama scored impressive weekend victories over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in several Democratic presidential nomination contests. He is well positioned for this week’s voting in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. But neither candidate has achieved what is most important for deciding their battle. That is breaking the pattern of voter preferences that has structured their competition so far.

headline: Bill Clinton Takes to the Churches
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. — After losing two caucuses and a primary to Senator Barack Obama Saturday, Senator Hillary Clinton’s campaign seemed like it might need a prayer. Or two. And so Bill Clinton started off his day of Potomac Primary campaigning with a stop at the Temple of Praise, an African-American church in Washington, DC.

headline: Conflict Hurts Kenya's Middle Class
text: Torn between their work identity and their ethnic backgrounds, members of Kenya's vibrant middle class anxiously try to stay in business.

headline: Beyond Buckingham Palace: Hip London Style Tours
text: London is a sprawling city, and can be difficult to navigate. The many tour buses that visit all the main sites of interest such as the Tower of London, Buckingham Palace and Houses of Parliament are great for first time visitors.

headline: World Club Top 10: Birth of the K.H.L.
text: Most European leagues have been on international break for the last week or thereabouts, so not much change in the Top 10.

headline: Tyree Talks About His Rise From Rock Bottom to Super Bowl Stardom
text: The Giants’ David Tyree spent about 90 minutes with The Times on Saturday morning for an article in Monday’s newspaper, and graciously recounted his arrest, his drunken blackouts, his finding faith and his mom’s death in December. He had just arrived home after taking a red-eye flight from Los Angeles, where he was making the talk-show rounds after making his memorable catch in the Super Bowl. He sat at his kitchen table, surrounded by family preparing for an afternoon baby shower. What follows are some excerpts from the conversation.

headline: In Mexico: A Bus of Women's Own
text: Mexico City has created "Women Only" buses in response to complaints of sexual harassment on public transportation.

text: In an attempt to increase book sales, HarperCollins Publishers will begin offering free electronic editions of some of its books on its Web site, including a novel by Paulo Coelho and a cookbook by the Food Network star Robert Irvine.

headline: This Week’s Major Business Events
text: COMPANY EARNINGS Some big names will post earnings this week, including Hasbro and Loews (Monday); Credit Suisse, General Motors, Marsh & McLennan, Molson Coors, Omnicom, Qwest Communications, Sanofi-Aventis and Schering-Plough (Tuesday); Belo, Coca-Cola, Deere and Jones Apparel (Wednesday); Clear Channel, Comcast, Daimler, Goodyear Tire & Rubber and UBS (Thursday); and Campbell Soup and Hormel Foods (Friday).

headline: John Alvin, Designer of Memorable Film Posters, Is Dead at 59
text: John Alvin, who created memorable images for movie posters, billboards and advertisements, including the two fingers touching above the Earth’s surface for “E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial,” died on Wednesday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 59.

headline: Nafta Is a Sweet Deal, So Why Are They So Sour?
text: Fourteen years after Nafta came into effect, the last remaining barriers to agricultural trade in North America were dismantled last month. Mexican corn farmers and American Big Sugar hate this unreservedly.

headline: Lowery Wins in Playoff After Collapse by Singh
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  Steve Lowery came in from the golf wilderness Sunday. Lowery, who was ranked 305th in the world and had not had a PGA Tour victory in the past seven years, rediscovered what it takes to win, birdieing the first hole of sudden death to defeat Vijay Singh in the Pebble Beach National Pro Am.

headline: Roy Scheider, Actor in ‘Jaws,’ Dies at 75
text: Roy Scheider, a stage actor with a background in the classics who became one of the leading figures in the American film renaissance of the 1970s, died on Sunday afternoon in Little Rock, Ark. He was 75 and lived in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Chávez Threatens to End Oil Exports to U.S. in Exxon Feud
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez threatened Sunday to halt oil exports to the United States if the oil giant Exxon Mobil succeeds in freezing billions of dollars of foreign petroleum assets controlled by Venezuela.

headline: Army Buried Study Faulting Iraq Planning
text: WASHINGTON  The Army is accustomed to protecting classified information. But when it comes to the planning for the Iraq war, even an unclassified assessment can acquire the status of a state secret.

headline: Train Strikes and Kills a Veteran N.J. Transit Welder
text: A longtime New Jersey Transit track welder was killed when he was hit by a train on Sunday morning near the Ridgewood station, a spokesman for the railroad said.

headline: As Toll Dodgers Get Creative, Eyes of E-ZPass Are Watching
text: Cameras photographing cars from just about every imaginable angle. High-speed radio frequency readers instantly scanning E-ZPass tags. Two dozen “image review clerks” hunched over computers in their cubicles examining thousands of photographs each day, waiting to pounce.

headline: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse

headline: Moderator and a Panelist Ousted at ‘Fox News Watch’

headline: Campaign Needed for Minority Candidates for Football Coach
