headline: Rolling Stones Comment on Drug Use by Others
text: Having been there and done that, a couple of Rolling Stones had a few words of counsel for today’s drug-prone young musicians, Reuters reported. In an appearance at the Berlin Film Festival, the guitarist Keith Richards, right, referring to Amy Winehouse, said, “She should get her act together.” The Stones’ frontman, Mick Jagger, in speaking about Ms. Winehouse and Pete Doherty, said times were different. Mr. Jagger said: “When we were experimenting with drugs, little was known about the effects. In our time there were no rehab centers like today. Anyway, I did not know about them.” Now 64, a grandfather and a fitness fanatic, Mr. Jagger said he couldn’t understand how the younger generation, knowing the dangers of drugs, could still be users.

headline: Would Voting at 16 Be Even Sweeter?
text: To the Editor:

headline: President of East Timor Wounded in Rebel Attack
text: President José Ramos-Horta of East Timor was shot and seriously wounded Monday, and gunmen attacked a convoy carrying Prime Minister Xanana Gusmão, threatening to further destabilize the struggling young nation.

headline: As the Tides Turned: Hollywood in 1967 Through the Lens of Five Films
text: In the same year and even on the same planet, five crazily diverse films became nominees for the Academy Award for best picture in 1967. At its April 1968 ceremony the academy chose among an instant-classic vision of the brand new Generation Gap (“The Graduate”), a painfully dated Hollywood dinosaur (“Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner”), a fierily innovative, mythic outlaw tale (“Bonnie and Clyde”), a walking lecture on racial prejudice (“In the Heat of the Night”) and a budget-busting musical full of animals (“Dr. Dolittle”). The last of these, stinker that it was, appropriately had to be filmed on sets with drains patrolled by workers wielding brooms.

headline: Consumer Product Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: West Gets a Workout in the Deductive Arts
text: Everyone makes mistakes at the bridge table, even experts. Twice I have seen top pairs fail to defeat three no-trump when in the suit led at Trick 1 declarer had a singleton on the board and three to the jack in his hand. Once the defenders blocked the suit; the other time the opening leader shifted at Trick 3.

headline: Bush, Breaking Campaign Silence, Offers a Nod to McCain (and Huckabee)
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush broke his silence on the 2008 presidential race on Sunday, giving his imprimatur to Senator John McCain of Arizona as a “true conservative,” who nonetheless has “got some convincing to do” to persuade fellow Republicans of his bona fides with the right.

headline: How Many More Warnings?
text: Even with families victimized in the Virginia Tech massacre looking on, lawmakers in Virginia lined up like clay pigeons for the gun lobby last month to block legislation that would have closed the state’s notorious gun-show loophole. That means that anyone  ex-felons and deranged citizens included  can continue to buy firearms at laissez-faire “sportsmen” shows.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Maine to Obama; Clinton Replaces Campaign Leader
text: VIRGINIA BEACH  Senator Barack Obama racked up his fourth decisive victory this weekend, winning the Maine caucuses on Sunday, as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton replaced her campaign manager and longtime aide in the biggest shakeup of her campaign to date.

headline: Drawn to the Screen, Big and Small
text: There are times when a heavy diet of one medium means less of another. For example, teenagers who play the video game Halo 3 are most likely to do so just before prime time, meaning they watch less television than the average teenager. One might imagine, similarly, that teenage moviegoers would see less television than their more movie-averse peers.

headline: And the Grammy Award for Best Polka Record Goes To...
text: Record of the Year: “Rehab,” Amy Winehouse

headline: In Britain, a Campaign Against Obesity Is Snarled in Controversy
text: LONDON  The campaign against AIDS has its red ribbons. The movement against poverty has its white wristbands. And if the advertising industry has its way, the effort to curb obesity may soon get its own instantly recognizable symbol.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: David Barrington joined the North American operations of MPG, New York, part of Havas, in a new post, executive vice president and managing director for video investments. He had most recently been the senior vice president and general sales manager at My Network TV, part of the News Corporation.

headline: Committee Chairman Criticizes Clemens’s Lawyer Over Remarks
text: The chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform criticized one of Roger Clemens’s lawyers Sunday for remarks he had made about a federal agent’s plan to attend a committee hearing Wednesday.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Microsoft Signals Fight for Yahoo Isn’t Over
text: Yahoo officially rejected Microsoft’s $44.6 billion takeover offer on Monday, calling the bid too low, but Microsoft appeared to signal that it was gearing up for a long acquisition fight.

headline: Threat to Campus Reactors Cited
text: WASHINGTON  The risk of a terrorist attack on a nuclear research reactor on a college campus, and the potential consequences, have been underestimated by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, according to Congressional auditors.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: HSBC Is Expected to Sell 400 Banks
text: LONDON  HSBC Holdings, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, a person with direct knowledge of the plan confirmed on Sunday.

headline: Tug of War Over Undecided Virginia Democrats
text: LEXINGTON, Va.  With less than 24 hours to decide, Priscilla Baker remained torn between voting for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama in the Democratic presidential primary here on Tuesday.

headline: L.I. Hospital Scrutinized After Deaths of Patients
text: Last spring, doctors at Mercy Medical Center on Long Island gave a patient the news she had feared: Cancer had been detected in her left breast.

headline: Restoring Luster to Two 20th-Century Dance Legends
text: This year brings the centenaries of the births of two choreographers who loomed large in New York in the middle of the last century: José Limón, who died in 1972, and Antony Tudor, who died in 1987. Theirs are once-big names whose legacies seem to be shrinking. Plenty of today’s dancegoers have never seen a single work by either. Special thanks, then, to the enterprising New York Theater Ballet last weekend for giving New York what I believe are the year’s first staged revivals of either man’s work.

headline: Houston’s Hip-Hop Scene Picks Up the Pieces After Yet Another Death
text: HOUSTON  On Friday night here at Warehouse Live, 48 hours and 1,500 miles from the Grammy Awards, more than a thousand fans gathered for a different sort of musical celebration.

headline: Hope Later
text: The Bush administration was too slow to wake up to the foreclosure crisis. Now it’s asking Congress for more time to show results through Hope Now, a mortgage industry alliance created at the urging of the Treasury Department. Given the administration’s poor record on the issue, lawmakers should not wait to pass their own foreclosure prevention plans. Most important is amending bankruptcy law to allow defaulting borrowers to modify the terms of their mortgages under court protection.

headline: Star-Crossed Lovers Caught in an Unenlightened Era
text: “Oroonoko,” which opened Sunday night at the Duke on 42nd Street, is a disappointment onstage, maybe in part because it sounded so intriguing on paper.

headline: Between States, Hard Feelings Over a Rock’s Place
text: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio

headline: Good Days Have Arrived, but Bad Times Have a Say
text: Better late than never: for reasons alluded to in “Before the Money Came (The Battle of Bettye LaVette),” her career-summarizing personal anthem of bad luck, hard times and ultimate triumph, the 62-year-old Detroit soul singer Bettye LaVette is only now receiving the kind of recognition she should have enjoyed 40 years ago.

headline: Bush Calls McCain a ‘True Conservative’
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush broke his silence on the 2008 presidential race on Sunday, giving his imprimatur to Senator John McCain of Arizona as a “true conservative,” who nonetheless has “got some convincing to do” to persuade fellow Republicans of his right-wing bona fides.

headline: Unworthy Nominees
text: President Bush staged an event in the East Room last week for his unconfirmed appointees and repeated a story line so tired that it’s hard to imagine even he believes it. His nominations  of judges, top Justice Department officials and others  are stalled, he said, because of undue Senate delay. The real problem, of course, is that 15 months after American voters put the Democrats in control of the Senate, Mr. Bush is still trying to muscle far-right ideologues with troubling records into important positions.

headline: On Single-Sex Buses, Relief From Unwanted Contact
text: MEXICO CITY  Body-to-body contact is inescapable on Mexico City’s crowded public transportation system. Get on a train or a bus during rush hour and a man in a business suit may have his arm resting against your shoulder, a woman toting a bulky shopping bag may have her back pressed against your flank, and a teenager listening to an iPod may tap his sneaker all over your newly shined left shoe.

headline: No Manchurian Candidate
text: I believe Barack Obama is a strong but not uncritical supporter of Israel. That is what the Middle East needs from an American leader: the balance implicit in a two-state solution.

headline: The Do-Not-Call List
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trading Pinstripes for Politics
text: You’ve been dating the same person for years. She’s not flashy, but she is steady and, to your mind, glorious. And then you begin to notice changes. A slimmer profile, a suddenly increased concern with appearances. You keep your suspicions to yourself, but it soon becomes obvious that everything is changing. And you finally just blurt it out.

headline: Feisty Birds of a Feather, No Chickens in Sight
text: Every workplace has someone like Rachel, an employee who beams with false confidence, broadcasts her talents and puts her own advancement ahead of teamwork. The Rachels of the world give themselves pep talks like this one: “You have to be able to look in the mirror and say, ‘I’m worth a thousand for half an hour, I’m worth $10,000 for a half an hour, I’m worth whatever.’ ”

headline: Keeping a Faun, a Scamp and a Firebird in Line
text: Marin Alsop’s motley program with the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday evening told several colorful tales, evoking the ill-fated scamp of Strauss’s “Till Eulenspiegel” and the exotic protagonists of Debussy’s “Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun” and Stravinsky’s “Firebird” Suite. But it only hinted at the tale that some listeners were most curious about: how Ms. Alsop’s relationship with the orchestra is faring.

headline: Proportion of Immigrants in U.S. Rises
text: If present trends continue, within two decades the proportion of immigrants in the United States will surpass the peak reached more than a century ago, a new analysis concludes.

headline: Rebels With Instruments: Dashing Tradition, Sort Of
text: “Hey, Johnny, what are you rebelling against?” The question was posed to a leather-jacketed biker tough played by Marlon Brando in the 1953 film “The Wild One.” His response is now legend: “Whaddya got?” The lines effectively defined an American type: the rough-hewn iconoclast with no use for the rules of polite (read: uptight) society.

headline: For McCain, Losses Signal Challenges
text: Just as Senator John McCain appeared poised to become the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, he was reminded over the weekend that many Republican voters still have not climbed aboard his bandwagon.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A caption on Thursday with a photograph of a home in Israel hit by a Palestinian rocket described the events surrounding the attack imprecisely. While the rocket attack followed an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, it was not known whether it was in fact in retaliation for the airstrike.

headline: In This Election, It’s Running Cats and Dogs
Energy Efficiency
text: To the Editor:

headline: Astronauts Attach Science Module to Space Station
text: WASHINGTON  Two astronauts and a robot arm on Monday guided Europe’s new Columbus science module out of the space shuttle Atlantis to become a permanent part of the International Space Station.

headline: Car Bombing Outside Market in Iraq Kills 23
text: BAGHDAD  At least 23 people were killed Sunday after a car bomb exploded north of Baghdad at a checkpoint run by the police and citizen patrols of Iraqis who have turned against the insurgency, Iraqi officials said.

headline: G.I. Gets 10-Year Sentence in Killing of Unarmed Iraqi
text: CAMP LIBERTY, Iraq  A military panel on Sunday sentenced an Army soldier to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee and planting a machine gun near his body to mislead investigators.

headline: A CBS Newsman’s Serenade: Give My Regards to Mr. Redstone
text: Two singers who owe their success, in part, to the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone paid tribute to him at a gala given in his honor last week in New York by the Paley Center for Media. One, Tony Bennett, the 81-year-old singer, sang “Fly Me to the Moon” and thanked Mr. Redstone for changing the path of his career.

headline: Tiny Cellphone Chip Aims to Improve Sound Quality
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A Silicon Valley start-up company that has modeled the function of the human ear plans on Monday to introduce an integrated circuit intended to improve the sound quality of cellphones.

headline: High Lead Levels Are Found in Vinyl Plastic Baby Products
text: High levels of lead were found in a handful of well-known baby products made of vinyl plastic by an environmental group based in California that spread the word about lead on vinyl baby bibs and lunchboxes.

headline: That Book About the Patriots’ Perfect Season Ended With a Giant Asterisk
text: Talk about premature congratulation: The Boston Globe had planned to run a supplement marking a big Super Bowl win for the New England Patriots in its Feb. 4 issue. Instead the paper carried the forlorn front-page headline “History Derailed.”

headline: An Absence of Scoring Leaves Jagr Cringing
text: The grimace has become so common now, the total disgust that consumes Jaromir Jagr’s face when another shot lands harmlessly in a goaltender’s pads. It is a look of pain and frustration that grows more acute as the Rangers’ season sputters along, with Jagr, their captain, wearing its effects for all to see.

headline: Highlights Showed a Hard Worker
text: David Tyree’s road to the N.F.L. was nearly as improbable as his remarkable catch in the Super Bowl. Coming out of Syracuse in 2003, his numbers  6 feet 1 inch, 197 pounds, 4.5 speed in the 40 and only 36 catches his senior season  did not appear to be N.F.L. material.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,947 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

headline: Film Prize Winners
text: The “Juno” script by Diablo Cody, below, won the prize for original screenplay when the Writers Guild of America announced its awards on Saturday in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported. The accolade for adapted screenplay went to the brothers Ethan and Joel Coen for “No Country for Old Men.” ... “Ratatouille” won best feature production and received nine other Annie Awards, honoring achievements in feature film and television animation, at an International Animated Film Society ceremony in Los Angeles on Friday, The Associated Press reported. ... The London Film Critics’ Circle named “No Country for Old Men” film of the year, the BBC reported. Honors for best actor went to Daniel Day-Lewis for “There Will Be Blood” and for best actress to Marion Cotillard for “La Vie en Rose.”

headline: Ex-Washington Post Reporter to Lead a Rival
text: WASHINGTON  For more than 25 years, The Washington Times has positioned itself against its more liberal cross-town rival, The Washington Post.

headline: After Strike, TV Shows Hurry Up and Wait
text: The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week, initiating a flurry of activity that may begin to restore the regularly scheduled programming interrupted when the writers’ strike shut down major parts of the television season.

headline: NBC News in Orbit
text: Network newscasts have been known to go to great lengths to find new viewers, but the “NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams” has taken that search to a place where few, if any, anchors, have gone before: outer space. In an interview from the International Space Station on Friday via satellite, an American astronaut, Daniel M. Tani, right, said he and his crew members “actually watch the ‘NBC Nightly News.’ ” Mr. Tani was responding to a question from an NBC correspondent, Tom Costello, about how the space station crew stays current on world events. The network said that Mr. Costello had been unaware that NASA regularly transmits podcasts of “Nightly News” (minus commercials) to the space station. The astronauts also receive news updates from The Houston Chronicle, one of NASA’s hometown newspapers. Brett Holey, director of “Nightly News,” said NBC began making the program available to the space station in early 2006. It did so, he said, after a “psychological support scientist” for NASA suggested the transmission as a way to ease isolation.

headline: How Sticky Is Membership on Facebook? Just Try Breaking Free
text: Are you a member of Facebook.com? You may have a lifetime contract.

headline: Wide BlackBerry Outage Reported
text: OTTAWA  For the second time in less than a year, a technical failure idled the thumbs of many BlackBerry users on Monday by severing their wireless link to e-mail and the Web.

headline: Top Dogs Live On, and On, in Progeny
text: Mick is a retired elite athlete whose libidinous talents were once so coveted that well-bred ovulating females flew to his crib near Sacramento in the fervent hope that their assignations would make them pregnant.

headline: Rangers Have the Chances, but Not the Result
text: WASHINGTON  For one stomach-dropping moment, Rangers goaltender Steve Valiquette watched Sunday’s game turn right in front of him. Washington defenseman Mike Green wound up for a slap shot on a power play in overtime, a shot that Valiquette saw but was left helpless to stop as it ricocheted off one of his teammates, defenseman Marc Staal, and sailed past him.

headline: Israeli Officials Seek Tougher Military Action in Gaza After Rockets Wound 2 in Sderot
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli cabinet ministers on Sunday urged sharper military action in Gaza after a rocket attack by Palestinian militants the night before seriously wounded two brothers, ages 8 and 19, in the town of Sderot on the Israeli border.

headline: Egyptian Court Allows Return to Christianity
text: CAIRO  Cairo’s highest civil court on Saturday ruled that 12 Christians who had converted to Islam could return to their original church, ending a bitter yearlong battle over identity and minority rights.

headline: Families Adopting in Vietnam Say They Are Caught in Diplomatic Jam
text: WASHINGTON  Eyes like black pearls, the softest skin and little tufts of hair made it totally easy to fall in love at first sight. And that is what Julie Carroll  and Jewel McRoberts and Tommi-Lynn Sawyer  did when they saw the three tiny girls at a Vietnamese orphanage. They adopted the babies after months of waiting and then had to leave them behind because they could not obtain entry visas to bring them back to the United States.

headline: Hedge Fund Group Increases Stake in Times Co.
text: The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on the board of The New York Times Company has more than doubled its stake in the company, to at least 9.96 percent of the regular shares, according to federal records filed Monday.

headline: Two Picasso Oils Stolen in Switzerland
text: Two Picasso oils valued at $4.5 million were stolen last week from a Swiss museum in Pfaeffikon, Agence France-Presse reported. The paintings, the 1962 “Tête de Cheval” (“Horse’s Head”) and the 1944 “Verre et Pichet” (“Glass and Pitcher”), were on loan from the Sprengel Museum in Hanover, Germany. The police theorized that the thieves, who touched off an alarm when leaving at 7 p.m., may have remained in the museum after it closed.

headline: U.S. Ties Europe’s Safety to Afghanistan
text: MUNICH  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates issued a stark warning on Sunday to Europeans, saying that their safety from terrorist attack by Islamic extremists was directly linked to NATO’s success in stabilizing Afghanistan.

headline: Israel’s Secret Success
text: Jerusalem

headline: Court Rebuffs Fisk University
text: Fisk University in Nashville suffered a setback in its efforts to ease its financial problems when a judge rejected on Friday its proposal to raise $30 million by sharing its Alfred Stieglitz Collection of modern art with the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, founded in Bentonville, Ark., by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton, The Associated Press reported. Davidson County Chancellor Ellen Hobbs Lyle ruled that such an arrangement would not reflect the wishes of the artist Georgia O’Keeffe, who donated the 101-piece collection to Fisk, a historically black university, in 1949. A trial scheduled for Feb. 19 will determine if Fisk should forfeit the collection to the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M.

headline: Footnotes
text: A Nicole Kidman swimsuit, abandoned at a Swedish pool, sold in Sweden at an auction for charity on Saturday for $2,500, enough to buy nine cows for poor families in India, Agence France-Presse reported. ... Two books are to be named winners of the 2008 Lincoln Prize for American history on Monday. The winners were “The Radical and the Republican: Frederick Douglass, Abraham Lincoln, and the Triumph of Antislavery Politics” (W. W. Norton) by James Oakes, a professor at City University of New York, and “Reading the Man: A Portrait of Robert E. Lee Through His Private Letters” (Viking) by the diplomat and historian Elizabeth Brown Pryor. Each author is to receive a $20,000 cash award and a bronze cast of an Augustus Saint-Gaudens sculpture of Lincoln.

headline: The Auction of Getty Images Appears to Be Stalled
text: The auction of Getty Images, the distributor of pictures and video, appears to be in jeopardy, people briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

headline: Inspired by America, Then Brought Onto the Stage
text: The New York City Ballet’s “American Songs and Dances” is an odd collection of dances. The program, seen on Saturday night at the New York State Theater, should have been much more fun and thought-provoking.

headline: Many Obstacles to Digital TV Reception, Study Says
text: Nearly six million people with digital receivers may still lose TV signals when digital-only broadcasts begin next February, a new study says.

headline: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
text: PARIS  The police investigating the trading scandal at Société Générale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed.

headline: Ivy Leaguer Is Intense Enough for Two Sports
text: The Columbia senior John Baumann was already known as Hard Hat and Mr. Saturday Night before Navy Coach Billy Lange added another name to the list. Lange was watching a tape of the Lions’ basketball team, admiring Baumann’s intensity, and could not resist calling Columbia Coach Joe Jones multiple times. With each call, Lange grew more excited.

headline: This Year’s Awards: Yesterday, Once More
text: The Grammy Awards hit 50, and looked older, on Sunday’s broadcast. Always distrustful of the noisy youth music that has sustained the business, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences went out of its way to let the air out of this year’s show.

headline: Putting Candidates Under the Videoscope
text: One late night last November, Mitt Romney, campaigning in Greenville, S.C., was approached by three young women in bright matching outfits looking for a hug. Mr. Romney, thinking they were cheerleaders from nearby Clemson University, obliged.

headline: After the Writers’ Strike
text: LOS ANGELES  It is not quite peace that has broken out here in Hollywood. But emotions are finally settling down in the entertainment industry’s bubbling cauldron of labor disputes. This calm holds the promise of three years without strike threats, picket lines and the loss of Americans’ favorite television shows.

headline: Scientists Find New Receptor for H.I.V.
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Government scientists have discovered a new way that H.I.V. attacks human cells, an advance that could provide fresh avenues for the development of additional therapies to stop AIDS, they reported on Sunday.

headline: Yahoo Bidder Wants a More Aggressive Microsoft
text: When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsoft’s $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsoft’s sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.

headline: Hate Springs Eternal
text: In 1956 Adlai Stevenson, running against Dwight Eisenhower, tried to make the political style of his opponent’s vice president, a man by the name of Richard Nixon, an issue. The nation, he warned, was in danger of becoming “a land of slander and scare; the land of sly innuendo, the poison pen, the anonymous phone call and hustling, pushing, shoving; the land of smash and grab and anything to win. This is Nixonland.”

headline: Amy Winehouse Wins Big at Grammy Awards
text: LOS ANGELES  Amy Winehouse, the troubled British soul singer with the darkly self-referential hit “Rehab,” failed to attend Sunday’s 50th annual Grammy Awards in person, but she proved a dominating figure nonetheless, picking up five trophies as voters kept her in a tight competition with the rap star Kanye West.

headline: Obama’s Path to Victory
text: Last summer, George W. Bush told The Washington Examiner’s Bill Sammon that Hillary Clinton would probably be the 2008 Democratic nominee. “She’s got a national presence and this is becoming a national primary,” he said. “And therefore the person with the national presence who has got the ability to raise enough money to sustain an effort in a multiplicity of sites has got a good chance to be nominated.”

headline: Hillary Clinton as the Fashion Police: My Polka-Dot Dress Should Be Arrested
text: In almost two decades on and off the campaign trail, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has weathered criticisms of her hair, her clothes and even a hint of cleavage. Last week, she decided to join the ranks of her own fashion police.

headline: Soccer as an Escape to Hope for Afghan Teenager
text: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J.  In world religion class, Shamila Kohestani is neither the adolescent who defied the Taliban in Afghanistan nor the symbol of liberation that shared the stage with stars from Hollywood and sports at the 2006 ESPY Awards. She is a teenager whose lips move as she takes notes, and whose list of words to look up grows exponentially each minute, each hour and each day.

headline: Isle-Hopping and Other Musical Jaunts
text: Foreign instruments, timbres and rhythms have long provided inspiration for classical musicians. The Silk Road Ensemble and composers including Osvaldo Golijov regularly demonstrate the fascinating results of adventurous border hopping. Other multicultural musical experiments serve as a reminder that cross-cultural relationships can be tense.

headline: A Parallel Musical Universe, Forged in South America
text: When the historical progression from Haydn to Mahler began to run out of options at the end of the 19th century, composers could either follow new trains of thought issuing from old ideas, or else declare bankruptcy and start all over again. For better or worse Schoenberg, Elliott Carter and the like have led classical music along a rational path into a smaller, perhaps finer world. A separation of the classes has been ensured: a knowing listening elite kept at a distance from an all-inclusive, less discriminating populace at large.

headline: New Shuttle Team Ready for Walk After Day’s Delay
text: WASHINGTON  Astronauts aboard the International Space Station spent Sunday moving supplies from the shuttle Atlantis and preparing for a spacewalk delayed by the illness of a German astronaut.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about the results of the Democratic primaries in New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to Richard J. Codey, the president of the New Jersey Senate and a supporter of Senator Barack Obama. He is not chairman of Mr. Obama’s campaign in New Jersey. (That post is shared by two mayors, Cory Booker of Newark and Jerramiah T. Healy of Jersey City.) Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the position held by Lowell P. Weicker, the Connecticut Republican, in 1992, the year that Connecticut voters chose Jerry Brown, the long-shot candidate from California, in the Democratic primary. At the time, Mr. Weicker was governor of Connecticut, not its senator.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A caption on Thursday with a photograph of a home in Israel hit by a Palestinian rocket described the events surrounding the attack imprecisely. While the rocket attack followed an Israeli airstrike in southern Gaza, it was not known whether it was in fact in retaliation for the airstrike.

headline: Attacks Pushing Darfur Refugees Into Chad
text: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of refugees fleeing attacks by Arab militias and Sudanese Army bombs in the ravaged western region of Darfur have flooded into neighboring Chad, the United Nations said Sunday, and many more may be on their way as Sudan strikes back at a rebel offensive in the area.

headline: Corzine Drops Route 440 From Toll Plan
text: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J.  Gov. Jon S. Corzine said Sunday that he would drop his proposal to turn a portion of Route 440 in Middlesex County into a toll road as part of his multibillion dollar package to restructure the state’s wobbly finances.

headline: 2 Celebrity Magazines Buck Circulation Trend
text: Sales of US Weekly and a new competitor, OK! Weekly, climbed sharply in the second half of 2007, even as a round of price increases contributed to an unusual drop in overall sales of celebrity magazines, according to a report released Monday.

headline: Coveted Quarterback Looks to Thrive on Next Level
text: SANTA ANA, Calif.  Autographed photographs of Matt Leinart and Colt Brennan hang on the wall in Bruce Rollinson’s office at Mater Dei High School.

headline: In Oil-Rich Mideast, Shades of the Ivy League
text: DOHA, Qatar  On a hot October evening, hundreds of families flocked to the sumptuous Ritz Carlton here in this Persian Gulf capital for an unusual college fair, the Education City roadshow.

headline: U.S. Seeking Execution for 6 in Sept. 11 Case
text: Military prosecutors have decided to seek the death penalty for six Guantánamo detainees who are to be charged with central roles in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, government officials who have been briefed on the charges said Sunday.

headline: Speechless Actors Roam London Stage
text: In a play new to the National Theater in London, 27 actors perform for 90 minutes without uttering a word. The attraction is “The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other,” a 1992 work by the Austrian playwright Peter Handke. The script has 60 pages of stage directions and no dialogue, although there are bangs, crashes, screams and laughter, The Independent of London reported. Mr. Handke said that the idea came to him in the 1980s when he found dramatic meaning in the comings and goings in a town square near Trieste, Italy. “Is there much to discover in it?” he said of his play. “I don’t know.”

headline: A Caribbean Corner of Brooklyn, Fighting to Survive
text: Inside the red brick shoe box that is the Moore Street Retail Market lies a tiny patch of Latin America. The stalls of this Brooklyn public market on the edge of Williamsburg explode with Caribbean colors and sounds, as local shoppers buy everything from yams and peppers to maracas and mystic potions.

headline: New CDs
text: LAURA MARLING “Alas, I Cannot Swim” (Virgin UK)

headline: Discovering Second Acts in Sustained Working Lives
text: Marc Freedman has become the voice of aging baby boomers who are eschewing retirement for what he calls “encore careers,” long periods of meaningful and sustaining work later in life. Mr. Freedman, who was one of the founders of Experience Corps, now runs Civic Ventures, an incubator of programs and ideas to redefine the second half of life. One of those programs, the Purpose Prize, gives monetary awards to entrepreneurial innovators over the age of 60 who have contributed to the social good.

headline: For an Era of Twins, the End May Be Near
text: Walk around the Upper West Side with a double stroller, as I do from time to time, and it’s amazing how long it can take to make it to Fairway. An older gentleman wants to know whether there were twins in the family. A middle-aged woman needs to stop and list every pair of twins she’s come to know in a five-block radius. There are many, many, many young twins in that five-block radius. The listing of them takes a long time. There are twins on 72nd Street and two sets in her building alone and girl twins on the corner and boy twins she always sees at the Starbucks ... Is it something in the water?

headline: Campaign Focus Shifts to Chesapeake Bay Region
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and John McCain were decidedly upbeat in separate appearances on Monday, as both parties prepared for Tuesday’s primary contests in the Chesapeake Bay region.

headline: Winter Storms Squeeze Supplies of Road Salt
text: Local governments in New England and in the Midwest are running critically low on road salt, the result of a stream of winter weather that has hit the regions in recent months.

headline: U.S. Charges 6 With Key Roles in 9/11 Attacks
text: WASHINGTON  Six Guantánamo detainees who are accused of central roles in the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, will be shown all the evidence against them and will be afforded the same rights as American soldiers accused of crimes, the Pentagon said Monday as it announced the charges against them.

headline: As Latest Skid Ends, Knicks Find Hope
text: As their latest serial nightmare faded late Saturday night, the Knicks stood, bounced and cheered. The bench, so often filled with sleepy stares and bowed heads, was empty.

headline: Spitzer Quickly Reduces Revenue Projections, Citing the Gloomy Economy
text: Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nation’s economy.

headline: A Return to Thrift
text: To the Editor:

headline: White House Remains Optimistic on Economy
text: WASHINGTON  The White House predicted on Monday that the economy would escape a recession and that unemployment would remain low this year, though it acknowledged that growth had already slowed sharply.

headline: Bruno’s Activities Give Pause to Ethics School
text: ALBANY  The federal investigation of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, is weighing on a Connecticut school dedicated to teaching ethics.

headline: The Bush Budget
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Super Bowl Spotlight Shines on a Changed Man
text: WAYNE, N.J.  The walls of the jail cell were built from stone, providing the perfect place for David Tyree to hit rock bottom. Arrested for drug possession after the police found half a pound of marijuana in his car, caged between stone walls and steel bars, Tyree covered his face with his hands.

headline: ‘Fools Gold’ Earns Real Money
text: “Fool’s Gold” (Warner Brothers), the action-romance-comedy starring Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey, right, captured the No. 1 weekend ranking at North American box offices by grossing an estimated $22 million in its debut, the tracking company Media by Numbers reported. Another new film, “Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins” (Universal), a comedy starring Martin Lawrence as a talk-show host visiting his relatives down South, took second place by drawing $17.1 million. Last week’s No. 1 film, “Hannah Montana/Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert Tour” (Disney) dropped to third place with a take of $10.5 million while averaging $15,295 per screen, more than twice as much as “Fool’s Gold.” Last week’s second-place film, “The Eye” (Lionsgate and Paramount Vantage), slid to fourth, pulling in $6.6 million. Continuing to climb, “Juno” (Fox Searchlight) moved up a notch, taking fifth place with $5.7 million for a total of $117.6 million in 10 weeks. The Paris Hilton vehicle “The Hottie & the Nottie” (Regent Releasing) amassed $25,500 in tickets sales at 111 locations. The site calculated that based on an $8 average ticket price, 29 paying customers showed up at each location over the three weekend days.

headline: You Can’t Keep That Carrot in Your Ear, Mr. Stubborn
text: Roger Hargreaves is the one of the best-selling authors in Britain. The son of a Yorkshire laundryman, Mr. Hargreaves aspired to be a cartoonist but did not find his way there until 1971, when his young son, Adam, asked him what a “tickle” looked like. Mr. Hargreaves responded by drawing an orange blob with friendly features and extremely long arms. Mr. Tickle, the hero of a colorful book for preschoolers and early readers, was born.

headline: 2008 Grammy Awards
text: Photos of winners and presenters at this year's awards.

headline: A Diaspora Through Dance
text: The choreographer Ronald K. Brown and his dance troupe examine the African Diaspora through movement.

headline: ‘They Were All in San Diego’
text: More of your “late night comedy (send via the comment link below):

text: “I Walk the Line” in German:

headline: It Takes a Pantsuit
text: US Weekly has Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s own picks of her all-time worst outfits, Monday’s Times reports:

headline: Moderator and a Panelist Ousted at ‘Fox News Watch’
text: “Fox News Watch,” one of two weekly television shows that assess the conduct of the national news media, has fired its longtime moderator and let go one of its more liberal panelists.

headline: Resolution Makes Actors’ Strike Less Likely
text: “It is not quite peace that has broken out here in Hollywood. But emotions are finally settling down in the entertainment industry’s bubbling cauldron of labor disputes,” Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes report.

headline: Yahoo Said to Be Restarting Talks With AOL
text: Yahoo is seeking to restart merger talks with AOL as a means of defending itself against Microsoft‘s unsolicited $44.6 billion bid, according to the Times of London.

headline: U.S. Wonders if Stock Deal Is Tax Abuse
text: A strategy that corporate executives routinely use to turn their stockholdings into cash while delaying payment of taxes is coming under increased scrutiny by the Internal Revenue Service.

headline: Credit Suisse Expected to Dodge Subprime Woes
text: The Credit Suisse Group is earning more than UBS for the first time in almost a decade after it avoided the write-downs that forced UBS to report the biggest-ever quarterly loss by a bank, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: Harbinger Injects $100 Million into TerreStar
text: A hedge fund, Harbinger Capital Partners, is teaming up with EchoStar and other investors to inject $300 million into TerreStar to help develop a land and satellite mobile broadband communications network.

headline: Tamping Down SocGen Chatter, HSBC Is Expected to Sell 400 Banks
text: HSBC, the biggest bank in Europe, plans to put about half of its 800 French consumer branches up for sale as it focuses on expanding in Asia and other emerging markets, according to press reports.

headline: V.C.’s Cut $12 Million Check fo Cellfire
text: A mobile phone coupon company Cellfire has raised $12 million in a third round of funding. The round includes a new investor, Silver Creek Ventures, and existing ones, including Menlo Ventures and Storm Ventures.

headline: V.C.s Shower Suniva With Cash
text: A solar cell maker, Suniva, has raised $50 million in its second round of funding to be used for a new manufacturing facility near Atlanta. The financing was led by New Enterprise Associates and Advanced Equities.

headline: Hedge Funds Reverse Position
text: If hedge funds are, as is often claimed, the investment vanguard, their latest moves appear to be telling financial markets it is time to take a break from the trading patterns that have dominated since mid-2007.

headline: Sale of Retailer Hits Legal Snag
text: The co-founder of Active Endeavors, an upscale clothing retailer, and two other investors who are owed $936,200 apparently have blocked, at least temporarily, the sale of the company.

headline: As Yahoo Balks, Microsoft Plots Next Move
text: When Yahoo sends its letter rejecting Microsoft‘s $44.6 billion on Monday, it will end up in the inbox of a largely unknown executive on Microsoft’s sprawling campus, Christopher P. Liddell.

headline: Overseas Funds Resist Calls for a Code of Conduct
text: Last year, as governments in Asia and the Middle East started to buy stakes in financial institutions in the West, the Bush administration called for an international code of conduct by sovereign wealth funds. The purpose was to get the funds to disclose more of their activities and not play politics with their investments.

headline: At Macquarie, a Dealmaker Takes the Helm
text: Smart, tough and above all a dealmaker, the Macquarie Group‘s new chief executive, Nicholas Moore, draws plaudits befitting the head of a global investment bank.

headline: Upstart Exchange Said to Eye Archipelago Founder for Top Post
text: Building up its arsenal before facing off against the CME Group, an upstart and still unnamed electronic futures exchange backed by a dozen financial players is considering Archipelago founder Jerry Putnam for its chief executive, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Should the Giants Trade Shockey?
text: Ernie Accorsi and then Jerry Reese made enough wise decisions to give the Giants a chance to win the Super Bowl. Now Reese must continue to make sound choices for an opportunity to repeat. One of those decisions has a name: Jeremy Shockey.

headline: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout
text: WestLB, a state-owned German bank, said Friday that it would reduce its work force by 25 percent and receive 5 billion euros ($7.2 billion) from its owners to cover losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market.

headline: Nucor Goes to Scrap Heap for $1.4 Billion Deal
text: A steel producer, the Nucor Corporation, is buying one of the biggest scrap metal companies in the United States for $1.44 billion.

headline: Milberg Case Alters Class Action Landscape
text: As the famed class-action lawyer William S. Lerach steps before a federal judge in Los Angeles on Monday to learn his sentence in a wide-ranging fraud and conspiracy probe, his misdeeds and those of his former colleagues might be helping to alter the way securities law is practiced, according to The Los Angeles Times.

headline: IAC Streamlines M&A Division
text: As the courts sort out a struggle for control of IAC/InterActiveCorp and its planned five-piece breakup, the company has reshuffled its in-house dealmakers.

headline: Dogged by the Media
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: Getty Images Auction Appears to Be Stalled
text: The auction of Getty Images, the distributor of pictures and video, appears to be in jeopardy, The New York Times reported Monday.

headline: TheStreet Sets Up Shop on MainStreet.com
text: After getting a $55 million injection from Technology Crossover Ventures last November, TheStreet.com is using some of that cash to roll out mainstreet.com today in a bid to expand beyond its pure-play financial focus and add celebrity news with a personal finance angle.

headline: Air Canada Attracts Buyout Interest
text: Air Canada’s depressed share price might put it in play for privatization or partnership with a carrier in the United States, the airline’s parent company, ACE Aviation Holdings, said Friday.

headline: SocGen Launches Rights Issue At Deep Discount
text: Société Générale, the French bank reeling from a rogue trading scandal, started a rights issue at a steep discount on Monday, intending to raise 5.5 billion euros ($7.97 billion) to bolster its balance sheet.

headline: Theory Gains That Trader Had a Helper
text: The police investigating the trading scandal at Société Générale were moving on Sunday toward a theory that its rogue trader, whom the bank blames for losing it nearly $7.2 billion, might not have acted alone, as he and the bank have claimed, The New York Times reported.

headline: “Atonement” Gets a Turn in Jolly Old England
text: At last night’s Orange British Academy Film Awards, otherwise known as the BAFTA’s, “Atonement” won best picture, the Coens won best director(s), Javier Bardem and Daniel Day-Lewis assumed their usual positions. But there were a few curves in the women’s category, with best lead going to Marion Cotillard for inhabiting the character of Edith Piaf in “La Vie en Rose” and best supporting going to British actress Tilda Swinton for her riveting portrayal of an American businesswoman with a taste for lethal solutions in “Michael Clayton.” Diablo Cody picked up another chit for conceiving “Juno,” while the adapted category went to Ronald Harwood for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.”

headline: The Men Behind Clark Kent: A Tribute to Jewish Cartoonists
text: By Robert P. Walzer

headline: Can These Girls Talk, or What?
text: The Bagger is not a huge podcast fan — they’re not searchable, for one thing, and it’s pretty obvious, listening to them, why most of the writers being recorded type for a living. But he made an exception for the gab session between Tom O’Neil, he of the Gold Derby, and Sasha Stone, empress of Awards Daily. Among other juicy bits, they fire back at some of the mainstream journalists who are in such a snit about the rise of the blogocrats. And they do a fine job of explaining how “No Country,” a film with lots of rough edges, ended up leading the Oscar pack.

headline: Still More Questions in Tobias’s Death
text: The life and mysterious death of Seth Tobias, the hedge fund manager found floating lifelessly in his pool last September, has fascinated the press for months. How could it not? The rogues gallery includes Mr. Tobias’s wife; a former assistant to Mr. Tobias (and reputed former pimp) named Bill Ash; a male go-go dancer named Tiger; and a mysterious Internet psychic who goes by the name Mama.

headline: Almost Famous
text: Lynn Hirschberg of the New York Times magazine muses on where fame comes from and anoints a new crop of the soon-to-be- famous in a remarkable portfolio of photos. The nascent pantheon includes a few folks who have been seen around Oscar-town this season.

headline: Grammy Awards Red Carpet
text: A look at the fashions at the 2008 Grammy Awards.

headline: Goldman Said to Buy 20% Stake in Capula Fund
text: A private equity fund run by Goldman Sachs has acquired about 20 percent of Capula Investment Management, a $3 billion hedge fund, The Financial Times reported citing unnamed sources. The stake could be worth as much as $100 million but carries no voting rights, the newspaper said.

headline: Terrorist Surveillance Bill at Issue in Congress
text: The continuing clash between Democrats and Republicans over national security will play out in Congress this week through a terrorist surveillance bill.

headline: CCMP Hires Advisers for Consumer, Healthcare Investments
text: CCMP Capital Advisors said that it had hired two executive advisers to help the private equity firm find investments in the consumer and healthcare sectors.

headline: The Early Word: Chasing Votes Near the Chesapeake
text: After another busy weekend on the campaign trail, both parties’ candidates will be canvassing the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia today ahead of Tuesday’s primary there.

headline: Will Write for Food
text: On Saturday night, the Bagger came in for the Writers Guild Awards at the Hudson Theater in Manhattan. He showed partly because there was news of a possible strike settlement, and partly because he has a soft spot for the event, which has little of the sizzle and none of the gloss of the other awards dealibops.

headline: What About the Bucket List?
text: Anne Thompson offers a clear view of the collective Id of the Oscars.

headline: Just remember, the financial problems are contained
text: To Planet Earth, that is — though I wouldn’t be surprised if all this eventually affects the International Space Station, too.

headline: State Revenue Projections Worsen
text: Only three weeks after presenting its budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration is lowering projections for tax revenue by $384 million, because of increasingly ominous reports of distress on Wall Street and in the nation’s economy, Danny Hakim reports. To keep the budget in balance, the governor is proposing several new spending cuts, including further paring back increases in Medicaid reimbursements and dipping into the state’s environmental protection fund. While the changes represent a fraction of New York’s $124 billion budget, they are a sign of how rapidly shifting economic forecasts are causing havoc with the state’s fiscal planning. It is rare for a governor to second-guess his own budget, especially so soon after releasing it.

headline: A Victory That Actually Means Something
text: The Bagger has a small admission to make. While the writer’s strike has been storming along, it’s been a little difficult to get excited about the micro and macro aspects of the Oscars. As long as people were out of work and both the outcome and the future were in doubt, the correct answer to the question of whether another film could sneak through for best picture if “No Country” and “There Will Be Blood” split the voters, was, “Who cares?”

headline: On race cards and all that
text: I’m starting to get emails from angry people who tell me that I’m ignoring all the terrible race-baiting the Clintons have done. I think I’ll just outsource my response to Clive Crook — who is, by the way, an Obama supporter.

headline: Microsoft’s Other Takeover Deal: Danger Inc.
text: Not everyone is so reluctant to be bought by Microsoft these days.

headline: Clinton Stops in D.C.
text: WASHINGTON – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has not spent much time courting voters in the District of Columbia, where Senator Barack Obama is heavily favored in the upcoming Democratic primary on Tuesday.

headline: Maybe He’s Cool and Smart
text: Matthew Yglesias doesn’t understand where the oft-heard notion that Barack Obama’s presidential campaign is vague on matters of policy comes from. Yglesias writes at his blog for The Atlantic:

headline: Egypt Ready to Take on the World
text: ACCRA, Ghana – Now the pressure is really on. Egypt defeated Cameroon, 1-0, in the final of the Africa Cup of Nations Sunday, the Pharaohs’ sixth cup victory. They are now the undisputed heavyweights of African soccer. Un-dis-puted.

headline: Answers From Charles E. Thorpe
text: Charles E. Thorpe, the dean of Carnegie Mellon in Qatar, answered questions on overseas branch campuses of American universities.

headline: Watching ‘NBC Nightly News’ In Orbit
text: Why did the “NBC Nightly News” anchor Brian Williams offer a “special hello to the International Space Station” on Friday’s evening newscast?

headline: Moscow’s Unusual Prize Distribution
text: The 2008 Moscow Open imbued the Swiss system with a unique Russian flavor.

headline: Yahoo Shareholders Believe Company Is Bluffing Microsoft
text: So far, investors are showing modest support for Yahoo’s board of directors, which formally rejected Microsoft’s $31-per-share buyout offer this morning.

headline: Science Debate Is Set; Now, Will Candidates Come?
text: The organizers of a proposed science and technology debate among the presidential candidates have set a date, April 18, and place, the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia. This would be four days before the Pennsylvania primary.

headline: Talk to the Newsroom: Sports Editor Tom Jolly
text: Tom Jolly, sports editor at The Times, is answering reader questions Feb. 11-15, 2008. (He previously answered questions in August 2006.) Questions may be sent to askthetimes@nytimes.com. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

headline: Shows Prepare To Resume Production
text: “The switch that controls the television business is expected to be flicked on all the way early this week, initiating a flurry of activity that may begin to restore the regularly scheduled programming interrupted when the writers’ strike shut down major parts of the television season,” Bill Carter reports.

headline: Bloomberg Urges U.N. to Act on Climate Change
text: Updated, 12:37 p.m. | Addressing the United Nations General Assembly this morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reiterated his call for a carbon tax in the United States, suggested that congestion pricing could be a model for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in other world cities and announced a plan to reduce the city’s use of tropical hardwoods, calling tropical deforestation an “ecological calamity.” And of course, he managed to throw in a boast about the city’s 311 line.

headline: Speaking Out: Show-Runners Talk About the Guild Deal
text: As the tentative writers’ deal is reviewed and the ratification vote is held, the opinions of the show-runners ­ people who work as both writers and producers, bearing both creative and professional control over shows ­ will be critically important. They serve as informal ring-leaders of the television community.

headline: D.E. Shaw’s (Very) Good Timing
text: When Alliance Data Systems announced Friday that it was dropping its lawsuit against the Blackstone Group, many shareholders surely leaped for joy as the company’s stock jumped 6.9 percent. But perhaps chief among the beneficiaries of the news was D.E. Shaw, which made an extremely timely investment, PE Hub’s Dan Primack points out.

headline: Has Oil Peaked?
text: The people who run the Dow Jones industrial average are messing with it again, and in that, there could be a warning that oil prices have peaked.

headline: For the Red Wings, Disturbing Signs of Imperfection
text: On Sunday Detroit lost at home to the defending Cup champion Anaheim Ducks, 3-2. It was a close game, and Nicklas Lidstrom’s apparent tying goal with less than a minute to go was waved off by referee Dan O’Halloran for goalie interference, as you can see here …

headline: Recipe of the Day: Pasta With Garlic, Anchovies and Tomatoes
text: For this recipe, steer clear of anchovies that come in two-ounce tins, usually packed in “vegetable” or other non-olive oil. The right ones are packed in jars, in olive oil from Spain or Italy, or packed in salt. The ones packed in salt require rinsing, de-boning and, preferably, a bit of marinating in olive oil before use. They’re really good but obviously far more work.

headline: In Britain, Attacks on a Surprising Group: Firefighters
text: British firefighters spent Saturday extinguishing a huge blaze in Camden Market, a trendy district in London, but they evidently spend most days under siege, according to a report from their union:

headline: Trading Retirement for Something Else
text: The “encore career” is the brainchild of social entrepreneur, Mr. Freedman, whom I interviewed for today’s Shifting Careers column. Through his nonprofit organization, Civic Ventures, and the book, Encore, Mr. Freedman has been working furiously to create a blueprint and tools for a generation of aging baby boomers who want to spend their later years productively.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: Racing season is back and so is Monday Morning Motorsports.

headline: Spike and Biscuit, Spot 1
text: A campaign for the Charleston Animal Shelter in Charleston, S.C., capitalizes on the intense interest in politics this year.

headline: McCain Plays Nice With Huckabee
text: ANNAPOLIS, Md. – Senator John McCain continued his campaign of congeniality with former Gov. Mike Huckabee today when he said that it was fine with him if Mr. Huckabee challenged the results of Saturday’s Washington State caucuses. Party officials have declared Mr. McCain the winner by several hundred votes, but the Huckabee campaign says that 1,500 votes went uncounted.

headline: New York Fashion Week | Tony Melillo
text: (Jimi Celeste)

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: New York: Random Thoughts
text: A deep winter freeze has settled on my part of the world. Last night, as the roast chicken and scalloped potatoes were coming out of the oven, the power went off. The lanterns were brought out and dinner resumed for the hour or so it took the electric company to patch things back together. The New York shows were that fast-receding train; suddenly, on Saturday morning, they were no more.

headline: Yahoo and the Art of the Rejection
text: Microsoft has already shown its skill in crafting a “bear hug” letter. Now Yahoo has tried its hand at the bid-rejection letter, and the result is remarkably, well, nice — especially when compared with the much harsher rejections that some other companies have issued in recent years.

headline:
The Answer Man:
You Can Take It With You
text: A reader writes: When I (infrequently, because of budget) eat out locally, it often happens that there is food left over and I ask (I don’t ask, I tell the waiter), “I’d like to take this home.” Does that happen at, say, Le Cirque? Do you always eat everything served or is it permitted in NY restaurants (of whatever quality) to walk out with a Styrofoam box of leftovers?

headline: New York Fashion Week | Marc Jacobs
text: (Evan Sung for The New York Times)New York Fashion Week is over, but The Fashion Telex continues as the editors of T: The New York Times Style Magazine file dispatches from last week’s shows.

headline: The Skinny on ‘Skinny Bitch’
text: The diet book called “Skinny Bitch” has been flying off bookstore shelves, buoyed by the modeling pedigree of its authors and a frank “stop eating crap” message that distinguishes it from traditional diet books.

headline: David Tyree, a Hard Worker
text: David Tyree's college highlight tape is filled with textbook blocks, busted wedges and smothering punt coverage.

headline: Borrow and Spend
text: Yesterday’s Times included an op-ed piece by W. Michael Cox and Richard Alm of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, arguing “You Are What You Spend.” They compare 1975 statistics to 2006 figures and conclude the bottom 20 percent of Americans in terms of income are doing better than you might expect in terms of consumption.

headline: Girl Power!
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

text: To: The Yahoo Board of Directors

headline: More Good News: ‘Krod Mandoon’ Will Start Shooting Soon
text: MRC, one of the studios that reached an interim agreement with the Writers Guild of America before the broader strike was settled, has just announced its first slate of television projects with broadcast and cable companies.

headline: Reason No. 4,782 Why It’s Good to Be David Wright
text: On the drive down to Port St. Lucie, Fla., from his home in southeastern Virginia, David Wright stopped to play 18 holes at the famed TPC at Sawgrass course in Ponte Vedra Beach, outside Jacksonville. The golf nuts among us will know it as the home to the Players’ Championship, but even the casual followers have probably seen its most recognizable hole, the par-3, 132-yard 17th that is known as the Island Green. Getting a chance to play that hole was, Wright said, his whole reason for stopping.

headline: Aftermath of the Strike: What to Expect on Cable
text: Cable networks have not felt the pinch of the writers’ strike to the extent the broadcast networks have. After all, they rely more extensively on repeats, reality shows and movies. Also, many of their series premiere during the summer months, against the grain of the September-to-May broadcast season.

headline: London Fashion Week | Topshop, Biba, Emilio de la Morena, Poltock & Walsh
text: Fall clothes at the Topshop show. (AP)

headline: London Fashion Week | Topshop, Biba, Emilio de la Morena, Poltock & Walsh
text: Fall clothes at the Topshop show. (AP)

headline: Flying New York-Hong Kong with kids?
text: Carey from New York asks about travel to Hong Kong with a 4- and 7-year-old. Are some airlines better than others in terms of space and services for children?

headline: The New Stimulus Package: A Big Disappointment
text: “Better than nothing” is the best thing that can be said about the economic stimulus bill passed by Congress last week and soon to be signed by President Bush. Yet congressional leaders are full of self-congratulation over the bill, because they passed it swiftly with bipartisan support.

headline: How Bad Is It? AIG Can’t Tell
text: If someone wants to buy insurance against a risk, perhaps the insurance company should assume the risk is real.

headline: Day One in Port St. Lucie
text: It’s been a full 10 months since I last set foot here, and it’s calming to see that not much has changed — a few more stoplights on Peacock Boulevard, a new shopping center (PETCO! Panera!) under construction. I’m a creature of habit, and as long as the weather is good, the iced tea at Camille’s is cold and the storylines are intriguing, I’m a happy camper. Spring training is all about routines, and I’m sure those players working out on the minor-league side this morning would certainly agree with that.

headline: Hedge Fund Group Raises Stake in Times Co.
text: The coalition of hedge funds that wants to place directors on The New York Times Company‘s board has more than doubled its stake in the company, to at least 10 percent of the regular shares, according to federal records filed Monday.

headline: Can You Sell Chinese Dumplings in Japan?
text: The race for the White House isn’t the only news story that is enriched (or perhaps not-so-enriched) by polls. Over the weekend, a poll conducted in Japan showed how seriously consumers are taking a recent food scare.

headline: Eat Your Brownies, er, Veggies
text: I sincerely hope that the moronic idea of hiding food that kids don’t like in foods they do — see “The Sneaky Chef” and “Deceptively Delicious” — is a passing phase. (The funniest thing about these two books is that the public uproar wasn’t over their approach to cooking but over which author had the idea first.) This does a real disservice to kids and — not that this is my bailiwick — is evidence that today’s parents will do anything to avoid a confrontation.

headline: Strike Fallout: A Complete Guide to How Your Favorite Shows Are Affected
text: Updated throughout on Tuesday afternoon.

headline: The Animated Life: Tulips
text: Variations on the kiss, animated in honor of Valentine's Day.

headline: Subprime Crisis Festers in New York
text: New York City’s 18,000 foreclosure filings last year accounted for more than half of state foreclosure filings in 2007. Now one out of every 40 homes with a mortgage in New York City had a filing as of the end of September 2007, more than twice the rate for the rest of New York State.

headline: Cheaper Wi-Fi Access at Starbucks and Beyond
text: The idea of city-sponsored Wi-Fi seems to be floundering. And the fancy wireless service that may come of the government spectrum auction will be many years away. But that doesn’t mean that there’s nothing new for road warriors who want a connection.

headline: Most Breast Cancer Sites Get It Right
text: The Internet is filled with unreliable health information and bogus claims. But sites dedicated to breast cancer information appear to have a high level of accuracy, a new study shows.

headline: Ask not to whom the Tolls sell
text: They sell to each other — unless they walk away from the contract.

headline: The Hillary Index
text: Ever since a sharp-eyed co-worker spotted an index entry years ago (in a book by McGeorge Bundy) that said, “Khrushchev, Nikita S. … salami-slicing technique of,” I’ve studied indexes closely, looking for anything that might brighten a dreary workday.

headline: Obama-Edwards Meeting Is Scratched, for Now
text: Updated Senator Barack Obama’s campaign has confirmed that he has canceled a meeting scheduled for today with former Senator John Edwards in North Carolina. The two have been talking on the phone and will meet soon, people close to both men say, but for now the media attention has become too intense and is out of control, with stake-outs at Mr. Edwards’s home.

headline: Lerach Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
text: William Lerach, a former partner at a prestigious New York law firm, was sentenced Monday to two years in federal prison for his role in a lucrative kickback scheme involving class-action lawsuits against some of the nation’s biggest corporations.

headline: Sunday Ratings: ‘Makeover’ Draws 16 Million
text: The Grammy Awards helped CBS finish No. 1 for the night over all, leading the 7 p.m. hour prior to the Grammy’s with “60 Minutes” (13 million viewers). ABC ranked second for the night thanks to a two-hour “Extreme Makeover: Home Edition” at 8 p.m. (15.8 million) followed by “Brothers & Sisters” at 10 p.m. (8.6 million).

headline: Viewership Down For Grammy Awards
text: CBS’s broadcast of the “50th Annual Grammy Awards” was the highest-rated program on Sunday night, both among overall viewers and within the choice demographic of adults 18 to 49. But the good news for the program pretty much ends there.

headline: I. M. Pei’s Silver Towers Could Become a Landmark
text: Updated, 10:56 p.m. | The Landmarks Preservation Commission is expected on Tuesday to schedule a hearing on whether to designate Silver Towers/University Village, a concrete complex designed by I. M. Pei that was part of Robert Moses’s vast urban renewal program, as a historic landmark. Preservationists have urged such a move, arguing that New York University’s proposed campus expansion could some day threaten the towers, which sit at the edge of the university’s campus in Greenwich Village.

headline: For the Heart, a Risky Emotional Duo
text: Emotional and personality traits have long been associated with heart disease. Now researchers have shown that the combination of two traits — hostility and depression — may exact a particularly risky toll on the heart.

headline: The Curious Incident of the Kellwood Tender Offers
text: The Kellwood deal took a slight turn this weekend. On Friday, Sun Capital amended its tender offer to include a new condition “that, upon the closing of the tender offer, Sun Capital representatives on the Kellwood Board of Directors will constitute a majority of the directors and be proportionate in number to Sun Capital’s percentage shareholding in the Company.”

headline: Love, Istanbul style?
For Jeter, the Manager Will Be ‘Joe’ or ‘Girardi’
text: Derek Jeter’s rookie season in 1996 coincided with Joe Torre’s first year as the Yankees’ manager and ended with a World Series title. Jeter had a strong relationship for 12 seasons with the man he called Mr. Torre or Mr. T.

headline: Kaffee und Kuchen in Frankfurt
text: Yes, I know the image of sitting down to coffee and cakes in the afternoon, a German and Austrian tradition especially, has the feel of something your grandparents do. You totter over to the table in your Sunday best and linger for lack of anything better to do in retirement. But soft! Doesn’t a ritual built around good coffee and delicious pastries deserve more respect than that? As a matter of fact, it does.

headline: Romanée-Conti Comes to Town
text: I don’t go to very many industry tastings. These are large, invitation-only events where an importer or distributor generally will show its roster of wines, often with winemakers themselves pouring samples. You can taste dozens if not hundreds of wines at these events, if you spit and work efficiently. Mostly, they’re useful to retail and restaurant buyers who have to stock their stores and wine lists. They’re rarely useful to somebody like me, unless I can target specific wines that I want to taste for one reason or another, or find specific people whom I want to speak with. I don’t learn much about wines in that kind of context.

headline: The Senators Load Up
text: The Ottawa Senators and Carolina Hurricanes have broken the ice, swinging the first major deal of the trading season, with two weeks to go to the Feb. 26 trade deadline.

headline: ‘Yellow Rat’ and Workers Reach a Settlement
text: This is not the kind of buzz typically sought by Yellow Rat Bastard, the trendy SoHo clothing retailer: It has agreed to pay $1.4 million to settle a lawsuit over unpaid wages and overtime, according to the state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo. The apparel and shoe chain, which takes its name from Frank Miller’s “Sin City” crime comics and cultivates an edgy notoriety with its pierced staff and graffiti decor, is no stranger to controversy.

headline: Posada: Dodging Bats and Chasing Boston
text: Jorge Posada swung, his bat shattered and, for a millisecond, everyone around the batting cage gasped. After Posada’s bat broke, a large chunk of it ricocheted off the backstop netting, the same side of the backstop where Derek Jeter was standing, and hit Posada in the right leg.

headline: The Smallest of Price Hikes
text: Prices hikes don’t get much smaller than this: The United States Post Office has decided to raise the price of stamps from 41 cents to 42. The new price will take effect in May, a year after a two cent increase. Other post office services will cost slightly more as well, but not more than the rate of inflation over the past 12 months. More details at the official site. –MN

text: ABC announced pick-ups for nine series on Monday, including five returning hits and four new programs.

Is the race for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination already over?

headline: ‘Microsoft Reserves the Right to Pursue All Necessary Steps’

headline: Exploring the Manhattan Grit Chamber

headline: Soft Serve | Posh Skin, Petrus Police, Gucci’s No-No
text: Ding, ding — Soft Serve is served. … New York Fashion Week ends, London Fashion Week begins. Fashion editors should be careful when exercising their expense accounts. A very wealthy restaurant patron in London suspects he was served a fake bottle of 1961 Chateau Pétrus (cost: about $35,000). To crack the case, the restaurant has called the Bloodhound Gang of the wine world, the Pétrus Police. … Talk about rip offs, a van Gogh, Monet, Degas and Cézanne were reported stolen a private collection (cost: about $100 million) … Usually Gucci is getting knocked off, not the other way around. The heat is on the luxury brand for its new campaign, an unauthorized homage to Milton Glaser’s I heart NY… Also in legal hot water is Croc, the un-chic shoe manufacturer. The family of a girl whose Croc got chewed up by an escalator is suing for $7 million. Croc has acknowledged, “a long-existing issue that we think is very important — escalator safety.” … For less serious scrapes and cuts, look forward to Band-Aids 2.0, with build-in microchips … Speaking of painful, this week New York Magazine’s Best Bets goes rummaging for 40-year-old junk. … Count us in, maybe, for a round of retail therapy at Damien Hirst’s London “Art Shop.” We can’t afford the $100 million diamond skull, but a second mortgage might afford us a $50,000 painted cranium. … We guess Londoners like to blow their cash on tighty whities. After the hunky David Beckham billboards were erected, Emporio Armani saw a 150 percent sales increase. Must be the packaging … Closer to home, Posh got a similarly jubilant reception last night from the gay crowd at Hiro nightclub. One solitary dissenter, the porn actor and activist Michael Lucas, poo-pooed Posh on dermatological grounds, saying, “I think I would commit suicide if I had her skin… her skin is yellow with big pores.” Major meanie! … Soft Serve will spice up your life tomorrow, when we return.

headline: Bloomberg Denies Talking With Hagel About White House Bid
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg denied today that he had spoken with Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, about mounting an independent presidential run, as reported in an article in The Times on Saturday.

headline: Spitzer’s Budget Is Under Fire by Hospitals and Environmental Groups
text: Another day in Albany, another skirmish in the budget wars. Over the weekend, Gov. Eliot Spitzer began floating some changes to his proposed budget for the coming fiscal year, including a projected $384 million in state revenue because of the worsening economy climate.

headline: The Mexican President’s Whirlwind Visit
text: One very rushed president, 50 community leaders, dozens of concerns and fewer than 30 minutes of face time: that, in a nutshell, is what characterized the meeting this afternoon between President Felipe Calderón of Mexico and a group of Mexican activists from across the New York region, held behind closed doors at the New York Marriott Downtown Hotel in Lower Manhattan.

headline: Tennessee Goes Pink
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — It is a spectacular and moving sight inside Thompson-Boling Arena on the Tennessee campus. They may have found the one sport and the one color that can finally trump football and the Big Orange: basketball and pink.

headline: A Fight About What?
text: The close and impassioned battle for the Democratic nomination is about many things — an insider versus an outsider, the boomer generation versus the millennial generation, a choice between two different “firsts” — but oddly enough, there is one thing that it is NOT about: policy.

headline: Obama’s Success in the Caribbean
text: Senator Barack Obama had a victory over the weekend that didn’t get much attention: he took the Democratic presidential caucuses in the Virgin Islands, riding a wave of black support on Saturday to add three delegates to his tally.

headline: Parker Plays Through the Pain
text: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — With less than a minute left in warmups before the Tennessee-Rutgers game, the Volunteers’ Candace Parker was still wearing her long orange warmup pants. Parker, the reigning national player of the year, injured her left knee Feb. 7 in a victory over Mississippi State and was carried off the floor.

headline: Speaking of Face Plants
text: The Bagger wrote about the Writers Guild awards ceremony at the Hudson Theater last Saturday night and suggested that the “head writer” for “The Daily Show” had a rugged time during his tour at the mic. While the would-be funny guy in question does work for “The Daily Show,” he is not the head writer. That guy’s name is Steve Bodow and he was at home taking care of his newborn daughter. He was nowhere near the mic or the Hudson Theater. The Bagger and David Carr both apologize for the error.

headline: Bristol Cars: Exclusive Anonymity
text: LONDON — Toby Silverton, chairman of Bristol Cars, is terribly disappointed. Sitting with him in Bristol’s only showroom in the world, on Kensington High Street, I’ve explained that 50 percent of my friends and car-loving colleagues had no idea who or what Bristol was when I mentioned my plan to visit the company — horrible news for any other car manufacturer.

headline: Stock-Car Science Quiz

headline: Is Interest in Bulgaria Waning?
text: The Financial Times is reporting that British home buyers have “disappeared” from Bulgaria hot spots. The article provides details of a sharp reduction in the sales of “moderately priced” holiday properties and notes that developers have started to offer steep discounts.
