text: The Bush administration’s decision to put six detainees at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, on trial before military tribunals and to seek the death penalty is both a betrayal of American ideals and simply bad strategy. Instead of being what they could and should be  a model of justice dispensed impartially, surely and dispassionately  the trials will proceed under deeply flawed procedures that violate this country’s basic fairness. The intense negative attention they will receive will do enormous damage to what is left of America’s standing in world opinion.

headline: Big Deal for NBC
text: A 90-minute edition of “Deal or No Deal” lifted NBC to another No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the game show from 9:30 to 11 p.m., making it the night’s top-rated broadcast. NBC also fared well earlier in the night as “American Gladiators” won its 8 to 9:30 time slot among adults 18 to 49, while attracting a modest 8.8 million viewers. ABC’s “Dance War” delivered slightly more viewers during the time period (9.2 million), but it lagged far behind in the 18-to-49 set, falling to its lowest ratings to date in that demographic. ABC finished a distant fourth over all as both “Notes From the Underbelly” at 9:30 (4.3 million) and “October Road” at 10 (4 million) continued to struggle. Fox was second in the 18-t0-49 set with “Prison Break” at 8 (7.9 million total viewers) and “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 (8.3 million). CBS fared slightly better in total viewers with its comedy lineup, which included strong ratings for a “Two and a Half Men” repeat at 9 (11.9 million).

headline: Times Co. Nominates Two for Election as Directors
text: The New York Times Company, which is under pressure from a group of hedge funds that want to gain representation on its board, said Tuesday that it had nominated two candidates to fill director vacancies.

headline: Teachers’ Union President to Step Down; New Yorker Is Seen as Successor
text: Edward J. McElroy, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, announced Tuesday that he would step down in the summer, a move widely expected to put Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers’ union in New York City, in line to succeed him.

headline: An Uneven Year Over, a Met Seeks the Grind
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Joe Smith wants to set the record straight. Although he is not about to beg the team elders  Billy Wagner, for instance  to dress him up in women’s clothing (leather miniskirt?) or an outlandish costume (Scooby-Doo, anyone?), he would not necessarily mind, either.

headline: Recipe: Pomegranate-Rose Cream Meringues
text: Time: 2 hours, plus 2 hours’ cooling

headline: House Vote on Contempt Is Expected Soon
text: WASHINGTON  Democratic House leaders plan to force a vote as early as Thursday on holding Joshua B. Bolten, White House chief of staff, and Harriet E. Miers, former White House counsel, in contempt of Congress.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A report in The Caucus column on Thursday about record voter turnouts in the Feb. 5 nominating contests referred imprecisely to the turnouts in Utah and New York, and the Jan. 8 primaries in New Hampshire. In each case, the turnout figures represented the percentage of all eligible citizens who voted in each primary, not the percentage of registered Democratic or Republican voters who did so. Turnouts in the three states were: 28.5 percent in the New Hampshire Democratic primary and 23.3 percent in the state’s Republican primary; 7.8 percent in the Utah Democratic primary and 18 percent in its Republican primary; and 13.6 percent in the New York Democratic primary. (The turnout figure for New York’s Republican primary was 4.8 percent.) (Go to Article)

headline: In Second Trial, Avastin Is Found Effective in Treating Breast Cancer
text: Genentech said Tuesday that a new clinical trial had shown that its best-selling drug Avastin was effective in treating breast cancer, a finding that could increase the chances that the product will be approved for that use.

headline: Verdian Victims of the Plague of Doubt
text: The title role of Verdi’s “Otello” is probably the most intimidating challenge for tenors in the entire Italian repertory. It demands visceral dramatic intensity, great vocal stamina and abundant power. Yet an Otello must also be able to shape Verdi’s phrases with lyrical elegance. It’s always an event when a tenor takes on Otello for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Mexico: Axa Buys Ing Insurance Unit
text: Axa, Europe’s second-largest insurer, agreed to buy part of the ING Groep’s insurance business in Mexico for 1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), the Dutch-based financial services group said in a statement. ING, based in Amsterdam, said it was selling the business, Seguros ING, and its subsidiaries.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the future of the Gambino crime family, whose entire leadership was arrested in federal raids last week, misidentified the boss of the Luchese family who was indicted in 1985 after a secret recording device placed in his Jaguar picked up incriminating conversations. It was Anthony Corallo, not Anthony Salerno. (Mr. Salerno, who was also indicted that year, was a leader of the Genovese family.) The error also appeared in a caption with a picture of Mr. Salerno.

headline: Star Wars: The Toons
text: New chapters in the everlasting George Lucas “Star Wars” saga will turn up on Turner Broadcasting’s Cartoon Network in the fall. The network broadcasts of the new computer-generated animated series, “Star Wars: The Clone Wars,” will be followed by broadcasts on TNT. Lucasfilm Animation has produced more than 30 half-hour episodes about the battle of Jedi Knights against villains seeking control of the galaxy. The series will follow the premiere of a film of the same title on Aug. 15.

headline: ‘Venom’? ‘Cult’? It’s Campaign Fever
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Changing View of Ear Infections
text: Dr. Stephen Berman, a pediatrician at the University of Colorado School of Medicine, has written extensively about ear infections. “My view on the management of ear infections has changed over the past decade, because of the rise of resistant bacteria and the importance of excessive antibiotic use in contributing to this rise,” Dr. Berman said. Here are five things he feels that every parent should know about ear infections.

headline: Zimbabwe: Party Formally Expels Mugabe Challenger
text: The ruling party, ZANU-PF, formally expelled Simba Makoni, a former finance minister who announced last week that he would challenge Robert G. Mugabe for the presidency. Nathan Shamuyarira, a party spokesman, said any party officials who supported the renegade candidacy would be similarly expelled. The Makoni candidacy might prove formidable, especially if he can unite opposition against Mr. Mugabe. But Morgan Tsvangirai, the candidate of the Movement for Democratic Change, has dismissed any notion of stepping aside for Mr. Makoni, calling him “old wine in a new bottle.”

headline: Looking for Sure Political Bets at Online Prediction Market
text: There is a professional poker player in Queens named Serge Ravitch who is convinced that he can make money off this year’s presidential election. But to explain what he’s up to, I want to start with a story about last week’s Democratic primary in California.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about efforts by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama to outdo each other in campaign fund-raising misstated the month that the totals for February will be made public by the Federal Election Commission. It is March, not April.

headline: U.S. Acts to Avert Tactic Expected in Qaeda Trial
text: WASHINGTON  Bush administration officials said Tuesday that they were confident that charges against six suspected members of Al Qaeda would survive expected defense contentions that the cases are based on unreliable statements obtained using harsh interrogation methods.

headline: 2 Boys, 2 Sides, 2 Beds in an Israeli Hospital Ward
text: TEL HASHOMER, Israel  Two small boys lay sedated in a hospital ward in this Tel Aviv suburb on Tuesday, unaware of each other or of the growing commotion around them.

headline: U.S. Program to Verify Worker Status Is Growing
text: LOS ANGELES  The number of businesses taking part in a voluntary program that allows them to verify electronically their newly hired employees’ legal authorization to work in the United States is soaring, the federal government said Tuesday.

headline: Nachbar Puts Aside Jump Shot for Dunks
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Bostjan Nachbar makes a living with a jump shot, often coolly launching it from long range. But he was on the Nets’ bench for the entire first half Tuesday and had stored up enough energy to try something much bolder.

headline: Twins Sign Liván Hernández
text: The right-hander Liván Hernández agreed to a one-year, $5 million contract with the Minnesota Twins on Tuesday. The deal could earn him an additional $2 million in performance bonuses.Hernández, who has never pitched in the American League, made $7 million last season with Arizona, going 11-11 with a 4.93 earned run average in 33 starts. He has played for Florida, San Francisco, Montreal, Washington and Arizona since his major league debut in September 1996.

headline: What to Ask About Ear Infections
text: Here are some questions you may not think to ask, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: A $1.2 Billion Write-Down at Credit Suisse
text: The Zurich headquarters of Switzerland’s two largest banks may be within walking distance of each other, but when it comes to weathering the credit crisis they are miles apart.

headline: Ex-Firefighter, 101, Fixture in Atlantic City Department, Dies in Home Fire
text: After starting as a police officer in the raucous Prohibition era, and serving another 47 years as a firefighter during Atlantic City’s rise and decline before the advent of casinos, Edward Jordan was a legendary local character.

headline: Swimsuit for the Olympics Is a New Skin for the Big Dip
text: Ryan Lochte, an Olympic swimmer, said he felt like a superhero. Michael Phelps, who is expected to win multiple gold medals at the Beijing Games, said it was as if he were wearing a spacesuit. And this was after Phelps, promoting a slinky black unitard swimsuit, stood on a podium with his arms and legs splayed like Leonardo da Vinci’s “Vitruvian Man.”

headline: Crew Powers Up Laboratory at International Space Station
text: WASHINGTON (Bloomberg News)  American and European astronauts on Tuesday inaugurated the Columbus science laboratory, the newest addition to the International Space Station and Europe’s largest contribution.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Monday about a production of Peter Handke’s play “The Hour We Knew Nothing of Each Other,” at the National Theater in London, referred incorrectly to the play. While it is new to the National Theater, it was written in 1992. It is not a new play.

headline: Lifeline for Whom?
text: When pressed by government officials, the mortgage industry has repeatedly pledged to modify the loans of at-risk borrowers.

headline: Nokia Dominates, but Rivals Insist That Could Change
text: BARCELONA, Spain  At a glance, the mobile phone, a steel-blue clamshell model able to display streaming video at broadband Internet speeds, could be mistaken for one of the more than 100 models made by Nokia, the world’s leading cellphone maker.

headline: Russia: Campbell Soup in Broth Venture
text: The Campbell Soup Company said it planned to team up with a Russian meat supplier, Joosten Products, to make broths at a factory outside Moscow. The company plans to start selling the locally made broth in Russia by the end of the year. “The opening of local production goes in line with Campbell’s strategic plans for the Russian market: to provide maximum accessibility of high-quality products in one of the world’s most promising markets,” Campbell said. The company, based in Camden, N.J., began selling imported broths in Russia in October.

headline: Smart Land Deals as a Cornerstone of Free Tuition
text: Most colleges sometimes get involved in the thorny world of real estate, but for the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, owning property in Manhattan and managing it wisely are an integral part of its success as a college.

headline: Man Is Sought in New York Psychologist’s Stabbing
text: Armed with a suitcase full of knives, an unidentified middle-aged man unleashed a rampage of violence inside the offices of an Upper East Side psychiatry practice on Tuesday night, fatally stabbing and slashing a well-known psychologist before wounding her colleague when he tried to come to her aid, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Letters
text: Anxiety and Me

headline: Bush Presses House on Surveillance
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush strongly urged the House of Representatives on Wednesday to quickly approve a surveillance bill passed by the Senate Tuesday evening, saying he would not agree to a further extension of the current eavesdropping law.

headline: Man Is Sought in New York Psychologist’s Stabbing
text: Armed with a suitcase full of knives, an unidentified middle-aged man unleashed a rampage of violence inside the offices of an Upper East Side psychiatry practice on Tuesday night, fatally stabbing and slashing a well-known psychologist before wounding her colleague when he tried to come to her aid, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: The Worlds of Flesh and of Ink Blur in an Animated Landscape
text: Flat feels surprisingly full in “The Slug Bearers of Kayrol Island (Or, the Friends of Dr. Rushower),” the droll and hypnotizing musical that opened on Tuesday night at the Vineyard Theater. This deadpan fable of colliding cultures from the urban-lore cartoonist Ben Katchor blurs the line between two and three dimensions to the point that it creates its own spatial universe, delicately wedged in between.

headline: Spielberg Drops Out as Adviser to Beijing Olympics in Dispute Over Darfur Conflict
text: WASHINGTON  Steven Spielberg said Tuesday that he was withdrawing as an artistic adviser to the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, after almost a year of trying unsuccessfully to prod President Hu Jintao of China to do more to try to end Sudan’s attacks in the Darfur region.

headline: Beagle, a Breed Long Unsung, Wins Best in Show
text: When Dr. J. Donald Jones, the judge for the best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show, looked at the seven competitors for the title Tuesday night, he saw four breeds that had been denied the crown and three that had captured it.

headline: With Surge in Momentum, Obama Makes His Case
text: WASHINGTON  The lopsided nature of Senator Barack Obama’s parade of victories on Tuesday gives him an opening to make the case that Democratic voters have broken in his favor and that the party should coalesce around his candidacy.

headline: Helicopter School Closes, Leaving Students in Lurch
text: LAS VEGAS  A helicopter flight training school run by a prominent Republican fund-raiser in Nevada has declared bankruptcy, leaving students in 18 states responsible for hundreds of thousands of dollars in uninsured student loans.

headline: Super, Sure. But Who Asked Them?
text: In late November, the Democratic superdelegates from New York met in Virginia, at a gathering of the party’s national committee. All but three or four people in the room wore buttons that said “Hillary.”

headline: Are Ear Tubes in Your Child’s Future?
text: Dr. Jack Paradise is professor emeritus of pediatrics at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine.

headline: From Russia With Verve: It’s Ovechkin
text: When Bruce Boudreau first met his players as the Washington Capitals’ coach, he had no idea what to expect. His career, spent largely bouncing around minor leagues, had not taken him in front of the kind of players now judging his every move.

headline: Creative Juices Flow for Pro Bono Effort to Aid Global Water Projects
text: LIKE the ripples from a drop of rain when it falls on a pond, a charitable campaign created last year by a New York boutique agency is arriving next month in more than a dozen other cities, and there are plans to expand it globally in 2009.

headline: Australia Says NATO Needs New Strategy in Afghanistan
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Australia wants a major reconsideration of Western strategy in Afghanistan and will not increase its troop levels in the country until “underperforming” NATO countries shoulder their fair share of the burden, the Australian defense minister said Tuesday.

headline: More Students Passing A.P. Exams
text: A higher percentage of students in public high schools are taking and passing Advanced Placement exams, according to a report issued Wednesday by the College Board. The gap between the performance of black and white students, however, remains large.

headline: Tasting Notes
text: OVER several weeks, through steady nibbling and one large blind tasting, members of the Dining section’s staff tasted more than 30 milk chocolates ranging from 30 percent to 50 percent cacao. These “dark milk” bars revealed a broad spectrum of color, creaminess, sweetness, spice and fruit.

headline: Girardi Urges Pettitte to Focus on the Future
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Long before Andy Pettitte fields his first questions from reporters this week about his turbulent off-season, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi has already plotted a strategy to assist him. Girardi’s comments indicate that he wants Pettitte to look forward, not backward, and feel normal, not abnormal.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page Inside summary on Feb. 5 for a sports article about Coach Bob Knight’s resignation at Texas Tech referred imprecisely to his place in major college basketball history. As the article noted, Mr. Knight won more games than any men’s coach, not more than any coach  a distinction that belongs to Pat Summitt, the women’s coach at Tennessee.

headline: McCain and Obama Turn Fire on Each Other
text: A day after his overwhelming victories in three eastern primaries, Senator Barack Obama hammered his economic message in Wisconsin on Wednesday, while Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sidestepped the next round of Democratic primaries to concentrate on the delegate-rich Texas race.

headline: 3 Arrested in Plot to Kill Cartoonist
text: BRUSSELS  Two Tunisians and a Dane were arrested in Denmark on Tuesday to prevent what the Danish police said would have been “a terror-related assassination” of one of 12 cartoonists behind caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad published in 2005 that provoked fury across the Muslim world.

headline: Southwest. Way Southwest.
text: DALLAS  Southwest Airlines, with a raucous corporate culture that is the exception in the grim airline industry, stands to look even wilder as some of its big competitors contemplate mergers that would only further muddy their corporate identities.

headline: Going Out to Eat, but Staying Green
text: AT the Oko frozen yogurt shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn, the counter and walls are made from sunflower seeds and its awnings have solar panels.

headline: Japan Focuses Anger on U.S. In Rape Arrest of a Marine
text: TOKYO  Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda of Japan voiced anger on Tuesday over accusations that a United States marine had raped a 14-year-old girl in Okinawa, calling the episode “unforgivable.”

headline: City Landmarks Named
text: The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission voted on Tuesday to give landmark designation to Congregation Tifereth Israel (1911), believed to be the oldest structure in Queens built as a synagogue. Estée Lauder attended services there as a young woman, and in 1979 and 1980 Madonna lived nearby in a building that used to be a yeshiva affiliated with the congregation. The two-story, wood-frame synagogue, right, designed by Crescent L. Varrone, at 109-18 54th Avenue in Corona, combines Gothic and Moorish design elements with Judaic ornaments: pointed-arched windows, a roundel with a Star of David in colored glass, and a gabled parapet. The original wooden stoop and railing have been replaced with a brick porch with an iron railing, and the wood clapboard siding has been covered with stucco. The design was modeled after synagogues on the Lower East Side, where the founders of the congregation, established in 1907, had originally lived. In 2002 the building was placed on the National Register of Historic Places. Also on Tuesday, the commission voted for a third time to designate the Jamaica Savings Bank building, an 1898 Hough & Duell Beaux-Arts structure at 161-02 Jamaica Avenue, in Jamaica, as a landmark. Twice previously, the commission’s landmark designation for that building has been overturned: by the Board of Estimate in 1975, and by the City Council in 1992. The building’s owner has agreed to support the current designation, which is expected to meet with Council approval.

headline: Sources of Heat and Light to Challenge an Icy Season
text: On a miserably cold winter evening, musical comfort food like Schumann’s vibrant Piano Quintet provides warming nourishment. It was given a vigorous performance on Monday at Weill Recital Hall by the Modigliani String Quartet and the pianist Jean-Frédéric Neuburger.

headline: India: More Than Half of Tigers Lost in 5 Years, Census Finds
text: A much-anticipated tiger census report found that their numbers had dwindled to 1,411 from 3,642 in 2002, the last census year. The report confirmed the fears of conservationists that India’s tigers are fast declining because of poaching and the loss of their natural homes.

headline: Richard Ford Leaves His Longtime Publisher
text: In a surprise move, Richard Ford, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “Independence Day” and “The Lay of the Land,” has switched publishers for his next three books.

headline: Clinton in El Paso
text: Hillary Clinton addressed supporters in Texas after losses to Barack Obama in Maryland, Virginia and Washington, D.C. (Video: NBC News)

headline: John McCain in Alexandria, Va.
text: John McCain spoke to supporters after winning contests in the District of Columbia, Maryland and Virginia. (Video: NBC News)

headline: Barack Obama in Madison, Wis.
text: Barack Obama celebrated wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. (Video: NBC News)

headline: Start Getting Your Brackets Ready
text: Just as Tom Lemming, Allen Wallace and other football recruitnics are being put into hibernation for a long winter’s nap (at least until Terrelle Pryor announces where he’ll play his college ball), the bracketologists are waking up. Well, they’ve actually been awake for a while. But now we can start paying legitimate attention to them. There’s just over a month remaining until Selection Sunday, which means that the bracket is coming into clearer focus.

headline: The Season in Quotes
text: We commend to you profootballoutsiders.com and their compilation of the season’s top quotations:

headline: Food Stuff
text: A Family Bakery, Still Going Strong

headline: Dell to Buy E-Mail Service
text: Dell, the computer maker, said on Tuesday that it would buy the business e-mail services provider MessageOne, which was co-founded by Michael S. Dell’s brother, in an effort to compete with similar services provided by Microsoft and Google.

headline: At Trial, Lawyer Says Buffett Gave Approval
text: The lawyer defending the former chief executive of General Reinsurance against fraud charges pointed the finger Tuesday at the investor Warren E. Buffett.

headline: Delphi Financing Hits Speed Bump
text: The $6.1 billion plan to bring auto-parts supplier Delphi out of bankruptcy protection may be in jeopardy as bank lenders face trouble syndicating loans to other lenders, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: MySpace to Launch Incubator, Report Says
text: MySpace plans to announce as soon as Wednesday 13 that it has formed a business incubator called SlingShot Labs to spawn Internet start-ups for News Corporation‘s growing empire of Web properties, which now includes The Wall Street Journal’s WSJ.com as well as the video game site IGN, according to BusinessWeek.

headline: Citi Sets Aside $3.5 Billion to Shore Up SIVs
text: Citigroup said on Tuesday it plans to provide a $3.5 billion facility to support six of the seven structured investment vehicles it took onto its balance sheet last year to shore up their debt ratings and protect creditors.

headline: SocGen Rights Issue May Not Deter Bidders
text: A deeply discounted $8 billion rights issue from Société Générale, seen in part as a bid by the scandal-hit French bank to remain independent, has not convinced analysts that it will deter predators.

headline: DBS Appoints Citigroup China Head to C.E.O. Post
text: The DBS Group, Southeast Asia’s biggest bank, said Wednesday that it had hired Richard Stanley, the chief executive of Citigroup China, as chief executive to revive its China business and expand outside Singapore.

headline: E.U. Antitrust Regulators Raid Intel Offices
text: The European Commission conducted antitrust raids Tuesday at the Munich offices of Intel, the world’s largest chip maker, and of retailers selling products made by the company, the commission and the chip maker said.

headline: Quebec Pension Fund Backs Exchange Merger
text: Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec, the powerful Canadian pension fund, is supporting the TSX Group‘s proposed 1.3 billion Canadian dollar takeover of the Montreal Exchange, provided that some operations stay in Montreal and its governance concerns are met.

headline: Alpha Mom Sells Stake to Fahrenheit 212
text: Alpha Mom, the popular parenting blog, has sold a minority stake to Fahrenheit 212, a consultancy, in exchange for its help in developing products and services to expand the brand nationally, The New York Post reported.

headline: Duquesne Capital Washes Its Hands of InterOil
text: InterOil, which is seeking to develop a liquefied natural gas project in Papua New Guinea, appears to have lost a believer, as a hedge fund run by one of the richest men in the United States has sold all of its shares in the company.

headline: The Point Gets “a Bunch of Money” from New Enterprise
text: New Enterprise Associates rallied around The Point with $4.8 million in funding for the company, a social networking site that was started late last year.

headline: Hedge Fund Investors Favor Emerging Markets
text: Inflows to hedge funds investing in emerging markets has increased more than 40 percent in two years to $9 billion, fueled by volatility in commodities and foreign exchanges.

headline: Canadian Private Equity Sector Shows Resiliency
text: Canada’s private equity deal makers showed resiliency in the face of the deepening credit crunch in the fourth quarter of 2007, but the quarter exposed the beginnings of a slower era facing the sector in 2008.

headline: Liz Claiborne Close to Selling Ellen Tracy, Reports Says
text: Liz Claiborne, the fashion apparel company, is close to selling its Ellen Tracy brand to a private investment consortium for $50 million, The New York Post reported Wednesday.

headline: Wellspring Said to Prepare Dave & Buster’s Sale
text: Wellspring Capital Management has decided to take a Dallas-based restaurant chain Dave & Buster’s to market months after an initial attempt to sell the company was pulled, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Britain Said to Request Improved Northern Rock Bids
text: Two suitors competing to rescue the British bank Northern Rock have been told to improve their offers to beat the alternative of nationalization, according to press reports.

headline: Speculation in the Valley: Oracle’s Next Big Deal?
text: Analysts and industry observers appeared split on whether a rumor that Salesforce.com has approached Oracle about an $8.9 billion deal to sell itself to Larry Ellison’s firm may become a reality.

headline: Yahoo Turmoil Stokes a Recruiting Frenzy
text: Microsoft‘s unsolicited — and recently rejected — bid for Yahoo is apparently creating a feeding frenzy of sorts for Silicon Valley headhunters.

headline: Delta’s Anderson to Waive Compensation in Merger
text: Delta Air Lines‘ chief executive, Richard Anderson, has told the airline’s board he will waive compensation in the event of a merger.

headline: ‘Hottest Female Associate’ Contest Leaves Skadden Unamused
text: Who’s the hottest young female lawyer at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom? Last week that question sent the New York firm into a bit of a tizzy.

headline: American Capital Agency Seeks $400 Million I.P.O.
text: The American Capital Agency has filed with regulators for an initial public offering in hopes of raising as much as $400 million on the Nasdaq stock market.

headline: Goldman Tops Tech Deal-Maker List
text: Goldman Sachs claimed the top spot as the busiest adviser in technology mergers during 2007, according to data compiled by The 451 Group. It was Goldman’s third year in a row at No. 1, as measured by the volume of tech deals on which it served as adviser. But its lead has narrowed from previous years.

headline: Buffett’s Rescue Seen as Shrewd Move
text: Warren E. Buffett volunteered on Tuesday to rescue Wall Street from its latest looming crisis.

headline: UBS Names Head of Investment Banking
text: UBS on Wednesday named Jerker Johansson as head of its investment bank, ending a protracted search that followed the write-downs of billions of dollars from the subprime crisis.

headline: Fujifilm to Bid for Toyama Chemical
text: Fujifilm Holdings, the digital camera and medical equipment maker, said it would take control of Toyama Chemical for up to 155 billion yen ($1.45 billion) to gain a foothold in the pharmaceuticals market.

text: Kris Tapley at Red Carpet District has a few items of ninny interest, including pointing us to a great story in Variety that deconstructs how the Academy’s music branch hit a few sour notes this year. He also hosts a “Juno Jargon Jenerator” that let’s readers listen to their hearts’ content to neologisms like “fo shizz.”

headline: The Greatest Comic Actor of Our Time?
text: Gold Rush says that the reigning funny man of our time is short, hairy, and prone to antic body movements. And no, it ain’t Robin Williams.

headline: Defamed
text: Over the past few years, the Bagger has found himself admiring, linking to and occasionally coveting the voice of Defamer, which always seems to have a ready supply of bemused élan on hand regardless of topic. Now comes word that Mark Lisanti, the site’s editor, who can turn any random starlet or studio monster into red mist with a flick of the mouse, is leaving “to spend more time with his family.”

headline: Who is Your Queen?
text: The FilmExperience blog has a bit of bake-off underway for Diva of the Year.  Where else could you seen Marjane of “Persepolis” and Cate Blanchett’s “Elizabeth” thowdown over the right to wear the crown? Marjane’s turn-on’s include Bruce Lee and bad 80s rock, but she still counts Abba among her turn-offs. Elizabeth, meanwhile, loves the art of human manipulation but cannot abide Spain.

headline: Paying the Full Price of Your Car
text: The mayor of London, Ken Livingstone, is once again ahead of the climate change game. On Tuesday he announced that drivers of vehicles producing very high levels of emissions would have to pay a very high price to enter central London: Â£25 a day, starting in October.

headline: In Denmark, Encore for Muhammad Cartoon
text: So many things to report, so little space. That’s chief reason newspapers aren’t usually in the business of reprinting things. Here’s another: To avoid worldwide fury.

headline: A Reversal of Position on School Vouchers
text: From his perch at the Manhattan Institute, the right-leaning research group, Sol Stern, 72, has reveled as the city’s cantankerous provocateur against liberal education policies, criticizing reading curriculums that de-emphasize phonics as well as public schools that focus on social justice, Jennifer Medina writes. Like many of his intellectual allies, he had ardently supported school vouchers as a way to give poor and minority children better educational choices and to create competition that would help improve public schools. Although colleagues long thought they had him pegged, he made an abrupt about-face on vouchers in the most recent issue of City Journal, the institute’s magazine, saying there was little evidence they had done much to improve public education across the country. In the circles Mr. Stern inhabits, such a sentiment is a kind of heresy, and his essay has set off a firestorm. But he is relishing the attention.

headline: The Early Word: On, Wisconsin
text: Barack Obama swept the Crab Cake Primaries in D.C., Maryland and Virginia on Tuesday, defeating his opponent Hillary Rodham Clinton by large margins. It was telling, perhaps, that Mr. Obama made his victory remarks at an arena in Madison, the capital of Wisconsin — the next primary battleground and a place where so far he holds a slight lead in the polls — while Mrs. Clinton watched Tuesday’s results from El Paso, Texas, where she was working to get a jump in that big, delegate-rich state, whose nominating contest is set for March 4.

headline: Be Like Mike?
text: How bad have things gotten for Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign? “If you look at the Clinton and Huckabee votes in Virginia, they mirror each other. They both do well where it’s poor and white,” writes Matt Cooper, the Washington editor of Portfolio (whose wife, Mandy Grunwald, works for Hillary Clinton), at his Portfolio blog. He later adds:

headline: PETA vs. the Dog Show
text: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals never shies away from publicity-seeking provocation (and media, including this blog, often cover it). This week, the group is starting an advertising campaign in New York and other cities that advocates dog population control, including one commercial that likens dog breeders to the Ku Klux Klan. In New York, like many other places, about half the dogs and cats taken into animal shelters are euthanized.One of the commercials shows a hooded Ku Klux Klan member walking into a meeting of the purebreds-only American Kennel Club, where the members eye him suspiciously. He gets the group to concede that they both believe in the “sanctity of pure bloodlines” and a master race. He sits down, saying, “I’ll fit right in here.” Then the message “All dogs are created equal” flashes on the screen.

headline: Mustard and Memories
text: As today’s review of the Second Avenue Deli notes, New Yorkers have very strong — and divergent — opinions about deli food.

text: Is it possible that Barack Obama has become the favorite in Texas, a state long considered to be a firewall for Hillary Clinton?

headline: Recipe of the Day: Winter Squash in Coconut Milk
text: Just before the first spring vegetables begin to appear, and almost at the last possible time to exploit last fall’s harvest, my friend Ed Schneider — who will be making his first guest appearance on this blog soon enough — dropped this gift in my lap: a recipe for a dessert soup of winter squash poached in coconut milk.

headline: Yo, State of da Union
text: Beat-boxing Bush, a Prez with a word up for his peeps:

headline: Satisfying Cravings
text: There are two addictions I find treated in especially perverse fashion in the contemporary food world: caffeine and alcohol. In most of the world, most of the time, both of these drugs are treated as such, and the delivery systems are rarely discussed. They may be better-tasting (espresso and Burgundy), or worse (coffee that sits on a hot plate for a few hours, or rotgut).

headline: Vietnam Enters a New Era
text: Thanks to its spectacular coastline and rich culture, tourism to Vietnam is soaring—and so are the country’s property prices. But it’s still a difficult market for international property investors, according to James Gonzalez, market analyst for Obelisk, the property firm.

headline: Around the World in One Hundred Years
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: 100 Days That Shook the Studios
text: The Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers broke its silence on Tuesday night over the end of the 100-day strike that crippled the entertainment community, with eight chief executives of media conglomerates releasing a celebratory joint statement.

headline: Spring Awakenings at CBS
text: Today is the day that the writers return to work, and — perhaps not coincidentally — CBS has announced the anticipated return dates for its popular shows that were sidelined by the work stoppage.

headline: Nostalgia Draped in Orange: Remembering ‘The Gates’
text: If you can have nostalgia for something that only happened three years ago, then the screening of “The Gates,” an HBO documentary about the 2005 Central Park art installation by Christo and Jeanne-Claude, inspired waves of it (and a lot of orange) at Gracie Mansion on Tuesday night.Jeanne-Claude’s hair was orange, the passionfruit and vodka drinks on the silver trays were orange, the ranuculus blossoms in scattered glass vases were orange, the chandelier was decked out in orange. Even Katherine Oliver, the city commissioner who oversees film and theater, had orange highlights in her suit.

headline: Will Zuckerman Bid for the G.M. Building?
text: As Harry Macklowe, the New York real estate magnate, prepares to sell the iconic General Motors Building to pay off a $1.2 billion loan, it appears a fellow high-profile rival may be interested in picking it up.

headline: London Fashion Week | Balenciaga Store Opening
Do Statins Make You Stupid?
text: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs have had a rough time of it lately.

headline: For Bear Fund Manager, the Split Was ‘Mutual’
text: When Ralph Cioffi left Bear Stearns, he did it quietly. Asked about the departure by Bloomberg News in December, a Bear Stearns spokeswoman wouldn’t discuss why he packed up his things. Mr. Cioffi, who had presided over two Bear Stearns hedge funds that filed for bankruptcy protection, wouldn’t comment to Bloomberg at all.

headline: Open Caucus: Obama’s Winning Streak
text: Our Open Caucus participants reacted to Barack Obama’s recent victories in D.C., Maryland and Virginia — not to mention last weekend’s contests in Louisiana, Nebraska and Washington. Is this momentum going to lead Mr. Obama to the Democratic nomination, or will Hillary Rodham Clinton stop Mr. Obama in Ohio? As always, feel free to join the discussion in the comments section below.

headline: Picking the Lock on Best Actor
text: The Bagger is still waiting for a copy of “There Will Be Blood” so he can check the view from the bubble. He knows that Daniel Day-Lewis is a lock for best actor, but had a naughty thought he should probably keep to himself, but that’s not in his nature. If the Bagger were a member of the Academy, he would not be marching in lock-step with his peers to put the crown atop Mr. Lewis’s head. He would instead pause, consider who did what in the context of the film, and mark the spot marked “Clooney.”

headline: Why Brooding Shoppers Overpay
text: When you’re depressed, you tend to devalue things around you. But then why are you more inclined to hit the mall and buy stuff at higher prices than you would at other times? A new paper to be published in Psychological Science provides an answer to that question — and support for a theory of the self proposed by William James more than a century ago.

headline: Clinton Goes Negative in Wisconsin Ad
text: Updated  The gloves are off. Hillary Rodham Clinton just released her first TV ad specifically attacking Barack Obama.

headline: A Good Kaning
text: Just had a look online at Christopher Kane’s collection, and what remarkable work it is. Completely engaging, and an extension in a way of his spring 2007 show, in Holland Park, with the decoration. Except now the clothes, and the thinking behind it, seems far more sophisticated and new. I was struck by exits #7, 12, 14 and 18, particularly the silver-black dress with lines that suggest suspension cables, like a Calatrava bridge.

headline: In Wisconsin, Obama Turns to Economy
text: JANESVILLE, Wis. – Emboldened by a fresh round of victories, Senator Barack Obama delivered a blistering critique of his Democratic and Republican rivals on Wednesday, blaming Washington for the economic crisis that has gripped the nation.

headline: Do bad wars hurt economic confidence?
text: One favorite claim of Bush supporters, trying to explain why people are so negative on what they insist is a terrific economy, is that people are upset about Iraq and project their bad feelings onto the economy, too. That — along with the evergreen claim that the liberal media refuse to report how great things are — is what seems to be going on in this example of whining.

headline: Putting ‘The’ Back in ‘The Daily Show’
text: After five weeks of “A” show, Jon Stewart will put the “The” back in “The Daily Show” on Wednesday.

headline: Bear Hugs From Abroad
text: In the midst of this weekend’s Yahoo hullabaloo, two other bear-hug letters — in addition to the one from Microsoft that we previously wrote about — were delivered to United States-based companies.

headline: Street Photography in an Image-Filled Age
text: In our media-saturated culture, everyone is a picture-taker and image-maker, adding a new wrinkle to the work of those who practice the time-honored tradition of street photography.“It’s harder and harder to take a picture without somebody in the picture who’s also taking a picture,” the Brooklyn-based photographer Gus Powell said on Tuesday evening, explaining that the mere act of taking a photo hardly makes him stand out in a crowd. “We all take pictures — that’s what we do. It’s more that your camera doesn’t look like a phone — that’s the bigger issue.”

headline: Heads, Hearts and David Frum
text: Academics build entire careers trying to figure out why we vote the way we do, whether we make our decisions with our heads or our hearts. Right now, it’s the hearts that are getting most of their attention, and two scholars who stress the role of emotions in political behavior, George Lakoff and Drew Westen, have become darlings of the Democratic party. People think with their guts, Westen says. Well, none of us really likes to believe that (is Westen thinking with his gut when he votes?), but what’s a poor rationalist to do? Politics is hard. Consider health care.

headline: Storybook Debut for Milan Teenager
text: Not bad — 18 years old and a goal-scorer 18 seconds into a debut on his first touch of the ball.

headline: Writers Return to Late-Night Shows
text: With the picket lines lifted, the previously writerless late-night television shows (especially “The Tonight Show” and “Late Night” on NBC and “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC) are now able to book the higher-profile celebrities that had scorned the shows during the strike.

headline: ‘A Size 48 Neck Is Completely Normal’
text: Aired Tuesday night on CBS: Cold here in New York City today. Were you folks cold outside? Here’s a tip. Here’s what savvy New Yorkers do on a cold day like this, I did it earlier today myself. Try it out, let me know what you think. You go over to Grand Central Station — you know where that is, the big train place? There’s the Oyster Bar up there. And on a really cold day like this, go up there and fill your pants full of steamed clams.

headline: Fashion Show | London’s Spring Projects Gallery
text: (Sølve Sundsbø)Just in time for London Fashion week, the well-known London photo studio Spring Studios has opened a new, experimental gallery space called Spring Projects. Directed by Andrée Cooke and with an opening solo show from the fashion photographer Sølve Sundsbø (his first), the gallery hopes to represent artists who bridge the gap between art, fashion and product design. T Magazine’s market editor of design, Andreas Kokkino, spoke with Cooke and Sundsbø about the launch of this new venue and about the relationship between art and fashion.

headline: Go Ahead, Ignore the Economy
text: LONDON — We devotees of American politics from across the pond have been so gripped by the battle between Barack Obama and the Clintons that we risk missing a very striking point about this election campaign. Had you asked European (and probably Asian) pundits on Jan. 1 what was their greatest fear in America’s election year, I’d bet that many of them would have said protectionism (or, for those that don’t care about economics, isolationism).

headline: Candidates Fine-Tune Their Fund-Raising Prowess

headline: ‘Idol’ Delivers Again
text: “Hollywood Week” on “American Idol” got off to a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of Fox’s talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Tuesday’s “Idol” audience grew by 2 million compared with a week ago, the first installment of “Hollywood Week” last year attracted 31.2 million viewers.

headline: N.Y.C. Condoms in Translation
text: “Get some” or “Put it on”? Both messages — one in English, the other in Spanish — are part of the new ad campaign for New York City’s redesigned official condom wrapper.On Valentine’s Day last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene unveiled the city’s first official condom. The letters “NYC CONDOM” were printed in white or black letters against colorful circles, evoking the letter symbols the Metropolitan Transportation Authority uses to represent subway lines. This year’s redesign — by Yves Behar, a noted product and industrial designer — features the letters “NYC” on black letters against three interlocking circles, with the word “CONDOM” underneath, each of the six letters in a different color.

headline: A 25-Year Deal on Horse Racing
text: State officials have announced a final deal — really — to extend New York’s state horse racing franchise another 25 years. Most of the details remain unchanged from what was in the works on Monday night.The New York Racing Association, which has run the tracks at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga Springs since 1955, will continue to run them for the next quarter-century, with an overhauled board of trustees and under the supervision of a new, five-member oversight board dominated by appointees of Gov. Eliot Spitzer. That board will review the association’s performance every five years against a predetermined set of benchmarks, including attendance and financial measures.

headline: Is the Mayor’s Housing Plan on Track?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has proposed a 10-year, $7.5 billion New Housing Marketplace plan to create or preserve 165,000 units of affordable housing. So, is the plan on track to be completed by 2013? A panel of experts, including the city’s commissioner of housing preservation and development, tackled that question this afternoon in a panel discussion at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

headline: A Guide to Yahoo’s Unlikely Alternatives to Microsoft
text: In the course of a terminal illness, a person will often start to cast about for alternative therapies: herbs, acupuncture, fasting on a Tibetan mountain. This exploration is simply part of the process of coming to terms with the painful truth.

headline: Clinton Drops MSNBC Debate Boycott
text: When you run an attack ad against your opponent for refusing to compete in a debate, you can’t very well bow out of one yourself. So today, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign said that she would participate in a debate sponsored by MSNBC in Cleveland, Ohio.

headline: Soft Serve | Purified Pepsi, Bachelorette Butlers, Cooking With Coolio
text: What’s worst than eating soft serve on a daily basis? The gym rats over at Men’s Health made a list of the Worst Food in America. The first place finisher is Outback’s Aussie Cheese Fries… Why not cook yourself something healthy like a caprese salad? Coolio, the host of an internet cooking show, has a recipe for a caprese that “will get them panties right off” … London’s May Fair hotel has another way to get a relationship to the next level. Its new proposal butler will help women pop the question to their man. Our favorite option on the proposal “menu” is one that “involves you and your loved one getting lost and (hopefully) finding each other at the center of the Hampton Court Labyrinth.” Of course. Because wandering around alone is so romantic… While in London, chug some Pepsi Raw, an all-natural soda targeted, ironically, at the nightclub set… If your love life needs a boost that all-natural soda can’t provide, CNN’s list of “surprising reasons you’re not having sex” may have some advice for you …Keeping the kids in their bed and out of yours has never been easier. For $2600, send your little ones into orbit with a Space Ship bunk … Speaking of orbit, NASA needs your help to name a satellite… Dreaming of Hollywood stardom? Snatch up the 138 acres — right next to the Hollywood sign’s letter ‘H’ — formerly owned by Howard Hughes. On second thought, at $22 million, you’d better be a star already… Come back tomorrow for more of the Soft Serve star treatment.

headline: Saving Afghanistan From the Sidelines
text: There are many ways to describe Paddy Ashdown: British politician. The “Michael Jackson of postconflict reconstruction.” The man “asked by the United Nations secretary general to be the UN’s special envoy in Afghanistan but was rejected by Mr Karzai.”

headline: Sun Hasn’t Set

headline: Strike Didn’t Change Late-Night Habits
text: “While loyal viewers undoubtedly noticed the absence of striking writers at the late-night comedy shows, it made little difference in their viewing habits, ratings show,” the Associated Press reports.

headline: Patterns
text: I have had migraines for most of my life; the first attack I remember occurred when I was 3 or 4 years old. I was playing in the garden when a brilliant, shimmering light appeared to my left — dazzlingly bright, almost as bright as the sun. It expanded, becoming an enormous shimmering semicircle stretching from the ground to the sky, with sharp zigzagging borders and brilliant blue and orange colors. Then, behind the brightness, came a blindness, an emptiness in my field of vision, and soon I could see almost nothing on my left side. I was terrified — what was happening? My sight returned to normal in a few minutes, but these were the longest minutes I had ever experienced.

headline: Writers Are ‘Really, Really, Really, Really Happy’ To Be Back

On Wednesday, back at work for the first time in more than three months, they began figuring out how to condense thirteen episodes of plot into seven hours of television.
