headline: Clemens-McNamee: Not Must-See TV for Yankees
text: As Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee verbally sparred at Congressional hearings in Washington, D.C., the Yankees held a seven-hour organizational meeting in Tampa, Fla. Manager Joe Girardi said that he and Yankees officials took a 10-minute break for lunch, but they never flipped on the television to monitor Clemens, the former Yankee, and McNamee, a former Yankee employee.

headline: Whether to Stay a Spectator or Take the Bidding Plunge
text: There are days when you feel that you should have stayed in bed. Things did not go well. But if you remained indoors all the time, life would be boring. You have to get out there and live.

headline: In Tribal Pakistan, Religious Parties Are Foundering
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Senator Asfandyar Wali, the leader of an opposition party, the Awami National Party, is campaigning for the elections next week from the safety of his bed, under a quilt and propped up on bolsters for his bad back at his country home outside Peshawar.

headline: The Sweet Smell of ... Nothing
text: PERFUME has long been an aphrodisiac decanted sparingly from an iconic glass bottle. But for Leslie Ware, a fashion editor at a quarterly magazine in Huntsville, Ala., fragrance has worked its magic in the opposite direction, as a romantic deal breaker.

headline: Vicious Killing Where Troubled Seek a Listener
text: It was just after 8 p.m. in a suite of mental health offices at East 79th Street and York Avenue. One doctor was seeing patients; another was working in her study.

headline: Seeing the Light
text: Goggles might not help you ski faster, but they can help you see icy spots and protect your eyes against the elements, making them a crucial component of any downhill adventure. Because most major manufacturers make goggles with interchangeable lenses, picking a frame is the easy part. Glen Traylor tells customers at Cole Sport, a retailer in Park City, Utah, that's frequented by both novices and members of the U.S. Ski Team: "If you like the way it looks, and if it fits well, then you've found your goggles."

headline: China Vetoes Film
text: China has blocked production of “Shanghai,” a Hollywood film about an American who investigates a friend’s death in Japanese-occupied Shanghai, The Associated Press reported. Luan Guozhi, the director of international cooperation at the Chinese Film Bureau, declined to reveal the government’s concerns, but said the filmmakers could alter the script and resubmit their application. The Japanese invasion of China during World War II remains a sensitive topic, and other filmmakers have had difficulty winning approval from China for projects set in the same era. Variety has reported that the cast includes John Cusack, Gong Li, right, and Ken Watanabe. Hundreds of thousands of dollars have already been spent on production, and the director, Mikael Hafstrom, has been in China since September preparing to film. Variety reported that he planned to move the production to Hong Kong.

headline: An All-in-One Printer, Without All the Messy Wires
text: Epson’s first printer with Wi-Fi, the Stylus CX9475Fax, also happens to be a scanner  and as the name suggests, a fax machine. Although it can hook up directly to a computer with a U.S.B. cable, it is really more at home on a wireless network, where it can be used by multiple computers in a household, a small business or a loft shared by starving artists.

headline: Before bin Laden, One of World’s Most Feared Men
text: WASHINGTON  Long before Osama bin Laden founded Al Qaeda and initiated the Sept. 11 attacks against the United States, Imad Mugniyah was perhaps the world’s most feared terrorist.

headline: A Clivia, Withholding
text: Q. A decade ago, I was given a baby offshoot from a friend’s clivia. It is kept in a cool greenhouse with medium light and has grown into a large, healthy plant. But all it does is make leaves. How do I get it to bloom?

headline: East Timor, Shaken by Attack on Leaders, Weighs Causes
text: DILI, East Timor  In the wake of Monday’s twinned attacks on the president and prime minister here, the United Nations, the international military force and the East Timorese government are all facing questions about how the country’s two top leaders were exposed to attack, why a renowned rebel leader and his gang were left largely free to roam the countryside for months and what exact motive the attackers had.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a new study on muscle fatigue and what could prevent it misidentified the exercise scientist at Appalachian State University who collaborated with the principal investigator, Dr. Andrew Marks. He is David Nieman  not Dr. Stephan Lehnart, who works in Dr. Marks’s laboratory. The article also misstated the name of the North Carolina town where Appalachian State is located. It is Boone, not Boonetown.

headline: Strike Disrupts Greece as Workers Seek to Protect Their Pensions
text: ATHENS  A 24-hour nationwide strike on Wednesday grounded air travel and shut down public services, state banks and hospitals in the latest show of swelling labor protests against government plans to make changes in Greece’s deficit-plagued pension system.

headline: At Home in the World
text: As soon as Jeffrey R. Immelt, General Electric’s chairman, became chief executive in 2001, his foreign-based managers began pressing him to move some major operations overseas.

headline: Police Identify Gunman in Illinois Killing
text: The authorities say a 17-year-old who was already detained on related charges was the gunman in the November 2007 shooting death of a University of Chicago graduate student from Senegal. The suspect, Demetrius Warren, is one of three teenagers and a 21-year old who have been charged in a series of crimes that culminated in the killing of the student, Amadou Cisse, 29, outside his apartment just off campus. Before killing Mr. Cisse, the authorities say, the group drove around looking for people to rob, mugging university students and shooting at an employee.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Money Managers to Post Full Details on Web
text: WASHINGTON (Dow Jones)  Money managers in the United States would have to provide online brochures describing their services, fees, investment performance and potential conflicts of interest under a proposal approved Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Here Comes Kosovo
text: Europe will get a new state, Kosovo, on Sunday and the long, bloody unraveling of Yugoslavia will be concluded 17 years after the first war of its dissolution broke out in Slovenia. That is cause for celebration.

headline: Gunman Kills 5 on Illinois Campus
text: A gunman killed five students and wounded 16 others in a Northern Illinois University lecture hall on Thursday afternoon in DeKalb before killing himself, according to university and police officials.

headline: As Mores Evolve, India’s Divorced Seek Second Chance
text: NEW DELHI  Above a working man’s diner in the middle of a hurly-burly city market, Yuvraj Raina abets what until recently would have been seen as a radical challenge to the social order.

headline: Senate Ethics Committee Admonishes Larry Craig
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Larry E. Craig was admonished by his colleagues on Wednesday for conduct that reflected poorly on the Senate as the result of his arrest and guilty plea last summer in an undercover sex sting in a men’s bathroom at the Minneapolis airport.

headline: What Was at Hand and Where He Found It
text: DESIGN, William Harvey-style, means working with what’s at hand, and what you find in his living room often ends up in a furniture line.

headline: Eavesdropping Law Is Likely to Lapse
text: WASHINGTON  Broad spying powers temporarily approved by Congress in August appear likely to lapse this week after a daylong game of chicken on Wednesday between the White House and House Democrats produced no clear resolution.

headline: And What About the Straws?
text: IF ever Nina Valenti had fielded a client’s request that sounded less like a challenge from “Project Runway,” she did not know what it was. Ms. Valenti, a Brooklyn designer, was at work on an ensemble for the concert pianist Soyeon Lee, who had asked for a dress made entirely of used juice pouches.

headline: Abscess Becomes a Key Point in the McNamee-Clemens Confrontation
text: WASHINGTON  Throughout the confrontation between Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee, much of the back and forth has been based on recollections of events as far as 10 years ago.

headline: The Mysterious Common Cramp
text: Cramps are common among endurance athletes, who get taken by surprise when they hit and the muscle contracts violently, as if prodded with a jolt of electricity. But as Gina Kolata writes in The Times today, cramps remain a medical mystery despite their ubiquity. Medical textbooks skirt the topic, and few scientists have studied them. That hasn't slowed the advice circulating on how to avoid them.

headline: Man Stabs 3 to Death in New Jersey, Police Say, Then Calmly Confesses
text: IRVINGTON, N.J.  Shortly after noon on Wednesday, the authorities said, a young man walked into the Fifth Precinct station house in Newark, approached the front desk and calmly made a startling announcement: “I just killed three people.”

headline: Small Companies Are Finding a Home on the Web
text: The Web site for Sophia Brodsky’s day spa in Philadelphia, the Body Klinic, was pretty rudimentary until a college student walked into the spa a little more than two years ago with an irresistible offer.

headline: Plaintiff Stops Bush Deposition
text: The plaintiff in a civil lawsuit against Reggie Bush walked out of a deposition Tuesday after the lawyer for Bush arrived with a plainclothes security guard who carried a concealed handgun.

headline: Bomb in Syria Kills Militant Sought as Terrorist
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A top Hezbollah commander long sought by the United States for his role in terrorist attacks that killed hundreds of Americans in the 1980s, died Tuesday night in Damascus, Syria, when a bomb detonated under the vehicle he was in, Syrian officials said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A headline on Tuesday about presidential campaigning leading up to three primaries that day referred incorrectly to the contests. They were held in two states and the District of Columbia, not in three states.

headline: Women in Politics
text: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Officials Say Broken Satellite Will Be Shot Down
text: WASHINGTON  The military will attempt to shoot down a crippled spy satellite some time in the next two weeks, senior officials said on Thursday, laying out a high-tech plan to intercept the large spacecraft over the Pacific Ocean just before it tumbles uncontrollably back to earth with toxic fuel aboard.

headline: New Settlement in 2003 Nightclub Fire
text: BOSTON  Clear Channel Broadcasting has reached a tentative $22 million settlement with survivors and families of those killed in a 2003 nightclub fire in West Warwick, R.I., according to court documents filed Wednesday.

headline: For Sale: Parcel Near Big Sign. Views Are Nifty.
text: LOS ANGELES  If Howard Hughes had had his way in 1940, the famous “Hollywood” sign would be sitting in the shadow of the sprawling mansion he planned to build for the woman he loved at the time, the actress and dancer Ginger Rogers.

headline: Yahoo Chief Explains Rejection of Microsoft Bid
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Jerry Yang, the chief executive of Yahoo, explained his company’s rejection of Microsoft’s buyout offer in a letter to shareholders late Wednesday outlining why he believed the bid, initially valued at $44.6 billion, was too low.

headline: Los Angeles Times Names New Top Editor
text: The Los Angeles Times named a new top editor on Thursday, Russ Stanton, three weeks after the previous editor, James E. O’Shea, was forced out for resisting another in a series of staff cuts.

headline: At Cellphone Trade Show, the Spotlight Chases Google
text: BARCELONA, Spain  Toru Arakawa, chief executive of Access, the biggest cellphone software company in Japan, took a diplomat’s view of Google’s foray into telecommunications.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Senator John McCain’s decision to hire Mercer Reynolds, one of President Bush’s major fund-raisers, misstated the position of Senator Barack Obama on using public financing for the general election. Although the Obama campaign has been raising private contributions for that election, Mr. Obama is still open to returning those contributions and abiding by the limits of the public financing system if the Republican nominee agrees to do the same. Mr. Obama has not definitively ruled out using public financing. (Go to Article)

headline: Tour Organizers Exclude 2007 Winner and His Team
text: For the second year in a row, the defending champion of the Tour de France is unlikely to be at the starting line in July.

headline: In a Time of Trouble, a Transcendent Valentine Bond
text: The first time Andrea Nieto Hernandez saw the ocean, she cried.

headline: Surprising Retail Sales Lift the Gloom, for a Day
text: Stocks rallied on Wednesday, sending the Dow Jones industrials up nearly 180 points, after the Commerce Department released some unexpected positive economic news: a climb in retail sales for January.

headline: McCain and Obama Take Their Senatorial Rivalry Into the Presidential Race
text: WAUKESHA, Wis.  Their tempest began well before their bids for a presidential nomination.

headline: Lottery Numbers
When We Torture
text: The most famous journalist you may never have heard of is Sami al-Hajj, an Al Jazeera cameraman who is on a hunger strike to protest abuse during more than six years in a Kafkaesque prison system.

headline: Residential Sales
text: Manhattan

headline: German Bank Receives Its Third Bailout
text: FRANKFURT  The German government said on Wednesday that it would participate in a third bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the lender whose near-collapse in July heralded the arrival in Europe of the crisis stemming from the faltering subprime mortgage market in the United States.

headline: Ambac’s Chief Risk Officer Leaves
text: The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned.

headline: Places to Find Jelena and Little Suzie
text: SOME of the best witch hazels for the Northeast may be ordered from Fairweather Gardens, in Greenwich, N.J. (fairweathergardens.com; 856-451-6261), which offers 25 witch hazels, including Barmstedt Gold, Orange Peel and Wisley Supreme.

headline: There, Amid the Music, a Mind Is on the Edge
text: As befits what is surely New York’s first mainstream musical about manic depression, “Next to Normal,” which opened Wednesday night at the Second Stage Theater, is apt to produce bipolar reactions in anyone who sees it. How could it be otherwise with a show that suggests a hybrid of fractured-family soapers like “Ordinary People” and “The Who’s Tommy,” the 1969 rock opera of illness and noncomformity?

headline: Trying to Capture That iPhone Flair
text: BARCELONA, Spain  The Mobile World Congress brought the cellphone industry together this week to show off the latest and greatest phones.

headline: Nuclear Application Delayed
text: WASHINGTON  Hearings on the first application in 30 years for an operating license for a nuclear reactor have been delayed indefinitely, because the applicant is not ready, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Wednesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Feb. 6 about the addition of Ukraine to the World Trade Organization referred incompletely to the reasons that Georgia, another former Soviet republic and W.T.O. member, opposes Russia’s quest for membership. While Georgian officials have objected to Russian membership in part because Moscow has banned imports of Georgian wine, the republic is also insisting on the removal of Russian customs checkpoints in the separatist territories of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.

headline: For Off Broadway Shows, an Encores!-Like Series
text: The Encores! series at City Center is devoted to “Great American Musicals,” which, in a cavernous, 2,750-seat theater, has pretty much meant Great American Musicals that appeared on Broadway. Thus there’s been no luck, so far at least, for “Little Mary Sunshine,” “Dames at Sea” or, sadly, “Bat Boy.”

headline: What the Next President Will Inherit
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thousands of New Prisoners Overwhelm Iraqi System
text: BAGHDAD  The increase in American troops in Iraq over the past year has been accompanied by waves of new Iraqi detainees, inundating the country’s already overburdened prisons and courts, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Italy: Rome Mayor Resigns to Take on Berlusconi
text: Walter Veltroni resigned as mayor of Rome to focus on his campaign to become Italy’s prime minister in the April national election. Mr. Veltroni, 52, representing the center-left, is running against Silvio Berlusconi, 71, a former prime minister and the country’s richest man, who is representing the conservatives. Recent opinion polls show Mr. Veltroni trails by almost 10 percentage points.

headline: Knocked Off Balance, Clinton Campaign Tries to Regain Its Stride
text: SAN ANTONIO  The Texas and Ohio presidential primaries, on March 4, have become must-win contests for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, her advisers say. So why is she just opening campaign field offices across those states?

headline: Amputee Sprinter Appeals
text: Oscar Pistorius, the double-amputee sprinter who was barred from able-bodied competition in January, is making his final bid to be eligible to qualify for the Olympic Games.

headline: Celebrity and Showmanship on a Soul Food Menu
text: ATLANTA  There is no limit, it seems, to this city’s claim on the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Suddenly, Everyone Hanging Out at the Water Cooler Is a Political Expert
text: WHITE PLAINS  They sound like seasoned political pundits, dissecting delegate counts, comparing speaking styles, conjuring dream tickets and eagerly anticipating the conventions.

headline: Clinton and McCain Jab at Obama, Who Offers Details of His Jobs Program
text: WASHINGTON  As Senators John McCain and Hillary Rodham Clinton accused Senator Barack Obama of using rhetoric that lacks specifics or fails to yield results, Mr. Obama countered on Wednesday by offering a detailed plan to spend $210 billion to create jobs in construction and environmentally friendly fields.

headline: For Clemens, No Joy Found in Testimony
text: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee kept a tight grip on their contradictory accounts of illegal drug use in a dramatic showdown Wednesday before a Congressional panel whose 40 Democrats and Republicans seemed to line up and take sides on a partisan basis.

headline: Poetry and Song to Plumb the Russian Soul’s Depths
text: The day the persecuted Russian poet Joseph Brodsky went into exile, a recording of Mozart’s Divertimento in D (K. 136) was on his record player, according to the program book for the concert by the Chamber Orchestra Kremlin at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening.

headline: The Kidd-to-Mavericks Trade Falls Apart
text: A blockbuster trade that would have sent Jason Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks, further escalating a virtual arms race in the Western Conference, fell apart late Wednesday, leaving confusion all around.

headline: Steve Gerber, Creator of Howard the Duck, Dies at 60
text: Steve Gerber, who created Howard the Duck, the dour, dyspeptic, utterly disagreeable and therefore wildly popular comic-book hero of the 1970s, died on Sunday in Las Vegas. He was 60 and lived in Las Vegas.

headline: The Top Steroids Investigator Is a Silent Presence
text: WASHINGTON  Less than 10 yards away from Roger Clemens on Wednesday was the I.R.S. agent who literally dug through trash to start the government’s investigation into performance-enhancing drugs four and a half years ago and will most likely soon consider what to do about Clemens.

headline: Astronauts Replace Spent Station Tank
text: WASHINGTON  Two spacewalkers, including a German astronaut who was too ill to venture outside the International Space Station earlier this week, replaced a large nitrogen tank on the station on Wednesday.

headline: Fed Chief Leaves Room for More Rate Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said on Thursday that the economic outlook had worsened, and he left room for the central bank to reduce interest rates yet again.

headline: Give a Spreadsheet More Room to Spread Out
text: Fans of devices running Windows Mobile just got a new sidekick. The Redfly from Celio, which looks like a mini-laptop, works with almost any Windows smartphone and provides a better look at data.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Settles Spying Case
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard has agreed to a financial settlement with The New York Times and three BusinessWeek magazine journalists in connection with the company’s spying scandal that stemmed from surreptitiously obtaining private phone records.

headline: Dumb and Dumber: Are Americans Hostile to Knowledge?
text: A popular video on YouTube shows Kellie Pickler, the adorable platinum blonde from “American Idol,” appearing on the Fox game show “Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader?” during celebrity week. Selected from a third-grade geography curriculum, the $25,000 question asked: “Budapest is the capital of what European country?”

headline: A Point-and-Shoot Camera Wrapped in a Suit of Armor
text: Neither rain nor sleet nor controlled drops from a height of 6.6 feet shall deter the Olympus 1030 SW from taking snapshots. This 10-megapixel point-and-shoot camera is waterproof, freezeproof and, interestingly enough, crushproof.

headline: A Long-Running Mystery, the Common Cramp
text: IT can happen for no reason, it seems, taking you completely by surprise. And it can be excruciating. Suddenly, a muscle contracts violently, as if it had been prodded with a jolt of electricity. And it remains balled in a tight knot as painful second after painful second drags on.

headline: Back as a Lad in Arcady, Safe or Sad
text: “The past is a foreign country; they do things differently there.” The British novelist L .P. Hartley was referring to childhood or, more exactly, to the memory of childhood. It’s the foundation of any explored adult consciousness, of course, and particularly that of the poet and often the novelist. It is most particularly true of British writers, who have made a virtual genre of traveling back to that foreign country and treating it as Arcadia.

headline: Bill Curbing Terror Interrogators Is Sent to Bush, Who Has Vowed to Veto It
text: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted Wednesday to ban waterboarding and other harsh interrogation methods that have been used by the Central Intelligence Agency against high-level terrorism suspects. The vote, following House passage of the measure in December, set up a confrontation with President Bush, who has threatened to veto it.

headline: German Executive Faces Tax Inquiry
text: BERLIN  German prosecutors accused one of the country’s most prominent business executives with tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

headline: Tip of the Week: Google’s Keyboard Shortcuts.
text: If you spend too much time pointing and clicking just to read your Gmail on the Web, check out Google’s set of keyboard shortcuts. Log into your Gmail account, click the Settings link and go to the General tab to enable keyboard shortcuts. Click the Learn More link to see a list of what you can do on the keyboard  or just click Save Changes and then type a question mark to see a list pop up on screen. Once you learn them, keyboard shortcuts can save time and mouse work  for example, just type an exclamation mark to tag an open message as spam and remove it from your In box.

headline: Upholding the Standards of Smooth Jazz Purists
text: Have you seen the Wikipedia entry on smooth jazz lately? Probably not, but it’s a mess. The administrators have tagged almost every section with provisos: “Its neutrality is disputed”; “needs additional citations for verification”; “reads like an advertisement”; may contain “unverified claims.”

headline: Time to Vote Contempt
text: Alberto Gonzales may be out, but the country is still waiting for a full accounting of how he and his White House patrons cynically politicized the Justice Department. Congress is rightly asking questions about the actions of yet another United States attorney: New Jersey’s Christopher J. Christie. The House also needs to stop procrastinating and vote to hold witnesses in contempt for refusing to testify in the wider scandal.

headline: What’s the Best Plan for the Hudson River Park?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Politicians Turn Steroid Hearing Into a Partisan Squabble
text: Washington

headline: Malaysia Leader Ends Parliament, Setting Stage for Bitter Contest
text: BANGKOK  Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi of Malaysia dissolved Parliament on Wednesday, paving the way for what is likely to be a rancorous election campaign amid ethnic tensions, scandals in the country’s judiciary and concerns over corruption and rising food prices.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture credit in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about Joel Berger, an expert on moose and other hooved animals, misidentified the newspaper that supplied a photograph of a moose crossing a road. It was The Peninsula Clarion, of Kenai, Alaska  not The Pennsylvania Clarion.

headline: Michelle Obama Thrives in Campaign Trenches
text: CHICAGO  There is no confusing Michelle Obama for her husband on the campaign trail.

headline: Scavenger King of Williamsburg
text: AMONG Williamsburg’s layered streetscapes, where tenements now wear vinyl clapboards in candy colors and the old brick warehouses have been converted to live-work studios for post-post-grunge hipsters or condo lofts for baby investment bankers, it’s hard to miss William Harvey’s handmade house, which fits into none of these categories.

headline: Little Room for Yahoo to Maneuver
text: Can Yahoo avoid being gobbled up by Microsoft?

headline: Venture to Use Sea to Fight Warming Runs Out of Cash
text: Planktos, a California company that is trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, canceled planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds. At the company’s Web site, planktos.com, a notice blamed a “highly effective disinformation campaign” for the cancellation.

headline: Exiled Georgian Opposition Politician Dies Near London at 52
text: MOSCOW  An exiled Georgian tycoon and opposition politician, who had accused the pro-Western Georgian government of tilting toward autocracy and corruption, died unexpectedly Tuesday night at his home outside London, the authorities said.

headline: Obama’s Lead in Delegates Shifts Focus of Campaign
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama emerged from Tuesday’s primaries leading Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton by more than 100 delegates, a small but significant advantage that Democrats said would be difficult for Mrs. Clinton to make up in the remaining contests in the presidential nomination battle.

headline: Notes From a Caucus
text: Once again, we are discovering that our election process works great as long as it doesn’t actually have to decide anything.

headline: Zimbabwe Opponent Criticizes Mbeki
text: JOHANNESBURG  The leader of Zimbabwe’s main opposition party said Wednesday that President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa had failed as a mediator in laying the groundwork for fair elections in Zimbabwe and urged him to show “a little courage” and stop his “quiet support for the dictatorship” of President Robert G. Mugabe.

headline: Oops!
text: The virtuoso instrumentalist and sometime model known as “the David Beckham of the classical violin” couldn’t have done more damage if he had kicked his violin past a goalkeeper. The musician, David Garrett, was leaving the Barbican Center in London after a concert at Christmastime when he fell down a flight of stairs and landed on his violin case. Inside was his 236-year-old Giovanni Battista Guadagnini instrument, known as the San Lorenzo. Mr. Garrett, 26, who was 14 when he became the youngest artist ever signed by Deutsche Grammophon, opened the case. Inside, he told The Independent, the London newspaper: “The violin was in pieces. I couldn’t speak, and I couldn’t get up. I didn’t even know if I was hurt  I didn’t care. I’ve had that violin for eight years. It was like losing a friend.” Repairs will take eight months and cost close to $120,000, and the violin may never sound the same. Mr. Garrett is scheduled to perform a Bruch violin concerto on Thursday night at the Barbican on a borrowed Stradivarius. A three-member security team will be helping him watch his step.

headline: Making (Some) Progress in Iraq
text: Good news is rare in Iraq. But after months of bitter feuding, Iraq’s Parliament has finally approved a budget, outlined the scope of provincial powers, set an Oct. 1 date for provincial elections and voted a general amnesty for detainees.

headline: So, What Were We Writing About Again?
text: LOS ANGELES  Facing his writing staff on Wednesday for the first time since the end of a 100-day strike, Shane Brennan, the co-executive producer of the CBS drama “NCIS,” asked a question that drew blank stares. “Can anyone remember what we were working on three months ago?”

headline: Gionta Revels in Some Open Ice as Devils Finally Solve Senators
text: NEWARK  Yet another tight game dragged into overtime Wednesday, but that turned out to be a good thing for Brian Gionta, the Devils’ energetic right wing. Gionta finally had room to move  and to try a maneuver that would result in a victory.

headline: The Fun Starts Here
text: LIGHTEN up, people. When times are tough, take a cue from Mary Poppins and eat some sugar, or go fly a kite. If that doesn’t put a smile on your face, you might delve a little further into the Disney songbook for inspiration. Think a little more “Zip-a-Dee-Doo-Dah” and less “Oh, Bother.”

headline: Jack Johnson Breaks a Curse
text: After painfully slow sales last month, the music industry finally has a hit: “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire), by Jack Johnson, above, sold 375,000 copies last week  more than six times the sales of the top album the week before  to reach No. 1 on the Billboard chart. It set a record for the most digital sales in a single week, with 139,000 copies, or 37 percent of its total, according to Nielsen SoundScan. In a week busy with high-profile releases, Sheryl Crow’s “Detours” (A&M) opened at No. 2 with 92,000 sales; Lenny Kravitz moved 73,000 copies of “It Is Time for a Love Revolution” (Virgin) to bow at No. 4; and K. D. Lang is No. 8 with her new “Watershed” (Nonesuch), selling 41,000. Last week’s No. 1, Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J), dropped two spots with 80,000. Any sales bumps after last Sunday’s Grammy Awards would be reflected in next week’s chart.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about Senator John McCain’s decision to hire Mercer Reynolds, one of President Bush’s major fund-raisers, misstated the position of Senator Barack Obama on using public financing for the general election. Although the Obama campaign has been raising private contributions for that election, Mr. Obama is still open to returning those contributions and abiding by the limits of the public financing system if the Republican nominee agrees to do the same. Mr. Obama has not definitively ruled out using public financing.

headline: Tension and Horror at the End of a Dark Hall
text: While I have tried, I find it impossible to play video games 24 hours a day, and must often stop because I am hungry, or tired, or my hands hurt or my head aches.

headline: Working in Mental Health, the Prospect of Violence Is a Part of the Job
text: Therapists  psychiatrists, psychotherapists, psychiatric social workers and other mental health professionals  are as much part of the New York landscape as hot dog vendors. And they have discovered, sometimes the hard way, that delving deeply into people’s feelings can be dangerous.

headline: Kon Ichikawa, Japanese Film Director, Dies at 92
text: Kon Ichikawa, the Japanese film director whose versatility ranged beyond his well-known antiwar dramas like “The Burmese Harp” and “Fires on the Plain” to comedies, documentaries and literary adaptations, died on Wednesday in Tokyo. He was 92.

headline: Do As I Do?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: A Light Show in a Bulb
text: Adding mood lighting to a space-age bachelor pad is easy with this five-watt L.E.D. bulb from ThinkGeek (www.thinkgeek.com) that comes with its own remote control.

headline: Mortals Amid the Immortals, Savoring the Romance of Art
text: On a recent cold and rainy Friday night, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s lobby was warm and inviting. Blossoms from quince branches arranged in giant urns with pussy willows shed their pale pink petals as couples, some on blind dates, arrived to meet.

headline: Scientists Find Solar System Like Ours
text: Astronomers say they have found a miniature version of our own solar system 5,000 light years across the galaxy  the first planetary system that really looks like our own, with outer giant planets and room for smaller inner planets.

headline: A Band That Cradles Its Rock, Even Under All Those Layers of Expectations
text: Yannis Philippakis, lead singer of the emerging British band Foals, spent most of Tuesday night with both his hands on his chest. He wasn’t being shy; he was playing the guitar. Like the bass player and the other guitarist, he wore a short strap, so the instrument was almost under his chin. And like them, he worked high on the fretboard, peeling off nimble riffs without ever uncrooking his arm.

headline: 2 Sue to Void Ban on Same-Sex Marriage
text: DENVER  A lesbian couple from nearby Englewood are seeking to overturn Colorado’s constitutional ban on same-sex marriage, in what is thought to be the first challenge to the 2006 ballot initiative that established it.

headline: Beautiful Models, Hairy Legs and All
text: NOW that Uno, the 15-inch beagle, has captured the crown, becoming the first of his breed to win best in show at the Westminster Kennel Club dog show, and now that more than 2,600 other canine competitors have been leashed and crated and hauled home to familiar kennels and sofas, it seems fitting to consider an overlooked aspect of this crowd-pleasing sport: the strange collision of fashion and dog shows.

headline: Viewing Old Photographs and Picturing the Stories
text: The choreographer Ronald K. Brown is something of an archaeologist. In his dances  poetic structures of great subtlety and force  there is the sense of a singular artist digging for a forgotten treasure. The qualities he holds dear are those that current society tends to ignore: legacy, tradition, heritage, gratitude and obligation. Yet Mr. Brown obstinately marches along his own path and, in doing so, conjures portraits of modern folklore.

headline: Exports Help Narrow Trade Gap
text: The United States trade deficit shrank in 2007 for the first time in five years, buoyed by a surge in exports that has helped domestic businesses stay afloat as the domestic economy flags.

headline: Parent Shock: Children Are Not Décor
text: WHEN Jacqueline Brown and her husband, Gavin Friedman, were in their early 30s, they lived in a condominium in Santa Monica, Calif., with a black leather Ikea couch Mr. Friedman had bought for law school, a few modest pieces from Pier 1 Imports and assorted hand-me-down furnishings. Within a few years, though, having acquired professional and financial stability  both were litigation associates at prominent law firms  they bought a house in Cheviot Hills, an affluent neighborhood in West Los Angeles, and began remodeling and decorating.

headline: Deal to Sell Clear Channel for $19 Billion Is Approved
text: The $19.5 billion sale of Clear Channel Communications to two private-equity firms cleared its final regulatory hurdle Wednesday with approval by the Justice Department’s antitrust division.

headline: Road Distractions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Footnotes
text: Michael S. Harper, a professor of English at Brown University and the first poet laureate of Rhode Island, has been named the recipient of the 2008 Frost Medal of the Poetry Society of America. The honor, recognizing distinguished lifetime service to American poetry, will be bestowed on April 21 at the society’s 98th annual awards ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York. ... The rapper Lil Wayne, right, has been indicted on felony drug and weapons charges by a grand jury in Yuma, Ariz., The Associated Press reported. Lil Wayne, 25, whose real name is Dwayne Michael Carter Jr., pleaded not guilty when arraigned on Friday. His lawyer, James Tilson, said on Tuesday that Lil Wayne’s tour would continue as scheduled. He is next due in court on March 7.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: On Design

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,952 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: A House Divided by Old Magic and New Residents
text: Every devoted reader of children’s literature knows that magic is difficult  for the young wizards who practice it, of course, but even more so for their would-be creators, who must compete in an ever more crowded field. Bookstore shelves are full of spells and sorcery, and so, these days, are multiplexes, as filmmakers take advantage of special-effects technology to bring literary enchantments to life.

headline: A Festival With Plenty of This, That and the Other
text: Boundaries of geography, genre and taste are tested and occasionally trampled in the ninth edition of Film Comment Selects, the annual cinema roundup from the editors of Film Comment magazine, which runs through Feb. 28 at the Walter Reade Theater. Such border crossings are common inside the pages of Film Comment, a citadel of intellectually committed, aesthetically adventurous, sometimes prickly, sometimes maddening, sometimes baffling, if invariably lively and passionate cinephilia that is published bimonthly by the Film Society of Lincoln Center. You may want to throw the magazine against the wall on occasion, but it remains essential reading.

headline: Agency Sued Over Death of Firefighter at Tower
text: The sister of one of the two firefighters killed in August fighting a fire at the former Deutsche Bank building sued the government agency that owns the building and several contractors on Wednesday, charging they knowingly created dangerous conditions that led to her brother’s death.

headline: The Sensation of Flight, on Terra Firma
text: Flight simulation programs can feel a little earthbound when played at a desk, but a new gaming chassis gets the whole body into the experience.

headline: Time-Space Continuum? No Big Deal. And the Swag...
text: It’s impossible for outsiders to know who deserves most of the blame for this dud  its director, Doug Liman, its three screenwriters, its multiple producers or the various studio executives who might have done far too much meddling or not nearly enough. Whatever the case, “Jumper”  a barely coherent genre mishmash about a guy who transports himself across the globe at will  is of interest only because it revisits a theme that Mr. Liman has explored in films like “The Bourne Identity” and, if reports about his troubled productions are true, speaks to his own reputation as an escape artist: the character who wiggles out of trouble.

headline: Daily News to Have Color for All Pages
text: The Daily News said Wednesday that it would become the first major newspaper in the country capable of printing full color on every page, a move to attract readers and advertisers in the fierce competition among New York’s tabloids.

headline: Thomas Gets a Head Start on the All-Star Break
text: BOSTON  Isiah Thomas was ejected for reasons he could not surmise from a defeat that he could not explain, and the Knicks trudged into the All-Star break as dizzy and disoriented as they have ever been.

headline: Social Equality Comes With a Beat, Again
text: “Step Up 2 the Streets” is an earnest sequel to the 2006 cornball musical drama “Step Up,” mixing new characters into the original’s setting, the neighborhoods surrounding the Maryland School of the Arts in Baltimore.

headline: Police Talk to Man About Therapist’s Killing
text: A law enforcement official said that detectives from New York City interviewed a man in Bethlehem, Pa., in connection with the killing of a psychologist in Manhattan on Tuesday.

headline: Ending Impasse, Iraq Parliament Backs Measures
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s parliamentary leaders on Wednesday pushed through three far-reaching measures that had been delayed for weeks by bitter political maneuvering that became so acrimonious that some lawmakers threatened to try to dissolve the legislative body.

headline: Preventing Plump: Start Young
text: Want your teenager to be trim as an adult? Give in to the whining and buy that skateboard he craves. That's the message of a major longitudinal study of adolescence and weight gain published last month in the journal Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine. In the study, led by researchers at Johns Hopkins University, 3,345 adolescents were asked about their daily physical activities, both in physical education classes and on their own. The kids reported their weights, which were used to calculate theirbody mass indexes. Most -- 72 percent -- were average weight or below.

headline: Witness in Absentia Appears in Words
text: Well before the Congressional hearing Wednesday, Andy Pettitte was viewed as being the most critical witness because he had acknowledged that the Mitchell report was correct about him, that Brian McNamee had injected him with human growth hormone in 2002.

headline: Protest Group Assails Eli Broad Art
text: The Guerrilla Girls, a group that protests what it calls “sexism and racism in politics, the art world, film and the culture at large,” sent an open letter to the philanthropist Eli Broad saying that female and minority artists are inadequately represented in the exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Mr. Broad’s private foundation. In a posting on the group’s Web site, guerrillagirls.com, the organization claims that of the 30 artists in the inaugural exhibition at the Broad Museum, 97 percent are white and 87 percent are male. Similarly, the group says that of the 194 artists in the collection of the Broad Foundation, the nonprofit organization that acts as a “lending library” for Mr. Broad’s art holdings, 96 percent are white and 83 percent are male. That, the group said, is “an insignificant number of women and artists of color.” Contacted about the statement, a spokeswoman for Mr. Broad and his art foundation, Karen Denne, said by e-mail: “Women are prominently featured in the opening installation at BCAM, which was curated by Lacma. In fact, 33 percent of the works in the exhibit are by women. One of the largest galleries at BCAM is devoted to Cindy Sherman, whose works the Broads have collected since 1981.’' Ms. Denne added, “Artwork with a strong social and political perspective has always been important to the Broads and to their collecting.” She said that 33 percent of the 43 artists added to the foundation’s collection since 1995 were women .

headline: A Strong Field in Boston
text: Lidiya Grigoryeva of Russia, who won the Boston Marathon women’s race last year, and Rita Jeptoo of Kenya, who won the year before, will compete April 21 in the 112th running of the event. Marathon officials also announced that Jelena Prokopcuka of Latvia, the runner-up the last two years, would be back. The women’s field will include three young Ethiopians: Askale Tafa Magarsa, 23, who won in Paris and Dubai last year; Dire Tune, 22, the Houston winner last year and this year; and Robe Tola Guta, 21, who won in Hamburg, Germany, two years ago. Other entries include Tetyana Kuzina-Hladyr of Ukraine, Magdaline Chemjor of Kenya, Alevtina Biktimirova of Russia and Bruna Genovese of Italy.The best American women will race on a different course the day before in the United States Olympic trials.

headline: Relying on New Jersey Roads, and Fearing Higher Tolls
text: DAYTON, N.J.  Up and down the New Jersey Turnpike, warehouse managers like Ray O’Brien are bracing for the worst.

headline: House Cites 2 Bush Aides for Contempt
text: WASHINGTON  The House voted Thursday to issue contempt citations against the White House chief of staff and a former White House counsel for refusing to cooperate in an investigation into the mass firings of federal prosecutors.

headline: Cone Denies Telling McNamee Owners Opposed Testing
text: TAMPA, Fla.  David Cone was casually monitoring the Congressional hearings featuring Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee from his home in Stamford, Conn. After he left the room for a few minutes, he said he was surprised when he heard his name mentioned on television.

headline: Clean Power Incentives
text: To the Editor:

headline: Surprise Twist Ends Old Homicide Case: Cocaine, Not Mother, Killed Girl
text: BUFFALO  Since 1993, prosecutors and defense lawyers have argued over who killed Crystallynn Girard, a 13-year-old girl who was found dead in her bedroom here exactly 15 years ago.

headline: Where Lincoln Sought Refuge in His Dark Hours
text: WASHINGTON  If you look out the windows of President Lincoln’s Cottage at the Soldiers’ Home  the idiosyncratic and intriguing museum that is opening to the public on Tuesday after a ceremonial event on Monday  you have to imagine what Abraham Lincoln might have seen during those summer evenings when he stood here. The cottage is on a hilltop, the third highest in the area. And when Lincoln first came here, seeking a respite from the summer heat, the swampy air and the incessant bustle of the White House, he could have looked out over the expanding city below him, with the unfinished Washington Monument and incomplete Capitol dome rising in the distance.

headline: City Council Approves a Bill Requiring Residents to Recycle Electronics
text: New York City is a step closer to adopting one of the toughest electronics recycling laws in the nation, despite strong objections from manufacturers and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: So Is That Like an A?
text: Time was that a fifth grader’s greatest concern about gym was whether he or she would be picked last for the kickball team. Now, in schools in Hartford, that 10-year-old would-be athlete is being graded on how he or she “establishes and maintains a healthy lifestyle by avoiding risk-taking behavior.” In music class, students are being graded on how they make “connections between music and other disciplines through evaluation and analysis of compositions and performances.” That is pretty far from just trying to sing “Yankee Doodle” on key.

headline: New York Times Plans to Cut 100 Newsroom Jobs
text: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain and eliminate about 100 newsroom jobs this year, the executive editor said Thursday.

headline: How I Met Your Mother: A History Lesson in Love
text: “Definitely, Maybe,” a nimble and winning little romance written and directed by Adam Brooks, begins with one of those awkward Important Talks that parents are sometimes required to have with their children. In this case Maya Hayes (Abigail Breslin) needs some debriefing after a sex education class at her Manhattan elementary school. She’s acquired some technical vocabulary but not a lot of context, and so it falls to her dad, Will (Ryan Reynolds), to do the necessary explaining.

headline: The Power to Say No
text: In recent weeks, the federal Forest Service awarded a British company the right to explore for uranium on 39 separate sites on national forest land just outside Grand Canyon National Park, less than three miles from a popular lookout over the canyon’s southern rim.

headline: U-Turn or Bump in the Road?
text: Do you think Roger Clemens's testimony at Wednesday's Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?

headline: Hollywood Produces for Idol
text: “Hollywood Week” on “American Idol” had a promising start on Tuesday as a two-hour edition of that Fox talent competition trounced its competitors in the ratings, drawing 29.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. Although Tuesday’s “Idol” audience grew by 2 million compared with last week’s, the first installment of “Hollywood Week” last year attracted 31.2 million viewers. Trailing far behind Fox in the night’s ratings, CBS drew the second most viewers, earning a solid 11.7 million at 8 p.m. for a rerun of “NCIS.” Later in the night, however, a more modest 7.3 million viewers tuned in at 9 for the premiere of “Big Brother: ’Til Death Do You Part,” the first winter edition of that CBS summer mainstay. At 10 the second season debut of “Jericho” attracted 7.2 million viewers, tying ABC’s “Boston Legal,” but trailing a repeat of NBC’s “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (8.3 million). NBC finished third for the night while edging past CBS for second place among adults 18 to 49 thanks to “The Biggest Loser,” from 8 to 10 (7.5 million). ABC was a distant fourth overall.

headline: Resolution on Prayer Is Approved
text: Conservative Judaism’s international assembly of rabbis voted Tuesday to approve a resolution criticizing Pope Benedict XVI’s revision of a Latin Good Friday prayer. The prayer calls for God to enlighten the hearts of Jews “so that they may acknowledge Jesus Christ, the savior of all men.” The resolution adopted by the rabbis said the prayer could set back Jewish-Catholic relations. Most Catholics worship in the vernacular, and their prayers will not be affected.

headline: If You Can’t Let Go, Twitter
text: SOMETIMES, you just have to trust your relatives. You have to be willing to let them leave the house unchallenged. Suspend disbelief and let them take the car.

headline: Lessons From the Intersection of Children and High Design
text: PARENTS Tracy McArdle Brady, 39, and Nathaniel Brady, 40, Carlisle, Mass.

headline: Dog Running: Easier Does It
text: FOR those who run with their dogs, trying to stay fleet of foot with a dog on a leash can be an exercise in futility. While the two-legged jogger aims for an even pace, the four-legged set sniffs, pulls, doubles back and dashes forward, yanking the shoulder socket. Regular leashes can also cause gait problems for serious runners, said Kelly Liljeblad, a dog owner and marathoner from Boulder, Colo. “If you run with the leash in the left hand, you’ll naturally bend to the left,” she explained.

headline: Moving Outlook: Mail to a Mac
text: Q. I am thinking of buying a MacBook to replace my Windows laptop. Is there a way to move the Microsoft Outlook file (e-mails, contacts and calendars) between a PC and a Mac?

headline: Chug-a-Lugging Aphrodisiacs
text: GRAVITY shifted the items in my dish rack the other day, making the blade of one of my better knives suddenly slide its entire length along the stem of a wet wineglass. It gave me goose bumps, it was such an unexpectedly erotic sound; the kind of foley you’d hear if Liliana Cavani (“The Night Porter”) directed a Batman movie: Zing!

headline: A Little Piece of Microsoft Aids Small Business
text: So Microsoft is making a hostile bid for Yahoo.

headline: This Is as Good as It Gets, Paws Down
text: When a dog trots around a show ring, what is he thinking?

headline: Inquiry Set on Health Care Billing
text: It is a common medical puzzler. The benefits statement arrives from the insurance company, saying that although the doctor has charged, say, $200 for that recent office visit, only $80 is covered  and the consumer is obliged to pick up the balance.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. Where can I find lightweight draperies that will block out the light?

headline: Primitive Bats Took to the Wing, but They Didn’t Have That Ping
text: The most primitive bat ever discovered could fly but not navigate by sound, scientists reported Thursday.

headline: Panama Releases Report on ’06 Poisoning
text: Panamanian investigators have concluded that at least 174 people were poisoned, 115 of them fatally, by counterfeit cold medicine linked to an unlicensed Chinese chemical plant.

headline: Barber, Bernstein and Other Heroes of U.S. History
text: Isn’t it odd how Lincoln Center’s constituent musical organizations present programs that should be the norm for 21st-century ensembles, but try to make them seem special or unusual by giving them names or calling them festivals? The New York Philharmonic has long done this with its Composer Focus programs, which rarely amount to more than a few of a contemporary composer’s works spread through a season. Behold the triumph of marketing as a substitute for creative programming.

headline: Defense Lawyer Casts Doubt on Timeline in Broker’s Killing
text: The Fifth Avenue real estate broker Linda Stein might have been “alive and well” for at least 45 minutes after the personal assistant who is accused of killing her left her apartment, the assistant’s lawyer contends in court papers that were filed on Wednesday.

headline: Chinese Factory Linked to Drug Under Inquiry in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  A Chinese factory that has not been inspected by the Food and Drug Administration is the source for the active ingredient of a critical blood-thinning drug whose production was suspended this week after 350 patients reported ill effects from it.

headline: UBS Posts Loss on Big Write-Down
text: PARIS  UBS offered no hope for a near-term turnaround in its business after it posted a huge fourth-quarter loss on Thursday and warned that 2008 would be a difficult year.

headline: Quite a Show, Offering Something New
text: Roger Clemens has starred in three major TV performances this year: a “60 Minutes” interview with Mike Wallace; a news conference in which he stormed out; and his testimony to the House oversight committee on Wednesday in which he continued to deny using human growth hormone or steroids, as alleged by his former personal trainer Brian McNamee.

headline: Why, Beethoven, You’ve Gone Mahlerian
text: Gustav Mahler’s orchestral transcription of Beethoven’s Opus 95 String Quartet suggests that inside every thin man is a fat one trying to get out. Such urges for physical change are usually practical ones; artistic advantage tends to be accidental.

headline: Correction: Reigning Trowel in a Kingdom of Orchids
text: An article last Thursday about Robert Fuchs, an orchid grower in Florida, gave an incorrect name for his nursery. It is R.F. Orchids, not R.H. Orchids.

headline: The Frosty Reality of Spring Training
text: Tampa, Fla.

headline: Garbage Truck Driver Charged in Crash That Killed Two Tourists
text: A New Jersey garbage truck driver was charged with manslaughter on Wednesday after a truck he was driving in Manhattan on Tuesday veered out of control, jumped a curb and killed two tourists from England, the police said.

headline: Yes, It’s Valentine’s Day, and Yes, France’s First Lady Is in Love
text: PARIS  In her first interview since she married President Nicolas Sarkozy, the model-turned-singer Carla Bruni said that they had fallen in love immediately and that only death would part them.

headline: Testy Moments Are Fueled by Nanny
text: WASHINGTON  Amid testimony regarding Roger Clemens, his former trainer, syringes and steroids, some of the most dramatic and heated moments in Wednesday’s House Oversight Committee hearing centered on a nanny, a barbecue, and suggestions of witness tampering.

headline: Larger Share of Students Succeed on A.P. Tests
text: A higher percentage of students in public high schools are taking and passing Advanced Placement exams, according to a report issued Wednesday by the College Board. The gap between the performance of black and white students, however, remains large.

headline: Limiting Power on a Shared PC
text: Q. What’s the difference between sharing a PC on an Administrator user account and a Limited user account? Is there any advantage to using one over the other?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about the theft of four masterwork paintings valued at $163 million from a Zurich gallery misspelled the name of the French village in the title of one painting, an 1879 Monet. It is “Poppies Near Vétheuil,” not Vertheuil.

headline: Lawmakers Put Out New Call for Earmarks
text: WASHINGTON  The window for Congressional earmarks is open once again. Lawmakers from both parties are inviting constituents and lobbyists to recommend pet projects that could be financed by the federal government as the 2008 earmark season gets under way.

headline: Big Selling Point for G.M. Tower: Naming Rights
text: What’s in a name? Tens of millions of dollars, the owner of the General Motors Building hopes.

headline: Mexico Human Rights Agency Called Ineffective
text: MEXICO CITY  There is a common saying in Mexico about police investigations and government inquiries that goes “no pasa nada,” or “nothing happens.”

headline: Oscar Night Starting to Seem Like Another Super Bowl
text: SPONSORS of the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on Feb. 24 are deciding that the show is no country for old ads.

headline: Flowing and Intricate, With a Toe in Many Styles
text: The pianist Edward Simon reconciles a few different agendas in his music, borrowing judiciously from classical impressionism, post-bop modality and the folk music of his native Venezuela. He’s careful with his calibration of these and other influences, but the effort doesn’t feel belabored. In his first set on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, his debut there as a leader, he projected flowing ease along with a canny sense of drama.

headline: Ruling on Fortunoff Sale
text: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware won court approval on Wednesday to sell its business for $80 million in cash to the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners, barring higher offers at auction.

headline: Harvard Research to Be Free Online
text: Harvard University will soon begin posting research and articles produced by its faculty on the Internet free of charge. On Tuesday the arts and sciences faculty voted overwhelmingly in favor of a resolution that would commit Harvard to open access  the movement to speed the exchange of knowledge by freely distributing research on the Web. “The chorus of ‘yeas’ was thunderous,” Robert Darnton, the director of the University Library, wrote in an e-mail message. “I hope this marks a turning point in the way communications operate in the world of scholarship.” The library will oversee an Office of Scholarly Communication, which is being created to handle the project. Professor Darnton said a Web site instructing the faculty on how to transmit articles is already up and running, and the technical work should be completed by April 1. Meanwhile open access took another step forward on Wednesday when Fastcase inaugurated the Public Library of Law (www.plol.org), a free online legal research site.

headline: Winter’s Cheerleader, Yelling for Spring
text: SUNNY, warm days in midwinter always send me in search of fragrant witch hazels, those graceful shrubs that unfurl their crinkled, confetti-like flowers from January to March.

headline: A Deep Injection of Righteous Hysteria
text: Last week, a famous pitcher likely bound for the Hall of Fame was reportedly injected with a steroid in an effort to prolong his career. This news, however, was not greeted with any widespread clutching of pearls. There were no calls for Congressional meddling and no inquiries about any palpable growths on his hindquarters. There was no talk, either, of the sanctity of the record books, and no earnest invocations of The Children, those poor souls sent down a wayward path because Nook Logan might've dabbled with growth hormone. In fact, it was all perfectly legal. The pitcher's injection, according to the Boston Globe, was part of a "conservative treatment plan" laid out by his team's medical staff. The headline: "Schilling receives shot of cortisone."

headline: A Struggle to Steal a Fur or Two
text: MILLBURN, N.J.  Perhaps the four thieves were not aware of the valet service available at The Mall at Short Hills.

headline: Interpreter Freed, but CBS Journalist Still Held
text: BAGHDAD  An Iraqi interpreter kidnapped in the southern city of Basra was freed Wednesday, but the CBS journalist seized with him this week was still being held.

headline: Back to Work
text: Playwright and television writer Diana Son goes back to work after the  Writers Guild of America ended its three-month-long strike.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Notes From a Caucus
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 14 column.

headline: After the Big Dig
text: With the $15 billion construction project officially over, the promised transformation of downtown Boston finally seems within reach.

headline: We Can’t Wait for the Video
text: This comes from Craig Custance of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution at Thrashers Blog via the ubiquitous Kukla’s Korner.

headline: Chinese Retailer Said to Bring HSBC and UBS on Board for I.P.O.
text: A Chinese department store operator, Maoye International Holdings, has hired two more investment banks to underwrite its postponed Hong Kong initial public offering, according to Dow Jones.

headline: S.E.C. to Ease Rules for Foreign-Share Registrations
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission may free some foreign companies from the agency’s oversight as long as they make financial disclosures widely available to investors over the Internet.

headline: S.E.C. Asks Money Managers to Post Full Details on Web
text: Money managers in the United States would have to provide online brochures describing their services, fees, investment performance and potential conflicts of interest under a proposal approved Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: German Bank Receives Its Third Bailout
text: The German government said on Wednesday that it would participate in a third bailout of IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the lender whose near-collapse in July heralded the arrival in Europe of the crisis stemming from the faltering subprime mortgage market in the United States.

headline: Commerzbank Takes $1.2 Billion Hit from Subprime
text: Commerzbank‘s bill from the subprime crisis crept up towards 800 million euros ($1.2 billion) in 2007 but the bank still managed a record profit for the year as bad debt provisions fell.

headline: AstraZeneca Spins Off Gastrointestinal Unit
text: AstraZeneca said Thursday it is spinning off its Swedish gastrointestinal research operations into a new company called Albireo, backed by a consortium of investment firms led by Nomura Phase4 Ventures.

headline: Air France to Buy Stake in Merged Delta-Northwest, Report Says
text: The Air France-KLM Group, Europe’s biggest airline, plans to invest in a combined Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines carrier, according to news reports.

headline: Intel Takes Up Bragster’s Dare
text: Bragster, a London-based site “for dares and social bets,” announced Wednesday that it had secured $3.5 million in Series A venture cash. The funding round was led by none other than Intel Capital, Intel’s investment branch.

headline: Investors Take Ellen Tracy Off Liz Claiborne’s Rack
text: A group of investors have agreed to try on Ellen Tracy for size.

headline: Judge Approves $80 Million Auction of Fortunoff
text: Fortunoff Fine Jewelry and Silverware won court approval on Wednesday to sell its business for $80 million to the private equity firm NRDC Equity Partners, barring higher offers at auction.

headline: Ambac’s Chief Risk Officer Leaves
text: The Ambac Financial Group, a bond insurer, said Wednesday that its chief risk officer had resigned. The executive, William T. McKinnon, left on Feb. 8, the company said in a regulatory filing.

headline: As Profits Rise, Rio Again Rebuffs BHP
text: Rio Tinto again rebuffed a hostile takeover bid by its larger rival, BHP Billiton, saying that there was “clear water” between BHP’s sweetened $147 billion bid and its fair value.

headline: Madison Dearborn: When Nice Doesn’t Finish Last
text: It could be argued that the maxim “nice guys finish last” was created with private equity titans in mind. The industry is littered with tales of cutthroat buyout competitions. The rivalry between Blackstone‘s chief, Stephen A. Schwarzman, and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, chieftain, Henry R. Kravis, alone has been been the subject of oceans of spilled ink.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Settles Spying Case
text: Hewlett-Packard has agreed to a financial settlement with The New York Times and three BusinessWeek magazine journalists in connection with the company’s spying scandal that stemmed from surreptitiously obtaining private phone records.

headline: NBC’s Silverman Sells Production Company to Shine
text: NBC Entertainment’s co-chairman, Ben Silverman, on Wednesday sold his television production company, Reveille, to London-based Shine, owned by the media baron Rupert Murdoch’s daughter Elisabeth, for $125 million.

headline: Banks Seek Government Help for Mortgages, Report Says
text: The banking industry is proposing to members of Congress and the White House that some of the risk of troubled mortgages should be shifted to the federal government, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Plankton-Seeding Venture Runs Out of Funds
text: Planktos, a California company that is trying to turn a profit by fertilizing the ocean with iron dust, canceled planned field tests on Wednesday, citing a lack of funds, The New York Times reported. At the company’s Web site, planktos.com, a notice blamed a “highly effective disinformation campaign” for the cancellation.

headline: Restricted Stock May Flood Market When Rules Take Effect
text: On Friday, billions of dollars in restricted stock will become eligible for trading on the open market as new Securities and Exchange Commission rules take effect.

headline: Harbinger Capital Raises Calpine Stake
text: Could a sale be in the future for the California power company Calpine?

headline: No Bad News for British Bankers’ Bonuses
text: Bonuses for 2007 rose or were unchanged for 80 percent of London’s financial-services employees as a second-half market slump failed to bite until this year, Bloomberg News reported, citing British recruitment company Morgan McKinsley.

headline: ‘Give Each Other the Mitten’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Justice Dept. Approves Clear Channel Deal
text: The $19.5 billion sale of Clear Channel Communications to two private-equity firms cleared its final regulatory hurdle Wednesday with approval by the Justice Department’s antitrust division.

headline: MBIA to Call on Congress to Rein in Ackman
text: MBIA, the world’s biggest bond insurer, is planning to hit back at the hedge fund heavy William A. Ackman, who has long been betting against the insurers’ shares.

headline: Freescale Names a New Chief Executive
text: Freescale Semiconductor, the chipmaker that was acquired by a group of private equity firms in 2006, named Rich Beyer as its new chief executive on Wednesday. Mr. Beyer was most recently the chairman and chief executive of Intersil, another semiconductor company.

headline: Little Room for Yahoo to Maneuver
text: Can Yahoo avoid being gobbled up by Microsoft? Many analysts say it is increasingly unlikely.

headline: Solutia Seeks to Depose Citi’s Pandit in Financing Suit
text: Solutia, a bankrupt chemical company, won’t be sending any Valentine Day’s goodies to Citigroup‘s chief executive, Vikram Pandit, but it will head to a Manhattan court on Thursday to try to persuade a judge to allow it to depose him.

headline: ‘Say It! Say It! Or We’ll Leave Again’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Big news for us, the writers’ strike is finally over and I just want to say personally it’s great to have them back. In fact, they wrote that. That was the first thing they wrote. “Say it! Say it! Or we’ll leave again.”

headline: Football Isn’t Held to the Same Standard (It Is What It Is)
text: Why does football get a pass?

headline: … And Speaking of Not Wearing Pants
text: Today’s obituary page notes the passing of Steve Gerber, who created Howard the Duck, the dour, dyspeptic, utterly disagreeable and therefore wildly popular comic-book hero of the 1970s (too bad the movie was a bomb). But folks at Disney were not among Howard’s fans, as the obit notes:

headline: For Your Next PowerPoint Presentation
text: Found at Mental Floss, which notes that:

headline: Looking for Passion, at Work
text: Whenever I write about finding passion in our careers, the naysayers show up to say that passion really doesn’t belong at work. So in honor of Valentine’s Day, I ask why was this advertisement one of the most popular videos on YouTube a week after it aired on the Super Bowl? Is it just a case of clever ad copy and animation? Or is it that people really do want something resembling passion in their careers? Either way, enjoy it if you haven’t yet seen it.

headline: I should count myself lucky
text: I get some pretty harsh comments. But they’re nothing like what I used to get when criticizing Dear Leader, back when he had an 80% approval rating, and — this is new to me — nothing like the comments people leave on financial blogs when they say a good word about short-sellers.

headline: Cocktail Art
text: The Bagger visited the preview Oscar luncheon in New York at the Carlyle Hotel where the chef came up with a plate to mirror each movie. There will be video of this momentous event, but in the meantime, Grub Street conjured a list of drinkables to match the nominees, including:

headline: UBS Expects ‘Another Difficult Year’
text: Shares of UBS, the Swiss bank, fell in Europe on Thursday after it confirmed its previous warning of a big fourth-quarter loss and said it expects 2008 to be “another difficult year.” The bank also revealed $26.6 billion in exposure to risky United States mortgages distinct from the now-infamous subprime loans, increasing its vulnerability to the global credit crisis.

headline: “Clayton” May Have One More Twist
text: The Spidey sense of Scott Feinberg, who follows the race closer than most, is tingling. He says that “Michael Clayton” is “surging across the board,” perhaps even “threatening Day-Lewis and Bardem.” Tilda Swinton is on a roll as well, according to Pete Hammond.

headline: Some Ripples in the Pool
text: Some of you have already started filling in your ballots for the Oscar pool, beginning with the easy ones, like Diablo Cody for original screenplay. Sasha Stones takes a hard look and smells a rat than might sneak up on her.

headline: Cheesy Theme Post
text: This being Valentine’s Day, the Bagger has to have a Hallmark moment and salute some of the great romances in the year’s movies.

headline: Wonky Enough
text: The New Republic’s Jonathan Chait tries to arbitrate the campaign dispute over whether Barack Obama has a firm enough grasp on policy matters to be president. “Well, it’s certainly true that Obama can’t match Hillary Clinton’s grasp of policy detail,” Chait writes at The Plank, his magazine’s staff blog. “Clinton is a true policy wonk.” He continues:

headline: Renewals on NBC: ‘Heroes,’ ‘Chuck,’ ‘Life’
text: The NBC dramas “Heroes,” “Chuck,” and “Life” will return for the next television season, the network said Wednesday.

headline: How Goodman Global’s Deal Got Done
text: Did you hear that sound Wednesday? It was a big sigh of relief among the arbitrage community as the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman completed its acquisition of Goodman Global.

headline: Waterboarding Not Legal Now, Justice Dept. Lawyer Says
text: Updated

headline: The Early Word: The Count
text: No matter which way you calculate the delegate count, that score is dictating the shape of the Democratic race these days.

headline: A self-reinforcing cycle of anxiety
text: Things are proceeding more slowly that I sort-of-but-didn’t-really predicted. But current events — in which every week or two some important market you never heard of seems to collapse — bear at least a family resemblance to the scenario I laid out a year ago.

headline: A Manhunt for Killer of Psychologist
text: The top story of the day is the police search for a man who fatally stabbed a psychologist, Kathryn Faughey, then attacked a psychiatrist, Kent D. Shinbach, in a medical office on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The man — described as middle-aged, with a black cap and sneakers — came in from the freezing rain, toting two pieces of black luggage and saying he was there to see Dr. Shinbach. But Dr. Shinbach had another patient, a woman, waiting for him, so the man sat on a couch and made small talk. Then he disappeared into the office of the other doctor, Kathryn Faughey, and stabbed her in the head, face and chest. Hearing her screams, Dr. Shinbach rushed in and saw her lying still and bleeding on the tan carpet by her desk.

headline: Buen Dia, Dakar Rally
text: So the Dakar Rally is moving to South America. Whether it will continue to be called the Dakar Rally is still up in the air, in part because the event’s organizers are holding out hope that the 30-year-old cross-continent rally might someday return to its Lisbon-Dakar route.

headline: Hooking Up on Valentine’s Day
text: It’s that time of the year when velvet boxes get opened — perhaps with some candlelight and a fancy dinner, just to seal the deal — and the question gets popped. In recent days, some were expecting that even Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines might feel the romance and choose Valentine’s Day to announce a merger agreement. Frank Boroch, an analyst at Bear Stearns, suggested last week that a Feb. 14 merger announcement would play up the friendly aspects of any proposal, as opposed to the ugly situation with Delta’s previous suitor, an unabashedly hostile (and ultimately unsuccessful) US Airways.

headline: U-Turn or Bump in the Road?
text: Do you think Roger Clemens’s testimony at Wednesday’s Congressional hearing will alter his path to the Hall of Fame? Should it?

headline: CSX Rebuffs TCI’s Demands for Special Meetings
text: There’s no love lost between CSX, the railroad operator, and The Children’s Investment Fund, the hedge fund battling for seats at the company.

headline: Sell Stocks, Buy Flowers
text: Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poor’s reports that St. Valentine’s Day tends to be a poor day in the stock market, with the S.&P. 500 rising only 39 percent of the time, and fallling 57 percent of the time.

headline: Creator of ’24’ Calls It Quits
text: Joel Surnow, the creator of “24,” is clocking out.

headline: A Soul Man
text: Shaila Dewan has a great piece today about the Soul Food Museum, which had an official opening of sorts in Atlanta yesterday. The museum is the creation of Kenneth Willhoite, whose expansive vision of soul food can accommodate both Smokey Robinson’s seafood gumbo mix (“The Soul is in the Bowl”) and Lucille Ball’s Predic-a-mints.

headline: Galaxies
text: The eventful life of galaxies in low density environments performed by Ruth Gruetzbauch and Jesús Varela.

headline: Refitting Repasts
text: A spatial exploration of food processing, sharing, cooking and disposal at the Dunefield Midden campsite in South Africa performed by Brian Stewart and Giulia Saltini-Semerari.

headline: The Ultimate Valentine Card: Full-Frontal Gorilla Love

headline: Diane Keaton Flips Legendary Los Angeles House

headline: News of Ledger’s Passion Emerges After His Death

The Australian actor, who died Jan 22 at age 28, apparently enjoyed the game as much as anyone in Hollywood. But the depth of his passion has only come out post-mortem.

This one, made predominantly with whole wheat flour, does it all — and with almost no work.

headline: Beautiful Mount Airy Lie

That hotel featured such things as floor-to-ceiling mirrors and heart-shaped bathtubs, but it had declined to a sad state by the time it closed in 2001.

headline: 30 Seconds Cost a Lot, but the Memories May Be Priceless

headline: Fox Shows Its (Mainly Unscripted) Cards

headline: A New Feature: Interactive Chess Puzzles
text: Feel up to testing your wits? These are interactive problems based on positions from recent tournament games. In each case, click on the chess board and wait for the viewer to load, then make a move on the chess board by clicking and dragging a piece and wait for the computer to respond. If you get the whole sequence of moves right (if more than one move is needed to solve the problem), the computer will let you know that you succeeded. Hints are available. The problems range in difficulty from easy to fairly hard. This feature will appear periodically.

headline: Writing to Sami al-Hajj
text: After reading today’s column about Guantanamo and Sami al-Hajj, plenty of people have been asking what they can do. I don’t have any great suggestions, although calls to the White House couldn’t hurt. Another option is to write Sami directly. He speaks and reads English, so that’s not a problem. The Pentagon claims that he gets mail, but his lawyers say he hasn’t received a single letter for the last three or four months, even though his wife writes him constantly. So I’m not sure he’ll get a letter, but someone will read it….and it’s just possible that some day a box of letters will be delivered to him. Here’s his address:

Standing in the shade, Brian Schneider and David Wright stopped their conversation to watch. John Maine, Mike Pelfrey and Joe Smith leaned against a fence and stared. A crowd of minor-league catchers hurried over, too.
