text: To the Editor:

headline: As Kenyan Rivals Haggle, a Mother Mourns at 2 Graves
text: KATITO, Kenya  It did not take many people to carry the coffins of Wycliffe and Cynthia Awino.

headline: Fresh Start Conservatism
text: In the 19th century, industrialization swept the world. Many European nations expanded their welfare states but kept their education systems exclusive. The U.S. tried the opposite approach. American leaders expanded education and created the highest quality work force on the planet.

headline: A Crisis of Faith
text: A decade ago, during the last global financial crisis, the word on everyone’s lips was “contagion.” Troubles that began in a far-away country of which most people knew nothing (Thailand) eventually spread to much bigger countries with no obvious connection to Southeast Asia, like Russia and Brazil.

headline: Biofuels and Emissions
text: To the Editor:

headline: China Denies Justice Department’s Accusations of Espionage
text: BEIJING  China denied Thursday that it was conducting espionage operations in the United States, rebutting accusations by the Justice Department this week that four people had passed military secrets to the Chinese government.

headline: Closings for Washington’s Birthday
text: Washington’s Birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

headline: David Groh of ‘Rhoda’ Dies at 68
text: David Groh, who in the 1970s sitcom “Rhoda” played Joe, the groom whose wedding to the title character became one of the highest-rated events of its time, died Tuesday in Los Angeles, where he lived. He was 68.

headline: China Rejects Darfur Criticism
text: BEIJING  China has dismissed Steven Spielberg’s move to link the Olympic Games with Chinese policies in Sudan, saying Thursday that sports and politics should be kept separate.

headline: Delegates of Steel
text: Washington

headline: U.N. to Help Organize Iraqi Elections Set for October
text: BAGHDAD  Iraq’s Parliament, faced with a stalemate in appointing election commissions in the most populous provinces and accusations of overt politicization of the election process, announced Thursday that it would welcome the United Nations to play a large role in organizing the vote.

headline: Ford Introduces One Small Car for a World of Markets
text: DETROIT  This time, the Ford Motor Company is keeping it simple  one car with one name for every market in the world.

headline: Sometimes Those Magicians of Song Need to Show What’s Up Their Sleeves
text: Magicians are generally ill advised to reveal their tricks, but when the conductor Kent Tritle let the audience in on a few crafty secrets during a concert by the Choir of St. Ignatius Loyola on Wednesday night, the tactic paid off. The major work on the program, presented at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola as part of its Sacred Music in a Sacred Space series, was the Concerto for Choir by Alfred Schnittke. Mr. Tritle and his choir performed the piece here in 2005; this time it was being recorded for a CD.

headline: Choi Takes Advantage of Early Tee Time to Aim at Flags
text: LOS ANGELES  This is a place of many languages and cultures and, during Thursday’s first round of the Northern Trust Open, so was Riviera Country Club.

headline: And Speaking of Broad
text: Eli Broad and the Broad Art Foundation have responded to the Guerrilla Girls, a protest group that accused them of inadequately representing female and minority artists in the inaugural exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Mr. Broad’s private foundation. (Reviews of the building and collection are on Page 31.) A statement issued by the foundation spokeswoman, Karen Denne, said work by women was prominently featured in the exhibition. “In fact, 33 percent of the works in the exhibit are by women,” the statement said. (The nearly 180 works include 49 photographs by Cindy Sherman.) The Guerrilla Girls had said that of the 30 artists in the Broad Museum show, 97 percent were white and 87 percent male. The Broad statement went on to say, “Since 1995, of the 43 new artists added to the Broad Art Foundation’s collection 14 (33 percent) are women, and nine of those are collected in depth.”

headline: Wintertime, and Fishing Is Easy
text: AS the lakes of the Midwest, Northeast and Canada freeze, clusters of fishing shacks appear, forming villages above the best wintertime fishing spots  despite the cracking, moaning and eerie warbling of the thickening but unstable skin of ice.

headline: Architect’s Plans Scrapped
text: Plans for a London building designed by the Pritzker Prize-winning, Baghdad-born architect Zaha Hadid have been dropped as a result of the credit crunch that began with the subprime mortgage collapse. The building was to have been the first permanent one in Britain by Ms. Hadid, who is known for bold, unconventional forms and was chosen last month to design the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum at Michigan State University in East Lansing. The $10 million London structure, scheduled for completion in July 2009, was to have served as headquarters for the Architecture Foundation. The Evening Standard in London reported that senior members of the foundation said they were unable to guarantee sufficient money from donors to cover the costs because of “economic nervousness” and a stock market slump. Ms. Hadid called the decision “disappointing.”

headline: High School High Jinks and the Depths of Dread
text: Choreography by committee seldom works, and it did not in “The Other Side,” an American premiere presented by Jonathan Hollander’s Battery Dance Company on Wednesday afternoon at the Tribeca Performing Arts Center at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. The three choreographers  Mr. Hollander, Thaddeus Davis and Daniel Cardoso  merged their work rather than adopting the more usual tactic of creating separate sections. The results were a mess.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the sentencing of Army Sgt. Evan Vela to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee described his relationship to the Army Rangers imprecisely. While he graduated from Ranger school and earned the qualifications to serve with the Rangers, he was not assigned to a Ranger battalion at the time of the incident or sentencing and therefore was not considered an Army Ranger.

headline: Scientists Call for Space Exploration
text: The next president of the United States should give NASA an additional $3 billion each year, both to get to Mars and to focus attention on science issues in space and on Earth, a group of scientists, industry figures and former astronauts said on Thursday.

headline: Pettitte Is Now Working on His Damage Control
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte had one pinstriped uniform, several blue shirts, a few Yankees caps and a toiletry bag in his locker here Thursday. Everything seemed to be in place for him to report with the Yankees’ other pitchers and catchers and be ready for the opening workout Friday. But Pettitte’s chair remained empty.

headline: Gunman Was Once ‘Revered’ on Campus
text: A day after a lecture hall was attacked at Northern Illinois University, the gunman emerged in two portraits not easily reconciled.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Justice Will Be Served Only if Clemens Isn’t Given a Pass
text: I listened to every second of Wednesday’s four-hour hearing, looking for hints to bolster my suspicion that the “American people” were being set up for an intentional walk for Roger Clemens. There were code phrases, like “We’re not here to convict” or “Let’s move on” and, of course, “Let’s get back to baseball.”

headline: FEMA’s Formaldehyde Foul-Up
text: Just when you thought the federal government could not possibly outdo its incredible record of ineptitude in the handling of the victims of Hurricane Katrina, it contrives, against all odds, to make yet another colossal mistake. The latest blunder involves the torpid response to the threat of formaldehyde contamination in trailers supplied to hundreds of thousands of New Orleans residents made homeless by the storm.

headline: A Couple of Country Singers Stop to Strut a City Stage
text: The tour is called “Love, Pain & the Whole Crazy Carnival Ride,” which doesn’t sound promising. Somehow, the organizers have turned two infelicitous album titles  Keith Urban’s “Love, Pain & the Whole Crazy Thing” and Carrie Underwood’s “Carnival Ride”  into one singularly unpleasant phrase, which is odd, especially when they could have called this tour “Keith & Carrie! Live! Seriously!” What else do you need to know?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend last Friday about “Jasper Johns: Gray,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, referred incorrectly to the orange, green and purple in the painting “Céline.” They are secondary colors (made by mixing primary colors), not tertiaries (made by mixing secondary colors).

headline: F.D.A. Broke Its Rules by Not Inspecting Chinese Plant With Problem Drug
text: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14  The Food and Drug Administration violated its own policies when it approved for sale a crucial blood-thinning drug without first inspecting a Chinese plant which, along with a plant in Wisconsin, made the drug’s active pharmaceutical ingredient.

headline: Tale of the Tapes Continues With New Evidence
text: A day after meeting with N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell to discuss the videotaping controversy that has entangled the league, Senator Arlen Specter said that he was “more determined” to continue probing.

headline: Deutsche Post Chief Under Tax Inquiry
text: BERLIN  German prosecutors accused one of the country’s most prominent business executives of tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

headline: British Ruling for Former 9/11 Suspect
text: LONDON  A British appeals court said Thursday that a pilot the American authorities had suspected of training some of the hijackers in the 9/11 terrorist attacks had been “completely exonerated.” The pilot, who had been held by the British for nearly five months, can seek compensation from the British government for wrongful arrest and detention, the court said.

headline: Some Cities Are Spared the Slide in Housing
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  The real estate market these days is a tale of two Americas, and one of them is not doing too badly.

headline: Gunman Slays 6 at N. Illinois University
text: DeKALB, Ill.  With minutes left in a class in ocean sciences at Northern Illinois University on Thursday afternoon, a tall skinny man dressed all in black stepped out from behind a curtain on the stage of the lecture hall, said nothing, and opened fire with a shotgun, the authorities and witnesses said.

headline: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
text: Microsoft announced a sweeping shake-up of its executive ranks Thursday, placing new executives over operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

headline: A Leap Forward, but Hurdles Remain in Narcolepsy
text: Scientists have begun to pull back the veil of mystery that has surrounded narcolepsy since it was first described more than 125 years ago. In 2000, investigators reported that a lack of a neurochemical called hypocretin is a prime culprit in the sleep disorder. Patients with classic narcolepsy — a combination of irresistible sleepiness and sudden collapses from muscle weakness — are missing most of the brain cells that make the wakefulness-promoting protein.

headline: Court Rules Waiters Are Entitled to Fees Disguised as Tips
text: In a major victory for the state’s restaurant employees, New York’s highest court ruled on Thursday that restaurants must pay their wait staff any mandatory service fees that customers are led to believe are substitutes for tips.

headline: New Therapies Aim at Lung Tumors, Case by Case
text: The numbers are terrifying: lung cancer kills more people in the United States and across the world than any other cancer. Fewer than half of newly diagnosed lung cancer patients live beyond a year. And only 16 percent survive for five years, only a few percentage points higher than when President Richard Nixon declared a “war on cancer” back in 1971.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Southern Greece
text: ATHENS  A powerful earthquake measuring 6.5 on the Richter scale shook southern Greece on Thursday, sending panic-stricken residents into the streets but causing no major damage or casualties.

headline: Torre Is Looking Good in a New Shade of Blue
text: Vero Beach, Fla.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about cellphone trends misstated the title of Daniel Moloney of Motorola, who commented on competition in the industry. He is president of the company’s home and networks mobility business, not its cellphone business.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about the sentencing of Army Sgt. Evan Vela to 10 years in prison for killing an unarmed Iraqi detainee described his relationship to the Army Rangers imprecisely. While he graduated from Ranger school and earned the qualifications to serve with the Rangers, he was not assigned to a Ranger battalion at the time of the incident or sentencing and therefore was not considered an Army Ranger. (Go to Article)

headline: President Putin Talks of the Future as Premier
text: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin, in the final weeks of an eight-year administration that secured his place as the country’s most popular politician, said Thursday that he intended to wield substantial and long-running power in the Kremlin after leaving office next month and becoming Russia’s prime minister.

headline: Selected Studies: Lung Cancer
text: Government agencies, universities, doctors and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information about these and other trials: ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Hezbollah Threatens Attacks on Israeli Targets
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Accusing Israel of killing one of his top commanders, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, threatened Thursday to intensify his group’s conflict with Israel and to retaliate against Israeli targets anywhere in the world.

headline: Israel Heightens Its Security After a Threat of Revenge
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli military’s chief of staff “ordered land, air and naval forces on alert to ensure the defense of the northern border and of other Israeli interests,” an army statement said Thursday, after the Hezbollah leader threatened to avenge the death of a senior military commander, Imad Mugniyah.

headline: Mistaken Iraq Battle Kills 6 Fighters Allied With U.S.
text: BAGHDAD  Six members of an Awakening Council, groups composed mostly of Sunni Muslims who have turned against the insurgency, were killed early Thursday after they mistakenly fired on American soldiers in the north, the Iraqi police said.

headline: Earnhardt Sets the Tone in a Qualifier
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Dale Earnhardt Jr.’s victory Thursday in the first Gatorade 150 qualifying race at Daytona International Speedway established him as the leading contender going into Nascar’s biggest event of the year, the Daytona 500.

headline: A Co-op for $14,000? It’s No Fiction
text: Like so many other single New Yorkers who stubbornly persist in pursuing fulfilling but decidedly nonlucrative careers, Matthew Thomas, a 32-year-old aspiring novelist, endured a housing history defined by transience and tests of endurance.

headline: 2 Ports of Stability in Florida’s Market
text: “It’s not Yahoo, but it is G.E.,” said Mike McMurray, an agent with VIP Realty in Sanibel, about the investment potential for property on Sanibel and Captiva Islands in Southwest Florida. “Even with general downturns in real estate, this market tends to be relatively stable,” he said.

headline: Rounding Up the Usual Suspects
text: LOS ANGELES  The inaugural exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art’s spanking new Broad Contemporary Art Museum has no title, because it isn’t really an exhibition.

headline: Attacks on the Homeless Rise, With Youths Mostly to Blame
text: CROSS CITY, Fla.  Warren Messner was 15 when he and some friends attacked a homeless man and left him for dead. Mr. Messner jumped on a log laid across the man’s ribs. He does not know why. He was high, does not remember much and wants to forget the rest.

headline: Hezbollah Leader Issues Threat to Israel
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hezbollah’s leader, Sheik Hassan Nasrallah, told 10,000 mourners on Thursday at the funeral of a senior commander killed in Syria that Hezbollah was ready to retaliate “anywhere” against Israel, which it blames for the death.

headline: Giants in Training for Life A.B.: After Bonds
text: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Matt Cain is a main cog in the San Francisco Giants’ starting rotation, but last year he was merely another setup man for the season-long spectacle that was the Barry Bonds Show.

headline: Missing Basquiat Painting Found
text: An $8 million Jean-Michel Basquiat painting whose last known owner was a bankrupt Brazilian banker has been found in a Manhattan warehouse, The Associated Press reported. Federal prosecutors filed papers seeking to seize the 1982 work, “Hannibal,” which was valued at $100 on a customs declaration form when it arrived by courier from London at Kennedy Airport after apparently being smuggled out of Brazil. Prosecutors are seeking to help Brazilian authorities claim the painting, whose last known owner was Edemar Cid Ferreira, former owner of Banco Santos and one of Brazil’s foremost art collectors. The bank went bankrupt in 2005, leaving debts of more than $1 billion. Mr. Ferreira was convicted of money laundering and bank fraud, and sentenced to 21 years in prison; a Brazilian court ordered seizure of $20 million to $30 million worth of his art, saying it was bought with proceeds of illegal schemes, but “Hannibal” was missing.

headline: Islam Critic Seeks European Union Protection
text: Ayaan Hirsi Ali, the former Dutch lawmaker who began receiving death threats in 2004, when she criticized political Islam, and later left for the United States, asked the European Union to pay for her round-the-clock protection while in the United States, saying that Europe had a responsibility to defend freedom of expression. Last year, the Dutch government said it would no longer pay for bodyguards while she is abroad.

headline: Hundreds Mourn at Burial of East Timor Rebel
text: DILI, East Timor  The body of the slain army mutineer who led attacks on the president and prime minister of East Timor was buried in the garden of his home here Thursday in a peaceful ceremony witnessed by hundreds of mourners.

headline: Zimbabwe: Inflation Surges to Official 66,000%
text: In November, the official rate of inflation, far and away the world’s highest, was 26,740.8 percent, so bad that a decent day’s pay was nearly worthless by the time a worker arrived home in the evening. But the December rate, announced Thursday by the Central Statistics Office, made that seem like the good old days. That rate was 66,212.3 percent.

headline: McCain and Obama Skirmish on Financing
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign said Thursday that it stood by a year-old pledge made with Senator Barack Obama that each would accept public financing for the general election if the nominee of the opposing party did the same. But Mr. Obama’s campaign refused to reaffirm its earlier commitment.

headline: Idol Marches On
text: Drawing an average of 24.6 million viewers, “American Idol” on Fox dominated Wednesday night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates, as “Idol” narrowed its remaining contestants to 24 semifinalists. Fox easily led the night over all, winning the 9 p.m. time slot after “Idol” with its new game show “The Moment of Truth” (14.5 million). NBC ranked a distant second, faring best at 8 with “Deal or No Deal” (11 million) and at 10 with “Law & Order” (10.2 million). ABC finished third among adults 18 to 49, thanks to a strong showing for that demographic from “Supernanny” at 9 (8.8 million). CBS, in fourth place among the 18-to-49 set, edged past ABC in total viewers with repeats. At 8, however, “Big Brother” on CBS attracted a disappointing 5.8 million viewers.

headline: Classical Visions, Romantic Eye
text: If a painter can be judged by the love he inspires, Nicolas Poussin (1594-1665) was one of art history’s favorite valentines. Corot, Delacroix, Constable and Cézanne all adored him. So did Picasso and Matisse. Nor were artists his only fans. The 19th-century English critic William Hazlitt surpassed himself in his praise of Poussin and may well have introduced his work to an already deeply Poussinian John Keats.

headline: Bush Appeals to Justices on Detainees Case
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration asked the Supreme Court on Thursday to review an appeals court decision that it said had created a “serious threat to national security” by requiring the government to supply extensive evidence supporting the classification of more than 180 Guantánamo detainees as enemy combatants.

headline: Something Wicked This Way Comes
text: His thoughts stalk him like snipers in the shadows, and when they attack, it’s with a violence that leaves him shorn of defenses. Bloodthirsty enemies on the battlefield, double-dealing politicians of the court and would-be assassins at home: the Macbeth embodied with such fearsome insight and theatrical fire by Patrick Stewart has the wiles and the nerve to conquer such adversaries. What he doesn’t stand a chance against is his own mercurial mind.

headline: Federal Housing Loans
text: To the Editor:

headline: FEMA Vows New Effort on Trailers Posing Risk
text: The federal government pledged Thursday to intensify its efforts to move Gulf Coast hurricane victims out of trailers and into apartments or hotels after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention finally confirmed that many trailers were contaminated with high levels of formaldehyde.

headline: New Top Editor for Los Angeles Times, the 4th in 3 Years
text: The Los Angeles Times named a new top editor on Thursday, Russ Stanton, three weeks after the previous editor, James E. O’Shea, was forced out for resisting another in a series of staff cuts.

headline: Black Leader, a Clinton Ally, Tilts to Obama
text: MILWAUKEE  Representative John Lewis, an elder statesman from the civil rights era and one of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s most prominent black supporters, said Thursday night that he planned to cast his vote as a superdelegate for Senator Barack Obama in hopes of preventing a fight at the Democratic convention.

headline: Tax Break Helps a Crusader for Deficit Discipline
text: “Where is it ordained that private equity pays only a 15 percent tax?”

headline: 4 News Companies Ally to Sell Ads on the Internet
text: Four large newspaper companies are joining forces to sell advertisements on the Internet, hoping that the combined heft of their Web sites will encourage large advertisers to spend more money.

headline: Philippines on Alert After Plot
text: MANILA  The Philippine authorities went on high alert Thursday after the discovery of what officials said was a plot to assassinate President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

headline: We’re Spending Too Much to Make a Little Money
text: Not a chance, my neighborhood news dealer said. He’s a friendly fellow. But no way was he about to count the 75 pennies put forth as payment for two newspapers. The woman at the bakery was absolute about not accepting 215 pennies for a danish.

headline: Sisterhood Is Complicated
text: Beth Henley’s comedy “Crimes of the Heart” has proved to be a durable showcase for actresses in the two decades and more since it won the Pulitzer Prize. A little bit Chekhov and a little bit Eudora Welty, it tells a twangy story of three Southern sisters loving, feuding and fussing through a very bad day.

headline: For No-Boarders in British Columbia, It’s No Bindings, No Problem
text: THREE miles into the Kootenay Range backcountry by snowmobile, I stood alongside 50 other riders, gathered at the bottom of a wide and untracked sub-alpine run. The mid-January snowpack was so deep in the Interior Mountains of British Columbia that the effects of logging were buried beneath 180 inches of powder  the downed trees, stumps and rocks all transformed by the bounty of snow into a snowboarder’s paradise.

headline: Theater Listings
text: ‘GAUGUIN/SAVAGE LIGHT’ Occasionally a musical will find new life through replacement casting. George Fischoff has taken things a step further with his pocket musical “Gauguin/Savage Light”: he has eliminated the cast entirely.

headline: A. D. Lewis, Administrator Behind Conrail, Is Dead at 89
text: Arthur D. Lewis, a transportation executive whose long career spanned airplanes, buses, and, most significantly, the formation of Conrail, which consolidated many of the country’s surviving freight lines, died on Jan. 12. He was 89.

headline: Romney Backs McCain’s Candidacy, Ending a Heated Campaign Feud
text: One of the bitterest feuds of the 2008 presidential race ended Thursday when Mitt Romney threw his support  and vowed to try to throw his delegates  behind his former archrival for the Republican nomination, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

headline: Striking When the Spirit Was Hot
text: “WACK!: Art and the Feminist Revolution” is a big, messy, fascinating scrapbook of a show. It doesn’t instruct or admonish us about gender and politics; rather, it haphazardly tells a story about freedom and possibility. The quality is uneven, but the overall effect is exciting. It takes you back to a heady time when female artists were throwing out old, patriarchal rules and reinventing art in all kinds of idiosyncratic and sometimes dangerously extreme terms.

headline: Lung Cancer, an Equal Opportunity Killer
text: Dr. Joan Schiller is deputy director of the Harold C. Simmons Comprehensive Cancer Center at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center. She is president of the National Lung Cancer Partnership, a nonprofit educational and advocacy group that focuses on women.

headline: What to Ask About Lung Cancer
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: All Nothing, All the Time
text: IF you’re wearing a cast right now, this advice comes too late, but file it away for next winter: There’s nothing wrong with doing nothing. And there’s a bed-and-breakfast out there, framed in snow but with plush rooms and welcoming fires inside, that is made for helping you remember how.

headline: Top Officials See Bleaker Outlook for the Economy
text: WASHINGTON  With the credit markets once again deteriorating, the nation’s two top economic policy makers acknowledged Thursday that the outlook for the economy had worsened, as both came under criticism for being overtaken by events and failing to act boldly enough.

headline: Pressing Beijing on Rights
text: To the Editor:

headline: Union Expects 15,000 to 20,000 G.M. Workers to Take Buyouts
text: DEARBORN, Mich.  The head of the United Automobile Workers union said on Thursday that he expected 15,000 to 20,000 workers to leave General Motors during a new round of buyouts, and that G.M. would replace nearly all of them with lower-paid employees.

headline: New Works That Employ or Disregard Electronics
text: Bang on a Can’s People’s Commissioning Fund is a lovely idea. Concertgoers contribute whatever they can afford, and Bang on a Can, the new-music organization, commissions a few new works, usually from young composers. The scores are played by the Bang on a Can All-Stars at an annual concert and recorded for broadcast on WNYC-FM.

headline: William D. Modell, Seller of Sporting Goods, Is Dead at 86
text: William D. Modell, who as chairman of the Modell’s Sporting Goods chain oversaw its expansion throughout much of the Northeast, died Thursday in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Hewlett Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Judge Says Use of MySpace May Violate a Court Order
text: In one of the first rulings of its kind, a Staten Island judge has said that a teenage girl could be charged with violating a restraining order by using MySpace.com to reach out to people she was told not to contact.

headline: Star Pitcher Says Mets Have Room for Another
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The doors swung open and out sauntered Pedro Martínez. His entourage  trainers, coaches, club officials, photographers, video cameramen  filed in stage left as he shook hands, waved, hugged and shimmied toward his red carpet, the lush green grass of Field No. 4.

headline: Where the Real Action Is
text: Not so long ago, the documentary feature category was among the snooziest at the Oscars, the target of jokes that said you couldn’t lose by making a film about the Holocaust. That backward-looking pattern began to morph when Michael Moore won the 2002 award with “Bowling for Columbine,” and exploded with last year’s win for Al Gore’s one-man show, “An Inconvenient Truth.” Odd though it sounds, Michael Moore and Al Gore have made the image of documentaries  O.K., maybe not sexy, but hot.

headline: Profiles of the Victims
text: The following six died as a result of the shooting at Northern Illinois University, as identified by the DeKalb County Coroner and the university:

headline: What to Ask About Narcolepsy
text: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening — and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why they’re important.

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Millionaires Are a Dime a Dozen
text: In the planned community of Ladera Ranch, Calif., there are signs asking dog owners to clean up after their pets. It also provides “mutt mitts” for this purpose. And in case civic duty doesn’t do the trick, Ladera contracts with a company called EntreManure just to come in and pick up the poop. According to the authors of a woefully ill-timed book about runaway American prosperity, delegating this type of job is a triumph of middle-class millionaire spirit.

headline: Love, Sex, Belly Dancing and Religious Differences
text: The star-crossed romance “David & Layla” tells of a beautiful young Iraqi Kurd named Layla (Shiva Rose) who is threatened with deportation from her adopted home, Brooklyn, and pins her hopes of staying on a suitor named David (David Moscow), an American-born agnostic Jew who has a public-access cable show about sex and is trapped in an unsatisfying relationship with a snooty fiancée (Callie Thorne of the television series “Rescue Me”).

headline: Heliport Owner Would Move Landing Pads Into Hudson
text: The operator of the heliport in Hudson River Park, spurred by a lawsuit brought by park advocates, has proposed moving its operation out of the park and about 100 feet into the river.

headline: In Guilty Plea, Actress’s Killer Changes Story to Robbery
text: His original confession had the ring of truth: He was an illegal immigrant working on a renovation job in a Greenwich Village building when the imperious woman upstairs confronted him over construction noise.

headline: Waxman Regrets Hearing Was Held
text: WASHINGTON  A day after a dramatic, nationally televised hearing that pitted Roger Clemens against his former personal trainer and Democrats against Republicans, the chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform said Thursday that he regretted holding the hearing in the first place.

headline: A Little Bit of Country, a Little Bit of Dark Despair
text: What can a Broadway country gospel singer bring to the lyrics of Billy Strayhorn, Stephen Sondheim and Lorenz Hart? Those are three of the super-urbane songwriters covered by Lari White in her new show, “Love Letters,” at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel.

headline: Georgia Exile Autopsied
text: LONDON  Initial inquiries and an autopsy gave no indication of foul play in the unexpected death of the exiled Georgian tycoon and opposition politician Badri Patarkatsishvili, the Surrey police said Thursday.

headline: Major Immigrant Smuggling Ring Is Broken in Phoenix, Police Say
text: PHOENIX  In a case highlighting this city’s prominent role in the smuggling of illegal immigrants across the border, the authorities conducted a series of raids on Thursday, arresting what they said were the leaders of a ring that helped transport hundreds of people to way stations in Phoenix.

headline: Turmoil in Africa Alters Focus of Bush’s 5-Nation Tour
text: WASHINGTON  On the eve of a planned trip to Africa, President Bush thrust himself into the role of peacemaker on Thursday, as his plans to promote American efforts against poverty and disease gave way to a more pressing imperative: addressing the violence and turmoil on the continent.

headline: Signs in Kenya of a Land Redrawn by Ethnicity
text: OTHAYA, Kenya  Sarah Wangoi has spent her entire life  all 70 years of it  in the Rift Valley. But last month, she was chased off her farm by a mob that called her a foreigner. She now sleeps on the cold floor of a stranger’s house, seeking refuge in an area of Kenya where her ethnic group, the Kikuyu, is strong. It is, supposedly, her homeland.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An obituary on Feb. 6 about Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, who introduced transcendental meditation to the West and gained fame as the spiritual guru to the Beatles, described incorrectly those who may bear the title of Maharishi, Hindi for “great seer,” and misstated his own eligibility for it. The title may be bestowed on people of any caste, not only Brahmins. He was not ineligible because he was from a lower caste.

headline: In Utah, the Fast Way to Town
text: J. T. ROBINSON parked his Subaru station wagon on 27th Street in Ogden, Utah, a residential road that dead-ends before a wall of mountains to the east. He shouldered his skis and pointed to a peak above town. “That used to be my route home,” he said, hand stretched toward a craggy pyramid that cut the sky.

headline: The Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain and Nizuc Resort & Residences
text: The Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain

headline: Show Us the Money
text: As the presidential campaign narrows and its costs skyrocket, detailed disclosure of financial resources becomes ever more important. Of the leading contenders, so far, only Senator Barack Obama has released his full income-tax returns  a level of disclosure once routine for candidates after the political corruption of Watergate.

headline: U.S. to Produce Data on Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: The Bush administration has agreed to turn over to international inspectors intelligence data it has collected that it says proves Iran worked on developing a nuclear weapon until a little more than four years ago, according to American and foreign diplomats.

headline: Ex-State Senator Is Charged With Extortion
text: NEWARK  A former New Jersey legislator was indicted on extortion charges in federal court Thursday, accused of using his position on the State Senate Budget Committee to steer millions of tax dollars to a hospital in exchange for more than $100,000 in consulting fees, prosecutors said.

headline: Lawyer Says McNamee Lied in a Recording
text: The day before the Mitchell report was released, Brian McNamee lied to investigators for Roger Clemens when he told them that federal authorities had additional evidence about Clemens’s use of performance-enhancing drugs. McNamee’s lawyer said Thursday that McNamee made up the story in order to explain his own discussions with the authorities.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: A Brazilian Boy, Alone in the Tumult of 1970
text: “The Year My Parents Went on Vacation” takes place in Brazil in 1970, when the country was ruled by a military dictatorship and its national soccer team, led by Pelé, was making its way toward the finals of the World Cup. Accordingly, sports and politics both play parts in this film, directed by Cao Hamburger, which filters the tumult and trauma of Brazilian history through the perceptions of a 12-year-old boy named Mauro.

headline: The Times to Cut 100 News Jobs
text: After years of resisting the newsroom cuts that have hit most of the industry, The New York Times will bow to growing financial strain and eliminate about 100 newsroom jobs this year, the executive editor said Thursday.

headline: Give This Man a Pencil
text: THE identity of the littlest conference room inside the headquarters of the Writers Guild of America East is situation-dependent: sometimes it functions as a law library, sometimes as the caucus room for mini-negotiations deemed too private to conduct in full conference mode. Writers are secretive: Think soap opera scribes.

headline: Warring on McCain, Limbaugh Sees No Reconciliation
text: Rush Limbaugh took his show on the road this week, forsaking his main broadcast studio in Palm Beach, Fla., for one in Midtown Manhattan. But the change of scenery did nothing to dampen the Republican-on-Republican smackdown he has been waging from afar against Senator John McCain, the party’s likely presidential nominee, whom Mr. Limbaugh considers too moderate.

headline: Entertainers Rally for Singer Opposed to Venezuela’s President
text: More than 80 entertainers, including Shakira, Jennifer Lopez, Marc Anthony, Ricky Martin and Penelope Cruz have signed a statement supporting the Grammy Award-winning Spanish singer Alejandro Sanz, below, after two of his concerts in Caracas were canceled because he criticized the president of Venezuela, Hugo Chávez, The Associated Press reported. The signatories said they “believe in a Latin America where we are all free to express our views.” Last week Venezuelan organizers announced that Mr. Sanz’s sold-out Feb. 14 concert would be canceled because it lacked “the appropriate conditions.” Another concert was canceled when officials withdrew permission to use a government auditorium. Mr. Sanz’s criticisms of Mr. Chávez have prompted Venezuelan officials to declare that he is not welcome in the country. On Sunday Mr. Sanz ended a concert in the Dominican Republic by dedicating a song to his Venezuelan fans, “a bunch of people in a country where I cannot go.”

headline: UBS Posts Huge Loss and Warns About 2008
text: PARIS  UBS offered no hope Thursday for a near-term turnaround as it posted an $11.3 billion fourth-quarter loss and warned that 2008 would be a “difficult” year.

headline: Municipalities Feel Pinch as Another Debt Market Falters
text: The credit crisis paining Wall Street is reaching out across the nation, afflicting municipalities, hospitals and cultural touchstones like the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: A Mountain Town Where Mineral Waters Flow
text: WHEN Zoe Burger first started spending weekends in Berkeley Springs, she was curious about the legendary healing powers of the warm mineral waters the region is named for. So she headed to Berkeley Springs State Park in the center of town, where public bathhouses offer a good soak for $20.

headline: Angels in the Infield at Daytona
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  On Sunday, the Rev. Ronnie Barton found himself comparing the trials of the Christian life to the challenges confronting Nascar race teams.

headline: Footnotes
text: The Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford has a new director. She is Susan Lubowsky Talbott, the director of Smithsonian Arts at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. She will assume her new post on April 15. She succeeds Willard Holmes, who announced in February 2007 that he was stepping down. ...Patrick Stewart, currently starring in “Macbeth” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is to receive this year’s Gielgud Award for Excellence in the Dramatic Arts. He will be honored on March 10, when the Shakespeare Guild joins the English-Speaking Union of New York and the National Arts Club in a gala at the club, 15 Gramercy Park South. ... Paramount Pictures is delaying the release of “Star Trek” to May 8, 2009, from Dec. 25, 2008, Variety reported. The studio said the film’s potential is greater as a summer season attraction. ...Tovah Feldshuh, who starred on Broadway in “Golda’s Balcony,” will make her debut at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency from March 4 to 15 with “Tovah in a Nutshell!” singing songs from Gershwin to Judy Collins and inhabiting a variety of characters.

headline: Arroyo Plot Reported
text: MANILA  The Philippine authorities went on high alert on Thursday after the discovery of what officials said was a plot to assassinate President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

headline: The Wake-Up Flight of a Wayward B-52
text: A B-52 bomber took off from an Air Force base in North Dakota in August and  in a startling mistake attributed to post-cold war operational complacency  carried six nuclear-tipped cruise missiles on a 1,400-mile flight to a base in Louisiana. The missile tips should have been dummies, but somehow actual nuclear warheads were loaded for the cross-country trip. “No one knew where they were, or even missed them, for over 36 hours,” said Senator Carl Levin in a hearing this week into preventing such a dangerous mix-up from ever happening again.

headline: Off the Set, Into the Desert
text: “This is the story of a couple who moved to California from the East Coast and then, one day, built a home in the desert,” said Tracy Tynan. Her voice slipped playfully into the earnest, dulcet tones of a museum docent, as if Jacqueline Kennedy’s tour of the White House were being played as screwball comedy.

headline: The Knicks’ Foundation Is Really a Pile of Sand
text: In the Knicks renaissance that took shape in Isiah Thomas’s head, Eddy Curry and Zach Randolph were twin bulldozers, brutishly blazing a path to better days. Overmatched opponents trembled. Rival coaches wailed. Thomas beamed with pride. It was a nice fantasy.

headline: Lowry Extends Tenure at MoMA
text: LOWRY EXTENDS

headline: Smaller Version of the Solar System Is Discovered
text: Astronomers said Wednesday that they had found a miniature version of our own solar system 5,000 light-years across the galaxy  the first planetary system that really looks like our own, with outer giant planets and room for smaller inner planets.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A headline in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about a lawsuit filed against New Line Cinema by heirs of the author of the “Lord of the Rings” trilogy misspelled the author’s surname in some editions. He was J. R. R. Tolkien, not Tolkein.

headline: British Judge Questions Halt to Arms Fraud Inquiry
text: LONDON  A British High Court judge raised new questions Thursday about why the government ordered the Serious Fraud Office to stop investigating claims of corruption related to a 1990s arms deal with Saudi Arabia that was brokered by BAE Systems, the biggest British weapons maker.

headline: Large Union Backs Obama; Another Is Likely to Do Same
text: Giving Senator Barack Obama new momentum, one of the nation’s largest labor unions, the United Food and Commercial Workers, endorsed him on Thursday. Another giant, the Service Employees International Union, was on the brink of backing him.

headline: Remembering a Woman of Very Original Tastes
text: Remembering a Woman

headline: Marketers Are Putting Nascar on Different Kinds of Circuits
text: “GENTLEMEN, start your modems.”

headline: Profit at Daimler After Chrysler Sale
text: Daimler, the German maker of luxury vehicles, reported a fourth-quarter profit on Thursday, helped by the sale of its Chrysler division in the United States and job cuts at Mercedes-Benz Cars.

headline: Spitzer Utilities Nominee Started Job While Still an Industry Lobbyist, Report Finds
text: Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s nomination early last year of a top energy industry lobbyist as chairwoman of the Public Service Commission created a number of ethical problems, the state inspector general, Kristine Hamann, said in a long-awaited report on Thursday.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: In Remote Valley, a Grim Redefinition of ‘Fishing’
text: RIO GRANDE VALLEY, Jamaica  Catching freshwater shrimp in the legendary Rio Grande here in the forested hills of eastern Jamaica used to be done at night with a homemade bamboo torch in one hand and a sharp spear in the other.

headline: When Strains on Military Families Turn Deadly
text: A few months after Sgt. William Edwards and his wife, Sgt. Erin Edwards, returned to a Texas Army base from separate missions in Iraq, he assaulted her mercilessly. He struck her, choked her, dragged her over a fence and slammed her into the sidewalk.

headline: State to Preserve Heart of Adirondacks
text: State environmental officials agreed on Thursday to preserve a vast swath of wild acreage in the northern part of Adirondack Park, using a combination of outright purchase and conservation easements meant to protect both wilderness and jobs.

headline: Man Fatally Stabbed With Corkscrew
text: The body of a Brooklyn man who had been stabbed in the side of the head with a corkscrew was discovered by relatives in his Prospect Heights apartment on Wednesday, the police said on Thursday.

headline: Art Museum Mixes Pomp and Hint of Pop
text: LOS ANGELES  This city is growing up, and I count myself among those who see that as a mixed blessing. Over the last decade or so it has embarked on its most ambitious cultural building boom in a generation, adding a new dimension to a city whose notable civic monuments have famously been its freeways. But with exceptions like Frank Gehry’s Walt Disney Concert Hall, these projects have often failed to live up to Los Angeles’s great tradition of architectural experimentation.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film column on Thursday about the Film Comment Selects series, at the Walter Reade Theater, misstated the given name of the director whose films “10 Rillington Place” and “Mandingo” will be shown. He was Richard Fleischer, not Robert.

headline: An Unfamiliar Take on Familiar Literary Figures
text: Don’t think of “The Jazz Age” as yet another go-round with sloshy Scott, zany Zelda and earthy Ernie, three of the last century’s most overexposed literary figures. Think of it as a chance to see three skilled actors demonstrate that even the familiar can be made very watchable.

headline: Company Behind Many TV Hits Is Sold
text: Ben Silverman, the co-chairman of NBC Entertainment, announced Thursday the sale of his independent production company Reveille to a British firm, the Shine Group, for $125 million.

headline: Deer Hunt Goes Ahead After Years of Protest
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  The hunters gathered on Thursday at the glow of dawn on the icy slopes of South Mountain Reservation in Essex County. By sunrise, the thermometer had risen to 27 degrees and they were 30 feet up in tree stands, camouflaged and waiting.

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about voters in Virginia in the lead-up to the Democratic primary that day misstated the distance between Lexington and Roanoke, two cities in the state where Senator Barack Obama was receiving strong support from young people. They are about 45 miles apart, not 100.

headline: Ex-Congressman Agrees a Road Should Not Bear His Name
text: TRENTON  When Gov. Jon S. Corzine signed a bill last month that officially changed the name Route 23 to the Robert A. Roe Memorial Highway, in honor of a former congressman who had represented North Jersey for more than two decades, it was the legislative equivalent of getting a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

headline: Imprisoned Rapper’s Father Elected in Belize
text: Jamal (Shyne) Barrow, the young rapper and Sean Combs protégé serving a 10-year sentence in New York State for a 1999 nightclub shooting that injured three people, has a friend in high places, highbridnation.com reported. Last weekend the Central American country Belize elected its first black prime minister. He is Dean Barrow, the father of Jamal, who could be released this year.

headline: Trade Deficit Shrank by 6.2% Last Year
text: The United States trade deficit shrank in 2007 for the first time in five years, the government said on Thursday. But while the numbers reflected strength in exports, they also indicated that American consumers had cut back on their spending as the economy flagged.

headline: Art in Review
text: ARS FENNICA

headline: Filmmakers Who Become Their Own Zombie Movie
text: In “George A. Romero’s Diary of the Dead,” the loosest, goosiest chapter in the filmmaker’s continuing zombieland epic, we meet the enemy and he is us, with video cameras. Set in Mr. Romero’s usual Pennsylvania stomping and chomping grounds (a k a Canada), the story pivots on a clutch of University of Pittsburgh students who, in the process of fleeing legions of the undead  despite their obvious handicap, zombies always find fresh meat  have taken up cameras, thus becoming the producers of their own snuff biopic.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Exploring Influences and Finding Inspirations
text: When the violinist Midori and the pianist Marc-André Hamelin performed Ravel’s Sonata for Violin and Piano on Wednesday evening at the Rose Theater, notes and phrases were as carefully placed as stones in a Japanese garden. But the details blended into a seamlessly organic whole, flowing from a languid, delicate Allegretto into Midori’s sultry, smoky rhapsodizing in the jazz-influenced second movement, then into the frenzy of the concluding Perpetuum mobile.

headline: A Window Into China
text: To the Editor:

headline: When a Woman Runs for President
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bleak New Batch of Data on Economy
text: A fresh batch of data on Friday presented a bleak picture of the economy, with rising prices of imported goods, struggling manufacturing and an erosion in consumer confidence.

headline: Frank Piasecki, a Pioneer in Helicopters, Is Dead at 88
text: Frank Piasecki, an inventor of one of the first helicopters and the first to develop a tandem-rotor helicopter  the so-called Flying Banana  capable of carrying large cargo loads or troops into combat, died Monday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 88.

headline: Clemens on the Hill
text: To the Editor:

headline: Service With a Caveat
text: WHAT’S the worst that can happen with a cleaning person or some other service at your second home? They don’t show up? They don’t do good work? Theft?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about efforts by the operators of E-ZPass in New York to track down highway toll evaders referred incorrectly at several points to the technology used to identify and match E-ZPass tags as a car passes through a lane. The tags are identified via radio frequencies, not optical scans.

headline: A Crime-Fighting Opportunity
text: In October, California Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger signed a smart new law that will help police apprehend violent criminals and deter the gun traffickers who supply them. The measure requires that all new semiautomatic pistols sold in the state starting in 2010 be equipped with technology known as microstamping, which will allow police to quickly match empty bullet casings to the weapon that fired them.

headline: ‘Boeing-Boeing’ Is Inbound
text: After a few months of circling Broadway, “Boeing-Boeing,” a revival of the 1960s farce by Mark Camoletti about an architect frantically trying to maintain relationships with three stewardesses, will touch down at the Longacre Theater. Christine Baranski, Mark Rylance and Bradley Whitford are to star in the play, currently a hit in London. Matthew Warchus (“Art”) will direct. Previews begin on April 19, with an opening set for May 4. The stewardesses have not yet been cast.

headline: When the Borders Between Sleep and Wakefulness Blur
text: Dr. Emmanuel Mignot is director of the Stanford Center for Narcolepsy. Trained in psychiatry and pharmacology, he has studied narcolepsy for more than 20 years and treats patients one day a month in the clinic.

headline: A Cuban-American’s Wish to Find Her Ancestral Home
text: At an anti-Castro protest in Miami, the playwright Carmen Peláez’s alter ego, Camila, visits her grandmother and hears again about the family’s flight from Havana decades before. “You are not free, because you’re Cuban and you’re not home,” her grandmother tells the American-born Camila.

headline: Make Big Profits Illegally (and Maybe Keep Them, Too)
text: There is not much doubt that Oleksandr Dorozhko used inside information when he made a killing trading stock options last fall. Nor is there a dispute that he gained the information illegally. His lawyer, arguing before an appeals court this week, spoke of “a high-tech lock pick.”

headline: U.S. to Attempt to Shoot Down Faulty Satellite
text: WASHINGTON  The military will try to shoot down a crippled spy satellite in the next two weeks, senior officials said Thursday. The officials laid out a high-tech plan to intercept the satellite over the Pacific just before it tumbles uncontrollably to Earth carrying toxic fuel.

headline: No Mickey Mouse Stuff
text: It would be a mistake to assume that the 10 movies nominated this year for best live-action and animated short film in the Oscar sweepstakes are the kind of cinematic amuse-bouches often shown before the main feature at film festivals. Most are not trifles, and some range from 30 to 40 minutes long.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Thursday about government assistance for a struggling German bank, IKB Deutsche Industriebank, misstated part of the name of a political party that has criticized the rescue effort. It is the Christian Democratic Union, not the Christian Democratic Party.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Wednesday about cockfighting in the Dominican Republic referred imprecisely to the legal status of the practice in the United States. Although all 50 states have voted to ban cockfighting, it is not yet illegal in all of them. (Cockfights can continue in Louisiana until the state’s prohibition takes effect in August.)

headline: French Trader’s Bets Said to Assure an Alarm
text: PARIS  Someone well acquainted with the trading controls at Société Générale said it was “inconceivable” that Jérôme Kerviel’s immediate supervisors were not alerted after his trades set off alarm bells at Eurex, the derivatives exchange based in Frankfurt.

headline: Oscar Organizers Express Relief at Show’s Resumption
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Both a little grayer then they were a few weeks ago, Sidney Ganis, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, and Gilbert Cates, producer of the Oscar telecast, said they were going full steam ahead with Show A.

headline: Even-Paced Movements, Ranging From Hip-Hop to Ballet
text: Kota Yamazaki is one of the mysteries of dance in New York City. He has skittered across the aesthetic map in the 11 years that he has been presenting dance here, never quite settling convincingly into one style but being consistently chosen to perform in major theaters.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Tuesday about efforts to find the source of fake ingredients in Chinese antimalarial medicine misstated the official name of the geographic area of southern China where Guilin Pharmaceutical, a company that discovered the fakes in 2006, is based. It is the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous region; there is no Guangxi “Province.”

headline: McCain Calls for Obama to Use Public Financing
text: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Hammering Senator Barack Obama for a fourth straight day, Senator John McCain said here on Friday that he expects Senator Obama to abide by his pledge use public financing for his general election if Mr. McCain does so as well.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Selected Studies: Narcolepsy
text: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information about these and other trials: ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

headline: Meditating on History, Art, Paris and Berlin
text: “The Blue Flower,” a production by the Prospect Theater Company at the West End Theater, bites off a compelling chunk of the 20th century and presents it in a way that too often resembles a disjointed historical pageant: See Paris in the teens! The battlefields of World War I! Weimar Berlin!

headline: New Trouble in Auction-Rate Securities
text: SOME well-heeled investors got a big jolt from Goldman Sachs this week: Goldman, the most celebrated bank on Wall Street, refused to let them withdraw money from investments that they had considered as safe as cash.

headline: European Union Seeks Longer Music Copyrights
text: BRUSSELS  The European Union said Thursday that it would seek to extend copyright protection for singers and musicians to 95 years  rather than the current 50  in a move intended to let performers receive royalty payments later in life.

headline: A String of Campus Gun Rampages
text: If the news from DeKalb, Ill. — a gunman bursting into a college lecture hall, killing 5 students and wounding 16 more people in a fusillade of gunfire, then killing himself — gives you a sickening feeling of familiarity, you’ve been paying attention. The Northern Illinois University shooting rampage joins a string of similar incidents to hit the headlines in recent years — one of them less than a week ago.

headline: Adler Planetarium and Astronomy Museum
text: The Adler Planetarium's collection of remarkable globes, star charts and moon maps suggest that the modern planetarium is just another reflection of ancient cosmological impulses.

headline: Game of the Week: North Dakota-Denver
text: The W.C.H.A. is college hockey’s version of the SEC. It’s stacked. With seven teams in the top 20 nationally, every conference game from here on in will have an impact on postseason seeding. Among many high-profile matchups in the West this weekend, North Dakota playing host to Denver University for the first time since October 2005 is easily the biggest. With the teams separated by the slimmest of margins in the Pairwise rankings, this weekend’s big winner will inch that much closer to a No. 1 seeding in the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.

headline: Devean George Enters Maelstrom as He Rejects Trade
text: Devean George had a television camera trained on him as he entered U.S. Airways on Thursday night for the Dallas Mavericks' game against the Phoenix Suns. It was a surreal scene for George, who is used to blending into the background, on and off the court.

headline: Lampert Begins Breaking Up With Citi
text: For Edward S. Lampert, it appears the bloom is off the rose at Citigroup.

headline: Plan to Rescue Bond Insurers Is Outlined
text: The recapitalization of bond insurers hit by the subprime crisis may occur soon, but if it fails, insurers can be forced to separate riskier activities from their municipal bonds business, New York State officials said Thursday.

headline: ‘Like a Party at Elton John’s House’
text: Aired Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Valentine’s Day started out as an ancient Roman fertility festival. What would happen is a young nobleman would charge through the street naked, striking people with a leather thong for good luck. It is like a party at Elton John’s house.

headline: Deutsche Post Chief Under Tax Inquiry
text: German prosecutors accused one of the country’s most prominent business executives of tax evasion on Thursday after conducting early morning raids on his home and office.

headline: Microsoft Reassigns Several Top Executives
text: As it continues to push for its $44.6 billion unsolicited bid for Yahoo, Microsoft announced a sweeping shake-up of its executive ranks Thursday, placing new executives over operations facing fierce new competition from Google, Apple and cellphone makers.

headline: Investors Remain Wary of $19.5 Billion Clear Channel Buyout
text: Now that the $19.5 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications by Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners has cleared all the necessary regulator hurdles, attention is turning to the sale of debt necessary to finance the deal.

headline: Buffett Becomes Kraft’s Biggest Shareholder
text: Warren E. Buffett seems to like Nelson Peltz’s work.

headline: NYSE Euronext Takes Stake in Indian Exchange
text: NYSE Euronext, which owns the New York Stock Exchange and four European bourses, is picking up a 5 percent stake in the Multi Commodity Exchange of India for $55 million.

headline: ‘I Guess Things Didn’t Go Very Well’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: It’s Valentine’s Day. So if you’re watching this show right now — I guess things didn’t go very well.

headline: Bear Stearns Investigation Said to Center on Managers
text: A criminal investigation into the collapse of two Bear Stearns hedge funds could hinge on whether managers misled investors about the funds’ difficulties on a conference call last April, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: ‘Yes, Another Success Story for eHarmony.Com’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: You folks having a good Valentine’s Day? Then why are you here?

headline: ArcSight I.P.O. Fails to Thrill
text: Silicon Valley’s first initial public offering of the year landed with a thud Thursday.

headline: IDS Group Seeks to Raise $86 Million in I.P.O.
text: IDS Group, which provides software for financial institutions and equipment manufacturers, is planning an initial public stock offering that could raise $86.25 million.

headline: The Carpetbagger
text: David Carr (a.k.a. the Carpetbagger) takes a sneak peek at the menu for a party scheduled to take place at the Carlyle Hotel on Oscar night.

headline: New Trouble in Auction-Rate Securities
text: Some well-heeled investors got a big jolt from Goldman Sachs this week: Goldman, the most celebrated bank on Wall Street, refused to let them withdraw money from investments that they had considered as safe as cash.

headline: Inspector Specter
text: After the embarrassing episode on Capitol Hill on Wednesday, when many members of Congress seemed to take sides on the Clemens-McNamee affair based on party affiliation instead of on the merits of the case, N.F.L. fans are fortunate that they have an impartial arbiter looking into the N.F.L. spying scandal.

headline: French Trader’s Bets Said to Assure an Alarm
text: Someone well acquainted with the trading controls at Société Générale told The New York Times that it was “inconceivable” that Jérôme Kerviel’s immediate supervisors were not alerted after his trades set off alarm bells at Eurex, the derivatives exchange based in Frankfurt.

headline: Transcript: Q & A With Ben Shpigel
text: The Mets’ pitchers and catchers reported to spring training Thursday in Port St. Lucie, Florida. Ben Shpigel, The New York Times’s Mets beat writer has been there for a few days, updating fans here on the Bats blog and in The Times’s baseball coverage.

headline: Greenhill’s SPAC Prices at $10 Per Share
text: As scads of firms are pulling their initial public offerings due to volatile market conditions, yet another special purpose acquisition vehicle continued merrily on its way to market. The I.P.O. of GHL Acquisition Corporation, backed by the boutique merger advisory firm Greenhill & Company, priced late Thursday at $10 per unit, raising about $400 million before commissions and discounts.

headline: In Second Installment, Hollywood Producer Wins the Lightning
text: In what amounts to a rerun of sorts, Hollywood producer Oren Koules is again on the verge of purchasing pro hockey’s Tampa Bay Lightning four months after the original deal he was a part of fell through.

headline: Cerberus Sees Potential ‘Difficulty’ at GMAC
text: Cerberus Capital Management‘s Stephen Feinberg said in a letter to his fund’s investors that GMAC, the auto and mortgage lender that it controls, may run into “substantial difficulty” if credit markets don’t improve, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Thoma Cressy Takes Macrovision’s Software Unit
text: As Macrovision seeks to shore up support for its $2.8 billion Gemstar-TV Guide acquisition, the company announced on Thursday that it is selling its software business to a unit of private equity firm Thoma Cressey Bravo.

headline: ‘Hoo You Gonna Call It?
text: Where is it written that new-media leviathans shall have benign-sounding if not silly names? There’s Microsoft, Yahoo, Google and now, with the prospective combining of the first two, quite possibly Microhoo — yes, if the media have their way. Brings to mind the giant Stay Puft Marshmallow Man ravaging New York at the end of “Ghostbusters,” doesn’t it? Some recent indicators:

headline: Carlyle Unveils Wave of Promotions
text: The Carlyle Group has promoted 30 executives to senior positions in the company, eight to managing director – the most senior role below those of senior adviser, founder and chairman – and 22 to director.

headline: Avedro Scores $8 Million in First Round
text: Medical device maker Avedro has raised an $8 million round of venture capital funding, according to a federal filing.

headline: United, Continental Said to Hold Advanced Merger Talks
text: United Airlines is in advanced negotiations to combine with Houston-based Continental Airlines and is poised to quickly seal a deal if Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines merge, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Go Chelsea Football! A Soccer Stadium Tour
text: Last week I received an e-mail from a fellow Chelsea football (soccer) supporter, who now lives in France, inviting me to join him on a tour of Chelsea Football Club’s stadium. I jumped at the opportunity — particularly since I can no longer afford to go to matches; the cheapest tickets of this much loved team are around 50 pounds.

headline: UBS Stock Falls After Bearish Citi Report
text: Shares in UBS fell again on Friday as fears of more massive losses mounted after equity analysts at Citigroup said UBS could need up to $18 billion in additional write-downs in 2008, Reuters reported.

headline: Citi Said to Lock Down 2 Funds Amid Losses
text: Citigroup has barred investors in one of its hedge funds from withdrawing their money, and a new leveraged fund lost 52 percent in its first three months, The Wall Street Journal reported on Friday.

headline: Bear and Citic Said to Renegotiate Deal
text: Bear Stearns and Citic Securities, China’s largest investment bank, are discussing a “reciprocal adjustment” of the stake-swap deal they negotiated in October, when Bear’s stock was much higher, The Financial Times reported Friday, citing a person familiar with the matter. Under the new terms, Citic’s stake in Bear is likely to reach 9.9 percent, up from 6 percent under the October agreement.

headline: Love and Despair on the Battlefield
text: Prolific and famous in his own country, the Swedish playwright Lars Noren is hardly known here. The American premiere of his 2003 work “War,” at the Rattlestick Playwrights Theater, may not explain that difference, but it offers clues, beginning with a title that is both overreaching and basic to the point of blandness.

headline: The Early Word: Center Stage Wisconsin
text: Three of the top four presidential candidates will campaign across Wisconsin today, all hitting Milwaukee at some point, ahead of the state’s Tuesday primary.

headline: A Cast That Jumps Through Hoops
text: Is there anything they can’t do?

headline: An Epic of Blood and Oil
text: Watching “There Will Be Blood” in his bubble, unable to hear every word of dialogue or note of Johnny Greenwood’s much-lauded contemporary soundtrack, was a bit of a revelation to the Bagger. The experience helped explain why he was never knocked down by this movie like other, more learned colleagues.

headline: A Grainy Reality
text: There are some stunning, hallucinatory moments in “Sand,” Trista Baldwin’s three-actor play about American soldiers in an unnamed, Iraq-like war zone. Pedro Pascal as Armando, a sergeant and the senior of the three, at times smoothly shifts into the role of Ahmed, a Middle Eastern man  he may be real or imaginary  who wanders into the barren desert where the soldiers are guarding a gas pump. In these graceful dramatic turns the play suggests how the line between enemies, and even identity itself, shifts as easily as the sands for anyone in the surreal state of combat.

headline: Clues, but No Arrests Yet, in Killing of Psychologist
text: E-mail messages and phone records led detectives to a Pennsylvania man who was questioned for eight hours and then released as part of the investigation of the killing of an Upper East Side psychologist, Kathryn Faughey. The man, William Kunsman, had met Dr. Faughey and her husband at a guitar camp six years ago and had recent contact with her via e-mail, according to Al Baker. While newspapers observed that Mr. Kunsman had little resemblance to the man in the videotape (Mr. Kunsman appeared to have a full head of hair, while the killer had a bald spot), he had been identified in a picture lineup by Dr. Faughey’s colleague, Kent D. Shinbach, a psychiatrist who was in the office during the murder and was critically injured. A patient who was in the office and tried to stop the assailant as he was leaving did not identify Mr. Kunsman.

headline: Pushing on a string
text: Ben Bernanke has cut interest rates a lot since last summer. But can he make a difference? Or is he just, as the old line has it, pushing on a string?

headline: Gingrich’s Call for a Re-vote
text: Partisan Democrats may suspect his motives, but Newt Gingrich sounds sincere when he calls, on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, for a “do-over” in the Democratic primaries in Florida and Michigan.

headline: T Online | Our Oscar Picks
text: Lynn Hirschberg, T Magazine’s editor at large, has a remarkable nose for Oscar nods. She plays a featured role in selecting the actors and actresses who will be photographed for the covers of T’s fashion issues, then interviews them for the magazine and for T’s “Screentest” films. One of her criteria: Is their work in the coming season Oscar worthy? As the 10 covers shown on the new home page of our mothersite, nytimes.com/tmagazine, show, she’s frequently right. Among the T talent hoping for gold at the Hollywood ceremony on Sunday Feb. 24 are Marion Cotillard and Tilda Swinton. Good luck, ladies.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Chili Garlic Paste
text: It has a reputation for being one of the mysteries of international cuisine, but chili paste is really about as easy to make as applesauce. Take dried chilies, soak them until they are soft, combine them with a spice or two (or not) and purée.

And there will be no shortage of A-Listers.

headline: For the Moment | Defragmentation of Machine and Man
Nine Months of Rehab for ‘Il Fenomeno’
text: For the third time, AC Milan striker Ronaldo underwent knee surgery to repair a ruptured tendon. This time, doctors operated on his left knee (in 1999 and 2000, it was the right). The surgery “went well,” according to renowned French surgeon Dr. Gerard Saillant, who operated on Ronaldo eight years ago and oversaw the procedure performed by Dr. Eric Rolland on Thursday night in Paris.

headline: In Ozone Park, the Mob Ties That Bind
text: Standing in front of the old site of the Bergin Hunt and Fish Club in Ozone Park, Queens, you can see a few immediate differences between its appearance now and its appearance when it was home base for the John J. Gotti and his associates in the Gambino crime family. First, the space, at 98-04 101st Avenue, has been divided into two businesses, a medical supply store and a pet groomer, and it looks a lot more welcoming now than it used to. Second, there was some faded graffiti on the front of the building. That is the kind of thing, people in the neighborhood said this week, that would not have flown when Mr. Gotti, who died in prison in 2002, was still around.

headline: Can a Toyota Win the Daytona 500?

headline: Imagine Everyone Was Equal, in Emissions

headline: Bloomberg on Illegal Guns and Rampages
text: Updated, 1:38 p.m. | The morning after the shootings at Northern Illinois University, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg rattled off a grim list of gun rampages across the country that have left at least 18 people dead in February alone, not counting the gunmen who in some cases killed themselves or were killed by police. Mr. Bloomberg’s comments on his weekly radio call-in were part of his crusade to get illegal guns off the streets.“This month John, so far, has just been wretched,” the mayor told John Gambling, his host on WABC-AM (770). He said he had asked his press secretary, Stu Loeser “to get me a list of things that occurred just this month alone. Yesterday, Northern Illinois University, six people, another one died this morning, six people killed. Last Friday in Baton Rouge, a college student shot and killed two people then took his own life. Last Thursday, a gunman shot and killed five people in Kirkwood, Mo., in the City Hall, killed two City Council members and two police officers, and the mayor was very seriously wounded, and he’s hanging in there. And Feb. 2, just a week ago, in the Lane Bryant store in Illinois, a gunmen shot and killed five customers and employees, all in their 20s and 30s.” (The Lede blog has a list of recent campus rampages.)

headline: A (Red) Auction at Sotheby’s, to Raise the Stakes
text: Christy Turlington dropped $170,500 on a watercolor painting. Takashi Murakami nodded off briefly after his painting sold for $1.65 million. Bono rallied the Sotheby’s crowd for a sing-along to the Beatles’ “All You Need Is Love.” And a greater-than-projected $42 million was raised for the Global Fund to fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria through the sale of 82 works of art at the Product Red Sotheby’s auction on Thursday night. (The original somewhat conservative estimate was that the items would sell for a collective $21 million to $29 million.)
