headline: The Sound of Howl
text: The earliest known recording of Allen Ginsberg reading from his epic poem “Howl” has been found at Reed College in Portland, Ore., the British newspaper The Guardian reported. It had been thought that Ginsberg, right, first recorded the work in Berkeley, Calif., in March 1956. But according to The Oregonian, the recently discovered recording was made several weeks earlier. Ginsberg, having hitchhiked to Portland with his fellow Beat poet Gary Snyder in the winter of 1956, gave a reading at a student hostel, the Anna Mann Cottage, that was recorded on a reel-to-reel machine on Feb. 14. The tape was found by John Suiter, a biographer of Mr. Snyder, in a box in the college archives labeled “Snyder Ginsberg 1956.” It contained a 35-minute tape of Ginsberg reading the first section of “Howl” and other poems. The recordings can be heard at reed.edu.

headline: Running From Despair
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  On a cold Saturday morning last month, 16-year-old Chantel Hunt ran across a highway onto a gravel road where the snow under her shoes packed into washboard ripples. She ran around a towering red rock butte, past two old mattresses dumped on the roadside, and into the shadow of a mesa she sometimes runs on top of.

headline: Russia Warns It May Back Breakaway Republics in Georgia
text: MOSCOW  Russia held a high-level meeting with the leaders of two breakaway republics in Georgia on Friday, and vowed to increase its support for the separatists if Kosovo declared its independence and was recognized by the West.

headline: Vast Legal-Aid Fraud Laid to Two Brothers
text: DENVER  For years, people who dialed information asking for legal aid, in the hope of getting a lawyer who could help them at little or no charge, were frequently given phone numbers of two half brothers. The brothers, named Brown and White, claimed to provide authentic legal services but did not, and ran a “nonprofit” that was anything but, the Colorado attorney general says.

headline: The Mittification of McCain
text: As Mitt Romney said this week when he endorsed John McCain, the campaign might have been rough but “we always had good laughs together.” As examples of this hitherto-unnoticed good fellowship, Mitt pointed cheerily to the fact that he and McCain had shaken hands before the debates and “said hi to each others’ wives.”

headline: A Split-Up of Insurers of Bonds Is Considered
text: Regulators and bankers racing to bolster troubled bond insurance companies are considering splitting the firms into two parts: one for safe municipal debt and the other for riskier mortgage-related securities.

headline: Famous Fund Open Again. Is It a Buy?
text: FIDELITY INVESTMENTS is welcoming new shareholders into its venerable Magellan fund after shutting them out for a decade. With the fund’s asset base shrinking, it is a sensible move for Fidelity, but should you accept the invitation?

headline: Solo Flight on Feathered Wings and Bare Back
text: First came a cloud of dark, ratty tulle, just visible at a back corner in the dim light. Then a few patches of glowing skin were visible. By the time the apparition reached the other end of the stage, shedding bits of tulle like molting fur, a woman was emerging.

headline: In State Senate, Aging Fingers Cling to Power
text: ALBANY  Last year was a tough one for State Senator Caesar Trunzo.

headline: Surviving in Style
text: “Survivor: Micronesia” helped CBS draw the most viewers on Thursday night, though ABC fared better with adults 18 to 49. ABC also had the top-rated show, “Lost,” which led at 9 with 13.6 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. “Survivor” won the 8 o’clock time slot with 13.1 million viewers; NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” had 12 million. Trailing “Lost” at 9 were CBS’s “CSI” repeat (11 million) and NBC’s “Celebrity Apprentice” (9.1 million). NBC tied CBS for second among the 18-to-49 set and tied ABC for second in total viewers. Fox finished fourth over all.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Thursday about a British musician who fell down a flight of stairs and damaged his violin, using information from the London newspaper The Independent, misidentified the maker of the violin. He was Giovanni Battista Guadagnini, not Antonio Stradivari. The report also misstated the age of the violin. It is 236 years old, not 290.

headline: If Clemens Is Pursued, a Grand Jury Is Probable
text: WASHINGTON  If the Justice Department moves ahead with an investigation into Roger Clemens’s statements under oath to Congress over the last several weeks, federal authorities will probably convene a grand jury to delve deeper into Clemens’s possible links to performance-enhancing drugs and to question him more directly.

headline: Showtime’s Serial Killer Moves to CBS, to a Not Entirely Warm Welcome
text: “Dexter,” the Showtime series about a sympathetic-seeming serial killer, went under the knife ahead of its scheduled broadcast debut Sunday night on CBS. The curse words were replaced, and the most visible moments of gore were truncated.

headline: Suit Could Shed Light on Actions of Patriots
text: A former St. Louis Rams player and three fans filed a lawsuit against the Patriots and Coach Bill Belichick on Friday, saying that the Patriots fraudulently gained an unfair advantage by taping a Rams walk-through practice the day before the teams played in the Super Bowl in 2002.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some copies of the Arts & Leisure section this weekend about the state of public broadcasting misspells the surname of a host whose show is distributed by Public Radio International. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Meredith Monk, at Symphony Space, misstated the date of the second concert, at which two members of her group will present works of their own. As noted elsewhere in the entry, the concerts were scheduled for Friday night and next Thursday night  not Friday and today.

headline: Veterans’ Charities
text: To the Editor:

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Wednesday about the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to a Justice Department examination of a contract that he awarded to former Attorney General John Ashcroft, who had been his boss. It was reviewed by the department’s criminal division, not the office of inspector general. (No wrongdoing was found.)

headline: Worries on the Vine
text: IN the coming decades, might oenophiles be debating the subtle aromas and delicate flavors of all the great new wines coming out of Saskatchewan?

headline: Germany: German-Pakistani Accused of Supporting Al Qaeda
text: The police in the western state of Rhineland-Palatinate have arrested a German citizen of Pakistani origin on suspicion of acting as a courier of money, night-vision equipment and radios to Al Qaeda in the Afghan-Pakistani border area. The authorities said the suspect, Aleem Nasir, left, had taken four trips to the region from April 2005 to June 2007, carrying at least the equivalent of $5,800 in euros each time, and equipment on three occasions. According to the prosecutor’s statement, he also received explosives training and successfully recruited another German resident for the terrorist group in 2006. In an interview in September, Mr. Nasir denied any Qaeda ties and said he had confessed while being beaten by Pakistani agents. German officials warned last week that Qaeda commanders had ordered terrorist attacks against the country and were increasingly seeking to recruit German-speaking terrorists over the Internet.

headline: Suicide Blast at Campaign Rally in Pakistan Kills 37
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed a car into a campaign rally in the tribal areas on Saturday, killing 37 people and injuring 90 others, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: In San Jose, Disputes and Anger After Vote on Street Name
text: SAN JOSE, Calif.  Story Road, at first glance, is unremarkable. Often congested, it runs beneath a freeway, over railroad tracks and through acres of parking lots.

headline: More Than a Feeling
text: Tom Scholz, the chief songwriter and founder of the band Boston, has written to Mike Huckabee, complaining of his use of the group’s 1976 song “More Than a Feeling” in his presidential campaign without permission, The Associated Press reported. A former band member, Barry Goudreau, has played the song with Mr. Huckabee at campaign events. Mr. Scholz, who supports Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, for president, objects to the implication that the band has endorsed the candidacy of Mr. Huckabee, a Republican. “You have taken something of mine and used it to promote ideas to which I am opposed,” Mr. Scholz wrote. “In other words, I think I’ve been ripped off, dude!” In response, Fred Bramante, who was chairman of Mr. Huckabee’s New Hampshire primary campaign, said: “Governor Huckabee plays ‘Sweet Home Alabama.’ Does that mean Lynyrd Skynyrd is endorsing him?”

headline: Corrections
text: A chart in some editions on Feb. 6 about possible nominees for vice president referred imprecisely to the work that one of them does now. Tom Daschle, a former senator who has been a mentor to Senator Barack Obama, is a consultant on public policy in the Washington office of a law firm; he is not a lobbyist. (Go to Graphic)

headline: China’s Trade Surplus Jumps, but Imports Are Rising
text: BEIJING (AP)  China’s trade surplus grew by 22.7 percent in January over the same month last year as foreign demand for exports stayed strong despite worries about slowing global growth, according to data reported Friday.

headline: Love’s Labors Tossed and Turned in a Survey of the Heart’s Hard Edges
text: Anyone with a romantic streak will have room in his heart for various kinds of unhappy ending. The love that cannot succeed in this world, at which ballet can excel, is part of what romanticism is all about. In what kind of grim “but not for me” temper, though, did New York City Ballet assemble “Matters of the Heart” on Valentine’s Day?

headline: Kenya Peace Talks Stall on Power-Sharing Issues
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Despite soothing words from Kofi Annan, the former United Nations secretary general who is trying to mediate a solution to Kenya’s political crisis, one thing seemed clear on Friday: Kenya is stuck.

headline: The Workplace as Clubhouse
text: BOEING is known around the world for building jetliners, but in Washington State, it also has a reputation for turning out top winemakers.

headline: Just Click the Mouse. Follow the Cursor. You Are Calm. You Feel Good.
text: GREENVILLE, N.C.  The Psychophysiology and Biofeedback Laboratory at East Carolina University here is in the subterranean bowels of a former gymnasium, just down the hall from an old locker room that still smells faintly of feet.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Is Satire in a Slump? ‘Yes’ and ‘No’
text: For 36 hours, Marco Ceglie was holed up this week in a borrowed apartment off the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, his eyeballs pinned to a computer screen. He was editing videotape at a full-out sprint. There was not a minute to waste. A group of celebrities organized by the musician Will.i.am of the Black Eyed Peas had already turned a Barack Obama speech into a spoken-word music video, “Yes We Can.” It instantly became a digital hymn watched by zillions.

headline: Political Heir Is Less Rosy Than Putin on the State of Russia
text: MOSCOW  The presumptive successor to President Vladimir V. Putin presented his platform for seeking Russia’s highest office on Friday, giving a speech before business leaders in Siberia in which he vowed to continue Russia’s economic revival, but also struck markedly liberal notes.

headline: Fire Department Frees Boy Stuck in Jetty’s Rocks
text: A 14-year-old boy whose foot had gotten stuck in the rocks of a jetty about 100 yards from the northern end of Orchard Beach in the Bronx on Friday was rescued by Fire Department divers, the authorities said.

headline: Gates Foundation’s Influence Criticized
text: The chief of malaria for the World Health Organization has complained that the growing dominance of malaria research by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation risks stifling a diversity of views among scientists and wiping out the world health agency’s policy-making function.

headline: Training for Alaska, in New Jersey
text: BLAIRSTOWN, N.J. (AP)  A state known for the turnpike and an abundance of oil refineries is not the easiest place to pursue sled dog racing.

headline: The Caucus and I: Democracy and Doughnuts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Confidentiality Hinders Police in a Therapist’s Killing
text: As part of an expansive effort to catch a knife-wielding attacker, police officials confronted a thorny legal hurdle on Friday as they sought the medical records of an Upper East Side therapist who was slain and those of a colleague who was wounded rushing to her aid.

headline: Cruel and Gratuitous
text: It happened last spring.

headline: Uranium Mining Isn’t Safe
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Pakistan, Islam Needs Democracy
text: Islamabad, Pakistan

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a report in the “Arts, Briefly” column in Weekend on Friday about the response by the Broad Art Foundation to criticism that female and minority artists were inadequately represented in an exhibition at the new Broad Contemporary Art Museum at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art and in the collection of Eli Broad’s private foundation reversed the given name and surname of the foundation’s spokeswoman. She is Karen Denne.

headline: By Making Holocaust Personal to Pupils, Sarkozy Stirs Anger
text: PARIS  President Nicolas Sarkozy dropped an intellectual bombshell this week, surprising the nation and touching off waves of protest with his revision of the school curriculum: beginning next fall, he said, every fifth grader will have to learn the life story of one of the 11,000 French children killed by the Nazis in the Holocaust.

headline: Looking at the Stars From Angles Old and New
text: CHICAGO  There is something very simple, almost elemental, at stake as I sit in a wooden cart, and the machinery begins to grind. I am slowly lifted up a ramp until I reach the center of a hollow, darkened 15-foot sphere. When the noise from the gears below stops, another rumbling begins that is difficult to place. I am stationary but feel as if I am rotating, levitating in strange directions. When I look up at the 692 pinpoints of light in the metallic ceiling, I see they are revolving in a painted nighttime sky, lines joining them in simple constellations.

headline: To Retire Better Off, Wait a Bit
text: COULD the secret to having enough money in retirement be as simple as working a bit longer? Writing in AARP magazine, Jonathan D. Pond, a financial planner, argues yes.

headline: Indian Point: Safety Must Come First
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kidd Deal Not Dead, but Maybe on Life Support
text: NEW ORLEANS  Jason Kidd sliced through a mob of cameras, microphones and bodies, settled into a padded chair and tried to dispel the chaos with a simple three-word introduction: “I’m a Net.”

headline: Two Immortal Lovers Have a Rematch in Paris
text: PARIS  The German choreographer Pina Bausch is celebrated (and occasionally denounced) for her epic tragicomic productions, in which her performers speak as much as they dance, offering vignettes of human life and behavior that are absurd, uncomfortable and moving amid strange and powerful stage landscapes.

headline: In the Case of the Model vs. the Boxer, a Court Showdown That Wasn’t
text: This one you couldn’t miss. The press release was just too good.

headline: ‘The Rings’ Prompts a Long Legal Mire
text: LOS ANGELES  According to the legend, one ring ruled the rest, with cruelty, malice and a will to dominate all life. It has also provoked an awful lot of litigation.

headline: McCain and Obama Tussle Over Future Financing
text: OSHKOSH, Wis.  Senators Barack Obama and John McCain tussled directly Friday over how they will pay for their campaigns, with Mr. McCain challenging Mr. Obama to abide by his earlier pledge to use public financing for his general election if Mr. McCain does so as well.

headline: Bomb Kills Man on Street in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  One man died and two people were wounded when a bomb exploded on a sidewalk just 300 yards from this capital’s police headquarters on Friday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: At Berra Museum, the Display of Clemens’s Jersey Is Over
text: The Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center last week removed a Roger Clemens jersey from an exhibit about the Yankee renaissance that started in the mid-1990s.

headline: U.S. Struggles to Tutor Iraqis in Rule of Law
text: BAGHDAD  A mob had gathered by the time the F.B.I. agents arrived at the house where an assassin’s bomb killed nine people last year, narrowly missing a deputy prime minister. Fearing their own lives might be at risk, the agents gave themselves no more than 30 minutes to collect evidence.

headline: All-in-One Telecom Packages: The Savings Don’t Come Simple
text: This month, my husband and I decided to make a major move in our lives.

headline: Buy Less but Pay Lots More, and Get a Misleading Rise in Sales
text: FACED with tightening credit and a slowing economy, America’s consumers are being forced to scale back their purchases, but high prices of necessities are keeping their overall purchases rising at a reasonably strong rate.

headline: Super Bowl and Olympics: This Marketer’s Dream Year
text: THE ADIDAS GROUP of Germany, which owns the formerly independent Reebok, is using major athletic events like the Super Bowl and the Summer Olympics in its battle to catch up with and surpass Nike, says Herbert Hainer, chief executive of Adidas. Adidas, based in Bavaria, makes only 5 percent of its sales in Germany and uses English as its official language. Mr. Hainer was interviewed in New York. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Athlete Hit by Javelin Is Healthy, but Angry
text: On Friday the 13th in July, Tero Pitkamaki of Finland, one of the world’s best at what he does, rumbled forward and released his javelin during a Golden League meet in Rome. It sailed far off target to the left, and nearly 80 meters away it landed in the back of an unsuspecting long jumper, Salim Sdiri of France.

headline: Exploring Folk and Soft Rock and Discovering Pop Standards
text: Unfailingly demure, stalwartly upbeat and blessed with a vocal technique second to none, Maureen McGovern might be described as the Julie Andrews of the Love Generation. Because she has devoted most of the last 25 years to a pop-jazz, Broadway and light classical repertory, I hadn’t thought of her quite that way until her captivating new show, “A Long and Winding Road,” at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: Developer Holds Off Creditors, for Now
text: Harry Macklowe, the embattled billionaire developer who is struggling to hold on to his real estate empire, persuaded his two largest lenders not to foreclose on billions of dollars in property debts on Friday, even as prospective buyers submitted bids for his most treasured asset: the General Motors Building.

headline: Phoenix Police to Check Arrestees’ Immigrant Status
text: PHOENIX  The police in this city at the center of the immigration debate will soon ask all people arrested whether they are in the United States legally and will in certain cases report the information to the federal authorities, Mayor Phil Gordon announced on Friday.

headline: Bush and the Earmarks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption on Friday with an article about Representative John Lewis’s possible shift of support from Hillary Rodham Clinton to Barack Obama misstated, in some editions, the day that the photograph of Mrs. Clinton holding boxing gloves was taken. It was Thursday, not Wednesday.

headline: Judges Asked to Widen Inquiry at French Bank
text: PARIS  A lawyer representing Société Générale shareholders asked judges on Friday to interview an immediate supervisor of Jérôme Kerviel, the trader the bank blames for billions of euros in losses from unauthorized trades, to try to determine when his superiors were first alerted to his actions.

headline: Gnarls Is Back
text: Gnarls Barkley, the duo consisting of Danger Mouse and Cee-Lo, has set April 8 as the release date for “The Odd Couple” (Atlantic), the follow-up to its platinum-selling, Grammy-winning 2006 debut album, “St. Elsewhere,” Billboard reported. The two plan to support the album with a summer tour.

headline: Nebraska’s Electric Chair
text: To the Editor:

headline: 4 Officers Charged After a Brawl in Yonkers
text: WHITE PLAINS  Four New York City police officers were charged Friday over their roles in a late-night brawl in Yonkers in September in which a man suffered a cracked skull outside a strip of Irish pubs.

headline: Brooklyn Scholars
text: The Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday announced the creation of the Samuel H. Scripps BAM Scholarship Fund, for students who pursue a higher education in arts administration, dance or theater. Awards will range from $4,500 to $20,000 and are open to any student who has taken part in the academy’s education program between kindergarten and the 12th grade. Roughly $45,000 will be disbursed yearly. Application details are at bam.org.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Talks Policy in Obama Territory
text: The question was one she had heard before, but this time it was asked in downright hostile terms.

headline: Universal Royalty Suit
text: The estates of some of American music’s biggest names, including Count Basie, Benny Goodman and Sarah Vaughan, have sued Universal Music Group for more than $6 million, claiming the company cheated them out of royalties, The Associated Press reported. The lawsuit, which was also filed on behalf of some living artists, asserts that the company withheld record royalties, engaged in self-serving schemes with record clubs and suppressed payments from Apple’s iTunes and other digital distributors. The court papers accuse Universal of breach of contract, breach of fiduciary duty and unjust enrichment. The 14 plaintiffs are Patti Page, Tony Martin, Dick Hyman, Richard Hayman, Kitty Kallen and the estates of Basie, Goodman, Vaughan, Woody Herman, Les Brown, the Mills Brothers, Jerry Murad, Frankie Laine and the gospel singer Sister Rosetta Tharpe. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, says Universal has been using questionable accounting practices since at least 1998. “We believe that these claims are baseless, and we are confident that we will prevail in court,” said Peter Lofrumento, a spokesman for the Universal Music Group.

headline: China Didn’t Check Drug Supplier, Files Show
text: A Chinese factory that supplies much of the active ingredient for a brand of a blood thinner that has been linked to four deaths in the United States is not certified by China’s drug regulators to make pharmaceutical products, according to records and interviews.

headline: Parks Worker Is Charged With Trying to Kill Birds
text: Around 3 p.m. on Friday, several people walking in Battery Park called 911 to report curious goings-on: a man driving a Parks Department golf cart was tearing erratically through a city park at 1 Whitehall Street.

headline: Reading the Discards Helps Israel to Another Victory in Japan
text: The 13th NEC Cup Bridge Festival ended on Sunday in Yokohama, Japan. For the fourth time in five years, Israel won, its team being Migry Zur Campanile, Michael Barel and Doron and Israel Yadlin, who are brothers.

headline: Bush Proposes Linking the Medicare Drug Premium to Beneficiaries’ Income
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush proposed legislation on Friday to increase prescription drug premiums for higher-income Medicare beneficiaries.

headline: Yankees Come and Go, but One Thing Remains
text: TAMPA, Fla.  When the Yankees’ pitchers and catchers gathered in right field to begin their first spring training workout, so much was new. The Yankees have a new manager in Joe Girardi and several new coaches; it was the start of a new season; and, in an office four floors above the field, they have a new leading voice in Hank Steinbrenner.

headline: Steve Fossett, Missing Adventurer, Is Declared Dead at 63
text: Steve Fossett, the wealthy, record-setting adventurer who for years blithely sailed, soared and drove through all manner of danger before disappearing in September during what was meant to be a routine short flight, was declared dead Friday by a Chicago court. He was 63, and had homes in Chicago; Beaver Creek, Colo.; and Carmel, Calif.

headline: For ‘EcoMoms,’ Saving Earth Begins at Home
text: SAN RAFAEL, Calif.  The women gathered in the airy living room, wine poured and pleasantries exchanged. In no time, the conversation turned lively  not about the literary merits of Geraldine Brooks or Cormac McCarthy but the pitfalls of antibacterial hand sanitizers and how to retool the laundry using only cold water and biodegradable detergent during non-prime-time energy hours (after 7 p.m.).

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A Public Lives profile in some editions on Friday about Michael Winship, the president of the Writers Guild of America East, misstated the purpose of a union vote on Tuesday night. The vote was to decide whether to end the strike; it was not to ratify a contract.

headline: Prosecutor, Under Fire, Steps Down in Houston
text: HOUSTON  Besieged by an e-mail scandal and perjury accusations, Texas’s most powerful prosecutor resigned on Friday, saying that a combination of prescription drugs had “caused some impairment in my judgment.”

headline: River of Danger, River of Peace
text: MANAUS, Brazil  For several miles flying northwest in a small plane out of this city in the northern part of Brazil, where the Rio Negro and the Rio Salimoes meet to form the Amazon River, there was evidence of humans: the cutting of forests, clearings with crops, buildings and roads. But then, suddenly, as if we had left a coastal city for the ocean, the development ceased.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Thursday about a new soul food museum in Atlanta referred incorrectly to Smokey Robinson’s Seafood Gumbo, a product on display at the museum. It is frozen gumbo, not a gumbo mix.

headline: A Fighting Chance?
text: There seems to be no end to the Big Three automakers’ woes. This week, General Motors offered a new buyout plan to its 74,000 unionized workers in the United States  those who didn’t take the 2006 buyout offer. The Ford Motor Company and Chrysler also have plans to buy out thousands of employees. Still, there is a glimmer of hope: the companies plan to hire new workers to replace at least some, and perhaps a substantial share, of those they let go.

headline: A Single-Payer Health System
text: To the Editor:

headline: After Slow January, Best Buy Lowers Forecast
text: MINNEAPOLIS (AP)  Best Buy said on Friday that its annual profit would be smaller than expected, hurt by a slowing economy as shoppers held back on purchasing TVs, digital music players and cameras.

headline: Favorite in ’08? Look to ’07 and ’06
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  On the way to winning consecutive championships in the Nascar Cup series, Jimmie Johnson has made a place for himself in stock car racing’s record book. In 2006, he became the only driver to win the Daytona 500, the Allstate 400 at the Brickyard, the All-Star race and the Cup championship in the same year.

headline: Defense Opens Its Case in Beating Death of Girl
text: Cesar Rodriguez has admitted brutalizing his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown  beating her with his hands and a belt, plunging her head into cold water, lashing her to a wooden chair to discipline her, and finally leaving her, naked and starving, on a cold floor.

headline: F.D.A. Seeks to Broaden Range of Use for Drugs
text: WASHINGTON  When federal drug regulators approve a medicine for sale, they limit how drug makers sell it. A drug approved to treat only breast cancer cannot be marketed for lung cancer even if some studies suggest that the medicine may save lung patients.

headline: Whither the Corsets of Yesteryear?
text: The BBC’s historical costume and wigs department has been forced to shut down after a deal to sell the department to a rival props company collapsed, The Times of London reported. The failure of the sale, part of a cost-saving drive, has created a crisis for period-drama productions. The BBC’s costume vault houses about one million outfits and 12,000 hairpieces. But BBC Resources, as the operation is called, has announced that it is shutting down. The costumes and wigs will be moved from London to Oxford and held in storage until their future becomes clear. The shutdown comes after the BBC announced a series of period pieces, including productions of “Tess of the D’Urbervilles” and “Little Dorrit.” A permanent closing would also hit film production. Sofia Coppola’s 2006 film “Marie Antoinette,” which won the Oscar for costume design, used 400 items rented from the department.

headline: Taps for HD DVD as Wal-Mart Backs Blu-ray
text: SAN FRANCISCO  HD DVD, the beloved format of Toshiba and three Hollywood studios, died Friday after a brief illness. The cause of death was determined to be the decision by Wal-Mart to stock only high-definition DVDs and players using the Blu-ray format.

headline: 17,000 Child Care Providers Joining Union
text: About 17,000 home-based child care providers will join the Civil Service Employees Association as a result of a lopsided pro-union vote, state officials said Friday.

headline: An Iranian Revolutionary, Dismayed but Unbowed
text: TEHRAN

headline: Blast at House in Gaza Kills Militant and 5 Others
text: JERUSALEM  A senior military commander of the radical Islamic Jihad movement was killed Friday night along with at least five others as a powerful explosion destroyed his house in Gaza, but the Israeli military denied having anything to do with the blast.

headline: Randolph Confident Mets Can Kick ‘Funk’
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  His funk, as Willie Randolph called it, set in immediately after the Mets’ meltdown in September. It lingered as his job security dangled for 24 hours, then as the leaves changed colors, as he cut the Thanksgiving turkey and as he opened presents on Christmas. It continued as he rang in 2008 and even into the last few weeks, when the acquisition of an ace, Johan Santana, temporarily brightened his mood.

headline: Bush, in Africa, Emphasizes Successes
text: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  Opening a six-day tour of Africa, President Bush on Saturday defended his decision not to visit violence-stricken nations like Kenya and Sudan, saying he wanted to focus on his programs to fight AIDS and malaria instead.

headline: Sharp Exchanges Over Surveillance Law
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush and House Democrats on Friday traded another round of angry words over whether to grant immunity to telecommunications companies that aided the Bush administration’s terrorist surveillance program by providing private data without warrants after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Religious Right May Be Fading, but Not the ‘Culture Wars’
text: On every side, one can read obituaries for the religious right.

headline: Data Shows Struggling Manufacturers, Costly Imports and Gloomier Consumers
text: A fresh batch of data released on Friday revealed an economy in distress, as manufacturers struggled, import prices rose, and consumer confidence continued to erode.

headline: Zimbabwe: Opposition Faction Backs Mugabe Challenger
text: Arthur Mutambara, the leader of a breakaway faction of the opposition Movement for Democratic Change, announced that he would support Simba Makoni, a former finance minister, in the March 29 presidential election. Mr. Makoni is himself a breakaway candidate, having defied the ruling ZANU-PF party and the country’s longtime president, Robert G. Mugabe, in order to run. “Makoni has shown great courage in standing up to Mugabe,” Mr. Mutambara told reporters. His backing makes it a three-man race among Mr. Mugabe, seeking a sixth term, Mr. Makoni, and Morgan Tsvangirai, the leader of the dominant faction of the M.D.C.

headline: Gunman Showed Few Hints of Trouble
text: DeKALB, Ill.  Steve Kazmierczak, the man who walked silently into a classroom here on Thursday and opened fire, was not seen as struggling in college. He was not an outcast. And until recently, at least, he was not brooding.

headline: Queens Man Arrested in Killing of Therapist
text: The police arrested a Queens man Saturday afternoon in connection with the murder of a psychologist on the Upper East Side, commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said in a news conference at police headquarters.

headline: Abortion Law Is Suddenly a Pivotal Issue in Italy’s Elections
text: ROME  With voting less than two months away, a bitter debate over abortion has unexpectedly flared up, putting the issue at the center of the Italian electoral campaign.

headline: Where’s the Beef? PETA Has Sent Treats
text: Roger Clemens has been called a steroid user, a hothead and a liar over the last two months, and he has denied them all.

headline: As Kosovo Rebuilds, U.N. Hurries to Return Property
text: GJILAN, Kosovo  The 9-year-old ethnic Albanian boy screamed until he was red in the face, pounding his fists on the door of a small concrete house that only minutes before he had called home.

headline: Democrats Look for Way to Avoid Convention Rift
text: Former Vice President Al Gore and a number of other senior Democrats plan to remain neutral for now in the presidential race in part to keep open the option to broker a peaceful resolution to what they fear could be a bitterly divided convention, party officials and aides said Friday.

headline: Reyes Happy the Mets Didn’t Give Up on Him
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It’s one of the tried-and-true realities of life in the Mets’ clubhouse. Looking for José Reyes? Just find the loudest shirt, and there he is.

headline: Eritrea: U.N. Protests Thwarting of Peacekeepers
text: In a rare rebuke of an individual nation, the United Nations Security Council “strongly condemned” Eritrea for obstructing the peacekeeping mission on its disputed border with Ethiopia, and Secretary General Ban Ki-moon demanded an immediate end to what he described as Eritrea’s threats, seizures of equipment and denial of food and fuel to the 1,200 peacekeepers there. “We are in a situation where it is getting harder to stay and harder to leave, and that’s untenable,” said Jean-Marie Guéhenno, the under secretary general for peacekeeping.

headline: For a Better E.R.
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wars Past and Present, Rockers Evergreen
text: BERLIN  In 1970 the Berlin International Film Festival ground to a halt over a movie about American wartime atrocities. “O. K.,” a film by the German director Michael Verhoeven, dramatized an actual event that had made headlines a few years earlier: the rape and murder of a Vietnamese girl by a group of American soldiers. (The incident later inspired Brian De Palma’s “Casualties of War.”) After the movie’s premiere, some members of the jury, led by the American director George Stevens, called it incendiary and demanded that it be pulled from the competition. The ensuing uproar  a flurry of protests, resignations and canceled screenings  was enough to shut down the festival.

headline: Joyously Leaping From Earthy to Spiritual
text: Ronald K. Brown’s repertory program, presented at the Joyce Theater on Thursday as an alternative to his evening-length “One Shot,” is something of a primer to his magnificently textured style, which shifts from earthy, raw-powered movement to jumps that send dancers sailing into the air like spirits. It’s the sort of metamorphosis that occurs within a single phrase.

headline: Conflict on the Menu
text: New York City’s new rules for menu labels at chain restaurants have set off a food fight among the nation’s obesity experts.

headline: Read Their Lips
text: A year ago, before Barack Obama’s prodigious fund-raising powers were clocked in at $1 million a day, the senator made a great show out of raising a good idea: He would take the narrower road of public financing in the general election if he secured the nomination and his opponent did the same. Senator John McCain, then a long shot, agreed. Mr. Obama even secured a ruling from the Federal Election Commission that he could return unused private donations and then accept public financing.

headline: ‘Present’ Perfect
text: Chicago

headline: Imprisoned, Rabbi Sues Over Space for Prayer
text: A Hasidic rabbi serving time at a federal penitentiary is suing the Bureau of Prisons to change its policy on where inmates can pray.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Thursday about a decision by the owner of the General Motors building in Manhattan to license naming rights for the tower misstated the name of the building where Bloomberg LP has its headquarters. Its official name is 731 Lexington Avenue; it is not named after the company.

headline: Presidential Politics and Support for Israel
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Wednesday about Russian politics misstated the reason that President Vladimir Putin closed the European University of St. Petersburg. Mr. Putin accused the university of being an agent of foreign meddling. The university did not criticize Mr. Putin.

headline: In Calmer Newark, the Unease Persists
text: NEWARK  The police say the streets here are quieter, with less shooting, fewer assaults and no killings since Jan. 13. But J. D. Crowder, whose son was murdered by robbers two years ago, still has trouble believing that anything has changed.

headline: A Muslim and a Hindu. Let’s Dance.
text: They may not make ’em like they used to in Hollywood, but sometimes in India they still do. “Jodhaa Akbar,” a historical romance directed by Ashutosh Gowariker, is filmmaking on the grand scale of Cecil B. DeMille, with romance, stirring battles, a cast of thousands and enough elephants and gold to sink the Titanic.

headline: An Auction for Love and for Money
text: A Valentine’s Day charity auction at Sotheby’s in New York raised more than $42.5 million to benefit H.I.V./AIDS relief programs in Africa, far above the presale estimate of about $29 million, The Associated Press reported. Organized by Sotheby’s, Bono, Damien Hirst (whose “Where There’s a Will There’s a Way,” above, was among the works sold) and the Gagosian Gallery, the event set sale records for 17 artists, including Howard Hodgkin, Marc Quinn and Keith Tyson, and included pieces by Jasper Johns, Jeff Koons and Ed Ruscha. Proceeds will go the United Nations Foundation and will support programs run by the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria.

headline: Wang to Earn $4 Million After Arbitration Loss
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Chien-Ming Wang experienced his first loss since a forgettable postseason Friday when he lost his arbitration case to the Yankees. Wang, who had been seeking $4.6 million this season, will earn $4 million, the amount the Yankees offered him.

headline: Unofficial Tallies in City Understated Obama Vote
text: Black voters are heavily represented in the 94th Election District in Harlem’s 70th Assembly District. Yet according to the unofficial results from the New York Democratic primary last week, not a single vote in the district was cast for Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Reforming the Mining Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture in some editions last Saturday with a sports article about Trindon Holliday, a world-class sprinter who plays football at Louisiana State University, was published in error. The photograph, supplied by Getty Images, was of Early Doucet, another player  not Mr. Holliday.

headline: Taking Aim at a Disabled Satellite
text: The United States has given a plausible reason for wanting to shoot down an errant spy satellite before it can tumble to Earth and release potentially harmful gas near the impact point. But that hasn’t calmed suspicions that what the Bush administration really wants to do is test its capacity for waging anti-satellite warfare.

headline: Headlong Rush for All Occasions
text: Joshua Bell, the young violinist, is one of American classical music’s continuing success stories. He is everywhere, doing everything, and people want to come and hear him play. Carnegie Hall’s 2,800 seats looked pretty much filled on Thursday night when he and his regular partner, Jeremy Denk, played a violin and piano recital. There were no surprises on this program of Tartini, Prokofiev, Dvorak and Grieg, but no one seemed to miss having them.

headline: Spears's Father in Control
text: A court has ruled that Jamie Spears, the father of Britney Spears, will retain control over her affairs for about three more weeks, Reuters reported. Mr. Spears was granted temporary conservatorship over his daughter’s affairs two weeks ago when she was in a Los Angeles hospital for psychiatric evaluation. Los Angeles Court Commissioner Reva Goetz has extended that conservatorship, giving Mr. Spears control over her business, finances and some personal affairs until March 10.

headline: Congress and Consumer Safety
text: To the Editor:

headline: Too Soon to Say Israel Has ‘Won’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Unanswered Questions Make a Goodbye More Painful
text: Mourners at Kathryn Faughey’s wake on Friday afternoon were by turns angry, apprehensive and generally bewildered by the gruesome circumstances of her killing and the fact that it remained unsolved nearly three days after it occurred.

headline: Grief and Questions After Deadly Shootings
text: DeKALB, Ill.  The day after five students were gunned down in an afternoon science class on the campus of Northern Illinois University here, survivors struggled to manage their grief as the authorities released more details about the shooting and the gunman.

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: The Mittification of McCain
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 16 column.

text: Earlier editions of this article failed to disclose that the author serves as an informal adviser to the Obama campaign.

headline: Jozy Altidore: Some Welcome Time Off
text: Red Bulls forward Jozy Altidore, who contributes items for The New York Times Goal blog, is back home in South Florida as the New York Red Bulls wrap up their two-week training session at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. Altidore is resting and preparing for his next trip … to Austria with the club the last week in February.

text: Correction Appended

headline: The Early Word: Superdelegate Dilemma
text: There are superdelegates, and then there are super-duper delegates. Well, among the Democrats, there’s one. His name is Al Gore. And party leaders wringing their hands over the nomination process are ringing the party’s most prominent neutral figure. Don Van Natta Jr. and Jo Becker report:

headline: Defining the macroeconomic problem
text: As we debate interest rates, fiscal stimulus and all that, I thought it might be worth backing up to think about what our macroeconomic problem is right now.

headline: In Berlin
text: Images from the films and from the red carpet of the Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Why Ovechkin, Lecavalier and Kovalchuk Can’t Win
text: Ever wonder why some of those Southeast Division teams are so bad? Why the Capitals, with the great Alex Ovechkin, are sub-.500? Or why Tampa, with the incandescent Vincent Lecavalier and Martin St. Louis, lose more often than they win? And how about Atlanta, with the magical Ilya Kovalchuk? With such great scoring stars, why do these teams have so much trouble winning?

headline: The good sense of GP2 in Asia
text: The first few times I heard about the GP2 Asia series, my eyes glazed over. Wasn’t one GP2 series enough? (Or maybe even too much?!) Slowly, though, it has begun to break into my conciousness, and I have suddenly seen how interesting and important this series is, maybe even more so than the original GP2 series.

headline: Rangers Return From Hiatus, With Shanahan
text: The Rangers’ strange schedule quirk comes to a close Saturday with a home game against Buffalo after five idle days of watching teams in the Eastern Conference catch up to them and knock them back to ninth place.

headline: Round 2 in Wisconsin: Obama Smacks Back
text: Updated How many rounds can the Democratic rivals go before Tuesday’s primary in Wisconsin?

headline: The Final Word?
text: In what might amount to a final comment on the partisan nature of Wednesday’s Congressional hearing, Representative Darrell Issa, a Republican from California, fired back Friday at Henry A. Waxman, chairman of the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform.

headline: The Station Survivors, 5 Years Later
text: Offers of help to the victims of a fire that killed 100 have all but disappeared.

headline: Finding a New Big Name for M.L.S.
text: When the Major League Soccer season begins March 29, there will be four players earning more than the league’s maximum salary of $400,000 and carrying the designated player tag reserved for mostly foreign superstars.

headline: Mercury in Fish: Two Views
text: Philippe Grandjean is adjunct professor of environmental health at Harvard University’s School of Public Health and chairman of the department of environmental medicine at the University of Southern Denmark. Dariush Mozaffarian is assistant professor of epidemiology at the Harvard School of Public Health.

headline: Road Trip: Surreal Night
text: FAIRLEE, Vt. — The whole thing played out in fast forward, yet it seemed like slow motion. Down 5 points with less than 30 seconds remaining, Cornell stunned Harvard by rattling off three consecutive baskets to win, 72-71. The surreal finish, however, soon met a harsh reality.

headline: Elegy for a Vanishing Pastime
text: When Charles McGrath writes about pond hockey, we listen.

headline: How Would Darwin Read?
text: Popular books applying Darwinian logic to everything from religion to dating to dealmaking may fly off the shelves, but attempts to apply evolutionary theory to literary analysis tend to make novelists, English professors and other humanist types break out in hives.

headline: Road Trip: Grand Larceny
text: FAIRLEE, Vt. –- There are certain moments in sports, indelible times from improbable games that resonate for years. For Cornell, its 72-71 victory at Harvard on Friday night was the type of game that the Big Red players and coaches will talk about long after graduation.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Saturday, Feb. 16:

headline: Girardi Nets Rangers’ Latest Contract Extension
text: The Rangers announced during the Rangers’ game against Buffalo that defenseman Dan Girardi had signed a two-year contract extension, prompting the question of when exactly Girardi signed the extension. Between shifts, perhaps?

headline: Prologue
text: Welcome back to the Reading Room! So far, we’ve discussed three works that would be strong contenders for any Great Books survey (you can revisit the conversations by clicking the links at right). This time around, we’re trying an instant classic.

headline: ‘They Leap to Embrace the Unknown’
text: “The Majlis” continues the conversation started by The Times’s series “Generation Faithful,” which began today with “Dreams Stifled, Egypt’s Young Turn to Islamic Fervor.” Commenting on the article is Osama Anwar Okasha, a leading Egyptian television script writer responsible for among the most popular Arabic language miniseries. His shows are known for examining a variety of complex social issues in Egypt and across the Arab world. He spoke in Arabic to Mona el-Naggar, a researcher-reporter in The Times’s Cairo bureau.

headline: What the Generation in Question Thinks
text: “The Majlis” refers to a group of people sitting down together to talk, informally or formally, or where they meet. These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in “Generation Faithful,” a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the “Stalled Lives” of Egypt’s young, and the initial “Majlis” entries are from the staff of The Times’ Cairo bureau.

headline: ‘Don’t Worry About Mitt’
text: Aired Friday night on CBS: President Bush says if John McCain is the Republican nominee, he will campaign for him. Well, you can’t do better than that. Top 10 List.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Feb. 17
text: Surrogates dominate this Sunday’s breakfast menu.

headline: ‘Close Friends Since the Civil War’
text: Aired Friday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: Former President George H.W. Bush will endorse Senator John McCain for president. They have been close friends since the Civil War and the former president says that John McCainis the only candidate who has the strength, the leadership and the vision to dig America out of this giant hole his son has put us in.

headline: ‘Same Reason Al Gore Didn’t Run for President’
text: More of your “late night” comedy (send via the comment link below):

headline: Pinhead or Partiot? ‘Why Can’t You Be Both?’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Yesterday appearing on stage together in Boston, Mitt Romney endorsed John McCain. You see that picture? You see him standing there? Looked like the head of Leisure World giving out an award to the senior shuffleboard champion. You know something? I don’t think there’s been a more uncomfortable embrace between two politicians since the last time Bill hugged Hillary.

headline: Literary Evolution
text: There was a time — in distant history to you and me, but to those who lived through that time very much a modern one — when, with nothing more than quill, parchment, gaslight and inkwell, Victorians, as they were called then, who thought themselves clever enough to take up the mighty yoke of language, crafted marvelous, dignified, soaring, melodic sentences that danced about the periphery of comprehension, through the very soul of the English language, down so many twists and turns and inlets and eddies that a reader, inundated by an onslaught of language as such, would be forced to compose himself and begin the tedious, but ultimately rewarding, process of returning to the start of such a sentence and piecing its meaning together word by word, clause by clause, until said reader felt satisfied and knowledgeable of the material written therein.

headline: A Sabres Audition That Flops
text: There were roughly a dozen N.H.L. scouts at the Rangers-Sabres game at Madison Square Garden Saturday afternoon and presumably some of them came to watch Sabres defenseman Brian Campbell as the trade deadline approaches.

headline: Road Trip: Midnight Run
text: HANOVER, N.H. –- The most important person in the Cornell traveling party isn’t Coach Steve Donahue, star guard Louis Dale or even the trainer Marc Chamberlain.

headline: Road Trip: The Tension Mounts
text: HANOVER, N.H. – Cornell Coach Steve Donahue gathered his team at halfcourt at their afternoon shootaround. His message typified the focused and straightforward demeanor he’s held on this weekend road trip.

headline: Kitchen Ambition
text: After immigrating to New York at 14, Domingo Torres washed dishes in the East Village. He is now a chef at two of the city's popular Mexican restaurants.

headline: Hello Bobby?
text: Kelvin Sampson’s troubles at Indiana have been a boon for conspiracy theorists.

headline: Road Trip: A Telling Message
text: HANOVER, N.H. — We got to see both sides of Cornell Coach Steve Donahue in the first half, as the Big Red leads by 36-35 at halftime. Donahue left the floor steaming mad after a turnover in the waning seconds allowed Dartmouth’s DeVon Mosley to bank in a 23-foot 3-pointer at the buzzer to cut the lead to a point.

headline: 10 Shots for the Thrashers — in the Entire Game
text: We don’t mean to harp endlessly on how bad the Southeast Division is, but tonight the Atlanta Thrashers lost on Long Island, 4-1, giving up 49 shots on goal while managing only 10 shots of their own in the entire game.

headline: Huckabee’s Island Getaway
text: GRAND CAYMAN, Cayman Islands — Mike Huckabee said he was having such a good time here in this sun-splashed tourist resort that it may take a S.W.A.T. team to get him out of his hotel room at the Ritz Carlton and head back to the snowy campaign trail in Wisconsin.

headline: Road Trip: On The Road Again
text: HANOVER, N.H. — There’s a strict rule on Cornell road trips: No movies on the team bus after a loss.

headline: More Fallout From Scott’s Recruitment
text: The Colorado recruit Darrell Scott and his mother are optimistic that St. Bonaventure High School’s firing of the recruiting coordinator Roger Sonsini will serve as a warning to other high school coaches.

headline: How the ‘Guaranteed Point’ Is Ruining the N.H.L.
text: The NHL’s system of awarding points in the standings is weird enough, but now players and coaches are saying it’s making them take it easy in the third period of close games. Our own Dave Caldwell has the story here.

headline: Audiotape in Murder Is Reported as Missing
text: A New York police officer who was translating wiretapped conversations in a case against a Queens doctor charged in the killing of her estranged husband, a dentist, is under investigation because one of the tapes is missing, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Correction: Cutting to the Quick
text: The Fair Game column last Sunday, about loan losses at Citibank during the 1990 recession, misstated the history of stock prices for the bank’s parent, then called Citicorp. The stock traded as low as $11.125 in October 1990, not $1.39. After the Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates, the price rose to $15.625, not $2.50, by March 6, 1991; it climbed to $67.25, not $10, by the end of 1995. (The lower prices were for Travelers, a company that later merged with Citicorp.)

headline: A Delicate Market
text: KIRK HENCKELS, the bow-tie-wearing broker serving the rich and would-be rich on the Upper East Side, offered a sobering thought in his latest report on the luxury Manhattan market.

headline: Honey-Lacquered | New Places in a Genteel Quarter
text: If you’re looking for a hot new restaurant, the East 60s may not spring to mind, but these recently opened places fit this quiet, upscale neighborhood like a satin glove.

headline: In the Eye of the Beholder: When a Boom Begins
text: AS Bill Clinton was the first baby boomer president, Barack Obama could be the first Generation X president.

headline: Slavery as Seen From the Other Side
text: BIYI BANDELE comes bearing human cargo.

headline: I Married a Republican: There, I Said It
text: IT was happening again. I was at a cocktail party where the hosts were people I had just met, people I wanted to become friends with, and was sipping chardonnay and nibbling papadum chips when a woman said, “Oh, the people next door! They’re ...,” she paused and lowered her voice, “ ... Republican.”

headline: Stern Says Relocation of Sonics Is an ‘Inevitability’
text: NEW ORLEANS  A prolonged legal and political battle to keep the SuperSonics in Seattle is all but over, and the result almost assured: the Sonics will be leaving, and only the timing of their move is in question.

headline: Hail, and Welcome
text: The nods towards suburbanization  the kids’ menu, the addition of gooey brownies and espresso that invite you to linger  are here. But they’re not what you notice right away about Hale and Hearty’s first foray into the land of strip malls and superstores. And they’re definitely not the first things you’re going to appreciate about the Manhattan-based chain’s Livingston location, which opened Feb. 4 and shares sidewalk space, somewhat unappealingly, with a Men’s Wearhouse off Route 10.

headline: The Lemur
text: Chapter 6: All Hands

headline: Jitters for First-Time Homebuyers
text: IF there is a bright spot in New York City’s uncertain real estate market, it is that over the last several months, some first-time buyers have found it easier to buy apartments.

headline: Anna Kohanski, Jordan Klein
text: Anna Leah Kohanski, the daughter of Cheryl Spielman Bari of Englewood, N.J., and Ronald Kohanski of Columbia, Md., is to be married on Sunday to Jordan Scott Klein, a son of Carol Klein and Dr. Howard Klein, both of Louisville, Ky. Rabbi Irving Spielman, the bride’s maternal grandfather, will officiate at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Urban Gumbo
text: In August 1769, a fleet of 12 Spanish ships carrying 2,000 troops sailed into the port of New Orleans. Alejandro O’Reilly, a Dublin-born officer of the Spanish military, was sent there to punish the rebellious leaders of a French town that had recently become a property of Spain. Since its founding in 1718, tiny New Orleans had scraped by on tobacco and indigo crops, a profitless outback of the French Empire. In contrast, the island of St. Domingue, with 400,000 slaves, had booming profits in sugar. Louis XV, reeling from wartime losses to Britain, gave Louisiana’s city to Spain.

headline: When Mrs. Robinson Met Dr. Dolittle
text: On July 4, 1965, Jane Fonda and her husband-to-be, Roger Vadim, had a party in their oceanfront home in Malibu and brought together, probably for the first time, old Hollywood and what would come to be known as the new Hollywood. Henry Fonda roasted a pig on one side of the house while the Byrds, hired by his son, Peter, played on the other. The guest list ran from William Wyler and Sam Spiegel to the then barely employed Jack Nicholson and Dennis Hopper. Lucky attendees might have glimpsed Sidney Poitier and Gene Kelly instructing Vadim’s little girl in tap-dancing, or Darryl Zanuck and George Cukor staring dumbstruck at a barefoot hippie nursing her baby.

headline: Letters: Much About History
text: I must take issue with the Ethicist’s response (Feb. 3) to the professor writing about a doctoral candidate in history who subscribes to the so-called “young earth” theory.

headline: Mexico City Bomber’s Motive Unclear, Police Say
text: MEXICO CITY  A bomb that exploded Friday near the Mexico City police headquarters was carried by an unidentified man wearing two layers of clothing, the police said Saturday. They said that the man died in the blast and that no evidence had yet been found linking him to a guerrilla group or a drug cartel.

headline: Hispanics Fight At-Large Voting System
text: Port Chester

headline: The Pyrotechnic Imagination
text: Cai Guo-Qiang says his favorite artistic moment is the pregnant pause between the lighting of the fuse and the detonation of the gunpowder. “There is a pressure in it to be preserved, and then it explodes,” he says. “This moment belongs just to the artist and the work.” On a breezy afternoon last September, in a large A-frame shed at the Grucci fireworks plant on Long Island, he was setting the stage. With the help of his wife, Hong Hong Wu, he cut a long green fuse into segments, then laid the pieces carefully on eight contiguous panels of handmade Japanese rice paper.

headline: Howard, the Next Big Thing, Still Has Room to Improve
text: ORLANDO, Fla.  Eight hours before tipoff last Monday, the coach was calmly detailing how he pushes and prods his budding star, a coltish player with infinite potential, toward becoming the standard by which contemporary N.B.A. big men are measured.

headline: Paperback Row
text: CALL ME BY YOUR NAME, by André Aciman. (Picador, $14.) In this first novel of adolescent sexual awakening, the precocious 17-year-old son of a wealthy academic falls for an older male graduate student who has come to his father’s well-appointed home on the Italian Riviera. The student is there to revise a manuscript, which, since this is a novel about time and love, is on Heraclitus. Stacey D’Erasmo, our reviewer, called it “an exceptionally beautiful book ... as much a story of paradise found as it is of paradise lost.”

headline: The Last Man Exits
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Alaska Avalanche Kills 2 Snowmobilers
text: ANCHORAGE (AP)  Two snowmobile drivers were killed Friday when they set off an avalanche in the backcountry near Turnagain Pass, about 70 miles south of here, Alaska state troopers said.

headline: The Girl in ‘the Bubble’
text: IN the spring of 2004, when my daughter, Hannah, was just shy of 2 years old, she and I walked into a children’s clothing store in Westchester. As we made our way to the back, we came upon two little girls seated in miniature rocking chairs in front of a TV. When we walked up behind them, one of them looked over her shoulder at Hannah and broke into a smile, then exclaimed to her companion: “Look! Look! A little girl!”

headline: Painted Whimsies
text: Though they have sold well and delighted many, the children’s books written and illustrated by Maira Kalman and produced by her husband, the influential designer Tibor Kalman, who died in 1999, have been criticized over the years. Irked reviewers and baffled kids have found them too hip and worldly-wise for humans too young to grasp a reference to, say, Swifty Lazar. In her new book, “The Principles of Uncertainty,” based on her illustrated blog for The New York Times, Kalman has explicitly concocted what her critics have always accused her of secretly wanting to create: a children’s book for adults.

headline: Learning From a Native Speaker, Without Leaving Home
text: THE best way to learn a foreign language may be to surround yourself with native speakers. But if you can’t manage a trip abroad the Internet and a broadband computer connection may do the job, too, bringing native speakers within electronic reach for hours of practice.

headline: Battlegrounds
text: A million years ago — or before the Iowa caucuses — the Op-Ed page asked several writers to file occasional dispatches describing how the presidential campaign was playing out in their part of the country. Here are their latest reports.

headline: The Rising Popularity of Queens
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: For Israel, Gaza Offers a Range of Risky Choices
text: JERUSALEM  Israel hoped that by pulling its settlers and troops from Gaza in 2005, it would also leave behind responsibility for the Gazans. With help from the West and some Arab nations, Israelis thought, the Palestinian Authority could begin to create a prosperous state, as if the continuing Israeli occupation of the West Bank were somehow irrelevant.

headline: What’s Your Poison?
text: To the Editor:

headline: At War With the Train Whistle
text: WHEN Robert and Kristin Schmid finally found a house they could afford after a long and frustrating search, they were ecstatic. For $474,000, they bought what they believed was their dream house, complete with a backyard and plenty of room for a family someday.

headline: Correction: Hey, Massachusetts, New Jersey Is Passing on the Left
text: An article last Sunday about the trend in New Jersey toward more liberal policies referred imprecisely to measures passed in the state’s capital, Trenton, and in Maryland that address the allocation of electoral votes in the presidential election. The measures would deliver the states’ entire allocation to the winner of the national popular vote if enough states  those with a majority of votes in the Electoral College  agreed to do the same. The measures do not take effect unilaterally.

headline: Drivers to Watch
text: Jimmie Johnson

headline: Master Builders of Ballet’s Future
text: BY the end of the last century ballet was looking more like a museum art than it had in more than 400 years. With the deaths of George Balanchine, Antony Tudor, Frederick Ashton, Kenneth MacMillan and Jerome Robbins, the ranks of world-class choreographers specializing in ballet looked thin or just empty. The three biggest names creating new ballets were Twyla Tharp, William Forsythe and Mark Morris: each, by ballet standards, in some way controversial and offbeat.

headline: Bookshelf
text: WHO WAS FIRST? DISCOVERING THE AMERICAS By Russell Freedman. Illustrated. Clarion. $19. (Ages 9 to 12)

headline: Perks: Upping the Ante Onboard
text: As cruise lines look to outdo one another when it comes to onboard amenities, the cruise experience is increasingly one that rivals a vacation back on land, with everything from water parks to elaborate spas becoming almost standard features. Here are some of the newest offerings by major cruise lines.

headline: Correction: Pulse
text: An entry on the Pulse page last Sunday about Stella McCartney lingerie omitted the first sentence in a description of the bra and panties. It should have read: “The Stella McCartney woman tends to let her flirty, feminine side peek out from under sharp-shouldered jackets.”

headline: Doctor Is Charged in a Killing, and Her People Bear the Shame
text: Dr. Daniel Malakov’s name is still on the placard that hangs outside his office in Rego Park, Queens, even though he was killed three and a half months ago, and even though another orthodontist now works there in his stead.

headline: Whom Do You Believe, G.P.S. or Your Own Eyes?
text: BEDFORD HILLS

headline: In France, the Heads No Longer Roll
text: PARIS  OF all the clubs in the world, the Club of 100 in France may be the most exclusive. Its ranks include leaders in business, politics and law, but it’s the admission policy that really makes the Club des Cent, as it is known here, truly remarkable: only when an existing member dies is space made for a new one.

headline: When Stock Meant Stock
text: WHEN the field takes the green flag for the start of the Daytona 500 on Sunday, Nascar’s departure from its stock car roots (not to mention its name) will be complete.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies of Arts & Leisure this weekend about the state of public broadcasting misspells the surname of a host whose show is distributed by Public Radio International. He is Kurt Andersen, not Anderson. (Go to Article)

headline: A Wedge Turns Dull
text: Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Helene Yan and Brian Yee
text: Helene Yilin Yan and Maj. Brian Kendall Yee are to be married on Sunday on Smathers Beach in Key West, Fla. Sharon Estenoz, a Florida notary public, is to officiate.

headline: McCain Draws Criticism on Torture Bill
text: Senator John McCain’s vote last week against a bill to curtail the Central Intelligence Agency’s use of harsh interrogation tactics disappointed human rights advocates who consider him an ally and led Democrats to charge that he was trying to please Republicans as he seeks to rally them around his presidential bid.

headline: Correction: New Rules Ease the Sting of Mortgages
text: An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report about tips for preparing a tax return referred incompletely to the limit on claims for refundable alternative minimum tax credits resulting from the exercise of incentive stock options. While it is $5,000 under one calculation method, some taxpayers may claim more than that under a second method if their income is not too high.

headline: Show Me the Delegate Rules and I’ll Show You the Party
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Taste Schmaste! This Is for a Diva
text: IT has been four years since Bette Midler last had her way with a stage in the United States. On Wednesday, when she opens at Caesar’s Palace in Las Vegas with “The Showgirl Must Go On,” the stage will reflect this pop diva’s reputation for extravagance. Over a year in the making, the set has components that were constructed in Los Angeles, New Jersey and New York before being shipped to Las Vegas, including three 45-foot-tall trees and curtains created out of hundreds of thousands of individually painted gold coins.

headline: General Motors Raids the Pantry and Bakes a Prize
text: IT seems unreal to be considering the Chevrolet Malibu as an alternative to such world-class cars as the Honda Accord and Toyota Camry, but it has happened. General Motors has finally delivered the first-class midsize sedan it promised for years if not decades.

headline: The Green Challenge

headline: Pack Light or Pay Up: 2 Airlines Add Charges
text: Heavy packers might want to reconsider what they’re bringing if they’re flying on United (www.united.com). Earlier this month, United announced that free bag check-in will be limited to one per person. Starting May 5, it will charge passengers with domestic nonrefundable economy tickets $25 to check a second bag. Exempt from the fee are those with Premier status or higher in United’s Mileage Plus program or those with Silver status or higher within the Star Alliance. The new charge will be applied to tickets purchased on or after Feb. 4.

headline: 8 People Are Killed at Site of an Illegal Road Race
text: ACCOKEEK, Md.  A car crashed into a group of people watching an illegal street race staged here in the early morning hours on a dark highway Saturday, killing eight people and leaving five hospitalized.

headline: That Newfangled Light Bulb
text: Across the world, consumers are being urged to stop buying outdated incandescent light bulbs and switch to new spiral fluorescent bulbs, which use about 25 percent of the energy and last 10 times longer. In Britain, there is a Ban the Bulb movement. China is encouraging the change. And the United States Congress has set new energy efficiency standards that will make Edison’s magical invention obsolete by the year 2014.

headline: Datebook
text: FLORENCE

headline: When There Is No ‘We’ in Marriage
text: AT many weddings, the officiant talks about how a husband and wife should be like two pillars on a porch: separate but together. In their marriage, Jennifer Belle, a novelist, and Andrew Krents, an entertainment lawyer, take the separation part to the extreme. It is almost as if they are afraid of spending too much time together.

headline: Correction: The Greenback Is Losing Global Appeal
text: Because of an editing error, the Practical Traveler column on Feb. 3, about the weakened dollar, misstated the value of the Indian rupee. There are 39 rupees to the dollar, not 29.74.

headline: Someone to Speak for Borrowers in Trouble

headline: Santana’s Here, and Mets Are ‘Team to Beat’
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The most amazing thing happened Saturday morning. Sitting on a stool in front of his locker, Johan Santana stuck his right leg into his baseball pants, then his left, and pulled them up. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, it is true: Santana does, in fact, put his pants on one leg at a time. Here is more bad news: Santana practiced looking runners back to second base. It is, alas, possible that someone gets that far against him this season.

headline: Potential Buyers Serenaded
text: YOU never know what a broker is going to find when showing a Manhattan apartment.

headline: For Patients, More Comfort and a Bigger Dose of Respect
