headline: Where You Going With That Monet?
text: THE plots of art heist movies are about as multifarious as the canvases of the paintings pilfered by their main characters  the postmodern heroin-cool of Nick Nolte in “The Good Thief”; the playboy-billionaire boredom of Pierce Brosnan in “The Thomas Crown Affair.” But one thing art theft movies tend to have in common is that they dwell on the heist and not on the aftermath, for reasons that are probably more than cinematic: art is an exceedingly dumb thing to steal.

headline: The Doctors Are In. The Jury Is Out.
text: THREE articles in The Times last month raised an intriguing question: When does fairness demand that a newspaper walk down the middle in a scientific dispute, and when does responsibility demand that it take sides?

headline: Despite the Wig, a Bronx Boy at Heart
text: I GREW up in the rough-and-tumble Morrisania section of the East Bronx. I’m not sure when Morrisania’s gangs began, but they were already there during the Revolutionary War.

headline: Daniella Giraldi, Kevin Prussia
text: Daniella Yetta Gioconda Giraldi, a daughter of Dr. Ernest Giraldi Jr. of La Jolla, Calif., and the late Gloria Isaacs Giraldi, is to be married on Sunday to Kevin Scott Prussia, the son of Valerie Mair and Bevin Prussia, both of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Ian Adler is to include Jewish and Methodist elements in a ceremony at La Valencia Hotel in La Jolla.

headline: Paradise of Lies
text: My mother ran away to Montreal shortly after my birth and left me behind in Jamaica. And the wealthy Chinese man from Montego Bay  whose name she gave me  denied he ever had any relations with her. I grew up with relatives, knowing I wasn’t like everybody else.

headline: A Greek Temple Dedicated to Art and Learning
text: THE giant blocky temple at 30th Street and Lexington Avenue is silent and cold now, over a year after Touro College sold it to an investor. Built in 1908 as the New York School of Applied Design for Women, this striking super-Classical building, an early work of Harvey Wiley Corbett, a visionary skyscraper architect, stands as an unusual counterpoint to his soaring towers.

headline: Out of Office, Will He Be Out of Sorts?
text: He would immediately find himself in the upper echelons of private philanthropy, with the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and the J. Paul Getty Trust.

headline: Greek Favorites, on a Simple Scale
text: HUNKERED down along Route 9 South, My Little Fat Greek Restaurant in Freehold occupies a building that brings to mind manufactured housing. The interior could have easily felt the same, but the tables are clothed in white, and the ceiling is festooned with strands of holiday lights that create a soft, sweet glow. A small waterfall divides the dining room and functions as a wind block as well, which is handy since there’s no vestibule between diners and the wintry blast that accompanies every opening of the door.

headline: Hawaii Budget Choices
text: To the Editor: In "Hawaii on a Dime" (Jan. 27), the couple missed a big chance to economize by not looking for places to stay, and go, on the eastern side of each island, which are generally more budget-friendly than the western sides.

headline: Wash, Spin, Dry, Gone
text: ALBERT BENNETT has lived for 52 years on the same block of Morton Street between Hudson and Bedford Streets, and like a lot of residents of Greenwich Village, he has a clear mental map of the area, both as it is and as it used to be.

headline: As Nuclear Waste Languishes, Expense to U.S. Rises
text: WASHINGTON  Forgotten but not gone, the waste from more than 100 nuclear reactors that the federal government was supposed to start accepting for burial 10 years ago is still at the reactor sites, at least 20 years behind schedule. But it is making itself felt in the federal budget.

headline: With Nuevo Comfort Food, Who Needs Pricey Cuisine?
text: NORWALK

headline: Obama Adding Detail to His Oratory
text: EAU CLAIRE, Wis.  If he does say so himself, Senator Barack Obama delivers a fine political speech.

headline: There Will Be Memories
text: THE Academy Awards may have been around for 80 years now, but, as Suzanne Stone Maretto (Nicole Kidman) in “To Die For” (1995) might have told you, if it wasn’t on television, it didn’t really happen. So an equally important anniversary is that of the Oscar broadcast. The ceremony was first shown on television in March 1953. (Above, Bob Hope was the host for that ceremony.) And it should go on (thank you, Writers Guild of America) for the 56th time next Sunday broadcast on ABC from the Kodak Theater in Hollywood with Jon Stewart as host.

headline: Syracuse Holds On to Early Lead and Beats Georgetown
text: SYRACUSE  With eight minutes left and Syracuse comfortably ahead of Georgetown, the manager of the Carrier Dome came tapping on the shoulders of the reporters seated by the court.

headline: Correction: Lenders Who Sold and Left
text: The Fair Game column on Feb. 3, about problems at mortgage lenders, misstated the circumstances surrounding a bankruptcy filing related to the home mortgage lending unit of NovaStar Financial. An involuntary petition to force the unit into bankruptcy was filed with the court on Jan. 24 by a creditor who won a $49 million judgment against the unit; the unit did not file for bankruptcy. (On Feb. 7, the judge overseeing the case ruled against the petition.)

headline: Deborah LaCoy, Jeffrey Dine
text: Deborah LaCoy and Jeffrey Malcolm Dine are to be married on Sunday at the Lotos Club in New York. Rabbi Jack Bemporad is to officiate.

headline: Speech on the Mideast Brings Opinions to a Boil
text: Greenwich, Conn.

headline: Dream Logic
text: “We poets in our youth begin in gladness,” wrote Wordsworth, who might have felt otherwise had he spent his own youth as an adjunct assistant professor of creative writing. If he’d done so, as many younger writers do nowadays, he’d probably have thought twice about pairing “gladness” with a job that often involves $50,000 in student loans and no health insurance. To be fair, it’s never been easy to be a young poet, and teaching creative writing is certainly safer than working as a roofer. Yet because most are neither wealthy (like the young James Merrill) nor constantly in jeopardy (like Villon), writers in their early careers today face a peculiar and sometimes unenviable set of circumstances. On the one hand, the proliferation of M.F.A. programs gives a poet the chance to make a sort-of living from his art; on the other hand, the insularity of that world can tax both an artist’s social skills and his resistance to fashion. Given these difficulties, it’s tempting to replace Wordsworth’s salute to youthful vitality with the 29-year-old Bon Scott’s less optimistic observation: “If you wanna be a star of stage and screen / Look out, it’s rough and mean.”

headline: Playing With Fire
text: Our small community of perhaps 60 homes lacks adequate fire protection. Equipment could arrive within 45 minutes, so some feel we should purchase our own. Only 15 homeowners have agreed to this. Should the need arise, must we provide this equipment to those who did not share in its purchase?  NAME WITHHELD, BAHAMAS

headline: Democratic Candidates Emphasize Need for Unity
text: MILWAUKEE  After days of battling each other in tit-for-tat television advertisements ahead of the Wisconsin primary, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama on Saturday night cooled their rhetoric and reminded Democrats of their fight ahead.

headline: A Cure for the Winter Doldrums
text: ON a recent gray day at the Long Island Children’s Museum in Garden City, 4-year-old Justin Lee of Plainview was standing in front of a waist-high microphone, tapping on his stomach. With an amplified thump, he played along with a video of the Blue Man Group’s “Belly Drum Song” on the monitor in front of him.

headline: Breathing Room Gone, Mickelson Maintains Lead
text: LOS ANGELES  Phil Mickelson holed a critical 7-foot putt for par on the final hole Saturday to cling to a one-stroke lead over Jeff Quinney at the Northern Trust Open at Riviera Country Club, moving a step closer to winning the West Coast tournament that has eluded him.

headline: Sometimes, the Real Stars Are Off the Court
text: Kathy and David Henry spent Valentine’s Day with the love of their lives  basketball.

headline: Questions, Not Just on Iraq
text: How the next president plans to handle the disastrous Iraq war is the most important foreign policy question of this year’s campaign. But it is not the only foreign policy question that voters need answered.

headline: That’s Not Old Stuff. That’s My Past.
text: AS a child, I dreamed of living in a one-room cottage deep in a fairy-tale forest. There I would have one bed, one chair and one table, one broom to sweep with and a wardrobe of two simple dresses. Obviously, I was already trying to conquer clutter and dodge the storage solution.

headline: Baba Amte, 93, Dies; Advocate for Lepers
text: Baba Amte, a follower of Gandhi whose dedication to helping the lepers of India brought him the Templeton Prize and many other international awards, died on Feb. 9 at his shelter for leprosy patients in the western Indian state of Maharashtra. He was 93.

headline: Excerpts of an Interview With Sheila Frazier
text: Sheila Frazier is a star of the 1972 film “Super Fly.” Her marriage to John Atchison is featured in Vows this week. She discussed how her acting career came about with the column’s author, Devan Sipher.

headline: Musical Marriages, Made by Design
text: JAY ANTHONY GACH, a 52-year-old composer who lives in Long Beach, admits he was “a little on edge” last month when he first met Soo Bae, a young cellist for whom he had just recently finished writing a piece.

headline: Religion and Divorce
text: To the Editor:

headline: Tracy Spitzberg, Marc Shedroff
text: Tracy Anne Spitzberg, the daughter of Alicia D. Leff of San Antonio and Larry A. Spitzberg of Houston, is to be married Sunday to Marc Daniel Shedroff, a son of Elissa S. Shedroff and Steven H. Shedroff of Allentown, Pa. Rabbi Samuel M. Stahl will officiate at the Westin Riverwalk Hotel in San Antonio.

headline: Letters
text: A Farewell to Paper?

headline: The Paranoiac and The Paris Review
text: When he died at 66 in 1992, Harold L. Humes had spent decades talking to himself, and to anyone else who would listen. Since the early ’70s, Humes  a bearded, generally benevolent figure, his mind ravaged yet not entirely destroyed by mental illness  had been a fixture around Harvard and Columbia, a self-appointed freelance professor entrancing acolytes with his theories on vast government conspiracies, the benefits of cannabis, the shape of clouds.

headline: An Iranian Magazine, Silenced

headline: Midwest Mex
text: Biggest home-chef mistakes: They don’t cook over high enough heat, and they don’t salt enough.

headline: Keep It Simple, Says Yale’s Top Investor
text: IT has been a time to worry even the savviest investors. The credit markets have been in a crisis, the domestic stock market has been shaky and overseas markets haven’t been much better.

headline: At Duke, Mentor Is the Message
text: DURHAM, N.C. (AP)  Johnny Dawkins did everything Mike Krzyzewski asked as an all-American player at Duke. But after years of taking direction, Dawkins felt odd speaking his mind as a new assistant when asked by his mentor for advice.

headline: Letters: A Statesman Without Borders
text: In his excellent article on Bernard Kouchner, James Traub (Feb. 3) attributes the aphorism “pessimism of the intelligence, optimism of the will” to Antonio Gramsci. This beautiful phrase actually comes from Romain Rolland, the French Nobel Prize-winning novelist, playwright and intellectual. Gramsci borrowed the line as the motto of his newspaper, L’Ordine Nuovo, appreciating its condensation of the revolutionary socialist process and the role of the radical intellectual. Kouchner is more Rollandist than Gramscian, especially given his critique of authoritarianism and blindness of the left.

headline: When God and the Law Don’t Square
text: A PRETTY good way to generate an outcry, as the archbishop of Canterbury learned in Britain recently, is to say that a Western legal system should make room for Shariah, or Islamic law. When the archbishop, spiritual leader of the world’s 80 million Anglicans, commented in a radio interview that such an accommodation was “unavoidable,” critics conjured images of stonings and maimings, overwhelming his more modest point.

headline: F.B.I. Gained Unauthorized Access to E-Mail
text: WASHINGTON  A technical glitch gave the F.B.I. access to the e-mail messages from an entire computer network  perhaps hundreds of accounts or more  instead of simply the lone e-mail address that was approved by a secret intelligence court as part of a national security investigation, according to an internal report of the 2006 episode.

headline: Up All Night
text: I was never an easy sleeper. On restless childhood nights, I played a game: first I imagined a bird’s-eye view of the bed where I lay awake, then let the lens pull back to reveal the rooftop of my family’s house, then our town from above, then the silhouette of New Jersey, then America, and finally the whole world.

headline: For Disabled Hunters, Sport Goes On
text: RINGOES, N.J.

headline: Saving the V-8 by Turning It Inside Out
text: LAST December, after President Bush signed a 35-mile-a-gallon-fuel economy standard into law, General Motors quickly shelved a new V-8 it was designing to replace Cadillac’s long-serving Northstar engine. The timing of these developments prompted a flurry of obituaries for V-8 engines, a breed with a reputation for speed, power  and lately, environmental insolence.

headline: Katharine Kolb, Thomas Brennan
text: Katharine Yvonnet Kolb and Thomas Mark Brennan were married on Saturday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Newburyport, Mass. The Rev. Marc Piché, the church’s pastor, performed the ceremony.

headline: An Imaginary Friend
text: Ever since Sherman McCoy’s boating moccasins touched down on Park Avenue 20 years ago, readers have been offered plenty of fictional opportunities to eavesdrop on the residents of the Upper East Side of Manhattan  via their lovers, their kids’ teachers, their oppressed editorial assistants. Inevitably, the critics complain that this new ZIP code 10021 genre can’t stand up to the past work of Edith Wharton, Truman Capote and Louis Auchincloss, or to Tom Wolfe’s “Bonfire of the Vanities.” Wharton herself frowned on employing her own tribe as protagonists, noting in her autobiography, “A Backward Glance,” that “the group in which I grew up was like an empty vessel into which no new wine would ever again be poured.”

headline: Correction: A Statesman Without Borders
text: An article on Feb. 3 about Bernard Kouchner, the foreign minister of France, referred incorrectly to the Charles De Gaulle, a ship that Kouchner mentioned while speaking about France’s relations with Russia. It is an aircraft carrier, not a battleship.

headline: Correction: 16 Ways of Looking at a Female Voter
text: An article on Feb. 3 about women’s voting patterns misidentified the legislative body of which James W. Wadsworth Jr., whom the New York League of Women Voters tried to unseat in 1920, was a member. It was the United States Senate, not the New York State Senate.

headline: Syracuse Holds On to Early Lead and Beats Georgetown
text: SYRACUSE  With eight minutes remaining in Saturday’s men’s basketball game between Syracuse and Georgetown, the manager of the Carrier Dome came tapping on the shoulders of all the reporters on press row.

headline: Two Paths for the Aspiring Alpha Female
text: IN the 1964 film “My Fair Lady,” Prof. Henry Higgins, played by Rex Harrison, famously asked, “Why can’t a woman be more like a man?” The subtexts of two new books that aim to guide women through the worlds of commerce and finance pose a strikingly similar question  Why can’t a businesswoman be more like a businessman?  and come up with strikingly different answers.

headline: From Dancehall Rapper to Nursery Rhymer
text: IF you’ve never heard of Father Goose, just ask a kid. As part of the eclectic family music ensemble Dan Zanes & Friends, Father Goose, a k a Wayne Rhoden, is the boisterous, big-bellied Jamaican guy who routinely steals the show with his gruff renditions of “Georgie Porgie” and the “Hokey Pokey.”

headline: Seeing the Sights, Ditching the Shipmates
text: AFTER standing in line for the buffet, staking out a lounge chair on the sun deck and squeezing into the hot tub with total strangers, you might be forgiven for dreading the cruise excursion, which typically involves hundreds of passengers piling into little boats to go ashore, queuing up for a bus to take you to the standard tourist sites and straining to hear the guide rattle off some rote facts.

text: Three bits of news from the first two months of 2008 highlight the galling inconsistency and inadequacy of the federal government’s system for turning immigrants into citizens.

headline: Miracle Workers?
text: Even today, in our high-tech, accountability-obsessed and, supposedly at least, patient-empowered times, the oldest of all relations between patient and physician  that of supplicant to shaman  continues to exert its authority. This may not seem sensible if the only valid criterion for judging the doctor-patient relationship is the use that is made of scientific data and clinical findings. But good doctors want to treat their patients, not just their patients’ diseases, and certainly most patients want to be treated as human beings, not cases. Viewed from that perspective, the elevated expectations patients bring to the consulting room may be for the best.

text: Jonathan M. Tisch, co-owner of the New York Giants and chairman and C.E.O. of Loews Hotels, is giving up one of his many extracurricular activities: his post as chairman of NYC & Company, New York’s tourism marketing organization.

headline: Old Clinton Ties and Voters’ Sway Tug at Delegates
text: WASHINGTON  The dwindling group of elected officials and party leaders publicly undecided in the Democratic presidential contest  about 300 out of the 795 so-called superdelegates who may determine the party’s nominee  includes at least 30 who have a long and often personal history with the Clinton family.

headline: Therapist Remembered as One Who Refreshed the Broken
text: Much of the later part of Kathryn Faughey’s life was contained on this block of East 79th Street between First and York Avenues. It was where she shared a top-floor apartment with her husband, bought flowers on the corner on special occasions and listened to her patients as they shared their troubles. And it was where her funeral Mass was held on Saturday  at a church steps away from where she was killed on Tuesday.

headline: Cabinets of Wonder
text: My friend was recovering from surgery. The tumor was entirely benign. “The doctor says it’s just a dermoid cyst,” she said. A what? We paused, as realization dawned. We had it: our search term. As any hypochondriac knows, a fresh new word from a doctor can set off a daylong orgy of medical Googling.

headline: The Executioner Waits
text: Imre Kertesz, who in 2002 was the first Hungarian to win the Nobel Prize in Literature, once said, “When I am thinking about a novel, I always think of Auschwitz.” One is also always thinking about Auschwitz when reading his novels, as the best-known of them form a loose tetralogy that give a fictionalized account of Kertesz’s own experience of the war. His unnerving 1975 debut, “Fatelessness,” recounts the story of a child deported to Auschwitz  and later Buchenwald and Zeitz. The subsequent volumes (“Fiasco,” “Kaddish for an Unborn Child” and “Liquidation”) portray him as an adult trying to make sense of his wartime experience through literature.

headline: Is PBS Still Necessary?
text: FOR the eighth straight year the Bush administration has ritually proposed taking a hefty whack out of the federal subsidy for public broadcasting. The cuts would in effect slice in half the money that public television and public radio get from the government. If we follow the usual script, this means it’s time for upset listeners and viewers to rally to the cause, as they have in the past, and browbeat Congress into restoring the budget.

headline: Letters: Back-Room Choices
text: As an example of how fluid the nominating process has become, Matt Bai (Feb. 3) cites the failure of the Culinary Workers Union to deliver its members to Barack Obama in Nevada. “Even union workers,” Bai writes, “once considered a monolithic bloc, no longer blindly follow their leaders’ dictates.”

headline: Ah, the Pothole Senator. Wait! The Flag’s Wrong!

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: A BOUND MAN: Why We Are Excited About Obama and Why He Can’t Win, by Shelby Steele. (Free Press, $22.) Personal motivation seems to lie behind this account, in which Steele comes across as far more fascinating than what he has to say about the candidate.

headline: Clemens Pays Price for Reputation That Is Soiled
text: What did Roger Clemens know, and when did he know it? To hear Clemens at last week’s hearing before the House oversight committee, he never knew anything. No one told him he was facing allegations that he had used performance-enhancing substances, not his long-time agent and lawyer, not the players association, not the commissioner, not George J. Mitchell.

headline: They Lost It at the Movies
text: CHARLTON HESTON, dressed for disaster in a tight-fitting lemon sweater in “Airport 1975,” may have been making a fashion statement 33 years ago as he rescued a 747 that had been rendered pilotless. But the actor’s appearance drew a very different interpretation from the Thursday night crowd at Clearview Chelsea Cinemas.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘The Cure Within’
text: A review on Jan. 27 about “The Cure Within,” by Anne Harrington, misstated the publishing status of a follow-up study on some 1989 breast-cancer research by the psychiatrist David Spiegel. The follow-up results have in fact been released, last year in the medical journal Cancer.

headline: Correction: A More Intimate Grand Bazaar
text: The Day Out column on Feb. 10, about the Cukurcuma antiques district in Istanbul, included an incorrect street number for a textiles shop, Leyla Seyhanli. It is at Altipatlar Sokak 6, not No. 19.

headline: Dress-Up for Dollars

headline: Notes on Camp
text: It is 1936, and we are in the Adirondacks, at a party at a luxurious camp on a vast private reserve. (“Camp” is a local upper-caste understatement, comparable to the use of “cottage” in Newport, R.I.) As the sun begins to dip behind the mountain range that dominates the horizon, a beautiful young woman detaches herself from her elders and walks barefoot to the shore of the lake. Suddenly a seaplane appears in the air and all look on, stunned, as it lands on the surface of the water. Such a thing has never before occurred, and furthermore is taboo under the largely unspoken laws of the reserve. A dashing aviator  we will discover that he is a famous artist, a radical, a free spirit  steps out of the plane and locks eyes with the glamorous yet troubled young woman.

headline: Old-Timers Get Their Due
text: MANUFACTURERS of die-cast models of stock cars tend to move as fast as the real cars that will hurtle around the Daytona International Speedway on Sunday. In pit-stop time, a die-cast model usually goes on sale right after a Nascar driver unveils a new sponsor or paint job.

headline: A Different Recollection
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art and Life, Steeping in a Teapot
text: FRITZ HAEG is not the best-known artist in the Whitney Biennial, opening next month. He has not had a breakout solo show at the Zach Feuer Gallery. He is not being wooed by Larry Gagosian. His prices at auction are nonexistent.

headline: In Hotel Design, He’s Mr. Prolific
text: IN his SoHo office, the architect Gene Kaufman is presenting drawings of his latest buildings.

headline: Slow Food
text: It’s no longer safe to assume that the winter will be cold, but February Sundays still have a cozy dreariness that carbon emissions have yet to thaw. What nicer day to spend the afternoon simmering a meaty ragù that will taste even better the following week? It will also freeze beautifully for that freak blizzard in April.

headline: Silicon Valley Starts to Turn Its Face to the Sun
text: CAN Silicon Valley become a world leader in cheap and ubiquitous solar panels for the masses?

headline: The World’s Worst Panderer
text: Even for those of us who shudder at many of John McCain’s positions, there is something refreshing about a man who wins so many votes despite a major political shortcoming: he is abysmal at pandering.

headline: Neighbor vs. Neighbor
text: IMAGINE a letter slipped under an apartment door, and then a warning of a lawsuit in the offing: “As you may not be aware, we are both lawyers and both litigators, for whom the usual barriers to litigation are minimal.”

headline: Arcane Market Is Next to Face Big Credit Test
text: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term.

headline: Bush, in Africa, Emphasizes Successes Over Conflicts
text: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  As violence in Africa threatened to overshadow his six-day tour of the continent, President Bush on Saturday defended his decision not to visit strife-torn nations like Kenya and Sudan, saying he wanted to focus instead on successes like his programs to fight AIDS and malaria.

headline: In New Rochelle, a Waterfront Plan Starts to Unfold
text: THOUGH at least several years and a host of bureaucratic hurdles from fruition, a plan to transform New Rochelle’s deteriorated Echo Bay waterfront into a vibrant neighborhood has been proposed, and the mayor calls it one of the most significant prospects in the city’s history.

headline: Correction: Which Worksheet Is for the Away Games?
text: An article last Sunday in the special Your Taxes report, about income taxes that must be paid by athletes who travel out of state, misstated the estimated New York tax liability of a hypothetical Boston Red Sox player making $20 million a year who appeared in nine games at Yankee Stadium. It would be about $60,000, not $100,000. (While such a player would be liable for New York State taxes, there would be no New York City tax due.)

headline: Bright Lights in the Wee Hours
text: IT is 2 a.m., and Eighth Avenue, the main drag of Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is eerily silent and deserted. The fishmongers and mushroom sellers have long since packed up their wares. All that is left from the day’s bustle are crushed produce boxes, pungent with the remains of unsold fruits and vegetables, stacked neatly along the curb.

headline: Historic Area, Great Shopping
text: LIKE a perfectly formed tic-tac-toe board, the quaint streets that straddle three of Amsterdam’s grandest canals form the city’s most quirky neighborhood: the Nine Streets, or Negen Straatjes (www.theninestreets.com). In the heart of the western canal belt, only a few minutes’ walk from the Royal Palace in Dam Square, the Nine Streets — easily Amsterdam’s best shopping hub — is a charming mixture of designer boutiques, art galleries, vintage clothing stores, hair salons, gift shops and places to eat and drink.

headline: No ‘D.I.Y.’ Rent Laws, Court of Appeals Rules
text: A RULING by the New York Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, underscores in no uncertain terms that tenants and landlords cannot write their own version of the rent-stabilization laws.

headline: Elegy for a Vanishing Pastime
text: IN the New England of my youth, back when we still had winter, ice  the kind you skate on  was as reliable as the calendar. It usually turned up overnight, smooth and glistening, the week after Thanksgiving, and it lasted, with perhaps a minor thaw or two, until Washington’s Birthday at least. What you did every day back then was skate  which is to say, play hockey. After school, your mom dropped you off at the pond, the lake, the frozen river, the flooded playground, and she picked you up when it was dark. On Saturdays she made you a baloney sandwich to take along, but by the time you remembered to eat it, it was frozen hard as a puck.

headline: Minority Rules
text: Walking through the Sur district of Diyarbakir with Abdullah Demirbas was like taking an old-fashioned mayoral stroll. As the day got under way in one of the largest cities in southeastern Turkey, Demirbas passed through the narrow stone alleys, and one by one, shopkeepers stepped outside and waved. In return, Demirbas patted his chest and called out loud greetings. He stopped to compliment a cafe owner’s new door frames, asked a trio of women if they were satisfied with the trash collection and teased some kids about getting to school on time. Demirbas addressed most of the locals in Kurdish, his native language, but every now and then he switched to Turkish. When I asked him why, he said he has known all his constituents long enough to remember which language each speaks.

headline: With Big Finish, Charity Drive Tops Last Year’s
text: On Friday, Feb. 8, the last day of the 96th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign, contributions had totaled $7,635,259. That was nearly $4,000 lower than the amount raised the previous year.

headline: The Short Sale Gains in Allure
text: EARLIER this month, Asaf German, a real estate lawyer, closed a deal in Oceanside in which a homeowner who had paid $700,000 for a house two years ago now agreed to sell it for $465,000. Yet somehow, as Mr. German put it, “it was a win-win; the deal helped everyone involved.”

He explores the tension between inspiring, idealistic leadership and the art of political compromise. This is not the United States election of 2008. It is the story of Nelson Mandela and the transformation of South Africa.

headline: Presumed Guilty
text: Years ago, I asked a class I was teaching to read the first chapters of Balzac’s “Eugenie Grandet” and “A Flag for Sunrise,” by Robert Stone. The Balzac begins with a leisurely tour of a provincial town, while, near the start of the Stone, a hippie backpacker’s corpse shows up in the freezer of an army lieutenant in a restive Central American country. I suggested to my students that the comparison might reflect one difference between 19th- and 20th-century fiction. Perhaps these contrasting openings had something to do with the way our attention spans have been altered  for better or worse  by the bright gratifications of movies and the rhythm of television, which has schooled us to expect the “hook” before the first commercial. Reading “A Person of Interest,” it occurred to me that if we’re lucky, Susan Choi’s new book may turn out to be a prototypical 21st-century novel, combining the unhurried pleasures of certain classics with the jittery tensions of more recent fiction.

headline: Resorts Springing Up on Costa Rican Shore
text: The Pacific Coast of Costa Rica  known as Guanacaste  is being snapped up by hoteliers and developers. Last summer, both Stephen M. Case, the co-founder of AOL, and the hotel chain Mandarin Oriental announced plans to build properties there. The Four Seasons Resort Costa Rica at Peninsula Papagayo and Hilton Papagayo Resort Costa Rica are open. And in January, Recreo (www.recreocostarica.com), above, a collection of 25 luxury villas on over 70 coastal acres, opened.

text: I GREW up in Napoleon, Ohio, in a great family that still gets along. I got my business skills from my father, who owned a hardware store, and people skills from my mother, who was a nurse.

headline: The Internationalist
text: On Aug. 19, 2003, a Kamash truck pulled into the alley behind the Canal Hotel in Baghdad and a bomb detonated, crumpling a corner of the United Nations’ mission in Iraq. Inside the building was Sergio Vieira de Mello, a Brazilian-born United Nations official who had previously served in Vietnam, Lebanon, Cyprus, Cambodia, Bosnia, Rwanda, Kosovo and East Timor. More than anyone else at the United Nations, he embodied the organization’s idealism, as well as its limitations. Vieira de Mello was pinned under the rubble and hung on for several hours before dying. The ineffectual efforts of American forces to save him were a harbinger of the larger American failure in Iraq.

headline: Letters to the Editor
Island Hopping Without Leaving the City
text: ISLAND hopping in the Caribbean is fine, if you have the time, money and sunscreen, but there is an alternative in New York: a trip to islands known (at least for the next 900 words) as the Five Borough Antilles. It takes just a weekend, and you’ll pay less than $20 for transportation on a trip that departs from New York, N.Y., hits ports of call in New York, N.Y., and returns to New York, N.Y.

headline: It’s Lonely at the Plaza Hotel ...
text: KATHY RULAND decorated her family’s new two-bedroom condo at the Plaza Hotel with care. The windows, overlooking Central Park, are draped with gold silk, and the living room showcases her beloved Indonesian painting of the Hindu goddess Sita, which was bought at a gallery near her main residence in Laguna Beach, Calif. When she wakes up to front-row views of Central Park, she says she feels like a princess.

headline: The Sound and the Fury
text: DOZENS of times a day in winter and more frequently in summer, a double-decker tour bus lumbers off Seventh Avenue South to head eastbound on Bleecker Street. The buses are a fact of life on this strip: fat, 13-foot-high behemoths, each with a tour guide lecturing through a powerful loudspeaker on local landmarks like Murray’s Cheese and the Bitter End.

headline: Cold Water Cruises

But others seem increasingly drawn to a vacation where the ice isn’t just in their drinks, but in the very waters that surround them.

headline: Life Is Sweet
text: “Delicious: The Life and Art of Wayne Thiebaud,” is the story of a happy man known for his happy paintings of cakes and pies. It turns out he also has many happy things to say about painting. For example: “I love art history” and “I was a spoiled child. I had a great life, so about the only thing I can do is to paint happy pictures.”

headline: Heartbreaking Work
text: “Caregiver” is a deceptively professional-sounding term for a role in which most of us are complete amateurs, and for one that is apt to descend upon us like a blow from fate, stunning and unforeseen. We have a great need to live with the illusion that we and those we love are immune to mortality, but inevitably, somewhere along the line, even if we ourselves are spared from illness, something cracks open  a father or a friend gets cancer, a mother succumbs to Alzheimer’s, a husband has a terrible accident, a child dies  and what Virginia Woolf once called “extreme reality” floods in. Like the 19 excruciatingly honest contributors to “An Uncertain Inheritance,” we may find ourselves tested to the limits of our endurance.

headline: The Power of Whimsy
text: SANDRA BOYNTON’S studio, in a converted barn next to her Connecticut home, bears the milestones of her singular career: a long rack of greeting cards featuring quirkily drawn animals; a room full of small, sturdy children’s books, with names like “Snuggle Puppy!” and “Barnyard Dance!”; and, upstairs, where she does much of her work, old-time radios and jukeboxes representing her more recent foray into music CDs for children.

headline: Serious Steaks, at Breathtaking Prices
text: WITH the recent rise of glass-clad towers and high-end boîtes, the once-modest city of White Plains seems to be doing its best to impersonate Las Vegas, the land that not a single celebrity chef forgot. Developers and restaurateurs, including Rick Laakkonen at Antipasti and Anthony Goncalves at 42, are betting that suburbanites in search of fine dining will snub Manhattan and sink into a banquette closer to home. At the red-hot center of this big push is BLT Steak, a brand from Laurent Tourondel, sleekly ensconced on the ground floor of the new Ritz-Carlton on Renaissance Place.

headline: Computers Are Ever Mightier, But They Still Have Their Flaws
text: If a computer played perfectly, could any human hope to achieve a draw? Chess engines are still far from perfection, but their advances have been staggering.

headline: Bizarre Turn at Hearing for Suspect in Stabbing
text: The arraignment of a Queens man in the killing of an Upper East Side therapist quickly took a bizarre turn on Sunday morning when the man interrupted the proceedings with demands for food and complaints about his court-appointed lawyer.

headline: Thai Antiquities, Resting Uneasily
text: IT just might rank as one of the biggest accidental discoveries in archaeology. In the summer of 1966 a Harvard student named Steve Young was living in a village in the northeast reaches of Thailand, going door to door canvassing political opinion for his senior thesis, when he tripped over the root of a kapok tree. As he hit the ground he found himself face to face with some buried pots, their rims exposed by recent monsoons. Intrigued by the look and feel of the unglazed shards, he knew enough to bring them back to government officials in Bangkok.

headline: Letters: Old-School Economics
text: Christopher Caldwell (Jan. 27) argues that because America now possesses a “new economy,” with more security guards than machinists, presidential candidates who express concern over our ailing manufacturing sector are engaged in “folkloric” pandering. The true folklore, however, is the perception that our new economy represents progress. Middle-class Americans borrow to maintain their standard of living, as well-paid manufacturing jobs, like machinists, are replaced by lower-paid “new economy” jobs, like security guards. Masters of the new economy on Wall Street make millions on financial alchemy that ultimately weakens our economy further. One hopes that our next president will recognize that “choreographers, blackjack dealers and security guards” can never form the “backbone” of a strong economy and take steps to revive America’s industrial base.

headline: 36 Hours in St. Barts
text: GETTING to St. Barts isn’t easy, not even with your own Gulfstream. On the final leg, trade your million-dollar jet for a tiny puddle jumper, before threading between two jagged peaks and touching down on a teensy runway that, islanders like to joke, is as short as an aircraft carrier’s. That might explain the island’s exclusivity. Although Jay-Z, Beyoncé and a rotating cast of celebrities have kept St. Barts in the tabloids, this tiny French island still exudes a chic, laid-back vibe unspoiled by gawkers and day-trippers. And despite a new wave of wine bars, chichi boutiques and designer restaurants, the island’s main attraction remains its luscious white sand beaches, fringed by the pool-blue waters of the Caribbean.

headline: Who Knew There Was Water There?
text: Hiking the mountains of Bhutan. Exploring the temples of India. Wandering the ancient grounds of Angkor Wat. These are some of the unlikely trips you can take when signing up for a cruise vacation these days.

Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 novel, “The Great Gatsby,” with its themes of possibility and aspiration, speaks to her.

headline: Seeking Space for Cars at Grand Canyon
text: PHOENIX (AP)  The National Park Service wants to add hundreds of parking spots in developed areas at Grand Canyon National Park, hoping to ease traffic at the park’s popular South Rim, officials said Friday.

headline: The Love Boat for Policy Wonks
text: I’M dancing on the top deck with a 71-year-old feminist and psychotherapist whom I’ve come to think of as the Twirler. We’ve spent two days attending seminars on The Nation magazine’s Alaska cruise; we’ve talked about the Bush presidency and prison reform and single-payer health care. Now, at almost midnight, my fiercely intelligent and opinionated new friend Charlotte is putting all the heady political talk behind her by bodily twirling.

headline: Scientology’s Star
text: The celebrity biographer Andrew Morton never met a grudge he couldn’t get behind. He has aired the grievances of Diana, Princess of Wales, against the British royal family, and of Monica Lewinsky against Kenneth Starr. Now he champions the indignation of mostly anonymous former Scientologists in this brutal biography of the controversial religion’s most famous advocate, Tom Cruise.

headline: Letters: Clean Look
text: Rob Walker’s article (Consumed, Feb. 3) on Tide’s iconic design gives a brief but revealing look at the culture of overthinking that inundates the marketing community. Consultants with fancy titles and advanced degrees are ready to offer complex answers to even the simplest questions. For example, Walker quotes a Ph.D. in art history who describes Tide’s logo as “almost a baroque composition” full of “great dynamic tension.”

headline: Inside the List
text: FLICKERS OF VANITY: Some of the writers who appear regularly on this page work hard  in their advertisements, anyway  to appear to be more or less ageless. Rita Mae Brown is not among these writers. Brown is best known, to some readers, as the author of the groundbreaking lesbian novel “Rubyfruit Jungle,” published in 1973. But in recent years she’s spent her time churning out two successful mystery series, one about a fox-hunting club in Virginia, the other about a sleuthing cat named Mrs. Murphy. (The new Mrs. Murphy novel, “The Purrfect Murder,” enters the fiction list this week at No. 16.) On her Web site, Brown, who is 63 and lives on a farm in Virginia, stares at herself in the mirror and writes: “I suppose I should say something about being older than dirt. Well, I’m working on it. I love it. As long as you’re healthy and have a job, life is really good. Yes, I look like my grandmother. My body hasn’t aged yet, the face has gone, but ... I was never going to make the cover of Vogue. And in those moments when a flicker of vanity hits me and I think, ‘Damn, I need a facelift,’ I remind myself that there’s a starving hound someone has abandoned and I must catch it, feed it and restore its confidence in the hound-human bond. So what if I look like hell? My heart is full, and I wish the same for you.”

headline: Turning Minuses Into Pluses

headline: China Wineries Become a Stop for Tours
text: China is the new frontier of the international wine scene, says Paolo Wakham, a sommelier and guide for China Wine Tours. The company (www.chinawinetours.com) offers trips that combine visits to some of China’s 500 wine producers with stops at more traditional destinations like the Great Wall, the Forbidden City and the Chang Family Mansion. The Shanxi Grace Vineyard in Taigu and the China Silk Winery in Urumqi are on the tour. Both produce cabernet sauvignon, chardonnay, riesling and merlot wines

headline: After Shootings, Illinois Campus Prepares to Mourn Victims
text: CHICAGO  Two days after a gunman opened fire at Northern Illinois University, killing five students and himself, academic officials announced that classes would resume in just over a week, to give the faculty and students time to deal with “serious wounds of body and spirit.”

headline: In a Corrupt World Where the Violent Bear It Away
text: HE has 60 titles to his credit, ranging from one-reel shorts to international epics, with an Academy Award-wining documentary along the way (the 1947 feature “Design for Death”). But Richard Fleischer remains among the least known and least honored of major American filmmakers, in part because of the sheer volume of his output. Even the most conscientious critic has a hard time picking through the many impersonal projects  films like “Doctor Dolittle” with Rex Harrison (1967), or the 1980 remake of “The Jazz Singer” with Neil Diamond  to uncover the core of his achievement.

headline: Modernizing an Old Elevator
text: Q I am an owner in a small co-op in New York City. The building was built in the early 1900s. We need to modernize the elevator, which rides on wood rails. Some elevator companies say we need to replace them with steel rails, an expensive proposition. Others say we don’t have to. Who is right?

headline: In the N.F.L., It’s Not Cheating Until You Start Videotaping
text: An N.F.L. team could place an army of lip readers on the sideline to try to steal messages from the opposing side. It could fill a row of seats behind the other team’s bench with espionage experts to decipher all the sideline cues. It could have scouts in the press box aiming binoculars at every opposing coach, scribbling notes to match with game tape to glean what all the signals mean.

headline: A Condo’s Bylaws Say Nothing About Proxies
text: Q Our condo just elected a new board at a meeting that began at 6:30 p.m.   Many of the owners were not able to attend, but when we asked about proxies to cast our votes, the managing agent told us that if we did not care enough to attend the meeting, we would not be allowed to vote.

headline: Stifled, Egypt’s Young Turn to Islamic Fervor
text: CAIRO — The concrete steps leading from Ahmed Muhammad Sayyid’s first-floor apartment sag in the middle, worn down over time, like Mr. Sayyid himself. Once, Mr. Sayyid had a decent job and a chance to marry. But his fiancée’s family canceled the engagement because after two years, he could not raise enough money to buy an apartment and furniture.

headline: The Price for Being International

headline: Deferred Dreams That Resonate Across Decades
text: IN the shabby living room of a Chicago apartment a frustrated young chauffeur dreams of owning a business and buying pearls for his wife. His fiery sister, a college student, dreams of becoming a doctor. His weary mother dreams of a nice home for them all, and his pregnant wife dreams of just holding on until their poverty eases.

headline: Of Crime and the River
text: In his unparalleled “Encounters With the Archdruid,” John McPhee describes the conservationist’s version of “hell on earth” as a series of concentric circles. At the outermost ring of the “devil’s world” is a moat “filled mainly with DDT” (this was 1971, remember). Next comes “a moat of burning gasoline,” then there are bulldozers and chain saws, until one reaches “the absolute epicenter ... where stands a dam.” Why? “Because rivers are the ultimate metaphors of existence, and dams destroy rivers.” It’s that simple.

headline: Long Cruises: Too Much of a Good Thing?
text: Cruises are like road races. Some are short and to the point, like 10Ks, and some are mileage-heavy, requiring a marathonlike time commitment. The trend for marathon cruises (longer than 30 days) is definitely strong, according to Mimi Weisband, a spokeswoman for Crystal Cruises, who attributes it to a growing distaste for flying and an already established pattern of passengers taking shorter back-to-back cruises to create longer travel experiences.

headline: Anna-Liisa Corsi, Daniel Gonda
text: Anna-Liisa Corsi, a daughter of Irmeli and Louis Corsi of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Daniel Francis Gonda, a son of Patricia and Frank Gonda of Fairfield, Conn., are to be married on Sunday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an events space in New York. The Rev. Bruce C. Page, a Presbyterian minister, is to officiate.

headline: Backers and Critics Spar Over a Rail Plan
text: WHILE some towns in central New Jersey are eagerly anticipating a New Jersey Transit plan to build a rail line intended to ease traffic congestion, others are refusing to climb on board.

headline: Some Offbeat and on Beat Frequencies
text: Troupe Majidi

headline: Old-School Spies
text: England’s enduring class system can be aptly summed up in two words: public school. Those who attend English public schools  in reality expensive private schools  inherit a kind of right to rule. They learn how to survive in a world no less riven by competition and cruelty than society itself. After graduating, they can forever recognize one another. Even those who rebel are shaped by the experience. To be an English public schoolboy  yes, most are still boys  is to belong to a caste.

headline: More Power? Add Pressure
text: IN simplest terms, an engine produces power by burning fuel; to make more power, it must burn more fuel.

headline: Officials Monitor G.P.S., and Car Batteries
text: THE global positioning system units installed in government vehicles around Long Island last year were intended to keep costs down and the staff in line, but they have kept some employees from going anywhere at all.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: Comedy

headline: A General in Army of Volunteers, Wade Is Honored
text: LOS ANGELES  Like nearly everything else in this ever-changing city, the professional golf tournament hereabouts has undergone more official name and address changes than Liz Taylor. At last count, what is now the Northern Trust Open has been known by eight different names and has been played on 11 different golf courses since its birth in 1926.

headline: A Collection Devoted to Space Saving
text: LITCHFIELD

headline: Forget Caps and Gowns, Try White Dresses and Bouquets
text: ON a recent Tuesday afternoon, dozens of girls descended on Botticelli Bridal Boutique in Bronxville, N.Y., and were quickly mired in layers of taffeta and satin. The girls were not preparing for a wedding, but for graduation ceremonies at their public high schools.

headline: Rediscovering Operas: What About Botstein?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Early Goal Gives Rangers a Shot of Momentum
text: It had barely registered to the Madison Square Garden crowd, not to mention the Buffalo Sabres, that Saturday afternoon’s game had started, when Rangers center Brandon Dubinsky grabbed control of the puck and barreled toward the Buffalo net.

headline: As O’Neal’s Shadow Fades, Who Will Cast the Next One?
text: NEW ORLEANS  Shaquille O’Neal was everywhere, dominating the French Quarter the way he once dominated the fourth quarter. That was his DunkTruck parked in front of the local aquarium, drawing curious onlookers and dunking contestants Friday morning. That was his party, with the N.F.L. star Reggie Bush as co-host, drawing the brightest stars Friday night.

headline: Nascar Returns to Basics in Hope Fans Will Return to Nascar
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  No one has acknowledged seeing The Punch, but it has already gone down in Nascar lore alongside the great fights in stock-car history. Tony Stewart versus Kurt Busch in 2008 may not top Cale Yarborough taking on Donnie and Bobby Allison after a wreck on the last lap of the 1979 Daytona 500.

headline: Unforgivable Behavior, Inadmissible Evidence
text: Washington

headline: Who’s That Kid Staging Sondheim?
text: WHEN people think of Broadway special effects, the first things that probably come to mind are big, lumbering spectacles like the chandelier in “Phantom of the Opera.” Such elements are designed to drop jaws, stop shows and above all draw attention. But they don’t always draw good reviews.

headline: When It Rains, It’s Porous
text: DAN RAIA thinks that the Pelham Gardens section of the northeast Bronx is sinking, and as proof he points to the hole in the concrete driveway at his boxy brick house.

headline: Being Poor in a ‘Charge It’ Society
text: To the Editor:

headline: Strange Magic
text: Your powerhouse of a musical, “Passing Strange,” is about to open on Broadway, which might seem like an unexpected turn of events for a 46-year-old songwriter who has spent most of his career rocking with underground bands in small clubs. Have you always loved musical theater? No. I’ve seen very few musicals, and my producers get scared when I give my opinion of them. Apparently, it’s not the thing to do when you’re on Broadway, to dis other shows. Let’s just say I loved “Chicago.”

headline: Queens Man Is Arrested in Killing of Therapist
text: A 39-year-old man who blamed a Manhattan psychiatrist for having him institutionalized 17 years ago was charged on Saturday with killing a female therapist in a furious knife attack and then slashing the psychiatrist when he tried to come to the woman’s aid, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Doubts on Security as Pakistani Vote Nears
text: GUJRAT, Pakistan  The winners of what may be the most anticipated election this country has held will be settled the usual way on Monday, by the number of ballots and fierce arguments over how they are counted. That, and perhaps the number of guns.

headline: Father Accused of Killing Daughter
text: A building superintendent in the Bronx with a history of mental illness strangled his 14-year-old daughter and tried to burn her body in the building’s incinerator, the police said on Saturday.

headline: New Site Tells All About New York’s Ports
text: There’s something reassuring about knowing you can hop on a ship and cruise to warmer climes when you’re living in the New York area in February. CruisingFromNewYork.com, a new Web site that was started last month, aims to expedite this fantasy. The site breaks down New York’s three ports Manhattan (55th Street and 12th Avenue); Brooklyn (Pier 12 in Red Hook), above; and Cape Liberty (Bayonne, N.J.)  including directions, port history, nearby restaurants and parking. It also gives itineraries, along with a calendar of departures for 2008 and 2009.

headline: The Grand Old White Party Confronts Obama
text: THE curse continues. Regardless of party, it’s hara-kiri for a politician to step into the shadow of even a mediocre speech by Barack Obama.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 37 at Pakistan Rally
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  A suicide bomber rammed a car into a campaign rally in the tribal areas on Saturday, killing 37 people and wounding at least 90 others.

headline: Correction: ‘Inside the List’
text: A brief report in the Inside the List column on Feb. 3 about the annual Edgar Awards, given by the Mystery Writers of America, misstated the date of this year’s presentation banquet. It will be May 1.

headline: Hemingway’s Letter: Better Left Unread
text: To the Editor:

headline: Married, in a Way, to the Mob
text: EVERY once in a while at the Dog ’n Cat House, a pet grooming business in Ozone Park, Queens, the doorbell will ring when no one seems to be outside. The women who work there, attending to poodles and fluffy lap dogs, do not flinch, a receptionist named Beatrice said the other day. “We just say, ‘Hi, John,’ ” she added with a laugh.

headline: Settling Into a Defensive Crouch
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Jorge Posada, who is 36 years old and has a bit of gray in his black hair, is still catching and still excelling for the Yankees. At an age when most catchers have retired to the couch, switched positions or stopped being productive, Posada is still a formidable threat.

headline: Division of Champions Is Now an Also-Ran
text: The years have not been kind to the N.H.L.’s Southeast Division. The Tampa Bay Lightning, winner of the Stanley Cup in 2004, has languished at the bottom of the standings. The Carolina Hurricanes, who won the Cup in 2006, the season after the lockout, have struggled to find consistency.

headline: The Charisma Mandate
text: TAKING office in 1933, Franklin D. Roosevelt confronted a country in crisis. Four in 10 working-age Americans were jobless. Banks were collapsing. There were long lines outside tellers’ windows as people rushed to withdraw their savings.

headline: A Future So Bright It Can Handle Dark
text: DURING the Metropolitan Opera’s 2004-5 season, when the mezzo-soprano Stephanie Blythe sang Eduige in a new production of Handel’s “Rodelinda,” I was not the only opera fan who thought that here, at last, was the true successor to Marilyn Horne in the Baroque and bel canto repertory.

headline: Restrained, With a Raucous Claim to Fame
text: THOUGH he hobnobbed with royalty, and might even have known a mermaid or two, the circus impresario P. T. Barnum retained a soft spot for Bethel, his hometown, 69 miles from Midtown Manhattan in northern Fairfield County.

headline: Head Scarves in Turkey
text: To the Editor:

headline: Marymount Being Sold; Village to Gain Taxes
text: FORDHAM UNIVERSITY has agreed to sell the historic Marymount College campus in Tarrytown for $27 million to EF Education, a private language school with 10 campuses in the country and 35 throughout the world.

headline: Everybody Hurts
text: If you believe you are by now immune to gory novels, here’s one with enough malevolence to give even the most hardened readers nightmares. “The Seven Days of Peter Crumb,” a chronicle of the final week in a psychopath’s life by the British actor and writer Jonny Glynn, is gruesome, obscene and utterly disturbing. It is also absorbing and well written. Reading it, I fought the urge to throw up. Needless to say, I was transfixed.

headline: Hitting the Books
text: To the Editor: In "In Summer, Hitting the Books, Not Just the Beach" (Feb. 3), I was exhausted just reading about summer programs where high school students can take college courses or SAT prep courses or perform community service to meet their schools’ service requirements or to enhance their college applications. What ever happened to the good old days when summer vacations were for fun?

headline: California Still Counting Heavy Feb. 5 Vote
text: SAN FRANCISCO  It has been nearly two weeks since primary day in California, and Stephen Weir is still ironing ballots.

headline: A Smiling, Fidgeting McCain, Learning to Rein Himself In
text: WASHINGTON  So this is what it looks like when the maverick becomes The Man.

headline: Transition Continues for Igawa and Yanks
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Even the wealthy Yankees are wary of wasting $46 million on one player, so they are not about to give up on Kei Igawa, the left-handed pitcher from Japan who was a disappointment in 2007, his first season in the United States.

headline: Liaisons Dangereuses
text: IT was a slow weeknight at the Comfort Zone, a meeting place for men that is in a drab office building amid the Broadway musicals on West 49th Street. Although snow and sleet fell in the streets, several men endured the frigid weather to make their way to the club’s spacious second-floor suite, eager to indulge the yearnings that had driven them out into the stormy night.

headline: Sheila Frazier and John Atchison
text: IN 1979, the shag was all the rage  the haircut that is  and John Atchison, a New York celebrity hair stylist, worked his magic on Sheila Frazier, a Los Angeles actress who was catapulted to sex symbol status after her performance in the 1972 film “Super Fly.”

headline: Taking Play Seriously
text: On a drizzly Tuesday night in late January, 200 people came out to hear a psychiatrist talk rhapsodically about play  not just the intense, joyous play of children, but play for all people, at all ages, at all times. (All species too; the lecture featured touching photos of a polar bear and a husky engaging playfully at a snowy outpost in northern Canada.) Stuart Brown, president of the National Institute for Play, was speaking at the New York Public Librarys main branch on 42nd Street. He created the institute in 1996, after more than 20 years of psychiatric practice and research persuaded him of the dangerous long-term consequences of play deprivation. In a sold-out talk at the library, he and Krista Tippett, host of the public-radio program Speaking of Faith, discussed the biological and spiritual underpinnings of play. Brown called play part of the developmental sequencing of becoming a human primate. If you look at what produces learning and memory and well-being, play is as fundamental as any other aspect of life, including sleep and dreams.

headline: Most Popular Cruises
text: Perhaps it’s no surprise that the Caribbean, long a traditional cruise destination, remains the most popular spot for vacationers, with 42.8 percent of respondents to an industry survey saying they were headed there in 2008. But Europe seems to be gaining in popularity (up by 42 percent over 2006)  perhaps because of the cruise industry’s efforts to convince customers that booking a cruise is a way to lock in costs, even if the dollar continues to decline in value.

headline: Britain to Nationalize Troubled Mortgage Lender
text: LONDON  The British government announced Sunday that it would bring Northern Rock, the struggling mortgage lender, under its control. It was the first nationalization of a bank in more than a decade and a huge blow for the government of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: Early Rally Offsets Economic Worries
text: Despite a decline on Thursday and Friday over worries about the economy, the stock market gained ground last week.

headline: That Boring Job Should Sound an Alarm
text: Q. When you get up in the morning, you never want to go to work. Your job is repetitive, uninteresting and offers no challenges. When you are there, the clock barely moves, and you can’t wait to leave.

headline: Banker Leaves Hong Kong Post
text: David Li, the Hong Kong banker and lawmaker who is paying $8.1 million to settle a United States inquiry into his possible role in an insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones & Company, resigned from the city government’s executive council late Saturday.

headline: Alice Marshall and Arthur Pesch III
text: Alice Spencer Marshall, a daughter of Lisa and Michael Marshall of Crozet, Va., was married on Saturday evening to Arthur Jacob Pesch III, a son of Patricia Harder of Free Union, Va., and Mr. Pesch of Champaign, Ill. The Rev. Dominic M. Langevin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the University of Virginia Chapel in Charlottesville, Va.

headline: The Forensic Humanitarian
text: International human rights work attracts activists and lawyers, diplomats and retired politicians. One of the most admired figures in the field, however, is a ponytailed statistics guru from Silicon Valley named Patrick Ball, who has spent nearly two decades fashioning a career for himself at the intersection of mathematics and murder. You could call him a forensic humanitarian.

headline: Correction: Rock Around the Block
text: The Weekend in New York column on Feb. 3, about rock ‘n’ roll sites, misstated the name of a club run by Andy Warhol. It was Dom  not the Electric Circus, its name under new management.

headline: Turning Minuses Into Pluses
The Hunt
text: An eager ex-Londoner found that just having money and browsing Craigslist wouldn’t get him an apartment.

headline: Famous Art Heists
text: The biggest art theft in American history occurred at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston on March 18, 1990.

headline: Drivers to Watch
text: Nascar wants the drivers in its premier Sprint Cup series to show more emotion this season as a way to lure back fans who may have soured on the sport.

headline: Another Broken Deal Ends Up in Court
text: Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio broadcaster in the United States, said Sunday that it had sued a unit of the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners to force a completion of a $1.2 billion purchase of 56 television stations.

headline: ‘The Last Flight of the Scarlet Macaw’
text: If you feel a need to escape the law, elude creditors, hide assets, or shed the skin of your humdrum life, you could do worse than run away to Belize. Belize is a tiny nation tucked between Guatemala, Mexico, and the Caribbean Sea. It's firmly attached to Central America but considers itself a Caribbean island, like a chicken that thinks it's a duck. For more than a hundred years Belize was known as British Honduras, one of the most remote outposts of the British Empire, which explains why it's the only Latin American nation to embrace English as its official language.

headline: ‘Detective Story’
text: The manuscript that I am hereby making public was entrusted to my care by my client, Antonio R. Martens. As to who he is, you will learn that from him in due course. All that I shall say in advance is that, given his scholastic attainments, he evinced a surprising flair for writing, as indeed does anyone, in my experience, who for once in his life steels himself to face up to his fate.

headline: ‘The Spare Wife’
text: Jacqueline Posner stood at the edge of her dining room and aimed a blow-dryer at the center of a pale peach rose. It just refused to open the way it should, and she was running so late she hadn't even checked the place cards Ponce had set out that afternoon.

headline: ‘Tree Shaker’
text: Mandela had started life as a child of royalty, had become the country's most notorious outlaw, and was now an emblem of moral courage around the globe.

These Lede posts continue the conversation about points raised in “Generation Faithful,” a Times series about Middle Eastern youth. The first article focuses on the “Stalled Lives” of Egypt’s young, and the initial “Majlis” entries are from the staff of The Times’ Cairo bureau.

text: Congratulations to my most successful Yale classmate, who gets a big spread in the NYT.

headline: Gore and the Internet
text: In badly worded earlier post I said something some people have interpreted as buying into the myth “Al Gore said he invented the Internet.” I was actually — if you read it closely — describing the claim that Al Gore said that as an example of a pervasive myth spread by some people in the news media.

text: An illustrated biography of the artist Wayne Thiebaud.

text: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times' archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

headline: Today on the Rangers’ Dotted Line: Tyutin
text: Another day, another Rangers’ contract extension. Today’s winner is defenseman Fedor Tyutin, who follows deals given goalie Henrik Lundqvist ($41.25 million over six years) and defenseman Dan Girardi ($3.1 million over two).

text: P. T. Barnum retained a soft spot for his hometown, where 18th-century Colonials and 1960s ranches house a tradition-minded community.

text: Cars like the Plymouth Superbird were once sold to the public just to make them eligible for the racetrack.
