text: Stories from the world of property:

headline: A Myth Debunked: The ‘Guaranteed Point’ and Tight Playoff Races
text: Gary Bettman, Brian Burke and the rest of the NHL establishment have said repeatedly that the “guaranteed point” teams get for being tied after 60 minutes has made playoff races tighter. Never mind that the system has everyone playing it safe and easy in the third period so they can get their 1 point, and never mind that last year’s playoff races would actually have been tighter under a 3-2-1-0 points system.

headline: Sunday’s Sampler
text: Things were fairly subdued on the morning’s news shows. And the weather in Wisconsin is certainly curtailing some events.

headline: Obama and Edwards Meet
text: CHICAGO – Senator Barack Obama and his former Democratic presidential rival, John Edwards, held a private meeting today in North Carolina, aides confirmed.

headline: Understanding the rules
text: I’ve written about Clinton Rules, under which anything a Clinton (or a Gore) says, no matter how innocuous it would seem if someone else said it, becomes proof of evil intentions.

headline: A Vanishing Pastime
text: Warmer winters are beginning to render the winter pond into the stuff of memory.

headline: Rangers Welcome Latest Shot of Youthful Energy
text: The Rangers were thrilled to get a dominant game out of rookie center Brandon Dubinsky on Saturday and just as happy to see forward Ryan Callahan dump in two goals against San Jose on Sunday. The injection of youth comes just in time, as the Rangers try to mount a serious run toward a good playoff berth in April.

headline: Road Trip: Home Again
text: I’ve got a confession to make. After spending three days with the Cornell basketball team as it traveled to Harvard and Dartmouth for a weekend road trip, I bailed before the most grueling part. That would be the six-hour bus ride back to Ithaca after the Big Red’s victory at Dartmouth on Saturday. (My official excuse is that I had to get home to write a story, which will appear in Monday’s New York Times.)

headline: Modigliani Does Madrid
text: Considering he’s so popular, there haven’t been as many shows dedicated to Italian painter and sculptor Amedeo Modigliani (1884-1920) as you might expect. If you are a fan, it’s worth braving the crowd to see “Modigliani and His Time,” the new show hosted by the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum and the Caja Madrid Foundation.

headline: The Octopus Tank
text: “August” is about an unwelcome reunion of the Weston family. For those of you who haven’t read or seen the play, here’s the setup: After the patriarch, Beverly, disappears, his far-flung and largely out-of-touch clan gathers together around Violet, the mother, at the family home in Pawhuska, Okla. As the grown Weston daughters arrive, it’s one confrontation and crisis after another. Ivy, the dutiful one who still lives close to home, is having a secret affair with her cousin Little Charles. Barbara and her husband, Bill, are trying to keep their impending divorce under wraps. Karen flies in from Miami with her lowlife fiancé, Steve — and he immediately devotes himself to seducing Jean, Barbara’s teenage daughter.

headline: British Bungle Bank Bailout
text: Is this a case of throwing good money after bad?

headline: Lifting, Lights, and Little People
text: Not every migraine has a prologue or “aura,” and not every aura is followed by a headache. Nevertheless, these overtures to pain or isolated events are the most peculiar aspect of the illness and may offer insights into the nature of perception itself. As a child I had what I called “lifting feelings.” Every once in a while, I had a powerful internal sensation of being pulled upward, as if my head were rising, even though I knew my feet hadn’t left the ground. This lift was accompanied by what can only be called awe — a feeling of transcendence.

headline: When ‘Identity Politics’ Is Rational
text: If there’s anything everyone is against in these election times, it’s “identity politics,” a phrase that covers a multitude of sins. Let me start with a definition. (It may not be yours, but it will at least allow the discussion to be framed.) You’re practicing identity politics when you vote for or against someone because of his or her skin color, ethnicity, religion, gender, sexual orientation, or any other marker that leads you to say yes or no independently of a candidate’s ideas or policies. In essence identity politics is an affirmation of the tribe against the claims of ideology, and by ideology I do not mean something bad (a mistake frequently made), but any agenda informed by a vision of what the world should be like.

headline: Ferris State Shocks Miami
text: Another weekend, another shakeup in college hockey. It seems like every week one team either makes a big jump or a steep plunge in its NCAA Tournament standing, and this week was no different. The weekend’s biggest surprise was Miami (Ohio) being swept by Ferris State. Riding a four-game winless streak, the RedHawks’ reward looks like a first-round showdown with Wisconsin at the Midwest regional in Madison. Some gift.

headline: Belichick Opens Up (Or, Who’s Matt Walsh?)
text: The Boston Globe has the first comments from Patriots Coach Bill Belichick on the spying scandal that he no doubt wishes would go away. Among other things, Belichick said he “couldn’t pick Matt Walsh out of a lineup,” a reference to the former Patriots staff member who has hinted that he may have a lot to say about the Patriots’ video library.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The TV Watch column on Wednesday, about coverage of the presidential primaries on Tuesday night, misidentified the channel that calls its stars “the best political team on television.” It is CNN, not MSNBC.

headline: No Windows, No Heat, No Staff, No Rent. This Is a Gallery?
text: The real estate listing would read something like this: Approximately 800 square feet, ground floor, no windows, no heat, no drain pipe under the sink (slop bucket required), constant traffic noise, fine coating of black gunk on everything.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
text: FRANKFURT  For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes an auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: Weather and Other Primaries Thwart Wisconsin
text: MILWAUKEE  After all the attention showered upon Iowa, New Hampshire and a coast-to-coast string of states with elections this month, the voters of Wisconsin were anticipating having the presidential race to themselves for a week.

headline: Mickelson Ends Long Wait With a Win at Riviera
text: LOS ANGELES  Phil Mickelson completed a quest Sunday at Riviera Country Club, reaching a goal that was personal and professional. His unrequited love affair with Riviera began when he first stepped inside the ropes here 20 years ago as a skinny 17-year-old high school golfer. Not until late Sunday afternoon, when he held aloft the silver trophy after his two-stroke victory in the Northern Trust Open, was it consummated.

headline: No Lull in Mortgage Pitches
text: The mortgage market may be in a historic upheaval, but mortgage companies continue to pump out upbeat advertisements.

headline: Newman Foils Stewart and Wins Daytona
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A pack of cars rounded Turn 2 on the final lap of the Daytona 500 on Sunday night, with Tony Stewart in the lead and close enough to imagine he might actually win this race after 10 years of futility and frustration. But out of the blue came a streak of blue.

headline: Sense of Freedom Follows a Career Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  His official portrait sits in a closet at the Connecticut Democratic Party headquarters in Hartford. Party elders have stripped him of his superdelegate cape.

headline: Iran Hangs 2 on Murder and Rape Charges
text: TEHRAN  Iran on Sunday executed two men  one accused of murder and the other of raping children  in a prison in the northeastern province of Khorasan, the ISNA news agency reported.

headline: New CDs
text: CHRIS CAGLE “My Life’s Been a Country Song” (Capitol Nashville)

headline: Director’s Reward: A Second First Chance
text: HOLLYWOOD  The movie industry loves a comeback, if you’ve achieved stardom once already. But what if that first big break slipped by unexploited?

headline: London Underground Vetoes Poster of Nude
text: She was born in 1532, but the golden-haired, milky-skinned woman cocking her hips behind a transparent veil in “Venus,” below, a painting by the German artist Lucas Cranach the Elder, is a bit too much for Transport for London, operator of the London subway system, The Associated Press reported. The painting is one of 70 works scheduled for exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London beginning March 8, and the academy wanted to advertise the show in the Underground system using a poster. But Transport for London said no, unless the bottom half was cropped, according to the academy. “I think it is because she’s totally nude as opposed to, say, she’s topless,” said Jennifer Francis, an academy spokeswoman. “We’re shocked. We wouldn’t have put a poster design forward if we thought it was offensive.” Transport for London said in a statement, “We have to take account of the full range of travelers and endeavor not to cause offense in the advertising we display.”

headline: Today, Class, We’re Playing Carnegie Hall
text: The Manhattan School of Music created a prototypical halfway house  a graduate program in orchestral performance  intended to help gifted students make their way from school to professional life. Its curriculum has been heavy on the practical: from learning symphonic as opposed to solo repertory to understanding the psychopathology of orchestra life and even to tips on travel.

headline: Huckabee Takes a Break and Heads to the Islands
text: GRAND CAYMAN, Cayman Islands  Mike Huckabee left voters behind in the snow in Wisconsin over the weekend and headed to this getaway resort island.

headline: Grosses Give ‘Jumper’ Cause to Celebrate
text: Newcomers led by “Jumper” captured four of the top five positions when the North American three-day weekend film box-office grosses were tallied by the tracking company Media by Numbers. “Jumper” (Fox), starring Hayden Christensen as a man with a talent for teleportation, pulled in an estimated $27.2 million. The sequel “Step Up 2 the Streets” (Buena Vista), about a teenage girl (Briana Evigan) with a talent for dance, took No. 2 with $19.6 million. Third place, with $19 million, went to “The Spiderwick Chronicles” (Paramount and Nickelodeon), about a family in a spooky old house. The only holdover in the Top 5 was “Fool’s Gold” (Warner Brothers). That action-romance-comedy, last week’s top-ranking film, slid to fourth place on a gross of $13 million. The romance “Definitely, Maybe” (Universal), with Ryan Reynolds and Abigail Breslin, finished fifth with $9.7 million.

headline: A Plan to Offer 50 Sites on Politics in 50 States
text: In the middle of a media-saturated political season, Jared Kushner, publisher of The New York Observer, has been quietly nurturing an ambitious political journalism venture.

headline: After Stumbling, Facebook Finds a Working Eraser
text: Facebook.com, stung last week by the wrath of members who want to sever their relationships, tripped again when it tried to let them do so.

headline: Moving the Grange, and Twisting It Around, Too
text: The idea is to restore Alexander Hamilton’s country home, the Grange, to a state that Hamilton himself would recognize.

headline: A Referral Service That Ensures Someone Actually Makes a Sale
text: ONLINE shoppers who can’t decide whether to pull the trigger on their next purchase may be surprised at a new alternative: an offer to get it free.

headline: Can’t We All Just Agree to Agree?
text: A paper in The Journal of Consumer Research explores the “false consensus effect,” the degree to which people assume, often incorrectly, that others share their opinion. The authors found that the effect is greater among people who hold positive opinions than among those who hold negative ones.

headline: Carpenters Fans Seek to Spare Home
text: Fans of the 1970s pop duo the Carpenters regard a modest home in the Los Angeles suburb of Downey, Calif., as their version of Graceland, but the owners want to tear it down to build a larger house, The Associated Press reported. Featured on the cover of the 1973 hit album “Now & Then,” the five-bedroom tract house, where the siblings Karen and Richard Carpenter lived, is also where they wrote some of their greatest hits and where Karen, an anorexic, collapsed in 1983 before dying. Manuel and Blanca Melendez Parra, owners of the house, apparently have grown weary of the visits of homage-paying Carpenters fans. They have torn down an annex used as an office, rehearsal studio and recreation room, and they want to replace the main residence. Officials in Downey said that they had received plans for a new residence, but had not issued a demolition permit. The musician Jon Konjoyan, above at the site with the album, is leading the campaign to save the home. He said he wanted it rehabilitated, or at least moved.

headline: Rangers Show They Can Win Against West
text: In their first nine games against the Western Conference this season, the Rangers ran up against a group of big, immovable teams, for whom a snarling defensive style has become the price of admission to any conference game.

headline: The New Boss’s Salty Language Raises Eyebrows at His Papers
text: Samuel Zell, the new head of the Tribune Company, is known for colorful language  the sort that cannot be printed in his newspapers.

headline: Commuting to School: Riders Tell Their Tales
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Lights and Darks of Life, Punctuated by Stillness and Guitars
text: “In the silent pools of the night,” Eva Yerbabuena writes in the program notes for her new flamenco show, “we learn how life is illuminated by light, but intensified by darkness.” Fittingly, Ms. Yerbabuena begins “Signs and Wonders” standing on a darkened stage illuminated only by an overhead light. In the first section, she emerges from the blackness  her long ruffled dress and bolero jacket adding texture to the intensity of the night scene  and grandly circles a stool, first lunging in front of it and then sitting with her hands on her knees, her eyes cast downward.

headline: Bracing for Revenge
text: Tel Aviv

headline: In Washington State Vote, Relevance Is an Issue
text: SEATTLE  As many as 1.5 million votes are projected to be cast in Washington State’s presidential primary on Tuesday. The question is whether they will count.

headline: Tanzania Welcomes Bush, but Obama Is Topic No. 1 on the Streets
text: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania  President Bush has been smothered with affection here, never more so than on Sunday, when he sat at a wooden desk under a sweltering sun with President Jakaya Kikwete by his side and signed a $698 million grant of foreign aid to Tanzania.

headline: Study Finds Cancer Diagnosis Linked to Insurance
text: ATLANTA  A nationwide study has found that the uninsured and those covered by Medicaid are more likely than those with private insurance to receive a diagnosis of cancer in late stages, often diminishing their chances of survival.

headline: Corrections
text: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Saturday misstated the 2007 compensation of John J. Mack, chief executive of Morgan Stanley. Mr. Mack, who did not receive a bonus in 2007, received compensation valued at $1.5 million, not $41.7 million. (The company’s Securities and Exchange Commission filing listed $40.2 million in stock awards for Mr. Mack in December 2006, which was in the company’s fiscal 2007 year, but those awards applied to fiscal 2006.) (Go to Article)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 29 about the filing of charges against an employee of the New York State Archives accused of illegally selling rare books and documents from the state’s collections included an erroneous spelling from an eBay listing for the surname of the addressee on an 1823 letter from John C. Calhoun, the 19th-century vice president. The addressee was Col. Charles Haines  personal secretary to DeWitt Clinton, the 19th-century governor of New York  not Haine.

headline: Kosovo Declares Its Independence From Serbia
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo  The province of Kosovo declared independence from Serbia on Sunday, sending tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians streaming through the streets to celebrate what they hoped was the end of a long and bloody struggle for national self-determination.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a pop music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday about Steve Riley and the Mamou Playboys, at Connolly’s on West 45th Street in Manhattan, misstated the date of the performance. It was on Sunday; the band will not perform on Thursday.

headline: Rebukes Are Swift for the Chief of Deutsche Post
text: BERLIN  The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: Vote Is Expected to Further Weaken Musharraf
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistanis began voting Monday morning in parliamentary elections that are expected to diminish President Pervez Musharraf further and present Washington with a challenging new political lineup here as it pursues its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda in the region.

headline: President-Elect of South Korea Is Questioned in Stock Scam
text: SEOUL, South Korea  President-elect Lee Myung-bak of South Korea was questioned Sunday by special prosecutors investigating accusations that he had engaged in financial fraud.

headline: Clinton and Obama Emphasize Economic Themes
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist economic appeals on Monday in an effort to attract support from economically struggling voters in Ohio and Texas, which are taking shape as potentially decisive contests in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: John Brunious, 67, Louisiana Trumpeter, Is Dead
text: John Brunious, a jazz trumpeter who devoted his career to the music of his native New Orleans, leading the Preservation Hall Jazz Band for more than a dozen years, died on Tuesday in Casselberry, Fla. He was 67 and had lived in Casselberry, outside Orlando, since being displaced by Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

headline: Former President Bush Backs McCain
text: HOUSTON  Senator John McCain got a President’s Day endorsement Monday from former President George Bush, who called him the best candidate to lead the country and dismissed conservative criticism of his candidacy as “absurd.”

headline: A Rip-Off by Health Insurers?
text: Have health insurers been systematically cheating patients and doctors of fair reimbursement for medical services? That is the disturbing possibility raised by an investigation of the industry’s arcane procedures for calculating “reasonable and customary” rates.

headline: Kennedy Assassination Trove Opened
text: DALLAS  After more than 40 years under lock and key, a large collection of documents and items related to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy was released by the Dallas County district attorney on Monday.

headline: Set Your Tasers on Slo-Mo Wipeout
text: The Japanese have always excelled at taking apart American products, making them better and then selling them back to us. Cars. Stereos. Cartoons. Outfielders.

headline: Chávez Backs Off Threats to Halt Oil Exports to U.S.
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  President Hugo Chávez said on Sunday that Venezuela was not planning to halt oil exports to the United States. The statement may ease fears in energy markets over fallout from Venezuela’s legal battle with Exxon Mobil over compensation for the nationalization of a large oil project.

headline: The Changed Seasons of Today’s Salt and Pepa
text: If you know nothing at all about the women who made up the former hip-hop duo Salt-n-Pepa, what you will learn from randomly watching a few minutes of the VH1 reality series about them is that they named themselves more aptly than most performers. There was no confusion in the birthing room, no mistake in the paperwork. They have fulfilled their titular destinies. Salt (Cheryl Wray) has become a woman of quiet and comfortable tastes, and Pepa (Sandra Denton) lives by the rules of spice and bite.

headline: Brazilian Film Wins Top Honors in Berlin
text: Films about police violence and prisoner abuse in Iraq captured the top prizes at the Berlin International Film Festival on Saturday. The Golden Bear for best film went to “Tropa de Elite” (“Elite Squad”), a Brazilian drama by José Padilha, right, about the black-uniformed paramilitary police who strike fear into residents of Rio de Janeiro shantytowns, The Associated Press reported. The Silver Bear jury grand prize went to “Standard Operating Procedure,” about the treatment of prisoners at the American-run Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. That film, directed by Errol Morris, was the first documentary ever shown in competition at the festival, where 21 films vied for honors this year. The Silver Bear for best director went to Paul Thomas Anderson for “There Will Be Blood,” starring Daniel Day-Lewis as an obsessed man in the oil industry.

headline: In a Hotel Deal, Showtime Fights HBO’s Dominance
text: The battle among pay TV channels may be entering a new arena: hotel rooms.

headline: Technology Can Be a Blessing for Bored Workers
text: OF all the repetitive, mind-numbing jobs in the late 19th century, cigar-rolling was special.

headline: Hendrick Dominant, Just Not in 500
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Of the 18 Nascar Sprint Cup teams that showed up at Daytona International Speedway at the start of Speedweeks, only two managed to generate the headlines and carry all of the expectations heading into Sunday’s Daytona 500.

headline: Antidoping Teams Lead California Event
text: PALO ALTO, Calif.  If professional cycling hopes to turn the page this year in its fight against doping, it hardly could choose a better way to start than with the group of racers who stood on the podium after the opening day of the Tour of California.

headline: 48 Hours on the Big Red Bus
text: HANOVER, N.H.  After victories at Harvard and at Dartmouth pushed his team’s record to 8-0 in the Ivy League, the Cornell men’s basketball coach, Steve Donahue, decided to indulge himself and his team.

headline: Team Takes Leave of Another Town
text: VERO BEACH, Fla.

headline: Veteran Judge in Bell Shooting Trial Has Seen It All Before
text: The first time Justice Arthur J. Cooperman of the State Supreme Court faced police officers charged in a high-profile case was in 1986, six years after becoming a judge. The case was tried in Queens, with the officers accused of torturing a teenage drug suspect with a stun gun.

headline: A Big-Time Injury Striking Little Players’ Knees
text: Last year, when Collin Link was 11 years old, he was tackled as he went in for a touchdown in pee-wee football.

headline: A Ring Doesn’t Ensure a Star’s Happiness
text: New Orleans

headline: Women of Flamenco Expand the Edges of Passionate Tradition
text: Flamenco is an art of fiery passion, as everyone knows. Its dancing feet are soul-shattering, its singing voices gut-wrenching. To renew or refashion flamenco, a little Latin influence is added here or an involved narrative there. But the four women who starred in “Mujeres” (“Women”), a gala program presented by World Music Institute’s New York Flamenco Festival 2008 on Friday at City Center, offered stunning proof that the old art lives on most vitally in committed new interpreters.

headline: Protecting a Monumental Sculpture
text: In the northeastern United States, with all the woods and hills, it is usually pretty hard to see five miles at a stretch. In a place like Utah’s Great Salt Lake  vast in its openness and flatness  five miles is a mere arm’s length away. That is why a Canadian company’s plan to begin oil-drilling from a pair of barges near Rozel Point, on the edge of the lake, has caused so much concern.

headline: Bad Apples and Blue Eyes: Shaking Loose Secrets From the Family Tree
text: There is a lake in the town of Templeton, where Lauren Groff’s debut novel is set. In that lake there is a dead 50-foot-long prehistoric monster. This may sound like a sufficiently major plot point on which to hang a story, but for Ms. Groff it’s just a teaser. To the extent that anything so casual is possible, Ms. Groff’s gigantic dead beast is a throwaway. And an opening salvo. The creature surfaces not at some dramatic climax, but in this book’s very first sentence.

headline: At Least 80 Are Killed in Afghan Suicide Bombing
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber blew himself up in a large crowd gathered at a dogfighting event just outside this city in southern Afghanistan, killing about 80 people and wounding more than 90 others in the country’s worst single bombing since 2001.

headline: A Day’s Work in Albany, a Day’s Pay, and $154 More
text: ALBANY  Assemblywoman Earlene Hooper and Senator Efrain González Jr. recorded more travel expenditures last year than any other lawmakers in their respective houses, according to records obtained from the state comptroller’s office.

headline: Balanchine, Steeped in Romance and Russia
text: New York City Ballet’s “Russian Treasures” program of works choreographed by George Balanchine to music by Tchaikovsky embodies important City Ballet history. All three ballets offer the usual chances for veteran dancers to “just do it,” an early central tenet of Balanchine’s work, as well as for dancers to prove their mettle in new roles, as three did on Saturday night in the first “Treasures” of the season, at the New York State Theater.

headline: After China Ships Out iPhones, Smugglers Make It a Return Trip
text: SHANGHAI  Factories here churn out iPhones that are exported to the United States and Europe. Then thousands of them are smuggled right back into China.

headline: A Quirky Night for Quirky Romance
text: At first blush the stage at the Allen Room on Friday night appeared to be set for seduction. Soft lighting? (Check.) Simmering groove? (Check.) Slow drift of headlights in the background, along Central Park South? (O.K., sure.) And finally Kurt Elling in a double-breasted suit, microphone in hand. “Love is the only thing to balance fearing,” he sang, with suave self-assurance. “Loving the deepest depths appearing.” (What’s that again?)

headline: Scripts Reappear on ‘Daily Show’
text: The teleprompter was working again on Wednesday at “The Daily Show,” as Jon Stewart performed his news satire on Comedy Central with the support of writers for the first time in more than three months.

headline: Government to Control Struggling British Bank
text: LONDON  The British government announced on Sunday that it would bring Northern Rock, the struggling mortgage lender, under its control. It was the first nationalization of a bank in more than a decade and a huge blow for the administration of Prime Minister Gordon Brown.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Before Murder, Troubled Quest to Find Mother
text: In the eight and a half months before his arrest in the fatal stabbing of a Manhattan therapist, a Queens man became so obsessed with his institutionalized mother that his father kept moving her from nursing home to nursing home, a law enforcement official said on Sunday.

headline: Back in Arizona, Johnson Is Staring Down 300-Win Milestone
text: TUCSON  As Randy Johnson approached the mound Sunday, Arizona Diamondbacks Manager Bob Melvin gave him a wide berth, as if trying to avoid being singed. Johnson’s burning competitiveness once again had turned him into the world’s tallest sparkler.

headline: Tally Ho! A Determined Crew Hunts for Fox Hunters
text: LUXBOROUGH, England  Graham Floyd, an operative from the League Against Cruel Sports, had been on the hill for about an hour when he thought he heard something. “Everybody in!” he barked, conveying his hefty, camouflage-clothed person with surprising agility into a nearby thicket of brambles.

headline: Suicide Bomber Is Spotted and Shot, but Kills 3 in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  It was Sunday, a busy day for shop owners in the bustling central Baghdad district of Karada, and Abbas Ali was tending to his morning routine when screams from people outside stopped him.

headline: Wisconsin Weighs on 2 Candidates
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton has vowed to make her stand in the Ohio and Texas primaries on March 4. John McCain has been embraced by Republican leaders as the nominee-apparent. But each has a big stake in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday  and it’s not just about winning or losing.

headline: Our Founding Lame Duck
text: HISTORIANS have often noted that George Washington not only began but also did much to define the American presidency. He imprinted on the office a sense of competence and integrity that can make later presidents, even successful ones, seem to fall short. Then to top it off, he left the job voluntarily. No law required him to step down, and running against him would have been impossible. Retiring after two terms, Washington enabled the transfer of executive power by electoral process.

headline: Celebrating the Semicolon in a Most Unlikely Location
text: It was nearly hidden on a New York City Transit public service placard exhorting subway riders not to leave their newspaper behind when they get off the train.

headline: In Harlem, Baby Talk and the Art of Diplomacy
text: Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, successor to Dr. Spock and a precursor to the hordes of child care experts whose books now crowd stores’ shelves, entered a small classroom at an elementary school in Harlem one Saturday not long ago and smiled broadly. The parents in the room, mostly mothers, did not return the favor. They were seeking child care advice because they’d had it, and they were evidently tired, in no mood to charm.

headline: Primal Call and Response at a Band’s Rumbling Bash
text: Sad-eyed Matt Korvette, lanky and a little slobby, stood on a chair, put his hands up by his clavicle and ripped off his white T-shirt from the collar down. Gathering concentration, he looked straight ahead as he made this strong and pathetic gesture.

headline: Gardner Lindzey, Former President of the American Psychological Association, Is Dead at 87
text: Gardner Lindzey, a psychologist, editor and former president of the American Psychological Association who helped build a national framework to encourage scholarly exchanges and collaborations in the social sciences, died on Feb. 4 in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 87.

headline: College Paper Vows to Fight a Takeover by Gannett
text: J. David McSwane, the student editor of The Rocky Mountain Collegian, was looking forward to a quiet spring semester at the Colorado State University after drawing global attention last fall for a four-word editorial criticizing President Bush.

headline: Angst in a Living Room Near You
text: Open house. The words are celestial music to the ears of certain real-estate-obsessed New Yorkers. What better way to spend a sleepy Sunday afternoon than by poking around condos and co-ops for sale, clucking with satisfaction at the lack of closet space or envying the eat-in kitchen?

headline: Back Today, Pettitte Discusses H.G.H. Use
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte will not be under oath Monday, but he will be in the spotlight when he meets with the news media for the first time to discuss his admitted use of human growth hormone.

headline: Judicial Rebukes on Clean Air
text: The federal courts have been a bulwark against the Bush administration’s relentless efforts to weaken 40 years’ worth of environmental law, including statutes protecting the nation’s forests, wetlands and endangered species. The courts have been especially important in resisting the administration’s assault on the 1970 Clean Air Act, which began with Vice President Dick Cheney’s 2001 energy report and continues to this day.

headline: In Images, the Lower East Side of Starker Days
text: Few parts of New York City have undergone a more rapid and drastic physical transformation over the past 20 or 30 years than the area below East 14th Street known broadly as the Lower East Side. In the 1970s and ’80s the neighborhood was a gritty and often dangerous district where the population was dwindling and businesses were gradually being shuttered.

headline: Deal for Kidd Has a Chance to Resurface
text: NEW ORLEANS  On a neutral court, in a meaningless game, Jason Kidd pulled on a blue jersey that read “East” across the chest and started bouncing clever passes to grateful teammates. He was neither a Net nor a Maverick in Sunday’s All-Star Game, his identity appropriately ambiguous for the evening.

headline: Democrats Should Read Kipling
text: Browsing through a used-book store Friday  in the Milwaukee airport, of all places  I came across a 1981 paperback collection of George Orwell’s essays. That’s how I happened to reread his 1942 essay on Rudyard Kipling. Given Orwell’s perpetual ability to elucidate, one shouldn’t be surprised that its argument would shed light or so it seems to me  on contemporary American politics.

headline: Footnotes
text: Zoe Caldwell and Sam Waterston will read from the personal papers of Katharine Hepburn at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts at 6 p.m. Tuesday. The event begins a series of four free public readings, “Remembering Kate,” celebrating the donation and opening for public view of the papers. Tickets, one to a person, will be distributed beginning two hours before each program. Participants in readings scheduled for March 31, April 12 and April 28 include Anthony Harvey, Katharine Houghton, Charlotte Moore, Dick Cavett and Marian Seldes. ... Eddie Vedder, the Pearl Jam frontman, will begin his first solo tour in the spring to promote his soundtrack album for the film “Into the Wild,” Reuters reported. The tour will open in Vancouver on April 2 and play five dates in California. Pearl Jam will headline the Bonnaroo Music and Arts festival in Manchester, Tenn., in June.

headline: 3 Internet Providers in Deal for Tailored Ads
text: LONDON  For years, Internet service providers have watched with envy as the likes of Google, Yahoo and Microsoft sliced up the online advertising pie. Selling Internet access has been a good business, but selling Web advertising has been an even more lucrative one.

headline: With a Timely Trump Lead, Thwarting Declarer’s Plans
text: The 13th NEC Cup Bridge Festival ended in Yokohama, Japan, eight days ago, and the diagramed deal featured probably the best defense during the five days of play. It was Board 13 of the quarterfinals.

headline: Dutch Protest 104-Year-Old Singer
text: A 104-year-old Dutch-born singer, Johannes Heesters  who once performed for Hitler  touched off a protest when he took the stage in the Netherlands on Saturday for the first time in four decades, The Associated Press reported. Speaking for about 50 demonstrators outside the De Flint theater in Amersfoort, where Mr. Heesters, above, performed, Piet Schouten said: “He kept singing for the Nazi regime, for the Wehrmacht, and he earned millions. Those are facts, and we have a problem with that on behalf of all the victims.” Mr. Heesters was never accused of being a propagandist, and the Allies allowed him to continue his career after World War II. But in the Netherlands he is viewed by some as unforgivable, though he wrote in his postwar autobiography, “I was ashamed of myself, and I still haven’t stopped feeling this way.” In 1964 he was booed off the stage in Amsterdam when he appeared as the Nazi-hating Captain von Trapp in “The Sound of Music.” No disturbances were reported during the concert in Amersfoort, where Mr. Heesters, who lives in Germany, was born. But a handful of neo-Nazis turned up, uninvited, to support him, and some were detained by the police after they hurled eggs at demonstrators.

headline: Demystifying Messiaen, With a Little Help From the Birds
text: As the climate for classical music in America adjusts to challenges (like the decline of arts education in public schools) and opportunities (the instantaneous availability of music on the Web), the role of the music director of a major orchestra is changing as well. It’s no longer enough to be a comprehensive musician, a strong conductor and a good schmoozer of potential patrons. The music directors who are making differences in their communities and winning new listeners are also good teachers, proselytizers and speakers, in person and, increasingly, in videos.

headline: Largest Recall of Ground Beef Is Ordered
text: A California meat company on Sunday issued the largest beef recall in history, 143 million pounds, some of which was used in school lunch programs, Department of Agriculture officials announced.

headline: Peter Newton, Napa Vintner, Dies at 81
text: Peter Newton, a noted California vintner whose two wineries, Sterling Vineyards and Newton Vineyard, produced some of Napa Valley’s most highly regarded wines, died Feb. 4 at his home in St. Helena, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Proven Winner Finally Finishes First at Daytona
text: Daytona Beach, Fla.

headline: Here Come the Superdelegates
text: To the Editor:

headline: Campus Violence Film Has Release Date
text: Delayed after the deadly shootings last year at Virginia Tech, a movie about campus violence starring Meryl Streep will be released in the spring, the distributor said on Friday, a day after the killings at Northern Illinois University. The Associated Press reported that the film, “Dark Matter,” also starring Liu Ye as a disgruntled Chinese graduate student in science, will open in New York on April 11 and then in other American cities, said Gary Rubin, president of First Independent Pictures. “Dark Matter,” directed by Chen Shi-Zheng, won the Alfred P. Sloan Prize for films about science at the Sundance Film Festival last year.

headline: Clashes With Israeli Troops Kill 4 Militants in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  Four Palestinian militants were killed in clashes with the Israeli Army in southern Gaza early Sunday, and an Israeli soldier was seriously wounded in an exchange of fire.

headline: One Friend Facebook Hasn’t Made Yet: Privacy Rights
text: A co-worker apologized to me recently for being slow on a task. “It’s probably just your insomnia from last night,” I said. She was confused about how I knew, but I reminded her we were Facebook friends, and that she had posted a “status update” about her sleeplessness.

headline: Corrections
text: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Saturday misstated the 2007 compensation of John J. Mack, chief executive of Morgan Stanley. Mr. Mack, who did not receive a bonus in 2007, received compensation valued at $1.5 million, not $41.7 million. (The company’s Securities and Exchange Commission filing listed $40.2 million in stock awards for Mr. Mack in December 2006, which was in the company’s fiscal 2007 year, but those awards applied to fiscal 2006.)

headline: Guantánamo, Evil and Zany in Pop Culture
text: This spring, the stoner screwball movie of 2004, “Harold and Kumar Go to White Castle,” will get a sequel. This time, because of some unfortunate confusion on an airplane between a “bong” and a “bomb,” our slacker antiheroes are shipped off to the moviemakers’ idea of the worst prison imaginable.

headline: Mets Turn to Schneider to Take Charge Behind Home Plate
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  On his life’s to-do list, Brian Schneider has already crossed off a great many things. Travel at the speed of sound? Yup. Catch ceremonial first pitches from the president and the vice president? Check. Fly with the Blue Angels  and keep his breakfast down? Done that, too.

headline: Dumb or Just Fun? Animation Illustrates a CBS News Item
text: Critics who regularly bemoan the dumbing down of television news would most likely have been enraged by the sight, on a recent weekday, of animated characters on an evening newscast explaining the political power wielded by superdelegates.

headline: McCain Facing Delicate Choice: A Role for Bush
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain’s campaign advisers will ask the White House to deploy President Bush for major Republican fund-raising, but they do not want the president to appear too often at his side, top aides to Mr. McCain said Sunday.

headline: A $1 Million Donation to a College, and $250,000 to Explain It
text: It did not cause quite the stir as when she claimed to have unmasked Jack the Ripper, but the crime novelist Patricia Cornwell still felt the need to explain herself in a very public way.

headline: Ivy Back-to-Backs: Basketball and Bonding, Checking Schoolwork and Scores
text: For players, any trip is a lesson in unintended consequences. Ivy League trips, with back-to-back games scheduled on Friday and Saturday so players don’t miss as much class, are even more so. I experienced this many times as a forward for Penn.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some copies on Thursday about a garbage truck driver who was charged with manslaughter after he had a seizure, veered out of control and killed two pedestrians, misstated the frequency with which commercial truckers who cross state lines must under federal law renew a certificate indicating that they do not have a debilitating medical condition. It is every two years, not every year.

headline: Not Everyone Wants a Coaching Change at Indiana
text: Any Indiana fan who watched the Hoosiers take apart Michigan State on Saturday night had to take heart. Clearly distracted by news media speculation that the coach may be relieved of his duties before the week is over, Indiana climbed out of an enormous hole to defeat the Spartans, 80-61.

headline: Washington’s Birthday
text: The holiday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed.

headline: N.B.A.’s Recovery Work Draws Malone Back Home
text: NEW ORLEANS  A severe knee injury pushed Karl Malone out of the N.B.A. four years ago. An injury to his home state helped bring him back.

headline: After Rape, Calls to Limit Where Sex Offenders Go
text: NEW BEDFORD, Mass.  After an arrest in the rape of a 6-year-old boy at the city library here late last month, the mayor drafted an ordinance to bar high-risk sex offenders from entering or coming within a certain distance of numerous public places.

headline: Poverty Is Poison
text: “Poverty in early childhood poisons the brain.” That was the opening of an article in Saturday’s Financial Times, summarizing research presented last week at the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

headline: Of All the Hurdles to a Merger, View on Technology Is the Highest
text: SAN FRANCISCO  If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?

headline: News Isn’t Wasted on the Young
text: Last Tuesday, Barack Obama stood in front of 15,000 shouting supporters in Madison, Wis., basking in wins in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. In addition to issuing a classic call to arms for the rest of the campaign, Mr. Obama took time out to welcome any Republicans to his bandwagon.

headline: A Start-Up Says It Can Predict Others’ Fate
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Is your start-up worthy of investment? Ask the venture investor in a box.

headline: An Obama Refrain Bears Echoes of a Governor’s Speeches
text: CHICAGO  Senator Barack Obama adapted one of his signature arguments  that his oratory amounts to more than inspiring words  from speeches given by Gov. Deval Patrick of Massachusetts during his 2006 campaign.

headline: First on the Scene, Again, Is the College Newspaper
text: When news breaks on college campuses  as it did when a gunman killed five students at Northern Illinois University last week  reporters from the college paper are often the first journalists on the scene. For reporters at The Northern Star, the student newspaper, the incident became far more personal when they learned that one of their own staff members was among those killed.

headline: Broadcaster Sues to Force Buyout Deal
text: Clear Channel Communications, the largest radio broadcaster in the United States, said Sunday that it had sued a unit of the private equity firm Providence Equity Partners to force a completion of a $1.2 billion purchase of 56 television stations.

headline: Language, the Muse That Provokes Stoppard and Albee
text: Do you know what it’s like to be deeply, unbearably in love, all the while aware that you can never completely trust the object of your affection? I would wager that Edward Albee and Tom Stoppard do, almost to the point of delirium.

headline: Global Heating, Atmosphere Cancer, Pollution Death. What’s in a Name?
text: [UPDATE, 5/2: John Broder has written a piece examining a new call for new terminology to describe the climate and energy problems confronting the country. What words, if any, do you think would be most apt to grab attention and propel change?]

headline: … But Keep This in Mind About Egypt

headline: Abe Lincoln, Standup Comic

I handed a five to the waitress for one more virgin scotch-and-soda with a twist as the final wannabe comedian walked onstage. He was tall, thin and bearded, wearing a stovepipe hat and looking at notes scribbled on the back of an envelope. I grabbed the five back from the irritated waitress, checked the picture and rubbed my eyes in disbelief – I was about to witness the first performance of Abe Lincoln, Standup Comic:

headline: Superdelegate Poll: Unsettled Ground
text: Despite Senator Barack Obama’s strong showing in recent primaries, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton continues to hold onto more support from superdelegates, the Democratic Party elites, according to a survey by The New York Times and CBS News.The current count is 189.5 superdelegate votes for Mrs. Clinton and 142.5 for Mr. Obama. But in a similar survey conducted last month, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Obama by 204 to 99. About 8 percent of the total 795 superdelegates changed their minds over the last few weeks, as many states held their primaries and caucuses. Few delegates switched allegiance from one candidate to the other; the main changes were among the undecided delegates. Among the previously undecided delegates who now are endorsing a candidate, Mr. Obama got more of their support. Some of Mrs. Clinton’s previous supporters are now undecided.

headline: E-Mail at Work: Some Basics
text: Two friends recently asked me for career advice using their companies’ e-mail accounts, something I thought we all knew was a no-no by this point in the electronic age. The first friend wanted to know if I thought she was revealing too many details about her employer on her blog. (She was.) The second asked me to review her résumé, which was attached. Shortly after these two incidents, I heard about a senior manager losing his job for revealing proprietary information about his firm, something he had done through the firm’s e-mail.

But one of my favorites, which requires considerably more time but almost no extra effort, adds the wonderful depth of flavor, silken texture and satisfying chewiness of slow-cooked meat, bone and marrow. Southern Italian in origin, it begins with bony meat (or meaty bones) and requires lengthy simmering.

headline: Milan: Please Don’t Come
text: Although I am holding an invitation to Giorgio Armani’s show today, at noon, I know I am not expected. Yesterday, shortly after I pulled the covers over my head for a little nap, I received an email from Robert Triefus, who is Armani’s head of communications. It was marked urgent and inquired if I had received a letter from Armani. I had not, but it didn’t take a genius to know what the letter was about. Armani had decided not to invite me to his show and, of course, that was the intent of the letter, once I had read it. He didn’t like the tone of my comments about his January couture show in Paris; specifically, he thought I was “belittling” of his family and friends. I had described their appearance and manner in the moments before the show. It was pretty innocuous stuff. Armani, though, didn’t think so. I asked Triefus why Armani had waited until just before today’s show to say something; the couture reviews had come out two or three weeks ago. Triefus said Armani had become preoccupied with his ready-to-wear show—we’re up to fall 2008—and hadn’t had time to return to the matter until now. “That’s our fault,” Triefus said.

headline: A Case for “August”
text: In the years since I worked as a drama critic — a period that ended in late 1993, just after the premiere of the second half of Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America” — I’ve seen few new plays as invigorating as “August: Osage County,” let alone on Broadway. Though it’s hard to separate the text from the extraordinary production and cast sent to New York by Chicago’s Steppenwolf Theatre Company, the virtues of Tracy Letts’s drama should be apparent to readers as well as theatergoers. (Which is not to say you shouldn’t rush to catch one of the remaining performances, if at all possible. Letts had most of these actors in mind when writing the play for the company, and when they disband after their limited run, now scheduled to end in mid-April, that’s it.)

(I guess what I’m saying is, “thanks to whoever taught me this!”) This is one such example, and it’s a good one. This will work with any firm white fish fillet, and any bed of vegetables. You almost can’t go wrong.

headline: Jil Sander: Counterpoint
text: I’ve just come from the Jil Sander show, at the end of a long, drab, shifty day. This may be the Milan season in which great significance is put on a pleat. The shift or sack dress seems a dominant trend (at Burberry, Alberta Ferretti, Ferre), at least on the first full day of the Milan shows. Dresses and full skirts have inverted or tacked-down pleats, all carefully placed but oh-so tedious–and not helped by the doll-like vague models lurching on high shiny heels.

headline: Off to Jury Duty
text: For months, I have known that I would be starting jury duty on February 19th. And for months I have been approaching this date with a mixture of anticipation and anxiety. The part of me looking forward to it hopes that I get selected for a jury. The part of me that is anxious has been hustling to get ahead on work and dodging meeting requests so that I am free in case I am out of commission for a week or longer. (I know that I can defer the jury duty to a more convenient time, but I have already deferred once and, in truth, there aren’t more convenient times.)

headline: Scientists Would Turn Greenhouse Gas Into Gasoline
text: If two scientists at Los Alamos National Laboratory are correct, people will still be driving gasoline-powered cars 50 years from now, churning out heat-trapping carbon dioxide into the atmosphere  and yet that carbon dioxide will not contribute to global warming.

headline: When Things Go Wrong
text: One afternoon last week, I noticed that one of our mares  a quarter horse named Ida  was stepping slowly as she came into the corral. A horse’s mobility is everything, and I began wondering about a hoof abscess or a muscle strain. But when I walked over to Ida, I saw a gaping wound on her neck. I could look through the muscle wall and into an anatomical cavern. There was blood, but not the disastrous stream there would have been if the wound had been a couple of inches lower. I could barely watch Ida while we waited for the veterinarian. I was afraid I would see her slide to the ground.

headline: Rice, in Nairobi, Offers Incentives to End Violence
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice held pointed talks with the leaders of Kenya’s rival political factions on Monday, and said afterward that while their differences were “not unbridgeable,” the two sides must move much faster to accept a power-sharing deal that would lead to a coalition government.

headline: Britain: Siv Nears Default
text: A $7.15 billion structured investment vehicle managed and sponsored by the British banking company Standard Chartered may default this week after failing to repay maturing debt, Standard & Poor’s said. The investment vehicle, Whistlejacket Capital, was put into receivership last week. It failed to pay notes due last Friday, S.& P. said, and will be in default if it fails to make a payment by Thursday, when a three-day grace period ends. Whistlejacket, based in the British Channel Islands, appointed receivers after a decline in the value of its holdings set into motion rules forcing it to wind down and prompted Standard Chartered to abandon a bailout it had proposed. Standard Chartered is pursuing a reorganization of Whistlejacket, S.& P. said, citing information from Deloitte & Touche, the company’s receiver.

headline: Britain: Life Sentence in Beheading Plot
text: Parviz Khan, the Birmingham man who pleaded guilty last month to plotting to kidnap and behead a British Muslim soldier, was sentenced to life in prison. Described by witnesses as a keen cricketer and pubgoer until contacts with Islamic militants radicalized him on a trip to Pakistan, he was ordered to serve at least 14 years for the plot, and for supplying militants in Afghanistan with money and equipment. The plot was uncovered by Britain’s security services. In secret recordings played in court, Mr. Khan was heard teaching his 5-year-old son to carry out a beheading. “How do you cut them with a knife?” he said to the boy. “Show me. Like this.” At another point, he asked the boy, “Who do you love?” The boy replied, “I love Sheik Osama bin Laden.” Mr. Khan then asked, “Who do you kill?” The boy’s reply: “America kill. Bush I kill, and Blair kill.”

headline: Brazil: Retail Sales Increase 9%
text: Brazilian retail sales climbed 9 percent in December from December 2006, capping their best year since at least 2001 as record low borrowing costs stimulated consumer spending. Retail, supermarket and grocery store sales rose 9.6 percent last year, the biggest gain since the national statistics agency started the current series in 2001. “The sales that gained the most were those that depend on credit,” said Alex Agostini, chief economist at Austin Rating Serviços Financeiros in São Paulo. Sales of home appliances and furniture rose 15.4 percent in 2007, the national statistics agency said. Computer and office material sales increased 29.4 percent and vehicle sales jumped 22.6 percent.

headline: Behavior: An Absence of Free Will, a Tendency to Cheat
text: If there is no such thing as free will, do you really have to put that money into the office coffee kitty when no one is looking?

headline: Gentlemen, 5 Easy Steps to Living Long and Well
text: Living past 90, and living well, may be more than a matter of good genes and good luck. Five behaviors in elderly men are associated not only with living into extreme old age, a new study has found, but also with good health and independent functioning.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Russian-Chinese draft treaty to ban weapons in space referred incorrectly to five signers of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that were asked to meet to discuss nuclear disarmament. They are the five nuclear powers that are parties to the treaty; they are not the only signers. (Go to Article)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page article on Saturday about mothers who promote environmentally friendly behavior misstated the Web address of an environmental news site. It is grist.org, not grist.com.

headline: An Oldie Vies for Nutrient of the Decade
text: The so-called sunshine vitamin is poised to become the nutrient of the decade, if a host of recent findings are to be believed. Vitamin D, an essential nutrient found in a limited number of foods, has long been renowned for its role in creating strong bones, which is why it is added to milk.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills 36 in Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  In the second serious attack in southern Afghanistan in two days, a suicide bomber set off an explosion on Monday as he drove his car near a convoy of Canadian troops on a crowded border town street, killing 36 civilians and wounding 38.

headline: Rambo Banned in Myanmar
text: DVD copies of the movie “Rambo,” starring and directed by Sylvester Stallone, below, are much in demand in Myanmar but very had to find, Agence France-Presse reported. That is because the police there have banned the film, in which Mr. Stallone portrays a Vietnam War veteran battling soldiers of the military junta that rules the country. “Police have warned me I could go to jail for up to seven years if I sell the latest Rambo film,” said a DVD vendor who declined to be identified. Another seller said that at least 20 customers asked for it every day. One democracy advocate, who declined to say how he obtained a copy, said, “I watched the movie at home with my family and gave it to my friends because I wanted them to see it.”

headline: Barred From Men’s-Only Event, Woman Sues Public Golf Club
text: Elaine Joyce, a champion amateur golfer, and her father were looking forward to a weekend tournament last May at the respected public course on Cape Cod where they hold full memberships. But their names were not listed when officials posted the tee times for the event at the Dennis Pines course.

headline: Putting His Faith in Telling the Truth

headline: Three Actors Replace Heath Ledger
text: Jude Law, Colin Farrell and Johnny Depp, from left above, will replace Heath Ledger, above right, in the film he was starring in when he died last month, Ain’t It Cool News reported. The future of the $30 million film, “The Imaginarium of Doctor Parnassus,” a morality tale directed by Terry Gilliam, was thrown in doubt halfway through shooting when Mr. Ledger died of an accidental drug overdose. In the film  which a synopsis says is about a traveling theater troupe that tempts its audiences with the chance to “transcend mundane reality by passing through a magical mirror into a fantastic universe of limitless imagination”  Mr. Ledger was playing a character who is transported into three separate dimensions. These will now be inhabited, instead, by Mr. Depp, Mr. Law and Mr. Farrell.

headline: Do Not Rank
text: MEXICO CITY  Fidel Castro stepped down Tuesday morning as the president of Cuba after a long illness, ending one of the longest tenures as an all-powerful, communist head of state in the world, according to Granma, the official publication of the Cuban Communist Party.

headline: No Polo Pony, but Penney’s New Label Is Pure Ralph Lauren Americana
text: WHAT do you get when the J. C. Penney Company and the Polo Ralph Lauren Corporation team up to sell an extensive new line of clothing and home furnishings? A branding mash-up that some might call Polo Penney.

headline: Feared Sweeps for Illegal Workers Found Just One
text: To great fanfare in October 2006, Steve Levy, the Suffolk County executive, signed a new law requiring 6,000 contractors working for the county to affirm that their employees were not illegal immigrants, prompting fear of impromptu inspections and roundups of Hispanic men.

headline: Jamie Davies Is Dead at 73; Made Sparkling Wine
text: Jamie Davies, who with her husband, Jack, founded Schramsberg Vineyards and pioneered the production of fine sparkling wine in California, died Feb. 12 at her home in Calistoga, Calif. She was 73.
