headline: Hispanic Classics Flavor a New York Debut
text: The first New York appearance by the State Symphony Orchestra of Mexico had all the makings of an occasion. Enrique Bátiz, an estimable maestro and the orchestra’s founder, conducted on Sunday afternoon at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx. The program featured a promising mix of European, Mexican and American classics, and a noteworthy soloist, the Mexican guitarist Alfonso Moreno.

headline: In a Divided Kosovo City, a Resounding Vow to Remain Part of Serbia
text: MITROVICA, Kosovo  A day after Kosovo’s ethnic Albanian leadership declared independence from Serbia, 7,000 Serbs took to the streets of this divided city, waving Serbian flags, chanting “Kosovo is Serbia!” and burning an American flag covered with the words “The Fourth Reich.”

headline: Plea for Aid as Winter Grips Tajikistan
text: ALMATY, Kazakhstan  United Nations officials issued an urgent plea on Monday for some $25 million in emergency aid to Tajikistan, the Central Asian country hardest hit by the region’s harshest winter in three decades.

headline: NASA Insists It Can Fix Flaw in Rocket Design
text: Preliminary calculations by NASA last summer suggested that the rocket it had on the drawing board to replace the space shuttle possessed a design flaw: vibrations in the booster might shake the top of the rocket so violently that any astronauts riding aboard would suffer severe, perhaps fatal, injuries.

headline: Candidate Wins Support in the East. No, Farther East.
text: OBAMA, Japan  Just before the results of the big Feb. 5 round of primaries and caucuses reached this snow-covered fishing town hard by the Sea of Japan, a few of its most enterprising residents realized that a man who shared their town’s name could be America’s next president.

headline: With Oil Prices Rising, Wood Makes a Comeback
text: NEWPORT, Vt.  As a child, Brian Cook remembers hurling wood into the big orange boiler his father bought during the oil crisis of the late 1970s, helping feed the fire that provided heat and hot water to his family.

headline: Oil Closes Above $100 for First Time
text: HOUSTON  Crude oil closed above $100 a barrel for the first time on Tuesday afternoon, vaulting through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.

headline: Tension About Religion and Class in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL  When two women in Islamic head scarves were spotted in an Italian restaurant in this city’s new shopping mall this month, Gulbin Simitcioglu did a double take.

headline: Kosovo Is Recognized but Rebuked by Others
text: BERLIN  Kosovo won the recognition of the United States and its biggest Western European allies on Monday, while earning rebukes and rejections from Serbia, Russia and a disparate mix of states the world over who face their own separatist movements at home.

headline: As the Wheels of the Economy Turn
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Claim: Honey Can Soothe a Burn
text: THE FACTS

headline: The Global Tobacco Threat
text: Three years ago, an international treaty took effect that was designed to help developing countries resist aggressive marketing by big tobacco companies. The idea was that if a large number of countries committed themselves to the same tobacco control policies  including bans on all advertising and promotion  they would be better able to resist pressure from multinational tobacco companies and their own domestic tobacco sellers.

headline: Judge to Settle McCartney-Mills Divorce
text: Paul McCartney and Heather Mills had their chance, and now it is up to a judge to determine a divorce agreement and financial settlement for them, The Associated Press reported. As legal teams left the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Monday after no deal was reached between the parties, Mr. McCartney’s lawyer, Nicholas Mostyn, said that Justice Hugh Bennett had reserved his ruling and would spend several weeks working out a settlement. Ms. Mills smiled as she departed. Mr. McCartney did not attend. The terms of a settlement will not become public unless it is challenged in the Court of Appeal or if one of the parties elects to disclose its contents. The couple, who separated in 2006 after four years of marriage, went to court to decide how much of Mr. McCartney’s fortune, estimated to be as high as $1.6 billion, Ms. Mills would receive.

headline: A Company Looks to Its Creative Side to Regain What It Had Lost
text: The great purveyors of modern mass entertainment  Walt Disney, Sumner Redstone, Ahmet Ertegun, Rupert Murdoch  have all known about the push-me, pull-you relationship between art and commerce. Give artists too free a rein, and they will come up with critically acclaimed statements that no one outside the Upper West Side or Laurel Canyon will buy. Hand over creative control to the bean counters and you end up with tepid, overly focus-tested disasters like “Waterworld.”

headline: A Face Travelers Will Find on Every Southwest Flight
text: I TRAVEL the world assisting golf courses on soil and grass issues, as well as making sure that a course’s turf meets players’ exacting standards. Essentially, someone pays me to visit some of the greatest golf courses on the planet. It’s a tough job, but somebody has to do it.

headline: Qatar Buying Credit Suisse Shares on Open Market
text: DOHA, Qatar  Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

headline: Decoding Human Rapport (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Obstacles Remain in  Kidd Trade
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Jason Kidd was a no-show at Nets practice Monday, but he was still officially a member of the team.

headline: A Cure for the Airport Blues
text: Airport hotels are enjoying a renaissance of sorts as business travelers, frustrated by mounting delays and canceled flights, are leaving the terminal in search of the wider array of amenities available nearby.

headline: Fear Keeps East Timor Tent Camps Full
text: DILI, East Timor  When the rain-laden clouds open up, as they frequently do this time of year, the tarpaulin over Alicia Pinto’s bed leaks and the pathway outside her tent home becomes a quagmire.

headline: ‘Have You Ever Been in Psychotherapy, Doctor?’
text: A curious thing happened to one of my psychiatric residents not long ago. One of his patients caught him off guard with a challenging question: “Have you ever been in psychotherapy yourself?”

headline: The Color of Victory? Rethinking the Power of a Blue Judo Uniform
text: It’s been said that Yankee pinstripes add a certain something to a ballplayer’s game, an aura of intimidation that will help him succeed. Red Sox fans and others may dispute that idea, but it raises an interesting question: Can an athlete’s uniform affect success?

headline: Brown Defends Takeover of Ailing British Lender
text: LONDON  Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Monday defended his decision to nationalize the ailing mortgage lender Northern Rock, facing down angry shareholders and even the bank’s own management.

headline: The Wrong Target
text: A New York City police detective and his girlfriend have been accused of kidnapping and forcing a 13-year-old girl into prostitution.

headline: Magnetic Personalities
text: Q. Why won’t a magnet stick to stainless steel?

headline: Yanks Say Mitchell Report Didn’t Affect Pettitte Deal
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Ever since Andy Pettitte’s use of human growth hormone was made public in the Mitchell report on Dec. 13, a day after his $16 million contract was announced by the Yankees, speculation has percolated about whether Pettitte and his agents had withheld important information from the club during negotiations.

headline: Prognosis: Large Social Networks May Help Surgical Patients
text: Having a large network of friends and family, a new study suggests, may help surgical patients experience less anxiety and pain before their operations and a quicker recovery afterward.

headline: Keeping Tabs on the Superdelegates
text: The last time the superdelegates really mattered in a Democratic primary was in 1984. One of the big differences between then and now is the Internet. This has allowed the emergence of a whole new political force that did not exist two decades ago. And it means everyone can watch the political alliances shift and, in a sense, everyone can play.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 21 about a fire that killed three day laborers in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, misstated the year in which Bensonhurst was annexed into Brooklyn. It was 1894, not 1890. The article also referred incompletely to the area that became Brooklyn’s 30th ward. It was New Utrecht that was annexed  not just Bensonhurst, which was part of New Utrecht.

headline: Regimens: Diet Supplement Seen as Risky for Some Users
text: Probiotics, the potentially beneficial bacteria and yeasts available as diet supplements and in some foods, may not be as helpful as widely believed. A new study suggests that under certain circumstances, they can be deadly.

headline: Assessing the ‘Moneyball’ Payoff
text: Not that they want to see any prospect fail, but old-line major league scouts everywhere stood up and cheered last week. Jeremy Brown, the Oakland Athletics announced, had retired.

headline: Consumers Urged to Be Fruitful, but Can Sales Multiply?
text: Editors’ Note: This issue of In Advertising is coming to you today because of the Presidents’ Day holiday yesterday. Look for the newsletter next week on its regular day, Monday.

headline: In Change, Busch Puts Teammate First
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The boos have rained down on Kurt Busch since 2003, when he instigated a fight with Jimmy Spencer at Michigan International Speedway. Spencer punched Busch in the nose, and Nascar suspended Spencer. Many fans have never forgiven Busch.

headline: ‘Black Watch’ Returns
text: The National Theater of Scotland’s production of “Black Watch,” Gregory Burke’s play about a Scottish Army regiment in Iraq, was on just about everyone’s Top 10 list last year but was scheduled for only 23 performances, all of which sold out, at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn. Good news: It’s coming back this fall for another limited engagement at St. Ann’s, from Oct. 9 to Nov. 30. ... Kate Moira Ryan and Linda S. Chapman’s play “The Beebo Brinker Chronicles,” which opened at the Fourth Street Theater last fall, is also coming back. Lily Tomlin and Jane Wagner are on board as producers, and are bringing “Beebo” to the 37 Arts Theater. Previews begin on Tuesday. Opening is set for March 5.

headline: David Oats, Park Advocate, Dies at 58
text: David Oats, who for 40 years bent the ears of New York City and state politicians in his efforts to protect and improve the 1,255 acres in Queens that he considered his backyard  Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the site of two world’s fairs  died in Queens on Feb. 5. He was 58.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: Neal Bangerter and Chris Betts joined Reactrix Systems, Redwood City, Calif., in new posts. Mr. Bangerter becomes vice president for product management; he had most recently been a business development manager and product planner in the entertainment and devices division at the Microsoft Corporation. Mr. Betts becomes vice president for corporate development; he joins from Hidden River L.L.C., San Francisco.

headline: Dorothy Podber, 75, Artist and Trickster, Is Dead
text: Dorothy Podber, a wild child of the New York art scene in the 1950s and ’60s who is probably best known for brandishing a pistol and putting a bullet through the forehead of Marilyn Monroe’s likenesses on a stack of Andy Warhol’s paintings, died at her apartment in the East Village on Feb. 9. She was 75.

headline: Democrats Make Populist Appeals Before Contests
text: WAUSAU, Wis.  Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama intensified their populist appeals on Monday, responding to widespread economic anxiety and pushing the Democratic Party further from the business-friendly posture once championed by Bill Clinton.

headline: From Tokyo, a ‘Raymonda’ Hints of the Romance of the Middle Ages
text: WASHINGTON  Romanticism was so called because artists seemed to be harking back to the pre-Renaissance spirit of romance, to the original era of chivalry, of Arthurian ideals and of legends in which knights encountered the supernatural. In that neo-medievalist era of “Ivanhoe,” “La Belle Dame Sans Merci” and “Lohengrin,” ballet came into its own  nowhere more evidently than in “Raymonda,” choreographed in 1898 by Marius Petipa toward the end of his long and prodigious career (he was 80) to a commissioned score by Alexander Glazunov. Its setting is medieval Provence, its hero a Crusader.

headline: Visitor Takes a Country’s Fate in Her Hands
text: Catherine Filloux’s “Killing the Boss” is not, as its title might suggest, a dark comedy to warm the hearts of oppressed workers everywhere. But this beautifully performed, touching one-act play is not quite the personalized cry against genocide that the playwright intends it to be, either.

headline: Protecting Doctors
text: To the Editor:

headline: Defender in the Case of a Slain 7-Year-Old Girl Has His Admirers: Other Lawyers
text: Returning to his law office the other day after yet another Sisyphean court session, Jeffrey T. Schwartz found a letter that, impressively, contained neither threats nor insults.

headline: Supreme Court Takes Case on Evidence
text: WASHINGTON  A string of utterly mundane events in southeastern Alabama one July day in 2004 gave rise to an important case that the Supreme Court accepted on Tuesday, turning on the question of when evidence gathered by the police in a wrongful arrest must be thrown out.

headline: Footnote
text: Dedication ceremonies are to be held on Wednesday for the Sheila C. Johnson Design Center for Parsons the New School of Design. The 32,800-square foot campus center, designed by Lyn Rice Architects and made possible in part by a $7 million gift from Sheila C. Johnson, a New School trustee and Parsons governor, combines learning and public program spaces with exhibition galleries at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 13th Street in Greenwich Village.

headline: Germany Breaks With Its Clubby Business Past
text: FRANKFURT  It has become a familiar tableau in Germany during this season of scandal, even if the names of the disgraced and the details of their misdeeds change from one case to the next.

headline: What You Don’t Know Can Hurt
Fighting Bedsores With a Team Approach
text: To understand why some doctors and nurses take bedsores so seriously, it helps to call them by their clinical name: pressure ulcers.

headline: A Violent Act Takes Shape When Seen Through Time
text: What is it that makes “Rules of Engagement,” Tuesday night’s “Frontline” offering on PBS, one of the more riveting recent installments of the program?

headline: Learning From Tijuana: Hudson, N.Y., Considers Different Housing Model
text: If you doubt that the derelict shantytowns of Tijuana could work as a template for redevelopment in a quaint, upscale town in the Hudson River Valley, you’re probably underestimating Teddy Cruz.

headline: As Lending Tightens, Education Could Suffer
text: Major commercial education companies are scrambling to ensure a steady stream of college-level students despite the credit squeeze, with some preparing to offer student loans themselves.

headline: New Yorker in the White House? Seems Like a Long Shot Now
text: For a while, it looked as if every day might become Presidents’ Day in New York.

headline: After Decades of Dormancy, Drake Shows Its Teeth Again
text: DES MOINES  As the most visible link to the greatest era of Drake University basketball, the radio analyst Dolph Pulliam wears his Bulldogs heart on his sleeves, his back and everywhere else.

headline: Obama Extends Streak With Ninth Victory Over Clinton
text: Senator Barack Obama won a decisive victory over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday night, cutting into Mrs. Clinton’s long-held support among women, union members and middle-aged voters.

headline: Mistake Led to Inspection Failure
text: Confusion over two Chinese factories with similar names led to regulators’ failure to inspect a plant that makes an ingredient linked to life-threatening side effects with the blood-thinning drug heparin, the Food and Drug Administration said. The regulators mistakenly referred to inspection records for a plant from a different company and cleared the heparin facility without necessary inspections and evaluations, said Joseph Famulare, deputy director at the agency’s Center for Drug Evaluation and Research. The agency will begin inspecting the plant this week. On Feb. 11, the F.D.A. said use of heparin in multidose vials made by Baxter International Inc., of Deerfield, Ill., had been tied to dangerously low blood pressure, vomiting and difficulty breathing. Four patients died, the agency said.

headline: Absolute Artifice: A Movie Star of the Old School
text: More than 30 years after her death, Joan Crawford continues to exert a fascination that has little or nothing to do with her gifts as an actress, a fact that is one working definition of the term “movie star.”

headline: Revealed: Secrets of the Camouflage Masters
text: WOODS HOLE, Mass.  The cuttlefish in Roger Hanlon’s laboratory were in fine form. Their skin was taking on new colors and patterns faster than the digital signs in Times Square.

headline: The Early Lure of Tobacco (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Opinions Abound on English Plan
text: The English Premier League’s plan for its 20 teams to play an extra league game outside England, a scheme that could be dubbed Plan 39 from Outer Space, gained a grain of support Monday.

headline: Man Dies After Fistfight
text: A man died Monday afternoon after a fight with another man at a Dunkin’ Donuts in eastern Queens, the police said.

headline: Patterns: A Video Game, an M.R.I. and What Men’s Brains Do
text: Why does it often seem that men enjoy playing video games more than women? Perhaps because they do.

headline: Strangers in a Very Dark New York Night
text: The lives of lonely New Yorkers come together and fall apart in “Unconditional,” a bluesy, moody, ultimately draggy new drama by Brett C. Leonard that opened Monday night at the Public Theater.

headline: Diana Inquest Hears Fayed’s Accusations
text: LONDON  Mohamed al-Fayed waited more than 10 years for the day in open court when he could lay out his theory of high-level conspiracy in the deaths of Princess Diana and his son Dodi, her lover when both died in a Paris car crash in August 1997.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a Russian-Chinese draft treaty to ban weapons in space referred incorrectly to five signers of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty that were asked to meet to discuss nuclear disarmament. They are the five nuclear powers that are parties to the treaty; they are not the only signers.

headline: Slain Editor Heads List of Polk Award Winners
text: A California editor slain as he investigated a business now linked to his murder, and reporters who exposed brutalities in Myanmar and Iraq, an environmental disaster in China and corruption in America were among winners of 14 George Polk Awards for 2007 announced Monday by Long Island University.

headline: French Police Round Up Suspects in November Unrest
text: PARIS  The French police on Monday carried out a series of high-profile raids in poor suburbs close to the capital, arresting dozens of people suspected of shooting at the police and setting fires during three days of unrest last November.

headline: Reports of Gunman’s Use of Antidepressant Renew Debate Over Side Effects
text: Steven P. Kazmierczak stopped taking Prozac before he shot to death five Northern Illinois University students and himself, his girlfriend said Sunday in a remark likely to fuel the debate over the risks and benefits of drug treatment for emotional problems.

headline: In Southern California, a Cotton Industry Fades
text: BRAWLEY, Calif.  When a cotton gin is running, it smells like hay, twigs and “freshly washed sheets,” said Wally Leimgruber, a former cotton farmer. But as is often the case, the gin at the Planters Ginning Company here was silent as Mr. Leimgruber walked the dusty floor one recent afternoon.

headline: What People Owe Fish: A Lot
text: Being a resolute hydrophobe who has no more desire to go for a swim than might a kitten in a bag or Luca Brasi in “The Godfather,” I admit I never thought of myself as a large, scaleless fish out of water.

headline: Unshakable Optimist of the House of Bhutto
text: Benazir Bhutto called her 1989 autobiography “Daughter of Destiny,” and when she was assassinated in December at 54, she became the fourth member of her immediate family to die violently against the backdrop of Pakistani intrigue and politics: her father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was hanged in 1979 on charges of having ordered the murder of a minor political opponent; her younger brother, Shahnawaz, mysteriously died of poisoning in 1985; and her other brother, Murtaza, was gunned down outside his home in 1996.

headline: No Admission of Guilt From Gagné
text: PHOENIX  The stakeout started last Thursday and continued through the weekend. By Monday the news media contingent camped at the Milwaukee Brewers’ spring training site to talk to a pitcher implicated in the Mitchell report was wearing down like a starter in the late innings.

headline: Credit Suisse Writes Down $2.8 Billion
text: PARIS  Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced a new write-down of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit and said it had suspended traders for errors that contributed to the loss.

headline: Image Awards for Great Debaters
text: “The Great Debaters” was a big winner at the 39th N.A.A.C.P. Image Awards ceremonies, Variety reported. The film, about the ascent of a debate team from a small all-black college in the 1930s, captured honors for best film, actor (Denzel Washington, who was also its director), actress (Jurnee Smollett) and supporting actor (Denzel Whitaker). Janet Jackson was named outstanding supporting actress for her performance in “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” In the ceremonies at the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles, “Talk to Me,” a tale of the symbiotic relationship of two men, was honored for its script, by Michael Genet and Rick Famuyiwa, and its direction, by Kasi Lemmons.

headline: Satellite Shooting Is Next as Shuttle Heads Home
text: WASHINGTON  The shuttle Atlantis left the International Space Station on Monday and headed home for a planned Wednesday landing, clearing the way for a Defense Department effort to shoot down a failed spy satellite.

headline: Makeshift Office at Heart of Obama Fund-Raising
text: CHICAGO  A cluster of cramped cubicles, tucked away in a rear corner of Senator Barack Obama’s campaign headquarters here, comprises the heart of a fund-raising machine that has reshaped the calculus of the 2008 election.

headline: Opponents Organize Against State’s Plan to Scrap Javits Center Expansion
text: The Spitzer administration’s decision to scrap a long-promised expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and sell some of its property to plug gaps in the state budget has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials, state legislators, trade show producers and tourism executives.

headline: Many Women Stay Away From the Polls in an Uneasy Pakistani City
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  They arrived in small groups over the course of the day, defying religious militants who say Pakistani women should not be allowed to vote.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about cities in which real estate values are holding up misidentified the state of one city cited as an example. The city is Salem, Ore., not Salem, Mass.

headline: 5 Iraqis Killed as Rockets Hit U.S. Base in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD  Five Iraqi civilians were killed when a barrage of rockets struck the large American military base near Baghdad International Airport and a nearby neighborhood late Monday afternoon, according to American and Iraqi officials.

headline: Exploring Different Sides of One of Handel’s Styles
text: Professional training workshops have been part of the programming fabric at Carnegie Hall since 1990, when they were introduced as part of the hall’s centennial celebration. The subjects of these concentrated coaching sessions change: chamber music, piano concertos, art song interpretation and conducting have been prominent in recent years. But Carnegie’s choral workshops have long held a special place in this constellation: the very first of the professional training workshops were those the great choral conductor Robert Shaw directed with his distinctive blend of experience, wisdom and inspiration.

headline: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
text: “We despise all the public attention we are getting,” Stephen Feinberg, the secretive founder of Cerberus Capital Management, wrote to his investors last month. “We do our best to avoid the spotlight, but, unfortunately, when you do some large deals, such as Chrysler and GMAC, it is hard to avoid.”

headline: House Committee Questions Contract for Former Bush Appointee
text: WASHINGTON  The House Small Business Committee has asked for an investigation into how a newly retired Bush administration appointee with no experience in helping small businesses compete for government contracts received money from the Small Business Administration to do exactly that.

headline: The Manchurian Conservative
text: I HAVE a framed New Yorker cartoon depicting two proper gentlemen in suits, eyeglasses and hats presenting themselves to the guard booth in front of the White House. The caption reads: “We’re from the Far Right. We’re here to be mollified.”

headline: Readers’ Responses
text: The following are excerpts of reader responses to Alina Tugend’s Feb. 16 Shortcuts column on whether to buy cable television, high-speed Internet and telephone service in a package from one company:

headline: For Perhaps $490 a Month, a Home on the Hudson River
text: Leslie Day flirted, dated, married, raised a family and found her life’s work in Manhattan  or rather, just off its shore.

headline: Princeton Plans for an Early Year Abroad
text: Seizing on students’ desire for a year off before college, Princeton University is working to create a program to send a tenth or more of its newly admitted students to a year of social service work in a foreign country before they set foot on campus as freshmen.

headline: Judge Orders Wikileaks Web Site Shut
text: In a move that legal experts said could present a major test of First Amendment rights in the Internet era, a federal judge in San Francisco on Friday ordered the disabling of a Web site devoted to disclosing confidential information.

headline: Thomas T. Roberts Dies at 84; Ruled That Baseball Owners Engaged in Collusion
text: Thomas T. Roberts, a prominent arbitrator best known for his mid-1980s ruling that major league baseball club owners had improperly colluded to prevent free-agent players from obtaining richer contracts, died in his sleep Wednesday at his home in Palos Verdes Peninsula, Calif. He was 84.

headline: Pettitte Apologizes to Yankees and His Fans
text: TAMPA, Fla.  In a one-hour news conference Monday that neither he nor the Yankees could have ever wished on themselves, a composed Andy Pettitte apologized for using human growth hormone in 2002 and 2004, said there was no other drug use he was concealing and revealed an awkward breakdown in his communications with Roger Clemens, his friend and former teammate.

headline: Russia’s Claim Under Polar Ice Irks American
text: Last August, a team of Russian scientists and legislators trekked to the North Pole and plunged through the ice pack into the abyss, descending more than two miles through inky darkness to the bottom of the ocean.

headline: MBIA Replaces Chief and Considers Split
text: The troubled bond insurer MBIA replaced its chief executive on Tuesday with its retired chairman, who said he would consider splitting up the company’s insurance business to restore confidence.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Sunday about the effect the arrest of a doctor accused of playing a role in the killing of her estranged husband is having on their Bukharan Jewish community in Queens misspelled the given name of the victim’s brother. (The error also appeared on Nov. 9 in an article in some editions.) He is Gavriel Malakov, not Gavril.

headline: Showcase for Talents in Progress, and Mentor
text: The premise behind Sugar Salon is serious business: to address the shortage of financing and performance opportunities for women by nurturing and commissioning work by female choreographers. But for a project with such lofty ambitions, isn’t the name a little demeaning? The word “daddy” seems to be lurking around the corner.

headline: Inspired by Buddha, Admired as Art
text: The stars of the show arrived in wooden crates at Kennedy Airport on New Year’s Eve. They had already enjoyed a hugely popular run in Japan and were now embarking on a world tour.

headline: Concert in North Korea to Be Broadcast Live
text: The North Korean government has agreed to a live national broadcast of the New York Philharmonic’s concert in Pyongyang next week, the orchestra said on Monday  an unheard-of event in that isolated country.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a news analysis article on Sunday about Israel’s quandary in deciding what to do about the control of Gaza by the militant Islamic group Hamas misidentified the location where an Israeli soldier, Cpl. Gilad Shalit, was captured in June 2006. It was in Israel, not Gaza. (He was later taken to Gaza.)

headline: Fines Sought on Tower Demolition
text: Federal regulators said today that they have cited the general contractor taking down the former Deutsche Bank tower and its former subcontractor for dozens of safety violations at the building where two firefighters died, proposing nearly half a million dollars in fines against them.

headline: When the Magic Fades
text: At first it seemed like a few random cases of lassitude among Mary Chapin Carpenter devotees in Berkeley, Cambridge and Chapel Hill. But then psychotherapists began to realize patients across the country were complaining of the same distress. They were experiencing the first hints of what’s bound to be a national phenomenon: Obama Comedown Syndrome.

headline: Villanova Runner Solves Sleeping Troubles
text: Two years ago, Marcus O’Sullivan, the former miler and now the Villanova men’s track coach, feared for Bobby Curtis’s future.“He’d fall asleep in the middle of a meet,” O’Sullivan once said. “I wasn’t sure if he would be awake for a race. I would enter two names for his relay leg. I thought his career might be over.”The problem was circadian rhythm disorder, which prevented him from sleeping or staying awake. Now Curtis, a senior from Louisville, Ky., is fine, and two weekends ago he ran 3,000 meters in 7 minutes 50.17 seconds, the fastest time indoors by a collegian this winter. He will run the 3,000 and the distance medley in the Big East indoor championships Saturday and Sunday at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.“I don’t have trouble with sleep now,” Curtis told the New York Track Writers Association by telephone Monday. “At the time, it was a very bad thing. For a while, I was going to bed at 2 a.m. and waking up at 7. I had no energy. It closed down everything. The problem was unbearable. It took four months, but I learned better sleeping habits. Now I sleep from 1 to 9 a.m. I feel good now.”

headline: Delgado Uses Off-Season to Rebuild His Swing
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The statistics compiled by Carlos Delgado during 14 years in the major leagues  particularly his 434 home runs  offer ample evidence that he knows how to hit a baseball. Contrary to popular belief, he did not forget how last season, the worst of his career. But he returned home to Puerto Rico feeling he had to do something radical nevertheless.

headline: BBC Ends English Shortwave Service in Europe
text: PARIS  The BBC World Service, which started its scratchy shortwave transmissions to listeners cut off by “desert, snow and sea” 75 years ago, ended its last English-language shortwave services in Europe on Monday.

headline: Forging a Singular Vision From a Many-Sided Talent
text: Meredith Monk’s career work has long been described, though hardly defined, in terms of its protean nature. Ms. Monk, 65, is a composer and a singer, true. But she is also a dancer and a choreographer, a director, a filmmaker and a conceptualist. She has performed most of her pieces herself, with an ensemble of versatile, sympathetic performers.

headline: Of Couples and Romance (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Japan Honors Eastwood
text: The Clint Eastwood film “Letters From Iwo Jima,” about the lives and deaths of Japanese soldiers in the battle for Iwo Jima in World War II, was named best foreign film at the 31st Japan Academy Awards ceremony on Friday in Tokyo, Variety reported. Joji Matsuoka’s “Tokyo Tower: Mom and Me, and Sometimes Dad,” about a mother-son relationship, took the prizes for best film, best director, best actress (Kiki Kirin as the dying mother), best supporting actor (Kaoru Kobayashi as the absent father) and best screenplay (Masuo Suzuki). Hidetaka Yoshioka, who won the best actor prize in 2006 for his performance as a struggling novelist in “Always,” won again for reprising the role in the nostalgic drama “Always 2.”

headline: In Search of a Real Urban Policy
text: By now, many Americans have heard the presidential candidates talk about issues close to the heart of rural America. They fell all over themselves to praise ethanol in Iowa and condemn nuclear storage in Nevada. But as important as rural problems are, they’re not nearly as big as the task of helping the nation’s struggling cities  where most Americans live or work. The cities have been the hardest hit as federal policies have failed or gone missing in education, housing, health care, jobs, transportation and environment, to name a few. Yet urban issues have gotten scant attention in this campaign.

headline: In Asian Reaction to Kosovo Declaration, Fears of Secession
text: HONG KONG  China, Indonesia and Sri Lanka on Monday criticized Kosovo’s declaration of independence from Serbia while Taiwan and Australia welcomed it, as Kosovo’s move appeared a litmus test of attitudes in Asia toward secession.

headline: Clinton Camp Says Obama Plagiarized in Speech
text: NILES, Ohio  With the next round of voters set to weigh in on the Democratic presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign on Monday accused Senator Barack Obama of committing plagiarism in a weekend speech. Mr. Obama dismissed the charge as absurd and desperate.

headline: In Books for Young, Two Views on Product Placement
text: Specifying a character’s brand of lipstick, shoes or handbag is a commonly accepted way to add an aura of reality or consumer aspiration to books aimed at young readers: just think of “The Gossip Girl,” with that series’s abundant references to Prada and Burberry. But what if writers and publishers enlisted companies to sponsor those branded mentions, as is the widespread practice in Hollywood?

headline: Pakistanis Deal Severe Defeat to Musharraf in Election
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistanis dealt a crushing defeat to President Pervez Musharraf in parliamentary elections on Monday, in what government and opposition politicians said was a firm rejection of his policies since 2001 and those of his close ally, the United States.

headline: John L. Phillips Jr., 83, Civil Court Judge Is Dead
text: John L. Phillips Jr., a retired Civil Court judge who owned theaters in Brooklyn that were a prominent platform for black activists in the 1980s, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. He was 83.

headline: For Publisher in Los Angeles, Cuts and Worse
text: The Hollywood Walk of Fame consists of more than 2,000 terrazzo-and-brass stars embedded in the sidewalk, bearing names from eminent to obscure (Strongheart the dog, anyone?). The walk attracts tourists, but most locals step over  make that drive past  without noticing.

headline: Proxy Fight Looms for Yahoo
text: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook.

headline: Lowering Odds of Multiple Births
text: In the complex, expensive and emotionally charged world of fertility treatment, doctors are sounding a call to arms to reverse the soaring rate of multiple births.

headline: A Young Politician Becomes a House Painter
text: On a late January morning, Jason West was under the weather and late for work. Sniffling and weary from nights of sleeping on a friend’s floor in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, the former mayor of the Village of New Paltz showed up at a building on West 60th Street, where he was on a job, in paint-splattered jeans and a work shirt.

headline: Welcomed in Iran
text: To the Editor:

headline: Silicon Valley Losing Middle-Wage Jobs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley is in danger of creating its own digital divide.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A photograph on Friday with an article about domestic violence among military personnel carried an incomplete credit. The photograph of Sgt. Jose Aguilar, who was deployed to Iraq despite a pending charge of child abuse, was provided by The Daily News/FENC, Jacksonville, N.C.  not just The Daily News, a Freedom Eastern North Carolina newspaper.

headline: China Expresses Concern Over U.S. Plan to Shoot Down a Faulty Spy Satellite
text: BEIJING  In response to a United States plan to shoot down a malfunctioning spy satellite, China has warned against threats to security in outer space, without mentioning its own successful anti-satellite missile test last year.

headline: Impressions of Terrorism, Drawn From Court Files
text: Jeffrey Breinholt, who is on leave from a counterterrorism post at the Justice Department, has been studying what he calls “an undervalued source of strategic intelligence about the threats we face from radical Islam within the U.S.” He has been looking at court decisions.

headline: Getting the Most Out of the Human Asset
text: “Our inventory goes down the elevator every night,” said Fairfax M. Cone, one of the pre-eminent advertising men of the last century. He was describing his company’s most important asset: its people.

headline: Support for a Theory as to Why Land Sinks Along the Gulf Coast
text: Climate change may be causing sea levels to rise, but in some coastal areas the problem is worsened because the land is sinking as well. That’s the case in Louisiana, where subsidence has caused erosion and loss of wetlands. Without wetlands to act as buffers, the devastation of storms like Katrina is even greater.

headline: Wall St. Banks Confront a String of Write-Downs
text: Wall Street banks are bracing for another wave of multibillion-dollar losses as the crisis that began with subprime mortgages spreads through the credit markets.

headline: Is There a Bass in the House?
text: In the middle of the first act of a packed English National Opera performance of Donizetti’s “Lucia di Lammermoor” on Saturday, a chest infection claimed the voice of the bass Clive Bayley, who was singing the leading role of Raimondo, Lucia’s tutor. Could the show be saved? Yes indeed, Reuters reported. Out from the audience came Paul Whelan, 38, who just happened to have been studying the role and was scheduled to take over from Mr. Bayley in a few weeks, through he had had no chance to rehearse. As the performance continued, Mr. Whelan sang from the wings and Mr. Bayley mimed the action. At the conclusion Mr. Whelan, wearing suit and tie, joined the cast for a bow onstage, above. The performers received a standing ovation. “I’m just so glad I was wearing my Armani tie,” he said.

headline: Promoting a Film, and Other Products
text: The American Basketball Association brought us the red, white and blue basketball, the 3-point shot, the slam dunk contest and huge Afros atop very tall athletes.

headline: In U.S., Cuban Exiles Unmoved
text: Cuban exiles in the United States reacted coolly on Tuesday to the overnight news that Fidel Castro was stepping down as president of Cuba, an island he has ruled with an iron fist for almost 50 years.

headline: Castro, the First Communist Retiree?
text: Fidel Castro's official announcement that he was stepping down as president of Cuba was long expected: he had temporarily given up power a year and a half ago when his health crisis first began. But Communist leaders are not known to give up power willingly, so Mr. Castro's exit might be a historical first. Or not.

headline: Out of Adventurous, Reactionary Vienna
text: Do not look for the Viennese soul in the waltzes of Johann Strauss. Try instead the dark places of Anton Webern’s Six Pieces for Orchestra or Alban Berg’s Three Orchestra Pieces, both played by James Levine and his Met Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon.

headline: Retired Police Officer Shot Dead at Home
text: A retired New York police sergeant was shot to death by his wife Monday morning during a domestic dispute at their home in Howard Beach, Queens, the police said.

headline: Scientists Finding Ways to Perfect a Cup of Joe, Without the Attitude
text: Television viewers of a certain age may remember El Exigente, the Colombian coffee buyer with strict standards in commercials for Savarin coffee in the 1960s and ’70s. Surrounded by local coffee growers, the white-suited Demanding One would take a sip of some of their fresh-brewed java. A smile of approval would be the cause for much rejoicing.

headline: Health Plans Put Onus on Insured
text: Let the patient beware. Going outside your insurer’s network of preferred doctors or hospitals could be even more hazardous to your financial health than you suspected.

headline: Lottery Numbers
New Trove Opened in Kennedy Killing
text: DALLAS  The Kennedy assassination  a defining moment in American history and a never-ending topic of debate among conspiracy theorists  re-entered the spotlight for a moment Monday, after the Dallas district attorney unveiled the contents of a safe that had been secret for more than 40 years.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an Associated Press report in the Sports Briefing column in some editions on Sunday about the runner Kenenisa Bekele’s world record for two miles at the Norwich Union Grand Prix in England misidentified the nationality of the former record holder, Haile Gebrselassie. He is an Ethiopian, not a Kenyan.

headline: Midlife Suicide Rises, Puzzling Researchers
text: Shannon Neal can instantly tell you the best night of her life: Tuesday, Dec. 23, 2003, the Hinsdale Academy debutante ball. Her father, Steven Neal, a 54-year-old political columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, was in his tux, white gloves and tie. “My dad walked me down and took a little bow,” she said, and then the two of them goofed it up on the dance floor as they laughed and laughed.

headline: China’s Inflation Rose to 7.1% in January
text: HONG KONG  Consumer prices rose 7.1 percent in China last month, the largest increase in more than a decade.

headline: A Strong Endorsement for McCain From a Former President
text: HOUSTON  When former President George Bush stood beside Senator John McCain here on Monday and gave him a Presidents’ Day endorsement, it was just the latest chapter in the sometimes-tangled saga of the Bush and the McCain dynasties.

headline: Week’s Notables
text: PLAYER Angelica Figueroa, a 17-year-old senior at Linden High School in California, is hoping to land a spot on Mexico’s women’s national team when it plays qualifying matches for the Beijing Olympics at a regional tournament April 2-13 in Juarez, Mexico. Two of the six teams in the tournament will advance to the Summer Games in August. Figueroa was born in the United States, but her parents are from Mexico. She is expected to be with the Mexican team Friday when it plays Southern California, the N.C.A.A. champion, in Los Angeles.

headline: Domestic Passenger Traffic Rose in 2007
text: CARRIER CUTS MILEAGE BENEFITS Starting in May, US Airways says, frequent-flier miles in its Dividend Miles program will be awarded based on the actual number of miles flown. The change affects passengers who fly short-haul trips of less than 500 miles, including those who use the US Air shuttle between New York and Boston and Washington. Under the previous policy, passengers were awarded a minimum credit of 500 miles a flight, which is standard practice in major airlines’ frequent-flier programs. US Airways also said that passengers who redeem miles for award travel within 14 days of departure would be changed a “quick-ticketing fee” of $50 a ticket. US Airways cited “record fuel prices and rising airline-related expenses” for the changes.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Monday about a New York City Transit employee’s deft use of the semicolon in a public service placard was less deft in its punctuation of the title of a book by Lynne Truss, who called the placard a “lovely example” of proper punctuation. The title of the book is “Eats, Shoots & Leaves”  not “Eats Shoots & Leaves.” (The subtitle of Ms. Truss’s book is “The Zero Tolerance Approach to Punctuation.”)

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A sports article on Thursday about medical testimony in the confrontation between pitcher Roger Clemens and his former personal trainer, Brian McNamee, misspelled the surname of a radiology expert interviewed by the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform about an infection that Clemens developed in his left buttocks. He is Dr. Mark Murphey, not Murphy.

headline: Little Panic on the Prairie: The Odd World of ‘Jericho’
text: The postapocalyptic fantasy “Jericho” has returned for a second season more pungent and more pointed than its first. (As a matter of procedure we properly ought to start by thanking the fanatics who borrowed from the show’s spirit of communitarianism, sending CBS executives 20 tons of peanuts to rescue the series from cancellation.)

headline: Higher Education Gap May Slow Economic Mobility
text: The widening gap in higher education between rich and poor, and between whites and minorities, may lead to a downturn in economic mobility, making it harder for today’s poor to move up the income ladder, according to the authors of a major research report issued Wednesday.

headline: Scientist at Work
text: Carl Zimmer visits Dr. Roger Hanlon in his lab at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass.

headline: Israel Museum
text: The Israel Museum in Jerusalem has opened an exhibition of important art looted by the Nazis from France and then returned after the war.

headline: How Much More Damage Can Brian Burke Do?
text: One-minute penalties! Bigger goal nets! Fixing the shootout … by adding more shooters! Yes, it’s that time of year again: the NHL general managers are meeting to concoct a whole new grab bag of innovations that read less like a summit of hockey executives and more like a Mad Magazine parody of a professional sport.

headline: $3.5 Million Homes
text: Properties on the market in Florida, California and Wyoming.

headline: Fidel Castro Resigns as President
text: The Cuban leader said that he will not return to lead the country.

headline: Credit Suisse’s $2.85 Billion Surprise
text: Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced new write-downs of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit, in a stunning reminder of the difficulty banks face in valuing complicated financial instruments under current market conditions.

headline: College Paper Vows to Fight a Takeover by Gannett
text: J. David McSwane, the student editor of The Rocky Mountain Collegian who drew global attention last fall for a four-word editorial criticizing President Bush, is facing another storm.

headline: A Start-Up Says It Can Predict Others’ Fate
text: Is your start-up worthy of investment? Ask the venture investor in a box.

headline: Rebukes Are Swift for the Chief of Deutsche Post
text: The German political elite has wasted no time in dissociating itself from Klaus Zumwinkel, the chief executive of Deutsche Post, who is suspected of using a foundation in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: Tax Scandal in Germany Fans Complaints of Inequity
text: For wealthy Germans, many of whom have long hidden their money outside the country to avoid its high taxes, this has been a weekend of high anxiety. For their fellow citizens, it has been a riveting spectacle, dominating the public discussion for days.

headline: Silicon Valley Starts to Turn Its Face to the Sun
text: Can Silicon Valley become a world leader in cheap and ubiquitous solar panels for the masses?

headline: Ericsson Sells Business Exchange to Canada’s Aastra
text: A Swedish wireless equipment maker, LM Ericsson, said Monday it would sell its enterprise PBX solutions business to Aastra Technologies of Canada for 650 million kronor ($103 million).

headline: Disney Seeks Controlling Stake in India’s UTV
text: The Walt Disney Company may acquire a controlling stake in India’s UTV Software Communications, maker of last year’s box-office hit “The Namesake,” after it offered to buy additional shares.

headline: Sweden Said to Choose 4 to Advance in Vin & Sprit Auction
text: Sweden’s center-right government has chosen four bidders in its auction of Vin & Sprit, the maker of Absolut vodka, that will be allowed to perform due diligence of the company, the business daily Dagens Industri reported.

headline: 3i Focuses on Ultralase
text: A buyout shop, the 3i Group of London, agreed on Friday to buy a laser eye surgery provider, Ultralase, from Spanish cosmetic surgery group Corporación Dermoestética for 174.5 million pounds ($343.2 million).

headline: Fortune Super Equity Captures Scorpion
text: Scorpion Offshore, a money-losing oil rig startup, agreed on Friday to a takeover offer from Abu Dhabi-based Fortune Super Equity Management .

headline: Season Awards for Giants
text: (This week’s guest blogger has been bleeding Giant blue since the late 1960s with Fran Tarkenton, Spider Lockhart and Ron Johnson. From 4th-and-17 to the Tyree-play-to-be-named-later, all things Giants football can be found on his blog at  ultimatenyg.blogspot.com)

headline: IKB Plans $2 Billion Share Sale as Part of Rescue
text: IKB Deutsche Industriebank, the German bank wracked by losses from the United States subprime mortgage crisis, has announced plans to sell 1.5 billion euros ($2.19 billion) in shares as part of a government-sponsored bailout, provided its shareholders agree to the move.

headline: NuConomy Raises $3 Million
text: A Web analytics company NuConomy has raised $3 million in its first round of venture funding led by a large advertising conglomerate WPP.

headline: Rural Electrification I.P.O., a Test for Investors in India
text: An initial public offering of 156 million shares of India’s state-run lender, the Rural Electrification Corporation, was fully subscribed within the first hour of the opening.

headline: Ex-Dow Jones Director Leaves Hong Kong Post
text: David Li, the Hong Kong banker and lawmaker who is paying $8.1 million to settle a United States inquiry into his possible role in an insider-trading case involving shares of Dow Jones & Company, resigned from the city government’s executive council late Saturday.

headline: In Turkey, Is Tension About Religion? Class Rivalry? Or Both?
text: ISTANBUL  When two women in Islamic head scarves were spotted in an Italian restaurant in this city's posh new shopping mall this month, Gulbin Simitcioglu did a double take.

headline: Abramovich’s Evraz Enters Asia With Delong Stake
text: Delong Holdings, a Chinese metals maker, gained 16 percent in Singapore after the Evraz Group, a steelmaker part-owned by the Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich, said it might buy the company in its first Asian takeover.

headline: Reliance Mulls Offering Bonus Shares After Debut Plunge
text: India’s Reliance Power, owned by the billionaire Anil Ambani, could issue bonus shares to investors in a move to compensate them for a sharp decline in its stock price, the company said on Monday.

headline: Qatar Petroleum Plans I.P.O. for Gulf Unit
text: Qatar Petroleum,a state-owned oil company, said on Sunday it would sell a 65.8 percent stake in a new holding firm in an initial public offering starting on Feb. 28.

headline: Private Equity Firm Said to Rev Up Deal for Ducati
text: A major shareholder in the Italian motorcycle maker Ducati plans to bid for the entire company and delist it, Italy’s financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore reported, according to Reuters.

headline: Deutsche Post Appoints Temporary Chief Amid Tax Scandal
text: The supervisory board of Deutsche Post on Monday picked Frank Appel to lead the mail and global logistics company after his predecessor resigned last week amid a growing tax evasion investigation that has gripped Germany.

headline: Final Push for Delta-Northwest Deal
text: CNBC interviews Ron Allen, former chief executive of Delta Airlines and Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, on the two carriers' push to create to world's largest airline.

headline: Subprime ‘Bloodbath’ to Cut ANZ Profits
text: The Australia & New Zealand Banking Group fell to a 2-1/2-year low in Sydney trading after the chief executive, Michael Smith, said the “bloodbath” in debt markets would erase profit growth this year.

headline: JPMorgan to Funnel $750 Million into Asia Private Equity Fund
text: JPMorgan Chase announced a major push on Monday into private-equity investing in Asia, saying it had earmarked at least $750 million of its own capital to take minority stakes in businesses in a region where buyouts are notoriously difficult.

headline: V.W. Denies Chairman Wants to Oust Porsche Chief
text: Volkswagen denied on Sunday that the chairman of its supervisory board, Ferdinand Piech, wanted to oust Wendelin Wiedeking as chief executive of the sports car maker Porsche, V.W.’s biggest shareholder.

headline: Hedge Fund Investor Raises $263 Million
text: Dexion Absolute, the largest listed closed-end fund investing in a pool of hedge funds, said it raised a further $263 million Monday as demand for those kinds of investments showed no signs of waning despite volatile returns in recent months.

headline: Refco’s Ex-Chief Pleads Guilty to Fraud and Conspiracy
text: The former chief executive of Refco, one of the world’s biggest commodities brokerage firms, pleaded guilty Friday to conspiracy and fraud charges that carry a possible prison term of more than 300 years.

headline: Silicon Valley Losing Middle-Wage Jobs
text: Silicon Valley is in danger of creating its own digital divide.

headline: Citigroup Sells Japan Headquarters to Morgan Stanley
text: Citigroup, which has been raising funds since taking a huge hit from the United States subprime mortgage meltdown, has sold its Japan headquarters to a rival, Morgan Stanley, in a deal reportedly worth $445 million.

headline: Citigroup Rescue Package Finds Admirer
text: In a six-month period from mid-summer to mid-January, government-allied, offshore institutional investors poured more than $40 billion into blue-chip American and European financial institutions, including Barclays, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and UBS.

headline: Hedge Funds Hit by Northern Rock Decision
text: RAB Capital and SRM Global, two of Europe’s best known hedge funds, are likely to be the biggest losers following the British government’s decision to nationalize the troubled lender Northern Rock.

headline: Brown Defends Takeover of Ailing British Lender
text: Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Monday defended his decision to nationalize the ailing mortgage lender Northern Rock, facing down angry shareholders and even the bank’s own management.

headline: More Blood Expected on The Street
text: Forget the big bonus, access to the corporate jet and oceans of pricey champagne at dinner. For many bond and equity traders, The New York Post suggests, the new status symbol on Wall Street may a steady job.

headline: In Microsoft-Yahoo Deal, Technologies Could Clash
text: If Microsoft succeeds in its conquest of Yahoo, what then?

headline: V.C.’s Hot on Pythagoras Solar
text: Solar energy startup Pythagoras Solar has completed a $10 million first round of funding led by Israel Cleantech Ventures, according to a report by Clean Edge.

headline: Reviewing Disney’s Pixar Gamble
text: In 2006, when a newly installed Robert Iger annexed Pixar Animation to Walt Disney, the company he had recently been appointed to run, the deal was met with skepticism.

headline: Singapore Said to Sell Part of Merrill Stake
text: It appears that Merrill Lynch is about to get another foreign investor, albeit one with a very small stake. South Korea’s Hana Bank has agreed to buy 1 million shares of Merrill Lynch from Temasek Holdings, Singapore’s state-owned investment company, for $50 million, according to Dow Jones.

headline: ‘His Hair Is Still Leaning Toward Hillary’
text: Aired Monday night on CBS: Ladies and gentlemen, I know you heard about this: the big tainted meat recall. This is a huge story. Out in California, they found out that something was haywire with the beef. They recalled –- listen to this –- 143 million pounds of tainted beef, 143 million, yes. That’s one triple stack burger at Wendy’s.

headline: Microsoft to Authorize Proxy Fight at Yahoo
text: In an escalation of its fight for Yahoo, Microsoft will authorize a proxy fight at the Internet company this week, people briefed on the matter told DealBook. Unless Yahoo quickly reverses course and enters into talks, Microsoft would then seek to nominate a slate of directors to Yahoo’s board by March 13, the final deadline for nominations, and pursue a lengthy campaign to oust the board.

headline: Qatar Buys Up Credit Suisse Shares
text: Qatar is buying shares in Credit Suisse in the open market and plans to spend as much as $15 billion on European and American bank stocks over the next year, according to its prime minister.

text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Happy President’s Day, or as Mitt Romney calls it, “Monday,” I guess.

The first article focuses on the “Stalled Lives” of Egypt’s young, and the initial “Majlis” entries are from the staff of The Times’ Cairo bureau.

headline: Slowdown to Test Market for Credit Default Swaps
text: Few Americans have heard of credit default swaps, arcane financial instruments invented by Wall Street about a decade ago. But if the economy keeps slowing, credit default swaps, like subprime mortgages, may become a household term, The New York Times says.

headline: Barclays Reports $3.1 Billion Write-Down for 2007
text: Barclays, Britain’s third-biggest bank, raised its 2007 write-down on the value of risky assets to 1.6 billion pounds ($3.1 billion) but reported profits broadly in line with analysts’ expectations.

headline: Wall St. Banks Confront a String of Write-Downs

headline: MBIA Reinstates Ex-C.E.O.
text: MBIA, the beleaguered bond insurer, said Tuesday that Joseph Brown had returned as chairman and chief executive, replacing Gary Dunton, who resigned. Mr. Brown, 59, served as chairman and chief executive until May 2004 and served as executive chairman until May 2007 before retiring.

headline: Delta Air Lines Said to Be Near a Northwest Deal
text: Delta Air Lines moved closer on Monday to a deal to buy Northwest Airlines, according to The New York Times.

headline: The Early Word: Another Primary Day
text: It’s no Super Tuesday, but Hawaiian Democrats and Wisconsinites will head to the voting booths today. Washington State Republicans will allot 19 more delegates in their primary (18 were doled out during the state’s caucus on Feb. 9). Early voting begins in Texas, as well.

headline: A Savior for Chrysler? Read On
text: In a letter to investors about the state of Cerberus Capital Management‘s investments in Chrysler and GMAC, the firm’s founder, Stephen Feinberg, came off sounding at turns cavalier and ruthless, says Andrew Ross Sorkin in his latest DealBook column.

headline: Making Fuel From Air – Some Details
text: Kenneth Chang has written a piece in this week’s Science Times exploring the Los Alamos National Laboratories concept for nuclear-powered fuel refineries that could turn atmospheric carbon dioxide and water into gasoline, jet fuel or methanol. headline: Buh Bye
text: Take a look at the video tribute to Mark Lisanti at Defamer, who is leaving so he has enough time to screw up his life enough so that he can go into rehab. The weird thing about the video? Everybody seems so darn sincere.

headline: Let’s All Meet at the In-N-Out Burger After
text: Surely something will rush in to fill the post-Oscar vacuum created by the cancellation of this year’s Vanity Fair party? Surely not, says Anne Thompson. She suggests all of the action will be on the run-up, after which the air will just start leaking out of the balloon. She also says that the Elton John bash, which is billed as a viewing party, will stay that way.

headline: ‘Juno’ How to Stir Up the Homestretch?
text: Even in the homestretch — Oscar ballots are due today — some people are having trouble generating enthusiasm about this year’s race. Scott Feinberg is not one of them. As the overlord of the And the Winner Is … blog he has covered every wiggle and wobble in the race, some real and some imagined, and spends a great deal of time reporting, which is breathtakingly uncommon in the blog world.

headline: Abandonment of Javits Expansion Stirs Opposition
text: The Spitzer administration’s decision to scrap a long-promised expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center and sell some of its property to plug gaps in the state budget has prompted opposition from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and other city officials, state legislators, trade show producers and tourism executives, Charles V. Bagli reports. It has also revealed deep fault lines within the coalition that in 2006 hailed a since-defunct $1.8 billion proposed expansion as critical to the city’s tourism industry and the creation of 20,000 jobs and tens of millions of dollars a year in economic benefits for New York.

headline: Following the Twists in the Clear Channel Suit
text: Last week we discussed how Goodman Global‘s deal got done. One of the points made there was that in these troubled times limiting complexity was a means to ensure greater certainty of deal completion in private equity deals.

headline: Moelis & Co. Said to be Planning a London Office
text: Moelis & Company, the boutique advisory firm set up last year by Ken Moelis, a former banker at UBS, plans to open a London office this year, according to the Financial News.

headline: Grand Dreams for Engineers
text: It’s not exactly light reading, but there’s plenty of good news in a report from the National Academy of Engineering. It’s a list of the “Grand Challenges” in engineering this century compiled by an array of experts like the genetics researcher J. Craig Ventner and Google’s Larry Page. What’s encouraging isn’t so much the list itself (which has predictably virtuous endeavors like improving the urban infrastructure) but the big picture if offers by comparing past achievements with the challenges of today.

headline: Playwrights and the Theater
text: Before I talk about “August: Osage County,” and what is astonishing about this play, I want to start by stating the obvious.

headline: Obama Campaign Responds to Delegate Report
text: Advisers to Senator Barack Obama denounced the Clinton campaign Tuesday morning over a report that it would pursue delegates that Mr. Obama has already won.

headline: Blogs Without the Links
text: By their very nature, the world’s 80 million blogs — give or take a few million — seem to defy easy categorization and evaluation. Sites like Technorati and Bloglines claim to track the most popular blogs, but popularity is just one way to find blogs worth reading. A new book, “Ultimate Blogs: Masterworks from the Wild Web,” takes a different tack. Edited by Sarah Boxer, it aspires to be a sort of Norton Anthology of Blogging, with excerpts from 27 blogs, 9 of them by people living in New York City.

text: The presidential candidates have already begun weighing in on the “retirement” of Fidel Castro, who announced early this morning that he was stepping down as commander in chief of Cuba after one of the longest reigns of a dictatorship in modern history.

headline: Credit Suisse vs. KPMG
text: I’d love to be a fly on the wall for discussions between Credit Suisse management and KPMG. In fessing up to a $2.85 billion “mispricing” of securities — a problem that senior management says it had no idea existed a week ago, when it reported fourth quarter profits — the bank says it is not sure whether the mispricing of assets will damage annual earnings for last year, but hopes that it will not.

headline: CNBC Video: Faber on MBIA’s New C.E.O.
text: As the assorted members of the bond insurance industry try to regain their footing, the largest of them announced a major shakeup on Tuesday. MBIA said that Joseph Brown, its former chief executive and chairman, would succeed the departing Gary Dunton.

headline: Hank Steinbrenner Says Baseball Is Being Picked On
text: Hank Steinbrenner, the senior vice president of the Yankees, repeated Tuesday his opinion that baseball players are unfairly cited for use of performance-enhancing drugs and that other sports might have a bigger problem.

headline: Paris Sights and Activities for a Teenage Boy

But when one, then two, then three balls sailed wide, a few other reporters and I started wondering what happened. Was this a new pitch? Was Pedro hurt?

headline: Brewer-Clifton and Scholium
text: Had dinner the other night with Greg Brewer of Brewer-Clifton, who was passing through New York. I’ve written about Greg before in the context of one of his side projects, Diatom. He and his partner, Steve Clifton, who with his wife, Chrystal, have their own side project, Palmina, are two of the more thoughtful winemakers I’ve met from California, dedicated to their own vision regardless of the critical consequences.

headline: Congressman Serrano Praises Castro
text: The news of Fidel Castro’s decision to step down as president of Cuba has generated an outpouring of reaction from American politicians. Most, like President Bush, have expressed hope that Mr. Castro’s departure from the helm of power will signal a democratic transition in Cuba. But one politician — Representative José E. Serrano, a Bronx Democrat — went out of his way to actually praise the Cuban leader today.

headline: A Stairway to Sports History From the Polo Grounds

headline: Game Shows on NBC Led the Ratings on Monday
text: The combination of “Deal or No Deal” and the new game show “My Dad is Better Than Your Dad” lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, the new show — which pits father-child teams against each other — attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for “Deal or No Deal” at 8 p.m.

headline: Keeping Tabs on the Superdelegates
text: In her column today, Katharine Q. Seelye writes, “The last time the superdelegates really mattered in a Democratic primary was in 1984. One of the big differences between then and now is the Internet. This has allowed the emergence of a whole new political force that did not exist two decades ago. And it means everyone can watch the political alliances shift and, in a sense, everyone can play.” Go to Column

text: The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan are taking a huge toll on the American military. Who says so? The nation’s military officers, who are in as good a position as anyone to know.

headline: Murder Case Focuses New Attention on Mental Illness Treatment

text: The Bugatti Type 41 Royale is widely considered the most expensive car in the world. Only six were ever built (between 1927 and 1933). And each is estimated to be worth around $10 million.

headline: The Meat Industry’s Real Malady
text: Two interesting links for those following the largest beef recall in our nation’s history. One — by the AP  — in yesterday’s Times includes a link to the video that shows workers at Westland/Hallmark Meat Co. of Chino, Calif., using fork lifts to ram still-living but sick cattle. The other, in the Wall Street Journal, quotes Westland/Hallmark president Steve Mendell as “shocked and horrified” by the video.

headline: Your Conscience or Your Constituency?
text: How should the nearly 800 unpledged “party leader and elected official” delegates — the so-called superdelegates — vote when the Democratic convention is held in August? These delegates may well hold the balance of power in this year’s nomination contest, and unlike “regular” delegates, they will not arrive at the convention with a binding pledge to vote for either Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama. How they will exercise their power is crucial, and is already the subject of some high-level angst among the Democratic Party’s most important leaders.

headline: Soft Serve | A Dolce & Gabbana Gym, Luxury License Plates and Kool-Aid Sneakers
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Smarties in Dumbo
text: It’s well established that Manhattan is for the rich, the rent-controlled and the prescient who bought years ago. And it’s old news that most up-and-coming New York writers and editors live in Brooklyn. But who’da thunk that Dumbo — the gritty-chic Brooklyn neighborhood whose acronym means “down under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass,” home of million-dollar condos, the York Street Projects, artists’ studios and high-end boutiques — would become a bastion of indie publishing? Lured by the subsidized rent offered by the developer David Walentas, in recent months, Verso, the leftie British press, and Melville House, the literary publisher, have moved to Dumbo, and the upstart literary quarterly N+1 is on its way. The London-based New Left Review has some space in Verso’s office, and the London Review of Books is also said to have scouted out space there.

headline: 10-Ton Fish Tanks Will Greet Staten Island Ferry
text: Staten Islanders understandably have a special relationship with the ferry terminals that greet them each day on their commutes to and from work. How else can one explain the grand announcement today that New York City will spend $750,000 in capital funds to erect two eight-foot-tall saltwater tanks — each weighing more than 10 tons — to house 400 colorful fish at the St. George terminal?

headline: Getting Ready for ‘The Endless Season’
text: After months of speculation, NBC confirmed on Tuesday that it would sidestep the annual star-studded “upfront” presentation for advertisers and hold a series of client meetings with media buyers instead.

headline: New York Democrats Fear Long Nomination Fight
text: New York Democrats are feeling the pressure building within their ranks and within the bigger Democratic machine, as Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama continue to battle it out on the campaign trail with no end soon in sight. Some of the more influential New York Democrats are even calling for one or the other to step down sooner or later to maintain accord in the party. “I think Hillary and Barack, if there’s not 2,025, have to get together and figure out a mechanism that they both abide by,” Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Clinton supporter, said after a speech at the annual Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian caucus for state lawmakers in Albany over the weekend.

headline: Moscow’s Immigrants Face Wave of Skinhead Violence
text: In response to a wave of recent skinhead attacks on non-Slavs in Moscow, city government officials sat down with representatives of ethnic diasporas on Monday for a tense meeting during which leaders from the Azeri, Kygyz and other communities accused law enforcement bodies of harboring sympathy for violent nationalists and for failing to adequately investigate and prosecute hate crimes.

headline: Civic Group Calls for Voting Investigation
text: On Saturday, Sam Roberts reported that in about 80 of the city’s 6,106 election districts, unofficial results showed Senator Barack Obama without a single vote, including several districts where he ran a respectable race in a nearby area. City election officials said their formal review of the results, which will not be completed for weeks, had confirmed discrepancies between the vote totals reported publicly — and unofficially — on primary night and the actual tally on hundreds of voting machines across the city.

headline: Will Rubber Ducky Ever Be Enshrined?
text: Tucked down Aisle 900 of Toy Fair (just Toy Fair, mind you, not “the Toy Fair”) at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center — amid the newest whirring, glowing, hovering, shrinking playthings clamoring to be the hit product this year — is a space reserved for the elite of the elite, the toys that don’t have to prove themselves anymore to anybody. They are the inductees to the National Toy Hall of Fame.The honored toys include the sophisticated but obsolete (Atari 2600, inducted in 2007) and the humble (cardboard box, 2005), the trademarked (Scrabble, 2004) and the generic (kite, 2007), the domestic (Easy Bake Oven, 2006) and the militaristic (G. I. Joe, 2004).

headline: When They Were Young
text: A friend found this picture in an archive and I love all that it conveys about Italian fashion. I’m not sure of the identities of the two women on the left (perhaps someone on the blog can help), but, from left to right, that’s Giorgio Armani, Valentino, a former Italian president, Mariuccia Mandelli, Gianfranco Ferre and Gianni Versace. Hovering in the background, behind Valentino, is Giancarlo Giammetti. Swell picture, isn’t it?

headline: The Biggest Airline Deals to Take Flight
text: As the boards of both Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines gather Tuesday to discuss a potential merger — one that could shake up an industry that has clamored for consolidation — it’s worth putting any deal that is reached in perspective. Dealogic helped DealBook out by listing some of the biggest airline transactions to get off the ground.

headline: The Party of the Elite
text: Just as Republicans base our party platform on the principle of individual freedom and opportunity, the ideological foundation for the Democratic Party is all about standing up for the little guy. Democrats want to give a voice to the voiceless and power to the powerless. Except when it comes to nominating their party’s candidate for president.

headline: Lukewarm
text: In 2005, meal assembly shops were the hottest trend in small business. But not anymore.

headline: Are the Westons So Different?
text: I don’t see many plays. In fact, being a mother of four small kids, I don’t see much of anything lately except for the interior windshield of my minivan. What goes down inside that minivan, however — and I mean along the lines of family conflict and sibling relations and, for that matter, angry mothers (me?!) lashing out at their children — what goes on inside that minivan as we tear away to drop the eldest off at first grade, or try to get our act together in the parking lot of a grocery store as a three year old is in shambles … well, let me tell you, it is high drama. I’m not kidding. Babies, toddlers, and small children are people who might as well be in the throes of Tracy Letts’s play. They are all raw and barely patient, attached to their siblings unwittingly, vicious and angry, and then, by turns, hysterically funny and apt.

headline: Leaving the Rabbit Hole
text: The worst thing, to me, about having a non-stop multi-year headache isn’t necessarily the pain. Or the way it tends to disrupt intimate relationships, empty all financial reserves, and sabotage the best-laid career plans. It’s not even the endless barrage of (albeit well-meaning) suggestions for “cures” from everyone you meet, most of which you’ve already tried anyway (except for the colon cleansing and the Jews for Jesus conversion).

text: The runway tonight at Prada swept down and circled around, so that the audience was almost always looking up at the clothes. With heavy eyebrows, pale lips and black snoods planted on their gel-darkened hair, the models did not resemble themselves. Lara Stone no longer looked like the blonde Lara Stone but, rather, a cameo figure. The same was true of Natasha P.

headline: Hello Wisconsin!
text: Wrapup | 11:40 p.m.:  Wrapup: Mrs. Clinton heads back to New York tonight and there probably aren’t too many people who want to be on that plane ride, unless they are the Houdinis of politics. Her presidential bid is handcuffed, in a locked treasure chest, under the ice. Will Ohio and Texas let Mrs. Clinton come up for air?

headline: Morton J. Savada, 85, Seller of 78-R.P.M. Records, Dies
text: Morton J. Savada, who lined the narrow aisles of his store in Midtown Manhattan with nearly a quarter of a million 78-r.p.m. records, offering devotees of King Oliver, Ma Rainey, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman the chance to hear the original sound of nondigital discography, died at his home in Harrison, N.Y., on Feb. 11. He was 85.
