headline: Research Centers on Finding New Drugs
text: After years of futile attempts at replacing the defective gene that causes Duchenne muscular dystrophy, researchers are now more intent on overriding the gene.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A sports article on Friday about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens over the use of performance-enhancing drugs misidentified the investigators to whom Mr. McNamee revealed that he had injected Mr. Clemens’s wife with human growth hormone. They were Congressional investigators, not Mr. Clemens’s investigators.

headline: Birds Sing, Glasses Wail, Storms Rage, Seas Toss
text: Among the great pleasures of regularly attending concerts is the occasional encounter with a performance that far surpasses expectations. The concert by the Juilliard Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday night did just that. I can’t think of another recent orchestral program that left me more exhilarated.

headline: Credit Suisse Says Traders’ Pricing Errors Will Cause $2.85 Billion in Write-Downs
text: LONDON  Credit Suisse shook the markets on Tuesday when it announced that pricing errors by traders on asset-backed securities would result in write-downs of $2.85 billion.

headline: Tape Inquiry: Ex-Spymaster in the Middle
text: WASHINGTON  It would become known inside the Central Intelligence Agency as “the Italian job,” a snide movie reference to the bungling performance of an agency team that snatched a radical Muslim cleric from the streets of Milan in 2003 and flew him to Egypt  a case that led to criminal charges in Italy against 26 Americans.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie  as a United States attorney  awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christie’s former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract. (Go to Article)

headline: After a Judgment, Music Label Files Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
text: TVT Records, long ranked as one of the top independent labels in the recording industry, filed for bankruptcy protection Tuesday as part of an overhaul that involved staff cutbacks and the closing of certain international offices, the company said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the Food and Drug Administration breaking its own rules by not inspecting a plant in China that made the active ingredient of a blood-thinning drug misspelled part of the name of the company that founded American Capital Strategies Ltd., the majority owner of Scientific Protein Laboratories, which owns the plant. It is Oscar Mayer, not Meyer.

headline: A Long Journey to a Kinder Chisel
text: IN the 1960s, when Downie McCarty was a teenager and his head was filled with the futuristic wonders of space age technology, he asked his father about his own future. “I used to say, ‘Dad, how am I going to make a living making these old kinds of tools?’ ”

headline: Making Economics Relevant Again
text: It was only a decade ago that economics seemed to be an old and tired discipline. The field no longer had intellectual giants like John Maynard Keynes or Milton Friedman who were shaping public policy by the sheer force of their ideas. Instead, it was devolving into a technical discipline that was even less comprehensible than it was relevant.

headline: Bank of Montreal Takes Write-Down and Bolsters SIVs
text: OTTAWA  The Bank of Montreal said on Tuesday that it would take a first-quarter charge of 490 million Canadian dollars, related to problems in the credit market.

headline: Corzine Is Said to Weigh Cutting 3,000 Jobs and One Department
text: TRENTON  Faced with a worsening economy, Gov. Jon S. Corzine is considering reducing the state’s work force by 3,000 employees and closing at least one department in the administration as part of his plan to slash up to $2.5 billion from next year’s budget, people who have been briefed on his plans said on Tuesday.

headline: Match-Play Event Brings Risks for Top 4 in Ranking
text: MARANA, Ariz.,  For one week each year, the normally staid golf governing bodies comprising the International Federation of PGA Tours step outside the lines and throw down some fairly risky behavior. This is that week, a week when the format is match play and the stakes are higher than only the $8 million purse at the Accenture Match Play Championship at The Gallery at Dove Mountain.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Monday of ****** Jeans at the Silent Barn in Queens misidentified the bassist. He is Randy Huth  not Dave Rosenstrauss, who left the band.

headline: Slowdown Hits Towns at Outskirts of Texas Boom
text: LAVON, Tex.  Once little more than a speed trap 25 miles northeast of Dallas, this town started to boom about a year ago, as turreted stone castlettes and modest brick bungalows began springing up in what had been wheat fields.

headline: Wisconsin? Texas and Ohio Are Where All the Action Has Gone
text: PARMA, Ohio  Before the polls even opened in Wisconsin on Tuesday, the two Democratic contenders had moved on to campaign in Texas and Ohio, the two next big prizes on the primary calendar.

headline: To Lure Adults From Their Living Rooms, More Cinemas Try a Full-Frills Model
text: SAN FRANCISCO  There’s more than popcorn and soda on the menu at Robert Redford’s new movie theater here. Try roasted game hen (priced at $17), braised oxtail ($21) or crab cakes ($12). Cocktails, craft beers and local wines round out the list.

headline: Commission Report Cites Flaws in New Jersey Civil Union Law
text: New Jersey’s civil union law “creates a second-class status” for same-sex couples and is particularly vexing for people in the military, transgender people, the poor and minorities, according to a report issued on Tuesday by a commission set up to review the law.

headline: Work on Site at Trade Center Is Completed 48 Days Late
text: After incurring $14.4 million in late fees, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey completed its excavation of the site for two office towers at the World Trade Center complex on Sunday, and turned it over to Silverstein Properties, the developer.

headline: Rice, Across Its Full Spectrum
text: ANYONE who has tried black rice or a good brown basmati knows that whole-grain rice has a bad rap, largely because it takes so long to cook.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births misstated the meaning of the term “vanishing twin.” It is a miscarriage of one twin, not a fetus eliminated in a medical procedure called a reduction.

headline: Kidnapping a Theater Critic, or Every Playwright’s Dream
text: How funny is the first act of “Gray Area” at the Barrow Group Theater? So funny that at the intermission you’ll be saying to yourself, “They can’t possibly keep this up.” And you’ll be right.

headline: New $2.8 Billion Write-Down Jolts Credit Suisse
text: PARIS  Credit Suisse on Tuesday announced new write-downs of $2.8 billion that cut $1 billion from its profit, in a stunning reminder of the difficulty banks face in valuing complicated financial instruments under current market conditions.

headline: Separating the Mythology From the Raw Politics of a Senate Campaign
text: One hundred and fifty years on, the Lincoln-Douglas debates enjoy the dubious status of myth. The specific circumstances and local passions that shaped them have long been forgotten, and subsequent events  the rise of Lincoln as a towering national figure and the Civil War  make it almost mandatory to read the debates as an ominous prologue or an intellectual dress rehearsal for national tragedy.

headline: Dog Comes Home
text: For the outcast A&E bounty hunter Duane Chapman, the foreseeable future is ending. Mr. Chapman, below, familiarly known as Dog, is going back on the air in his reality show “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” the gossip Web site TMZ.com reported on Tuesday. The site said that preparations were in progress to restart production as soon as possible, although a premiere date had not been set. The series, the most successful on A&E in recent years, was suspended last fall after Mr. Chapman made racially charged comments in a private telephone conversation that was made public by The National Enquirer, which paid Mr. Chapman’s son for it. At the time, A&E announced it was stopping production “for the foreseeable future.”

headline: Bush Welcomes Castro’s Resignation
text: KIGALI, Rwanda  President Bush said Tuesday that the resignation of Fidel Castro “ought to be a period of democratic transition” for Cuba, and that the country must hold free and fair elections to pick a successor after half a century of Communist rule.

headline: Pakistan Victors Want Dialogue With Militants
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The winners of Pakistan’s parliamentary elections said Tuesday that they would take a new approach to fighting Islamic militants by pursuing more dialogue than military confrontation, and that they would undo the crackdown on the media and restore independence to the judiciary.

headline: Abbas and Olmert Struggle to Move Talks Forward
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli and Palestinian leaders met here on Tuesday amid growing dissonance over the content of their talks and the kind of agreement they are trying to achieve.

headline: Document Says Trader’s Rogue Bets Began in Summer
text: PARIS  New details about the actions of a former trader accused of making billions of dollars of unauthorized bets at the French bank Société Générale showed that he exposed the bank to a significant trading loss in July, six months earlier than the bank has acknowledged.

headline: Castro Quits One Role, but May Not Be Done Yet
text: HAVANA  Fidel Castro, bedridden for 19 months, on Tuesday gave up the almost unlimited power he has wielded in Cuba for nearly 50 years, but whether the surprise announcement represented a historic change or a symbolic political maneuver remained unclear.

headline: China Notes Pollution at Three Gorges Dam
text: HONG KONG  China’s State Environmental Protection Administration said on Tuesday that water quality is barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam and in the upper reaches of the Yangtze River, although the water does meet Chinese national standards for drinking, fisheries and swimming.

headline: Father Tells of Slaying Suspect’s Long Ordeal
text: On Saturday, shortly after the police arrested David Tarloff, he was permitted to talk on the phone with his father.

headline: Chinese Envoy to Revisit Darfur
text: HONG KONG  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China told Prime Minister Gordon Brown of Britain on Tuesday that China’s special envoy for the Darfur region, Liu Guijin, would make his fourth visit to Sudan on Sunday, China’s Foreign Ministry said.

headline: Defense Says Fetus in a Jar Shows the Fall of a Mother
text: Among the many gruesome discoveries detectives made after they entered the Brooklyn apartment where 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown was found dead more than two years ago was a jar containing a fetus on a dresser in the bedroom of the girl’s parents.

headline: With These Nutrition Bars, Every Order Is Special
text: Los Angeles

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about grief on campus after the shootings at Northern Illinois University misstated the course of study in graduate school of the gunman, Steve P. Kazmierczak. He had been a graduate student in social work at the University of Illinois  not sociology, his undergraduate major at N.I.U.

headline: Minutemen Fight Change in Highway Cleanup Site
text: SAN DIEGO  When California awarded the San Diego Minutemen, a group well known for its border monitoring in search of illegal immigrants, a permit last Nov. 21 to clean a stretch of highway including the Border Patrol checkpoint at San Onofre, complaints from immigrant advocacy groups and Hispanic lawmakers were swift and strong.

headline: More on the Jameel Poverty Action Lab
text: Click on the links below for more information on the Jameel Poverty Action Lab and studies mentioned in David Leonhardt's Economic Scene column:

headline: Kidd Really Is Traded to Dallas This Time
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Jason Kidd era officially came to an end for the Nets on Tuesday, when they completed a trade that sent Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks for a package that included the talented point guard Devin Harris.

headline: Abandoning Ship Is the Way Out for Captain Kidd
text: Nets fans should wish Jason Kidd well as he sets out on yet another expedition in search of that elusive holy grail: an N.B.A. championship.

headline: Judge Shuts Down Web Site Specializing in Leaks
text: In a move that legal experts said could present a major test of First Amendment rights in the Internet era, a federal judge in San Francisco on Friday ordered the disabling of a Web site devoted to disclosing confidential information.

headline: In Milan, a Four-Year Hunt for the Perfect Home
text: MILAN

headline: Twilight of the Dictators: A Chance for Pakistan — and the U.S.
text: After years of American enabling and billions in American aid, Pakistan’s Pervez Musharraf, was  to put it delicately  trounced in Monday’s parliamentary elections. The results are much better than the United States could hope for, and more than President Bush deserved after overinvesting in the former general and his anti-democratic excesses.

headline: In Mamet’s Political World, the One With Ideals Is Odd Woman Out
text: David Mamet’s blog promoting his Broadway comedy “November” (at novembertheplay.com) is an intriguing if half-hearted experiment. Written in the voice of the main character, a bumbling president who tries to blackmail and buy his way to re-election, the blog occasionally echoes Mr. Mamet’s 2005 Off Broadway play, “Romance,” a too-late attack on political correctness. But more often it exploits the sitcom rhythms of “November” itself. The president mistily recalls phrases his father used at the dinner table, and writes on the blog: “ ‘Stuffing the ballot box,’ I, of course, associated with Thanksgiving, and ‘voting the dead,’ with Halloween.”

headline: Raw Broccoli by Another Name
text: “HOW about sexy, spicy broccoli,” a friend suggested.

headline: Obama Extends Streak to 10, Makes Inroads Among Women
text: Senator Barack Obama decisively beat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in the Wisconsin primary and the Hawaii caucuses on Tuesday night, accelerating his momentum ahead of crucial primaries in Ohio and Texas and cutting into Mrs. Clinton’s support among women and union members.

headline: Justices Will Hear Case on Evidence Suppression
text: WASHINGTON  In theory, a criminal-law doctrine known as the exclusionary rule forbids prosecutors from using evidence obtained by the police as the result of an improper search. In practice, the rule has significant exceptions, like for evidence obtained in good faith through reliance on an invalid search warrant or as the result of erroneous information from a court official.

headline: A Pastor Begs to Differ With Flock on Miracles
text: CHIMAYO, N.M.  “It’s not the dirt that makes the miracles!” the Rev. Casimiro Roca said with exasperation.

headline: Comments Bring Wives Into Fray in Wisconsin
text: BROOKFIELD, Wis.  In the last week, Senator John McCain has increasingly been taking on Senator Barack Obama at campaign events. And now their wives seem to be entering the fray, with Cindy McCain seeming to get in a dig at Mr. Obama’s wife, Michelle.

headline: With Earnings Up 38%, H.P. Raises Its Forecast
text: SAN FRANCISCO  While some technology companies have warned of softening in the global economy, Hewlett-Packard is not seeing slowing demand in its own international business, company executives said Tuesday.

headline: It’s on to Plan B as a Hot Trend Cools Off
text: IN 2005, meal assembly shops were the hottest trend in small business, a concept taken on with gusto by mom-and-pop entrepreneurs. In storefront and shopping-center kitchens nationwide, they sold millions of uncooked entrees in freezer-ready Ziplocs and to-go tins, with stick-on instructions for boiling, simmering, baking or stir-frying the contents into quick dinners at home.

headline: Spitzer Aide Uses $30,000 From Funds
text: ALBANY  Declaring that his administration would adhere to high ethical standards, Gov. Eliot Spitzer moved in early 2007 to ban his appointees from campaigning for political office, including fund-raising and spending to promote a candidacy.

headline: Newest Restaurants Still Reflect Flush Times
text: SOMEBODY forgot to clue Daniel Boulud in to all of this recession talk. John Fraser and Ed Brown didn’t get the memo, either.

headline: One Man’s Jury Duty Is Another Man’s Inspiration to Make Choreography
text: Dancers and choreographers tend to walk through the world wondering what each empty space they see would look like filled with dance. Arthur Mitchell, the artistic director of the Dance Theater of Harlem, is not immune. Called to jury duty three years ago at State Supreme Court in Manhattan, Mr. Mitchell gazed at the elegant rotunda of the courthouse at 60 Centre Street and saw his dancers performing there.

headline: So Much Data, and So Many Ways to Guard It
text: PROTECTING the electronic re- cords of your business has gotten easier and more affordable, thanks to services that can make backups of computer files across the Internet.

headline: In Her Own Words
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, speaking on Wednesday at Hunter College in New York City, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

headline: Japan: Destroyer Hits Fishing Boat
text: A Japanese naval destroyer collided with a two-man fishing boat in waters near Tokyo, apparently slicing the smaller craft in two, Japan’s military said. No survivors from the fishing boat have been found. The authorities are investigating why the ultra-modern warship’s crew and sophisticated Aegis radar systems had not seen the fishing boat.

headline: Where to Find Some of the Good Stuff
text: AFTER tasting artisanal dairy products for the last six months, it was apparent that descriptors like artisanal, small batch, farmstead, local and grass-fed are no guarantee of great flavor. Here are some favorites:

headline: Packing Heat in the Parks
text: A sound and bipartisan public lands bill is being held up in the Senate in behalf of the gun lobby’s attempt to overturn decades-old safety regulations barring people from carrying loaded guns in national parks.

headline: Bond Insurer in Turmoil Turns to Familiar Leader
text: Joseph W. Brown Jr. got an inkling three weeks ago that retirement would have to wait. Former colleagues began calling to lament the tough times facing MBIA, the bond insurance company he used to run.

headline: Driving to the Gold Rush
text: MAGUARICHIC, Mexico  In these mountains, where conquistadors once gouged gold from open veins in the mountainside, the hardened gold miner of film lore is giving way to a new breed of prospector: geologists and engineers, armed with sophisticated equipment and millions of investor dollars.

headline: Inflation Continues to Edge Up
text: Consumer prices rose more than expected last month, the government reported on Wednesday, reinforcing concerns at the Federal Reserve that inflation still poses a threat to the American economy.

headline: Justices Make It Tougher to Sue Medical Device Makers
text: WASHINGTON  In a case with huge implications for the health care-technology industry, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that the manufacturer of a federally approved medical device cannot be sued under state law if the device causes an injury.

headline: Eat 300 and Say ‘Spherification’
text: A BARTENDER’S arsenal has looked roughly the same for a century or so. Just about any drink in the book can be whipped up with a sturdy bottle opener, a corkscrew, a long-handled bar spoon, a sharp knife and an all-purpose cocktail shaker.

headline: Chianti Steps Out of Its Straw Skirt
text: THE Chianti region in the hills of Tuscany is the spiritual home of the sangiovese grape. With its black cherry and violet aromas, its earthy mineral flavors, its lively acidity and its sometimes dusty tannins, sangiovese speaks directly from the Italian soul.

headline: Ex-Refco Chief Faces Civil Fraud Charges
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil fraud charges on Tuesday against Phillip R. Bennett, former chief executive of the commodities broker Refco Inc., days after he pleaded guilty to criminal charges in a scheme to mask the company’s financial health.

headline: They're Working on Their Own, Just Side by Side
text: SAN FRANCISCO

headline: Bank Tower Contractors Accused of 44 Violations
text: Federal safety regulators have accused the contractors who were taking down the former Deutsche Bank tower in the summer of indifference or intentional disregard for dangerous conditions that led to a fatal fire there, and of a host of other serious safety violations, officials said on Tuesday.

headline: Warehouses Nibble on Edge of Giant California Ranch
text: LEBEC, Calif.  Anyone who has traveled between Los Angeles and San Francisco along Interstate 5 has driven along the western flank of Tejon Ranch, a vast expanse of luminous oak-studded hills that divides the southern and central portions of the state.

headline: Trial of 2 Ex-Officials in Iraq Is Delayed as Witnesses Fail to Show
text: BAGHDAD  The trial of two former government officials widely seen as a test of the impartiality of Iraq’s judicial system got off to an inauspicious start on Tuesday when it was delayed because crucial witnesses failed to appear.

headline: No. 5 Rutgers Struggles Early, but Finishes Strong
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  The Rutgers women’s basketball team is hardly a free-flowing group to begin with, but Notre Dame made it even harder for the fifth-ranked Scarlet Knights to find their way to the basket Tuesday night, forcing them to think hard about every pass.

headline: U.S. Ponders Next Steps in Pakistan After Election Results
text: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration was scrambling Tuesday to pick up the pieces of its shattered Pakistan policy after the trouncing that the party of President Bush’s ally, President Pervez Musharraf, received in parliamentary elections.

headline: Stolen Art on Display in a Search for Owners
text: JERUSALEM  In a remarkable feat of cooperation between France and Israel, requiring intensive negotiations and the passage of a law by the Israeli Parliament, the Israel Museum here has opened an exhibition of important art looted by the Nazis from France and then returned after the war. Some of it was never reclaimed, presumably because the owners were killed in the Holocaust.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a dance entry on Sunday in the Week Ahead report in Arts & Leisure misstated the date of Fluid hug-hug’s final performance at the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival. The troupe’s final performance was Sunday; it is not this Sunday.

headline: Inspiration Strikes Only a Desk Away
text: ONE of the most frequently cited advantages of coworking is the cross pollination that takes place. People share ideas rather than actually drum up business.

headline: Celebrity Chef Sells His TV Shows and Products to Martha Stewart
text: Is there room in the well-appointed house of Martha for another larger-than-life name brand?

headline: Hospital’s Accounting Is Under Fire by a Union
text: A union is trying to force nonprofit groups like hospitals to comply with standards of governing similar to those that federal law requires of private companies.

headline: Tax Inquiry? Principality Is Offended
text: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  It’s not exactly the “mouse that roared,” though maybe the mouse that resisted.

headline: Fed Sharply Reduces Forecast for Growth
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, for all its power, faces tough new limits on its ability to keep the economy out of a recession this year.

headline: A Window Into Druse Cooking
text: IN the day you may spy Gazala Halabi in the window of her four-month-old restaurant, making Druse pita on a sagg, a griddle that looks like an overturned wok. By dinnertime the pita is made and Mrs. Halabi is at work in the open kitchen at the back of the 18-seat space, meticulously composing appetizer platters and tending to baskets of falafel in the deep fryer.

headline: Actions Considered Insane Often Don’t Meet the Standards of New York’s Legal System
text: A diagnosis of schizophrenia and repeated commitments to mental institutions might seem like obvious qualifications for an insanity defense  or maybe not.

headline: In His Own Words
text: Senator Barack Obama, speaking on Wednesday afternoon at a rally in the Reunion Arena in Dallas, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.

headline: Task of Shooting Down Satellite Begins
text: WASHINGTON  The many moving parts of a mission to shoot down a dying spy satellite with an anti-missile interceptor lined up Wednesday after the space shuttle Atlantis returned to Earth, officials said.

headline: OTB Unanimously Approves Plan for a Shutdown in June
text: With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sitting beside them, the board members of the nation’s largest legal off-track betting operation voted Tuesday to shut down by mid-June, a plan that would close more than 60 neighborhood betting parlors and idle nearly 1,500 workers.

headline: Microsoft Said to Plan Proxy Fight for Yahoo
text: Microsoft has begun to make preparations to proceed with a proxy fight against Yahoo as it seeks to gain control of the Internet company, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

headline: Ex-Patriots Employee Key Factor in Spy Case
text: Despite Coach Bill Belichick and the Patriots re-entering the public-relations quagmire of the spy saga, deciphering the depth and breadth of their electronic taping habits still largely rests with a former video assistant being prodded to talk from several angles.

headline: Jon Stewart, Hands Long Tied by Strike, Pedals Fast for Oscars
text: LOS ANGELES  In the bowels of the Kodak Theater, one floor below the auditorium where the elaborate set for the Academy Awards telecast on Sunday was already in place, Jon Stewart, unshaved and wearing Army boots, was sitting in his modest dressing room, just back from the latest planning session with his writing team.

headline: Guess How Tooth Fairy Gets Her Cash
text: Imagine you’re a playwright given the assignment of writing about the lives of sex workers. Should you titillate? Enlighten? Put corrupt society under a microscope?

headline: Small Online Contributions Add Up to Huge Fund-Raising Edge for Obama
text: CHICAGO  A cluster of cramped cubicles, tucked away in a rear corner of Senator Barack Obama’s campaign headquarters here, serves as the heart of a fund-raising machine that has reshaped the calculus of the 2008 election.

headline: Sears Case Cited by Critics of Safety Panel
text: WASHINGTON  In an effort to pressure lawmakers to toughen legislation on consumer product safety, consumer groups this week began publicizing the recent settlement of a major lawsuit against Sears for installing millions of kitchen ranges that were vulnerable to tipping over.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart on Sunday listing Democratic superdelegates who are supporting a candidate other than the one who won their state or Congressional district erroneously included Representative Bill Pascrell Jr. of New Jersey, a superdelegate who supports Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Mr. Pascrell’s district was won by Mrs. Clinton, not by Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Attack Iran, With Words
text: Prague

headline: O’Neal Brings Hope and Disquiet to the Valley of the Sun
text: PHOENIX  The Phoenix Suns plumped up their middle by adding center Shaquille O’Neal, to the mortification of many denizens of this city who pride themselves on not being superficial. This Botoxing of the Suns’ starting lineup has launched a thousand scowls, the general sentiment being that it is foolish to risk losing the expressiveness of the Suns’ offense simply to keep up appearances in the bulked-up Western Conference.

headline: Positive Government: A Republican About-Face?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Toshiba Concedes Defeat in the DVD Battle
text: TOKYO  The biggest consumer electronic format war in a generation is officially over.

headline: Girardi Hopes He’s Seen as Prepared and Caring
text: TAMPA, Fla.  For most of his 12-year stint as manager of the Yankees, Joe Torre made an opening speech to his players that became reasonably predictable: play hard, show up on time. Other maxims in the Torre Rule Book were little more than an index card.

headline: Not the Price of Doing Business
text: Most contributors to political campaigns are probably unaware that their money, under federal and state laws, can be used for all sorts of purposes. It can be channeled to other candidates, stored away for a future campaign or spent on unrelated expenses. A prominent New Jersey politician recently tried to use campaign funds to pay his defense lawyers. The state’s election officials were right to turn him down.

headline: Pairings: Lentils With Merguez
text: YEARS ago, when the dollar was stronger and the choices in wine shops fewer, Chianti Classico was the all-purpose wine, served with everything from spaghetti to steak. Even today, an unpretentious bottle of Chianti Classico, with its plummy fruit, good acidity and depth of flavor reminiscent of dried tomato, can stake a claim to an array of dishes.

headline: Angry Serbs Burn Border Posts in Kosovo
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Serbs set fire to two United Nations border posts in the north of Kosovo on Tuesday, forcing NATO troops to intervene and fanning fears that the Serbian-dominated north could boil over into violence and lead to the partition of the newborn country.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Monday about President Bush’s role in Senator John McCain’s presidential campaign referred incorrectly to the campaign position of Mercer Reynolds, a Cincinnati businessman. As a national finance co-chairman, Mr. Reynolds is one of several people raising money for Mr. McCain; he is not leading the fund-raising effort. (That position is held by former Representative Tom Loeffler of Texas, the national finance chairman.)

headline: Wealth Gap Growing Bigger Among American Colleges
text: Stanford University had an exceptional year for fund-raising in 2007, collecting $832 million in private donations. Harvard, too, reaped a bounty, with $614 million in gifts.

headline: On Havana’s Streets, Few Expect Much Change
text: Despite looming large over the Cuban people for half a century, engineering their lives down to the city block and barraging them with his innermost thoughts in speeches and essays that went on ad infinitum, Fidel Castro elicited a rather muted reaction on the streets of Havana on Tuesday with his decision to finally stand down as president.

headline: Gunman Hid His Tracks, Officials Say
text: CHICAGO  The man who killed five students at Northern Illinois University in DeKalb and himself on Thursday took steps to hide his tracks and conceal his motive, the police said Tuesday.

headline: Go on, Leave Your Job
text: FOR those who have started their own business or are thinking of doing so, there’s inspiration, comfort, camaraderie  as well as nitty-gritty advice  online. Dozens of blogs offer small-business owners and entrepreneurs free start-up tips and business advice  much of it drawn from their creators’ experiences.

headline: What Does Simplicity Mean? It’s Complicated
text: Milan

headline: Salem Girls Gone Wild, Townsfolk Gone Irrational
text: The thought of facing “The Crucible,” especially on a raw February night, can be fatiguing. All those righteous and base emotions, those Salem girls gone wild, those chilling New England interiors  it’s not easy, as an artist or an audience member, to go head to head with Arthur Miller’s cruelly magnificent play.

headline: Shuttle Lands Safely in Florida
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  The space shuttle Atlantis, after successfully delivering a major new section to the International Space Station, glided home for a landing at the Kennedy Space Center on Wednesday, announcing its arrival moments before with twin sonic booms.

headline: New Directors Festival Picks Opening Film
text: “Frozen River,” which won the grand jury prize at the 2008 Sundance Film Festival, will open the 37th New Directors/New Films series, from March 26 through April 9 in New York at the Walter Reade Theater and the Museum of Modern Art. Starring Melissa Leo, far right, and Misty Upham, near right, “Frozen River,” directed by Courtney Hunt, is the story of two women in upstate New York  one recently left with two sons to rear, the other a widow on a Mohawk reservation  who become partners in smuggling illegal immigrants from Canada into the United States.

headline: Auctions Yield Chaos for Bonds
text: As municipal bond auctions continue to fail  and to produce very odd interest rates when they succeed  it is becoming clear that the auction-rate market is in crisis and chaos, and many securities may never have a successful auction again.

headline: An Author Looks Beyond Age Limits
text: Three years ago James Patterson, the creator of the blockbuster best-selling Alex Cross and “Women’s Murder Club” series, began “Maximum Ride,” a series for young adults about a group of genetically mutated kids who are part human, part bird. The idea, he said, was to get children to love reading  or at least to love reading his kind of books.

headline: Ex-Official in Russia Is Convicted of Aid Theft
text: MOSCOW  Russia’s former nuclear energy minister, who has been charged in the United States with stealing $9 million in American aid intended to improve Russia’s nuclear security, was found guilty in a Moscow court on Tuesday of embezzlement and abuse of office.

headline: Japanese Destroyer Strikes Fishing Boat
text: TOKYO  A Japanese Aegis destroyer ran into a two-man fishing boat on Tuesday in waters near Tokyo, apparently slicing the smaller craft in two, Japan’s Self-Defense Forces said.

headline: Justices Say 401(k) Participants Can Sue
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously upheld the right of participants in 401(k) retirement plans to sue in an attempt to recover losses if they think their accounts have been mishandled.

headline: Court Rejects Suit on Faulty Medical Device
text: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Supreme Court on Wednesday made it harder for consumers to sue manufacturers of federally approved medical devices.

headline: Reporter Held in Contempt in Anthrax Case
text: WASHINGTON  A federal judge found a former reporter for USA Today in contempt of court on Tuesday for refusing to name her confidential sources who had discussed a former Army scientist’s possible role in the 2001 anthrax attacks.

headline: Ethan Coen to Have a Return Engagement
text: Sold out in January before its first preview at the Atlantic Theater Company’s Stage 2, Ethan Coen’s “Almost an Evening,” which recently closed, is headed for a second life at the Bleecker Street Theater. Its three short works, which constituted Mr. Coen’s debut as a playwright, is to open in previews on March 20 for a run through June 1 at the theater, at 45 Bleecker Street, between Lafayette and Mott Streets, Greenwich Village.

headline: Corrections
text: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie  as a United States attorney  awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christie’s former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract.

headline: After Wins, Obama Is Focus of McCain and Clinton
text: The Democratic contenders on Wednesday both focused their campaigns on Texas, which has emerged as a critical race for the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Toshiba Concedes Defeat in the DVD Battle
text: TOKYO  The biggest consumer electronic format war in a generation is officially over.

headline: Games Pay Off for NBC
text: The combination of “Deal or No Deal” and the new game show “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad” lifted NBC to a solid No. 1 finish in the ratings on Monday. Nielsen estimated that the new series, which pits father-child teams against one another, attracted 9.8 million viewers at 9 p.m., a respectable showing, but far less than the 16.9 million who tuned in for “Deal or No Deal” at 8 p.m. Opposite the game shows, however, the finale of ABC’s “Dance War” averaged 9.1 million viewers while earning the show’s lowest ratings among adults 18 to 49. ABC ranked fourth over all, trailing with “October Road” (4.4 million) at 10 p.m. behind NBC’s “Medium” (8.5 million) and CBS’s “CSI: Miami” repeat (9.6 million). CBS finished second for the night behind NBC, but third among adults 18 to 49, behind NBC and Fox, which got a boost in that demographic from the finale of “Prison Break” at 8 (7.4 million) and “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” at 9 (8.1 million). On Sunday NBC’s “Knight Rider” (12.7 million) drew the highest ratings in the 18-to-49 age group for a made-for-television movie on any network in almost three years.

headline: Lacking Cure, a New Tack on a Muscle Disease
text: For more than four decades, on telethons featuring celebrity performers and children in wheelchairs, Jerry Lewis has been raising money each Labor Day for the Muscular Dystrophy Association and the disease that helped make “poster child” part of the American idiom.

headline: Supply Fears Push Oil to Triple Digits
text: HOUSTON  Crude oil closed above $100 a barrel for the first time Tuesday, vaulting through a longstanding psychological barrier amid persistent concern about whether production can keep up with rising global demand.

headline: Reread ‘Gatsby’: The Dream Was Hollow
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Pakistan, Musharraf’s Party Accepts Defeat
text: LAHORE, Pakistan  Pakistan appeared on Tuesday to be heading for a transition to an elected civilian government after President Pervez Musharraf told visiting United States senators that he accepted the resounding defeat of his party in elections and would work with a new Parliament.

headline: Church Choir Director Hired a Pedophile, Prosecutors Say
text: NEW HAVEN (AP)  A former music director at a prominent Greenwich church who was convicted of possessing child pornography hired a pedophile and failed to tell the authorities when that man sexually assaulted a choirboy, prosecutors disclosed on Tuesday.

headline: In Newark, Children Reclaim a Playground’s Meaning
text: NEWARK  To cover the littered lake of cracked asphalt, the students suggested gardens. For the darkest corners of the schoolyard, they asked for new playgrounds, safe and bathed in light.

headline: Some Tweaks Bring Success
text: AS the mother of three small children, Missy Carr loved the meal assembly concept. Go to a store, use its recipes and raw ingredients to prepare meals and cart home a bunch of dinners that could be cooked with a toddler hanging on your leg. In May 2006, Ms. Carr, a trained chef who once owned a catering business, opened Thyme Out in Gaithersburg, Md., on her own.

headline: To Catch a Thief
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Making the Breakup Much Easier
text: MICHAEL AYOUB was an experienced chef and restaurateur when a Brooklyn business owner enlisted his help in 1988 to turn around a struggling catering company. In exchange for his sweat equity, Mr. Ayoub would acquire a one-third interest and be an equal partner with the founder and his daughter.

headline: Politics Through an Orwellian Lens
text: To the Editor:

headline: Natalia Bessmertnova, Ballerina of Innate Lyricism, Dies at 66
text: Natalia Bessmertnova, a ballerina with the Bolshoi Ballet known for her lightness, delicacy and Romantic style, died on Tuesday in Moscow. She was 66.

headline: Angler Who Can Make His Line Dance, Too
text: ANDERSON, S.C.  The bass fisherman Skeet Reese rolls into the marina parking lot pulling a boat while bumping to hip-hop on his iPod. His truck is an eccentric size that holds 214 gallons of fuel and requires a climb to the door handle.

headline: Telecommuters Cry ‘Ouch’ to the Tax Gods
text: TENS of thousands of telecommuters are receiving tax bills from states where they do not live, do not vote and do not use local services like schools.

headline: Twilight of the Dictators: And a Chance for Cuba — and the U.S.
text: It was age and illness, not the free voice of the Cuban people, that finally led Fidel Castro to announce Tuesday that he is stepping down as Cuba’s president  after a mere 49 years of absolute power. Mr. Castro’s immediate successor is likely to be his 76-year-old younger brother Raúl. Still, the post-Fidel era is clearly at hand, and the Bush administration has done almost nothing to prepare for it.

headline: Recipe: Panthay Noodles
text: Adapted from Irene Khin Wong, Saffron 59

headline: 2 More Indictments in Tax Shelter Case
text: Federal prosecutors have widened their criminal case involving questionable tax shelters at the accounting firm Ernst & Young, adding two outside defendants.

headline: A New Role for Bollywood's Bardot
text: Mallika Sherawat, above, the actress known in some circles as Bollywood’s Bardot, has been cast as an ascetic who befriends Jesus of Nazareth in “The Aquarian Gospel,” a Hollywood film based on the legend that Jesus visited India, Reuters reported. The $15 million film, directed by Drew Heriot, deals with the life of Jesus between the ages of 13 and 30, a period not documented in the Gospels, when some believe he journeyed through India, Tibet and Persia. In a statement released by her press agent, Ms. Sherawat, whose 17 kissing scenes in her Bollywood debut, “Khwahish,” created a stir, said: “I find that in most mythological and spiritual film stories, women seem to be lacking any true wisdom or a sense of humor. I look forward to bringing both of those qualities to this character.”

headline: A Warm Welcome Helps Pettitte Get Back to Work

headline: China: Water Quality Worsens Near Three Gorges Dam
text: The Environmental Protection Administration said water quality was barely improving in the main body of water behind the Three Gorges Dam and in the upper reaches of the Yangtze, although the water does meet national standards for drinking, fisheries and swimming. Water quality is worsening in several branches of the Yangtze that drain into the main reservoir, the agency said in a water management plan, echoing previous government documents. The dam has slowed the flow of the Yangtze, and that reduces the ability of the river and its tributaries to flush out polluted areas.

headline: First Film Festival in Saudi Arabia
text: Saudi Arabia, where movie theaters are banned, has something new to look forward to, Agence France-Presse reported, citing the English-language newspaper Arab News: its first official film festival. On May 20 a five-day competition underwritten by the government will feature films from Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf and Arab states. Planned as an annual event and including the participation of film critics from the region for the first time, the festival will take place in the eastern city of Damman under the auspices of the Damman Literary Club and the Saudi Society of Arts and Culture. Films were exhibited in private clubs in Saudi Arabia until all public screenings were banned in the early 1980s on the ground that they contravened Islamic law. Nevertheless, cafes in main cities show films, sports and video clips on large-screen televisions.

headline: Corrections

It has written down $1.2 billion, not $13.7 billion, and it earned 1.33 billion Swiss francs in the fourth quarter  it did not lose 12.5 billion Swiss francs. The article also misstated the date of the earnings report. It was Feb. 12, not Thursday. (The figures cited were for another large Swiss Bank, UBS.)

headline: Supreme Court in Japan Upholds Mapplethorpe
text: The Supreme Court of Japan on Tuesday overruled a 2003 Tokyo High Court decision and decided that “Mapplethorpe,” a book of erotic photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe (1946-89), shown at right in a self-portrait, did not violate obscenity laws, The Associated Press reported. The decision should pave the way for sale of the book in Japan for the first time in eight years. Although it decided that the book was not indecent, the Supreme Court rejected a demand by the publisher, Uplink, for government compensation of $20,370, according to Takashi Ando, a spokesman for the court. Takashi Asai of Uplink had been contesting the confiscation of the book in 1999 and his voluntary suspension of its sales in 2000 in response to police warnings. In the Supreme Court decision, by a majority of the five-judge bench, Justice Kohei Nasu wrote that the 384-page volume of black-and-white portraits, including 20 close-ups of male genitalia, “compiles work from the artistic point of view, and is not obscene as a whole.” Mr. Asai sold about 900 copies of the Japanese version of “Mapplethorpe,” originally published in Japan by Random House in 1994 without objection from the authorities. But airport customs officials, declaring the book obscene, confiscated Mr. Asai’s copy when he returned from a trip to the United States in 1999. He called the Supreme Court decision “groundbreaking” and said it “could change the obscenity standard” used for banning foreign films that depict nudity and for censoring photographs in books.

headline: Video Intensifies Abortion Debate in Albany

Republicans will try to hold on to their thin margin in the Senate, their last bastion of power in Albany, but strong turnout for the presidential election could aid Democratic efforts to take control of the entire Legislature for the first time in decades.

(After Sidney), Malkin has 11 goals, 16 assists and 27 points. That’s Martn Straka’s point total in 45 games.

headline: Bronx Landlord Is Jailed for Code Violations

headline: Ryan Giggs’s European Century
text: Only eight players have reached the century mark in Europe’s top club competition. And Manchester United’s dynamic Welshman Ryan Giggs is now one of them. He started the team’s European Champions League match Wednesday against Lyon, notching his 100th appearance in UEFA’s top club competition.

headline: Men in Chadors
text: Fareed Zakaria’s forthcoming book, “The Post-American World,” tackles big issues – globalization, the rise of China and India, the decline of American hegemony – sometimes by looking at small facts. In a couple of pages, Zakaria discusses the relationship between modernity and clothing, particularly women’s clothing. “Not surprisingly,” he writes, “the Muslim world has the biggest problems with its women wearing Western-style clothes. It is also the region where women remain the farthest behind by any objective yardstick.” Zakaria has less to say about men’s styles, but the connections he draws between politics and clothes made me think of a photograph of one of the Republican presidential debates that appeared in The New York Times last December.

headline: McCain’s Campaign Cash Totals
text: By the end of January, Senator John McCain, who had struggled all of last year in raising money, brought in $11.7 million in contributions, close to the most he had ever raised in a three-month span previously, as Republican donors jumped on his bandwagon, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Professor in Noose Case Is Cited for Plagiarism
text: Updated, 5:18 p.m. | A Columbia University professor who was the apparent target of a hate crime last October, when a noose was left on her office door, has been sanctioned for plagiarism, university officials confirmed today. The plagiarism investigation of the professor, Madonna G. Constantine of Teachers College, was reported today by The Columbia Spectator. This afternoon, she called the investigation “biased and flawed” and accused the university of a “witch hunt.”

headline: How the West Was Lost?
text: “For Democrats, 2008 was supposed to be the year of the Mountain West, when three years of relentless Republican attacks on undocumented immigrants would fuel a backlash among Hispanics that would change the playing field in Arizona, Colorado, Nevada and New Mexico, and perhaps alter the landscape of presidential politics for a generation,” reports The Washington Post’s Jonathan Weisman. “But the emergence of Sen. John McCain (Ariz.) as the likely standard-bearer for the G.O.P. may have scrambled the equation, cooling a potential political revolt among Hispanics and sending Democrats in search of a new playbook.”

headline: The Discouraging End of the Larry Craig Case

headline: In Mortgage Crisis, Church Offers Financial Counseling
text: With Brooklyn and Queens accounting for 40 percent of New York State’s home foreclosures last year, pastors in Catholic churches in the two boroughs started seeing a sharp rise in parishioners with mortgage problems last fall.As a result, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn has put together the largest coordinated financial counseling effort since the Sept. 11 terror attacks, focusing on the most vulnerable neighborhoods, in eastern Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: Blu-ray Won the Battle. Now Comes the War
text: There is a concept rattling around the blogosphere that Sony’s victory over Toshiba in the war to define the high-definition video disc format is moot because soon people will be downloading high-definition videos rather than buying them on discs.

headline: Two New Jersey Superdelegates Now Back Obama
text: Senator Barack Obama’s resounding victory in Wisconsin on Tuesday echoed in New Jersey today, where he won the backing of two additional superdelegates, including one who had previously declared for his opponent, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.One of the superdelegates, State Senator Dana Redd, who had backed Mrs. Clinton, said she switched because Mr. Obama’s growing support had convinced her that he was the best choice to win the general election and lead effectively as president.

headline: Maybe They Don’t Want to Change
text: With Michelle Obama’s remarks about finally being “really proud” of America having set off a mini-firestorm, a speech she gave at U.C.L.A. in early February is coming under renewed scrutiny. The conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt has audio here, and the passage that has him and others riled up comes at the 8:40 mark: “Barack Obama will require you to work. He is going to demand that you shed your cynicism. That you put down your divisions. That you come out of your isolation, that you move out of your comfort zones. That you push yourselves to be better. And that you engage. Barack will never allow you to go back to your lives as usual, uninvolved, uninformed.”

headline: 3Com: A Failure to Communicate
text: The pending 3Com acquisition on Wednesday joined the Alliance Data Services transaction in regulatory limbo. 3Com announced that it and its agreed buyers, Bain Capital and Huawei Technologies, had withdrawn their application for clearance of the acquisition under Congress’ Exon-Florio provision.

text: PARIS — A group of spiky-haired teenagers and a small crowd of tourists cracked up as I drove past them in the center of Paris. They had a good reason; I was behind the wheel of an Aixam Scouty R, a two-seater city car built in France.

headline: Lawsuit Over Police Press Passes
text: The Police Department has faced some recent complaints over how it decides to issue press credentials for journalists. Now it is facing a lawsuit from the New York Civil Liberties Union, which is seeking information about the department’s press pass policy.Last year, Rafael Martínez Alequin, a City Hall gadfly who writes about city government for his personal Web site, said he had been denied a press pass because of the often critical questions he poses to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Jury Duty: It Came. It Went. I Served.
text: After all my anticipation and anxiety, jury duty came and went in a flash. Day 1 was interesting. And short. I arrived at 60 Centre Street at 8:45 a.m. along with throngs of fellow citizens and took my seat. The clerks who run the jury process — two women so polished they could play their roles in “Jury Duty, the Movie” — began orientation with a list of rules. They sprinkled their instructions with more than a few well-placed one-liners. “Do not remove any articles of clothing below the waist.” “Never put your face to the water-fountain fixture. We have cups.” “Never abandon your possessions; we have had thefts.” My neighbor leaned in and whispered to me, “If they say it, it’s happened.” We bonded. She agreed to be the trusted buddy whom Clerk #1 advised us to find, available to watch my possessions should I need to use the restroom. I offered the same back.

headline: For Advertisers, The Countdown To The 2009 Super Bowl Has Begun

headline: The Indian in the Attic
text: Several readers have pointed out the importance of Johnna, the Cheyenne woman whom Beverly hires to keep house at the beginning of the play — and in whose arms Violet takes comfort at its very end. Since we get to know the Westons through their pathologies and their acid tongues, it’s easy to ignore the other woman in the house: she’s kind to everyone, stays in the background and is all but mute in most of her scenes. But, as Paul Gambaccini points out in a comment, she is essential to the symmetry of the play. In the prologue, Beverly quotes T.S. Eliot’s poem “The Hollow Men” to her: “Life is very long.” And in that final scene, when Violet has finally driven the last of her daughters away, Johnna sings to her from the last lines of the same poem: “This is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends, this is the way the world ends.” (Eliot’s punchline, not spoken in the play but entirely relevant: “Not with a bang but a whimper.”)

Two seasons after George Mason’s magical run to the Final Four and one year after Virginia Commonwealth beat Duke in the N.C.A.A. tournament, one of the most formidable mid-major leagues looks like it could receive only one bid for the tournament field.

text: ACCRA, Ghana  Traveling across Africa this week, President Bush has been a little like Santa Claus, a benevolent figure from another land handing out gifts  American foreign aid  and generating smiles wherever he goes.

headline: Shuttle Lands, Clearing Skies for Pentagon
text: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla.  After a challenging 13-day mission that delivered a major new section to the International Space Station, the space shuttle Atlantis glided home Wednesday for a landing at the Kennedy Space Center, announcing its arrival with twin sonic booms.

text: MEXICO CITY  Investigators have determined that a man linked to drug traffickers was trying to plant a bomb in a police official’s car when it blew up and killed him on a busy avenue here last week, the city’s attorney general said.

headline: A Private Matter in the Backyard
text: I WANTED to build a cottage in our backyard. The problem was my wife. I had to do it before she noticed.

headline: Opposition in Kenya Threatens More Protests
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya’s leading opposition party on Wednesday accused the government of stonewalling in negotiations to resolve the country’s festering political crisis and threatened to resume protests if a power-sharing agreement was not reached within a week.

headline: Mammals Misbehaving, and Agonized Farewells
text: Cynics and conspiracy theorists might have suspected a hidden agenda in a concert presented by the Da Capo Chamber Players at Merkin Concert Hall on Tuesday night. The group, an accomplished instrumental quintet, augmented by many guests, offered four vocal pieces. Three featured poems by Dana Gioia, who also happens to be the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts.

headline: The People’s Questions
text: Tonight, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate in Texas. What should the professional questioners ask the Democratic candidates? Many, many more terrific (and funny and pointed) suggestions can be found at nytimes.com/campaignstops.

headline: The Biggest Beef Recall Ever
text: A nauseating video of cows stumbling on their way to a California slaughterhouse has finally prompted action: the largest recall of meat in American history. Westland/Hallmark Meat Company has issued a full recall of more than 143 million pounds of beef produced over the last two years, including 37 million pounds that went to school-lunch programs.

text: Larry Davis, the Bronx man who became a hero to some and pariah to others after waging a shootout with a group of police officers who sought to arrest him for murdering rival drug dealers, was killed in a prison-yard fight on Wednesday, the State Department of Corrections said.

headline: Spirits That Fly High While Rooted in Tradition
text: There is a photograph in the program for the Nrityagram Dance Ensemble, which opened at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night, that says a great deal about this unusual Indian dance troupe.

text: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawrence Lessig, the Web legal scholar, said Wednesday that he was mulling a campaign for the House of Representatives, a move that could pit the Internet icon in a race against a Democratic loyalist.

headline: Top Court Allows Suit Over 401(k)
text: WASHINGTON  Participants in 401(k) retirement plans can sue to recover losses when their investment instructions are ignored or the account is otherwise mishandled, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

text: FRANKFURT  Dresdner Bank said on Thursday that it would bail out its vehicle for investing in complex financial products, the latest bank to take the step to avoid a forced sale of assets into turbulent financial markets.

headline: Work to Begin on Platform Over Tracks on the West Side
text: Despite a flagging economy, Brookfield Properties says it will start work in June on a $600 million platform over railroad tracks near Ninth Avenue, where it plans to build two towering office buildings.

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting Rid of That Nagging Balloon
text: If you’re tired of Windows XP nagging you to clean up unused icons from your desktop, you can pop that little yellow balloon for good. Right-click on the desktop and select Properties. Click the Desktop tab and then the Customize Desktop button. In the resulting Desktop Items box, remove the check next to “Run Desktop Cleanup Wizard every 60 days” and click the O.K. button.

headline: Files for Suicide Bombers Show No Down Syndrome
text: BAGHDAD  Psychiatric case files of two female suicide bombers who killed nearly 100 people in Baghdad this month show that they suffered from depression and schizophrenia but do not contain information indicating they had Down syndrome, American officials said Wednesday.

headline: Valentín Wants Chance to Make a Difference
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The way Jerry Manuel remembers it, José Valentín had been a member of the Chicago White Sox for a little more than a month when, during a spring training meeting in February 2000, he got up from his chair and shared a few thoughts.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Tuesday about the opening concert in the Meredith Monk/Multi-Musics series, at Symphony Space, gave the wrong date for the next performance. It is today, not next Thursday. The phone number for information is (212) 864-5400.

headline: For the Record
text: A letter on Tuesday by Doug Hostetter about Iran carried an incorrect dateline. It is Valley Cottage, N.Y., not Cottage.

headline: A Big-Screen TV That’s Not Even 2 Inches Thick
text: L.C.D. televisions are all alike, right? A bright screen, some input ports and a power button are all you need. In an effort to mix things up, LG decided to make their latest sets superslim and designer-friendly.

headline: Don’t Step on My Steel-Toed Shoes
text: IF you think presidential candidates mix their messages as they move between blue-collar and white-collar worlds, look at men’s fashion. Many mass-market clothes try to convey class, even as some designer clothes work hard to suggest that the men wearing them do the same. Ponder, for example, that Ralph Lauren’s Polo line, reeking of upper-class British life, is less expensive and more available than RRL, his vintage-ranch-hand line.

headline: Paying Patients Test British Health Care System
text: LONDON  Created 60 years ago as a cornerstone of the British welfare state, the National Health Service is devoted to the principle of free medical care for everyone. But recently it has been wrestling with a problem its founders never anticipated: how to handle patients with complex illnesses who want to pay for parts of their treatment while receiving the rest free from the health service.

headline: Britain: Bank Drops Rescue of Fund
text: The British bank Standard Chartered said it had abandoned a plan to rescue its $7 billion structured investment vehicle, Whistlejacket, which was placed into receivership last week and failed to make a debt payment due on Friday. Standard Chartered said it had withdrawn conditional proposals to rescue Whistlejacket because of a number of factors, including ”the pace of continuing deterioration in the market for certain asset classes and the impracticality of completing any proposal within the confines of the receivership as it has evolved.” .

headline: The Amber Room at Last?
text: Could it be that more than 60 years after the end of World War II, the Amber Room has been found? Long-lost amber panels backed with gold leaf were stolen by the Nazis from the Soviet Union during the war. Now it appears they may lie in a man-made cavern 60 feet underground near the village of Deutschneudorf on the German border with the Czech Republic, Spiegel Online International reported. The Amber Room, below, created by German and Russian craftsmen, was a gift from King Friedrich Wilhelm I of Prussia to his ally Czar Peter the Great of Russia in 1716. The possible discovery of an estimated two tons of gold was made over the weekend when electromagnetic pulse measurements found the cavern near a long-abandoned railway station. Heinz-Peter Haustein, the mayor of Deutschneudorf and a member of Parliament who led the search, said, “I’m well over 90 percent sure we have found the Amber Room.”

headline: In All Corners, the Sons of Drago
text: Wladimir Klitschko of Ukraine fights Sultan Ibragimov of Russia on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden to unify the heavyweight championship, or at least the shares that aren’t held by Oleg Maskaev, another Russian, and Ruslan Chagaev of Uzbekistan.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about a design flaw in the Ares I, the rocket NASA plans to use to replace the space shuttle, misstated the process by which a solid-fuel rocket burns its fuel. It burns outward from the center of its cylindrical core, not from bottom to top.

headline: The Bride Wore Very Little
text: THE gown was almost wanton  fluid but curvy with a neckline that plummeted dangerously. “It makes me feel sexy and beautiful,” said Natasha DaSilva, who slipped it on for a fitting last week.

headline: Missile Strikes a Spy Satellite Falling From Its Orbit
text: WASHINGTON  A missile interceptor launched from a Navy warship has struck a dying American spy satellite orbiting 130 miles over the Pacific Ocean, the Pentagon announced late Wednesday.

headline: Unpopular Findings
text: "Baseball Prospectus," the annual handbook of major league statistics, prides itself on including a heavy dose of counterintuitive thinking. Steven Goldman, an editor of this year's edition, which comes out Monday, described it as "the antidote to Joe Morgan" -- the Hall of Fame player whose game analysis supplies regular fodder for those following new statistical measurements.

headline: Distorted Photos on a Wide Screen
text: Q. Since switching to a widescreen computer monitor, all my photos are horizontally distorted, making people look wider and shorter. Is there a way I can adjust the screen image to properly display the pictures?

headline: French Bank Says Its Controls Failed for 2 Years
text: PARIS  A rogue trader at Société Générale, Jérôme Kerviel, began making unauthorized transactions beginning in 2005, and lapses in the bank’s internal controls allowed the trades to go undiscovered until January, according to a preliminary report released Wednesday.

headline: Rising Inflation Limits the Fed as Growth Lags
text: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, for all its power, faces tough new limits on its ability to keep the economy out of a recession.

headline: Bronx Landlord Fined and Sentenced to 9 Days in Jail for Code Violations
text: A Bronx landlord, Hamid Khan, was sentenced to nine days in jail and fined $156,000 for failing to correct more than a thousand housing code violations in the 94-unit, 6-story building he owns at 1055 Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard, the city’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development said on Wednesday.

headline: Obama, Drawing Criticism on Two Fronts, Fires Back
text: DALLAS  Coming off a decisive string of victories, Senator Barack Obama pushed back against attacks by his political rivals Wednesday as the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination entered a combative and critical two-week period.

headline: Guilty Plea in Refco Fraud Case
text: Robert C. Trosten, the former finance chief at the futures trader Refco Inc., pleaded guilty on Wednesday to helping hide hundreds of millions of dollars in debt.

headline: You Could Look It Up
text: MY bible for rejuvenating plants is “Making More Plants: The Science, Art and Joy of Propagation” by Ken Druse (Clarkson Potter, 2000). I also use Google and have turned up countless Web sites with helpful articles and photographs (for close-ups of rare plants, insects and diseases, you might try images.google.com).

headline: At a Knockout Teams Event, a Master-Point Milestone
text: Last weekend in Hilton Head, S.C., Michael Passell of Las Vegas became the second player to accumulate 60,000 master points. (The first was Paul Soloway, who died three months ago with 65,511.92 points.) Passell, 60, reached the milestone while winning the Friday-Saturday Knockout Teams at the Low Country Classic Regional with Carolyn Lynch of Scottsdale, Ariz.; David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

headline: Columbia Cites Plagiarism by a Professor
text: A professor at Columbia University’s Teachers College who was propelled into the national spotlight when a noose was found on her office door last fall has been found to have plagiarized the work of a former colleague and two former students, the college has announced.

headline: Correction: Critical Shopper | Carrots
text: The Critical Shopper column on Dec. 27, about Carrots, a boutique in San Francisco, misspelled part of the name of a brand of dresses sold there. It is Helmut Lang, not Helmet. A reader pointed out the error in e-mail message last week.
