headline: Footnotes
text: Viacom’s BET Networks will make their debut in Britain on Feb. 28, carrying American series like “106 & Park,” “College Hill” and “American Gangster” to more than 8.8 million digital satellite homes, Reuters reported. In time the network, intended for African-American viewers, seeks to develop shows for a British audience. ... The 10-time Grammy winner Beyoncé, above,  will be an executive producer and star as Etta James in “Cadillac Records,” a Sony BMG film about the Chicago label Chess Records, Billboard reported. She joins a cast that includes Adrien Brody as Leonard Chess, the label’s founder; Jeffrey Wright as Muddy Waters; Cedric the Entertainer as Willie Dixon; and Columbus Short as Little Walter. Darnell Martin, who wrote the screenplay, will direct. ... Owen Wilson is to return to work next month for the first time since his reported suicide attempt last summer, The Associated Press reported. On March 10, Mr. Wilson and Jennifer Aniston are to begin starring with Alan Arkin in “Marley & Me” for 20th Century Fox. The film, directed by David Frankel, tells of a couple who adopt a dog as preparation for parenthood, only to find the mischievous animal more than they bargained for. ... Hasbro Inc. and Universal Pictures have entered a six-year partnership to produce at least four films based on Hasbro games, including Monopoly, Battleship, Candy Land and Ouija. An announcement said the first film would be released in 2010 or 2011.

headline: Snow, Fly a Kite
text: As Newton knew, gravity is great. But for snow lovers searching for an alternate force to help them cruise, carve, and catapult into the air, wind power is the way to go. Over the past 10 years, the sport of snowkiting, in which skiers and snowboarders strap themselves to lightweight foil kites and ride the wind, has started to blossom in the United States -- and not just in mountain regions. Minnesota and North Dakota are some of the current snowkiting hotspots where beginners, using their own skis, boots and snowboards along with the specialized kites, can figure out how to harness the breezes in just a few hours. (Though snowkiting is, of course, colder than its liquid counterpart, called kiteboarding, it's also safer and easier to learn.)

headline: Sales Bumps for Grammy Winners
text: Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal) is the No. 1 album for a second week, with sales of 180,000 copies, but the big winners on the Billboard chart are Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock, who had big post-Grammy Awards sales bumps. Ms. Winehouse, who won five Grammys, jumped 22 spots to No. 2 with “Back to Black” (Universal), selling 115,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. And Mr. Hancock, whose “River: The Joni Letters” (Verve), above, was named album of the year, leaped to No. 5 from No. 159 with 54,000 sales, a 967 percent increase from its sales the week before. Alicia Keys, who performed at the ceremony and took home two prizes, holds at No. 3 with 109,000 sales of “As I Am” (J), and the compilation “2008 Grammy Nominees” (Hip-O/Universal) is No. 4 with 72,000. ... A new 25th-anniversary edition of Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” (Epic), with several new tracks, was the second-best-selling album in the country last week, moving 166,000 copies, but Billboard’s rules prevent “Thriller” from appearing on its main album chart; instead, it is No. 1 on the catalog chart, for albums more than 18 months old.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Thursday about favored projects, known as earmarks, that lawmakers sponsor in spending bills misstated the approach that Representative Bill Sali, Republican of Idaho, uses in dealing with people seeking such funds. Mr. Sali provides earmark application forms to those who ask; he does not solicit applications for earmarks.

headline: Restaurants Must Rehire Deliverymen, Judge Rules
text: For nearly a year, devotees of Vietnamese food have encountered deliverymen picketing in front of two of Manhattan’s most highly rated Asian restaurants: the Saigon Grills on the Upper West Side and in Greenwich Village.

headline: A Call for Volunteer Runners
text: New York Road Runners, the club that organizes the New York City Marathon, is asking its members to volunteer if they want to compete. About 7,000 club members gained entry to this year’s marathon, which will be run Nov. 2, by competing in at least 9 of 41 races of various lengths in 2007. To qualify for the 2009 marathon, members will also be required to volunteer for one of the 50 events the Road Runners organize this year.

headline: Lohan Assumes the Pose: Monroe’s Final Sitting
text: The Feb. 25 issue of New York magazine welcomes this spring fashion season with a cover image that doesn’t bother trying to promote the Op-Art prints of Miuccia Prada or the free-form gowns of Missoni or Lanvin. The marketing of fashion has had little do with clothes for a long time, after all. At play instead is a commercialism that is both creepier and more compelling: a picture of a nude Lindsay Lohan, less than a year out of her third go at rehab.

headline: Look, Up in the Sky!
text: Let us pause to consider the Pentagon’s effort to shoot down USA-193, an intelligence-gathering satellite the size of a bus that went out of commission shortly after its launch in 2006 and then began hurtling toward Earth. A window of opportunity opened Wednesday night and soon the world will know whether it has been saved from peril.

headline: Wladimir Klitschko Hopes to Reduce Ranks of Heavyweight Champs
text: Quiz:

headline: Note on Wall Shuts College in Jersey City
text: Hundreds of students and faculty members were evacuated from classrooms and buildings on the campus of St. Peter’s College in Jersey City for about two hours on Wednesday after officials at the Jesuit institution discovered a handwritten note taped to a hallway wall. A college spokeswoman said the note referred to the massacre of more than 30 students and teachers at Virginia Tech in April.

headline: Home in Box Had Its Problems; Alternative Does, Too
text: The box is as long and low as a frontier coffin, and answers soundly a knock of the knuckles. It has four small wheels and a heavy chain that snakes through a hole on the side and wraps around a “No Standing” sign. Hundreds of neighbors and Little Italy tourists pass it every day, just off a strip of busy lighting stores on the Bowery at Broome Street. They pass the box with barely a glance.

headline: Web Movies Show Why DVDs Sell
text: Ten days ago, Netflix announced that it would abandon HD DVD, Toshiba's entry in the high-definition DVD format war. Six days ago, Wal-Mart dropped HD DVD, too. Then two days ago, Toshiba surrendered, marking the end of the most pointless format war since Betamax-VHS.

headline: A Gaping Divide: Straddling Capitalism’s Fault Line
text: Jamie Johnson, an heir to the pharmaceutical fortune that bears his family’s name, has made a career out of retailing his wealth guilt, and so far the results have been anything but shameful. In “Born Rich,” shown on HBO in 2003, young people living on ancestral largess spoke  insightfully, candidly, obnoxiously  about the joys and agonies of their circumstances. The film garnered Mr. Johnson two Emmy nominations, and he deserved them. It also won him a chance to try his hand again, this time with “The One Percent,” another documentary, which arrives with the goal of examining the great, gaping disparity in wealth that severs the American soul.

headline: O’Neal Shows He Could Be the Suns’ Missing Piece
text: PHOENIX  The nifty over-the-shoulder pass for an easy basket brought Suns fans out of their seats Wednesday night at U.S. Airways Center. This was not the Suns’ superlative playmaking guard, Steve Nash, summoning his usual wizardry. It was Shaquille O’Neal recording his second assist as a Sun with a blind pass inside to Leandro Barbosa for a first-quarter layup against the Los Angeles Lakers.

headline: Permission to Use iTunes
text: Q. When I try to add new music to my iTunes library, I keep getting an error message that says I “don’t have enough access privileges for this operation.” This is my own computer, so what does this mean and how can I fix the problem?

headline: A Korean Village Torn Apart From Within Mends Itself
text: KURIM, South Korea  This village was once drenched with blood. Bodies of villagers shot or stabbed to death lined its lanes, and the stench of people burned alive saturated its air.

headline: An Eco-Friendly Pianist Wears Her Heart on Her Sleeveless Dress
text: Bowing to the protocols of classical music, most female performers give a great deal of attention to selecting a recital dress. But the one the gifted young Korean pianist Soyeon Lee wore during the second half of her recital on Tuesday night at Zankel Hall was almost the center of attention.

headline: Walter J. Burghardt, Social Justice Advocate, Dies at 93
text: The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt, a Jesuit priest widely known for emphasizing social justice in the many books he wrote and the seminars he gave on the history and art of preaching, died Saturday in Merion Station, Pa. He was 93.

headline: City’s Sweeping Rezoning Plan for 125th Street Has Many in Harlem Concerned
text: The street may not be much to look at now, say people who grew up in Harlem during the 1950s and 1960s, but back then, 125th Street seemed like the bustling center of the world.

headline: Puttin’ on Razzle-Dazzle, One Bead at a Time
text: CRANFORD, N.J.  Glitz doesn’t just happen.

headline: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
text: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said Thursday that it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry and competitors.

headline: Hearing Is Delayed on Contract for Ashcroft
text: A Congressional hearing into lucrative no-bid contracts awarded by federal prosecutors has been postponed because the Justice Department has not indicated whether a leading witness, the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, will testify, Representative Frank Pallone Jr. said on Wednesday.

headline: Work to Begin on Platform Over Tracks on the West Side
text: Despite a flagging economy, Brookfield Properties says it will start work in June on a $600 million platform over railroad tracks near Ninth Avenue, where it plans to build two towering office buildings.

headline: 2 Superdelegates Declare for Obama in New Jersey
text: Senator Barack Obama won the backing of two additional superdelegates from New Jersey on Wednesday, including one who had declared for his opponent in the Democratic presidential race, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Embracing Women’s Inner Goddess
text: AS fierce as competition can get in the marketplace, the fight is seldom fought with blades  except, of course, when it comes to the battle between razor companies.

headline: Justices Rule on Retroactivity of Decisions
text: WASHINGTON  In a new pro-defendant twist on federalism, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that state courts are free to give criminal defendants the benefit of new constitutional developments, even when federal courts would be foreclosed from doing so.

headline: For Ruby, Tall, Thin and Young
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Bob Howsam, 89, Sports Executive, Dies
text: Bob Howsam, who founded the Denver Broncos as an original franchise in the American Football League and later built the Cincinnati Reds’ championship teams known as the Big Red Machine, died Tuesday at his home in Sun City, Ariz. He was 89.

headline: That ’70s Look: Stagflation
text: Lately, many people are hearing an echo  faintly perhaps but distinctly audible  of the stagflation of the 1970s.

headline: Sometimes Woods Is Down, Although Never on Himself
text: MARANA, Ariz.  With the sun sinking slowly over the desert moonscape, it was time to cue the theme from “The Good, the Bad and the Ugly.” Tiger Woods had one foot in the desert waste and another down the road in Tombstone. Three down with five holes to play Wednesday in his match against J. B. Holmes, he was on the verge of a most untimely departure in the first round of the Accenture Match Play Championship.

headline: More Americans Are Giving Up Golf
text: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y.  The men gathered in a new golf clubhouse here a couple of weeks ago circled the problem from every angle, like caddies lining up a shot out of the rough.

headline: Justices Shield Medical Devices From Lawsuits
text: WASHINGTON  Makers of medical devices like implantable defibrillators or breast implants are immune from liability for personal injuries as long as the Food and Drug Administration approved the device before it was marketed and it meets the agency’s specifications, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: CBS Shows Slump
text: One week after registering relatively mediocre ratings in their debuts, CBS’s “Big Brother” and the second season of “Jericho” each lost more than a million viewers on Tuesday. According to Nielsen’s estimates, “Big Brother” drew just 5.4 million viewers at 9 p.m., compared with 6.9 million a week ago, while “Jericho” attracted 5.9 million at 10 p.m., down from 7.1 million. CBS ranked third for the night over all, faring best at 8 p.m. with a rerun of “NCIS” (10.8 million). Fox dominated the night with a two-hour edition of “American Idol” (28.8 million). NBC finished second over all, winning the 10 p.m. hour following “Idol” with “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit” (9.3 million). NBC’s “Biggest Loser” (8.2 million) was also the runner-up from 8 to 10 p.m. among adults 18 to 49. ABC was a distant fourth for the night.

headline: As Fire Inquiry at Ground Zero Grows, So Do the Legal Bills
text: The Bloomberg administration and the state-run Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, both under scrutiny in the criminal investigation into the fatal Deutsche Bank fire, have incurred more than $2.2 million in fees for outside lawyers to defend their roles in the events that led up to the blaze, officials said this week.

headline: U.S. Security Concerns Block China’s 3Com Deal
text: WASHINGTON  Does the “America for Sale” sign require a warning label?

headline: Samuel Karlin, Versatile Mathematician, Dies at 83
text: Samuel Karlin, a mathematician who applied his theoretical brilliance to such far-flung areas as economics and population studies, before helping to find ways to analyze DNA swiftly and comprehensively, died on Dec. 18, in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Business Schools Break Tradition in Global Education
text: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA universities have long led the nation in the number of students enrolled from other countries. Now the universities’ business programs are taking the globalization of education to a different level, offering courses that go beyond dry corporate case studies and broadening their collaboration with universities and businesses abroad, particularly in Asia.

headline: Sorry, Boys, This Is Our Domain
text: THE prototypical computer whiz of popular imagination  pasty, geeky, male  has failed to live up to his reputation.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Jazz World Confronting Health Care Concerns
text: Not quite a month ago the alto saxophonist Andrew D’Angelo had a major seizure while driving his elderly landlady to a store in Brooklyn. “I was convulsing all over the place,” he later wrote on his blog, “grabbing onto the steering wheel violently, biting my tongue and basically acting crazy.”

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,956 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:

headline: Reality-Based Rate Cuts
text: Since last summer, when the financial markets began to crack, Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke has taken his share of criticism. When he didn’t immediately cut interest rates, he was accused of being too timid. When he cut aggressively last month, critics said he had panicked.

headline: Hate Mail Sent to Blacks at Prep School Is Investigated
text: CONCORD, N.H.  A police investigation is under way at an elite prep school here after many black students received anonymous letters that the head of the school described as “threatening hate mail.”

headline: Treating Diabetes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Enlisting a Laptop Docking Station to Tame the Motley Tethers of the Modern Workspace
text: A cluttered desk may be a sign of genius, but even Einstein might have found himself hopelessly tangled up in the cords and cables of a modern office. By keeping things simple, the Bluelounge SpaceStation, a laptop docking port, might help bring order out of chaos.

headline: Do You Get Where He’s Coming From?
text: WHEN I first visited Adam, the picture windows displayed a female mannequin that was trapped inside a bell-shaped bird cage, wearing a fur-lined silver vest. A male mannequin in the opposite window was paradoxically free: seated on a wooden bench in a comfortable Mr. Rogers zip cardigan, reading a book about architecture, surrounded by a nifty collection of ornamental bird cages.

headline: A Camera That Shows That Simplicity Can Be Costly
text: For a camera priced at $1,000, there is a lot missing from the Sigma DP-1. For starters, it is not a single-lens reflex camera. Indeed, the DP-1’s optical viewfinder is an optional $150 accessory. Nor does its lens zoom.

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. I’ve heard about public buildings with green walls, but can they be used in a house, like green roofs?

headline: Journalist Sentenced to Death in Iran, Accused of Terrorism
text: TEHRAN  Iran has sentenced a journalist to death, accusing him of being a member of a terrorist group in the country’s southeast, the judiciary said Tuesday.

headline: 3 Coins Might Short Out This Fountain
text: As a massive crane stacked units of curved steel embedded with thousands of light bulbs on a vast circular base on Sunday, passers-by couldn’t help but wonder what was rising on the exact spot where the fabled tree stands every Christmas in Rockefeller Center.

headline: Of Course I Washed My Hair Last Year (I’m Almost Certain)
text: CLEANLINESS may be a virtue, but when it comes to hair? Apparently, not so much.

headline: Facing Questions, Rodriguez Raises More
text: During his first interview with reporters at the Yankees’ spring training complex on Wednesday, third baseman Alex Rodriguez was peppered with questions about Roger Clemens, Andy Pettitte and the scrutiny he expects as he pursues baseball’s career home run record.

headline: Canadian TV Network Seeks Release of Afghan
text: OTTAWA  Canada’s largest commercial television network is asking for the immediate release of an Afghan employee who it has been told is being detained by the United States military.

headline: The Head That Wears the Crown
text: BOY-SHORT, peroxide-blond heads of hair are appearing all over fashionable London, replacing the long and shaggy locks that were the dominant look of the last few years.

headline: Health Insurance Data
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stem Cell Therapy Controls Diabetes in Mice
text: Scientists reported on Wednesday that they were able to control diabetes in mice by harnessing human embryonic stem cells. The work raised the prospect that the embryonic cells might one day be used to provide insulin-producing replacement cells to treat the disease in people.

headline: Cuba and the World Wonder: Now What?
text: MEXICO CITY  When Fidel Castro promised to step down this week as Cuba’s head of state, he left the Cuban people and the rest of the world wondering not only what role he will play in retirement, but what changes will follow in the country he has run for nearly 50 years.

headline: New Nets Arrive, but Harris’s Debut Is Delayed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The last vestiges of the Jason Kidd era had been peeled away, quite literally, from the Izod Center by the time the Nets resumed their season Wednesday night.

headline: Put Another File in the Jukebox, Baby
text: IT’S only a mild case of audiophilia, according to the professionals, but it’s causing me significant discomfort.

headline: Clemens Pulls Out of ESPN Event
text: Roger Clemens withdrew Wednesday from a scheduled appearance at an ESPN event at Disney World in Florida because, he said in a statement, “I believe my current participation could be a distraction.”

headline: Mercury Taint Divides a Japanese Whaling Town
text: TAIJI, Japan  For years, Western activists have traveled to this remote port to protest the annual dolphin drive. And for years, local fishermen have ignored them, herding the animals into a small cove and slashing them until the tide flows red.

headline: Moving Soon to an Apartment Near You
text: BROOKE BERMAN is living in Seventh Heaven this week. That’s the name of the three dorm rooms that New Dramatists, a nonprofit center for playwrights housed in an old church on West 44th Street, offers its 49 artists-in-residence for short stays.

headline: Union Says Immigration Policy Doesn’t Go Far Enough in Phoenix
text: The union representing 2,500 rank-and-file Phoenix police officers said Tuesday that a new policy requiring the police to ask the immigration status only of people under arrest does not go far enough and could allow illegal immigrants to commit more crimes. The policy announced Friday by Mayor Phil Gordon and an advisory panel applies to misdemeanor and felony arrests but not civil traffic stops. The police would have the option to send written notification to Immigration and Customs Enforcement on people detained but not arrested. Mark Spencer, president of the union, the Phoenix Law Enforcement Association, said a suspect’s immigration status was already checked at the county jail under a sheriff’s department policy, making the Phoenix policy moot.

headline: Britain: Diana Claims ‘Ridiculous,’ Ex-Spy Chief Tells Inquest
text: Sir Richard Dearlove, the retired chief of MI6, the Secret Intelligence Service, told the inquest into the 1997 car death of Diana, Princess of Wales, that allegations that the agency plotted the crash were “without substance, utterly ridiculous and completely off the map.” The claim that MI6 worked with French intelligence agents and the C.I.A. to kill Diana and her lover, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi, and that the plot was directed by Prince Philip and Prince Charles was made at the inquest this week by Mr. Fayed’s father, Mohamed al-Fayed. Sir Richard, below, who led MI6 from 1999 to 2004, was its operations director at the time of the crash. Breaking with the agency’s longstanding policy of never commenting on allegations about its activities, he said he could state with “complete confidence” that MI6 had no operations involving Diana in the summer of 1997 and that allegations of complicity between the agency and Philip and Charles were “absurd.” Sir Richard said he knew of no occasion during his 38 years with MI6 when it had assassinated anyone.

headline: Girardi Ushers in a New Generation
text: TAMPA, Fla.  For the last dozen seasons as Yankees manager, Joe Torre was a father figure to many players, or at least an Uncle Joe. Born in 1940, Torre was at least two decades older than most of his players and more than 40 years older than some of them.

headline: Pentagon Is Confident Missile Hit Satellite Tank
text: WASHINGTON  Just hours after a Navy missile interceptor struck a dying spy satellite orbiting 130 miles over the Pacific Ocean, a senior military officer expressed high confidence early Thursday that a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel had been breached.

headline: Thousands in Armenia Protest Results of Presidential Election
text: ISTANBUL  Thousands gathered Wednesday in Yerevan, the capital of Armenia, to protest Tuesday’s presidential election, which they said had been rigged, although international observers evaluated it as relatively free and fair.

headline: Jewelry of Mets Reliever Is Stolen From His Hotel
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Mets reliever Ambiorix Burgos said he had more than $270,000 worth of jewelry stolen from his hotel room earlier this week, but by Wednesday afternoon he had recovered all but five pieces. Burgos said through an interpreter that he reported to the police Tuesday that a black leather bag containing the jewelry had disappeared and that hours later an unidentified man dropped it off at Burgos’s hotel, the SpringHill Suites, before speeding away.

headline: Russia Denies Visa to Rights Group Leader in Days Before Report
text: MOSCOW  Human Rights Watch released a report here on Wednesday accusing the Kremlin of using a host of bureaucratic rules to hinder the work of nonprofit organizations. The group did not have to look far to find what it said was a fresh example of the problem: Its own executive director was denied a visa to come to Moscow to present the report.

headline: Scores With a Youth Movement
text: Youthful exuberance is a marketable commodity everywhere, and in the classical music world it commands a premium. Still, Mannes College the New School for Music offered a generous sampling of it free on Tuesday evening, when the Mannes Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall.

headline: The Sharper Image Files for Bankruptcy Protection
text: The Sharper Image, the 31-year-old purveyor of futuristic adult gadgetry like $5,000 massage chairs and $300 robotic vacuum cleaners, has filed for bankruptcy protection after years of slipping sales, stiffening competition and image problems over its Ionic Breeze air purifiers.

headline: Cellphone Carriers Test All-You-Can-Talk Menus
text: A PRICE war among cellphone carriers is giving users a chance to stop counting their minutes.

headline: Turkey: Parliament Backs Return of Minorities’ Properties
text: Parliament passed a law that would return properties confiscated by the state, including hospitals and churches, to non-Muslim minorities. The law, championed by the party of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan but opposed by nationalists, was sought by the European Union. Liberals have criticized the law, saying it does not go far enough because it does not apply to property sold to third parties.

headline: Launching from Both Ends
text: Twin-tips, skis rounded and curved up at the tail like the front of a traditional ski, simplify jumping and landing backward. And as The Times reports, sales of twin-tips have increased 32 percent in specialty stores and 167 percent in online sales over last season, adding up to 46,429 pairs sold this season -- making them the second most popular kind of ski. "The answer to their sudden popularity is as old-fashioned as it is modern," The Times reports. "Twin-tips are new, cool and make people feel young. So middle-aged men and women are buying them, and not just for their sons and daughters."

headline: Letting the Inner Angst Out, Loudly
text: Dave Grohl was a smiling, gum-chewing, hair-flopping, guitar-thrusting rock star when his band, Foo Fighters, headlined Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night. He was also the guy who wrote and sang lyrics like “Hearts gone cold and hands are tied/Why’d you have to go and let it die?” in a voice that was both mournful and enraged, while the music moved from melancholy fingerpicking to a hard-rock stomp. His songs grow troubled, but Mr. Grohl himself never comes across as tortured.

headline: Kidd’s Debut for Mavericks Ends With a Hornets Victory
text: Jason Kidd made his Dallas Mavericks debut against the host New Orleans Hornets on Wednesday night, so invigorated by the prospect of playing for a contender again that he dismissed concerns of travel fatigue or his immediate insertion into the starting lineup of a team he has practiced with twice.

headline: A Traditional Therapy Finds Modern Uses
text: QUITTING cigarettes had always been agony for Michele Fenzl, a 55-year-old computer operator from Denver. Pregnancy got her to stop for a while. But in 35 years of smoking a pack a day, nothing else gave her a reprieve.

headline: ‘SNL’ Is Ready to Make Up for Lost Time
text: Lorne Michaels has been running NBC’s “Saturday Night Live” for so long that when he is asked about the impact the writers’ strike had on his show, he can legitimately ask: Which one?

headline: McCain Answers Questions About Lobbyist
text: The following is a transcript from John McCain’s news conference, as provided by Federal News Service.

headline: Ousted Publisher Joins Nan A. Talese
text: Janet Silver, recently ousted as publisher of Houghton Mifflin’s adult trade division in the wake of the company’s merger with Harcourt, has been appointed editor at large at Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, an imprint of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group. Last month Ms. Silver, 53, was edged out of Houghton Mifflin Harcourt Adult Trade Books when Becky Saletan, publisher of the trade division of Harcourt, was appointed publisher of the combined unit. At Nan A. Talese Ms. Silver, who spent 24 years at Houghton, will focus on editing while working out of her home in Concord, Mass.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Wednesday about the strategy that winners of Pakistan’s election hope to use to deal with Islamic militancy misstated, in some editions, the government experience of Asif Ali Zardari, the widower of Benazir Bhutto and the leader of the Pakistan Peoples Party. He has indeed held office, having been elected to the National Assembly twice and to the Senate once.

headline: Justices Add Legal Complications to Debate on F.D.A.’s Competence
text: WASHINGTON

headline: For Muslim Students, a Debate on Inclusion
text: SAN JOSE  Amir Mertaban vividly recalls sitting at his university’s recruitment table for the Muslim Students Association a few years ago when an attractive undergraduate flounced up in a decidedly un-Islamic miniskirt, saying “Salamu aleykum,” or “Peace be upon you,” a standard Arabic greeting, and asked to sign up.

headline: Research Explains Formation of Unique Martian Fans
text: To figure out an odd landscape feature on Mars, play in a big sandbox.

headline: Oscar Nomination Caps Columbia Film Professor’s Long Journey
text: Dozens of people have been nominated for Oscars this year, but none of them got there quite the way that Jamal Joseph did.

headline: Fans Asked, and They Have Received
text: It was with considerable amusement that I, an inevitable University of Illinois alumnus from birth, watched as Indiana Hoosiers fans openly speculated that the only way their troubled basketball program could possibly be salvaged would be the return of Bloomington's prodigal son, Bob Knight. (Though it's sometimes difficult to imagine Knight as anyone's "son.")

headline: I’m Ill, but Who Really Needs to Know?
text: ONE of the first decisions you make in the emotional hours after a scary diagnosis is whether to tell others. Most of us share the news with our loved ones, but what of the circles beyond, particularly those at work? Your boss?

headline: Germany Prods Liechtenstein on Fighting Fraud
text: FRANKFURT  Having turned a spotlight on what it calls Liechtenstein’s brisk business in abetting tax evasion, Germany has raised the prospect of retaliation in other areas unless the principality cooperates more on tax policy.

headline: Broken Borders and Dover Sole: My Lunch With Lou Dobbs
text: So I was having lunch at the Four Seasons with Lou Dobbs the other day, locked in disagreement over who cared more about working people, him or me.

headline: Prep Star’s Rise Aided by His Brothers’ Best Intentions
text: ASTON, Pa.  Tyreke Evans has been rehearsing for this moment since he was 6 years old, when his brothers used an old boxing trick and duct-taped his right arm to his body, forcing him to dribble with his left hand. He learned a game of basketball Twister to improve his first step and played in the rain and the snow, even carried his basketball to bed.

headline: New South Korean Leader Cleared in Fraud Inquiry
text: SEOUL, South Korea  A special prosecutor on Thursday cleared President-elect Lee Myung-bak of South Korea of fraud accusations, four days before his inauguration.

headline: Stanford Set to Raise Aid for Students in Middle
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Stanford University on Wednesday became the latest prominent university to expand financial aid well into the middle class. It announced that students from families earning less than $100,000 a year would not be charged tuition.

headline: Teamsters Endorse Obama, Offering a Blue-Collar Lift
text: In a surprising boost for Senator Barack Obama, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters endorsed him on Wednesday, giving him new momentum among a group where he is eager to shore up support: blue-collar men.

headline: 3 Hit by Trains, 2 Fatally
text: In three separate subway track accidents on Wednesday, trains struck and killed two men and injured a third, Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials said.

headline: A Primer for Viewing the Democratic Debate
text: Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have not met face to face in a debate since their love-fest in Hollywood on Jan. 31.

headline: Most Children Still Live in Two-Parent Homes, Census Bureau Reports
text: The American family may be under stress, but most children still live in two-parent households, the Census Bureau reported Wednesday.

headline: The Long and Winding Political Road
text: To the Editor:

headline: Parents’ Influence in the Fight Against Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Newly Released
text: It’s a cliché by now to note the rise of the Scottish thriller, and “ripped from the headlines” plots punctuate that “ka-chung” sound on “Law & Order” so often you’d think there’d be none left to fuel fiction writing. Still, among this month’s new releases are books from both those categories; whether they’ll transcend their genres remains to be seen. Also new this month: unnerving short stories and a book about a C.I.A. agent who just can’t stay out of trouble.

headline: Corrections
text: An article on Feb. 9 about the fading possibility of Michael R. Bloomberg’s becoming a candidate for president misidentified the person with whom Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, discussed the possibility of running on a ticket with the New York City mayor. Senator Hagel said there had been talks about it, but one of his aides said later that the talks had been with Deputy Mayor Kevin Sheekey, not with Mr. Bloomberg.

headline: Picture, Picture on the Wall ...
text: THERE has always been a certain status attached to owning a home that is featured in a magazine. And a certain pleasure, for a homeowner, in leaving the evidence lying casually on the coffee table.

text: CABRA, Kosovo  Serbs in northern Kosovo on Wednesday continued what appeared to be a drive to force a partition three days after the ethnic Albanian majority declared the province’s independence from Serbia.

headline: Race Matters Less in Politics of South

headline: The Oracle of the Phillies Has the Last Words
text: CLEARWATER, Fla.  In its never-ending quest to mirror the American political landscape, baseball has found its answer to the latest Clinton-Obama hullabaloo.

headline: When Addicted Son Hurts, Father Feels His Own Pain
text: Addiction is a compulsion to do the same thing over and over, despite knowing that the outcome will almost certainly be the same. Addiction memoirs often illustrate this same definition of insanity. They follow the same arc, voice the same helplessness and arrive at the same set of conclusions. Yet the genre itself remains so addictive that readers keep hoping to discover something new.

headline: Repotting for Spring, Mixing in Some Memories
text: NOW that spring is near, I’ve been repotting dozens of houseplants  begonias, aloes and oxalis  and have started to make cuttings of others, like geraniums, aeoniums and kalanchoes.

headline: Richard Westenburg, Choral Conductor, Dies at 75
text: Richard Westenburg, a choral conductor who founded the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra in 1964 and made it one of the most renowned choruses in New York by the end of the 1970s, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Norwalk, Conn. He was 75 and lived in Redding, Conn.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A dance review on Tuesday about the Sugar Salon showcase, at the Abron Arts Center, misstated the title of a piece choreographed by Heather McArdle. It is “Ballad of Arrivals & Departures”  not “BlueprintViolation: Ballad of Arrivals & Departures,” which is the name of Ms. McArdle’s company.

headline: Stifling Online Speech
text: The rise of Internet journalism has opened a new front in the battle to protect free speech. A federal judge last week ordered the disabling of Wikileaks.org, a muckraking Web site. That stifles important speech and violates the First Amendment. It should be reversed, and Wikileaks should be allowed to resume operations.

headline: From China, Cellphone à la Carte
text: The Zzzphone, a made-to-order cellphone, recently captured the imagination of the gadget crowd. But it remains to be seen whether it can live up to its promise.

headline: The McCain Article
text: A recent New York Times article examined a number of decisions by Senator John McCain that raised questions about his judgment over potential conflicts of interest. The article included reporting on Mr. McCain’s relationship with a female lobbyist whose clients often had business before the Senate committee led by Mr. McCain. Since publication of the article, The Times has received more than 2,000 comments, many of them criticizing the handling of the article. More than 4,000 questions were sent via e-mail to The Times on Thursday night and Friday. Editors and reporters who worked on the article answered some of the questions on Friday. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Nov. 5 about Maria Bartiromo, the CNBC business reporter, misspelled the surname of the dean of the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, who commented on her promotional appearance on behalf of Citigroup, a frequent subject of CNBC coverage. He is John Lavine, not Levine. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message last Thursday.

headline: McCain Denies Aides’ Statements About Lobbyist
text: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator John McCain said Thursday that an article in The New York Times about his close ties to a woman lobbyist was untrue, that he had no romantic relationship with the lobbyist and that he had no confrontations in 1999 with worried staff members who told him to stay away from her.

headline: Antiquities Trial Continues in Rome
text: More than six months after the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles agreed to hand over 40 artifacts to Italy, the criminal trial of its former curator of antiquities lumbers on in Rome. A prosecution witness painstakingly presented the court with photographs and documents on Wednesday in an effort to establish that more than a dozen looted artifacts had made their way into the Getty’s collection. Marion True, the former Getty curator, is charged with conspiring to acquire illicitly excavated antiquities for the museum. Several of the pieces discussed on Wednesday by the prosecution witness, Daniela Rizzo, are now on view at the presidential palace in Rome as part of an exhibition of objects recovered from American museums in the last two years. Ms. Rizzo repeatedly projected an image of an artifact onto a screen next to a photograph of the same piece in a dirt-encrusted, unrestored state. For most of the pieces, she said, acquisition documents provided by the Getty did not cite the object’s provenance. “If it came from an authorized dig, it would say so and give a date,” she said. “The fact that it doesn’t makes you think, doesn’t it?” Ms. True and the American dealer Robert Hecht, who is on trial with her on similar charges, have both proclaimed their innocence. The next trial hearing is scheduled for mid-March.

headline: Gesink Wins 3rd Stage of Tour of California
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP)  Robert Gesink of the Netherlands claimed the day’s honors and Levi Leipheimer became the third overall race leader Wednesday in the mountainous third stage of the Tour of California.

headline: Rio Tinto May Break With Other Producers on Iron Ore Price
text: SYDNEY, Australia  Rio Tinto, the world’s second-largest iron ore producer, has indicated that it is not satisfied with the 65 percent increase in the benchmark ore price negotiated by Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the Brazilian mining conglomerate, with Nippon Steel of Japan and Posco of South Korea.

headline: Google Health Begins Its Preseason at Cleveland Clinic

headline: Gucci: A Ticket to Ride
text: First of all, thanks to everyone for the terrific comments and funny asides on the blog, and to georgianna8 for the lace history (new stuff to learn!), RC (glad you couldn’t resist), Marko for mentioning Raf Simons the big romantic (let’s not talk austere anymore), and, Brooksie, couldn’t agree with you more that it’s Miuccia’s responsibility to show racial diversity on her runway. It DOES matter, it’s not a trend, and it astounds me that designers in Europe and the U.S. are blankishly ignorant about why this matters. One or two black or Asian or Latina models on their runways is not enough. In general ways, in skin color, body shape, and physical expressiveness, the runways need to be far more diverse and surprising than they are. And a designer should lead the way.

headline: Why Americans Are Giving Up Golf
text: Over the past decade, golf, the leisure activity that is often closely associated with corporate success in America, has been in a kind of recession, Paul Vitello writes. The total number of people who play has declined or remained flat each year since 2000, dropping to about 26 million from 30 million, according to the National Golf Foundation and the Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association. More troubling to golf boosters, the number of people who play 25 times a year or more fell to 4.6 million in 2005 from 6.9 million in 2000, a loss of about a third.

headline: Playing by Party Rules
text: When Bill Clinton ran for president in 1992, he talked, memorably and incessantly, about protecting those families who “worked hard and played by the rules.” Sixteen years later, it appears ever more likely that the outcome of this year’s Democratic nomination fight will rest, in the end, on how party leaders interpret the rules. As I’ve written here before, there is no real ideological divide in the party; most Democrats would seem to be satisfied with either Hillary Rodham Clinton or Barack Obama, so there’s no reason to think either candidate’s followers will automatically revolt if they lose. But no matter who wins, if the process itself ends up confirming the growing suspicion among voters that the rules are only there to be rigged, then the outcome could devastate a party whose central argument is all about fairness. Much has been written about the possible permutations in the Democratic race from here on out, but at this point it’s fairly simple. After his victories Tuesday, Mr. Obama now has a slim but hard-to-surmount lead in “pledged delegates” — those awarded in state contests. If Mrs. Clinton were to win the trio of Texas, Ohio and Pennsylvania by huge margins, then she might be able to overtake him, but that doesn’t seem terribly likely, given the dynamic of the race right now. Even so, neither candidate has much chance of emerging from the primaries with the 2,025 delegates needed to lock up the nomination, which means that even if Mr. Obama maintains his lead, Mrs. Clinton can—and probably will—fight on.

headline: Fans Asked, and They Have Received

headline: Tough Recoveries for 2 Wounded in Shooting Rampages

But in the toll of wounded, grievous injuries may be obscured among more minor ones.

headline: ‘A Shouting Match With an Oil Well’
text: Aired Wednesday night on CBS: You excited about the big Presidential race? Whoo, how about that Hillary Clinton campaign? You know, they’re worried now. They’re worried and a little bit nervous. They’re campaigning in Texas today. Give you an idea how nervous Hillary is: she showed up in a pantsuit and chaps. And last week, in Wisconsin, she showed up in a cheese pantsuit.

headline: Is This the End of Off-Track Betting?
text: Video

headline: CNBC Video: Faber on the Credit Markets
text: “The credit markets are broken.”

headline: Weekend in New York
text: Seth Kugel explores three of New York's ethnic grocery stores.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Overtures to Communist Nations
text: The Philharmonic will very likely win a huge bit of cachet with its trip next week to North Korea. Look for these phrases in coming articles (no exemptions claimed here): “extraordinary visit,” “historic event” and “unprecedented trip,” along with comparisons to the Philadelphia Orchestra’s visit to China in 1973, a musical volley in Ping-Pong diplomacy. Are the Philharmonic’s rivals on the orchestra scene a bit jealous? Perhaps.

headline: Superdelegate Fight Seeps Into a Brooklyn Race
text: There is no question that the political climate of the Democratic nomination for president is seeping into contests within New York City. The latest example is in a Congressional race in Brooklyn, where Kevin Powell is seeking to unseat Representative Edolphus Towns, a longtime incumbent.

headline: Clinton Friends to Mount Ohio Ad Campaign
text: As the Clinton campaign scrambles for cash, one outside group has sprung up to help her in Ohio and Texas.

headline: New York Philharmonic at the Shanghai Grand Theater
text: Images from the New York Philharmonic's first performance at the Shanghai Grand Theater.

headline: Citi Appoints 2 New Power and Utilities Executives
text: Citigroup appointed two new co-heads of its North American power and utilities group in investment banking, the SparkSpread Web site reported Thursday. Kirk Andrews and Dean Keller, who are both managing directors and who advised clients like Royal Dutch Shell and Bechtel Enterprises Energy, will assume those roles.

headline: Johnna Above it All
text: Johnna’s umbilical cord locket really struck me, I think, because of the horror of the idea that if it ever gets lost it, “our souls belong nowhere and after we die our souls will walk the Earth looking for where we belong.” I found my mind wandering off after that line, wondering: how does it stay on? How can she be sure the clasp doesn’t break and it falls off? Does she periodically replace the cord, meticulously, in order to be sure it remains intact for her whole life? And if it does get lost, would Johnna’s friends and relatives shake their heads, shrug their shoulders — sorry, your soul belongs nowhere now?

headline: London Not Calling
text: There will always be an England … or will there (Part II)?

headline: Can Two Wrongs Make a Successful Racing Series?
text: The Indy Racing League and Champ Car World Series sure hope so — as do open-wheel racing fans in America.

headline: Excursions Around Florence in March
text: We are going to Italy in March and will stay just outside Florence for four days. What itinerary do you recommend in Tuscany for someone who has never been before?

headline: Make That 11 for Obama
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Barack Obama won his 11th straight nominating contest on Thursday, carrying the Democrats Abroad global primary by a 2-to-1 margin over Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and prevailing among American expatriates in every region of the world.

headline: Surprises in dry F1 testing in Spain
text: Yes, I know, we say it every year: You cannot really see through winter testing who is going to win the championship. And thank goodness for that! On the other hand, in the first day of dry testing this week at Barcelona, there were some interesting surprises. Or maybe not. Can we still be surprised by Nakajima’s rocket? It seems to have lifted off several times this winter – and in Brazil – and this time Kuzuki outdid the two McLarens as well as his teammate, Nico Rosberg.

headline: T Magazine | Preview the Spring Issue
text: It may be 32 degrees outside, but at T, we’re ready to peel off our boiled-wool swing coats and bare our shoulders to the to the 20-mph winds. It’s spring! Today on T Online, you will find the best of our Spring 2008 Women’s Fashion issue, packed with sun-friendly solutions to the slate-colored winter sky. The actress Charlize Theron warms our cover and talks about her new movie, “Sleepwalking,” in an interview with Lynn Hirschberg. The Italian supermodel Mariacarla Boscono takes center stage in a Jean-Baptiste Mondino shoot (and a web-exclusive video), while Cathy Horyn gets inside the growing Comme des Garçons empire. Be sure to check out the actress Chloë Sevigny’s “Sassy” duds in Profile In Style and the skin-tingling portraits of the performance artist Orlan in My Life in Pictures. You can also take shelter in the colorful home of Warhol-muse Jane Holzer. Spring is a just click away.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Salvatore Ferragamo
text: (AFP/Getty Images)

headline: The Chumby Is Open, but Not for Business
text: I find Chumby fascinating for a lot of reasons. Meant to replace a clock radio, it is a $179 device with a Wi-Fi connection, a 3.5-inch touch screen and a squishy leather case. It displays various widgets with information pulled off the Internet, and it plays podcasts, Internet radio and some Web video. I suspect over the next decade we will be deluged by various connected devices offering various views of information and entertainment. (Here is John Markoff’s experience with one last fall.)

headline: ‘Chuck Norris Just Sends His Stunt Double’
text: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: Welcome to “The Tonight Show.” Happy Black History Month. Did you know this is Black History Month? If Barack Obama keeps winning, it looks like Hillary could be history.

headline: Accounting for Emeril’s $20 Million Kicker
text: There’s a meaty accounting lesson in the details of Martha Stewart’s recent deal with Emeril Lagasse, the celebrity chef.

headline: Change to Win Gets Behind Obama
text: Its member unions represent 175,000 workers in Ohio alone. Nationwide, the group represents more than five million workers. And now Change to Win, a coalition of seven unions, is jumping on board the Barack Obama bandwagon.

headline: Should All of 125th Street Be Declared Historic?
text: Adam Leitman Bailey, a lawyer who was born in Queens and grew up in New Jersey, has devised a novel way to halt gentrification in Harlem. Mr. Bailey, 37, has proposed having 125th Street, from river to river, declared the “Harlem Historic Zone,” which he believes would make it more difficult to tear down the neighborhood’s old buildings and replace them with new ones.

headline: True Lies
text: Yesterday’s Times had an article on Jose A. Rodriguez Jr., the C.I.A. official who authorized destroying the tapes of C.I.A. agents questioning terrorism suspects.

headline: Ratings: ‘Idol’ Soars; ‘Top Model’ Looks Thin
text: As the top twelve female contestants competed on “American Idol” on Wednesday, Fox once again easily dominated the night’s ratings as 28.7 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for a two-hour edition of the show, according to Nielsen’s estimates.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Thursday, Feb. 21:

headline: Brian Schneider: Throwback
text: Brian Schneider has been called a “throwback” for the way he plays. It’s fitting, too, considering he’s a fan of Mitchell and Ness, the amazing throwback jersey store in Center City Philadelphia, whose T-shirt he was sporting this afternoon. Schneider said he has a huge collection, ranging from Hall of Famers to current All-Stars — all baseball — that he will store in the house he is building in Pennsylvania.

headline: Stopping One Avalanche but Missing Another
text: NOTES ON THE NEWS Spam filters mistakenly hold back important e-mails all the time, but this particular instance reported by The Denver Post stopped an electronic avalanche while leaving Coloradans in the dark about a real one:

headline: Josh Horowitz Drinks the Milkshake
text: Some hussy from MTV makes a late grab for best Oscar-related video of 2008 and triumphs. The Bagger was left with a frozen smile on his face and a wan wave from the cheap seats.

headline: Of Cell Phones and Land Lines
text: NOTES ON THE NEWS A cell phone company is offering an unlikely product to customers in Dallas and Seattle: landlines.

headline: A Symphony of Confusion
text: In the best song category, chaos reigns. “Once” was in, then it was out, then it was in again. The song from “August Rush” made it in, but no one saw the movie. And then three, count ’em, three songs from “Enchanted” made it in, but given the demographics of the Academy, it’s likely that not many voters actually saw that movie either.

headline: Bush’s Popularity: A (Really) New Low?
text: The American Research Group, a well-known polling organization, released a pretty surprising poll yesterday putting President Bush’s approval rating at a new low: just 19 percent.

headline: Not Very Brainy
text: From Yahoo:

headline: Re-Starting ‘Saturday Night Live’
text: Bill Carter interviews Lorne Michaels, the executive producer of “Saturday Night Live,” ahead of the show’s Feb. 23 return:

headline: The Oscars Movie
text: It’s an award-winning formula, from “The Soup” on E! Entertainment:

headline: Saarinen Terminal to Reopen at Kennedy Airport
text: After a long darkness, the Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport — that abandoned embodiment of the “Come Fly With Me” era of jet-setting — would reopen this year, under a plan advanced Thursday by the Port Authority.The authority’s board approved a $19 million project to perform the essential repairs needed to allow travelers to pass through the 46-year-old terminal on their way to the enormous new JetBlue Airways terminal that wraps around the T.W.A. building in a crescent shape.

headline: Movie Minutes: 'The Counterfeiters'
text: A. O. Scott reviews "The Counterfeiters," directed by Stefan Ruzowitzky.

headline: Boone Pickens on Wind Energy
text: CNBC interviews Boone Pickens, chairman of BP Capital Management, on the prospects for various types of alternative energy.

headline: Serbs Protest Kosovo Independence
text: Rioters set fire to buildings and attacked the United States Embassy in Belgrade, the Serbian capital, on Thursday after tens of thousands of people rallied to protest Kosovo's declaration of independence four days ago.

headline: Calls for a New Park on the East River
text: Federal, state and city officials joined several civic organizations today to express support for a new four-acre waterfront park that would be built in the shadow of the United Nations and cost as much as $100 million, but the project faces considerable logistical and financial hurdles. The park would be at the northern end of Glick Park, at 36th Street and Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive in Manhattan, where decaying concrete is blocked off by a gate and a fence with barbed wire. The area, which houses a now-defunct Consolidated Edison, is one of the largest parcels in Manhattan facing redevelopment in the next few years.

headline: The View From Paris, Part One
text: I can’t say that my first impressions of Paris, this time around, were all that encouraging. There was the sad Vietnamese restaurant where I had dinner my first night. There were the crepe-makers, working in advance, stacking their crepes twenty high in anticipation of customers. (Isn’t half the reason for getting a crepe watching the process?) I can’t remember when the pre-made sandwich thing took over completely. (Oh, and now there are “paninis.”) Why would anyone spend 15 euros for pre-shredded cabbage?

headline: John McCain Press Conference
text: CNBC coverage of a press conference by John McCain as he discussed a Times article dealing with allegations of ethics breaches with a lobbyist.

headline: The Hangtown Fry
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, makes scrambled eggs with bacon and oysters.

headline: Strike News: ‘Criminal Minds’ First Back On Set
text: The CBS drama “Criminal Minds” will become the first television drama to resume production today, only eight days after the writers’ strike ended, the network confirmed today.

headline: S.F. Zoo Reopens Tiger Exhibit
text: The San Francisco Zoo reopened the tiger and lion exhibits today almost two months after a deadly incident proved improvements were needed. The cats are now surrounded by 19-feet high walls made of glass and concrete, high enough to satisfy the requirements of the Association of Zoos & Aquariums. The previous walls were almost 4 feet short of the standard.

headline: News Or Nancy Grace? Headline News Viewers Have Voted With Their Remotes
text: Three years after the attorney-turned-television-personality Nancy Grace helped Headline News reinvent its prime time line-up, the verdict is in: viewers prefer views to news, at least at night.

headline: City Warns of Fraud in Tax Preparers’ Loans
text: A city investigation into fraudulent and illegal practices by the income-tax preparation industry has, in its first six weeks, identified more than 500 violations, including misleading or illegal advertisements in newspapers and misrepresentations concerning so-called refund anticipation loans. The number of violations so far rose by 75 percent from the same period a year ago, officials said.

headline: Soccer Fever Fails to Grip Hawaii
text: I would love to be able to tell you that the state of Hawaii is gripped by soccer fever this week. Unfortunately, the first two games of the Pan-Pacific Championship Wednesday night drew few fans to Aloha Stadium.

headline: What Will the Season Bring for Duke and Indiana?
text: Indiana and Duke have long been two of the preeminent programs in men’s college basketball. The past week or so, however, will not be looked upon fondly by the fans of either team.

headline: Rethinking Priorities
text: Saturn wants its image to reflect a new approach to building cars.

headline: A Different Kind of Woman
text: Cadillac promotes the virtues of cupholders and the women who like them.

headline: Veteran Returns to Oversee Risk at Morgan Stanley
text: As banks try to rebuild themselves amid the subprime mortgage meltdown, one of the mantras on everyone’s lips is risk management. Battered by $7.8 billion in trading losses incurred last year, Morgan Stanley is bolstering its own internal controls by appointing a former executive as a new overseer of risk.

headline: Macho Guys Soften Up for Oscar
text: After the writers strike, ABC ramps up its Oscar promotion.

headline: Desperately Seeking Fauxbama
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: Fish Wrapped in Romaine Leaves
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, poaches fish in lettuce for a simple and sophisticated entree.

headline: A Beatle’s Haunt, Cafe La Fortuna, to Close Its Doors
text: Two deaths brought about the decision to close Cafe La Fortuna, the three-decade-old cafe that attracted John Lennon, Yoko Ono and many other Upper West Side neighborhood residents with its outdoor garden, opera music and Italian desserts.The first death, which took place a few years ago, was of the longtime landlord, who had generously kept the rent for the space at 69 West 71st Street at a reasonable rate despite the escalating real estate costs in the neighborhood.

headline: The New York Philharmonic in Asia: Scenes From the Shanghai Grand Theater
text: Slide Show

headline: Is the End Near for El Duque?
text: Orlando Hernandez revealed something interesting this afternoon: that bunion surgery he had last October? Never happened (that’ll have to be fixed in the media guide). Instead, he had a tendon fixed in the second toe of his right foot. The toe, he said, was shortened, and he’s still trying to adjust and work on his balance when he pitches.

headline: A Curious Notice from a SPAC Under the Gun
text: When last we left Michael S. Gross, the former private equity executive was staring down a barrel at his special-purpose acquisition company. Marathon Acquisition had to make a deal by Feb. 25, or he would have to return the $300 million he has raised from investors.

headline: City Workers Object to ‘Palming’ the Clock
text: A group of city Parks Department workers said today that the agency’s intention to use palm scanners in place of time sheets is a violation of their privacy. The Parks Department is one of more than two dozen city agencies that is preparing to use — or has already began using -– the Bloomberg administration’s “CityTime” payroll plan, which includes the use of biometric devices such as palm scanners to collect workers’ start and end times.According to the city’s Office of Payroll Administration Web site, supervisors may choose to place the scanners near the entrance of an office, allowing an agency to record when employee arrive at work and leave for the day.

headline: Microsoft Open to Sharing
text: CNBC interviews Tom Robertson of Microsoft, who discusses his company's decision to open its vault of software secrets to outside developers.

headline: Simon Set to Return
text: Islanders Coach Ted Nolan just said that left wing Chris Simon, who has finished his N.H.L. record 30-game suspension, will be in the lineup Thursday against the Tampa Bay Lightning, the first game in which he is eligible to play.

headline: City Announces 52 New Schools
text: The New York City schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein today, announced that 52 new schools will open in September. But the average parent or student would not necessarily see all 52 schools as “new.” Of the total, 25 will replace schools that are being phased out, 12 will open in new school buildings constructed to alleviate crowding and the remaining 15 will open in underused school buildings or school buildings where schools are being permanently reduced in size.

headline: Soft Serve | Chanel’s Chocolate Phone, Ikea Chic, Diamonds For Slashers
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.

headline: Roots of the Embassy Attack
text: No, the photos are not of John McCain supporters outside my door here but rather Serbian demonstrators who have “attacked the United States Embassy and set part of it ablaze on Thursday as tens of thousands of angry Serbs took to the streets of Belgrade to protest Kosovo’s declaration of independence.”

headline: Bill Clinton: Texas and Ohio or Bust
text: While Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign has been signaling how critical the Texas and Ohio primaries are, Bill Clinton took that a step further, suggesting during a campaign stop in Texas that the two states are must wins.

headline: U.S. Table Tennis, Beijing Style
text: For years, Wang Chen was one of the best table tennis players in China, but never competed in the Olympics. Now, as a U.S. citizen, she will.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Versace
text: (Alessandro Garofalo/Reuters)

headline: Remains of a Satellite: Pentagon’s One-Hit Wonder
text: The questions began shortly after the Pentagon announced its intention to shoot down a falling satellite, and they continued afterward, sometimes in circles: the threat of the 1,000 pounds of hydrazine, the heavy diplomatic costs, the video released today, and more.

headline: Buying Votes
text: There is another election campaign going on, other than the one that is getting all the publicity. And in a perfectly legal way, it looks as if somebody was buying votes in that election today.

headline: Submit Questions for Oliver Sacks
text: To follow  last week’s post, “Patterns,” and the comments it generated, Dr. Sacks has offered to take questions from readers. (Readers should submit their questions as comments to this post, not to “Patterns.”) Please note that Dr. Sacks will select the questions he will answer.

headline: The Week Ahead
text: Alison Smale, of the International Herald Tribune, discusses events in the world this week.

headline: Weekend in New York
text: Seth Kugel explores three of New York's ethnic grocery stores.

headline: Madonna Ends Apartment Dispute
text: Madonna has reportedly settled her lawsuit with a New York co-op board, which refused to allow her to buy her neighbor’s apartment. “I bought the apartment upstairs, so now everything’s A-OK,” she told New York magazine.

headline: McCain Told He Must Take Public Money
text: A bank loan that Senator John McCain took out late last year to keep his campaign for the Republican nomination afloat financially is now complicating his desire to withdraw from the public financing program for his primary bid.

headline: Bourbon Apple Cake
text: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, lets a sweet, buttery apple cake have a drink.

headline: Screen Test: George Clooney
text: Exclusive interview with George Clooney.

headline: Great paper titles
text: Unfortunately, I missed the seminar. But from Princeton’s Office of Population Research:

headline: Now Screening | George Clooney
Early Voting in Texas
text: Early voting in Texas is on track to break records, especially among Democrats. After only two days of early voting, according to data from the Texas Secretary of State, early voting totals after only two days are two-thirds the total after two weeks of early voting in 2004.

headline: Live Blogging the Texas Showdown
text: Wrapup:  Maybe we were expecting too much — an intergalactic showdown. Instead, it was more of a chess game, with each side moving forward and occasionally knocking off the other’s pieces. Instead of ending in checkmate, they ended with a hands-across-the-water moment.

headline: Names from the Combine: Shane Longest
text: INDIANAPOLIS — Of all the players paraded through the media room today at the N.F.L. scouting combine, Shane Longest was my favorite.Puns? Way too easy. Longest is – surprise, surprise – a punter and kicker from St. Xavier in Illinois. He told reporters Thursday his longest made field goal in a game was from 55 yards. He also said that during practice he once hit a 75-yard field goal – the, um, longest I have ever heard of.

headline: Roasted Tomato Soup
text: Mark Bittman and a guest celebrity chef make an off-season tomato soup.

headline: The Med Scare
text: At the end of my last column, I wondered about the purpose served by the narrative of the disastrously overmedicated American. I’ve been pondering this question as it relates to children for the better part of the past four years.

headline: Vows: Courtney & Michael
text: Courtney Wisotsky and Michael Weinstein are avid runners who were  once told "those who run together, stay together."

headline: An Eco-Chat With Ed Begley Jr.
text: Times environment reporter Andrew C. Revkin talks with actor Ed Begley Jr. about living green.

headline: Some Suspect Meat Used in School Lunches, U.S. Says
text: Days after the largest beef recall, the Agriculture Department said Thursday that more than a third of the meat had been used in federal nutrition programs, including school lunches.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: Security Council Weighs New Sanctions on Iran
text: UNITED NATIONS  The Security Council on Thursday began formal consideration of a new resolution on Iran’s nuclear program that imposes restrictions on cargo to and from Iran, travel bans, the freezing of assets for people involved in the program and tightened monitoring of Iranian financial institutions.

headline: Kenya’s Glimmer of Hope
text: After weeks of horrific tribal violence, Kenya’s rival leaders appear to be closing in on a political deal. That is the only hope for stopping the killing and the only chance for salvaging a country that until recently was one of Africa’s most stable and prosperous.

headline: Georgia Claims a Sliver of the Tennessee River
text: ATLANTA  WHEREAS, in 1818 when the border between Georgia and Tennessee was marked by surveyors, mistakes were made that deprived Georgia of a sliver of the Tennessee River.

headline: Acropolis Museum to Open in September
text: The new Acropolis museum in Athens will open in September, the Greek culture minister announced on Wednesday. “In one month, we are to finish moving all the pieces from the old museum,” the minister, Michalis Liapis, said during a visit to the site, Agence France-Presse reported. The new museum, above, designed by the Franco-Swiss architect Bernard Tschumi, is a three-level, 270,000-square-foot structure, including a room on the top floor with an area reserved for the Elgin Marbles, now in the British Museum in London. Greece has long sought the return of the friezes. The new Acropolis museum was to have been completed for the 2004 Olympics in Greece but encountered bureaucratic and technical setbacks.

headline: A Window That Reflected a Golden Age Comes Down at Kennedy Airport
text: Back when Kennedy International Airport was called Idlewild and the jet age was just blooming, airports were considered elegant, even majestic destinations.

headline: Rev. James E. Orange, 65, Aide to Dr. King, Dies
text: The Rev. James E. Orange, an aide to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. whose arrest in Alabama in 1965 is considered one of the catalysts for the historic Selma-to-Montgomery march, died on Saturday in Atlanta, his hometown. He was 65.

headline: Qualms Over Clean Energy That Would Come From 12 Stories Up
text: WAYNE, N.J.  Hamburg Turnpike, a six-mile stretch dotted with strip malls and low-rise office buildings, does not seem like the place for innovation, and many people who live here seem just fine with that.

headline: Putting Civility and Sportsmanship Back in Game, if Not in the Stands
text: The bench area at college basketball games had become a maelstrom, with coaches ranting along the sidelines, assistant coaches jumping up and down exhorting players, and officiating crews engaging in heated exchanges with coaches after disputed calls on the floor. The fans rode along with the same passion.

headline: Former Concentration Camp Guard Dies
text: Erna Wallisch, a former concentration camp guard who was under investigation for war crimes, died in a Vienna hospital last week, Austrian prosecutors said. Investigators had reopened the case against the 86-year-old woman earlier this year after new evidence from Polish witnesses suggested that she was involved in the murder of inmates in the Majdanek concentration camp near the city of Lublin, Poland. Mrs. Wallisch, who ranked seventh on the Simon Wiesenthal Center’s list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals, evaded prosecution in the 1970s due to a lack of evidence linking her directly to Nazi genocide.

headline: Knee-Jerk Calls to Act Follow a Brutal Crime
text: Every once in a while something happens that is so awful, it leads immediately to cries of “there ought to be a law,” because everyone knows that passing laws is how to cure all of society’s ills. We have such a situation now after last week’s shocking murder of Kathryn Faughey, the psychologist who was stabbed repeatedly in her office on the Upper East Side.

headline: Rescues for Homeowners in Debt Weighed
text: WASHINGTON  Prodded in part by some of the nation’s biggest banks, the Bush administration and Congress are considering costly new proposals for the government to rescue hundreds of thousands of homeowners whose mortgages are higher than the value of their houses.

headline: Magazines Up for Sale, Including Variety
text: Variety, Publishers Weekly and dozens of other trade publications are going up for sale as the publishing company Reed Elsevier looks to get out of the uncertain advertising market.

headline: Lineup Confirmed for All Points West
text: Radiohead and Jack Johnson will perform as headliners at the inaugural All Points West music festival in New Jersey this summer, organizers confirmed on Thursday. The three-day event, representing the first major East Coast venture by the concert promoter behind California’s taste-making Coachella festival, will take place Aug. 8 to 10 at Liberty State Park in Jersey City. Radiohead will play the first two nights, Mr. Johnson the third. The lineup, announced yesterday by the promoter, Goldenvoice, also includes Underworld, Kings of Leon, Cat Power, the Roots, Animal Collective and Black Kids. The promoter’s attempt to establish a beachhead near Manhattan, which has lacked for major festivals with multiple acts, highlights the influence such events are gaining with live-music fans across the country. Tickets for All Points West go on sale Feb. 29 through Ticketmaster.com; one-day passes are $89, three-day passes $258.

headline: When Bankers Fear to Act
text: Where is the next J. P. Morgan?

headline: Don’t Rerun That ’70s Show
text: Will the next president be the second coming of Jimmy Carter? Given Thursday’s economic headlines, full of dire warnings about the return of 1970s-style stagflation, you might think so.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: Enduring Image Leads to Enduring Dispute
text: Tommie Smith and John Carlos were at the Black National Theatre in Harlem on Wednesday. The event was sponsored by Nike as part of its Olympic year celebration of Black History Month. Nike chose six key Olympic moments to celebrate; Smith’s and Carlos’s moment on the victory stand at the 1968 Mexico City Games was one of the six.

headline: Outdated Prices Blamed in Credit Suisse Error
text: LONDON  The surprise $2.85 billion write-down at Credit Suisse this week underscored the difficulty banks face in valuing complex investments. But the cause of the blunder may be simple: traders at the bank used old prices.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the sale of some parts of the chef Emeril Lagasse’s franchise to Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia misstated which of his two Food Network television programs was older. “Essence of Emeril,” which had its debut in 1994, was Mr. Lagasse’s first program on the cable network  not “Emeril Live,” which ran from 1997 to 2007. (“Essence of Emeril” went off the air in 1996 and returned in 2000 in a new form. It continues to be produced.)

headline: Fraud Unit Seeks Europe Report
text: BRUSSELS  Europe’s antifraud investigators on Thursday demanded a copy of a confidential European Parliament report that one lawmaker says reveals such abuses in the way members are paid that some of his colleagues could be prosecuted.

headline: ‘Knicks in 60’: Too Much Failure to Edit It All Out
text: With its “Knicks in 60” replay vehicle, MSG has a tool with which it can alter history. A loss doesn’t have to look so awful, a win can look a smidgen better through deft editing from two and a half hours to 60 minutes.

headline: Teo Macero, 82, Record Producer, Dies
text: Teo Macero, a record producer, composer and saxophonist most famous for his role in producing a series of albums by Miles Davis in the late 1960s and early 1970s, including editing that almost amounted to creating compositions after the recordings, died on Tuesday in Riverhead, N.Y. He was 82 and lived in Quogue, N.Y.

headline: New Claim of Taping Emerges Against Patriots
text: INDIANAPOLIS  The Patriots’ pattern of illicitly videotaping the signals of opposing N.F.L. coaches began in Coach Bill Belichick’s first preseason with the team in 2000, a former Patriots player said. The information was put to use in that year’s regular-season opener against the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, Belichick’s debut as New England’s coach.

headline: Agency Confronts Iran With Evidence on Weapons
text: WASHINGTON  The International Atomic Energy Agency said Friday that it had confronted Iran for the first time with evidence supplied by the United States and other countries that strongly suggested the country had experimented with technology to make a nuclear weapon, but that Iranian officials dismissed the documents obtained from an Iranian scientist as “baseless and fabricated.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Feb. 12 about a lawsuit challenging a new campaign finance law in New York City, filed by a lawyer who successfully challenged Vermont’s campaign finance restrictions before the United States Supreme Court, misstated, in some copies, the limit per donor for each election in statewide races in Vermont, which the justices said would prevent some candidates from getting their message out. It was $400, not $200.

headline: Northeast Hit by Major Winter Storm
text: A major winter storm struck the northeast Friday, with snowfall causing massive delays at airports, closing schools and snarling traffic on streets and highways in the region.

headline: Think Summer (a Warning)
text: LET’S start with the bad news. Thanks to the weakness of the dollar, staying close to home this summer is probably going to be more popular than jetting off to Europe  which means everyone you can think of will be competing for nearby rentals. The good news, however, is that during the past few years, the number of rentals on the market has shot up, so there’s more to go around. The even better news? If you’re just starting to think about securing a spot for the season, it’s not too late.

headline: French Bank’s Troubles Now Include Record Loss
text: PARIS  Société Générale said Thursday that the rogue trading uncovered last month, combined with significant write-offs of United States subprime mortgage investments, had pushed it to a record loss in the quarter.

headline: A Journey Shaped by a Guitar
text: EVEN though Nazareth, Pa., isn’t quite the holy city its namesake is, pilgrims with a musical bent still go there every weekday in search of a potentially spiritual experience. They head to a quaint brick building, lured by the promise of taking a tour at the C. F. Martin & Company guitar factory.

headline: Retired Priest Sentenced for Bilking Two Churches
text: RICHMOND, Va.  A retired Roman Catholic priest was sentenced Thursday to more than five years in prison for bilking two churches out of hundreds of thousands of dollars while he led a double life as a husband and father.

headline: Art in Review
text: NAYLAND BLAKE

headline: Renovated T.W.A. Terminal to Reopen as JetBlue Portal
text: The Trans World Airlines terminal at Kennedy International Airport  that abandoned embodiment of the “Come Fly With Me” era of jet-setting  would reopen this year under a plan advanced on Thursday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

headline: Bank Chief Says Japan’s Economy Resilient
text: TOKYO (Reuters)  The governor of the Bank of Japan, Toshihiko Fukui, said on Friday that the global economy continued to expand but that a slowdown in the United States, if it deepens, could affect growth in other parts of the world.

headline: A Google Competition, With a Robotic Moon Landing as a Goal
text: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earth’s barren cousin.

headline: Classic Beach, but Much More
