text: WITH its classic amusement pier, glittering bay and surfers bobbing on swells, Santa Monica was a perfect setting for “Baywatch.” But take a short walk inland, and this city on the edge of Los Angeles reveals itself as more than a stereotypical beach town.

headline: A Table Tennis Star in China Now Uses Her Paddle for the U.S.
text: Wang Chen is one of two American table tennis players ranked high enough in the world to automatically qualify for the Olympics this summer in Beijing. Yet she has no coach and she receives no direct financing from the sport’s national governing body.

headline: Time Appeals Libel Ruling Over Suharto in Indonesia
text: Time magazine filed an appeal Thursday of an Indonesian court ruling that awarded former President Suharto more than $100 million in damages over an article about what the United Nations calls one of the most gargantuan thefts of our time.

headline: Triple Threat
text: This three-part horror movie directed by a trio of Atlanta filmmakers is set during the collapse of Terminus, a fictional city whose citizens are being driven to rage by a mysterious signal that jams televisions and phones.

headline: Two Brit Awards for Arctic Monkeys
text: For the second consecutive year, the Arctic Monkeys won honors for best British group and best British album (“Favourite Worst Nightmare”) when the Brits, Britain’s annual pop music awards, were handed out on Wednesday night in London, Agence France-Press reported. Other winners of two accolades were the re-formed pop group Take That (best live act and best British single, for “Shine”) and the American rockers Foo Fighters (best international group and best international album, “Echoes, Silence, Patience & Grace”). Paul McCartney received an award for outstanding contribution to music.

headline: The Parks, He Knows. But the Trees? Don’t Ask.
text: ANY doubts whether Julius Spiegel, Brooklyn’s commissioner of parks since 1981 and ostensibly forever, is capable of overt bossiness are dispelled the instant one squeezes into the passenger seat of his city-issued Prius. “Buckle your seat belt,” he orders, unfurling the suave Canadian accent he’s retained since moving here from Montreal four decades ago to earn a master’s degree in sociology from the New School for Social Research.

headline: Donors Worried by Clinton Campaign Spending
text: This article was reported by Michael Luo, Jo Becker and Patrick Healy and was written by Mr. Healy.

headline: High School’s the Same; the Drugs Have Changed
text: Ever since he played a forlorn 11-year-old boy in the insufferable 2001 tear-jerker “Hearts in Atlantis,” the Russian-born actor Anton Yelchin has seemed destined to step into the shoes of Hollywood’s favorite quiz kid, Matthew Broderick. And in the precociously articulate title character of “Charlie Bartlett,” he may have found a contemporary equivalent of Mr. Broderick’s beloved hooky-playing high school trickster, Ferris Bueller.

headline: For Founder’s Grandson, On-the-Job Education
text: TOYOTA CITY, Japan   A verdigris-coated bust of the company founder Kiichiro Toyoda greets visitors to Toyota’s headquarters building here.

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: At Toyota, a Global Giant Reaches for Agility
text: TOYOTA CITY, Japan  At Toyota’s training center inside its Motomachi assembly complex here, workers use golf balls to limber up their fingers before they learn new tasks on the factory floor.

headline: Slain in Prison, but Once Celebrated as a Fugitive
text: The chronicle of Larry Davis was over on Thursday. Stabbed repeatedly in his arms, head, back, legs and chest by another inmate wielding a nine-inch shank, he fell in the yard of an upstate prison, and thereupon hangs the strange tale of a notorious killer, the antihero of another era of New York City.

headline: Mangini Assesses State of the Jets
text: After his first season in 2006, Jets Coach Eric Mangini arrived at the N.F.L. scouting combine with a 10-6 record, a playoff appearance and status as the coaching Mangenius. He named quarterback Chad Pennington his starter during a news conference. He also repeatedly noted that each season was different than the next.

headline: McCain Loan Complicates Financing of Campaign
text: A bank loan that Senator John McCain took out late in 2007 to keep his presidential campaign afloat is complicating his desire to withdraw from public financing for his primary effort.

headline: Waterboarding Approval Focus of Justice Investigation
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department revealed on Friday that its internal ethics office is investigating the department’s legal approval of waterboarding of Al Qaeda suspects by the Central Intelligence Agency and is likely to make public an unclassified version of its report.

headline: A Monet Is Back on the Market
text: A MONET IS BACK

headline: Pakistanis Strike Political Accord
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The two main opposition parties that won Pakistan’s elections this week announced Thursday that they had set aside their differences and would form a government, further isolating President Pervez Musharraf, America’s favored ally here.

headline: Italy Follows Trail of Secret South American Abductions
text: BUENOS AIRES  In an unusually sweeping investigation, Italian authorities are seeking to prosecute former top officials in seven South American countries for their roles in a secret operation in the 1970s and 1980s by the region’s security forces to crush left-wing political dissent.

headline: Magazine Appeals Ruling That It Libeled Suharto
text: BANGKOK  Time Magazine filed an appeal Thursday in Indonesia of a court ruling awarding former President Suharto more than $100 million in damages over an article about what the United Nations calls one of the most gargantuan thefts of our time.

headline: Joe Louis and Harlem, Connecting Again in a Police Athletic League Gym
text: It was the evening of June 22, 1938, and nearly everyone in Harlem was doing the same thing. Huddled around radios on their fire escapes and roofs, in their kitchens and living rooms, people were listening to the heavyweight boxing match between Joe Louis and Max Schmeling.

headline: Earnings Up Across the Board at Nestlé
text: VEVEY, Switzerland (AP)  Nestlé, the food and drink company, reported a 16 percent rise in full-year profit Thursday on growth across all segments.

headline: 5-Year-Old Boy Dies in Queens Apartment Fire
text: A 5-year-old Queens boy died Thursday in a fire that broke out after he had apparently been left alone in his family’s locked apartment, the authorities said.

headline: One Assassination Attempt, a Multitude of Perspectives
text: “Vantage Point,” a gimmick in search of a point, is nothing if not, er, timely. Set in the picturesque Spanish city of Salamanca (otherwise known as Mexico City), this jigsaw puzzle exploits a repellent conceit  the shooting of an American president (William Hurt, effectively insincere)  in a vague attempt to explore questions of narrative and subjectivity (like “Rashomon”) through the box-office-friendly form of a thriller (like the "Bourne” flicks). Instead of pushing the story forward, the filmmakers instead repeatedly return to the crime, or rather to a handful of witnesses, all of whom saw the same exact event from critically different angles.

headline: Protesters Attack U.S. Embassy in Belgrade
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  Demonstrators attacked the United States Embassy and set part of it ablaze on Thursday as tens of thousands of angry Serbs took to the streets of Belgrade to protest Kosovo’s declaration of independence.

headline: A Plan for a New Riverfront Park Faces a Struggle
text: Federal, state and city officials, as well as several civic organizations, expressed support on Thursday for plans for a waterfront park to be built in the shadow of the United Nations.

headline: China Criticizes U.S. Missile Strike
text: HONG KONG  The Chinese government objected Thursday to the American missile strike against a dying United States spy satellite over the Pacific Ocean, warning that the United States Navy’s action could threaten security in outer space

headline: An Oscars Crystal Ball
text: YOU could be forgiven for arriving poolside for the Oscars in tardy fashion this year. With the brutal writers’ strike and the most interesting primary political season in a half-century, perhaps the most frequent answer to the question “What will win best picture this year?” is “Who cares?”

headline: The Cost of Collusion, Paid in Phony Currency
text: The Italian writer Primo Levi, looking back on his time in Auschwitz, observed that in the Nazi death camps “the worst, that is, the fittest, survived.” “The Counterfeiters,” a brisk, tough new movie from the Austrian director Stefan Ruzowitzky, is in some ways an illustration of this axiom. Like most films about the Holocaust it is a survivor’s tale, and its protagonist, at least at first, seems long on guile and short on scruple. He is Salomon Sorowitsch, a master forger and a fixture of the Berlin underworld, and his yellow star is overlaid with a green triangle marking his status as a “habitual criminal.”

headline: Spare Times
text: Museums and Sites

headline: Sun Valley
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Pop and Rock Listings
text: POP

headline: Rustic Retreats
text: Cabins in off-the-grid settings are available at several locations in the Northeast.

headline: Hockey Fan, and Investor, Buys Bauer From Nike
text: OTTAWA  As a child in Montreal, W. Graeme Roustan regularly received hand-me-down Bauer hockey skates from his older brother, and he has continued to buy Bauer Supreme skates ever since.

headline: With Strike’s End, Oscars Regain Marketing Allure
text: A TELEVISION show on Sunday will bring into millions of homes subjects like war, betrayal, corporate malfeasance, murder, greed, illegal drugs and unwed motherhood.

headline: Simon Ends His 30-Game Ban and Rejoins the Surging Isles
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Islanders fans did not shower Chris Simon with love when he took his first shift in more than two months on Thursday night. A thin round of applause was peppered with catcalls, and he was booed when he first touched the puck.

headline: Deal to Share Power in Kenya Appears in Reach
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya’s rival political parties have nearly completed a deal to end the crisis that has kept this country on edge for almost two months, with the government agreeing to create a prime minister position, one of the opposition’s chief demands, a high-ranking government official said Thursday.

headline: Roster Change at 'Law & Order'
text: Detective Ed Green of the New York Police Department is turning in his shield. What that means is that Jesse L. Martin, above, is leaving the role he has played since 1999 on the NBC drama “Law & Order,” The Associated Press reported. An episode to be filmed in the spring will account for Green’s departure. Mr. Martin, who took a break from “Law & Order” to star in the 2005 film version of the Broadway musical “Rent,” is to portray the singer Marvin Gaye in the film “Sexual Healing,” scheduled to begin production in the spring, with James Gandolfini among his co-stars. Anthony Anderson, whose credits include the Fox television series “K-Ville,” FX’s “Shield” and the films “The Departed” and “Transformers,” was reported to be concluding negotiations with “Law & Order” to join the cast as the new partner for Detective Cyrus Lupo, played by Jeremy Sisto.

headline: Bankers Sentenced in Enron Fraud
text: Three British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months in prison each for their role in an Enron-related fraud.

headline: Doctor Says Exam of Girl Revealed Single Injury
text: An emergency room doctor who treated 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown for a cut on her forehead in November 2005, six weeks before she died, testified on Thursday at the murder trial of Nixzmary’s stepfather that no other injuries or signs of abuse were found at the time on the girl’s body.

headline: Covers and Classical Moves From a Bluegrass Virtuoso
text: To call the 27-year-old mandolin virtuoso Chris Thile the Les Paul of his instrument describes only one aspect of a musician who could just as rightly be compared to a great classical guitarist. Although Mr. Thile, an alumnus of Nickel Creek, can toss off witty, jazz-flavored bluegrass solos with breathtaking velocity, his technique is merely the starting point for serious experiments in genre bending that incorporate music ranging from Bach to Radiohead.

headline: A Pianist Bids Farewell With Schubertian Grace
text: The audience at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, which spilled over into stage seats, would have been happy to let the ovations for Alfred Brendel go on and on. But after a substantive program devoted to the Classical masters he has championed and three encores, Mr. Brendel crossed his arms over his chest in gratitude and signaled that that was it. The time had come. With one more bow, he left the stage and ended the New York chapter of his towering 60-year career.

headline: Professor at Columbia to Keep Job
text: Columbia University’s Teachers College will not dismiss Madonna G. Constantine, the professor it charged with plagiarizing numerous works by another professor and two former students.

headline: High School Star Lacking in Height, Not in Range
text: The last 3-point shot, his coach insisted, came from about 35 feet. Erving Walker was so far behind the arc that his high school coach, Bob Oliva, later said his star guard’s backside was inches from the team’s bench.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A film review last Friday about this year’s Oscar-nominated shorts misidentified the animation technique used in Aleksandr Petrov’s “My Love.” It was hand-drawn using oil paint on glass, not pastels.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about the big legal bills being run up by New York City and a state authority over a criminal investigation into the fatal fire at the former Deutsche Bank building last August referred incorrectly to the two law firms hired by the city and the authority, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The law firms  Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel, and Dechert L.L.P.  are full-service firms; their practices are not limited to criminal defense.

headline: If OTB Goes, So Would a Relic of a Grittier City
text: The Off-Track Betting parlor on Seventh Avenue at 38th Street is a two-story affair, psychically as well as architecturally.

headline: Trading the World for a Cabin in the Woods
text: IT’S my first night in the cabin, and I can’t sleep. The quiet is too loud, as if I were holding a conch shell tight over each ear, and any sounds that do seep through  a wet bulge of snow sliding off a fir tree, the pop of a log in our blazing wood stove  send me tossing and turning, a skittish city mouse in the country.

headline: The Furor Over the McCain Report
text: To the Editor:

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A theater review last Friday about the musical “The Blue Flower,” at the West End Theater in Manhattan, misquoted part of a lyric that served as a response to a series of deaths and dislocations in the show. It should have been “All ships that are sailing/Will come again to port,” not “And ships that are sailing.”

headline: Dance Listings
text: DANCE

headline: Children in Poverty: There Is No Excuse
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeing MoMA’s Sculptures With a Distinctive Tool: Fingers
text: In their baseball caps and Timberlands, the five Tibetan young people giggling in the sculpture garden of the Museum of Modern Art on Wednesday might have been members of some kind of teen tour or youth group from abroad, chatting their way through yet another art museum, half-oblivious to its contents.

headline: Cheeky Hipsters in the Halls of Victorian Brigadiers
text: The Park Avenue Armory has been undergoing a striking makeover overseen by a dedicated conservancy. Last fall it was the backdrop for a performance involving a fleet of motorcycles by the emerging artist Aaron Young; next month it will serve as a satellite location for the Whitney Biennial. This weekend old and new coexist happily there at the Art Show, the annual fair held by the Art Dealers Association of America.

headline: More Down to Earth in the High Country
text: AT first sight, Edwards, high in the mountains of central Colorado, comes across as a jigsaw puzzle whose pieces don’t quite fit.

headline: No Recourse for the Injured
text: Consumers are already at the mercy of the all-too-fallible Food and Drug Administration. So it is especially disturbing that the Supreme Court ruled this week that patients injured by defective medical devices cannot sue for damages in state courts if the device was approved for marketing by the F.D.A. and made to the agency’s specifications.

headline: C.I.A. Used a British Island to Transport Terrorism Suspects
text: LONDON  In tones freighted with frustration, Britain’s foreign secretary, David Miliband, on Thursday told the House of Commons that “contrary to earlier explicit assurances” the Central Intelligence Agency had confirmed using an American-operated airfield on the British island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean for refuelling two American “rendition” flights carrying terrorism suspects in 2002.

headline: Hills Behind Gates
text: My wife, Julie, and my son and I live in Florida, but I was raised in the western mountains of New England, and that left me with a longing for the four seasons and a desire to introduce my son, Zachery, who is 12, to nature and hunting and fishing. So I set out to determine what the closest geographical location might be to build a second home at a high elevation. We chose South Carolina.

headline: Clinton and Obama Debate Once More, and Does It Matter?
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton saved what her campaign views as her personal best for last.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about plans to move and restore the Grange, Alexander Hamilton’s country home in Upper Manhattan, attributed an erroneous distinction to that home. At least one other house associated with Hamilton survives: the Schuyler Mansion in Albany (also known as the Pastures), where he was married. The Grange is not the only one associated with him that still exists.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Washington State’s presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the state’s nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one. (Go to Article)

headline: Scientists Measure What It Takes to Push a Single Atom
text: I.B.M. scientists have measured the force needed to nudge one atom.

headline: McCain Denies Aides’ Statements About Lobbyist
text: TOLEDO, Ohio  Senator John McCain on Thursday disputed an account in The New York Times that top advisers confronted him during his first presidential run with concerns about his ties to a female lobbyist.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Jan. 12 about jury selection in the murder trial of Cesar Rodriguez, a Brooklyn man accused of fatally beating his 7-year-old stepdaughter, Nixzmary Brown, referred incorrectly to Mr. Rodriguez’s courtroom attire. He wore handcuffs as he was led into and out of the courtroom while prospective jurors were absent; he was not wearing handcuffs, hidden beneath his leather jacket, in the presence of prospective jurors. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message the day the article ran; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Washington State’s presidential primary attributed an erroneous distinction to the state’s nominating system. Washington is one of several states that have both primaries and caucuses; it is not the only one.

headline: Rodriguez Says He Wasn’t Specific About Drug Tests
text: TAMPA, Fla.  A day after raising questions about himself by saying he had been tested for performance-enhancing drugs up to 10 times last season, Alex Rodriguez tried clarifying Thursday. While he declined to be specific, he did say that he had been tested more than once, but probably fewer than 10 times, the highest number he had cited Wednesday.

headline: In Chicago, the Elusive Genius of Tudor Revisited
text: CHICAGO  What are the two greatest ballets by Antony Tudor, often still credited with having invented the “psychological ballet”? Most dancegoers who know his work would vote for the two oldest to survive in performance: “Jardin aux Lilas” (1936)  or “Lilac Garden,” as the Joffrey Ballet and some other American companies call it  and “Dark Elegies” (1937). It’s fascinating, therefore, to see these together on a triple bill that the Joffrey has mounted to commemorate Tudor, who was born in England 100 years ago but lived and worked in the United States from 1939 on.

headline: Inspiration Lives on Where Writers Dwelled
text: I WAS wandering down an unassuming street in London, where I lived in the early 1990s, when I came upon an otherwise-ordinary Georgian house that proclaimed itself to be the home of Charles Dickens. The front door was propped open, and a small sign advertised the visiting hours and entry fee. I was trying to write my own first novel then, and had been reading the great British novelists  from Jane Austen to P. D. James, from Martin Amis to, yes, Charles Dickens  for both inspiration and insight into my adopted country. But it had never occurred to me that Dickens might be my virtual neighbor.

headline: She Floats Through the Air, Trailed by Angst and Unease
text: Probably you’re familiar with the phrase “meet cute.” The couple in Carla Cantrelle’s “Looking Up” don’t, but the play does end cute, as it were.

headline: Idol Tops Its Rivals
text: As the top 12 female contestants competed on “American Idol” on Wednesday, Fox once again easily dominated the night’s ratings as 28.7 million viewers tuned in to a two-hour edition of the show, Nielsen estimated. Also on Wednesday, the 10th season of CW’s “America’s Next Top Model” made its debut at 8 p.m., drawing an underwhelming 3.8 million viewers. Although the modeling competition was the runner-up to “American Idol” with the night’s second-highest ratings among adults 18 to 34, it also became the third-lowest-rated premiere of the series ever among adults 18 to 49. CW finished fifth for the night but not far behind ABC and CBS, which broadcast repeats following “Big Brother” at 8 (5.2 million). ABC edged past CBS for third place in the 18-to-49 set, faring best at 9 p.m. with “Supernanny” (6 million). NBC ranked second, leading the 10 p.m. hour with “Law & Order” (10.8 million).

headline: Another Casualty of High Rents on the Upper West Side
text: Two deaths brought about the decision to close Cafe La Fortuna, a beloved three-decade-old cafe that drew John Lennon, Yoko Ono and other Upper West Side residents with its garden, opera music and Italian desserts.

headline: A New Direction With Twin-Tip Skis
text: O.K., raise your hand if you have used your skis to fly off a jump backward this winter.

headline: With Sinker in Tow, a Journey Begins
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Once in a while, Eddie Kunz will insert into his DVD player a disc of a baseball game played June 13, 2005. He fast forwards to the juicy part, the sixth inning, and he watches himself, a 19-year-old freshman at the time, throw the biggest pitch in the history of Oregon State’s baseball program.

headline: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
text: The last time a senior Republican senator secured his party’s presidential nomination it wasn’t long before he concluded it would be better to become an ex-senator for the White House stretch run.

headline: Arizona: A Run Reconsidered
text: Less than two weeks after announcing plans to retire, Representative John Shadegg said he would run for re-election in November after all. Mr. Shadegg, 58, Republican of Arizona, said he changed his mind after 146 House Republicans signed a letter last week asking him to reconsider. He said in a statement that he also received a similar letter from 33 conservative groups urging him to stay.

headline: Down by the Blue Purple Yellow Red Water
text: “Look!” says the man for whom seeing is everything, in a voice that both commands and beseeches. “Look!”

headline: Correction: All Nothing, All the Time
text: A credit for an illustration with an article last Friday about visiting a B&B for a do-nothing getaway misspelled the given name of the artist. He is Christoph Niemann not Christophe.

headline: German Bank Offering Aid for Its Troubled Investments
text: FRANKFURT  Dresdner Bank said on Thursday that it would bail out its investment vehicle for complex financial products, the latest bank to take the step to avoid a forced sale of assets into turbulent markets.

headline: Cars and Gunpowder and Plenty of Noise
text: The Guggenheim Museum’s retrospective of the work of the Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang is nothing if not action packed. The galleries are so rife with the sound of explosions and the sight of suspended objects and wildlife (stuffed) that it might almost be a movie set for some new martial-arts spy thriller. Perhaps “The Air-Bourne Aesthetic: Writhing Tigers, Hurtling Wolves.”

headline: Detainees at Guantánamo Fight Further Appeal Delay
text: WASHINGTON  Lawyers for a group of Guantánamo detainees who are appealing their classification as enemy combatants have told the Supreme Court that it would be “unconscionable” to grant the Bush administration’s request for further delay in producing the records necessary for the appeals to move forward.

headline: Fairness on the Farm
text: Against all odds, there is still hope that Congress will produce a halfway decent farm bill, one that increases spending for underfunded programs like food stamps and conservation while decreasing subsidies to rich farmers who have never had it so good. The reason for hope is President Bush, who has been on the right side of the farm issue from the beginning and is threatening to veto any measure that resembles the stinkers produced by the House and Senate last year.

headline: Renzo Piano to Design Greek Opera House
text: Renzo Piano has been chosen as the architect for a new national opera house and cultural park in Athens, Agence France-Presse reported. The Niarchos Foundation, financing the project, said on Thursday that Mr. Piano, co-designer of the Pompidou Center in Paris and designer of The New York Times building, will also create a cultural complex, including a new national library, surrounding the opera house on the site of a former racetrack that was leveled and used as a bus depot for the 2004 Olympics. The estimated cost of the project is $441 million.

headline: Violence Against Women in War Zones
text: To the Editor:

headline: 7 Birdies Not Enough to Save Mickelson
text: MARANA, Ariz.  After two rounds of the Accenture Match Play Championship, the fundamental truths about match play in golf remain intact. A golfer can play very well and lose  ask Phil Mickelson, whose seven birdies Thursday were not enough to defeat Stuart Appleby; a golfer can play not so well and win  ask K. J. Choi, who beat Ian Poulter in 19 holes despite shooting one over par in his last 16 holes.

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings
text: CLASSICAL

headline: Omar Sharif Ordered to Pay Damages
text: A $318,190 damage judgment was entered against Omar Sharif, below, after he failed to appear on Tuesday for a deposition in Los Angeles County Superior Court in a suit brought by a parking lot attendant, Juan Luis Ochoa Anderson, who claimed Mr. Sharif had punched him, The Associated Press reported. According to the lawsuit, Mr. Sharif, 75, who played leading roles in the films “Doctor Zhivago” and “Lawrence of Arabia,” was belligerent and intoxicated, calling Mr. Anderson, a Guatemalan immigrant, a “stupid Mexican” and punching him for refusing a 20-euro note in the 2005 episode outside a steak house in Beverly Hills. Last year Mr. Sharif pleaded no contest to misdemeanor battery and was ordered to take an anger management course. Calls to his press agent and lawyer were not immediately returned.

headline: Behind the Mask of Civility, the Battles Rage On
text: Jacques Rivette’s “Duchess of Langeais” seems to me a nearly impeccable work of art  beautiful, true, profound. Based on Balzac’s 1834 short novel and set against the French Restoration  Napoleon is in exile and a Bourbon king again sits on the throne  it traces how a passionate affair of the heart curdles into cruelty and obsession. Originally titled “Don’t Touch the Ax” (a threat guaranteed to make noble necks twitch), it is a story about manners, language, power and society and the bodies caught in their grip. “Life,” one character observes, “is simply a complication of interests and feelings.” Art too.

headline: One of the Biggest Sinners to Play in Sin City
text: Jose Manuel Vigoa Perez, one of thousands of refugees who fled Cuba on the Mariel boatlift, arrived in Las Vegas on a blistering hot afternoon in July 1980. The bright lights and the hectic atmosphere came as a shock. “I felt like I had walked through a time tunnel and was in another world and dimension,” he later recalled.

headline: Go on a Savings Spree
text: CONGRESS has passed and President Bush has signed legislation to rescue the economy from the jaws of recession. The $168 billion package, which includes an effort to increase consumer spending by distributing $600 rebates to individuals, can be faulted in many ways: with two wars and a budget deficit the nation can’t really afford it; it will probably arrive too late in the business cycle to actually make a difference; and the near-universal aspect of the rebates doesn’t make much sense. But the most fundamentally troubling thing is the premise that while consumer overspending got us into this mess, more will get us out of it. This is akin to the old saw about curing a hangover with the hair of the dog that bit you.

headline: Arab Leaders Say the Two-State Proposal Is in Peril
text: CAIRO  Arab leaders will threaten to rescind their offer of full relations with Israel in exchange for a complete Israeli withdrawal from occupied lands unless Israel gives a positive response to their initiative, indicating the Arab states’ growing disillusionment with the prospects of a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: La Punta Papagayo and the Kootenai
text: La Punta Papagayo

headline: Arizona Congressman Indicted in Land Swap Scam
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Rick Renzi, a Republican who represents a vast region of Arizona, has been indicted on charges of using his office to enrich himself through a complex land swap scam, federal prosecutors announced on Friday in Phoenix.

headline: Now a Reminder From Mr. Cunningham
text: Another shoe dropped this week in a major Congressional corruption scandal. Defense contractor Brent Wilkes was sentenced to 12 years in prison for bribing former Representative Randy Cunningham, a California Republican who was once a high-flying appropriator. Mr. Cunningham had already been sent to prison for eight years for accepting millions in cash, antiques and luxury vacations from Mr. Wilkes.

headline: Struggling but Grateful, Liberia Welcomes Bush
text: MONROVIA, Liberia  It has been 30 years since a sitting president of the United States has visited this West African nation, and in the decades since, rebel generals with nicknames like Butt Naked laid waste to this seaside country, raping and plundering, and a brutal warlord named Charles G. Taylor campaigned for the presidency under the slogan, “He killed my ma, he killed my pa, but I will vote for him anyway.”

headline: Pakistan Shift Could Curtail Drone Strikes
text: WASHINGTON  American officials reached a quiet understanding with Pakistan’s leader last month to intensify secret strikes against suspected terrorists by pilotless aircraft launched in Pakistan, senior officials in both governments say. But the prospect of changes in Pakistan’s government has the Bush administration worried that the new operations could be curtailed.

headline: A Final Hurrah for a Pioneering Dealer in Qing Textile Art
text: A FINAL HURRAH

headline: The Soul in the New Machines
text: Bioengineered crossbreeds. Temperamental robots. Spermatozoa imprinted with secret texts. Although the fascination with organic form has been around since the Renaissance, we have now entered an age in which designers and architects are drawing their inspiration from hidden patterns in nature rather than from pretty leaves or snowflakes. The results can be scary, but they may also hold the key to paradise.

headline: Clinton Says Debate Remark Not Meant as Farewell
text: DALLAS  With the mood of her campaign darkened by the death of a motorcycle officer escorting her motorcade Friday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton vowed to carry on her campaign despite reflective remarks in a debate Thursday night that some people took as a valedictory to her long effort to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: An Errant Satellite Is Gone, but Questions Linger
text: WASHINGTON  Videotape of the Navy mission to shoot down a dying spy satellite made available Thursday shows an interceptor missile ascending atop a bright trail of burning fuel, and then a flash, a fireball, a plume of vapor. A cloud of debris left little doubt that the missile had squarely hit its mark as the satellite spent its final days orbiting more than 130 miles above the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Off-Track Betting
text: A horseplayer with an itch to bet has two options in New York City. Drive out to the racetrack—Aqueduct in the winter, Belmont or Saratoga in the summer—or step into one of the 60 or so Off-Track Betting parlors scattered over the five boroughs. Option two is not an inviting prospect. Most of the city's OTBs are cramped, featureless storefronts packed with angry men screaming at the overhead television monitors as their selection of the day limps across the finish line in last place. Losing tickets litter the floor. Sullen clerks take bets. Marginal characters drift in and out. It's not a pretty sight.

headline: Sites for ‘Maharishi Effect’ (Welcome to Parma) Spread Across U.S.
text: PARMA, Ohio  Maharishi Mahesh Yogi, the “giggling guru” who founded the Transcendental Meditation movement, proclaimed throughout his 50-year career that he knew the secret to worldwide peace. And now, this Cleveland suburb is poised to play a role.

headline: Microsoft to Share More Technical Secrets
text: Seeking to satisfy European antitrust officials, Microsoft said on Thursday that it would open up and share many more of its technical secrets with the rest of the software industry and competitors.

headline: On Health Care, Affordability and Comprehensiveness
text: Health care was the flash point of one of the most contentious exchanges between Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton on Thursday night, with Mrs. Clinton again taking the offensive.

headline: Illinois: Gunman Took Anti-Anxiety Drug
text: The gunman who killed five students and then himself at Northern Illinois University took an anti-anxiety drug and a sleeping aid in addition to the antidepressant Prozac, his girlfriend told CNN. Earlier the woman, Jessica Baty, told the news network that the gunman, Steven P. Kazmierczak, stopped taking Prozac three weeks before he entered a university lecture hall and opened fire. On Wednesday, CNN reported that in a follow-up conversation, Ms. Baty said he also took Xanax and Ambien, at least occasionally. Mr. Kazmierczak was under the care of a psychiatrist, she said, who had prescribed the drugs. Mental health specialists say the combination is not uncommon. The university observed five minutes of silence on Thursday, one minute for each of the students killed.

headline: Medical Device Ruling Redraws Lines on Lawsuits
text: The Supreme Court’s decision Wednesday protecting many types of medical device makers from personal injury lawsuits began rippling through the courts and law offices almost immediately.

headline: U.S. Sues 2 Over Gold-Mine Tax Promotion
text: The Justice Department filed two lawsuits on Thursday in a move against what it said was a fraudulent gold-mining scheme sold to dozens of wealthy investors, including seven current or former National Football League players.

headline: New Role for Edie Falco
text: The former Carmela Soprano has a new role in life. Edie Falco, below, winner of three Emmy Awards for her portrayal of the mob boss Tony Soprano’s wife on the HBO series “The Sopranos,” has agreed to star in the pilot for an untitled half-hour series for Showtime and Lionsgate Television. Described in an announcement as a dark comedy, the show calls on Ms. Falco to portray “a strong-willed iconoclastic New York City nurse juggling the frenzied grind of an urban hospital and an equally challenging personal life.” Filming will take place in New York.

headline: Sentence in Volkswagen Scandal
text: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen’s long-running corruption scandal has blackened its name and tainted some of Germany’s most influential businessmen. On Friday, a court handed down the first jail time in the affair, sentencing Volkswagen’s former top labor leader to nearly three years in prison.

headline: In Trial Over Police Killing in Queens, Focus May Be on First 2 of 50 Bullets
text: It has become widely known as the “50-shot” case, but as the trial of the detectives accused in the killing of Sean Bell approaches on Monday, the defense is expected to concentrate in particular on 2 of those 50 bullets: the first one fired by each of the two detectives who are charged with manslaughter.

headline: City Offering Hepatitis Vaccinations for Patrons at Restaurant Where Bartender Was Infected
text: The city’s health department is offering hepatitis A vaccinations “as a precautionary measure” to patrons who may have been exposed at Socialista, a West Village lounge and restaurant where a bartender was found to have the disease.

headline: Squaw Valley USA
text: Updated: December 2008

headline: Suit Says Spinal Disk Maker Falsely Won F.D.A. Approval
text: A patient suing the maker of an artificial spinal disk now says the original maker of the device, Spine Solutions, and the investment firm that financed its development misled patients and federal regulators about the disk’s safety and effectiveness.

headline: Eden Corrupted
text: The flesh is weak but the spirit is indestructible in “Cover,” a ham-fisted morality tale eager to prove that infidelity may be bad but playing with a member of one’s own team is infinitely worse.

headline: Another Round of Explosions, but This Time It’s Fake
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Lebanon is a country on edge, with every side warning about foreign interference and the spark that could lead to factional war.

headline: Tough Quarter for J.C. Penney, and More Expected
text: PLANO, Tex. (AP)  Fourth-quarter profit at the J. C. Penney Company, the department store retailer, declined 10 percent as customers struggled with a weakening economy, the company said Thursday.

headline: Researchers Find Way to Steal Encrypted Data
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A group led by a Princeton University computer security researcher has developed a simple method to steal encrypted information stored on computer hard disks.

headline: ‘Oil!’ and the History of Southern California
text: Eric Schlosser, the author of "Fast Food Nation" and "Reefer Madness," owned the film rights to "Oil!" the 1927 Upton Sinclair novel that was the inspiration for "There Will Be Blood," the movie made by Paul Thomas Anderson. In this interview Mr. Schlosser explains how and why he became entranced by the book, and discusses the tumultuous era in Southern California that Sinclair wrote about.

headline: Profit Surges at MGM Mirage
text: LAS VEGAS (AP)  The casino giant MGM Mirage reported soaring fourth-quarter profit Thursday, including a hefty gain related to a foreign investment in its CityCenter project, which is under construction on the Las Vegas Strip.

headline: Looking at You Looking at Her
text: Exhibitions don’t come any smaller than “Parmigianino’s ‘Antea’: A Beautiful Artifice” at the Frick Collection. A painting, a wall text, a nugget of a scholarly catalog, and that’s it.

headline: Bill Clinton Raises the Stakes of Two Contests Next Month
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign has been signaling the importance of the Ohio and Texas primaries next month, but former President Bill Clinton is taking that a step further and suggesting the two contests are ones she must win.

headline: Not Your Ordinary Swap Meet
text: An obscure pressure point in the credit squeeze popped up this week when a boutique investment bank in Houston held a “public auction” for dozens of the most arcane products in the financial world.

headline: Debate Takes On Contentious Air
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama veered from collegial to clenched and combative in a debate on Thursday, with Mrs. Clinton turning especially aggressive as she all but accused Mr. Obama of plagiarism and derided his political message as “change you can Xerox.”

headline: Generations Shake and Shift as Time Maintains Its March
text: Countless plays have used earthquakes as metaphors for emotional disturbances and ruptures. Not to be outdone by its predecessors, “Imminence” features a set, designed by Nic Ularu, that actually rumbles and splits down the middle, the jagged chasm between its two hemispheres periodically widening as the action unfolds. Feelings: they’re strong stuff.

headline: Theater Listings
text: THE COLOR PURPLE For anyone who has walked by “The Color Purple” and not noticed it, time is running out. The Broadway musical based on Alice Walker’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel and produced for the stage by Oprah Winfrey, among others, will close on Sunday after 30 previews and 910 regular performances.

headline: Tit for Tat on a Night Where Spin Is Master
text: Mark Penn, pollster and chief strategist to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, how special were your candidate’s last comments in this Texas debate? Were you touched?

headline: U.S. Ends Protections for Wolves in 3 States
text: DENVER  The Bush administration on Thursday announced an end to federal protection for gray wolves in Montana, Wyoming and Idaho, concluding that the wolves were reproductively robust enough to survive.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The State of the Art column in Business Day on Thursday, about movie downloading, referred incorrectly in some editions to a feature of the TiVo digital recording device that lets users rent or buy movies from Amazon. The movies can be ordered and downloaded through TiVo; it is not necessary to order the movies from Amazon.com using a personal computer.

headline: Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Co. to 15.6%
text: The hedge funds that hope to elect dissident directors to The New York Times Company board said Thursday that they had increased their holdings to at least 15.61 percent of the company’s common stock.

headline: Step Dancing to the Lively Rhythms of a French Canadian Poet
text: There was the seed of a good show in “Rapaillé,” performed by [Zogma] on Wednesday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater. Founded in 1999 and based in Quebec, the company describes itself as an urban folk collective devoted to the old French Canadian tradition of step dancing.

headline: Across the Bay, on a School Bus Wearing Skis
text: LA POINTE, Wis.  From a distance, the large red aluminum contraption parked on the frozen shore of Lake Superior here looks like a small houseboat perched on skis. Up closer, as schoolchildren pile in with their backpacks and iPods, it becomes clear that the mystery vehicle, with two large fans on the back, is something else entirely.

headline: On a Tour of China, Some Musicians Feel Overlooked
text: SHANGHAI  The New York Philharmonic’s recently appointed principal oboist is a native of China. Its fast-rising associate conductor is too. And they collaborated in a well-received concerto performance in Hong Kong during the orchestra’s current tour in Asia.

headline: The McCain World Rift
text: The staff of the McCain campaign had a rude awakening last Jan. 25th. They opened The Washington Post and found a front-page story linking McCain’s campaign manager, Rick Davis, to the Russian aluminum magnate Oleg Deripaska. Who, some wondered, was feeding damaging information about Davis to the press?

headline: Lottery Numbers
Time Runs Short to Decide Albany Health Care Cuts
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has not called anyone in the health care lobby a crybaby this year. At least not yet.

headline: Cavaliers Trade to Get James Some Company
text: LeBron James pined for Jason Kidd, watched a blur of stars crisscross the country and impatiently tapped his fingers, wondering when a crimson-and-gold cavalry would appear on the horizon.

headline: Paco: Argentina's Cheap Drug Scourge
text: Paco, a highly addictive form of crack cocaine that sells for less than $2, has destroyed thousands of lives in Argentina.

headline: Hockey East Showdown
text: There’s no question Hockey East is having a down year. But its two best teams will be going head-to-head this weekend and the outcome will decide if the run for the regular-season title is a thrill or a snoozer.

headline: EMC Acquisition Shows It Wants to be a Cloudmaster
text: EMC, the big computer storage company, bought a little Seattle start-up on Thursday for an undisclosed price. Still, the deal and the forces behind it are intriguing indeed.

headline: Anand Leads Morelia-Linares, as Topolav Falters
Lessons in Shanghai
text: The New York Philharmonic coaches students at Shanghai Datong High School in Shanghai.

headline: Beauty In Motion
text: Images from the  ballerina Diana Vishneva's engagement at New York City Center.

headline: Giants 2008: The Year Ahead
text: The Fifth Down’s guest blogger of the week, Andrew Furman, peppered the Comments section with insight during the Giants’ playoff run. He has his own blog, ultimatenyg.blogspot.com. Last in a series:

headline: Impressionistinnen: Women Do Impressionism
text: Unless you know that the suffix “-innen” denotes the feminine plural in German, you might miss the meaning conveyed by the title of this exhibit. You’ve probably heard of Manet, Monet, Renoir and Degas. This is all about the women who belonged to the same movement in late 19th century Paris, but have been unjustly filtered out of most historical accounts.

headline: Shakespeare marathon & 15 liters of “blood”
text: Do you love Shakespeare, fancy English history and have 1,389 minutes plus to spare? If so, a unique opportunity is available, thanks to a mammoth project by the Royal Shakespeare Company, in what has been described in The Guardian newspaper as “One of the greatest events of modern theatre”.

headline: The Scene at the Debate in Austin
text: Supporters of Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama gathered for the debate at the University of Texas.

headline: ‘Red-Faced Canadians Missing Pants’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Sovereign Bancorp Fires Chief Financial Officer
text: Sovereign Bancorp, the second-largest savings and loan in the United States, said on Thursday it had fired its chief financial officer, Mark McCollom, and named Kirk Walters to succeed him.

headline: Transoma Medical Pulls the Plug on I.P.O.
text: Transoma Medical withdrew its registration for an initial public offering on Thursday, citing unfavorable market conditions.

headline: China Everbright Names Underwriters for I.P.O.
text: China Everbright Bank appointed China International Capital, China Jianyin Investment Securities and Shenyin & Wanguo Securities to underwrite its planned Shanghai initial public share offering.

headline: ‘Calling the School SMOO’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Today’s New York Times is claiming that John McCain, who is 71 years old, had an inappropriate relationship with a woman who is a Washington lobbyist. The good news is there’s no footage.

headline: DB Zwirn to Wind Down Principal Funds, Report Says
text: A New York hedge fund, DB Zwirn, is winding down its principal funds after investors – rattled by lapses in internal controls, including the expense of a private jet used by the firm’s founder – said they would withdraw more than $2 billion, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Russia’s Binbank Sold
text: Mikhail Shishkhanov, a nephew of a Russian billionaire, Mikhail Gutseriyev, has agreed to sell a Russian lender, Binbank, to a businessman and senator, Vadim Moshkovich, the bank said on Friday.

headline: Dakim Snags $10.6 Million From V.C.’s
text: Dakim, a developer of software and systems that help seniors retain brainpower, raised $10.6 million in Series C funding led by Galen Partners to market its products to care facilities and to launch new ones for home use.

headline: Miles Electric Moves into High Gear With $15 Million Injection
text: Miles Electric Vehicle, a maker of low-speed electric vehicles, plans on releasing a model that can reach highway speeds in late 2009 after raising $15 million in a new round of funding.

headline: Tough Sledding for Hedge Funds
text: The year has begun on a brutal note for many hedge funds, judging from recent fund data and new reports of losses and liquidations at some major funds. It appears that pointed comments from Hillary Clinton are the least of the worries facing hedge-fund managers in these choppy markets.

headline: ‘More Alike Than the Olsen Twins’
text: Aired Thursday night on “Jimmy Kimmel Live” on ABC: There was a big story in The New York Times today about Senator John McCain, who’s running for president. It questioned his ties to a lobbyist named Vicki Iseman.” The story “hinted” that McCain may have had an extramarital affair with her, but the weird thing is she looks almost exactly like John McCain’s wife, Cindy. So he might have just got confused and grabbed the wrong woman. These two look more alike than the Olson twins.

headline: Terra Firma and Suez Said to Be in Talks About Biffa Bid
text: Terra Firma, the private equity firm run by the British financier Guy Hands, is in talks with the French industrial group Suez about a 1.5 billion pound ($3 billion) counter-offer for Biffa, the waste management company, according to The Telegraph.

headline: Google Shoots for the Moon
text: More than three decades after the last Apollo astronauts roamed the lunar surface, disparate universities, open-source engineers and quixotic aerospace start-ups are planning to start their own robotic missions to the Earth’s barren cousin.

headline: ‘A Very Tough Day for John McCain’
text: Aired Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: It’s been a very tough day for John McCain with the New York Times’ allegation that he had an affair. The paper is saying McCain had an affair, years ago, with Joan of Arc or something.

headline: Hedge Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Co.
text: The hedge funds that hope to elect dissident directors to the The New York Times Company said Thursday that they had increased their holdings to at least 15.61 percent of the company’s common stock.

headline: ‘Operation Bore Them to Death’
text: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton still doing very well in one state — the state of denial, ladies and gentlemen. Well, after winning 10 in a row, political experts say there’s a very good chance that Barack Obama could end up as our next president. See, that shows you the progress we’ve made in this country. We can have a black man in the White House. I remember when we couldn’t get a black man in the cast of “Friends.”

headline: After Rio Move, Chinalco Mulls More Acquisitions
text: The Chinese aluminum company Chinalco, which this year led a $14 billion acquisition of 12 percent of Rio Tinto, said in remarks in an influential magazine that it will continue to seek acquisitions abroad.

headline: Bridgepoint Close to Buying Pret a Manger, Report Says
text: Bridgepoint Capital, a London private equity firm, is close to an agreement to buy Pret A Manger (Europe), a sandwich chain, in a deal that would also give Goldman Sachs a minority stake in the company, The Telegraph reported. Bridgepoint reportedly fended off rival bidders Advent International and Morgan Stanley.

headline: HLTH’s WebMD Merger Creates Attractive Deal Target
text: The merger of HLTH Corporation and WebMD Health could make the combined company a takeover target for larger Internet companies such as Google, industry observers said Thursday.

headline: Magazines Up for Sale, Including Variety
text: Variety, Publishers Weekly and dozens of other trade publications are going up for sale as the publishing company Reed Elsevier looks to get out of the advertising market.

headline: News Corp. Raises Stake in Premiere
text: News Corporation has raised its stake in Premiere, Germany’s largest pay-television operator, raising speculation that it could push for a full takeover of the company.

headline: ‘Out of Force of Habit, Hillary Is Standing by Him’
text: Aired Thursday night on CBS: Big weekend planned for the Academy Awards Sunday night? Are you folks excited about the Academy Awards? I mean, my gosh, how can you not be? Listen to this: this year, the movies were unbelievable. We had one about a serial killer; one about Alzheimer’s; one about a kidnapping; one about a guy with a stroke –- by God, that’s entertainment, isn’t it, ladies and gentlemen?

headline: Lehman Brothers to Cut 200 Jobs, Report Says
text: Lehman Brothers is cutting 200 jobs, equivalent to 10 percent of its investment banking staff, CNBC television reported on Thursday.

headline: Outdated Prices Blamed in Credit Suisse Error
text: The surprise $2.85 billion write-down at Credit Suisse this week underscored the difficulty banks face in valuing complex investments. But the cause of the blunder may be simple: traders at the bank used old prices.

headline: Turkey Says It Has Sent Ground Troops Into Iraq
text: SAMSUN, Turkey - Turkey's military said it had sent ground troops into northern Iraq Thursday night in an operation aimed at weakening Kurdish militants there, the first confirmed ground incursion since the United States invaded Iraq in 2003.

headline: Not Your Ordinary Swap Meet
text: An obscure pressure point in the credit squeeze popped up this week when a boutique investment bank in Houston held a “public auction” for dozens of the most arcane products in the financial world.

headline: A Harsh Winter for Hedge Funds
text: Hedge funds around the world had the worst month in at least eight years in January as equities worldwide tumbled amid concerns that the U.S. economy was headed for a recession, according to Eurekahedge.

headline: Bond Insurer MBIA Pulls Out of Trade Group
text: MBIA, the world’s largest bond insurer, said Thursday that it was withdrawing from the Association of Financial Guaranty Insurers, citing disagreement on the future direction of the bond insurance industry.

headline: A Post-Mortem of Dead Deals
text: From PHH to SLM, plenty of leveraged buyout transactions have failed to make it to the finish line in recent months. Private equity firms have taken a lot of heat for walking away from these deals, but Investment Dealers’ Digest suggests that despite the criticism, buyout firms deserve credit for being disciplined investors.

headline: UBS Said to Search for New Chairman
text: UBS has quietly sounded out some of Europe’s top bankers to join its board of directors and eventually replace the troubled Swiss bank’s long-serving chairman, Marcel Ospel, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Parliament Approves Legislation to Nationalize British Bank
text: The British Parliament passed legislation on Thursday allowing the government to nationalize the struggling lender Northern Rock, five months after the bank became a high-profile casualty of the global credit squeeze.

headline: When Bankers Fail to Act
text: Where is the next J. P. Morgan?

headline: Friday’s Links: How to Talk (or Not Talk) About Salary, and Other Interviewing Pointers
text: Today’s links all relate to improving our interviewing skills, whichever side of the table we’re sitting on:

headline: Nascar Riddles Solved
text: We have a winner in the stock-car science quiz, plus answers to some of the other questions about Nascar that Lab readers asked Diandra Leslie-Pelecky, the University of Nebraska physicst and subject of my Findings column.

headline: Chow Fun
text: The Bagger is a little long on material and a little short on space (and he thought the Interweb was infinite), so forgive him if he sounds like Liz Smith with a modem. O.K., here goes: The dinner after the opening at the Gagosian was thick with luminaries. Russell Simmons was there, as were Colin Callendar of HBO Films, his wife Elizabeth and Chris DeWolfe, the founder of MySpace. And that was just at the Bagger’s table.

headline: Which of These Things?
text: The Gagosian Gallery on North Camden Drive in Beverly Hills hosted the opening of a massive array of skeletons on Thursday night by an artist who also makes the occasional movie. The work was by Julian Schnabel, and was inspired by some X-rays, made early in the 20th century, that he came across in an uninhabited house in Berck-sur-Mer on the Normandy coast while making “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” The paintings, like the film, explore the human condition from the inside out. And they were also virtually cinematic in size, towering over the gallery full of filmies, arties and wannabees.

headline: Demon ethanol
text: I’m almost never censored at the Times. However, I was told that I couldn’t use the lede I originally wrote for my column following the 2007 State of the Union address, in which Bush made ethanol the centerpiece of his energy strategy: “Before the State of the Union address, there had been hints and hopes that President Bush would offer a serious plan to reduce our dependence on imported oil. Instead, however, he took refuge in alcohol.”

headline: A Critic’s Critic
text: Paul Thomas Anderson, apart from being the holy vessel of hope and aspiration for critics and cinéastes, is known in the industry as both a straight shooter and a barrel of monkeys, someone who takes the work, but not himself, seriously. He did not disappoint.

headline: Pickery
text: The eagle may not have landed–– it was actually shot out of the sky on Wednesday — but the Bagger has. His picks are in the can, beyond the pale and in the paper.

headline: The Early Word: Onward From the Debate
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, fresh off a strong closing set of lines at an otherwise fairly tame debate with her rival Senator Barack Obama, hit the morning news shows today.

headline: Funkytown
text: The calendar year doesn’t get much traction in many parts of Los Angeles. The Oscars is New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day rolled into one, a single day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew.

headline: Tower of Obabble
text: What’s next? We’re wondering when someone’s going to Obamify the lyrics to Little Richard’s “Tutti Frutti” (“A-womp-bomp-Obama, a-womp-bam-boom!”), if that hasn’t already been done. (Or maybe readers would like to give it a try? Go for it!) Meantime, help yourself to Slate’s Encyclopedia Baracktannia, compiled from fans and detractors alike. Here’s a sampler (culled by About.com Political Humor):

headline: Panic, Deja Vu
text: My column today quotes from one of the most insightful books I have ever read, “The Panic of 1907.” When I read it last year, I thought it had lessons for today, but I did not realize just how quickly those lessons would become crucial.

headline: Ratings Forecast For The Academy Awards
text: If advertisers had it their way, the five best picture nominees for Sunday’s Academy Awards would be blockbusters. “In recent years, the ratings for the show have improved when the nominated films were widely popular and have fallen when they were not,” Stuart Elliott writes in today’s New York Times.

headline: What to Look For in the Sean Bell Trial
text: It has become widely known as the “50-shot” case, but as the trial of the detectives accused in the killing of Sean Bell approaches on Monday, Michael Wilson reports, the defense is expected to concentrate in particular on 2 of those 50 bullets: the first one fired by each of the two detectives who are charged with manslaughter. If the two detectives can prove that they were not acting recklessly or with criminal intent in firing their first shots at Mr. Bell and his friends in Queens on Nov. 25, 2006, then the shots that followed — 40 more rounds between them — could be determined to be justified as well, said lawyers who have represented police officers in the past and people who have been briefed on the case. A third detective faces two misdemeanor charges.

headline: Parsing Clinton’s Praise
text: “Has Hillary caught Obama fever, or is she just throwing in the towel?” asks Stephen Spruiell at National Review Online. “Near the end of Democratic debate at the University of Texas Thursday night, Hillary Clinton praised her opponent, Barack Obama, in terms so glowing, she seemed like one of those people who have been fainting in his presence lately.”

headline: Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe
text: Images from the show at the Guggenheim Museum.

headline: Design and the Elastic Mind
text: Images from the show at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: We Love This Dirty Town (on Film)
text: Arguably, no one can outdo Martin Scorsese as a New York filmmaker. “Taxi Driver.” “Mean Streets.” “Who’s That Knocking at My Door?” Not only was he born in New York, but he also went to New York University’s film school. He even had a film called “New York, New York” (though admittedly a box-office and critical failure).So it was rather disappointing that, after being shut out numerous times, the movie that won him an Academy Award for best director was “The Departed,” which (gasp!) is set in Boston. That would be like Joe Torre taking over the Red Sox and managing them to a World Series title.

headline: Riding With Ed: An Actor Devoted to the Green Life
text: I often hear people asking whether it’s worth trying to limit your personal “greenhouse effect” by driving less, buying less, eating local, and the like. Personally, I choose to limit my energy use as much as I can for both economic and environmental reasons. I try to telecommute whenever possible not just to save the planet, but to relish a break taken walking in the woods instead of to an elevator.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: A Lot of Night Music
text: While most of the New York Philharmonic remained back in Shanghai on a free day on Friday, three members had duties in Beijing, the orchestra’s next stop. Sheryl Staples, the principal associate concertmaster; Cynthia Phelps, the principal violist; and Carter Brey, the principal cellist, joined for a trio performance at the residence of the American ambassador, Clark T. Randt Jr. Mr. Randt held a reception for patrons, orchestra staff, corporate sponsors and Chinese guests.

headline: A Moment of Silence, Then Back to the Rancor
text: Municipal politics can get heated and personal in almost any city or town in America, and Kirkwood, Mo., was no exception even before Charles Lee Thornton, a 52-year-old contractor, walked into a city council meeting on Feb. 7 and opened fire, killing two council members, the city public works chief and two police officers and wounding the mayor and a reporter before he was shot dead by police. Mr. Thornton, in fact, was said to have been a frequent, angry presence at earlier meetings, waging a war of shouts with city officials that led to him being banned from speaking.

headline: Courts Weigh in on Valuation Debate
text: That was fast.

headline: Giants Set to Reward Coughlin With Multiyear Deal
text: INDIANAPOLIS — The Giants are closing in on a multiyear contract for Tom Coughlin, who deftly recast himself as a willing ally of his players and steered the team to a surprising Super Bowl victory.

headline: Stray Questions for: Sean Wilsey
text: Sean Wilsey is the author of “Oh the Glory of It All,” a memoir.

headline: And The Emmy For Best Promo Goes To…
text: The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences is introducing two new Emmy Awards categories for the producers and editors who create commercials: one for an episodic message (encouraging viewers to tune in for a specific show) and one for an institutional message (publicizing the network).

headline: CBS Will Beam…Uh, That is, Stream ‘Star Trek’ And Other Classics
text: Do you miss the original “Star Trek,” “Melrose Place” or, god help us, “MacGyver?”

headline: This Kitchen’s Soup Is Just Starting to Simmer
text: The people at the Greenpoint Reformed Church, whose new soup kitchen and food pantry I wrote about for the Dispatches feature in this week’s City Section, say they got the whole endeavor off the ground, in seat-of-the-pants fashion, without a lot of instruction or training. Asked if, four months in, it was living up to what they had envisioned, the Rev. Jennifer Aull, one of the Brooklyn church’s pastors, said: “I don’t know if we really had much envisioning. You know, you kind of don’t know how to do things until you’ve done them already.”

headline: Chatting With Violet
text: A quick announcement: Deanna Dunagan, who plays Violet in the current production of “August,” will be on a panel of Broadway actors in a TimesTalks event this coming Monday, Feb. 25, at 6:30 at the Times Center in Midtown Manhattan. Campbell Robertson, the Times theater reporter, is interviewing her along with Ian McShane and Brian Cox.

headline: Poor Gazza?
text: Just when you thought it couldn’t get any weirder, any sadder, for former England international and midfield magician Paul Gascoigne, the 40-year-old was detained under Britain’s Mental Health Act yesterday after he was identified as a “potential menace” to hotel guests in Tyneside.

headline: Rodriguez Calls Fit-and-Trim Jeter an M.V.P.
text: Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees has won the American League’s Most Valuable Player award three times, including last season, and teammate Derek Jeter has never won it. But Rodriguez predicted on Thursday that Jeter would have an M.V.P. season in 2008. Rodriguez based this on a conversation he had at lunch with Jeter on Thursday about Jeter’s conditioning during the off-season.

headline: Audi Quattro, New Cop Show Resurrect the ’80s
text: I never watched “Life on Mars,” a high-concept cop show on BBC America, but I recall reading that the detective drove a Ford Cortina. Maybe that’s why I never watched the show.

headline: Fantasy Football Draft ’08, Part I
text: (Mark St. Amant is the author of Committed: Confessions of a Fantasy Football Junkie and Just Kick It: Tales of an Underdog, Over-Age, Out-of-Place Semi-Pro Football Player.)

headline: Candidates Quietly Shore Up R.I., Vermont Support
text: Small states Rhode Island and Vermont may be suffering from a slight case of middle-child syndrome, as their March 4 primaries are being largely overlooked as the candidates spend all of their time (and most of their money) in the upcoming big states Ohio and Texas, which vote the same day.

headline: Making America Safe for Nonfiction
text: The documentary nominees held a round-up of truth-tellers on Wednesday at the Samuel Golden Theater and indieWire reports that Michael Moore, who is among the annointed with “Sicko,” has a plan to open up some real estate for docs.

headline: From Where I’m Standing
text: Over a year ago at Sundance, the Bagger saw Josh Radin playing at a small party and there was a woman behind him hitting all his notes and some of her own. Upon inquiry, the Bagger found out her name was Schulyer Fisk, who was then dating Mr. Radin. It turned out that she also had her own musical career, along with film and television work, including a role in “I’m Reed Fish.”

headline: Golden Guy Prefers White Guys
text: The University of Southern California released a study yesterday about the preferences of the Academy and found that in almost in any given year of best picture nominations, the roles for people who are neither white nor male are few and far between.

headline: Tearing the Roof Off the Kodak
text: Trust the Bagger when he says that one of the show-stoppers of Sunday night will come when Impact Repertory sings “Raise It Up,” one of the nominees for best song, from the movie “August Rush.” The kids from Harlem who give voice to the song are in rehearsals today at the Kodak and the word is that they will rock the place.

headline: Eurostar Chief Touts Green Advantage of Trains vs. Planes
text: It seems that concern about global warming means that selling seats has never been easier for Richard Brown, the chief executive of Eurostar, the high-speed train service linking London with Brussels and Paris.

headline: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
text: In his column today, Carl Hulse writes that there are some “suggestions that Senator John McCain might do the same and give up his Senate seat to devote full-time to his presidential bid, avoiding the political potholes Senate Democrats are certain to place in his way in the coming months,” as Bob Dole did in 1996.

headline: Buying Movies on Flash Drives: Nice Idea That Doesn’t Work
text: Over the last few months, we’ve had quite a debate in the comments here about the relative merits of Blu-ray, HD DVD and standard DVD discs. Some argue we don’t need discs at all because we’ll all be able to download movies. And others have suggested that the price of memory chips is falling so fast that we might still buy movies in stores, but they may come loaded on U.S.B. memory sticks or the sort of SD memory cards that go in digital cameras.

headline: Milan Fashion Week | Fendi

headline: The Week in Comments: ‘Don’t Cover It in Glass!’

If you would like to have your comments considered for publication, please use your real name or initials and include a valid e-mail address so we may contact you. Thanks.

headline: Officer Traveling with Clinton Killed in Crash
text: Updated A Dallas police officer traveling with Hillary Rodham Clinton’s motorcade en route from the airport to a campaign rally was killed Friday morning in a motorcycle accident. Upon learning of the fatality either during or after her first event, Senator Clinton briefly addressed the crowd gathered at a second rally in Fort Worth but then canceled it.

headline: Perez Wins Arbitration
text: The mets have confirmed that Oliver Perez has won his arbitration hearing in the team’s first case since 1992. Perez will make $6.5 million this year; the team offered $4.725 million.

headline: The Browser Choices We Make
text: TechCrunch noted Thursday that Mozilla was about to celebrate its 500 millionth download of Firefox, the open source browser that has made inroads into Microsoft’s dominant market share. By this morning, the official Spread Firefox site was claiming an additional 340,000 downloads, putting it over the half billion mark.

headline: Domaine du Jaugaret
text: I’ve had Bordeaux  on the mind recently, and it reminded me of a talk I had last summer with the importer Neal Rosenthal. Most of our conversation had to do with honey, as Neal not only imports some beautiful, distinctive European honeys, he is now a dedicated beekeeper and produces his own buckwheat honeys from his farm in upstate New York.

headline: The Art of Waste
text: Chris Jordan’s photography isn’t really about food — it’s about consumption — but it isn’t a coincidence that nearly half the images on his stunning website are of disposable packaging related to food or drink. Check it out.

headline: All Alone By the Telephone
text: The Bagger likes to keep things on the down-low out here — the paparazzi, the bill collectors, the federales all pose significant threats — so he never mentions that he is staying at Le Parc a secret, undisclosed location in West Hollywood. Which may explain why he never got the invite to Bryan Lourd’s party for CAA clients and friends tonight. And the gang at Endeavor, where Ari Emmanuel is getting funky with Tilda, Javier and Viggo, must be having trouble finding him as well. The Bagger does have one e-mail invite to small studio gig tonight and Miramax might let him in tomorrow, but he often has trouble at the door, so who knows?

headline: McCain Hits Obama on Cuba
text: With an eye on the general election and presumably those Cuban-American voters in Florida and their supporters around the country, the Republican party and Senator John McCain quickly seized on remarks made during last night’s Democratic debate by Senator Barack Obama.

headline: New York and the Vanguard of Digital Design
text: Several works in “Design and the Elastic Mind,” an exhibition that opens at the Museum of Modern Art on Sunday, offer intriguing and unexpected perspectives on New York. A team at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has mapped the international phone calls and Internet traffic that connect the city with countries around the world, showing, for example, just how often Queens immigrants are on the phone back home with India. A design lab at Columbia University has traced the costs of incarceration in poor minority neighborhoods, demonstrating that taxpayers in some cases pay $1 million a year to imprison inmates from a single Brooklyn block.

headline: Is Nasdaq Starting a Race to the Bottom for SPACs?
text: The Nasdaq Stock Market announced Thursday that it would propose new rules permitting special purpose acquisition companies, or SPACs, to list on its market.

headline: Not Drinking — More Like Hitting the Sauce
text: A new way to deny you have a drinking problem: edible Cointreau! (There’s also the wine glass that holds a full bottle.)

headline: Man Is Injured in Midtown Robbery
text: Updated, 4:52 p.m. | A man in his 50s was injured in an apparent robbery at 2:05 p.m. today near West 56th Street and Sixth Avenue in Midtown, according to the police. The victim was taken with a head injury to NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, and his condition was not immediately known.

headline: Undefeated and Under Pressure
text: Sports can be startlingly simple. Two teams play; one emerges the winner. And this season every time Memphis has stepped on the court it has left victorious. That is the kind of perfection that garners attention.

headline: M.T.A. Puts Off Weekend Subway Work
text: If there is a silver lining to the wet storm that blanketed the Northeast with snow this morning, this is it: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has just postponed all construction activity that had been planned this weekend, meaning that most subways will run on their normal weekend schedules. Typically on weekends, subway service is limited or rerouted to accommodate track and signal work.

headline: Coca-Cola Says It Won’t Rely on Deals for Growth
text: Coca-Cola said on Friday it would continue to make acquisitions, but they were not necessary for the company to meet its long-term growth objectives, Reuters reported.

headline: Ratings: On Fox, ‘Idol’ Wins And Gives A Long Echo To ‘Lyrics’
text: The results edition of “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to the network’s other singing competition, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics.”

headline: A Playwright’s Choice
text: I have to confess that as far as Johnna goes, I feel she’s the one discordant note in the play because, as Eliza says, she is “a sort of weak character” and also because she seems too manifestly a device and, ultimately perhaps, a symbol. If, as Blake persuasively argues, she’s a political device or symbol, that only compounds the problem because that meaning seems superimposed on a character too thin to carry the weight of so heavy a slice of the American gestalt.

headline: Breaking Up in Five Rhyming Lines
text: You won’t hear many limericks in Limerick, but evidently you will hear “It’s all over between us” pretty often. The Independent reports today that Limerick city, the third-biggest in the Republic of Ireland after Dublin and Cork, leads the nation in divorces.

headline: Lather Up: The Hand-Wringing Over Hand-Washing
text: You’ve seen the signs. So have we: “Employees Must Wash Hands Before Returning to Work,” required by the city health code in all bathrooms in restaurants and bars. In fact, we’ve even seen the signs in Spanish and Chinese, as well as English.

headline: CHC Agrees to $1.5 Billion Buyout in Big Oil Services Deal
text: CHC Helicopter, which provides transportation to oil rigs, agreed to be acquired by a private equity company for $1.5 billion, the largest-ever oil-field services buyout.

headline: Argentina's Cocaine Problem
text: A highly addictive smokable cocaine residue, known as paco, has emerged in Argentina over the past five years and destroyed thousands of lives.

headline: Report on Potential Ambac Bailout Reverses Stock Slide
text: Update: The New York Times reported Friday afternoon that Ambac will split itself into two parts and raise $3 billion. The plan, drafted by a consortium of eight banks including Citigroup and UBS, still needs approval by the credit ratings agencies but could be formally unveiled as soon as Monday.

text: Ralph Nader is scheduled to appear on NBC’s “Meet the Press” on Sunday, sparking speculation that he is planning another third-party run for the White House.

headline: Ask About Nature in New York
text: Leslie Day, the author of “Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City” (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), took questions from readers over the past week. Dr. Day, who has a doctorate in science education from Teachers College at Columbia University and developed the City Naturalists Summer Institute at the Central Park Conservancy, is an environmental and life science educator at the Elisabeth Morrow School in Englewood, N.J. She is also an adjunct faculty member at Bank Street College of Education. Dr. Day and her husband live on a houseboat on the Hudson River in Manhattan.

headline: This Should Clear Things Up
text: Several readers have asked about the math work involved in a chart this week that explained the probability for a player to be chosen for a random drug test under the Major League Baseball policy. As the chart explained, there are 1,200 players and baseball conducts 660 random tests over the course of a year.

headline: There Will Be Oscars
text: The odds for the Best Adapted Screenplay Oscar seem to be on the Coen brothers’ straight-shooting adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s “No Country For Old Men.” But Paul Thomas Anderson could still walk away on Sunday night with the statuette for “There Will Be Blood,” his freewheeling and darkly poetic reimagining of Upton Sinclair’s 1927 novel “Oil!” (Pop quiz: Does anyone know any novelists besides Sinclair and Dave Eggers who have used exclamation points in their titles?)
