headline: Warner to Obama: Bring Me Your Captain
text: One of the dramatic moments in Thursday’s Democratic debate came when Senator Barack Obama — in making the case that Iraq was the wrong place to launch a war — cited an Army captain in Afghanistan who told him of a rifle platoon that lacked manpower, ammunition and Humvees. As Mr. Obama recounted, the soldiers looked for captured Taliban weapons as it was easier to be armed that way than “to get properly equipped by our current commander in chief.”

headline: China and the Philharmonic, in Harmony
text: SHANGHAI  In a chilly classroom at Shanghai Datong High School, the New York Philharmonic musician counted out, “One, two, one, two” in Taiwanese-accented Mandarin. A dozen student violinists sawed out a theme from Bizet’s “Carmen,” laughing nervously when asked if they would like to go a bit slower.

headline: A Bad Year to Be a Mallard

headline: Shuttle Director Transferred
text: N. Wayne Hale Jr., a 30-year veteran of NASA who helped lead the space agency’s recovery from the 2003 Columbia disaster, was transferred from his job as manager of the shuttle program. Neither NASA nor Mr. Hale gave a reason for the shift, to a new position in space operations at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. Mr. Hale, who championed making safety the paramount factor in deciding when shuttles are to fly, said in a memorandum to colleagues that he had expected to stay with the shuttle program until it ended in 2010 with completion of the International Space Station, but that he had recently been asked to assume the new job. He will be succeeded by John Shannon, a former flight director who is chairman of NASA’s Mission Management Team.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in some editions on Jan. 16 about Katherine Gamble, a woman who got help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to declutter her Manhattan apartment after depression and ill health made it difficult for her to throw things out, misstated her age. She is 60, not 50. A social services agency that worked with Ms. Gamble pointed out the error recently; this correction was delayed for research.

headline: Panel Considers Subpoenaing Ashcroft in Deal
text: WASHINGTON  The House Judiciary Committee disclosed Friday that it was considering subpoenaing former Attorney General John Ashcroft to testify about a contract worth at least $28 million that was steered to his consulting firm by the Justice Department.

headline: A Neanderthal, Club in Hand, Finds a Thrill on the Greens
text: I STRODE onto the tee box of the 18th hole at Emerald Dunes Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla., with a 25-mile-an-hour wind blistering my cheeks and an existential quandary befuddling my brain. My industrialist friend David Koch and I were embroiled in a best-ball match against two veteran professionals. After losing three straight holes on the front nine, we had battled back to tie the match with one hole to go. But all I could think about was a vintage B.C. comic strip.

headline: Three Sides of a Prima Ballerina, Made to Order
text: Audiences who came of age in the Iron Curtain era still find it astonishing to contemplate a career like Diana Vishneva’s. Ms. Vishneva is the prima ballerina of the Maryinsky (Kirov) Ballet in St. Petersburg, Russia, and appears on its foreign tours, dancing not just its old ballets but also its newly acquired Balanchine repertory. She is a leading guest artist with American Ballet Theater in its New York seasons at the Metropolitan Opera House, dancing both ballet classics and mid-20th-century gems by Frederick Ashton and Kenneth MacMillan. Now she is presenting a season of her own at City Center, dancing in a triple bill of ballets created for and around her by more or less eminent choreographers.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article on Feb. 15 about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens paraphrased incorrectly from a transcript of a conversation between Mr. McNamee and investigators for Mr. Clemens on the day before the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball was released. Mr. McNamee said he told Jim Murray, a New York-based representative for Mr. Clemens’s agent, that steroids had come from the former Mets bat boy Kirk Radomski. He did not say he had purchased steroids and growth hormone from Mr. Radomski.

headline: 4 Decades After Shooting, Effort to Make Punishment Fit the Crime
text: CHICAGO  What punishment should be imposed on a man who shot a police officer almost 40 years ago and fled to Canada, but went on to live an upstanding life as a husband and father who worked in a library?

headline: Troubled Firm to Close 2 Funds Worth $4 Billion
text: D.B. Zwirn, a New York hedge fund that has been plagued by accounting irregularities, is closing two of its largest funds after investors demanded the firm return $2 billion.

headline: Files and McCain Letter Show Effort to Keep Loophole
text: WASHINGTON  In late 1998, Senator John McCain sent an unusually blunt letter to the head of the Federal Communications Commission, warning that he would try to overhaul the agency if it closed a broadcast ownership loophole.

headline: Insurer Works to Prevent Ex-Chief From Seeing Files
text: The American International Group, the insurance company, is pulling out the stops to try to prevent its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, from seeing confidential internal documents.

headline: Some Nifty Declarer Play From South Carolina
text: The winners of the Friday-Saturday Knockout Teams at the Low Country Classic Regional in Hilton Head, S.C., last weekend were Carolyn Lynch of Scottsdale, Ariz.; David Berkowitz and Larry Cohen of Boca Raton, Fla.; Jeff Meckstroth of Tampa, Fla.; Mike Passell of Las Vegas; and Eric Rodwell of Clearwater Beach, Fla.

headline: An Odd Couple, in Character and in Harmony
text: There are no casting directors in jazz, but sometimes you see a pair of musicians who could have been brought together by one: for example, Enrico Rava and Stefano Bollani, the Italian trumpeter and pianist.

headline: With Housing in a Downturn, a Company Renovates
text: AS the post-holiday blues drag on for retailers, even high-end brands are feeling the pinch. Hunter Douglas, in Upper Saddle River, N.J., is the leader in the custom window coverings industry, but even it is not immune from the housing slowdown and the current economy. While waiting for the housing industry and consumer confidence to improve, Hunter Douglas is focusing on its internal operations and strengthening its dealer and distributor alliances.

headline: Final Birdie by Woods Proves to Be Biggest
text: MARANA, Ariz.  Under leaden skies as gray as his sweater, Tiger Woods again stood on the edge of elimination Friday. He stood with face set and arms crossed, first on the 18th green, then on the first hole of sudden death, watching Aaron Baddeley twice line up putts to send him home early from the Accenture Match Play Championship.

headline: New Tactics to Control Immigration Are Unveiled
text: Bush administration officials said Friday that they would begin using new technology to create a virtual fence along sections of the border with Mexico, and that construction had been completed on 302 miles of physical fence.

headline: Rotating Yankee Veterans to Find the Right Balance
text: TAMPA, Fla.  For his first five seasons as a Yankee, Hideki Matsui was a fixture in left field, a steady and heady veteran who was rarely injured, hit with power and for average, and enjoyed the trust of Joe Torre. But much has changed.

headline: Politics and Needle Exchanges
text: Needle exchange programs save lives. They slow the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and they help get addicts into treatment. Yet when it comes to supporting these programs, it seems that the political cowardice never ends.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart on Friday comparing fund-raising and spending for presidential candidates misstated the amount of money raised by two of them between Jan. 1, 2007, and Jan. 31, 2008. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton raised $133 million in contributions, loans and transfers, not $118 million. Senator John McCain raised $52 million, not $48 million.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the higher risks involved in multiple births referred incorrectly at one point to the procedure by which embryos enter the womb in in vitro fertilization. They are transferred, not implanted.

headline: Barnum on Each Bench in Most Unlikely Rivalry
text: MEMPHIS  Walking to class Friday morning, Memphis point guard Derrick Rose and a few of his teammates were greeted with an unusual sight. Eight people, including one with a bullhorn and a speaker, were following them around campus.

headline: Nuclear Agency Says Iran Has Used New Technology
text: WASHINGTON  The International Atomic Energy Agency described for the first time on Friday the evidence it has shown to Iran that strongly suggests the country had experimented with technologies to manufacture a nuclear weapon, but reported that Iranian officials had dismissed the documents as “baseless and fabricated.”

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Friday about the building of a Transcendental Meditation palace in Parma, Ohio, referred imprecisely in some editions to the percentage of the population practicing TM that Maharishi Mahesh Yogi believed would be necessary to achieve increased coherence in the collective unconscious. It is the square root of one percent of the population (for example, about 1,700 people in the United States)  not merely “the square root of one percent,” which is 10 percent.

headline: Rambo Loses a Battle
text: Odeon, Britain’s largest chain of moviehouses, will not show “Rambo” at its theaters this weekend, citing “commercial reasons,” Variety reported. This is the film’s opening weekend in Britain. The news has enraged fans of Sylvester Stallone, right, especially those who live in rural areas where their only local cinema is an Odeon. The company said “the decision not to screen ‘Rambo’ will free up screens to show alternative popular new films such as ‘Jumper,’ ‘Be Kind Rewind’ and ‘Juno,’ ” but there was speculation among British movie exhibitors that the cause of the abrupt move was a disagreement over terms between Odeon and Sony, the film’s distributor. “I can’t remember the last time this happened in the multiplex era,” one film booker said. Sony Pictures Releasing U.K. declined to comment.

headline: Is He Insane? No, He’s Larry
text: “Witless Protection,” the third feature film starring Larry the Cable Guy, finds this comedian’s recurring character, Larry, here a small-town deputy, fantasizing about becoming an F.B.I. agent. He plays out his hero fantasies by rescuing a sultry trial witness named Madeleine (Ivana Milicevic, her arrival heralded by hubba-hubba sax music) from the custody of F.B.I. agents who Larry believes are working for the rich crook Madeleine is supposed to testify against in a tax fraud case.

headline: Sardonic Tales of Disillusionment Banged Out Quietly on the Bouzouki
text: Verbally meticulous, restrained and constitutionally glum, the songwriter Stephin Merritt is no one’s idea of a rocker  apparently not even his own. His band the Magnetic Fields usually performs in a quiet acoustic lineup. So “Distortion” (Nonesuch), their latest album, was a surprise, since its songs are awash in guitar discord over a big beat. Would the Magnetic Fields plug in and rock out for their four-night stand at Town Hall?

headline: Cheap Cocaine Floods Argentina, Devouring Lives
text: BUENOS AIRES  Bilma Acuña has two drug-addicted sons and roams the streets of the Ciudad Oculta slum here with a purpose: to save others from the same fate.

headline: Man Attacked and Robbed of $150,000 in Midtown
text: A man carrying a bag filled with nearly $150,000 in cash that he had just withdrawn from a bank in Midtown Manhattan was assaulted and robbed by an armed man on Friday afternoon, officials said.

headline: Open-Wheel Series Unite in Effort to Halt Decline
text: The rift that has divided open-wheel racing in the United States since 1996 and helped lead to the decline of the sport is finally over. Officials from the Indy Racing League announced Friday that they reached an agreement with leaders of the opposing Champ Car World Series to unify the two into one open-wheel racing series.

headline: A ‘Moral Hazard’ for a Housing Bailout: Sorting the Victims From Those Who Volunteered
text: WASHINGTON  Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for “financial innovation.”

headline: Before Another Bridge Falls
text: Nearly seven months after a highway bridge collapsed in Minneapolis, a federal commission put a jaw-dropping price tag on starting to attend to America’s crumbling foundations: $225 billion a year for the next 50 years just to maintain and upgrade surface transportation.

headline: Sidney Watters Jr., 90, Trainer of Champion Racehorses, Is Dead
text: Sidney Watters Jr., the Racing Hall of Fame racehorse trainer who saddled the champion colts Hoist the Flag and Slew o’ Gold, died Feb. 14 in Towson, Md. He was 90.

headline: In Germany, Boxing Finds Appreciation and a Hub
text: HAMBURG, Germany  When Wladimir Klitschko steps into the ring at Madison Square Garden against Sultan Ibragimov on Saturday night, New York City will once again be the focus of the heavyweight boxing world. But once the fight is over, the center of gravity for heavyweights will swing back to its new and unexpected home, Germany.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Rescuers Find Wreckage of Plane Carrying 46 in Venezuela
text: CARACAS, Venezuela  Capping a frenzied search by helicopter high in the Andean mountains of western Venezuela, rescue teams said Friday that they had found the debris of a plane carrying 46 people that had crashed shortly after taking off on Thursday from the provincial city of Mérida.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Wednesday about August Wilson’s 20th Century, a series of staged readings of the playwright’s 10-play cycle, at the Kennedy Center, misstated the history of the plays. “Jitney” was written first, not “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom.”

headline: Footnotes
text: The 92nd Street Y named Deborah Grace Winer, a playwright and author of several books on American song, the artistic director of Lyrics & Lyricists, the Y’s long-running American Songbook series. She replaces Kristin Lancino, who will leave at the end of the 2008 season. ... Jennifer Lopez, who is married to Marc Anthony, gave birth to twins, a boy and a girl, on Friday morning, The Associated Press reported. The girl arrived first. ... Stacy Keach will star as Richard M. Nixon in the national tour of “Frost/Nixon,” Playbill reported. The role was created on Broadway by Frank Langella, who won a Tony Award for it. The tour is scheduled to start on Sept. 26 in Owensboro, Ky.

headline: 3 Are Shot, 1 Fatally, in Brooklyn
text: One man was killed and two others were injured in a shooting at a popular Mexican restaurant in Brooklyn on Friday night, the police said.

headline: Paris Puts Up the Stats as Her Sister Plays the Foil
text: NORMAN, Okla.  It was a tight fit for the twins Courtney and Ashley Paris as they sat on the piano bench Thursday night, jockeying for position. With their hands poised over the instrument, they shot each other a look and then started plunking on the keys.

headline: The Conflict of Spending and Candor
text: WHEN I told my husband recently how much I had spent on a birthday gift for a relative, he had a bit of an “Exorcist” moment.

headline: More Sharp Words Traded Over Lapsed Wiretap Law
text: WASHINGTON  A new round of political sparring erupted Friday over the government’s wiretapping powers, as the Bush administration asserted that the lapsing of a surveillance law a week ago has already led to the loss of important intelligence information and made private phone carriers less willing to cooperate.

headline: Fallacy in Iraq
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An obituary on Thursday about the choral conductor Richard Westenburg misidentified the resident choir at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church while he was music director there. It was the church’s own choir of paid professionals and church members  not the Musica Sacra Chorus, though Musica Sacra sometimes performed at the church. The obituary also misstated Mr. Westenburg’s title at the Collegiate Chorale from 1973 to 1980. He was music director, not conductor.

headline: 2 Ex-Marsh Officials Convicted on Antitrust Charge
text: Two former executives of Marsh Inc., the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

headline: E-Mail Threats Lead to Arrest of a Woman
text: JERSEY CITY  Two days after the police canceled all classes at Saint Peter’s College and searched 20 campus buildings with bomb-sniffing dogs, an 18-year-old woman was arrested in Corpus Christi, Tex., on Friday and charged in connection with threatening e-mail messages that were sent to a 19-year-old male student at the college.

headline: On Clothing Racks, Inflation Is the Hot Trend
text: THE great clothing price deflation  brought on in part by China’s entry into the world economy  may be over.

headline: Much to Applaud, With Footnotes
text: Milan

headline: In California, Coastal Commission Wields Vast Power
text: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.  The battle here over a proposed toll road near a state park has entangled powerful interests from across California: Labor is pitted against surfers, American Indians against developers, commuters against campers and coastal people against inland dwellers.

headline: Sentence in Volkswagen Scandal
text: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen’s long-running corruption scandal has blackened its name and tainted some of Germany’s most influential businessmen. On Friday, a court handed down the first jail time in the affair, sentencing Volkswagen’s former top labor leader to nearly three years in prison.

headline: An Introspective Shade of Virtuosity
text: We tend to think of virtuosity as the musical equivalent of an extreme sport: lots of fast, loud, bravura passages that show off finger power and agility, ideally with enough originality in the phrasing to make the performance seem more than just whiz-bang display. But in his recital at the Rose Theater on Wednesday evening, the pianist Christian Zacharias argued that virtuosity comes in other forms as well, most notably as an expression of patient introspection.

headline: Rocker Joins Entourage in Africa
text: MONROVIA, Liberia  The contingent of reporters accompanying President Bush on his trip to Africa was small, a reflection of how the press is turning its attention away from the current president and toward the race to succeed him. But in Rwanda this week, Mr. Bush had a celebrity journalist in his entourage: Bob Geldof, the Irish rock star.

headline: Small Vendors Feel Pinch of Clinton’s Money Troubles
text: It was just $2,492.63, a pittance, really, alongside million-dollar television buys and direct mail drops.

headline: Man Departs a Life Lived on the Fringes of Fame
text: He died away from the noisy, glittery, late-night places where he was a regular among regulars, where he was, by turns, a promoter and a would-be gossip columnist who once asked Arthur Miller about sex with Marilyn Monroe.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article last Saturday about competition at the Berlin Film Festival misstated the day awards were to be handed out. The ceremony took place last Saturday, not Sunday.

headline: Raymond Kennedy, Novelist, Dies at 73
text: Raymond Kennedy, a writer known for his dark, absurdist novels set largely in his native New England, died on Monday in Brooklyn. He was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Memo to the ‘EcoMoms’: Really Go Green
text: To the Editor:

headline: Plan to Rebuild Penn Station Area May Be Close to Failure
text: The sweeping $14 billion proposal to transform Pennsylvania Station and the district around it is in danger of collapse because of the softening economy, shortfalls in government financing, political inertia and daunting logistical problems, government officials and real estate executives involved in the project said this week.

headline: With Oscar Show Salvaged, a Planned Film Museum Is Back in Play
text: LOS ANGELES  Until a settlement was reached two weeks ago, officials at the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences were worrying that a bitter Hollywood strike might take the polish off more than Oscar night. They were concerned that it would force them to shelve an institutional transition that had suddenly become tangled in a mess of writers, ratings and real estate.

headline: Israel Rejects Arab League Criticism on Palestinian Peace Talks
text: JERUSALEM  Israeli officials on Friday rejected Arab complaints that they were not committed to a two-state solution for Israel and the Palestinians and said Prime Minister Ehud Olmert had responded positively to the Arab League initiative as a basis for negotiations.

headline: Iraqi Shiite Cleric Extends Cease-Fire by His Militia
text: BAGHDAD  The Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr ordered his Mahdi Army militia on Friday to extend its cease-fire for six more months, bolstering hopes that a recent trend toward sharply lower Iraqi civilian and American military deaths in Baghdad would continue.

headline: The Magnificent Jet Age
text: To the Editor:

headline: Will Smith Wins a Libel Suit
text: Will Smith has received an apology and damages from a news agency after it falsely accused him of saying Hitler was “a good person,” the BBC reported. World Entertainment News Network published the article “Smith: Hitler Was A Good Person” in December, after which Mr. Smith sued for libel in a London court. “The defendant accepts that the allegations concerning the claimant were misleading and published in error,” the agency’s solicitor said.

headline: Photograph Could Put Clemens at 1998 Party
text: One day before Roger Clemens testified to a Congressional committee, a man told Clemens’s lawyer that he had a photograph placing Clemens at a party held by José Canseco, according to lawyers for Clemens and Brian McNamee, his former personal trainer.

headline: The Double Standard in Crisis Resolution
text: As the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by almost a third last month while the White House and Congress scrambled to concoct a $150 billion-plus fiscal stimulus package to loosen up the credit crunch, economic policy makers in developing countries couldn’t help but raise an eyebrow.

headline: Unfair Fixes for the Medicare Drug Plan
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Thursday about campaign spending by Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama misstated, in some copies, the amount of money Mrs. Clinton had at the end of January. For the nominating contests, she had $8.9 million, not $10 million. For the general election, she has $20.3 million set aside, not $19 million.

headline: Hollywood Gets Ready for Hoopla as Usual
text: LOS ANGELES  The calendar year doesn’t get much traction in many parts of Los Angeles, where the Carpetbagger has been since Wednesday, trolling for tidbits to feed his blog about all things Oscar. The Academy Awards are New Year’s Eve and New Year’s Day rolled into one, a day of reckoning when accounts are tallied, blessings are counted and resolutions are forged anew.

headline: Waterboarding Focus of Inquiry by Justice Dept.
text: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department revealed Friday that its internal ethics office was investigating the department’s legal approval for waterboarding of Qaeda suspects by the Central Intelligence Agency and was likely to make public an unclassified version of its report.

headline: Turkish Troops Enter Iraq in Pursuit of Kurdish Militants
text: BAGHDAD  Turkey’s military said Friday that it had sent troops into northern Iraq on Thursday night, in what Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey called a limited operation to weaken Kurdish militants there.

headline: Defending Champion Holds On to Lead
text: SOLVANG, Calif.  On paper, Levi Leipheimer looked to be facing one of his toughest days ever on the bike Friday at the fifth stage of the Tour of California.

headline: For Engineer, a Cloud of Litigation After 9/11
text: To hear Ramon Gilsanz speak  voice calm and measured, even on a day when travel plans are tied in a knot by a snowstorm  you would never guess that he is being sued by thousands of people. And that does not count the man who is suing him on behalf of everyone in the United States.

headline: All Those Foul Words Are Tennessee Williams’s
text: Was Big Daddy always such a potty mouth?

headline: Gates Calls Australia Alliance Strong
text: CANBERRA, Australia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and top Australian officials insisted Saturday that the security alliance between the United States and Australia had not frayed despite Australia’s recent pledge to remove all combat forces from Iraq.

headline: Cardozo Wins Girls Team Title
text: Dalilah Muhammad led Cardozo High School of Queens to the girls’ team title with 78 points in the Public Schools Athletic League indoor championships at the New Balance Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Muhammad won the high jump, finished second in the 55-meter hurdles and was third leg on Cardozo’s 4x800 winning relay (9:27.11). Midwood of Brooklyn captured the boys’ team crown with 51 points. Donald Williams paced Midwood with a victory in the 55-meter dash and ran second on Midwood’s winning 4x400 relay (3:28.60). Nadonna Rodrigues of Brooklyn’s Boys & Girls, who recently posted the fastest 400-meter time in the country at 52.83 seconds, took the 300 in 38.39 seconds and anchored her school’s winning 4x400 foursome (3:56.83).

headline: Liechtenstein Looks to Move Beyond Tax Feud
text: VADUZ, Liechtenstein  Do not mention the war  the tax war with Germany, that is.

headline: Clear Channel and Balky Suitor Talk
text: Clear Channel Communications is in negotiations with Providence Equity Partners to strike a new agreement for its television unit, people briefed on the situation said Friday.

headline: Powerful Union May Be Hedging Its Bets in Albany
text: ALBANY  No group has been more loyal or financially helpful to state Republicans than the powerful hospital workers’ union, 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East.

headline: Move Over, Oil, There’s Money in Texas Wind
text: SWEETWATER, Tex.  The wind turbines that recently went up on Louis Brooks’s ranch are twice as high as the Statue of Liberty, with blades that span as wide as the wingspan of a jumbo jet. More important from his point of view, he is paid $500 a month apiece to permit 78 of them on his land, with 76 more on the way.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards on Sunday, misidentified the American Express executive who discussed his company’s sponsorship of the broadcast. He is Diego Scotti, not Aldo Papone.

headline: Ruling to Come on Art Collection
text: A county judge in Nashville is to issue a ruling within 30 days on whether Fisk University can keep a 101-piece art collection that includes “Radiator Building  Night, New York” (1927), below, given to it by the artist Georgia O’Keeffe, The Associated Press reported. In a three-day trial that ended on Thursday, lawyers for the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., argued that Fisk lost the right to the prized collection and violated the terms of the 1949 gift when it took the works off display and tried to sell some. Fisk countered that it had never tried to sell the whole collection and that it now had the money to display the works according to the artist’s wishes. Seeking to shore up its finances, Fisk agreed in principle last fall to sell a 50 percent stake in the collection to the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark., for $30 million. But on Feb. 8 Ellen Hobbs Lyle, a Davidson County Chancery Court judge, struck down that proposal, saying it went against the donor’s wishes. Now the judge will rule on whether Fisk has forfeited its right to the art and whether it should go to the O’Keeffe Museum, which represents the artist’s estate.

headline: Judge Hints He May Reject 9/11 Families’ Plea to Sift Fresh Kills for Remains
text: At an inconclusive yet uncomfortably emotional hearing on Friday, a federal judge strongly suggested that he would turn down the request of several families of people who died at the World Trade Center to sift through a million tons of debris at the Fresh Kills landfill in a search for human remains left from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack.

headline: 2 Plans and Many Questions on the Uninsured
text: ATLANTA  Brandy Coons is what health economists call a free rider.

headline: Viewpoints Vary on Videotape Scandal
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Three N.F.L. coaches whose teams might have been targets of the illicit videotaping by the Patriots each view the controversy differently, highlighting the conflicting emotions that it has created within the league’s coaching fraternity.

headline: Boy’s Killing, Labeled a Hate Crime, Stuns a Town
text: OXNARD, Calif.  Hundreds of mourners gathered at a church here on Friday to remember an eighth-grade boy who was shot to death inside a junior high school computer lab by a fellow student in what prosecutors are calling a hate crime.

headline: Landmark Massachusetts Building Where Wharton Wrote Faces Foreclosure
text: The Mount, Edith Wharton’s estate in Lenox, Mass., is in danger of being put in foreclosure, says Stephanie Copeland, president of Edith Wharton Restoration, the organization that owns and maintains this stately residence and its surrounding gardens.

headline: Morocco: Prison for Facebook Prince
text: Fouad Mourtada, a 26-year-old engineer, was sentenced by a Casablanca court to three years in prison for creating a fake profile of the king’s brother on Facebook, the Internet social networking site, the official news agency MAP reported. He was accused of “villainous practices” and of stealing the identity of the crown prince, Moulay Rachid. The case has ignited the Moroccan blogosphere, which used it as a prime example of deteriorating freedom of expression in the North African kingdom. Hundreds of prank profiles exist on Facebook, for everyone from President Bush to Osama bin Laden. At least four fake Moulay Rachid Facebook pages have now been set up, apparently from the safety of overseas. The defense said it would appeal the sentence, MAP reported. MAP announced at the time of Mr. Mourtada’s arrest that no Moroccan royals maintained Web sites or blogs.

headline: Fraud Case Tied to Enron Ends in Prison for 3 Men
text: HOUSTON  Three former British bankers were sentenced on Friday to 37 months each in prison for their role in a fraud related to Enron.

headline: ‘A Father’s Law’
text: He saw the dim image of the traffic cop make a right-face turn and fling out a white-gloved arm, signaling that the flow of cars from the east should stop and that those toward the south now had the right of way, and at the same instant he heard the cop's shrill whistle: Wrrrriiiiiieee ...

headline: A Visit That Crosses Two Centuries and an Ocean
text: Given talent and the right connections, opera composers have at least an outside chance of a premiere performance by a reputable opera company. Revivals are the problem. The odds against them are long, but Conrad Susa’s “Dangerous Liaisons” has done better than most of its contemporaries.

headline: New CUNY Center to Focus on the Art of the Biography
text: Hoping to elevate the art and scholarship of biography, the Graduate Center of the City University of New York is setting up a center where its practitioners can meet, trade ideas and work.

headline: Grand Jury Indicts Arizona Congressman
text: WASHINGTON  Representative Rick Renzi, Republican of Arizona, was indicted this week by a federal grand jury on 35 counts of corruption, including fraud, money laundering, extortion and other crimes, federal prosecutors said Friday.

headline: 'Idol' Beats Competition
text: The results edition of “American Idol” lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Thursday while giving a considerable boost to that network’s other singing competition, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, 23.2 million viewers tuned in at 8 p.m. for “American Idol,” the night’s top-rated show. At 9, “Don’t Forget the Lyrics” drew 12.5 million viewers, more than 5 million above its average this season. Among adults 18 to 49, this karaoke-themed game show ranked third for the night, trailing only “American Idol” and ABC’s “Lost,” which led at 9 with 13.5 million viewers. ABC finished second for the night in the 18-to-49 set but third in total viewers behind both Fox and CBS, whose reruns of “CSI” at 9 (11.9 million) and “Without a Trace” at 10 (12.1 million) buoyed the network after a solid showing for “Big Brother” at 8 (12.5 million). NBC was a distant fourth over all, as both “The Celebrity Apprentice” at 9 (8 million) and “Lipstick Jungle” at 10 (5.8 million) struggled in their respective time slots.

headline: The Lost Treasure of Machu Picchu
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Debate Close Wasn’t a Farewell, Clinton Says
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio  With the mood of her campaign shadowed by the death of a police officer escorting her motorcade Friday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton vowed to carry on despite remarks in a debate Thursday night that some people took as a valedictory to her long effort to win the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: S.M.U. Makes It Official: Bush Library Is Coming
text: DALLAS  A center devoted to the life, works, papers and policies of President George W. Bush will be built at Southern Methodist University, officials announced Friday, despite faculty members’ lingering concerns and opposition from some Methodists.

headline: Being Fast Is Only the Start to Racing Success
text: BOSTON  Many people work out at home. Some run on treadmills. Some stretch or do yoga. Carmelita Jeter leans.

headline: F.D.A.’s Rule on Off-Labels
text: To the Editor:

headline: Coughlin’s Success Changes Opinions
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Tom Coughlin is suddenly brilliant and wildly popular. On Friday, he walked through the wide concourse of the convention center that serves as the nexus of the N.F.L. scouting combine. Fans reached for autographs and peers sought a handshake. Coughlin seemed to be in no hurry to go wherever it is that he goes from here.

headline: No Trades for Knicks, but Something to Cheer
text: The fast-moving gears on the N.B.A.’s trading season grinded to a halt Thursday, after two-thirds of the league made attempts to improve their prospects with moves large and small. The Knicks were shut out of the proceedings, leaving Coach Isiah Thomas with nothing to sell Friday but well-worn rhetoric.

headline: A Choreographer’s Life, Depicted in, Well ...
text: Dancers scattered throughout St. Mark’s Church read books in a murmured cacophony in Juliette Mapp’s new “Anna, Ikea and I” on Thursday night. This 90-minute piece is in a way a book itself: a sweet-tempered, witty and eloquent autobiography written by a wryly self-deprecatory dancer, choreographer and teacher about her years in dance.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the Art Show fair, at the Park Avenue Armory, contained an outdated reference to the Armory Show, an annual fair that opens on March 27 this year. It is held solely at Pier 94  not at two piers, as was the case from 2001 to 2006.

headline: Castro, Nearly Retired, Keeps Busy With a Few Pokes at U.S.
text: HAVANA  If anyone thought Fidel Castro was going to slip into quiet retirement, he dispelled that notion on Friday when he published a broadside against American politicians who have called for democracy in Cuba.

headline: Hillary on the High Road?
text: A referee would stop the fight. Hillary Clinton is exhausted, and her supporters are becoming increasingly demoralized. The candidate who tried to present herself as inevitable has been out-maneuvered nearly every step of the way by a prodigy with a warm and brilliant smile who still seems as energetic as an athlete doing calisthenics before a big game.

headline: Trapped in the Past
text: Kosovo’s declaration of independence was never going to be easy. Still, it is alarming to see the Serbian government so unwilling to peacefully channel its citizens’ anger and disappointment. Its failure to control rampaging crowds that set fire Thursday to part of the United States Embassy compound in Belgrade  and attacked several other embassies  is a shocking and unacceptable abdication of responsibility.

headline: Suspect Found Fit to Stand Trial in Therapist’s Killing
text: A man with a history of schizophrenia who was charged with killing an Upper East Side therapist with a meat cleaver and knives has been found mentally competent to stand trial.

headline: An Arsenal Against Drugs
text: To the Editor:

headline: Orin Lehman, 88, Parks Steward, Dies
text: Orin Lehman, who turned to public service rather than a career in his family’s investment company and eventually became New York State’s longest-serving commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,960 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Friday:

headline: Stimulus Plan Aids Buyers of High-Priced Homes
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Elizabeth and Ben Kilgore are back in the real estate market. All it took was a little-publicized section of the economic stimulus package President Bush signed into law last week that lowered the borrowing cost of buying a more expensive home.

headline: Bond Insurer Plans a Split to Protect Ratings
text: Ambac Financial Group, the embattled bond insurance company, plans to split itself in two in a bid to safeguard its top credit ratings and avert losses on securities that it guarantees for big banks.

headline: Health Coverage Often Stops at the Campus Gate
text: PARENTS often do not think twice about health coverage when their children head to college, but it might be to their advantage to take a second look before doing a double-take when they see their bills.

headline: Corrections
text: A sports article on Feb. 15 about the veracity of comments by the personal trainer Brian McNamee in his dispute with pitcher Roger Clemens paraphrased incorrectly from a transcript of a conversation between Mr. McNamee and investigators for Mr. Clemens on the day before the Mitchell report on performance-enhancing drugs in baseball was released. Mr. McNamee said he told Jim Murray, a New York-based representative for Mr. Clemens’s agent, that steroids had come from the former Mets bat boy Kirk Radomski. He did not say he had purchased steroids and growth hormone from Mr. Radomski.

headline: Ahhh, the Seductive Fragrance of Molecules Under Patent
text: Its scent is reminiscent of a mixture of a just-picked apple and a rose in its prime. But to the Takasago International Corporation, which manufactures this synthetic material, it smells even sweeter.

headline: No Longer in Race, Richardson Is a Man Pursued
text: SANTA FE, N.M.  Lots of people are calling Gov. Bill Richardson these days, “just to check in.”

headline: Ominous Signs Remain in City Run by Iraqis
text: BASRA, Iraq  This southern port city has been, in effect, on its own since September, when British forces here moved to the outskirts, yielding authority to local leaders. British and American officials say Basra’s experiment in self-rule could serve as a model for Iraq’s future, but if so  many locals and outside advisers say  that future remains dark.

headline: And Now, Back to the Democrats ...
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Global Journey, Relying on Kindness and a Donkey
text: TINACO, Venezuela

headline: Serbia Is Warned by Europe to Deter Embassy Attacks
text: BRUSSELS  European diplomats demanded Friday that Serbia provide better protection for Western embassies, warning that further talks on ties between Belgrade and the European Union could not take place unless violence subsided.

headline: Desegregation Order Lifted From a School in Brooklyn
text: A federal judge on Friday lifted a 1974 desegregation order for a Brooklyn middle school, effectively eliminating racial quotas that had been in place at Mark Twain Intermediate School for more than three decades.

headline: Big Raise for Pérez After Rare Arbitration
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Pérez had barely entered the Mets’ clubhouse Friday morning when Joe Smith asked the question.

headline: Suburbia’s March to Oblivion
text: THE mortgage crisis has put “for sale” signs in front of houses across the country  including so-called McMansions  the large, expensive, often tasteless homes that have taken up so much suburban space over the last couple of decades.

headline: In Aftermath of Article, McCain Gathers Donations
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Senator John McCain declared the battle over on Friday morning, but by then his lieutenants believed he had already won the war.

headline: Japan: Navy Chief Fired
text: Prime Minister Yasuo Fukuda ordered a review of the Defense Ministry’s structure amid mounting criticism of its handling of a collision between its most advanced naval destroyer and a small fishing boat. Shigeru Ishiba, the defense minister, also fired the head of the Maritime Self-Defense Force, which took 90 minutes to inform Mr. Ishiba of the accident on Tuesday morning. The Atago, a new destroyer equipped with the advanced Aegis system, rammed into the two-man fishing boat near Tokyo Bay even though it had spotted the small vessel 12 minutes before the collision. The fishermen have yet to be found.

headline: A Black Boxer Whose Opponents Included Segregation
text: Maya Angelou still retains the girlish ecstasy she felt as a 9-year-old in Stamps, Ark., listening to her grandmother’s radio as Joe Louis defeated James J. Braddock to win the heavyweight championship in 1937.

headline: China, in New Role, Presses Sudan on Darfur
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Amid the international outrage over the bloodshed in Darfur, frustration has increasingly turned toward China, Sudan’s biggest trading partner and international protector, culminating in Steven Spielberg’s decision last week to withdraw as artistic adviser to the Beijing Olympics.

headline: Fantasy Football Draft ’08, Part II
text: (Mark St. Amant is the author of Committed: Confessions of a Fantasy Football Junkie and Just Kick It: Tales of an Underdog, Over-Age, Out-of-Place Semi-Pro Football Player.)

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: A Bad Year to Be a Mallard
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Saturday, Feb. 23 column.

headline: Four Seasons, One Silly
text: The bar at the Four Seasons hotel in Beverly Hills is a good place to take a seat in the peanut gallery. In the early evening, Harvey Weinstein motored through, Leslee Dart and Allan Mayer, the reps to the stars, were sharing a drink. Mr. Mayer said that the Oscar weekend’s quieter affect had less to do with some mutual agreement to keep a lid on than a kind of opportunity.

headline: Fetal Monitor
text: Diablo Cody has been motoring through the season without much of a hitch, but Saturday was tough.

headline: A Duet of Nerves
text: Glen Hansard, front man of The Frames and a best song nominee for “Falling Slowly” from “Once,” thought for a quick second when the Bagger asked whether he was more intimidated by the prospect of performing for the Oscar hordes or sitting in his seat while the best song winner is announced.

headline: A Tiny Bit of Perspective
text: Industry types have taken a few gentle whacks at the diminutive 20-year-old, Ellen Page, suggesting that the star of “Juno” and a best actress nominee has not paid respect to all the glamour and gravitas of the Oscar season as she should. Page is not unaware of the blandishments of the process, she just prefers to treat it as a buffet table, taking some of it and leaving the rest, rather than just diving in. The Bagger interviewed her at the beginning of the season and now at its end, and she has not lost any of her gee-whiz or her innate skepticism of the trappings of stardom.

headline: The White Hot Center and the Hole in the Middle of the Donut
text: Oscar weekend, for a blogger who has been mostly typing in his basement, is disconcerting in that suddenly this world he has been flicking at from a distance comes to life before his very eyes.

headline: Pick. Your. Poison.
text: The Bagger’s picks for the podium tomorrow. All caveats apply – let’s just say that Anton Chigurh is not the only one who flipped a coin on the way to the Oscars. (For more details on the nominees and the picks, go here.) Now, what say you?

headline: ‘Dude, Guess What I Just Heard’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama had another debate last night. Clinton accused Obama of plagiarism. Obama denied that what he did was plagiarism. I don’t want to comment on that, but you have to admit that it would be great to one day have a president who can pronounce words like plagiarism.

headline: ‘Look! The Piñata Is Singing!’
text: Aired Friday night on NBC: Last night, Senator Hillary Clinton once again accused Barack Obama of plagiarizing a speech from another politician. Hillary said, “Plagiarizing is the second worst kind of cheating.”

headline: El Ted Sings
text: Perhaps not since the Taco Bell chihuahua have we seen such an homage to Mexican culture. Senator Kennedy at an Obama rally in Laredo, Texas (also see the Conan O’Brien monologue below):

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: In Beijing, Attention Shifts to Pyongyang
text: The morning of the New York Philharmonic’s debut at the Egg, otherwise known as the National Center for the Performing Arts, in Beijing on Saturday yielded a news conference with orchestra officials and Lorin Maazel, the music director. The main entranceway to the new center, a vast domed structure (hence “the Egg”) surrounded by a moat, passes under the moat water, which reflects down on a red carpet. Large posters of Mr. Maazel lined each side of the carpet.

headline: Economics in movies
text: A cute entry on the WSJ economics blog. But somehow they missed The Internecine Project, with James Coburn as a suave, murderous chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers who gets all his enemies to kill each other, or something like that.

headline: Paris, Saturday
text: I arrived in Paris from Milan last evening, on a flight with perhaps 20 models, including Lily D and Coco Rocha, and nearly half of them carried stuffed animals in their arms. It’s a strange sight to be standing at baggage claim watching ordinary travelers stare at giraffes with teddy bears and blue stuffed dogs, and I was surprised how many pieces of luggage a model could have, considering she spends her day wearing other peoples’ clothes. Girls are girls, I guess.

headline: Snow Swoops In
text: Planes and Buses Go Way Off Schedule

headline: Hockey Fan Buys Bauer From Nike
text: Ian Austen, who wrote in the Times business section earlier this month about Nike’s de-Canadianization of Bauer as part of its failed effort to break into hockey, reported in yesterday’s paper about the $200 million purchase of the Bauer division by a native Montrealer. The hockey and inline-skating businesses being what they are these days, that figure is about half what Nike paid for Bauer in 1994.

headline: The Early Word: Hard Times for Hillary Clinton
text: Friday was a rough day for Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as she sought to dispel speculation that her closing debate remarks amounted to a concession amid the death of a police officer escorting her campaign – all while Senator Barack Obama was stumping around South Texas, one of her strongholds in the state.

headline: The Hazards of Politically Correct Research
text: The debate on female initiation rites continues. An earlier post by World Health Organization researchers discussed the hazards of the practice they call FGM (female genital mutiliation). Here’s a response from two Swedish scholars who have studied the topic over the past 10 years, Sara Johnsdotter, a senior lecturer in medical anthropology at Malmö University, and Birgitta Essen, a senior lecturer in international maternal health and associate professor in obstetrics and gynocology at Uppsala University:

headline: The Moment, Interrupted
text: Many thought that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s answer to a debate question about a “moment” that tested her sounded like a concession. So many, in fact, that she had to formally deny it on Friday. And now her campaign wants to use that “moment,” or a selected 60 seconds of it, in a new campaign spot.

headline: Tidbits From Port St. Lucie
text: After spending the morning posing with assorted plastic vegetables, pots and pans for their second annual Gourmets cookbook, the Mets moved on to more important things. You know, like Jose Reyes’s flitting around the clubhouse and morphing into Mike Wallace, interviewing Pedro Martinez for a Spanish-language TV station. Yes, it’s business as usual in the clubhouse, which always tends to be a little more raucous earlier in camp for the simple reason that there are about twice as many people here now.

headline: A Police Chase From Newark to Brooklyn
text: A man who was stopped by the police in Newark on Friday for driving a stolen car struggled with an officer, whose gun fell into the car, the police said. The man drove off, and was hit in the hand when another officer fired at him. The man then drove east and made it to Brooklyn before the car smashed into another vehicle at Smith and Pacific Streets, where the driver was arrested, the police said.

headline: Will Clooney Take a Walk?
text: Tom O’Neil tiptoes out on a limb  and says the geezer demo might, could, may, push George Clooney past Daniel Day-Lewis in best actor. Cool call, a swing for the fences.

text: Dinner at the Palazzo. Photos by Joyce Hor-Chung Lau

headline: Clinton Slams Obama Tactics
text: CINCINNATI – Accusing the Obama campaign of using tactics “that are right out of Karl Rove’s playbook,” Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton angrily denounced Senator Barack Obama on Saturday for sending fliers to Ohio voters that she called misleading and false.

headline: New Lawsuit Against Chess Federation
text: Gordon Roy Parker has filed a lawsuit in the Eastern District of Pennsylvania accusing several current and former chess officials of conspiring to destroy the United States Chess Federation to profit from its demise.

headline: Your Examples of Obama and Clinton Courage
text: I’ve had a ton of indignant emails about last Sunday’s column about John McCain, in which I said I disagreed with his positions but admired his willingness to disagree so often with the voters whose support he needed. I argued that he pandered when necessary — witness his recent tack to the right — but with evident discomfort and incompetence, and that it wasn’t instinctive as with many candidates. Most of the criticism was from people who think it’s wrong to give McCain any credit, given his recent moves to the right.

headline: Election Prediction Contest
text: We’re going to close entries to my election prediction contest in the next couple of days. So if you want to enter, and win eternal glory, then hurry up…

headline: Your Comments on my Obama Roots Column
text: My Sunday column is about Barack Obama’s ancestral village of Kogelo, Kenya, where I met his grandmother — actually it’s his step-grandma, but she’s the one who raised his Dad and whom he calls his grandmother. Post your comments about the column and the video here.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Putting the Egg to the Test
text: Slide Show: Performing at ‘The Egg’

headline: Devils Snatch Mediocrity From the Jaws of Disaster
text: The Devils beat the Islanders, 4-2, on Saturday afternoon, concluding their five-week-long homestand in which they played 15 out of 18 games at the Prudential Center. Going into the homestand, it seemed as if New Jersey would rack up the points and zoom to the top of the East — but that’s not what happened.

headline: Koufax Visits and Pedro Talks
text: It isn’t every day – or ever, really – that Sandy Koufax decides to speak with reporters but that day came today (you can read all about him online later tonight) Koufax, a childhood friend of Fred Wilpon, usually drops by spring training to speak with a left-hander – Tom Glavine or Al Leiter, in the past – and he did so today at the request of Billy Wagner, who is learning to throw a curveball. And, really, is there anyone better to learn that pitch from than Koufax? But Koufax has a very special relationship with Pedro Martinez, who met Koufax about 20 years ago when he was a 17-year-old in Dodgertown, up in Vero Beach, for the first time. Pedro spoke about that relationship with us today. Some of it you’ll see in my story, but Pedro was so fantastic speaking about the subject that it would be unfair for baseball fans not to read more. Here’s a chunk of the Q&A with Pedro. Enjoy.

headline: More Puzzles From Recent Events
text: Even very strong players are not immune to making fairly basic mistakes, as shown by the first two problems in this set, which come from games in the Aeroflot Open. Endgames are often won with precise play, as seen in the fourth problem. The last problem is not from a game, but rather is based on an actual position and involves a king hunt. In each case, click on the chess board and wait for the viewer to load, then make a move on the chess board by clicking and dragging a piece and wait for the computer to respond. If you get the whole sequence of moves right , the computer will let you know that you succeeded. Hints are available. Enjoy!

headline: Independent Spirits: On the Beach, Under the Wire
text: The Bagger took his dune buggy down the hill to Santa Monica and has pulled up to the Independent Spirit Awards, the annual hoedown dedicated to independent film. Just after the talent finally made their way in, the rain came. The year, Rainn Wilson (Dwight on “The Office”) is hosting the event and said he works in something called “television,” a device that Indywood don’t much about, along with the people who enjoy it.

headline: Deconstructing an Obama Victory
text: Here’s further grist for the mill for anyone deconstructing how Senator Hillary Clinton lost so many states to Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Sunday’s Breakfast Menu, Feb. 24
text: Senator John McCain has said he “does not intend to discuss it further,” but his top advisers are likely not finished talking about a New York Times article examining his ties to a lobbyist on Sunday’s news shows. Charlie Black, a top strategist, is slated for CBS’s “Face the Nation,” Robert Bennett, his lawyer dealing with this matter, is on CNN’s “Late Edition,” and Rick Davis, the campaign manager, is on “Fox News Sunday.”

headline: Independent Spirits: She’s Right There
text: Best supporting female went to Cate Blanchett, who is very much with child, for her inhabitation of Bob Dylan. After taking a while to get up to the podium, she said, “It’s not polite to make a pregnant lady waddle that far.”

headline: Wonderful World of Color
text: Children of all ages are hooked on pink and blue, a trend ensured by parents who begin collecting for sons and daughters when they are infants.

headline: Independent Spirits: Yelling Cut on the Cut-Up
text: A series of fake auditions by Rainn Wilson with the real directors – Julian Schnabel and Todd Haynes so far – have been over the top hilarious. Wilson, who has made a fine career out of acting the fool on “The Office,” is knocking them dead at the Spirits. His “audition” as Bob Dylan had people choking on their blow-dried chicken entrée.

headline: Getting Ready for Tip-off in Memphis
text: MEMPHIS — It’s a sunny Saturday here, and the streets around the downtown are already buzzing for the big No. 1 vs. No. 2 game tonight between Memphis and Tennessee.

headline: Independent Spirits: A Savage Love
text: Philip Seymour Hoffman, who won for best male lead, said that he felt as if he had “gained two sisters” in making “The Savages.” “The sublime Laura Linney,” speaking for many in mentioning his co-star, and director Tamara Jenkins.

headline: Back in Buffalo
text: The Rangers’ game tonight in Buffalo not only brings the team back to the site of their moment of defeat to the Sabres in last year’s playoffs, but also brings the architect of that defeat — then-Sabres captain Chris Drury — back here as well.

headline: Independent Spirits: June Bug Goes Big
text: Ellen Page seemed actually surprised she won best actress – no one else was – and she said this is pretty much “all Diablo Cody’s fault. She wrote one of the best screenplays I have ever read.”

headline: Showing Up Late for Spring Training
text: The Yankees’ pitchers and catchers reported to spring training on Feb. 14, and the rest of the squad showed up a few days later. Yet I’m just now flying to Tampa.

headline: Clinton Offers Regrets for Spouse’s Remarks
text: NEW ORLEANS – Appearing before a predominantly black audience here Saturday afternoon, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton defended her husband’s legacy on race relations and offered an apology of sorts for comments he made in South Carolina several weeks ago that many people viewed as racially insensitive.

headline: Star Gazing at FedEx Forum
text: MEMPHIS – This game between Memphis and Tennessee has been a fascinating portrait of just how much the country cares about college basketball. While we won’t find out until the ratings come out if Memphis and Tennessee moves the television needle, it certainly has attracted an unusual blend of celebrities.

headline: The Romance of Family
text: Like Frank quoting Marsha, I too “didn’t quite buy that the Mother needed comforting at the end.” Also, like Frank, I wanted more of a catharsis and for Violet “to have a last moment in communion with her existential terror.”

headline: Highs and Lows in the Record Books
text: Memphis and Tennessee might be the talk of college basketball today, but this was significant day for two other teams — for vastly different reasons. Let us consider the fates of Bentley College and the New Jersey Institute of Technology, which were each featured in articles by The Times last month (here and here).

headline: Lifting Spirits
text: There are those, count the Bagger among them, who think the ’08 season could use a lift. And it arrived the day before the Oscars: a wrasslin’ match occurred on Santa Monica beach that seemed to indicate that one way or another, all will be well.

headline: U.S. Defense Chief and Australians Insist Alliance Is Strong
text: CANBERRA, Australia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and top Australian officials insisted Saturday that the security alliance between the United States and Australia had not frayed despite Australia’s recent pledge to remove all combat forces from Iraq.

headline: Power Play
text: There’s a school of style slut (and I’ll own up to being a member) that likes to believe changes in fashion reflect broader shifts in society, geopolitics, the arts, the economy and so on. Maybe it makes us feel less guilty about spending quite so much time and money on what we wear, or perhaps it gives us an excuse to talk about it longer.

headline: Now Swapping | Musical Ensembles
text: Swap-a-rama Razzmatazz is one of London’s most fashionable club nights  and certainly its most eccentric. Its origins date to the time when a chap named Alex Collins studied abroad and lived on a commune where many garments were communal property. Eager to recreate back home that “year of my life when not having possessions didn’t bother me,” Collins held a party at which guests were told to swap outfits every time a whistle blew. The mayhem inspired Eloise Markwell-Butler, Dean Slydell, Dani Mazzer and Nick Frew to take the concept public, aided by donations from the vintage megastore Beyond Retro. Swap-a-rama Razzmatazz is now held at Favela Chic in the Shoreditch neighborhood once every month. Clotheslines festoon the club, and when the klaxon sounds, you either swap or split: ogling bystanders are evicted. Markwell-Butler likens it to “being in a mad person’s laundry.” Since partygoers keep their booty, at £3 for admission, it’s London’s cheapest way to get a new wardrobe. [?][?][?]SARAH NIR

headline: An Approach to Cuba
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kill and Be Killed
text: Peter Robinson is a good, gray writer who, while lacking a dazzling literary style, brings much sober intelligence and technical skill to the plotting of his police procedural series featuring Detective Chief Inspector Alan Banks and various colleagues in the Eastvale constabulary. While all that well-hammered craftsmanship can feel a bit leaden, Robinson always tells a dandy story. And when he chooses  to challenge himself or merely to sate the current publishing appetite for supersized mysteries with bloated plots  he can even tell two stories at once, as is the case in FRIEND OF THE DEVIL (Morrow, $24.95).

headline: Goddess in the Details
text: This is the Year of the Goddess, judging by the clothes that designers sent down the runway. So much for the sirens: they had their day, and now they’re tired; some are in rehab. More preferable, as archetypes go, is the goddess, with her ancient Grecian pedigree, her aloof demeanor suggesting self-possession and powers of divine intervention, her sensuous revelry in her own body. The goddess ratchets our standards considerably higher where sex is concerned: only gods need apply.

headline: Big Wheels for Iraq’s Mean Streets
text: ON the first day of his third deployment to Iraq, Marine Staff Sgt. Christopher Spurlock was traveling in a convoy that was helping to clear roadside bombs in Ramadi. Sergeant Spurlock was riding in an armored transport known as an MRAP, and his vehicle, a Cougar, was fourth or fifth in line.

headline: L’Heir du Temps
text: If you’re in Paris and you want to see Ingres’s 1862 masterpiece, “Le Bain Turc,” or his earlier flirtation with neo-Classicism in “Oedipus Explaining the Enigma of the Sphinx,” or the Greek Classicism that inspired it, you can take the Métro to an art museum called the Louvre. If you want to smell the original 1966 Aramis, which descended from the 1944 Bandit, which itself was built on the principles of Fougère Royale created for the house of Houbigant in 1884, you can take the RER to another Paris art museum: the Osmothèque, at 36 rue du Parc-de-Clagny.

headline: A Country Music Veteran Proves He’s No Mere Hat Act
text: NASHVILLE

headline: Putin’s Iron Grip on Russia Suffocates Opponents
text: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia  Shortly before parliamentary elections in December, foremen fanned out across the sprawling GAZ vehicle factory here, pulling aside assembly-line workers and giving them an order: vote for President Vladimir V. Putin’s party or else. They were instructed to phone in after they left their polling places. Names would be tallied, defiance punished.

headline: Stefani Zaidman and Michael Ash
text: Stefani Lauren Zaidman, a daughter of Susan and Louis Zaidman of Manalapan, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Michael Jared Ash, a son of Sharon and Abraham Ash of Monroe, N.J. Rabbi Ira J. Rothstein performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in Closter, N.J.

headline: Pink Is for ...
text: THE inspiration for JeongMee Yoon’s photographic project was her 5-year-old daughter, Seowoo, who loved things pink. As a setting for a portrait, Ms. Yoon assembled all of her daughter’s pink possessions  stuffed animals, dolls, plastic toys, books, clothes, jewelry, makeup and school supplies  into an orderly display. Seowoo’s bedroom was transformed into a pink kingdom for a child queen.

headline: Looking for Music, but Not ‘Celebration,’ to Remember Castro? Put the Radio On
text: JERSEY CITY

headline: Correction: Essay
text: An essay on Feb. 10 about F. Scott Fitzgerald’s Pat Hobby stories added a word to the title of one of Fitzgerald’s novels. It is “The Beautiful and Damned,” not “the Damned.”

headline: Closed Kingdom Cracks a Door Open
text: IF you were running a restrictive Islamic state where the women can’t drive and restaurants are segregated between families and single men, the last idea that might occur to you is to invite Westerners in to have a look. And yet, that’s exactly what the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is doing.

headline: Imagination Business Begins at Home
text: NOT so long ago, all you had to do to show disdain for something was to look bored and say, “Oh ... it’s so derivative.”

headline: Jeepers Peepers!
text: American culture has long fetishized the eyelash. Designed by nature to be the simple shrubbery that protects the cornea from dust and small particles, the humble strip of cilia has evolved into an object of sensual fascination, aesthetic peacockery and, most recently, federal concern of such magnitude that the F.D.A. and a squadron of marshals were forced to intervene.

headline: With Simple Tools, an Expression of Fragility and Humanity
text: An abbreviated list of materials used in Fred Holland’s exhibition at the Amelie A. Wallace Gallery includes yams, wax, gold leaf, honey, soap, water, dirt and electricity. A sculptor and conceptual artist, Mr. Holland has turned the three large galleries here into a seductively cryptic meditation on impermanence, fragility and regeneration.

headline: Hey, Humvee, Move Over: Driving an MRAP
text: MRAPS are indeed huge and ungainly, but they have a surprisingly supple ride and are quick when they have to be. Although I could not imagine maneuvering them through narrow Iraqi streets, they perform well on the open road.

headline: In Two Minutes, Devils Get Upper Hand on Islanders
text: NEWARK  Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro kept his helmet on just in case, but he finished Saturday’s game against the Devils on the bench, replaced by an extra skater. His mastery over the Devils had been undone by a third-period onslaught.

headline: House Weighing Independent Ethics Panel
text: WASHINGTON  Days after another member of Congress was charged in a broad criminal indictment, the House is set to consider the creation of an independent ethics panel that supporters hope will restore credibility to efforts to police Congress internally.

text: The hodgepodge of fabrics stitched together by MARC JACOBS this spring recalled Margiela’s early experiments with deconstruction and layering.

text: WITH more than 20,000 subprime mortgages in Connecticut scheduled to reset to higher interest rates over the next two years, the wave of foreclosures currently flooding court dockets throughout the state represents the early stages of what could be a protracted deluge. While foreclosures are up all over the state, the region hit hardest so far is New Haven County.

headline: Once Pure White, American Classics Cross a Color Line
text: THEATER people have been talking for decades about James Earl Jones playing Big Daddy. The established white Southern setting of Tennessee Williams’s “Cat on a Hot Tin Roof” notwithstanding, Mr. Jones, the barrel-chested actor with the inimitable basso profundo, strikes many as a natural fit for the foul-tempered, vulgar landowner. There was serious discussion about building a production of the play around him back in 1987, and when the producer Stephen Byrd approached him about the part in the mid-’90s, Mr. Jones told him, “I always wanted to play that cracker.”

headline: A Kingdom in the Mountains Shares Its Secrets
text: WHEN American curators arrived one spring morning at Norbugang Yu Lhakang, a Buddhist temple in a remote village in western Bhutan, they found a group of monks sitting on the floor in bright robes, chanting. They had been there since 6 a.m., intent on creating the right ambience for a divination ceremony.

headline: Courtney Coles, Jonathan Evans
text: Courtney Elizabeth Coles, a daughter of Maryellen Coles and Julian R. Coles of Cape Elizabeth, Me., was married on Saturday to Jonathan Perry Evans, the son of Constance F. Tierney of New York and Robert S. Evans of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Suzanne Meyer, a Unitarian minister, officiated at La Playa Beach & Golf Resort in Naples, Fla.

headline: The Plaza to Reopen After $400 Million Face-Lift
text: The Eloise of the new millennium should be thrilled to return to her beloved Plaza, which after two years and a $400 million renovation, is set to reopen March 1. The hotel has maintained its Old World grandeur by redressing 282 guest rooms and suites with custom-made furnishings and furniture à la Louis XV, while it has simultaneously entered the modern age with touch-screen AMX Systems in each room that control the temperature and lighting and put guests in direct contact with concierge services. Eloise would also be impressed with the hotel-wide wireless Internet access, flat-screen televisions, 24-karat gold-plated bathroom faucets and white-glove butler service. The Plaza will have 35,000 square feet of meeting space (including an upgraded Grand Ballroom and Terrace Room), and high-end shopping at the Plaza Retail Collection, which will also house a spa, salon, and fitness center. There will also be two new elegant watering holes: a champagne bar in the lobby and the Rose Club, which will serve signature cocktails. Nightly rates start at $1,000 (www.theplaza.com).

headline: Off-Road, and Off-Limits
text: CHATSWORTH, N.J.

headline: Big Hat Millie and Other Reminders of a Vanishing Past
text: THE last time Camille Taylor caught a whiff of fame was more than 60 years ago on the stage of the Apollo Theater in Harlem. Back then, Ms. Taylor was a spunky young woman who had moved to New York from Charlotte, N.C., and edged her way onto the black vaudeville circuit. Her stage name was Big Hat Millie, a nod to the wide-brimmed hats she favored.

headline: You Hate His Toll Plan; Ready for His Budget?
