headline: How to Date a Video Gamer
text: The first time Miho Walsh visited Roy Prieb’s New York apartment in 2003, she spent three hours watching him and his roommates play the video game Splinter Cell. “I got a good sense of what Roy likes to do in his spare time,” Ms. Walsh said.

headline: Frill Seekers
text: Who needs television writers when you’ve got big-city housewives willing to bare all? The women who star in “Real Housewives of New York City,” which premieres on Bravo on March 4, recently provided enough material for a novel, but a thousand words will have to suffice.

headline: Echoes of Amado in the Dark and the Light
text: IN Portuguese, “amado” means “beloved,” and in more than a score of novels, the Brazilian writer Jorge Amado made clear his eternal passion for Salvador da Bahia, the city that took him in as a teenage boarding student and became his home. Salvador, in turn, loved him back, and even now, more than six years after his death, Amado’s exuberant spirit, aesthetic and characters seem to permeate the streets of the place he described both as “the most mysterious and beautiful of the world’s cities” and “the most languid of women.”

headline: Susannah Foster, Kenyon Weaver
text: Susannah Landes Foster, a daughter of Jane L. Foster and Edward I. Foster of Merion Station, Pa., was married on Saturday evening to Kenyon Sean Matthew Weaver, a son of Jacqueline L. Weaver and Kirk K. Weaver of Houston. Rabbi Vivian E. Schirn officiated at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

headline: Now Buying | Guerrilla-girl Bags
text: The latest addition to the fashion world’s motley crew of multitaskers is a group of drug guerrillas turned handbag designers. Not to be confused with the feminist art gang the Guerrilla Girls or Comme des Garçons’ temporary “guerrilla” stores, these unlikely artisans work with Egg, a Bogotá-based nonprofit organization that is teaching reformed Colombian rebels how to make crocodile totes. Currently, a battery of 20-something men  all from the Antioquia region, where the Colombian armed conflict still has legs  learn construction techniques from native craftsmen. “They’re fiercely dedicated to their work,” says Claudia Gaitán de Caballero, Egg’s co-director. “And it’s a great way for them to become regular citizens.” The bags, which have been picked up by decidedly imperialist institutions like New York’s Takashimaya and Saks Fifth Avenue Mexico, retail for about $1,300. [?][?][?]SUSAN CERNE

headline: The Greek Ideal
text: Aphrodite, goddess of desire and beauty.

headline: Tristram, Tom and Gulliver
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Peek Behind North Korea’s Iron Curtain
text: The Berlin Wall might be a thing of the past, but the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea  the world’s most heavily armed border  is still a modern-day phenomenon. Americans who’d like to take a peek behind North Korea’s Iron Curtain, including the zone have a chance to do so this fall with two tours offered by Snow Lion Expeditions (www.snowlion.com), a Salt Lake City-based travel company. “We have a crack in the door for Americans to get in,” said Steve Pastorino, vice president of marketing for the company, who has found a way to procure visas for Americans through a partnership with Koryo, a British consortium of documentary filmmakers and tour guides who work regularly in North Korea. The 11-day tours visit both North and South Korea, using Beijing as a home base. Highlights of the itinerary include attending the Mass Games, a color-coded, athletic performance organized by the state, and visiting sites like Kumsusan Memorial Palace, the mausoleum of Kim Il-Sung. The trip starts at $5,895, including guides, lodging, meals and admission  but not flights.

headline: New Group Chooses Its First Battle, Asthma
text: GWENDOLYN STRETCH, the medical director at the Elsie Owens North Brookhaven Health Center, in Coram, had a lot to do during the 20-minute appointment with her next patient. After examining Nelia McPherson, 44, a chronic asthma patient from East Patchogue, Dr. Stretch renewed prescriptions and discussed some of the risks that could trigger an asthma attack  including rugs and plastic covers on mattresses. Atop the doctor’s priority list was to encourage her patient to stop smoking.

headline: Weight Watchers
text: They’re not just slimming: when priced by the pound, this season’s most diaphanous dresses might make you lightheaded. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER

headline: Poet-Soldiers Lend Voices on Iraq War
text: Teaneck

headline: The Illusionist
text: Steven Millhauser doesn’t traffic in emotional upheaval or interpersonal conflict. Most fiction writers try to make characters seem like real people, but Millhauser flattens them, giving his books the paradoxical effect of seeming realer than reality. For him, meticulous observation does the work of psychology. Millhauser is also our foremost animist: in his stories, mannequins walk out of department store windows and figures in paintings knock hats off innocent bystanders. His vehicles for these effects are the parable and the confession. There is a disquieting quiet to every Millhauser sentence that makes it immediately recognizable, a feeling that each was recorded for posterity by the last man living.

headline: Pirates’ New Management Team Asks Fans to Hope Against Hope
text: BRADENTON, Fla.  Frank Coonelly, the new president of the Pittsburgh Pirates, was soaking up the sounds of bat cracking ball and ball popping leather on Thursday when a fan pierced the paradise.

headline: At 17, a Folk Artist on the Rise
text: Croton-on-Hudson

headline: What’s My line?
text: Play’s the thing for this season’s dress rehearsal. The starlet MariaCarla Boscono bones up.

headline: Primary Sources
text: David McCullough, the best-selling historian, insists that the secret to his craft is simple: tell stories. If we say, “The king died and then the queen died,” we have two events. If we add that the queen died of grief, we have a story, and a good one because the reader has a reason to care. This maxim (McCullough borrowed it from E. M. Forster) is less helpful when there’s no royal paper trail. Can history assume the queen’s grief because it makes a good story? A good story may stand in for a true one.

headline: Baby Steps
text: The model Liya Kebede has made great strides for racial diversity in fashion (see her in “Toga Land,” Page 236). Now, she’s starting Lemlem, a mostly hand-woven line of children’s clothes made in Africa, in the hope that a younger crowd will embrace her multi-culti ideals. “The name means ‘to bloom,’ ” says Kebede, who on a visit to her native Ethiopia met talented weavers struggling to survive. “I wanted to help preserve their art while creating job opportunities.” The outfits, at Scoop and Barneys New York, have an Ethiopian vibe with a New World ease. Finicky tots will approve. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER

headline: A Run for Governor, Rough Edges Included
text: An article last Sunday about James A. Amann, the speaker of Connecticut’s legislature, who is exploring a run for governor, misstated the surname of the winner of Connecticut’s 2006 Democratic primary for the United States Senate. It is Ned Lamont, not Lamott.

headline: Boston Has High Hopes Now That the Dig Is Done
text: BOSTON  In the gloom of winter, it is hard to see potential amid the strips of brown grass and pavement that lie where this city’s hulking elevated highway used to be.

headline: Teamwork’s Rewards
text: I WAS born with social activism in my DNA. My grandfather was a union organizer in the garment district in New York City. My mother took me to a civil rights demonstration in Washington in my stroller. My father was worried that I’d be the youngest person to have a photograph in an F.B.I. file.

headline: Don’t Go There
text: As the author of more than 20 contentious volumes of criticism, George Steiner hasn’t exactly been one to hold back. Yet some projects have been too sensitive, difficult or doomed for him to undertake. His new collection of essays, “My Unwritten Books,” offers blueprints and eulogies for seven books he says he’ll never write, on topics including his Jewish identity, teaching, animals and politics. These essays are not imaginary CliffsNotes; they stand alone and reveal Steiner at his most complex: irascible and passionate, erudite and self-absorbed, determined to engage the most difficult cultural problems. His lyric fury is sharpest in “School Terms,” in which he surveys educational practices across the globe  then takes a flamethrower to them. Steiner, who taught at a string of top institutions before settling down at Harvard, then Cambridge, ultimately proposes an übersyllabus that would gorge us on the world’s diverse knowledge.

headline: Correction: In Miami, the Beach Party Moves Indoors
text: An article on Feb. 3 about the art scene in Miami misspelled the name of a collector and real estate developer in one reference. He is Craig Robins, not Robbins.

headline: A Silken Mountain of Forgery
text: IN 1957 the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, snagged what appeared to be a rare masterpiece by the 10th-century Chinese painter Guan Tong. Not only was “Drinking and Singing at the Foot of a Precipitous Mountain” a spectacular example of the monumental landscape tradition  a view of cloud-dappled peaks, densely forested slopes and swirling waters  but the painting’s pedigree also seemed impeccable. Inscriptions on the worn, fragile silk indicated that through the centuries it had been among the treasured possessions of princes, emperors and connoisseurs. The latest of those collectors was Zhang Daqian, then in his 50s, one of the pre-eminent authorities on Chinese art and a renowned painter in his own right.

headline: Correction: The Power of Whimsy
text: An article last Sunday about Sandra Boynton, the children’s book author and greeting card creator, quoted incorrectly the final part of a passage from her book “Barnyard Dance!” It is “Bow to the horse. Bow to the cow. Twirl with the pig if you know how,” not “Bow to the horse if you know how.”

headline: Public Broadcasting: Yes, It’s Necessary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Vaccinating Boys for Girls’ Sake?
text: HOW cool are those Gardasil Girls? Riding horses, flinging softballs, bashing away on drum sets: on the television commercials, they are pugnacious and utterly winning. They want to be “One Less,” they chant  one less victim of cervical cancer. Get vaccinated with Gardasil, they urge their sisters. Protect yourselves against the human papillomavirus, or H.P.V., which causes cervical cancer.

headline: Letters
text: One President’s Impact

headline: Profane Poet
text: The apotheosis of David Mamet comes near the start of the movie version of “Glengarry Glen Ross.” Alec Baldwin  hair slicked back, pocket square peaking just so  unleashes a furious, seven-minute tirade against some underperforming real estate salesmen. “First prize is a Cadillac Eldorado,” he says of a sadistic new contest to increase business. “Second prize is a set of steak knives. ... Third prize is you’re fired.” After insulting his listeners’ manhood, competence and just about every other attribute that can be impugned with a well-aimed profanity, Baldwin caps the presentation by extracting from his briefcase and brandishing a pair of huge brass balls.

headline: Upheaval Over Kosovo’s Independence Echoes in a New York Enclave
text: For Serbian-Americans, the news from their home country continues to be bad.

headline: Elusive Equality
text: In 2006, New Jersey’s Supreme Court declared that same-sex couples must be guaranteed all the rights and benefits that come with marriage, but left it to the State Legislature to figure out how. Instead of simply granting gay people the right to marry, the Legislature joined Vermont and Connecticut in creating a lesser category, civil unions. Predictably, civil unions are proving to be an inadequate remedy.

headline: In Pursuit of Britten’s Hated Outsider
text: THE game is constantly afoot in Benjamin Britten’s “Peter Grimes.” Everyone, it seems, is hunting for something or someone in this opera, most spectacularly in the third and last act, when the entire little fishing community on the harsh North Sea coast of England transforms itself into a vicious mob on the track of Grimes himself, “the borough criminal” who must be caught and destroyed. One of the most terrifying scenes in opera, it is likely to chill audiences once more when the Metropolitan Opera unveils its new staging on Thursday evening. This is the company’s third production since it introduced this compelling work in 1948, just three years after the world premiere at the Sadler’s Wells Opera in London.

headline: On Air, a Broadcaster and a Killer Shared a Platform
text: Larry Davis, the notorious Bronx killer who was stabbed to death in prison last week, was effectively cut off from the outside world when he was sentenced for murder in 1991. But during his years of incarceration, he found a way to reach beyond his prison bars.

headline: Not Too Late for a Dash to the Games
text: IT’S not too late to plan a trip to the Beijing Olympics. Sure, more than a million visitors are expected to visit during the Summer Games this August, and most tourist hotels are booked solid. But procrastinators can still chase Olympic gold if they’re willing to be flexible, spend a little more money and perhaps blend in with the locals.

headline: ‘Beginner’s Greek’
text: For its entire history, the firm of Beeche and Company, which could trace its origins to New Amsterdam, had engaged solely in one commercial activity: trading. At no time had it cultivated or mined or manufactured any good; it acted, rather, as merchant, factor, broker, financier. At its beginnings, it imported the axes that it traded for wampum, which it traded for beaver skins, which it sold for export. Later on, it bought corn and wheat from the farms of the north and sent its ships laden with them to the Caribbean, where they exchanged their cargo for sugar, rum, molasses, and indigo, which, on the ships' return, Beeche re-exported to the east and west; sometimes, the eastbound ships, after first calling in Britain or France, traveled down to the African coast and then sailed back across the Atlantic with cargo that was human. Beeche was among the first in New York to trade commercial and government paper, and as the years passed it added the securities of banks, then of railroads, then of manufacturers, to its repertoire. By the turn of the last century the firm had grown into a large financial enterprise with thousands of employees, branches throughout the world, and a dozen divisions. Yet its basic business remained the same: trading for its own benefit and brokering the trades of others. No Beeche had touched a plow or a hammer for centuries, nor had he employed anyone who did.

headline: A New President for a Diverse Board of Rabbis
text: Merrick

headline: From the New Deal, a Way Out of a Mess
text: THE question of the day seems to be this: Are we in, or heading for, a recession? But so much attention is focused on that question that we may be losing sight of an even greater danger: the possibility that powerful headwinds may prevent a strong recovery from any slowdown.

headline: Certifiably Chic
text: Insanity. The style industry loves it. And why not? Fashion itself

headline: Paperback Row
text: THE WELSH GIRL, by Peter Ho Davies. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.95.) The lives of three people intersect in a town in northern Wales during World War II: a sheep farmer’s pregnant daughter who yearns for bigger things, a young German prisoner of war imprisoned in a camp near the town and a half-Jewish German who interrogates prisoners for the British. Davies’s first novel is a “kaleidoscopic study of the clash ... between personal history and ‘history’ as it plays out on the world stage,” Jennifer Egan wrote in the Book Review.

headline: A Public-Office Pay Gap
text: IN the suburbs, real estate, trusted help and income matter, even for the county legislators.

headline: Retracing the Elusive Footsteps of a Secretive History
text: ONE balmy day last April, an art and architecture historian named Fern Luskin hauled her laptop and a collapsible chair up to the roof of the Chelsea town house where she lives to work outside for a while. From the top of her building, on West 29th Street near Eighth Avenue, the view to the south is dominated by the bulky towers of the Penn South apartment complex. To the northeast, the Empire State Building pierces the sky.

headline: In an Era of the Beatles, the Shags Ruled, Too
text: PUT the words “Connecticut” and “garage” together, and most people see visions of weed whackers and garden hoses, not long-haired guys with guitars.

headline: You Want Pasta, We’ve Got Pasta
text: Fratelli Market is not the sort of Italian place that carries more types of cheeses and dry-cured sausage than you can shake a pepperoni stick at. Its specialty is pasta, particularly ravioli, with so many choices you may take to shopping there week after week.

headline: Slavs to Fashion
text: On a recent trip to Moscow, I heard about a fancy Fabergé egg being sold for $18.5 million. The news came across as I was looking out a hotel window at the ugliest, most stolid gray building you could find from the Soviet era.

headline: As Goals Decline, Calls for Change Increase
text: N.H.L. general managers took a big step last week toward ending the goal drought that has afflicted their league for more than a decade, voting unanimously to push for the downsizing of overgrown goalie equipment.

headline: Faces From the Screen, Now Life Size
text: ONE man has a dead horse, another a crumbling career; then there is a woman who is among literature’s most manipulative. We can only guess at how strong the productions that will bring us these characters might be, but it’s a sure thing that the actors who portray them are fascinating to watch.

headline: Jane’s Addiction
text: It’s mid-December, and Jane Holzer has a chill. Maybe it’s just the weather, or maybe the 60-something socialite and Warhol superstar turned real estate developer and art collector stayed too long on a construction site. (These days, Holzer buys, renovates and sells town houses.) Anyway, she’s frozen, so she’s snuggled in her bed, fully dressed in a black long-sleeved top and pants, conducting an interview. “You don’t mind if we do this here?” Holzer asks. One of Andy Warhol’s “Mao” paintings hangs above her head; nearby hang some of his flower paintings. A nude by Tom Wesselmann adorns another wall. Furniture by 20th-century design heavyweights like John Dickinson, Samuel Marx and Alessandro Albrizzi fills the space. But of course the most riveting thing in the room is Holzer herself, whom we persist in knowing as Baby Jane Holzer, even though, as she told The Times several years ago, “When I introduce myself at a bankers’ meeting, do you think I introduce myself as Baby Jane?” The old hallmarks still rivet, though: those big eyes, that infectious enthusiasm and, of course, that hair. The gorgeous blond hair that, in part, prompted Warhol to stop Holzer in front of Bloomingdale’s in the 1960s and ask if she wanted to be in the movies. (“Sure,” she replied. “Anything beats being a Park Avenue housewife!”) The hair that Irving Penn immortalized in his 1964 Vogue portrait. The hair that Tom Wolfe, in “The Girl of the Year,” his 1964 essay about Holzer, called “an incredible mane, a vast tawny corona.” It’s still major, and it crowns a very brainy head.

headline: With Chamberlain Around, Yanks Find Little Peace
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain recently tried to involve his fellow pitcher Mike Mussina in some postpractice recreation in the Yankees’ clubhouse.

headline: Lacroix, Sweetie
text: As a child in southern Provence, Christian Lacroix, the master of maximalist chic, would haunt a small museum filled with dusty wax tableaus illustrating the Spanish influence on local costumes and customs. He decided then that he would be a museum curator, but life had other plans. With the opening last November of a retrospective celebrating the 20th anniversary of his couture house, curated by Lacroix himself, that long-held ambition was finally realized.

headline: Any Given Monday
text: FOR New York basketball fans, 33 is either a famous or an infamous number, depending on your age. If you’re over 20, you can probably remember when the Knicks were ruled by Patrick Ewing, the dominant center with a blazing 33 on his chest.

headline: Troop Leader
text: As the governor of Texas, do you feel it is getting a little crowded there lately as the presidential candidates and their busloads of campaigners continue to descend in preparation for the primary on March 4? We tried to move our primary up, and it didn’t work. This is a very rare occurrence, to have a primary of national import in Texas.

headline: Elaine Riano and Gregory Brevetti
text: Elaine Riano and Dr. Gregory R. Brevetti were married on Friday. C. María Luisa González Castro, the municipal director of the civil registry of San José del Cabo, Mexico, officiated at the One & Only Palmilla, a resort there. Afterward, Marco Aréchiga, a Universal Life minister, led a nondenominational ceremony in the same location.

headline: Missile Strike by Israelis in Gaza Kills 3 Palestinians
text: JERUSALEM  Three Palestinians were killed in an Israeli Army missile strike in the northern Gaza Strip on Saturday afternoon, Palestinian medical officials said. It was not immediately clear whether those killed were civilians or combatants.

headline: Oh, Just Lighten Up and Enjoy the Show
text: SOMETIME on Sunday the subject of the Oscar broadcast will come up at your house or among your friends  perhaps it already has  and a screed against the national parade float that is the Academy Awards will commence.

headline: Heel, Girl!
text: In this season of intolerably high, architectonic (indeed, it might be said, misogynistic) heels, heels that look like a child’s Lego tower and defy spatial logistics, it behooves me to confess that I have never been able to wear heels higher than two and a half inches, three inches max. I have tried, Lord knows, I’ve tried. Who, after all, hasn’t been drawn to the invincible come-hitherness of stilettos, the way they announce your sexuality before you’ve so much as hit the pavement, accentuating the lithe, curvy line of a leg or the sinuous thrust of your hips? I envy friends who are able to glide freely in them, as though they were walking on air, giving off a these-boots-are-made-for-walking insouciance as they sail through the world. Me, I totter forward like a toddler learning to walk or weave from side to side like an old drunk.

headline: Letters: Man Bites Insect
text: For those interested in further entomophagous literature, there is the 19th-century classic, “Why Not Eat Insects?” by Vincent Holt. Particularly apropos of Sam Nejame’s (Feb. 10) conclusion  “Why douse fields with pesticides if the bugs we kill are more nutritious than the crops they eat?”  the quotation on the title page of Holt’s volume reads, “Them insecs (sic) eats up every blessed green thing that do grow, and us farmers starves./Well, eat them, and grow fat!” The book ends with examples of dinner menus in French and English (choufleurs garnies des chenilles: cauliflower garnished with caterpillars).

headline: In the Basement, Deeper Answers About You
text: THE distant “Eek!” from the basement was startling, though it didn’t cause me to panic. The tone signaled that my wife, who was doing laundry at the time, wasn’t in any imminent danger. I could tell she’d experienced some kind of shock, however.

headline: Now Shopping | Gucci Trumps Manhattan
text: No one can ever accuse Gucci of doing things halfheartedly. For the opening of its largest boutique in the world  a 46,000-square-foot gold-and-glass extravaganza in Manhattan’s Trump Tower  Madonna and the Gucci creative director, Frida Giannini, held a star-studded fund-raiser on the north lawn of the United Nations to benefit Unicef and Raising Malawi. But those looking to combine their altruism with a little swag need not have worried  Giannini also designed two bag collections for the occasion: “Heritage” (left) plays up Gucci’s history with a rendition of a print from the 1950s, while “New York Exclusive” pays tribute to the Big Apple, with all proceeds benefiting the Central Park playgrounds. [?][?][?]LEE CARTER

headline: Working All Corners in a Global Talent Hunt
text: MALTE VON PUTBUS has a mission. As global recruitment manager for the International Finance Corporation, the investment banking arm of the World Bank, he oversees efforts to find new employees around the world.

headline: Riders for Slipstream Are Gaining Notice
text: SANTA CLARITA, Calif.  Even before many of his riders had set out on Friday’s time trial at the Tour of California, Jonathan Vaughters, the sports director of the Slipstream-Chipotle team, could not help looking ahead to the final two days of the Tour.

headline: Prisoner of the Palace
text: Royal families and imperial dynasties are by nature closed and hidden. Unless they can maintain their mystique in this democratic age, they have little reason to exist. Queen Elizabeth II does not give interviews and neither do the emperor and empress of Japan. Stephen Frears’s film “The Queen” attempted to imagine what goes on inside the

headline: Battle Company Is Out There
text: WE TUMBLED OUT of two Black Hawks onto a shrub-dusted mountainside. It was a windy, cold October evening. A half-moon illuminated the tall pines and peaks. Through night-vision goggles the soldiers and landscape glowed in a blurry green-and-white static. Just across the valley, lights flickered from a few homes nestled in the terraced farmlands of Yaka China, a notorious village in the Korengal River valley in Afghanistan’s northeastern province of Kunar. Yaka China was just a few villages south and around a bend in the river from the Americans’ small mountain outposts, but the area’s reputation among the soldiers was mythic. It was a known safe haven for insurgents. American troops have tended to avoid the place since a nasty fight a year or so earlier. And as Halloween approached, the soldiers I was with, under the command of 26-year-old Capt. Dan Kearney, were predicting their own Yaka China doom.

headline: Somber Clinton Soldiers On as the Horizon Darkens
text: To her longtime friends, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sounds unusually philosophical on the phone these days. She rarely uses phrases like “when I’m president” anymore. Somber at times, determined at others, she talks to aides and confidants about the importance of focusing on a good day’s work. No drapes are being measured in her mind’s eye, they say.

headline: The Undecider
text: WHEN it comes to this year’s presidential race, Marc Baum offers, like a villanelle, two refrains: “I’m a lifelong Democrat” and “I have no idea.”

headline: Full Disclosure | FASHION OPENS UP.
text: Calvin Klein Collection silk organza molded dress, $1,450. Go to calvinklein.com.

headline: Up on the Tightrope
text: Mental patients come in handy on stage and screen. Characters who are officially disturbed can say things like “I sit still and listen. It’s like praying, I think” without coming off as pretentious. Or “I’m perking up inside. That’s where it starts” without seeming painfully obvious. Or “It’s getting extra white in here” without having to explain.

headline: Out on Highway 61
text: “In Search of the Blues” is not about the blues, or the people who made the blues. It’s about people who made the dark side of blues music into what popular mythology calls “the Delta blues.” Those people aren’t singers or players but folk song scholars and record collectors.

headline: Criminal Neglect
text: To the Editor:

headline: Countering Above-Average Fees
text: AS higher maintenance and common charges become the norm these days, higher-than-average monthly fees have lost some of their tendency to curdle the blood of buyers. But pricing these apartments can be more art than science.

headline: American Models, Plucked From Everyday Life
text: Virginia Snedeker was a member of the American Scene movement, a group of painters of the 1920s through the 1940s who rejected avant garde modernism and chose instead to embrace social realism and the depiction of everyday life. Ms. Snedeker focused her attention on life in New York, producing paintings and drawings in addition to illustrations and covers for The New Yorker.

headline: Once Immune, Utah Is Feeling Economic Dip
text: SALT LAKE CITY  In the economic boom that thundered through Utah over the last few years, many people saw a kind of perfect chemistry at work.

headline: What Is Left Out
text: Robert Creeley (1926-2005) was one of the darker poets of his generation, and also one of the best. He experienced hardship early on, losing his father, and also his left eye from an accident, by the time he was 5. The death of his father, a doctor, straitened the family’s circumstances. But the character of his darkness probably has more to do with New England  Hawthorne’s “grave and dark-clad company”  than anything else. It’s a severity of outlook that underpins the work of Emily Dickinson and Robert Frost, as well.

headline: Fashion Emergency
text: Everywhere you look  from Richard Prince’s kitschy “Nurse” portraits to Keira Knightley’s wartime angel of mercy in “Atonement” to the white-suited vixens in recent videos for Duran Duran and Good Charlotte  Florence Nightingale and friends are having a moment. Not since Catherine Barkley, the love interest in “A Farewell to Arms,” achieved literary immortality wearing “what seemed to me to be a nurse’s uniform” has the peaked-capped protector generated so much cultural traction.

headline: Peeking Inside the Mind of the Boy Dating Your Daughter
text: THE image of the testosterone-fueled teenage boy is a familiar one. It has been reinforced by movies such as “Porky’s,” “American Pie” and “Superbad,” which chronicle the escapades of high school boys determined to lose their virginity.

headline: A Detour to Homeownership
text: IT took Enrico Gomez and Kevin Moore a long time to prepare for homeownership. Four or five years ago, when interest rates sank to historic lows, everyone at work began talking about buying a home, Mr. Gomez said. So he and Mr. Moore began talking about it, too.

headline: Citywide Scissors, Bloodletting in the Neighborhood
text: AT Public School 308 in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, mornings officially begin with an address to teachers and students by the school’s tall and commanding principal, Gail Bell-Baptiste.

headline: A Precinct’s Hard Road Back
text: Nine blocks from where Sean Bell was shot and a few hours after three detectives go on trial in his death, the mournful notes of a bagpipe will mark another moment when a Queens neighborhood was filled with the staccato of gunfire.

headline: Immigrant Artists
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ambiguities
text: “‘I want a swift and hard cleanup out there. I want this kidnapping wave stopped. I want all this molesting of young children by perverts stamped out. I want housebreaking cleaned up. I want the streets of Brentwood Park so calm that a 6-year-old girl can roll her hoop down the main street without fear, singing her little nursery song. ... Can you do that for me, Ruddy?’

headline: Letter: Breaking Through
text: Having greatly enjoyed the film “Juno,” I was delighted to see Ryan McGinley’s photograph of Ellen Page on the cover of the Feb. 10 magazine. I read with interest Lynn Hirschberg’s description of Page as a tomboy. It is unfortunate that we have no other word available to describe this strong, independent young woman than to refer to her as a tomboy. This continues to convey to girls that growing up clear-eyed and courageous is being like a boy.

headline: Can a Sponsor’s Tenant Be Evicted in Queens?
text: Q For the last 18 months I’ve been renting an apartment in a Queens co-op that was converted in 1987. I just received an eviction letter because the building’s sponsor is selling the rental apartments. I don’t want to buy. Do they have the legal right to evict me?

headline: The Talk
text: dishabille / (dis& e be\l) / n. / (From the French déshabiller, “to undress.”) The state of being partially or very casually dressed, as in, “The teen star gives an extremely naked performance in the CW remake of ‘Bilitis,’ spending the entire movie in varying degrees of dishabille”; a front-row buzzword in a season in which designers have stripped back the silhouette to its conceptual, neoburlesque bare bones, e.g., “The collection was very mid-’90s Madonna dishabille in Seville meets Dita Von Teese in Greece.”

headline: Dress Me Up, Dress Me Down
text: Excuse me while I slip into something more comfortable.

headline: What That McCain Article Didn’t Say
text: BILL KELLER, the executive editor of The Times, said the article about John McCain that appeared in Thursday’s paper was about a man nearly felled by scandal who rebuilt himself as a fighter against corruption but is still “careless about appearances, careless about his reputation, and that’s a pretty important thing to know about somebody who wants to be president of the United States.”

headline: Friends, Romans, Countrymen, Lend Me Your Speech
text: ON Feb. 9, 1950, Senator Joseph McCarthy claimed his place in the history books by telling a crowd in Wheeling, W.Va., that the State Department was full of Communists. “We are not dealing with spies who get 30 pieces of silver to steal the blueprint of a new weapon,” he said. “We are dealing with a far more sinister type of activity because it permits the enemy to guide and shape our policy.” The claim was baseless, scurrilous  and plagiarized. The same words, practically verbatim, had been spoken on the floor of the House of Representatives two weeks earlier, by Representative Richard M. Nixon of California.

headline: Enticing Theatergoers to Make Travel Plans
text: NEW YORKERS sometimes admit this only grudgingly, but there is a world beyond Manhattan, and this spring the rest of the country will yield some interesting theater, over and above the usual assortment of revivals and star vehicles.

headline: On Center Stage, a Candidate Letting His Confidence Show
text: AUSTIN, Tex.  Barack Obama has a Barcalounger manner about him these days, padding about those campaign stages like a man commanding his den.

headline: Inside the List
text: 25 YEARS AGO: The advice, how-to and miscellaneous lists first appeared in the Book Review early in 1984. Before this catchall category existed, advice best sellers were placed on the general nonfiction list, where they crowded out almost everything else. See the list below, for example, which ran 25 years ago, on Feb. 20, 1983. Of the 10 books printed here, only three  Andy Rooney’s, William Least Heat Moon’s and Russell Baker’s  would qualify for the general list today. “Jane Fonda’s Workout Book,” by the way, spent more than half a year at No. 1 and more than 16 months in the top five.

headline: Calling All Rock Stars in Aprons
text: MIAMI

headline: 36 Hours in Mont Tremblant, Quebec
text: FOR an East Coast ski resort, Mont Tremblant seems to have it all. Combining the Canadian charm of a rustic logging town with the Old World flavor of the French Alps, Tremblant is consistently ranked by Ski Magazine readers as the East’s No. 1 resort. There’s been only one problem: getting there required an hours-long slog from Montreal through the boondocks of Quebec. But all that changed this winter. Continental started offering direct flights to Mont Tremblant from Newark, making it possible for morning commuters from New York to stroll its faux-European base village by midafternoon. Things will get even nicer, when a new village (with 21,000-square-foot casino) and gondola open up some time later this year.

headline: Letters: Father and Sons
text: I admire the three sons for their willingness to donate a kidney to their aging father (The Ethicist, Feb. 10). But the issue that I believe is even more at the crux of the ethical matter is that of an “aging” father asking, or even accepting, the offer by his children to donate a kidney. As a 68-year-old father who recently had a kidney removed, I would not even contemplate accepting such an offer from my children if I were to lose my remaining kidney. Jeopardizing my children’s future well-being in exchange for a few more years of my own life would just not be worth it.

headline: Anterior Motives
text: On a recent Friday morning in Los Angeles, a handful of eager women sat on sofas in the Sunset Boulevard offices of Dr. David Matlock noshing on bagels and cream cheese. Dr. Matlock, who made his name performing liposuction and then transplanting the fat to create a “Brazilian butt augmentation,” and who later went on to have a role on the reality show “Dr. 90210,” patiently explained the ins and outs of the injectible procedure of the moment, one that he claims to have invented and that makes Botox seem so five wrinkles ago.

headline: With Open Adoption, a New Kind of Family
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J.

text: ENCINO, Calif.

headline: And Liberty for All

headline: Out of Kisumu
text: We should have seen it coming. The violence between the Luo and the Kikuyu tribes that started after the December elections was spreading again down Kenya’s Rift Valley. By Sunday evening, there was news that 19 people, including women and children, all Luos, had been burned in a house in Naivasha. But by Monday morning in Kisumu, the Luo-dominated city in western Kenya, everybody went about business normally.

headline: Maybe Microsoft Should Stalk Different Prey
text: OVER the years, Microsoft has pummeled countless rivals, including the superheavyweight I.B.M. But it has never faced a smaller foe as formidable as Google. The tale of the tape gives Microsoft a $100 billion advantage in market capitalization, but it counts for little: Google appears to be its superior in strength, speed, smarts.

headline: Police Seek Help in Criminal Deportation
text: LAST summer the Suffern police arrested a 17-year-old illegal immigrant after he was found peeping into a girls’ bathroom at the village recreation center.

headline: Governors of Both Parties Oppose Medicaid Rules
text: WASHINGTON  Governors of both parties strongly objected on Saturday to a half-dozen new federal Medicaid regulations that they said would shift billions of dollars in costs to the states, forcing them to consider cutbacks in services.

headline: The Roitfelds | Family de la Mode
text: Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of Vogue Paris, bequeathed her children her soigné style as if it were their birthright. Her daughter, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, is a freelance art director for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier and was the face of Tom Ford’s latest fragrance; her son, Vladimir Restoin-Roitfeld, is a film school graduate and a sometime model. Going to a fashion shoot when they were young, says Mom, was as normal as tarte Tatin. (The photographer Mario Testino is their godfather.) Many consider Roitfeld the stilettoed embodiment of modern dressing: she describes her style as “tacky chic.” Never afraid to take a risk, she has put a bearded drag queen on a cover and printed a fashion story with a model dressed as an Anna Wintour clone. After 20-plus years in the business, certain things have changed: “I don’t go too much to the parties now, but my kids do.” Like their mom, they’re always on the list. [?][?][?]ALEX HAWGOOD

headline: Insurance Fears Lead Many to Shun DNA Tests
Finding New Life in the Arts
text: FOR centuries, the northwest corner of old Bologna was an industrial zone, home to slaughterhouses, salt works and tobacco factories. But now the once neglected neighborhood, a 15-minute walk from the city center, is churning out a new commodity: art.

headline: Philandering Father
text: Are the heroes of picaresque the blondes of literature? They certainly have more fun. They’re never stuck at home on a Saturday night. They’re never stuck at home, period. Dubious company becomes them. We count on them for brazen behavior, the more so as it’s their job to expose the rotten planks of society, the underside of human nature. If they’re not conning someone into whitewashing the fence, they can be found cozying up to the wrong woman. To their ranks, the two Toms, Sawyer and Jones, may welcome Johnny One-Eye, Jerome Charyn’s newest brainchild.

headline: Letters: Cybercourting
text: Laurie Kasparian’s Feb. 10 Lives column was one of the most romantic pieces of writing I’ve ever encountered. Thank you for an early Valentine’s Day treat.

headline: Prospect for N.F.L. First Ran From Liberia
text: INDIANAPOLIS  Each evening at the N.F.L. scouting combine, Jehuu Caulcrick sits in a chair across from N.F.L. coaches and executives. They ask about Michigan State, where he played football. They ask about the small western New York farm town where he grew up.

headline: Profile in Style: Chloe Sevigny
text: HER POSSE: Chloë Sevigny says her friends and family have influenced both her career and her style. Her mother, Janine, would chauffeur her from Darien, Conn., to Manhattan for auditions; her mom’s pal even snapped some of Sevigny’s first head shots. She credits her brother Paul, a D.J., for her early punk sensibilities: “I was obsessed with the different hair colors of all his girlfriends.” The designer Benjamin Cho meticulously drew her 30th-birthday invitation, and she even wrangled her girlfriends to model for a showing of her new clothing line with Opening Ceremony. “All my friends are insane, but I’m actually quite normal,” she says. “I think they are attracted to my sanity.” her 30th-birthday invite. right: with the designers of proenza schouler.

headline: IN – STORE | China Shop
text: 1. Sarah Rutson doesn’t take no for an answer. The fashion director of Lane Crawford, a bevy of luxe boutiques in Hong Kong and Beijing, digs her Louboutin heels in when it comes to the designers and trends she believes in: “I won’t shut up until the order is written!” Here she wears a dress by Roland Mouret.

headline: Correction: Is PBS Still Necessary?
text: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the state of public broadcasting misstated the former position of Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, who encouraged public-television stations to broadcast a program whose host was Paul Gigot, editor of The Wall Street Journal’s editorial page. Mr. Tomlinson was chairman of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting; he was not chairman of PBS.

headline: Correction: Curves in the Road to Redeeming Miles
text: The Practical Traveler column on Feb. 10 about redeeming frequent flier miles misstated the cut-off date for an American Airlines award for tickets between New York and London that cost only 40,000 miles; the offer is through May 15, not June 15.

headline: At 31, Robinson Says Breaking Record in 800 Is Only One Goal
text: BOSTON  Khadevis Robinson is the United States’ most productive 800-meter runner since Johnny Gray in the 1980s and 1990s. Gray’s career seemed to last forever, including an Olympic final at 36, but he sees greater glory for Robinson, which makes generous sense. He coaches him.

headline: Now Printing | Cecil Beaton
text: Cecil Beaton possessed a keen eye for all things fashionable. While he found his métier as a portrait photographer, he also played the role of dandy, diarist, Oscar-winning costumer and, oddly enough, fabric designer. Now, through the London interior design company Beaudesert and the archives of Ascher Studio, reproductions of Beaton’s checks, florals and stripes are being sold at Liberty of London. The Cecil Beaton fabric collection  on silk, cotton, linen and wallpaper  was inspired by a scarf that Beaudesert’s managing director, Andrew Ginger, found on eBay; Beaton had originally designed it for the textile firm Ascher. In the 1940s and early ’50s, Zika Ascher commissioned artists such as Henri Matisse and Henry Moore to design fabrics, paying them £25 per motif, according to his son, Peter. All the big designers, like Balenciaga, Givenchy, Lanvin and Yves Saint Laurent, would buy their fabrics from Ascher Studio. Although not known for his brush strokes, Beaton was an obvious choice for fabric, and Zika allowed him free rein. “An artist with a color sense is not someone you mess with,” Zika has been quoted as saying. The timing couldn’t be better, as this spring’s runways were full of blossoms. Can’t you just see the Beaton bouquet on your fainting couch? [?][?][?]MELISSA FELDMAN

headline: World Food Without Leaving the Neighborhood
text: GROCERY stores in other countries have long been a stealth tourist attraction for travelers. The format is familiar — aisles, shopping carts and screaming children — but the food is anything but, ranging from the exotic to the merely intriguing. And then you turn the corner and see the familiar face of Tony the Tiger hawking a strangely-renamed product (Frosties, Zucaritas, Sucrilhos), bringing perhaps a pang of cultural imperialist guilt.

headline: Late Stand by Lundqvist Boosts the Rangers
text: BUFFALO  As Buffalo forward Thomas Vanek skated in on Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist late in a tie game that the Rangers needed so desperately to win Saturday night, it seemed as if the Rangers’ entire season could hang on the moment.

headline: Correction: So Who Wins the Big Prize? It’s the Host

In “The Price Is Right Million-Dollar Spectacular,” contestants have chances to win $1 million in cash, not a showcase of prizes worth $1 million.

headline: The Skies Are Alive With Fees
text: THE low-fare European carrier Ryanair is the world champion among airlines in generating extra cash by charging customers fees for services and products that most airlines include in the ticket price: checked bags, beverages and  for a time before the idea was dropped amid public outcry  even using a wheelchair.

headline: The Pond, the Murals. Oh, and There’s Food.
text: FROM its unusual name and dramatically illuminated facade to its theatrical interior, BOE@324 Restaurant is so distractingly elaborate that what’s on the menu almost becomes a vague afterthought.

headline: Nets Find Scoring Help Up and Down Lineup
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Maybe the Nets will not miss Jason Kidd after all. They won for the second time in three games since trading Kidd to Dallas, defeating the Indiana Pacers, 102-91, on Saturday with some familiar and unexpected names leading the way.

headline: A Fire in the Heart
text: We all live in the shadow of history, and the play of its lights and shades over individual lives is the stuff of historical fiction. In his sweepingly ambitious, captivating second novel, “The Age of Shiva,” Manil Suri creates a woman who is never an actor in the great events of India’s post-independence decades but cannot escape their power to shape her.

headline: For Out-of-Towners, the Race Is to the Sleepless
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: A Place to Park That Million-Dollar RV
text: About 8.3 million American households currently own an RV, according to the Recreation Vehicle Industry Association. It seems only fitting that the luxury RV crowd  some of whom may have paid upwards of $2 million to purchase their mobile homes prefer lots a bit spiffier than your average roadside campground. Although private gated communities for RVs exist, starting this spring the country will have its first national chain. Called Bella Terra (www.bellaterrarvresort.com), the chain will open its first resort, above, in Gulf Shores, Ala. The property will include a clubhouse, pools, a children’s water play area, a movie theater, a lake stocked for fishing and business and fitness centers. Nightly rates will be about $100; those interested in purchasing lots will be able to do so for a starting price of $100,000. The chain is expected to develop five more properties within the next 38 to 46 months.

headline: Never the Twain Shall Meet
text: I COULD not get “East Side, West Side, all around the town”  lyrics from the classic “Sidewalks of New York”  out of my mind after visiting two buildings on opposite sides of Central Park. The Laurel is a 31-story condominium going up on East 67th Street, at First Avenue. And 610 West 110th Street is a 15-floor prewar building being renovated at that address, between Broadway and Riverside Drive.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: THE LAST FLIGHT OF THE SCARLET MACAW: One Woman’s Fight to Save the World’s Most Beautiful Bird, by Bruce Barcott. (Random House, $26.) A bitter legal battle over a river valley in Belize is waged in a steamy climate of corruption and intrigue.

headline: Emily Stein, Benjamin Lupin
text: Dr. Emily Caren Stein, a daughter of Billie Stein and Dr. Marc Stein of Vineland, N.J., was married on Saturday evening to Benjamin Scott Lupin, the son of Linda S. Lupin and Steven H. Lupin of Blue Bell, Pa. Rabbi Gregory S. Marx officiated at the Philadelphia Marriott Downtown.

headline: 40 Killed in Blast Amid Crowd of Shiites in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber detonated amid a crowd of Shiites making a pilgrimage to the Shrine of Imam Husayn in Karbila, Sunday, killing at least 40 people and injuring more than 100.

headline: Amsterdam Tries Upscale Fix for Red-Light District Crime
text: AMSTERDAM  Some of the most visited brothels in Amsterdam’s red-light district have gained unexpected new neighbors.

headline: Are Oscars Worth All This Fuss?
text: THERE is something of a consensus among critics  a disagreeable bunch, it should be noted  that 2007 was one of the best years for movies, American movies in particular, in recent memory. As a result the leading contenders for major Oscars have unusually solid aesthetic bona fides. Of course there are those who grouse about the endings of “There Will Be Blood” and “No Country for Old Men,” who find “Juno” more grating than charming, who were baffled by “Michael Clayton” or who were bored by “Atonement,” but all in all it looks like an impressively strong field. Meanwhile the Writers Guild strike, which had threatened to encircle the Kodak Theater with picket lines and bury the Academy Awards in bad feelings, has been settled. The show will go on  Sunday night at 8  and everybody’s happy.

headline: A Big Year for a Full-Service Composer
text: AS an applicant to the composition program at the Paris Conservatoire in 1960, the Seattle native William Bolcom churned out his regulation fugue and sonata movement on cue. But asked to present what he was working on, he offered “One Little Bomb and Boom!,” a jaunty waltz from his cabaret opera “Dynamite Tonight,” modeled on novelty numbers from the time of World War I. The lyric was by the New York poet Arnold Weinstein, who blended classical learning and jive with wicked panache.

headline: Lisa Sigloch, Mark Markowski
text: Lisa Montagu Sigloch and Mark Paul Markowski were married on Wednesday at the New York City Municipal Building. Blanca Martinez, a staff member at the office of the city clerk, officiated. The couple had another ceremony on Feb. 2 at the Ceiba del Mar Beach and Spa Resort in Puerto Morelos, Mexico, at which the Rev. Enrique Monroy, a Catholic priest gave a blessing.

headline: Neighbor vs. Neighbor
text: A report in the Big Deal column last Sunday about lawyers who sue their neighbors in apartment buildings misstated the circumstances under which lawyers can be refused housing in New York City. Although a 1977 court decision upheld a landlord’s right to refuse to rent to a lawyer, the city’s human rights law was amended in 1986 to bar discrimination in housing on the basis of a lawful occupation. Co-op and condominium boards may, however, reject lawyers and other applicants based on specific actions  for instance, a pattern of filing lawsuits against neighbors.

headline: Lemon Zest
text: ON a cold morning late last month, I took a subway to Union Square Park to see a bird I had never seen. The bird, a Scott’s oriole, had been noted intermittently behind the statue of Mohandas Gandhi since December, though it took birders several weeks to figure out that it was not in fact an orchard oriole  which would have been unusual enough for winter in Manhattan. Scott’s oriole is a bird of the Southwest and has never been recorded in New York. It should be no farther east than Texas, which is why, despite my sluggardly winter ways, I decided it was worth a trip down from the Upper West Side, where I live.

headline: Peeking Inside the Mind of the Boy Dating Your Daughter
text: THE image of the testosterone-fueled teenage boy is a familiar one. It has been reinforced by movies such as “Porky’s,” “American Pie” and “Superbad,” which chronicle the escapades of high school boys determined to lose their virginity.

headline: Georgia Peach
text: STYLE MAP | SAVANNAH In the 1997 film “Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil,” a New York writer visiting Savannah, Ga., describes the town as “ ‘Gone With the Wind’ on mescaline.” It’s easy to see what he meant: the Spanish-moss-draped streets are lined with stately Southern homes, barbecue joints and dusky bars. Recently, however, a little cool has been injected into the antebellum mix, with style-savvy design students, smartly restored inns and a handful of trendy new shops. [?][?][?]ARMAND LIMNANDER

headline: The Battle Over the Greens
text: PERHAPS more than any other civic rivals, street vendors and brick-and-mortar stores seem to play a zero-sum game. The stores are wary of the vendors, whom they see as nimble nuisances undercutting their prices, unfettered by regulation or rent. The vendors see the stores as competition-hating Goliaths.

headline: Maiden Voyage
text: The shipping news? Brash prints and bold lengths.

headline: No Longer an Afterthought
text: Specializing in seafood and other dishes in the Cantonese style, Aberdeen in White Plains is one of the county’s few regional Chinese restaurants holding out against the recent Pan-Asian invasion. Dishes of Canton reflect the region’s mild climate and its position on the South China Sea, where a full supply of fish, meats, fruits and vegetables available throughout the year has helped establish Canton’s reputation for producing China’s most varied, creative and savory dishes.

headline: The Color Purple | IT’S the ROYAL HUE
text: To get a modern stained lip, Page blended two lipsticks on the back of his hand: a Bordeaux cream, like M.A.C. Media, and a fuchsia cream, like Nars Funny Face. Then he used his fingertip to blot it onto the lips.

headline: The Sound and the Führer
text: Among the many acid pleasures of the work of Roberto Bolaño, who died at 50 in 2003, is his idea that culture, in particular literary culture, is a whore. In the face of political repression, upheaval and danger, writers continue to swoon over the written word, and this, for Bolaño, is the source both of nobility and of pitch-black humor. In his novel “The Savage Detectives,” two avid young Latino poets never lose faith in their rarefied art no matter the vicissitudes of life, age and politics. If they are sometimes ridiculous, they are always heroic. But what can it mean, he asks us and himself, in his dark, extraordinary, stinging novella “By Night in Chile,” that the intellectual elite can write poetry, paint and discuss the finer points of avant-garde theater as the junta tortures people in basements? The word has no national loyalty, no fundamental political bent; it’s a genie that can be summoned by any would-be master. Part of Bolaño’s genius is to ask, via ironies so sharp you can cut your hands on his pages, if we perhaps find a too-easy comfort in art, if we use it as anesthetic, excuse and hide-out in a world that is very busy doing very real things to very real human beings. Is it courageous to read Plato during a military coup or is it something else?

headline: Crisis Management
text: A writer, Eudora Welty insisted, must know her characters’ “hearts and minds before they ever set visible foot on stage. You must know all, then not tell it all, or not tell too much at once: simply the right thing at the right moment.” When fiction doles out its revelations in this way  when it allows just the right sequence of glimpses through a parted curtain  we misleadingly call it “realistic.” Actual existence is rarely well choreographed.

headline: Miho Walsh and Roy Prieb
text: IT started with shrimp dumplings.

headline: Testing Your Water for Contaminants
text: MOST homeowners, particularly those who get their water from private wells, are curious or concerned about the quality of their water.

headline: The Audacity of Hopelessness
text: WHEN people one day look back at the remarkable implosion of the Hillary Clinton campaign, they may notice that it both began and ended in the long dark shadow of Iraq.

headline: Correction: There Will Be Memories
text: A chart last Sunday showing highlights of Oscar telecasts over the last 54 years misidentified the actress who in 1953 sang “Thumbelina” to her thumb. She is Celeste Holm, not Ginger Rogers.

headline: Memories of a C.I.A. Officer Resonate in a New Era
text: LOCUST GROVE, Va.  Larry Devlin is 85 now, suffering from emphysema and tethered to an oxygen tank, his Central Intelligence Agency career long behind him. But he recalls with sunlit clarity the day in Congo nearly half a century ago when he was handed a packet of poisons, including toxic toothpaste, and ordered to carry out a political assassination.

headline: Seeing the City by the Bay, Affordably
text: Top reader suggestions on San Francisco, compiled from user comments posted on the Travel section’s Web site. You can read more comments, as well as add your own, at nytimes.com/travel.

headline: Italy Wide and Varied, Warm and Intimate
text: THE subtitle at Finalmente Trattoria, one of Westport’s newer restaurants, is “regional Italian cuisine.” This proves apt, for the menu has dishes that range all over the map of Italy, including a wild king salmon entree from Elba of all places.

headline: Blood and ‘Oil!’
text: The best moments in Paul Thomas Anderson’s film “There Will Be Blood” and in “Oil!,” the 1927 novel by Upton Sinclair on which it is loosely based, are identical. They depict the fiery immolation of an oil rig. “There was a tower of flame,” Sinclair writes, “and the most amazing spectacle  the burning oil would hit the ground, and bounce up, and explode, and leap again and fall again, and great red masses of flame would unfold, and burst, and yield black masses of smoke, and these in turn red. Mountains of smoke rose to the sky, and mountains of flame came seething down to the earth; every jet that struck the ground turned into a volcano, and rose again, higher than before; the whole mass, boiling and bursting, became a river of fire, a lava flood that went streaming down the valley, turning everything it touched into flame, then swallowing it up and hiding the flames in a cloud of smoke.”

headline: Texas Women, With a Strong Legacy, Size Up the Democratic Field
text: HOUSTON  She served as first lady through her husband’s two terms, suffered the indignities of his impeachment and then made history running for his office on her own.

headline: Traditional Visit With an Untraditional Twist
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  It happens every spring, or close to it. The slender, silver-haired maestro drives from his home in Vero Beach, spends a few hours reconnecting with old friends and pupils, then ducks out a side door or back exit. His departure is as stealthy as his arrival, leaving others to reflect on their audience with one of the greatest left-handed pitchers ever.

headline: He Was Nouveau When It Was New
text: THESE days, the name Robbe-Grillet doesn’t ring many bells. A new chateau perhaps, whose grand cru goes well with meat? A deputy minister in Sarkozy’s government? An up-and-coming couturier?

headline: The Flapper Doesn’t Change Her Spots
text: As a Baby Star of 1927, Sally Phipps seemed destined for silent film immortality. The organization that bestowed the award  the Western Association of Motion Picture Advertisers, or Wampas  had a genius for spotting talent. Joan Crawford and Clara Bow had been Baby Stars, and in 1927, the 16-year-old Phipps shared the accolade with future fan-dance sensation Sally Rand.

headline: Patient Is a Virtue
text: 1. Symptoms

headline: Honored Ancestors on the Skyline Family Tree
text: IT is quite possible that the enthusiasts who know the most about the Nissan GT-R are those still a few years away from getting their driving licenses. Such is the downside of a car best known as a video game icon. Even so, the GT-R’s exterior styling is not so extreme that drivers old enough to vote would reject it as overtly adolescent.

headline: Deep-Fried Mars Bars
text: These restaurants on Greenwich Avenue are eclectic and cozy, like the surrounding neighborhood.

headline: Kosovo and the State’s ‘Responsibility to Protect’
text: To the Editor:

headline: Once Exclusive Enclaves, Subject to Change
text: IN the case of tiny Agate Court in Brooklyn, perhaps the sincerest form of flattery is not imitation, but annexation. The little cul-de-sac of 18 row houses off chaotic Atlantic Avenue in southern Bedford-Stuyvesant was built in the late 1880s along with the flanking Alice Court, and the two have slumbered for more than a century with little change.

headline: Charlize Angel
text: In your new film, “Sleepwalking”, you not only star but you also produce. Was that difficult?People forget that I produced “Monster” [the 2003 film for which Theron won the Oscar for her portrayal of the prostitute and gay serial killer Aileen Wuornos]. And, before that, we worked on “Sweet Home Alabama” for two years, which ended up starring Reese Witherspoon. I produce films that I feel deserve the light of day. “Monster” was a great learning experience for a producer. Initially, having my name attached to the project helped with getting the financing. People are more likely to say yes to tricky material when a star is interested. But then, with “Monster,” they’d say, “It’ll be a hot lesbian movie, right?” That was one of the selling points until they figured out what we were actually doing.

headline: Starship Kimchi: A Bold Taste Goes Where It Has Never Gone Before
text: SEOUL, South Korea  After South Korea began sending soldiers to fight beside American forces in Vietnam, President Park Chung-hee made an unusual plea. He wrote to President Lyndon Johnson to say that his troops were miserable, desperate for kimchi, the fermented cabbage dish that Koreans savor with almost every meal.

headline: Early Bloomers
text: There were a few blousy moments during the spring collections when you could be forgiven for thinking you were attending an 1850s suffragist rally or a gym class at Vassar in the 1920s. Bloomers  sometimes diaperish, usually subversive and most women’s idea of fashion hell  produced smirks and double-takes in New York and Europe. Gaultier’s iteration had a “Pirates of Penzance” picturesqueness. In an unusually insane show, Comme des Garçons advanced the possibility of bloomers that were not just frilly but also falling apart. Prada’s take, short-short and sewn in shiny fabrics, was straight from the stroller. Betsey Johnson, well, you can guess. While today’s bloomers can be traced in a straight line to the pumpkin breeches that Renaissance men wore at the top of their hose, they are but fuzzy cousins to the garment favored by the early women’s libber who lent them her name, Amelia Bloomer. She rebelled against the petticoats and floor-grazing skirts of the mid-19th century in favor of knee-skimming designs layered over ballooning trousers gathered at the ankles. The bifurcated look had something weirdly haremlike about it and, however liberating, was light only in relation to what had come before. Bloomer was ridiculed but of course vindicated with the hindsight of history. Designers have fallen in and out of love with bloomers at least since 1976. Bonnie Cashin, the sportswear pioneer, celebrated the bicentennial with a collection of “Amelias.” “Bonnie loved bloomers because they could be completely customized by the wearer,” says Stephanie Lake of the Bonnie Cashin Foundation. Is there any designer who hasn’t dabbled in bloomers? You can wear out your search engine trying to find one. Saint Laurent’s fling was in 1987. Vivienne Westwood cast her vote in velvet in 1998. Armani has shown bloomers off and on for several years. Spinning positive, one buyer called them a “skirt replacement.” That or gym clothes.[?][?][?]CHRISTOPHER PETKANAS

headline: Room for Eating, and Improvement
text: AFTER emigrating from Portugal in 1986, Carlos Lopes worked in construction, cooked in a succession of middling restaurants around northern New Jersey, even ran a lunch cart in downtown Newark. But all the while, he must have been thinking big. How else to explain his five-month-old restaurant, Solar do Minho in Roselle Park?

headline: Cascya Charlot and Thomas Ludwig
text: Dr. Cascya Charlot and Thomas Robert Ludwig were married on Saturday at the St. Peter Great House and Botanical Gardens, a former plantation on St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands. William L. Arnet, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Correction: The Other Iran
text: An article on Feb. 10 about an American’s trip to Esfahan, the old Persian capital of Iran, mistranslated a word the writer used when he sought directions by asking “Madrasa kojast?” Madrasa means school in Farsi; the writer did not ask, “Where is the religious school?”

headline: 1876: New Jersey Blanc Mange
text: People in the 19th century had a more robust appetite for food with unusual textures. Pickled oysters were a common snack, and you could find the occasional brain fritter and kidney omelet. But nothing seems to have got cooks more excited than a chance to entomb a favorite food in jelly. Into a preserve went perfectly innocent ham, pineapple, calf’s foot, sole, even a chicken or two. And then there was milk. Sweetened with sugar, lemon, almond, cinnamon and sometimes even chocolate, milk was ideal for pouring into molds and serving for dessert as a beloved dish called blancmange, which means “white food.” Tapped out of its form, blancmange is gorgeous and subdued, like a piece of carved ivory.

headline: I Have Just the Client for You
text: LOS ANGELES

headline: Pounding the Pavement to Buy a Car
text: Some products lend themselves to online sales  books, computers and toys come to mind. But cars are a tougher sell. Most consumers still head to the lot to seal the deal.

headline: Correction: Hemingway, Your Letter Has Arrived
text: An article on Feb. 10 about a letter that Ernest Hemingway sent to The New York Times about writing his play “The Fifth Column” while covering the Spanish Civil War misidentified the person whose reference to an attack on Madrid became the play’s title. It was General Emilio Mola  not Francisco Franco  who said that he had four columns advancing on Madrid and a fifth column of loyalists inside the city ready to attack from the rear.

headline: Paris Passes Milestone as Oklahoma Prevails
text: NORMAN, Okla.  Fans began lining up outside the arena hours before Saturday’s tipoff between the highly ranked in-state college basketball teams. Once inside, the fans seemed to flip the calendar with their collective breath, creating an atmosphere more like March Madness.

headline: Woods Continues His March to the Final
text: MARANA, Ariz.  Tiger Woods started his day at 3:45 a.m. Saturday, an hour ahead of his alarm clock, four hours ahead of his tee time and about 12 hours before he mowed down his second opponent of the day in the Accenture Match Play Championship.

headline: Seeking to Give Power to the People, at Least Symbolically
text: PAUL SOKOLOFF, a 51-year-old bartender with a small earring and a smoker’s rusty chuckle, is a blunt-spoken man, not the sort one expects to talk like a civics textbook. But that is how he sounded a few days ago when he described the vote he had cast in his local schoolhouse on the day of the New York primary.

headline: Phelps Summons His Inner Early Riser
text: Before Michael Phelps even knew there was such a concept as early person/late person, he was the embodiment of a night owl.

headline: In City Waters, Beds (and a Job) for Oysters
text: Hendrix Creek, flowing for just over a mile in Brooklyn through East New York, passes under the Belt Parkway and between two dormant landfills before it empties into Jamaica Bay. The creek, once fed by a natural stream, now starts at the output pipe of a wastewater treatment plant.

headline: Reese Enjoys the Fruits of His Role in Scouting
text: INDIANAPOLIS  At least one of the text messages that buzzed Jerry Reese’s phone as he stood atop the champions’ podium after the Super Bowl came from a peer. The Giants’ surprising playoff run and their 17-14 victory over the Patriots was fueled, in large part, by an infusion of young players.

headline: Ethanol by the Numbers
text: Even those who regard ethanol as the holy grail of energy policy concede that there is a right way and a wrong way to produce it. Done right, ethanol could help wean the country from its dependence on foreign oil while reducing the emissions that contribute to climate change. Done wrong, ethanol could wreak havoc on the environment while increasing greenhouse gases.

headline: Rachel Butler, David Campbell
text: Rachel Butler, a daughter of Deanna L. Butler and Mark E. Butler of Brooklyn, was married Saturday to David John Thomas Campbell, a son of Kim L. Campbell and Stewart T. Campbell of Calgary, Alberta. Frank W. Miller Sr., an elder serving in the Manhattan New York Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, performed the ceremony.

headline: No. 1 No More: Memphis Falls to Tennessee
text: MEMPHIS  In the week leading up to No. 2 Tennessee’s game at No. 1 Memphis, Volunteers Coach Bruce Pearl did everything he could to play down the matchup. He insisted that Tennessee’s coming games with Vanderbilt and Kentucky were more important and said that the Volunteers could still earn a No. 1 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament if they lost.

headline: Radical, Chic
text: Outrageous!, for example, is a work of talent, originality and vision. It smells deeply artificial in the best sense, intentionally bearing the same relationship to the natural world that Tang does to orange juice. Outrageous! is not a synthetic version of nature but a free-standing creation that refers to the natural world ironically and revels in its own artifice. It is, in fact, the smell of Tang sprinkled on a plate of polyurethane on which sit grapes, apples and pears made of polyvinyl chloride. The scent of kerosene ingeniously adds alarm to the soft, dystopian glow. Frowning, I once said to Sophia Grojsman, who created it for Barneys New York Co-Op, “It makes me think of a Mondrian: rigid, unnatural rectangles of artificially bright colors.” She put her hands on my shoulders and squeezed with delight.

headline: Come Back, Little ’50s, Even With the Clouds
text: THIS spring at the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center a young, radiant and unmistakably American woman will proclaim proudly in song that she is “as normal as blueberry pie.” And when audiences listen to Kelli O’Hara deliver this assertion as Nellie Forbush in the musical “South Pacific,” they will most likely believe, at least for that moment, that all-American normalcy is a wonderful state of being.

headline: He Said, He Said
text: Addiction is repetitious. The fact that alcoholics and drug abusers often tread the path of use, rehab, sobriety and relapse presents a challenge to authors of addiction memoirs, who must squeeze this dispiritingly cyclical behavior into a straight-ahead narrative or risk telling the same story over and over. “Beautiful Boy” is an addiction memoir once removed, depicting the collateral damage that a drug-abusing child inflicts, yet it underscores how the heartbreaking circle game of addiction can fetter a writer’s sense of what to include and, more important, when to stop.

headline: Yes, Screw Caps on the North Fork
text: Screw caps have come to the North Fork. Using a bottling line installed in September, Paumanok has been putting screw caps on 2007 whites; the apparatus handles corks, too. The Premium Wine Group, a for-hire winery, hopes to install a screw cap bottler this year. Martha Clara wants to start using the caps, and Pellegrini is considering them.

headline: Reader, He Married Her
text: This is a deeply strange book. In fact, it is, to the best of my knowledge, a nonesuch: a 400-plus-page first novel by a 49-year-old American male, dedicated to the highly dubious proposition that such a thing as perfect romantic love is possible in these doomy, gloomy, over-psychologized, terminally ironic, post-humanist, post-postmodern times. Part comedy of manners, part chick lit in male drag, James Collins’s “Beginner’s Greek” is a great big sunny lemon chiffon pie of a novel, set, for good measure and our sociological titillation, among the WASP ruling classes, people who work at white-shoe investment firms and own villas in southwestern France and can instantly tell the difference between fine Bordeaux and plonk.

headline: GT-R Waiting Game About to End

In the last decade, introductions for vehicles as disparate as the Volkswagen New Beetle, Chrysler PT Cruiser, Mini Cooper and Ford GT each resulted in months-long waiting lists, accompanied by gigabytes of Internet speculation.

headline: Kusama Dot Com
text: We hope you will understand.” With typically fervent Japanese politeness, Yayoi Kusama’s staff warned me that the resurgent queen of the Japanese art world, now approaching 80, no longer permits herself to be photographed. But when she learned that the photographer in question was Nobuyoshi Araki, the celebrated master of nude bondage pictures, it turned out that Kusama was only too happy to oblige. And so, on a quiet Thursday afternoon, after an hour or so of failed efforts to interview Kusama, I waited with the artist and her staff around a conference table for Araki’s arrival. Wearing a bright red wig, matching lipstick and her signature polka-dot motif  a red kimono-like dress adorned with circles of black and white felt  Kusama looked like a small grave clown, in the lull before a birthday party begins.

headline: Rising Above Racism
text: You may have heard of Charles Ethan Porter, but very few people can recall seeing one of his paintings. He was a dedicated painter who attracted the patronage of Mark Twain and Frederic Edwin Church.

headline: The Magnificent Seven
text: 1. Christophe Decarnin is revamping Balmain with Native American, Indian and animal prints, as well as a surfeit of beads, fringe and studs. Who’s afraid of a little boho? At Jeffrey New York and Intermix.

headline: One for the Price of One
text: “Do we really want a rerun of that soap opera?” Among friends and acquaintances talking through their presidential choices, it often comes down to this: excited to have two such inspiring candidates as Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton, they all roll their eyes at the melodramatic baggage that comes along with the former first couple. Not merely for the undecided voters among us, but for everyone involved, I think the situation calls for a deus ex machina solution drawn straight from the soaps themselves. Whisking a star offstage  often to some dire fate or unspecified location  is the tried-and-true secret to rescuing a flagging story line. For a campaign badly in need of an upswing, the moment has come for Hillary to declare plans to dispatch Bill to Africa once she takes office.

headline: Raúl Castro Named Cuba’s New President
text: HAVANA  Raúl Castro, who has labored in the shadow of his brother Fidel since the days of the Cuban revolution, became the new president of the Communist island on Sunday, ending his brother’s 49-year rule, as well as speculation that a younger generation would take power.

headline: Sydney’s Beachside Cuisine
text: ON an oppressively hot day in mid-January, at the peak of the Australian summer, tiny Shelly Beach, in the Sydney suburb of Manly, is crowded with sun-worshipers, body-surfers, teenagers on school break and young families gathered around blankets and picnic baskets. As the midday sun beats down, beachgoers take a dip in the cool waters of the protected cove, seek shelter in the shade of some nearby trees or just slather on another layer of lotion and contentedly bake away.

headline: Correction: The Charisma Mandate
text: An article last Sunday on the role of charisma in politics referred incorrectly to Republicans who were important to President Johnson’s push for the Civil Rights Act. They were Senate Republicans, not Southern Republicans. The article also referred imprecisely to Johnson’s well-known “We shall overcome” speech before Congress. He made it in 1965 as part of his push to get the Voting Rights Act passed; he did not give the speech before the Civil Rights Act, which had passed the previous year.

headline: Where ‘Mortgage’ Isn’t a Scary Word
text: INVEST in a mortgage REIT? For some people, that might seem as foolhardy as buying swampland in Florida.

headline: At Old Racetrack’s Site, a Sure Thing

From the outside it might be taken for one of the chain restaurants nearby, but the interior is dazzling, and so is the food. Actually, City Cellar is partly owned by the Big Time Restaurant Group, which has two other City Cellars in Florida.

headline: After the War, a New Battle to Become Citizens
text: Despite a 2002 promise from President Bush to put citizenship applications for immigrant members of the military on a fast track, some are finding themselves waiting months, or even years, because of bureaucratic backlogs. One, Sgt. Kendell K. Frederick of the Army, who had tried three times to file for citizenship, was killed by a roadside bomb in Iraq as he returned from submitting fingerprints for his application.

headline: Clinton Criticizes Obama Over Fliers on Trade Pacts Distributed to Voters in Ohio
text: CINCINNATI  Accusing the Obama campaign of using tactics “that are right out of Karl Rove’s playbook,” Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton angrily denounced Senator Barack Obama on Saturday for sending fliers to Ohio voters that she said falsely characterized her position on trade agreements.

headline: Trying to Put New Zip Into Moore’s Law
text: IF innovation has a heart, it’s probably a semiconductor, beating to the pace of Moore’s Law. Under this principle, named for the Intel co-founder Gordon Moore, the chip industry in the last four decades has doubled the number of transistors it crams onto a chip about every 18 months.

headline: The Road to Vegas: $55 and 70 Years
text: Before she retires as chief executive on March 1, Marilyn Carlson Nelson will preside over a 70th anniversary celebration in Las Vegas this week for Carlson, the travel, lodging, restaurant and marketing business that began as the Gold Bond Stamp Company in 1938.
