headline: Serb Grief Over Kosovo Runs Deep
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  Nationalist hooligans may have been behind the torching of the United States Embassy here, but the feelings of anger, sorrow and betrayal over the loss of Kosovo cut across all segments of Serbian society.

headline: Red Fox
text: I was about 20 years old and determined to wear a red Valentino dress to my friend’s debutante ball. I had a crush on a boy who was going to be there, and had seen how when my mother wore Valentino couture she immediately became the center of attention. Without fail, a moment of silence would occur as she stepped into a room, much like a pause in a music score. I wanted to experience this intense feeling for myself. When I asked to borrow Mom’s dress, she flatly refused, saying that red at a coming-out party went against all codes of etiquette. So I did what any savvy New York girl would do: I called Valentino himself, who was thrilled at the idea of making me the social scandal of the season. He gave me my own gown, and since then, I have worn many more  recently to his anniversary in Rome and to Elton John’s birthday party. The effect is always the same: his shade of red is so rich and beautiful that it makes you want to slightly misbehave. Oh, and about that guy I liked way back then  it worked.

headline: Phantoms of Broadway: The Season That Wasn’t
text: IN a parallel universe you could be deciding tonight whether to try to score a hard-to-get ticket to Annette Bening’s play or Spike Lee’s Broadway directorial debut, or to grovel for a spare ticket to Jake Gyllenhaal’s Off Broadway play. headline: True Grit? Not So Much, Anymore
text: The “Living In” column on Feb. 10, about the East Village, misstated the number of city-recognized historic districts in the area. The East Village does indeed have one district: St. Mark’s Historic District, designated in 1969. It is not totally without such districts.

headline: Jazz Man
text: Nearly a century after jazz emerged as a musical form with profound cultural resonance, the jazz novel, like the theater of the absurd and radio drama, seems an archaism, a good subject for a third-year undergraduate elective or a Bravo documentary. When we think of jazz fiction, we think not only of books centered on the music but of work steeped in the jazz aesthetic  an implacably rigorous and cosmopolitan tradition rooted in the blues and the African-American experience, in which obedience to the moment has primacy. We also call to mind writers dating back to the Harlem Renaissance. We think of Langston Hughes and Jean Toomer; and of F. Scott Fitzgerald, whose legend is inextricable from the age named for jazz; we think perhaps of Kenneth Rexroth; of Ralph Ellison and James Baldwin and Amiri Baraka; and of Jack Kerouac and his fellow Beats, among many others. We think of past eras in a montage of changing modes of headwear: top hats ... fedoras ... kufis ... berets. But we are unlikely to think immediately of jazz when we think of contemporary literature, and we may well conceive of the act of writing a jazz novel in the 21st century as akin to wearing a hat today  as an affectation, a mark of a retro obsession or a hint that one is trying to hide a certain lack of something up top.

headline: The Innocence Project
text: Born as common as nondairy creamer, the daughter of a stableman and a domestic servant, Jane Burden rose to the crème de la crème of fin de siècle English society. The tousled-haired Pre-Raphaelite beauty not only became the wife and muse of William Morris, the founder of the British Arts and Crafts movement, but she is also believed to have been an inspiration for George Bernard Shaw’s “Pygmalion.”

headline: Flight Risk
text: We members of an online pilots’ forum often discuss a book about an airplane model flown by many of us. The book is out of print and, despite our many requests, likely to remain so. One of us posted an electronic copy of the book and invited others to download it and (at another member’s suggestion) send a check to the author. Ethical?  JOHN FELLEMAN, PALO ALTO, CALIF.

headline: McCain’s Age May Figure in Choice of a Running Mate

John McCain, 71, is hoping to become the oldest candidate ever elected to a first term in the White House.

headline: The Dirt Devil | SLINGING MUD HAS ITS ADVANTAGES - AT LEAST FOR SKIN AND HAIR
text: We’re entering the “Just-spring” portion of the year, according to E. E. Cummings, when the world turns “mud-luscious.” The Samurai Shopper has already sprung from the hibernal freeze to roll around cheek by jowl, a prehistoric swamp thing adrift in mud-luscious eddies. There’s mud on my scalp, mud on my face. Ripples of viscous silt voluptuously coat my nutrient-starved skin, nestling in nooks where the sun don’t shine.

text: WHEN I started practicing as a certified divorce financial analyst in 2004, I knew that I would use the skills I had acquired over 16 years in the financial services industry. But what I didn’t realize was that I would often feel like a therapist.

headline: The Heart and Soul of Suburbia
text: THE bustling family- and singles-friendly neighborhood known as Huntington Village is neither incorporated nor an official government entity. But this restaurant-laden, shopper-happy 36-square-block cosmopolitan oasis is popular with residents and tourists as the downtown hub and the unofficial capital of the town of Huntington.

headline: The Lemur
text: Chapter 7: The Cleaver

headline: Contributors
text: NOBUYOSHI ARAKI : The legendary Japanese photographer Nobuyoshi Araki shot the artist Yayoi Kusama (center) for “Kusama Dot Com” (Page 266), but it wasn’t the first time the icons crossed paths. “She and I go back a long time,” he says, adding that he first photographed her for a 1980s Japanese porn magazine for which he wrapped her in toilet paper. Despite their history, Araki admits there are still some unfinished chapters in their relationship: “I’ve never slept with her, so we’ll never come to know everything about each other.” After more than 40 years snapping everything from painted flowers (above) to scenes of fellatio, Araki is one of the most prolific and passionate artists working today. “Photography is my nutrition, and the sound of the shutter is my heart-beating pulse.” A show of his work at the Kestnergesellschaft in Hannover, Germany, runs through May 12.

headline: Universities Make Plans to Expand
text: EXPANSION plans are in the air for some state and private universities on Long Island, as Hofstra University is near an agreement for a new medical school and Stony Brook University is talking to a state official about starting a law school, which would be only the second at a state university in New York.

headline: Serbia Seeks Rioters Who Set Fire to the U.S. Embassy
text: PRISTINA, Kosovo  Serbia’s top state prosecutor said Saturday that the authorities were hunting for the rioters who attacked the United States Embassy and other diplomatic missions last week.

headline: Did You Hear the One About the Christian Comedian?
text: If you are a mother with children between the ages of, say, 5 and 55, you have probably been the recipient  once, twice, maybe even more times  of an e-mail message directing you to a particular YouTube clip. The grainy film features a somewhat ordinary looking woman of indeterminate age with longish red hair who is wearing glasses, slacks and a leather jacket. She stands on a stage next to a piano and grasps a microphone and, like a magician introducing her next trick, explains that she will condense into 2 minutes and 55 seconds “what a mom would say in a 24-hour period.” Then she looks down, clasps her hands, looks up and, as the familiar horns of the “William Tell Overture” sound, declares: “Strap on your seatbelt. Here we go.” Then she starts to sing, with a slight Southern accent, at breakneck speed:

headline: Sydney’s Rock Pools
text: NEARLY every day for 14 years, Denise Leith, a writer and university lecturer, has risen before dawn and headed to the beach at Newport, a pleasant, residential suburb 19 miles north of downtown Sydney, with fruit stands, pharmacies and small shops along the main road, within the sound and smell of the sea. She walks to the south end of the long beach and after donning her cap and goggles plunges into a 50-meter pool.

headline: Your Publicist Should Call My Publicist
text: LOS ANGELES  AT the annual Oscar nominees luncheon a few weeks ago, Frank Pierson  the writer of “Dog Day Afternoon,” the director of “A Star Is Born” and a former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences  expressed wonderment as he sized up the room. And he wasn’t marveling at George Clooney’s smile.

headline: Harlem Pas de Deux
text: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about gentrification in Harlem referred imprecisely to an increase in apartment prices there. While prices for some apartments have indeed doubled in the past year, the prices of other apartments did not increase that much. (As the article noted, the average sale price in Harlem in the last quarter of 2007 was 93 percent higher than in the last quarter of 2006.)

headline: Pretty Ugly
text: Any aficionado of early Mad comics published during the first half of the 1950s, when Mad was still a riotous comic book and not yet a formatted magazine, will recognize the brilliantly perverse parody of a Life magazine cover featuring a portrait of a hideous girl next to the headline “Beautiful Girl of the Month Reads Mad.” The artist who concocted this misshapen, bug-eyed, fang-toothed, pimply-faced, spaghetti-haired, pig-nosed monstrosity was Basil Wolverton (1909-78), a Mad mainstay who specialized in things ugly. He created Lena the Hyena, a character who appeared in Al Capp’s “L’il Abner” and was known as “the ugliest woman in Lower Slobbovia.” And he was the mastermind behind “Powerhouse Pepper,” a mock-heroic melodrama, as well as covers for GJDRKZLXCBWQ Comics: A Gallery of Gooney Gags and DC Comics’ Mad-like Plop! Always recognizable for unbridled grotesquerie, his art ran the gamut from political satire (“Candid Close-Ups: Hitler”) to goofy science fiction (“Rocket Rider”) to biblical illustrations (for a decade he wrote and illustrated the Bible story, serialized in The Plain Truth magazine, for the Worldwide Church of God). His epic in this last genre was a gory interpretation of Armageddon, complete with horrific atomic aftermaths. He did, however, also produce posters for Topps, the trading card company. While his penchant for extreme physical exaggeration may not have been to everyone’s taste, through Mad he exercised incalculable influence on the history of comics and the perceptions of impressionable preteens, like me. “Gross” was and remains a generational code.

headline: You Better Werkstatte
text: At the Wiener Werkstätte, artists believed that a piece of jewelry should serve as something more personal than an advertisement for wealth. Josef Hoffmann, one of the workshop’s founders, used semiprecious stones including coral and moonstone to create brooches that resembled stained glass (left). His pieces also referred to Gustav Klimt, who happened to be an important patron. The artist Dagobert Peche went a more organic route with nature-inspired bracelets and pendants. “They were thinking in more abstract ways,” says Janis Staggs, who curated the show “Wiener Werkstätte Jewelry,” which opens at the Neue Galerie in New York on March 27. “It was about experimentation of color and pattern.” But not necessarily about perfection. As Staggs explains, “No two pieces were alike. There were always inconsistencies, which add to the charm.” [?][?][?]MAURA EGAN

headline: Letters: In Vino Veritas
text: So those grotesque drunk videos posted online aren’t pornography, and it’s perfectly fine to enjoy watching drunken people debase themselves (The Medium, Virginia Heffernan, Feb. 10). But why does it still seem so skeevy? Because it is, in fact, thoroughly pornographic in its most basic nature. Even if it isn’t specifically sexual (which I believe it may well be in some perverse sublimated form), this still involves objectification and dehumanization.

headline: Amid Weeds and Rust, a Ruin Seeks a Second Act
text: FOR as long as most people living in Farragut Houses can remember, the 10 weed-choked town houses around the corner have lain in ruins, partly hidden behind a high fence and ignored by all who pass.

headline: Reluctant Landlords Settle Into a Rental
text: BERNIE DeCHANT owns a two-family house in a nice San Francisco neighborhood. His buddy Pascal Balthrop owns a three-story town house in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn. But the two choose to live together as roommates on nearby Union Street in a two-bedroom rental that Mr. DeChant describes as more of a hovel than a palace.

headline: Bird-Dog Minute
text: Responding to a cockamamie question a few weeks ago about whether there is a secret agreement to merge the U.S., Mexico and Canada into a single continental nation (MexiCanUs?), Senator Hillary Clinton gently replied, “I’ve heard that story, and there’s not a lot of truth to it.” Not to put down her somewhat vituperative Missouri questioner, the senator added, “If I am president, if I discover there is such an agreement, it’ll be gone in a bird-dog minute.”

headline: Bright Yarn Thing
text: Just as her muse Jean-Michel Basquiat used to say, “Believe it or not, I can actually draw,” the British knitwear sensation Clare Tough says she can actually knit. Still, grandmothers everywhere may grumble that some of her graffiti-inspired creations (like her Brooklyn Bridge bra, a skimpy creation in wool and balsa wood) break every rule of the purl-one-knit-two set. Ditto for the zippered cardigan with an overload of ribbed patchwork and vibrant embroideries, which she says has about 50 types of yarn. Tough first got noticed in 2004 with her Central Saint Martins graduation show: the string outfits of Jamaican dancehall queens re-envisioned as cobwebby knit dresses. But her real obsession is ’80s New York, having grown up in the picture-postcard spa town Malvern listening to Fab 5 Freddie and old hip-hop compilations. Tough, 27, is bent on expanding the definition of knitwear. “I didn’t invent crochet, obviously, but I really think the way I patchwork garments together hasn’t been done before,” she says in her East London studio. “Knitting has got a frumpy image, and it really shouldn’t.” [?][?][?]SUSIE RUSHTON THE REMIX

headline: The Stages of Bart Sher
text: The young man opened his mouth to sing, and the sound was so rich, so beautiful that when he finished there was only stunned silence. He left the audition room, and the appreciative murmuring began  with one exception. “He sings great, but he has no pearly mist,” Bartlett Sher said flatly. “There’s something not appealing about him.” The other men at the table, including the musical director, were dumbstruck. But Sher was resolute. “The big perfect voice is not always the point,” he said. “Let’s go on.”

headline: Made in the Shade
text: When I turned 10, my family moved from a solidly middle-class suburb of Los Angeles, where time seemed to have stopped in a kind of sleepy Norman Rockwell fashion, to Brentwood, which is nestled in the much posher, much faster west side of the city. There had been a divorce and nearly instant remarriages, and my mother, who is relentless and clever about forward motion, realized that where we were living was not where we should be living. This was a shock for many reasons, most of which had to do with the girls in my new sixth-grade class. I had come from the land of saddle shoes, bobby socks and plaid jumpers, and suddenly I was confronted with a world of snobby 11-year-old sophisticates in nylons, heels and miniature versions of their mothers’ ’70s sheaths. I was still a child — I wanted to go trick-or-treating on Halloween, they wanted to play truth or dare with the boys; I was proud of my Girl Scout merit badges, they wanted to wear their green uniforms to entice older boys. But most of all, and most shocking to me, was that they all wore black. Not every day, but for special occasions — class photo, assembly, sixth-grade graduation — and I had never known anyone of any age who wore black for anything other than a funeral.

headline: Four or Five Things You Don’t Know About Me
text: THE other day I was walking down the street and I realized that everyone was wearing earmuffs. I myself was wearing earmuffs at the time, but that wasn’t the reason I noticed all the other earmuffs  I noticed them because I happen to know that I personally started the trend of earmuffs. I began wearing them at the age of 21, when you could barely find a pair in a store, which doubtless was one reason no one wore them but me. The only ones for sale were made of felt, came in two separate bits and hooked over your upper ear and then snapped against your head. They were inadequate thermal protection compared to my current pair, which are made of fake fur; but they were far superior to being outdoors in winter without anything at all over your ears. I had serious fantasies that by wearing them, I would start something, fashion-wise, and now it seems I have. It’s true it’s taken a while, 45 years to be exact, but earmuffs are definitely catching on, and it’s because of me.

JENNIFER AULL has been doing a lot of food shopping lately, for a while at a supermarket and then at a wholesale distributor where she buys peanut butter, crackers, canned vegetables and macaroni and cheese in bulk. To the people doing the billing, she must look like the owner of a small grocery.

headline: A Web Portal for Shopaholics
text: If you’re tired of shopping at the same old chain stores, then check out www.storeadore.com. The new Web site aims to personalize the traveler’s shopping experience by using local writers to provide information on their city’s most estimable boutiques. Started by a former editor at Lucky Magazine and a former management consultant, the site, which also publishes exclusive shopping deals, currently covers New York, Boston, Los Angeles and Washington, as well as online stores. In June, it will expand its coverage to include San Francisco, Chicago, Philadelphia, Dallas and Miami. Users may create their own profiles with shopping “bios” and customize a favorite stores map, as well as keep current by reading the site’s blog, which is constantly getting updated with new trends and ideas.

headline: Feed Your Face
text: l1 It’s not easy to get face time with Tracie Martyn. The beauty guru’s appointment book is crammed with names like Kate Winslet, Sandra Bullock, Madonna and Renée Zellweger, all of whom get their glow on with Martyn’s Red Carpet and Resculpting Facials. “My treatments are like having mini-lifts without the down time,” Martyn says. In addition to cleaning the skin, she aims to firm and contour the jaw, cheekbones and eye area. Mere mortals can join the wait list. Go to traciemartyn.com.

headline: Attacks Show Easygoing Jamaica Is Dire Place for Gays

headline: A Sign of Hope for Stocks
text: FROM at least one perspective, the stock market peak of last October was not accompanied by the speculative excesses found at the height of previous bull markets. This raises hope that the market decline that began in the fall may not turn out to be severe  and that it may have already run its course.

headline: Michelin Gives Stars, but Tokyo Turns Up Nose
text: TOKYO  The Michelin guide recently ventured into Asia for the first time in its 108-year history to research and publish a Japanese-language guide to Tokyo restaurants. To gain credibility, it hired Japanese restaurant judges to work with its European experts and adapted its standards to the nation’s special culinary culture.

headline: Breaking the Mold of the Musical
text: THE spring season’s small crop of new musicals is intriguingly diverse, signifying how the definition of the Broadway musical continues to expand. Artists grope their way forward, trying to invigorate the old forms, even as they search out new ones. Each represents one or another of the assorted impulses behind the making of the 21st-century American musical.

headline: It Must Be Ohio
text: The Ohio Democratic primary is still nine days away and Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are already accusing each other of being soft on trade. Criticisms of trade agreements in Ohio are as predictable as praise for ethanol in Iowa. But they do the voters no favor.

headline: Correction: Review of ‘Brooklyn Was Mine’

headline: The April Fools’ Joke I Played on Myself
text: MY girlfriend and I were descending into the Eighth Avenue L train subway station when I remembered it was April Fools’ Day. I am not a big fan of this day; I’m not an office jokester, always ready with a back slap and witticism. But the realization gave me the urge to contact my little brother.

headline: Nader to Run Again

headline: Not Maxed Out
text: Last night’s Miramax party had all the trappings of a major Oscar bacchanal. Tight door, movie stars, even an appearance by the elusive Cormac McCarthy (the author of “No Country for Old Men”). The Soho club here offered a great space and amazing views and even a smoking cage, a place where the muse often hunts the Bagger down, but no one wants to put both pom poms in the air – not the night before, and maybe not the night after. Strike, rain, macro-business problems, the death of Heath Ledger, blame it on whatever you want, but no one is doing the backstroke in Oscar froth this year.

headline: The Man Who Wouldn’t Die
text: Just saying: You might want to be wary of a book in which the author reveals the exact size of his erect sex organ on Page 48. Those boys!

headline: Crowded High Wire
text: Yesteday, Tom O’Neil took a seat on the high wire, suggesting that George Clooney could sneak past Daniel Day-Lewis in the best actor category. He got some company yesterday. The Bagger bumped into Tom Bernard, the co-chief honcho at Sony Pictures Classics, at the Spirit Awards. Bernard has a pretty good record in Oscar matters and has good sources among old members of the Academy, although he was wearing sunglasses that play MP3’s, so there is that. (Dog the Bounty Hunter, who is staying at the Bagger’s hotel, has a similar pair.) And Bernard said that Day-Lewis may not be the lock we have all said he was. “You’re probably right about Daniel Day-Lewis, but I wouldn’t be surprised to see Clooney sneak in.”

headline: Funny Girl
text: At yesterday’s rehearsals, according to The Associated Press, Cameron Diaz, in a gray sweater, skinny black jeans and towering high heels, opened a prop winner’s envelope and said, “The Oscar goes to — your mama. No, I’m just kidding.”

headline: Calling an Audible
text: This year’s Oscars would have seemed to be a great time to innovate, to put together a show on the fly that perhaps attacks some of the creakiness and convention that is part of Oscar gospel. Ain’t. Gonna. Happen. In spite of the fact that organizers had little more than a week to put together the show, this will be no ad-hoc Oscars. Look for the same glorious goo to be poured into the extant template. People who have seen the auditions say that there is a palpable desire for normalcy, for business as usual, but that means the same brutal copy will show up on the teleprompter and be beamed straight at you.

headline: Breaking the Rules
text: When he learned I wanted to write a play, Jon Jory, who was then Artistic Director of Actors Theatre of Louisville, took me out to lunch and said, “OK, here are the three mistakes you don’t have to make.” And that’s pretty much the way I teach to this day — telling writers the traps they don’t have to fall into, not saying how it has to be done, just trying to save them some of their precious time. Over the years people have yelled at me for teaching the rules, or even for suggesting that there are rules. But I never expect these rules to be followed absolutely. They serve the same purpose as the boundary flags in ski resorts. You can ski in the ungroomed powder if you want, but you’d better know what you’re doing, and be willing to take the risk. Still, we do not turn on the television to watch average skiers take safe trips down the green trails. We turn on the X Games to see heli-skiers land on the top of glaciers and shoot off the edges of the cliffs, or watch the great Shaun White “shred some gnarly terrain”, as my son says. And that brings us to “August: Osage County,” a play that only seems traditional, but actually creates its excitement by breaking the rules.

headline: Stuffing the Ballot Box with Electrons
text: Dan, the Bagger’s digital peer, has been crunching some data: For the third straight year, our readers have weighed in on the race. The first year … well, we let people vote more than once, so the results were just a tad skewed. But this year, the numbers look right, and in more ways than one. NYTimes.comers’ votes align nicely with the general zeitgeist (though not necessarily with the Bagger’s picks), though there are a few surprises. “No Country” gets picture, director, supporting actor and screenplay. But Daniel Day-Lewis is neck and neck with Johnny Depp for Best Actor. Cate Blanchett would win both actress awards if the readers were in charge.

headline: British Hegemony
text: Every year, the Oscars pay a visit to that mid-Atlantic place where British and American culture mash up into something that combines Yankee rigor with English refinement. This year, that phenomenon shows up in the form of “Atonement,” with a young British director, Joe Wright, and ingénue Keira Knightley defining Anglophilian upper crust lust. And in the acting categories, you’ve also got your Tilda Swintons – who could win this year, btw – and Julie Christies, who is favored to win. Cate Blanchett is nominated, twice in fact, a sorta Brit from Australia.

headline: The Oscars: A Love/Hate Story
text: The Bagger’s more carefully considered doppelganger has a point-counter point about the cultural value of the Oscars in the newspaper today with A. O. Scott, a real, actual movie critic. The package includes an audio file of the throw-down, but the overlords at the House of Many Doors edited out the part where Scott called the Bagger an “ignorant slut,” but it is still a lively and blessedly brief – the Bagger’s voice has been compared to the sound cows emit when they get a batch of bad feed – podcast about the worthiness of the national bonfire of glitter and gamesmanship.

headline: Kodak Moment: Intermittent Rain, a Stalled High Pressure System
text: Over the past few days, unseasonable cold and rain in Los Angeles has occasionally given way to some moments when the sun breaks through, bathing the city in welcome light and flicking at the dampness. People will scan the sky, turning their face toward sun that is generally a prerogative of living here. (Update: 11:30 PST. Sunny but chill.)

headline: The Roitfelds | Family de la Mode
text: Carine Roitfeld, the editor in chief of Vogue Paris, bequeathed her children her soigné style as if it were their birthright. Her daughter, Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, is a freelance art director for the likes of Jean Paul Gaultier and was the face of Tom Ford’s latest fragrance; her son, Vladimir Restoin-Roitfeld, is a film school graduate and a sometime model. Going to a fashion shoot when they were young, says Mom, was as normal as tarte Tatin. (The photographer Mario Testino is their godfather.) Many consider Roitfeld the stilettoed embodiment of modern dressing: she describes her style as ‘‘tacky chic.’’ Never afraid to take a risk, she has put a bearded drag queen on a cover and printed a fashion story with a model dressed as an Anna Wintour clone. After 20-plus years in the business, certain things have changed: ‘‘I don’t go too much to the parties now, but my kids do.’’ Like their mom, they’re always on the list.

headline: Clinton Turns From Anger to Sarcasm
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. – On Saturday, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton showed her angry side, admonishing Senator Barack Obama for a campaign mailing that she called misleading.

headline: The Candidates on Nader
text: The Democratic and Republican candidates have begun weighing in on Ralph Nader’s announcement this morning on NBC’s “Meet the Press” that yes, he has decided to run for the presidency, again. While he has been derided by Democrats for taking away votes from Al Gore in the 2000 presidential race, his impact in 2004 was minimal.

headline: Post-Strike ‘Saturday Night Live’ Gets Ratings Bounce

headline: Electronic Arts Offers $2 Billion for Take-Two
text: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for a rival, Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise. The deal would reshape the rapidly growing video game industry, which has begun a wave of consolidation.

headline: Have Your Guy Talk to My Guy So We Can Talk About This Guy
text: The Bagger has assumed the position, behind one of the hedges on the red carpet at the Kodak Theater. And who will he talk to while he is there? Fabulous movies stars, perhaps? Perhaps, But first, even here, he will spend time talking publicists. In the business section of The New York Times, Michael Cieply writes a quiet, but savagely hilarious piece about the publicity apparatus that comes to a head today.

headline: That Scary Movie Sound
text: The crowd across the way on the carpet is making that freaky, scary happy noise and boy are they ready. There was just a huge roar and the Bagger is pretty sure it was somebody bringing a tray of sandwiches inside.

headline: Together Again
text: The Bagger is stationed next to Robert Osborne, the television host who has been introducing the talent on the carpet to the adoring hoardes for the past three years. He loves the gig.

headline: The $136.5 Million Pitcher Hits the $119 Million Center Fielder
text: Johan Santana threw an inside fastball to Carlos Beltran, but it sailed too far inside and drilled Beltran in the left triceps. The sound of the ball hitting Beltran’s flesh was unmistakable and even sounded like it hurt.

headline: Stand-Up Accounting
text: Rick Rosas and Brad Oltmanns, those two guys from PricewaterhouseCoopers, who know all and tell nothing, came in with their briefcases that contained all the results. The Bagger took a picture and said it was an X-ray camera. Rosas said, “We use lead envelopes.” The briefcases looked new. “We use the same ones every year,” said Oltmanns. What if someone were to cheat or misspoke? “We would correct them immediately,” they both said in unison.

headline: Sunshine & Pillow-snatchers
text: (Photo: A look from the Rick Owens fall 2008 collection in Paris. (Jean-Luce Huré for The New York Times))   I had plans--plans I tell you!--to be up early and roaming the town but my pillow snatched me back and it was past noon before I set off to the Place de la Concorde, already crowded with people. It was a stunning day, cloudless and mild. The first show for most of the editors and buyers was Balmain (the tightest, smallest pants and club tops in leather and metal mesh, nothing surprising) and a number of the guests had brought their young children. In the course of the day I heard a lot of things. Will Robert Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano of 6267 take over Ferre? Is Hedi Slimane in negotiations for his own men's and women's label? Time will tell. I thought Slimane's pictures (in New York Magazine) of Carine Roitfeld were terrific, and evocative of her. And take a look at the spreads with Lara Stone in the current Paris Vogue, particularly Neo Classiques, by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott.   (Photo: Another look from the Rick Owens fall 2008 collection in Paris. (Jean-Luce Huré for The New York Times))   Rick Owens was this afternoon: great show. The collection is more voluptuous than last season, with the familiar darkness and Owens grit. Owens gives a kind of hour-glass shape to jackets, sometimes using two or three fabrics in combination, and creating sculptural effects. The thought process seemed very top to toe, with small, square-ish caps, fins and cube-like volumes on some of the jackets, and wedge-heel boots with flaps that spill around the calf and drag on the ground. In the midst of all this shape and texture were simple tank dresses and skimmy biker shorts in cashmere. Thom Browne happened to be at the show.   The New York Times Magazine and the International Herald Tribune had a party tonight at the Mini Palais. I stopped by for a few minutes. Well, that was the plan... I saw Stefano Pilati, Sidney Toledano of Dior, Kris Van Assche, Maria Cornejo, and Manuel Puig, whose company owns Nina Ricci. Puig is an interesting guy to talk to--about business, U.S. politics, Europe, Formula 1 racing. On my way out, I ran into Karl Lagerfeld and Amanda Harlech. Lagerfeld told me his suit was a Jil Sander by Raf Simons. I jumped in Mr. Alloux's waiting taxi, thinking I'd better save my strength for the rest of the week.   More photos from Paris Fashion Week here.

headline: Sunshine & Pillow-snatchers
text: I had plans–plans I tell you!–to be up early and roaming the town but my pillow snatched me back and it was past noon before I set off to the Place de la Concorde, already crowded with people. It was a stunning day, cloudless and mild. The first show for most of the editors and buyers was Balmain (the tightest, smallest pants and club tops in leather and metal mesh, nothing surprising) and a number of the guests had brought their young children. In the course of the day I heard a lot of things. Will Robert Rimondi and Tommaso Aquilano of 6267 take over Ferre? Is Hedi Slimane in negotiations for his own men’s and women’s label? Time will tell. I thought Slimane’s pictures (in New York Magazine) of Carine Roitfeld were terrific, and evocative of her. And take a look at the spreads with Lara Stone in the current Paris Vogue, particularly Neo Classiques, by Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott.

headline: Wanted: Someone Who Knows Nothing About the Job
text: In one of those ironies that make life interesting, the University of Colorado, which dismissed controversial professor Ward Churchill because of doubts about his academic qualifications, has appointed a president who doesn’t have any. (The final vote was taken on Feb. 20.)

headline: For Some Top Players, Invitations to Elite Tournaments Are Scarce
text: Sergey Karjakin of the Ukraine is ranked No. 14 in the world and has been ranked in the top 30 for a year. Last December, he made it to the semifinals of the World Cup before narrowly losing to Alexei Shirov Spain. Because of that performance, he is seeded into the Grand Prix, the series of tournaments that will help select a challenger for the world championship. He holds the record as the youngest grandmaster in history (12 years 7 months). And he turned 18 a little more than a month ago.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia:  New Harmonies
text: Young Chinese musicians introduced their original compositions to veteran professionals from the New York Philharmonic during the orchestra’s visit to Shanghai.

headline: In November, Will Age Matter?
text: As John McCain comes ever closer to securing the Republican nomination, his age has remained notably absent as a campaign issue. So far it has attracted so little attention that the network exit pollsters have not included even one question on the subject in 23 state surveys — an extraordinary occurrence given that Senator McCain would be the oldest man ever to take office, if he were to win the presidency.

headline: Let’s Roll
text: The good news is they were able to right this overturned vehicle. The bad news is they were able to right this overturned vehicle:

headline: ‘Turned Out To Be False’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Spoof Dogg
Generational Exchange
text: Julie Christie, in the midst of a long career that this year includes a best actress not, looked down the carpet a few feet at Ellen Page, her fellow nominee.

headline: Close Contests Ahead
text: The Texas and Ohio Democratic primaries on March 4 are critical to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has lost the last 11 contests. The latest polls show that the races are close. In Texas, Mrs. Clinton and Senator Barack Obama are neck and neck. In Ohio, Mrs. Clinton has a slight lead.

headline: In Calm Before the Storm, an Opportunity to Regroup
text: Video

headline: Learning to Speak Oscar
text: Marion Cotillard has been on the circuit for a month, going hither and yon in Los Angeles in support of “La Vie en Rose” and her nomination for best actress. Her English has improved rapidly — “Why thank you!” –as has her understanding of the business. “I had no idea that a little French movie would go this far, but this is what you do once it does.”

headline: Criss-cross
text: Ellen Page, the tiniest presence on the circuit, at least in terms of body mass, was standing in front of the Bagger when Michael Moore, one of the largest, came by. They squeezed by each other, a waif walking around a mountain, award circuit familiars.

headline: Complain, Who Me?
text: Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in “Charlie Wilson’s War” — and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won, btw.) Hoffman is known as somebody with very little taste for the pomp and silliness of the awards campaign.

headline: Hemmed In
text: Miley Cyrus (a k a Hannah Montana), one of the evening’s presenters, was told by her publicist that it was time to quit an interview and step up to be interviewed by Robert Osborne, the red carpet host of the Oscars.

headline: Homers
text: The press room generally likes a surprise as much as the next person — “Golden Compass for effects!????” — because it makes for a story that has a few twists and turns. But the newsies like a front-runner because it makes them feel smug and knowing. Which is why they yelled like 8-year-olds when the Javier Bardem won for best supporting male.

headline: Cheese Curdles
text: The press room may be the worst place in the world to watch the Oscars, but the Bagger is beginning to notice a trend. Even though the strike lifted and the whole show is back on, Jon Stewart and the producers continue to insist on showing filmed segments that would have been broadcast, as if to menace the crowd with what might have been. Maybe it would have been worse, but for the time being, there seems to be an odd juxtaposition of hackery — a filmed riff on telescopes and binoculars — sentiment — Jon Stewart going so sweet on the kids from “August Rush” — and vamping — pregger jokes about Cate Blanchett and Jessica Alba.

headline: ‘Curiouser and Curiouser’
text: “‘Who in the world am I?’ Ah, that’s the great puzzle!” says Lewis Carroll’s Alice after experiencing a sudden, disorienting growth spurt.

headline: Secure in Their Beliefs
text: The Bagger showed up on time this year — he got clobbered last year for trying to slip in late and caused a red alert. This year, he was far more obedient and the staff was enormously helpful. But what could have been a gracious ingress and egress was marred earlier when he busted a move down the carpet to leave a little early. Two guys came up on either side and walked him to a gate. They told him he could go in through the adjacent hotel. The Bagger knew better. He was ejected. The guys with the headpieces can smell fear, and the Bagger knew what was coming. He has finally hacked his way back in.

headline: What Is This, a Surprise Party?
text: The show may be short on surprises, but the actual awards have provided plenty. Tilda Swinton walked by Amy Ryan and Ruby Dee, winning best supporting for her turn as a sweaty, grasping corporate executive in “Michael Clayton” who drowns in her own venality. “Golden Compass” was on no one’s radar, but walked past the artful machines of “Transformers” to win effects. And art direction, which many thought would be the Academy’s way of recognizing the achievement of “There Will be Blood” or perhaps giving a bon-bon to “Atonement,” went to “Sweeney Todd” instead, a movie that dropped off the radar some time ago.

headline: SNL: Back and ‘In the Tank’ for Politics
text: “Saturday Night Live” plunged into presidential politics as the show returned to the air over the weekend for the first time since Nov. 3. In a faux debate, it mocked the media as a tool of Senator Barack Obama:

headline: The Euros Are Up
text: Three acting awards handed out and three go to actors whose professional homes lie outside Hollywood.

headline: Let the Games Begin – The Market Will Speak on Proposed Game Merger
text: Electronic Arts made its offer for rival Take-Two Interactive. Take-Two declined.

headline: Tilda Exclaimed
text: Tilda Swinton could not be any more different that the doughy, sweaty character she plays in “Michael Clayton.” With a shock of red, short hair and a very thin draped in black velvet, she looked like a human exclamation point.

headline: Not a Suspense Director
text: Jason Reitman, the director of “Juno,” is oddly one of the people in the room who will not be on pins and needles waiting for the best picture announcement.

headline: The Political Climate in Ohio
text: Senators Clinton and Obama are facing a electorate that has been promised many things by many presidential candidates over the years.

headline: Fighting Fires With Fans
text: On Governors Island, the New York Fire Department intentionally sets fires in order to analyze the movement of air, fire and smoke.

headline: A Message From God
text: Glen Hansard showed up on the red carpet with his beat-up guitar on one arm and his professional and personal partner Marketa Irglova on the other.

headline: Bonbon Dispenser
text: Remember in first grade when everybody won a little something? If not first honors, then some kind of very special person award. This Oscars is feeling like that. Little “Atonement,” we have original score award for you. And “There Will Be Blood?” We have a cinematography award for you. “Juno,” we see you, you little dickens back there. Here’s a screenplay win for you.

headline: Average Joe
text: Back in Sundance, the Bagger was doing videos and talked to a quiet nice man who chatted amiably on camera about the movies at Sundance. Somebody finally interrupted the Bagger and said, “Hey, that guy makes movies too. His name is Alex Gibney. He makes documentaries.” As of a few minutes ago, he makes Academy Award-winning documentaries, in this case, “Taxi to The Dark Side.”

headline: Four-Star Euro Hotel
text: Each year, four acting slots come up for grabs. European actors frequently are part of the mix, but they never have walked away with four. (Wrong, as a reader points out. It happened in 1964.) Taking cultural hegemony to a new tier, Hollywood mostly stood by.

headline: Dubai Powerhouse Makes First Move into Latin America Market
text: Nakheel, the state-controlled Dubai developer, has purchased a half interest in a Mexican resort, its first foray into Latin America. Nakheel paid $315 million (€213 million) for the 50 percent share of Palmilla, a high-end resort and condo development outside Cabo San Lucas, on the southern tip of Baja California.

headline: Israel Adds Border Forces Ahead of Protest in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM  The Israeli Army bolstered its forces on the Israeli side of the border fence with the Gaza Strip on Sunday after Palestinian advocates there called on residents to form a human chain on Monday along the Gaza side, from Rafah in the south to Beit Hanun in the north.

headline: Metropolitan Diary
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: He Stomps Like Godzilla, Stings Like a... Don’t Ask
text: In “Monster, 1959” David Maine invites readers into the pea-sized brain of a 40-foot “monstrous smorgasbord” known as K. Described as “something to cause Darwin to burn his notebooks and run shrieking to the nearest monastery,” K. lacks lips but is a kissing cousin to Godzilla. He is a hapless, guileless, rampaging creature straight out of B-movie science fiction. In light of Mr. Maine’s flair for domesticating larger-than-life subject matter, his new book’s premise seems hard to resist.

headline: Pentagon Calls Satellite Hit a Success
text: WASHINGTON  The Pentagon announced Monday that the mission to launch a Navy missile-interceptor at a dead spy satellite appears to have succeeded in destroying a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel.

headline: In the Drama of Britney Spears, a Show Business Fortune Is at Risk
text: LOS ANGELES  Britney Spears’s klieg-lighted meltdown sent her to the psychiatric ward twice, and left her long-divorced parents, her brother, and a SWAT team of lawyers and accountants grappling with how to protect her from predatory hangers-on, from the paparazzi who dog her every move and from her own erratic behavior.

headline: A Momentary Pause, in Praise of Punctuation
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Carpet, Starry Sights, Sounds and Even Smells
text: HOLLYWOOD  In his seasonal quest to sate his blog with all things Oscar, the Bagger returned Sunday evening to the red carpet  breaking a vow, but keeping his job. Both he and Hollywood were trying hard not to get too frantic in what has been a subdued, strike-affected year, but when you have George Clooney walking by Javier Bardem while Amy Adams looks on, it’s hard not to get your freak on.

headline: Toasting an Oscar Win, Hoping for Greater Rights
text: WEST ORANGE, N.J.  It was part Oscar party and part civil rights rally.

headline: Studios Are Trying to Stop DVDs From Fading to Black
text: A winner has finally been declared in Hollywood’s high-definition DVD war. So why isn’t there more cheering?

headline: It’s All About Him
text: Last October, a reporter asked Barack Obama why he had stopped wearing the American flag lapel pin that he, like many other public officials, had been sporting since soon after Sept. 11. Obama could have responded that his new-found fashion minimalism was no big deal. What matters, obviously, is what you believe and do, not what you wear.

headline: Fire Officials Tackle Challenges of High-Rise Blazes
text: In the smoky caldron of a high-rise fire, it is the firefighter’s worst nightmare: a door left ajar, a window that suddenly breaks under intense heat and a blast of wind.

headline: Network of TVs Talks to Cellphones and Trades Clips for Advertising
text: A LITTLE-KNOWN private company, Akoo International, is setting up a network of digital screens that can send and receive messages from cellphones. The company aims to transform mobile devices into universal remote controls that can select on-demand content from big-screen TVs in airports, bars and restaurants.

headline: Mother Is Held in L.I. Slaying of 3 Children
text: A Long Island woman described as emotionally disturbed and afraid of losing custody of her children called the police on Sunday and led officers into a blood-spattered bedroom where her young daughter and two small sons lay slain on a bed, investigators said.

headline: Deliveryman Shot Dead in Argument on the East Side
text: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot on a Midtown street Sunday morning, the police said. The killing occurred just two blocks from his workplace, a company that copies and prints legal documents.

headline: Locking in Viewers to Watch the Commercials
text: Looking to strike a blow against the proliferation of digital video recorders, the ABC network, its affiliated broadcast stations, and Cox Communications’ cable systems are establishing an on-demand video service that would allow viewers to watch ABC shows like “Lost” and “Desperate Housewives” any time they choose.

headline: A Beef Scandal of Our Own Making
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sex in the Cities
text: WASHINGTON

headline: F.C.C. to Act on Delaying of Broadband Traffic
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The head of the Federal Communications Commission and other senior officials said on Monday that they were considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from discriminating against content providers as the broadband companies go about managing heavy Internet traffic that they say is clogging their networks.

headline: Fewer Youths Jump Behind the Wheel at 16
text: DETROIT  For generations, driver’s licenses have been tickets to freedom for America’s 16-year-olds, prompting many to line up at motor vehicle offices the day they were eligible to apply.

headline: Respite for Alicia Keys
text: The Grammy Award-winning singer Alicia Keys, below, ordered by doctors to give her voice a rest, postponed concerts on Monday in Glasgow and Tuesday in Manchester, England, The Associated Press reported. Her publicity representative, Patti Webster, said Ms. Keys had laryngitis. The dates are to be rescheduled.

headline: Slow Day Can’t Keep Angler From Title
text: GREENVILLE, S.C.  The spectator and media boats were starting to gather behind Alton Jones just after noon here Sunday as he started to build a seemingly insurmountable lead in the Bassmasters Classic. He was tucked in at a spot on Lake Hartwell the locals call Party Island, and camera shutters clicked and an ESPN broadcast crew bobbed in the water 75 yards away from where he was throwing his bait.

headline: A Battle of Legal Briefs Rages Over ’07 Nigerian Vote
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan  Just as Kenya’s electoral crisis eases, a battle is brewing over a deeply flawed and highly contested election in another fractious, ethnically and religiously divided African nation, Nigeria.

headline: Poles Apart on Online-Video Habits
text: The gulf between casual and heavy consumers of online video is startlingly wide, according to figures released in mid-February. Among people who watch at least some online video each month  from short clips on YouTube to full-length programs on NBC.com and the like  the highest-consuming fifth watches more than 140 times as much as the lower half.

headline: On the Internet, Everyone Can Hear You Complain
text: A San Francisco start-up called Get Satisfaction is the latest online ombudsman to try to mediate customer service complaints.

headline: Actress Playing Piaf Wins French Prize
text: For her portrayal of Édith Piaf in “La Vie en Rose,” Marion Cotillard won the César for best actress when the French equivalent of the Academy Awards were announced on Friday in Paris, Reuters reported. The prize for best actor went to Mathieu Amalric for his performance as a man crippled by a stroke and able to communicate only by blinking an eyelid in “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly.” (Mr. Amalric was in Panama, playing the villain in the next James Bond film.) The directing award went to Abdellatif Kechiche, whose film “La Graine et le Mulet” (“The Secret of the Grain”), about an elderly shipyard worker who dreams of establishing a couscous restaurant, took best film.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Iraq Troop Level to Remain Elevated
text: WASHINGTON (AP)  The Defense Department is projecting that when the U.S. troop buildup in Iraq ends in July, there will be about 8,000 more troops on the ground than when it began in January 2007, a senior general said Monday.

headline: Distrust of McCain Lingers Over ’05 Deal on Judges
text: WASHINGTON  Back in 2005, Senator John McCain of Arizona and fellow members of the so-called Gang of 14 were hailed as heroes in some quarters when they fashioned an unusual pact that averted a Senate vote on banning filibusters against judicial nominees.

headline: Spitzer and Aide Differ on Presidential Race, but ‘It’s a Free Country’
text: ALBANY  Gov. Eliot Spitzer has endorsed Hillary Clinton, but one of his closest aides and friends, Lloyd Constantine, is solidly in Barack Obama’s corner.

headline: Pfizer to End Lipitor Campaign by Jarvik
text: Under criticism that its ads are misleading, Pfizer said Monday it would cancel a long-running advertising campaign using the artificial heart pioneer Dr. Robert Jarvik as a spokesman for its cholesterol drug Lipitor.

headline: Holocaust Classes Are Seldom Easy on Children
text: When President Nicolas Sarkozy mandated recently that every French fifth grader would learn the life story of a French child who died at the hands of the Nazis, the proposal didn’t exactly generate the overwhelming gratitude he might have expected from Holocaust educators in his country.

headline: Justices Take Vehicle-Search Case
text: WASHINGTON  A seemingly routine drug arrest in Tucson, Ariz., will be reviewed by the Supreme Court to clarify the circumstances in which police officers who do not have a warrant can search the vehicle of a person who is under arrest.

headline: Book Title Search Yields Weird Works
text: The polls are open in the annual balloting for the Diagram Prize, honoring the world’s oddest book title, Agence France-Presse reported. Conducted by The Bookseller, a British trade magazine, the vote at www.thebookseller.com asks participants to choose from six mostly nonfiction titles on the shortlist, culled from titles submitted by publishers, bookstore workers and librarians around the world. The nominees are “I Was Tortured by the Pygmy Love Queen” by Jasper McCutcheon; “How to Write a How to Write Book” by Brian Paddock; “Are Women Human? And Other International Dialogues” by Catharine A. MacKinnon; “Cheese Problems Solved” edited by P. L. H. McSweeney; “If You Want Closure in Your Relationship, Start With Your Legs” by Big Boom; and “People Who Mattered in Southend and Beyond: From King Canute to Doctor Feelgood” by Dee Gordon. The winner is to be announced on March 28. The prize has been offered since 1978, when the winner was “Proceedings of the Second International Workshop on Nude Mice.”

headline: For Rangers, Five Goals and a Little Levity
text: When the Rangers’ captain, Jaromir Jagr, skated in for a picturesque goal Sunday night, drawing Florida goalie Tomas Vokoun out of his net and calmly sliding a backhand shot behind him, it was a snapshot of Jagr at his best, spectacular because it has happened so rarely this season.

headline: Blogger, Sans Pajamas, Rakes Muck and a Prize
text: Of the many landmarks along a journalist’s career, two are among those that stand out: winning an award and making the government back down. Last week, Joshua Micah Marshall achieved both.

headline: A Night With Stars of Phone and Rap
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  “T-Pain! Seventeen million ring tones later!”

headline: Nader to Run, Citing Events of 2004 Race
text: When Ralph Nader ran as a third-party candidate in 2000 and drew 96,837 votes in Florida, he was widely derided by Democrats, who saw him as a spoiler who siphoned crucial votes from Al Gore and tipped the election to George W. Bush. When he ran again in 2004, Democrats in many states tried to keep him off their ballots.

headline: Biofuel, Partly From Nuts, Is Tested on an Airline Flight
text: Virgin Atlantic Airways, the British carrier controlled by Richard Branson, tested a jumbo jet on Sunday that was partly powered by a biofuel made from babassu nuts and coconut oil, a first for a commercial aircraft.

headline: Faulting UBS for Losses in Bad Debt, Bank Is to Sue
text: LONDON  HSH Nordbank, a state-controlled German bank, said Sunday that it planned to sue the Swiss bank UBS over a portfolio of complex debt products, which it contends that UBS improperly sold and mismanaged.

headline: Got a Problem? Ask the Super
text: AS the race for the Democratic presidential nomination nears its end and attention turns to the role of so-called superdelegates in choosing the nominee, it is instructive to look at why my party created this class of delegates.

headline: Countrywide Puts an End to Ski Junket
text: The weather forecast may call for snow and good skiing conditions in Avon, Colo., on Monday. But no one at the luxury resort, near Vail, will be hitting the slopes  or eating $105 Kobe steaks  on Countrywide’s dime this week.

headline: The Sound of the ’70s From a Singer in Her 20s
text: It may seem paradoxical to describe the driving hard-rock sound of Grace Potter and the Nocturnals as comfort music. But a sense of familiarity, of a time-honored ritual expertly and reverently re-enacted, is one of the attractions of this Vermont quartet, which played a 100-minute set at the Allen Room on Thursday evening as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.

headline: In Argentina, No Assistance From Region on Gas Needs
text: RIO DE JANEIRO  Brazil has declined to cede any natural gas shipments from Bolivia to Argentina, which is struggling to find more energy sources to help it avoid supply shortages that could derail its fast-growing economy.

headline: At Governors’ Meeting, a Vice Presidential Buzz
text: WASHINGTON  Energy policy, health care and highways were the top issues on the agenda of the National Governors Association here Sunday, but many governors were consumed with presidential politics, buzzing about the possibility that the next vice president would come from their ranks.

headline: Visa Plans $17 Billion Public Offering
text: Undaunted by recent turbulence in the financial markets, Visa Inc., the nation’s biggest credit-card network, said Monday that it would forge ahead with what would be the largest initial public stock offering in United States history.

headline: Leipheimer Wins Title, but Uphill Climb Awaits
text: PASADENA, Calif.  Levi Leipheimer and his Astana cycling team came to the Tour of California with multiple goals, including successfully defending Leipheimer’s title and trying to convince the organizers of the Tour de France and the Giro d’Italia that they made a mistake in excluding them from this year’s events.

headline: In Calm Before the Storm, an Opportunity to Regroup
text: Here’s a change that Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign really can believe in: There is no chance whatsoever that she will lose to Barack Obama this week.

headline: A Hazardous Afterlife
text: Americans have a voracious appetite for new technology, but it comes with a cost not included on the price tag: electronic waste is the fastest-growing part of the garbage stream. Much of the equipment contains toxic substances, like mercury, lead and cadmium. And once in landfills and incinerators, the poisons are on their way into soil, water tables and the air. The problem can be controlled, but only if everyone commits to recycling.

headline: In Painful Past, Hushed Worry About Obama
text: DALLAS  There is a hushed worry on the minds of many supporters of Senator Barack Obama, echoing in conversations from state to state, rally to rally: Will he be safe?

headline: Home Resales and Prices Decline
text: The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.

headline: A Clash of Titans, With Little Panache
text: Wladimir Klitschko has managed to bring some control to boxing’s heavyweight division, and set it back at the same time.

headline: Living With Danger, and Wondering How to Live Without It
text: NEWPORT, Ind.

headline: Liechtenstein’s Friendly Bankers
text: History records that the Liechtenstein family began purchasing the lands that now make up the tiny European principality in 1699 to secure a seat on the council of the Holy Roman Empire. It was several decades before any prince of Liechtenstein actually set foot in his fiefdom. That was the first use of the Alpine hideaway as an address of convenience for powerful Europeans.

headline: Pressure on Young Athletes
text: To the Editor:

headline: Douglas A. Fraser, 91, Union Chief Who Helped Chrysler, Is Dead
text: DETROIT  Douglas A. Fraser, who as president of the United Automobile Workers union agreed to concessions that helped the Chrysler Corporation avoid bankruptcy in the late 1970s, died late Saturday. He was 91.

headline: When Puppet and Puppeteer Switch Places
text: It’s not often that a piece makes you sit up straighter, wondering what it is exactly you are seeing, but these are the moments that lovers of the arts live for. And it happened on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam, which presented the first program of “Gene Pool,” a selection of offerings from 10 choreographers who all teach there.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
text: The organizers of Advertising Week, which takes place in New York each September, formed a “sister city” partnership with Moscow, where the first Advertising Jubilee is scheduled for Sept. 22-28, 2008. That week is also when the Advertising Week events in New York are planned to take place.

headline: Virginia and Vita, Still Linked After All These Years
text: Versatile though she is as an actor, Eileen Atkins might have built an entire career around her sideline: writing and performing pieces inspired by Virginia Woolf, like the one-woman show “A Room of One’s Own.” Her perceptive play “Vita & Virginia” deftly weaves the letters and diaries of Virginia Woolf and Vita Sackville-West into the story of the friendship  improbable, briefly physical and emotionally enduring  between the aloof literary genius Virginia and the aristocratic yet middle-brow novelist and poet Vita.

headline: ‘Vantage Point’ Looks at Substantial Income
text: “Vantage Point,” the gimmicky thriller that examines and re-examines the shooting of an American president from witnesses’ differing angles, took over the No. 1 ranking at North American box offices in its debut weekend. Starring Dennis Quaid, Forest Whitaker, Matthew Fox and Sigourney Weaver, the Columbia Pictures release drew an estimated $24 million, according to the tracking company Media by Numbers. Each of the previous weekend’s top films slipped a notch. “Jumper” (Fox) dropped to second place on a gross of $12.65 million, just ahead of “The Spiderwick Chronicles” (Fox and Nickelodeon) with $12.6 million. Fourth place went to “Step Up 2 the Streets” (Buena Vista), which took in $9.7 million. The No. 5 film was “Fool’s Gold” (Warner Brothers), with $6.2 million. “Juno” (Fox Searchlight) passed the $130 million mark in its 12th week in release, and “The Counterfeiters” (Sony Pictures Classics) led the competition in its debut by taking in an average of $12,559 on each of the eight screens where it played. “Vantage Point,” by comparison, averaged $7,621 a screen.

headline: Bank’s Suit May Hurt Deal for Clear Channel Unit
text: Another buyout is in danger of collapsing  but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

headline: Cink Is No Match for Woods. Right Now, Nobody Is.
text: MARANA, Ariz.  Tiger Woods scorched the high desert Sunday, roaring like a wildfire across the Gallery Club at Dove Mountain with a phenomenal display of golf, incinerating Stewart Cink, winning the Accenture Match Play Championship and setting his sights on higher ground.

headline: New CDs
text: JANET JACKSON “Discipline” (Island Def Jam)

headline: Game Maker in $2 Billion Bid for Rival
text: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for rival Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, a deal that would further a wave of consolidation in the rapidly growing industry.

headline: Raptors Dominate Knicks From Every Angle
text: TORONTO  The Knicks had big-man problems again Sunday night  at both ends of the court, on both benches, in the lane and 24 feet from the basket. They also had problems with small- and medium-size men, and just about everyone wearing a white Toronto Raptors jersey.

headline: The Red (Can’t Go Wrong) and the Black (Sober Is So 2008)
text: HOLLYWOOD  The movie industry must have woken up from the writers’ strike with a rotten hangover, unable to even think about frivolous things like parties and frocks. It was such a buzz kill that quite a few of the actors on the red carpet at the Academy Awards looked as if they either couldn’t be bothered with fashion this year  so not superficial were they  or had dressed in the dark on a rainy Sunday afternoon.

headline: Americans Change Faiths at Rising Rate, Report Finds
text: WASHINGTON  More than a quarter of adult Americans have left the faith of their childhood to join another religion or no religion, according to a new survey of religious affiliation by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

headline: A Tale of Race and Family and a $10,000 Question
text: “A Raisin in the Sun,” which plays Monday night on ABC, is a cleanser for selves soiled by a thousand “Millionaire Matchmakers.” It is a noble enterprise never dulled by its good intentions. Starring core members of the cast of the 2004 Broadway revival of Lorraine Hansberry’s 1959 play, the television adaptation offers polish and feeling, grievance and gut. It moves and it sings, even if the gifted Broadway musical star Audra McDonald, who appears as Ruth Younger, doesn’t ever actually get to hit a note.

headline: Golden Raspberries for Murphy and Lohan
text: Question: When are the winners losers? Answer: When the prize is the Golden Raspberry Awards, or Razzies. Eddie Murphy, top left and right, and Lindsay Lohan, above, were the big winner-losers when the Razzies founder, John Wilson,  presided over the annual awards ceremony on Saturday at a magic shop in Santa Monica, Calif., The Associated Press reported. Ms. Lohan, who played a double role in “I Know Who Killed Me,” won two worst-actress trophies for that film, which received a record eight Razzies, including worst picture. Mr. Murphy amassed three Razzies as worst actor, supporting actor and supporting actress for the comedy “Norbit.”

headline: The Skinny on the Mets’ New Reliever? Great Changeup, Bad Luck
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  His name is Matt Wise. Some people know him as Wiser, but that is a little boring. In Milwaukee, his former teammates dubbed him Woody because of his spooky resemblance to that character from the movie “Toy Story.” A few years ago, when he played with the Angels, a few of his friends started calling him Skeletor.

headline: N.C.A.A. Isn’t Allowing Athletes to Be Regular Students
text: Los Angeles

headline: Huskers’ New Coach Promises to Heed Program’s Old Ways
text: GRAND ISLAND, Neb.  It did not matter that it was 10 degrees outside, that they were missing work, that the Cornhuskers’ season opener was still six months away. The people of central Nebraska had come to see two of the most important men in the state. They already knew  and loved  Tom Osborne, the iconic former football coach, a three-term United States representative and the current athletic director.

headline: ‘Academy’ Award for Will Smith
text: Will Smith has won an academy award  the first Cadet Choice Movie Award, bestowed by the cadets of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y. The accolade honors a fictional screen character who best personifies West Point leadership qualities. Mr. Smith, who received 27 percent of 2,200 online votes, was chosen for his portrayal of the Army virologist Robert Neville in “I Am Legend,” about a zombie-making virus that devastates Manhattan.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 40 at Iraq Highway Rest Stop
text: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Sunday attacked a crowd of Shiite pilgrims heading toward the city of Karbala to visit the Shrine of Imam Hussein, killing at least 40 people and wounding at least 100, Iraqi officials said. The American military said that at least 60 people had been wounded.

headline: Chinese Submarine Fleet Is Growing, Analysts Say
text: BEIJING  Several recent events, from an eagle-eyed spotting of an image on Google Earth to an overt military delivery from Russia, suggest that China is continuing its rapid expansion of a submarine fleet that would be particularly useful in a conflict with the United States over Taiwan, analysts and military officials said.

headline: Ray Wu, 79, a Genetic Transformer of Crops, Is Dead
text: Ray Wu, a biochemist and genetic engineer who helped lead research at Cornell University on genetically modifying rice and other crops to better withstand environmental stresses, died on Feb. 10 in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 79.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Headed for Korea, Orchestra Gets Tips
text: BEIJING  Anti-American posters have become hard to find on the streets of Pyongyang, North Korea. The news media there have been presenting instructional pieces on Western orchestras. Officials in that isolated and poor nation are ready to play good hosts.

headline: ‘No Country for Old Men’ Wins Oscar Tug of War
text: HOLLYWOOD  “No Country for Old Men,” Joel and Ethan Coen’s chilling confrontation of a desperate man with a relentless killer, won the Academy Award for best picture on Sunday night, providing a more-than-satisfying ending for the makers of a film that many believed lacked one.

headline: Serbian Rage in Kosovo: Last Gasp or First Breath?
text: BELGRADE, Serbia  Nationalist hooligans may have been behind the burning of the United States Embassy here, but the feelings of anger, sorrow and betrayal over the loss of Kosovo cut across all segments of Serbian society.

headline: Rising Inflation Creates Unease in Middle East
text: AMMAN, Jordan  Even as it enriches Arab rulers, the recent oil-price boom is helping to fuel an extraordinary rise in the cost of food and other basic goods that is squeezing this region’s middle class and setting off strikes, demonstrations and occasional riots from Morocco to the Persian Gulf.

headline: Premieres Range in Palette From Balkans to Argentina
text: When writing “... hold me, neighbor, in this storm...,” Aleksandra Vrebalov, a Serbian composer living in New York City, was inspired by the musical fusion of diverse cultures in the Balkans, artistic marriages that thrive in a region long troubled by ethnic intolerance.

headline: Eclectic Public-Radio Show Has Found Its Voice
text: Riding the C train this month just after his move to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, from Atlanta, Terrance McKnight found himself in a car with a testifying Christian. Some New Yorkers would have retreated to a newspaper or an iPod; he whipped out his cellphone to record her mesmerizing lyrical cadences. He heard music there.

headline: An Article Brings Sharp Responses From Russians
text: MOSCOW  Some readers called it blatant propaganda from the West. Others viewed it as a depressing exposé that rang true. A third group said the facts did not matter, outsiders simply had no right to train a critical eye on their country.

headline: Big Weekend Gives Zito Hope for the Derby
text: The last Sunday in February was good to the trainer Nick Zito. His best 3-year-old made a successful return to the races and a second stringer won the year’s first major Kentucky Derby prep race. With less than seven weeks to go to the Derby, it appears that the Zito stable is ready to play a strong hand on the first Saturday in May.

headline: Economic Reports Scheduled for the Week
text: ECONOMIC SIGNALS Housing will lead off this week’s economic data, with existing-home sales for January (Monday) and new-home sales for January (Wednesday).

headline: Taking Blows From All Sides and Weighing When to Punch Back
text: LORAIN, Ohio  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois is getting the customary greeting that the political tribe accords to apparent front-runners: He has taken rhetorical mortar shots from all sides.

headline: New Jersey College Taking Div. III Play to a Higher Level
text: UNION, N.J.  On another frenzied night at Harwood Arena, the Kean University women’s basketball team looked again like a Division I opponent in Division III clothing.

headline: Yanks’ Quiet Bullpen Acquisition Impresses
text: TAMPA, Fla.  LaTroy Hawkins found a seat next to the veteran Bob Tewksbury on the Minnesota Twins’ bench in the top of the seventh inning on May 17, 1998.

headline: Shhhhh! Emotions at Work
text: Some pianists, when performing Schumann’s “Kinderszenen,” offer bold emotional contrasts, loudly evoking what seems like a disturbed childhood. But when Stephen Kovacevich played the work on Thursday, it felt as if he were whispering a bedtime story, inviting the audience to share memories almost too private to reveal.

headline: At Cuba Helm, Castro Brother Stays the Course
text: HAVANA  Raúl Castro, who has labored in the shadow of his brother Fidel since the days of their revolution, became Cuba’s new president on Sunday, ending his brother’s 49-year rule and washing away hopes on this Communist island that a younger generation might take power.

headline: A Byline Strike in Honolulu Extends to Newspaper’s Blogs
text: Writers sometimes take breaks from the daily demands of posting to a blog, but they rarely, if ever, stop posting in the name of a protest.

headline: So Far, Time Has Been on Obama’s Side
text: WASHINGTON  They are certainly premature, but the postmortems are beginning to roll in on Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential campaign. Mrs. Clinton, looking ahead to Ohio and Texas next Tuesday, is clearly not yet out of the running. But should her candidacy ultimately fail, there will be a lot of blame to spread around.

headline: A Sparkling Bit of Defense From a Man on a Hot Streak
text: The most successful player at the Winter Sectional in Woodbridge, N.J., two weeks ago was Richard Ross of Highland Park, N.J. In five events he had three firsts and two seconds with six different partners. (In the Swiss Teams he played with three of his four teammates.)

headline: Footnotes
text: On Thursday the Metropolitan Museum of Art welcomed the millionth visitor to its New Greek and Roman Galleries, 10 months after their opening. The museum said the galleries, displaying Hellenistic, Etruscan, South Italian and Roman art, have attracted an average of 3,700 people a day, about 27 percent of the museum’s total attendance in that time. ... Off Broadway tickets costing $20 will be offered at box offices 20 minutes before the curtain rises at more than 20 shows from Monday through March 9 in the return of the 20at20 celebration. Information: www.offbroadway.com. ... Michel Legrand, above, winner of three Oscars and five Grammys and the composer of more than 200 film and television scores, as well as a pianist, vocalist, arranger and conductor, is to perform with the bassist Ron Carter and the drummer Lewis Nash at Birdland from Tuesday through Sunday. ... Barbara Cook will present “Love Is Good for Anything That Ails You,” a new program featuring songs by Irving Berlin, Rodgers & Hart, Burton Lane and Stephen Sondheim, among others, at the Café Carlyle from March 4 through April 12.

headline: Patriotism on the Sleeve, or in Disguise
text: Civility versus incivility might have been the subheading for a concert at the New York Society for Ethical Culture on Friday evening. For the latest in its American Voices series, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered four specimens of homegrown art.

headline: Money and the People’s Choices
text: A mind-boggling amount of money has already been spent on this year’s presidential election, and we haven’t even gotten to the conventions. The raising and doling out of lavish sums has been dispiriting to watch, a muddle of incompetence, avarice and special pleading, only vaguely restrained by the nation’s campaign finance laws. We sincerely hope that things improve before the general election onslaught.

headline: Constraining the Medicare Debate
text: The Bush administration has just made several proposals  some sensible, some not  to reform Medicare financing and spending. Unfortunately, the exercise is seriously hobbled by an ill-advised 2003 law that prevents consideration of some of the best and fairest ways to begin fixing Medicare.

headline: Moments to Savor After Battle for No. 1
text: MEMPHIS  Few people have a better perspective of the impact that Tennessee Coach Bruce Pearl has had in Knoxville, Tenn., than Chris Lofton.

headline: Prizes for ‘Juno’
text: “Juno,” the oh-so-popular little comedy about a pregnant 16-year-old, added to its accolades when it was named the best independent film of 2007 on Saturday at the Spirit Awards in Santa Monica, Calif., The Associated Press reported. Its star, Ellen Page, was chosen as best actress, and Diablo Cody, its writer, won for best first screenplay. Honors for best actor went to Philip Seymour Hoffman for his work in the sibling drama “The Savages.” The directing award went to Julian Schnabel for “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” based on the memoir of the French Elle magazine editor Jean-Dominique Bauby, who suffered a paralyzing stroke. The Spirit Awards, presented by the Film Independent organization, honors movies that cost less than $20 million and derive a significant part of their budget from outside the Hollywood studio system.

headline: Brown Ends Tuition for Lower-Income Students
text: Brown University is eliminating tuition for students whose parents earn less than $60,000, after decisions by fellow Ivy League universities to bolster financial aid as their endowments grow.

headline: In Mosaics, an Artist’s Lasting Impression
text: There is life in the hands of Manny Vega. With nothing more than a pair of pliers, thick fingers and boundless patience, he transforms thousands of stubby tiles of stone and glass into glimmering mosaic portraits of poets, drummers, mothers and sons. By the end of the workday, he has to plunge his numb, dust-covered hands into hot water to revive them.

headline: German Vote Confirms Shift of Political Center to the Left
text: FRANKFURT  The successor to the East German Communist Party won representation in the legislature of the northern city of Hamburg on Sunday, confirming a leftward political shift across Germany.

headline: A Falsetto for All Seasons
text: John Lloyd Young may have the role of a lifetime playing in the smash-hit Broadway musical “Jersey Boys.” But his New York concert debut at the Allen Room on Saturday evening as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series suggested that his career milestone could turn into a millstone.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,961 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Sunday:

headline: Adobe Blurs Line Between PC and Web
text: SAN FRANCISCO  On sabbatical in 2001 from Macromedia, Kevin Lynch, a software developer, was frustrated that he could not get to his Web data when he was off the Internet and annoyed that he could not get to his PC data when he was traveling.

headline: Small Coffee Roaster Gets ‘Ugly’ to Gain Recognition
text: Move over, Maria from “West Side Story.” A campaign for a coffee marketer is proclaiming that feeling pretty is overrated when it comes to your morning cup of joe.

headline: Leap Year Day Is Special, and Marketers Know It
text: According to folklore, leap year day is the choice moment for women who have no interest in waiting for the guy to pop the question.

headline: L.I. Duck Farms Struggle With Water Regulation
