text: MORICHES, N.Y.  Long coops, each housing ducks of a different age, hug the ground and form a courtyard at the entrance to the Jurgielewicz family property  believed to be the only major free-range duck farm in the United States.

headline: Montages, Wistful Flashbacks and a Few Lingering Clouds
text: Were they ready or rusty?

headline: Taking the Long Way, Cantwell Reaches the Top
text: BOSTON  Christian Cantwell won the highly anticipated men’s shot-put Sunday at the national indoor track and field championships. But his biggest victory was just getting here.

headline: Grandfather Is Accused in Baby’s Injury
text: A 6-month-old infant in the Bronx suffered critical injuries on Saturday when she was accidentally struck by the head of a golf club that snapped off while her grandfather was swinging the club during an argument, the police said.

headline: Texas Hispanics Face a Tough Choice in Primary
text: SAN ANTONIO  As recently as two weeks ago, Rudy Davila III, a pharmacist, was part of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s political firewall, the bloc of Hispanic voters from here to the border with Mexico whom she counted on to keep her presidential campaign from collapse. But the firewall is showing signs of cracking.

headline: Born Irish, but With Illegal Parents
text: DUBLIN  Cork-born and proud of it, George-Jordan Dimbo is top to toe the Irish lad. He studies Gaelic, eats rashers, plays hurling, prays to the saints, papers his walls with parochial school awards, and spends Saturdays at the telly watching Dustin the Turkey, a wisecracking puppet, mock the powerful.

headline: E-Newsletter Tracks Job Changes of Business Journalists
text: Late in 2006, a free e-mail newsletter sent by a company with an unusual name began to reach the overstuffed in-boxes of business reporters and editors, many of whom either skimmed it  or just deleted it.

headline: Electronic Arts Offers $2 Billion for Take-Two
text: Electronic Arts, the video gaming giant, made an unsolicited $2 billion bid on Sunday for rival Take-Two Interactive, publisher of the Grand Theft Auto franchise, a deal that would further a wave of consolidation in the rapidly growing industry.

headline: Go Vegetarian
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Minefield of Health Insurance
text: A little over a week ago, I asked Shifting Careers readers to tell me about their experiences with health insurance. I’ve been reading comments and e-mail about the sorry state of our health insurance system ever since.

headline: See You at the Hoedown
text: The Bagger is switching 10/20’s to the Governor’s Ball and will check in later with party blather. Thanks for all of you for checking in. Now go to bed.

headline: This Land: A Protector, Enemy and Provider
text: For Newport, Ind., the removal of chemical weapons agents is a blessing and a curse.

headline: Back in Business With the Combine
text: Our guest blogger of the week:

headline: The 2008 Academy Award Winners
text: This year's Oscars celebrated an international selection of talent.

headline: A Taste of Colombia, on Wheels
text: Rustic Colombian party buses called chivas are rolling through the streets of New York. Riders enjoy live music, drinks, and food while dancing the night away, on board.

headline: What's Happening with My Favorite Shows?
And the Winner Isn’t …
text: Our review of the hastily prepared, strike-challenged Oscars broadcast says its host, Jon Stewart, had “a few amusing lines but clearly didn’t have time to put together a polished and cogent monologue.” The main coverage notes that he riffed on the three-month walkout by writers:

headline: China Railway Cuts I.P.O. Amid Weakening Demand
text: China Railway Construction has cut the size of its initial public offering in Shanghai amid signs a slew of new shares entering the market is overwhelming investor demand.

headline: Aon Picks Up Arthur J. Gallagher Units
text: Aon said Friday that it has agreed to acquire Arthur J. Gallagher‘s reinsurance brokerage operations in the United States and Britain for $30 million, plus an additional sum based on the performance of the businesses in the coming year.

headline: UBS Denies Report on Chairman’s Term
text: UBS, Switzerland’s largest bank, on Sunday denied a newspaper report that its chairman, Marcel Ospel, would definitely leave after another year at the helm, but reiterated that his future after that period was undecided.

headline: 2 Ex-Marsh Officials Convicted on Antitrust Charge
text: Two former executives of Marsh, the insurance broker, were convicted Friday on an antitrust charge involving a bid-rigging case brought by New York State prosecutors.

headline: Rval Bidders Drop Pursuit of Biffa
text: Shares in Biffa , a British waste management company, fell more than 6 percent Monday after the company disclosed that all but one bidder for the business had dropped out.

headline: China Fund to Spend $10 Billion in Japan, Report Says
text: China’s increasingly aggressive sovereign wealth fund is poised to unleash a $10 billion investment spree in Japan and is initially expected to set its sights on the energy sector, The Times of London reported.

headline: Faulting UBS for Losses in Bad Debt, Bank Is to Sue
text: HSH Nordbank, a state-controlled German bank, said Sunday that it planned to sue the Swiss bank UBS over a portfolio of complex debt products it contends were mismanaged and improperly sold by UBS.

headline: Offers for Morgan Stanley’s Stake in China Capital Said to Be Cut
text: Three suitors vying for Morgan Stanley‘s stake in China International Capital Corporation have cut the value of their offers, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Unexpected Retirement at the Top of Vanguard
text: The Vanguard Group, a fund manager known for its low-cost portfolios, surprised the industry on Friday when it announced that its chief executive, John J. Brennan, would step down.

headline: Microsoft Announces $3 Million Fund for Health Care Applications
text: Got a good idea for a health care application? If so, you could get as much as $500,000 in funding from Microsoft.

headline: T Magazine’s Oscars Wins
text: Congratulations to Tilda Swinton and Marion Cotillard, who won top honors at last night’s Academy Awards. Both ladies played leading roles on the cover of T Magazine and we couldn’t be more proud of them. Ms. Cotillard won best actress for “La Vie en Rose” and Ms. Swinton’s role as a corporate climber in “Michael Clayton” paid off. Get caught up on Hollywood’s new royalty: read T’s profiles of this year’s  best actress and best supporting actress.

headline: A Capitalist Jolt for Charity
text: Philanthropies, discovering that for-profit status and financing can be a useful tool, are changing their spots and making use of some of capitalism’s virtues, The New York Times reports.

headline: Royal Bank of Canada Scoops Up Phillips Hager for $1.35 Billion
text: Royal Bank of Canada has won one of Canada’s last remaining independent money managers with a 1.36 billion Canadian dollar ($1.35 billion) takeover bid for Phillips Hager & North Investment Management.

headline: United Said to Mull Options as Delta-Northwest Talks Drag On
text: United Airlines is pondering its strategic options as stalled talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines threaten other linkups, including a potential tie-up between United and Continental Airlines, The Chicago Tribune reported.

headline: Temasek: The Rise of ‘Singapore Inc.’
text: Temasek Holdings, a decades-old Singaporean sovereign wealth fund, has its roots as a financial backer of domestic companies. In recent years, however, Temasek has moved aggressively, first within Southeast Asia, then Asia as a whole and finally to the West. It has acquired stakes in critical industries such as telecommunications and in companies that are household names, most recently Merrill Lynch.

headline: Countrywide Puts an End to Bankers’ Ski Junket
text: The weather forecast may call for snow and good skiing conditions in Avon, Colo., on Monday. But no one at the luxury resort, near Aspen, will be hitting the slopes – or eating $105 Kobe steaks – on Countrywide‘s dime this week.

headline: Maybe Microsoft Should Stalk Different Prey
text: Having exhausted its best ideas on how to deal with Google, Microsoft is now working its way down the list to dubious ones – like pursuing a hostile bid for Yahoo, says Randall Stross, writing in The New York Times.

headline: New Threat to Clear Channel Unit Sale
text: Another buyout is in danger of collapsing – but this time because one of the banks involved is suing its own client, the private equity firm trying to do the deal.

headline: Prince, O’Neal, Mozilo to Testify Before Congress on Pay
text: Two former Wall Street chieftains and the head of the nation’s largest home lender will testify next week before a congressional committee examining the link between executive pay and the mortgage crisis.

headline: Nymex-CME Deal May Be Announced in March, Report Says
text: A deal between the CME Group and The New York Mercantile Exchange to create a $40 billion futures trading powerhouse could be formally announced by early March, The New York Post reported.

headline: Cablevision Said to Hire Bear Stearns as Adviser
text: Cablevision has been quietly working with Bear Stearns on ways to enhance shareholder value, including putting a value on its Rainbow Media unit ahead of a possible sale and drawing up a list of targets for potential acquisitions, according to The New York Post.

headline: Messengers of Sound
text: The New York Philharmonic readies to make its historic journey to Pyongyang, North Korea.

headline: Citi Hedge Funds Get Credit Line
text: Citigroup said on Friday that it had provided a $500 million line of credit to its Falcon multistrategy fixed-income hedge funds, and as a result will move the funds’ $10 billion of assets and liabilities onto its balance sheet.

headline: T Party | Last Night’s Fete In Paris
text: (Stephane Feugere for The New York Times)

headline: Internal E-Mails
text: To: Mouth@Body.comFrom: Stomach@Body.com

headline: Sorting the Mortgage Victims From Those Who Volunteered
text: Over the last two decades, few industries have lobbied more ferociously or effectively than banks to get the government out of its business and to obtain freer rein for “financial innovation.”

headline: DN Capital Connects With iFamily
text: London’s DN Capital has provided $1.5 million in Series A funding to iFamily, a New York start-up whose Familybuilder application seeks to update the Web genealogy market by tapping into the power of social networks.

headline: Whack Museum
text: Tell us what’s going on in the photo above (use the comment link below). It’s the latest of the uncaptioned photos we’re posting each Monday. For your caption to be considered, follow the guidelines. Last week’s funniest captions are at right.

headline: RBS Shares Rise on Report of Potential Qatar Stake Purchase
text: Shares in the Royal Bank of Scotland jumped more than 5 percent on Monday on hope that Qatar’s sovereign wealth fund could take a stake and the expectation it will lift its dividend and post strong results this week.

headline: Glam Raises $85 Million in Funding
text: Glam Media, a network of fashion, style and entertainment Web sites, said Monday it had raised $65 million in new venture funding and $20 million in “revenue-based debt financing.” The latest financing round was led by Hubert Burda Media, a German publishing group, and includes GLG Partners, a publicly traded hedge-fund firm.

headline: Iraq Returns to the Stage in Congress
text: Congress returns from a week-long break today as senators anticipate the reappearance of an issue that has been relegated to the background so far in 2008 – the war in Iraq.

headline: Visa Offering Could Set U.S. Record
text: Behold the power of plastic: Visa said Monday that its highly anticipated stock sale could raise nearly $18.8 billion, which would make it the largest initial public offering in United States history. In an updated regulatory filing, the credit-card giant said it would sell as many as 446.6 million shares for an expected $37 to $42 per share.

headline: Not Too Shabby
text: The Bagger went 16-8 (a correction from PriceWaterhouseCoopers to the Bagger’s original report of 18-6) on his picks, not magnificent, but good enough in a complicated year. (You can see the winners here.)

headline: How Virtuous is Ed Begley Jr.?
text: My colleague Andy Revkin recently had a good chat with Ed Begley Jr. during a pedicab ride in New York, which you can watch at DotEarth. It was the perfect vehicle for discussing Mr. Begley’s famed green lifestyle, and it got me wondering: Is a pedicab really more virtuous environmentally than a taxi?

headline: Bonjour From Colette!
text: This week, The Moment is coming to you live from our new Paris headquarters, Colette. T Magazine has invaded Paris’s chicest boutique, where we’re showing off our films, flaunting our Web site, giving away our new women’s fashion issue and making friends with the cool crowd. If you’ve never been, Colette is more than a hip shop — it’s ground zero for Paris’s fashion-week scene. Imagine the coolest product-design store with well-curated fashion, books, the best in beauty products, and a subterranean bar that specializes in premium water. Can’t wrap your head around it? Stay tuned this week for more news from the shop and it’s owner, Sarah, who is our guest blogger.More On Colette:

headline: Brinks Plans Home-Security Spinoff
text: The Brinks Company, which has been under pressure from activist investors, said Monday it would spin off its home security unit into a separately traded company, Reuters reported.

headline: Covering Its Bets
text: What is an outfit to do when it is confronted by all manner of movies with no runaway hit? Why not spread the hardware around? When the Bagger went to the Governor’s Ball following the awards, he noticed that the Oscars were very evenly distributed about the room, as were the smiles.

headline: Studying the ‘Blowtorch Effect’ on Governors Island
text: The fearsome “blowtorch effect,” which has killed 11 people in New York City fires since 1980, has drawn firefighters and engineers to Governors Island in an expanding search across the nation for better ways to prevent or contain high-rise infernos, Thomas J. Lueck reports.

headline: Getty Images to Sell Itself for $2.4 Billion
text: Getty Images, the world’s biggest pictures and video distributor, agreed Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

headline: Where Do You Find Peace in New York?
text: Allan Ishac’s “New York’s 50 Best Places to Find Peace and Quiet,” a guidebook he started in 1991, offers a rich trove of suggestions for any New Yorker who wants to get away from — but perhaps not too far away from — the busy bustle of the city. But keeping the list fresh has required Mr. Ishac to make some editorial choices over the years. Earlier editions recommended the Russian and Turkish Baths, but then Mr. Ishac heard from readers who felt an uncomfortable vibe from other clients. Mr. Ishac also removed the Carapan Day Spa after a reader told him she had been yelled by the staff for complaining about construction noise. (The spa’s staff confirmed the customer’s account. The spa has since closed and is now a boutique health club called Clay.)

headline: Jerry Yang Calls on Sue Decker to Bolster Pitch
text: CORRECTION: See end.

headline: The Early Word: Nice No More
text: Democrats Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama exchanged niceties at a debate last week in Austin, Texas. Over the weekend, however, Mrs. Clinton took a decidedly different tone against Mr. Obama (calling his message one of “magic wands” and “celestial choirs”) and said she couldn’t wait to debate him in Ohio.

headline: The Skim
text: A quick hike through the Sunday (and a few non-Sunday) book review sections.

headline: Positive Signs For Spanish-Language ‘Mas Vale Tarde’
text: In December TV Decoder noted that Telemundo introduced a new late-night talk show, “Mas Vale Tarde con Alex Cambert.” In Sunday’s New York Times, Marc Weingarten notes that it is a “radical experiment” for Spanish-language television, and finds some encouraging signs for the show:

headline: Red Carpet at the Oscars
text: Despite the rain, the stars looked stunning at the 80th Academy Awards.

headline: Locking in Viewers to Watch the Commercials
text: Bill Carter reports in Monday’s Times:

headline: Pakistan Blamed for Worldwide YouTube Break
text: If all had gone according to plan, Pakistan would have been the latest government taking part in an unsettling trend from Brazil to Thailand: YouTube blocking. Unlike its predecessors, though, Pakistan also affected thousands of people beyond its borders.

headline: They Don’t Call Him ‘Angler’ for Nothing
text: He’s still only one man, but he’s also still two branches of government: Vice President Cheney is still clinging to the notion that his duties as president of the Senate make him part of the legislative branch as well as the executive branch, a Washington Post editorial notes.

headline: Take-Two Rejects Takeover Bid
text: CNBC's David Faber looks at Electronic Arts' unsolicited offer for the maker of Grand Theft Auto and what the game giant's options are.

headline: The Answer Man: Ordering As You Go
text: A reader recently wrote to ask me “what is going on” with restaurants that insist on diners “ordering everything from beginning to end at once?”

headline: ABC Promotes ‘Dancing’ and ‘Oprah’s Big Give’ During Oscars
text: To get a sense of which television shows are priorities for ABC, look no further than the house ads during the Academy Awards.

headline: The Return of the Mega-Offering
text: Consumers aren’t the only ones with a weakness for credit cards. Wall Street appears to have a nearly insatiable appetite for them, judging from the proposed size of Visa‘s initial public offering, which it described in a regulatory filing on Monday.

headline: Trial Starts for Detectives in Bell Shooting
text: Updated, 1:08 p.m. | Prosecutors and defense lawyers offered sharply differing accounts this morning of the November 2006 shooting that killed Sean Bell, as the trial of three New York City police detectives charged with killing Mr. Bell began in State Supreme Court in Queens.

headline: Why PATH Rides Are Free Today
text: One hundred years ago, a nickel bought admission to what President Theodore Roosevelt called the “greatest subaqueous tunnel in the world” and a “bigger undertaking than any Alpine tunnel which has yet been constructed.” He meant the Hudson & Manhattan Railroad, which linked New Jersey and New York for the first time on Feb. 25, 1908.Today, admission is free.

headline: New Obstacle to Clear Channel Deal
text: As a deal to sell Clear Channel's TV stations looked near, Wachovia now seeks to back out. CNBC's David Faber explains.

headline:
Talk to the Newsroom:
Graphics Director Steve Duenes
text: Steve Duenes, graphics director for The Times, is answering reader questions Feb. 25-29, 2008.

headline: At HBO, a Touch of Clairvoyance
text: HBO looked awfully smart on Sunday night. The premium cable channel bought the rights to the film “Taxi to the Dark Side” last week, just days before it received the Academy Award for best documentary feature.

headline: CNBC Video: Faber on Take-Two and EA
text: The unsolicited — and possibly hostile — deals keep on coming. The latest example hit Sunday when Electronic Arts, the video game giant, made a $2 billion offer for a rival, Take-Two Interactive Software. Take-Two, the maker of the wildly popular Grand Theft Auto series, quickly rebuffed the bid.

headline: Monday Morning Motorsports
text: IndyCar: It’s official. As reported last week, the Champ Car World Series will fold into the Indy Racing League this season. The I.R.L. schedule will expand from 16 races to 19, and it will include the Long Beach Grand Prix, which had been on the Champ Car calendar.

headline: Burgled in the ’Burg
text: What we’re looking at on the Web today…

headline: Securing Santana’s Signature
text: Collecting autographs is one of the essential parts of spring training. Fans carry baseballs, caps, pictures and jerseys and hope that their favorite players stop and sign them.

headline: Take-Two Rejects EA Bid
text: CNBC interviess Andrew Ross Sorkin of The Times about why Take-Two rejected Electronic Arts' unsolicited $2 billion offer.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Sautéed Scallops Stuffed With Basil
text: The sea scallop is one of the most perfect of nature’s convenience foods — because almost nothing cooks faster. They’re also in season through most of the year. Make sure you buy “dry” scallops — they should not be sitting in liquid (and they should smell like the sea).

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

headline: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Takes On Drug Ads
text: At a time when the drug industry is facing increasing scrutiny from Congress and the public, the cast of “Saturday Night Live” has weighed in with a hilarious spoof of television drug ads.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Messengers of Sound
text: The New York Philharmonic readies to make its historic journey to Pyongyang, North Korea.

headline: Obama Photo Becomes an Issue
text: The Clinton campaign struck back today at suggestions that it was behind the release of a photo of Senator Barack Obama in African garb. In an intriguing response to the Obama campaign’s charges, the Clinton campaign manager, Maggie Williams, turned the matter on its head: it essentially suggested the Obama campaign was deriding ethnic dress by making an issue of the photo. At the same time, it did not deny any role in distributing the photo. Here’s her statement:“Enough.

headline: Lessons From Hawaii
text: A larger and more spirited crowd of 23,000 turned out in Hawaii for the final two games of the Pan-Pacific Championship.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Atlantic Edition
text: Today, with the NHL stretch run heating up, we start a new feature here on Slap Shot at The Times: Hockey Night in Blogdom. Why? Because a newspaper or TV network has never been able to capture the passions of fans who avidly follow a professional sport and, after all, make the whole thing happen. And besides, who’s more passionate than hockey fans? So we’ll be asking specific questions of 30 independent bloggers, one for each league club, and through their fevered rantings they’ll tell us about the team they support and express their, ahem, core beliefs.

headline: So Far, Time Has Been on Obama’s Side
text: In his column today, Adam Nagourney writes, that “political analysts and journalists, in judging a candidacy gone bad, invariably focus on a campaign’s bad moves and wrong turns, with a dash of the requisite infighting among powerful staff aides and complaints by contributors. And the Clinton campaign, after starting off smoothly and with such self-assurance, provided a wealth of that: Wasted money, bad strategic calls on what states to contest, a message that failed to grasp how the mood of Democrats had changed and the questionable deployment of a certain former president.”But could even the best-operated campaign have done better against Mr. Obama?

headline: The Northeast Joins America
text: There is plenty of bad news in the existing home sales report, even if there was a slight uptick in the seasonally adjusted annual rate of single family sales. Actual sales — the monthly number before the seasonal adjustment — are the lowest in a decade for single family homes. For condos, where they have been keeping the data only since 1999, the figure is a record low.

headline: Video-Game Deals: Who’s Next?
text: In December, when Activision and Vivendi Games announced they were joining forces, Brent Thill, an analyst at Citigroup, said “we expect further industry consolidation.” He named Take-Two Interactive, which makes the popular video-game series Grand Theft Auto, as a potential takeover target.

headline: Doggy Gastronomy in Paris
text: Since I first smelled ginger and peanut butter pupcakes baking at Mon Bon Chien, I’ve been following the ongoing adventures of Hat Sternstein, an indefatiguable American baker whose grand ambition is to secure an exalted place for canine gastronomy in Paris.>By Richard Harbus

headline: Scandalous?
text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Yang: Microsoft Bid Was a “Galvanizing Event” for Yahoo
text: If Jerry Yang is upset that Microsoft bid to buy the company he co-founded 13 years ago, it didn’t prompt any angry words as he spoke Monday morning at the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s annual meeting in Phoenix. Rather, he talked about how the bid for Yahoo and the company’s frenzied search for a way to fend it off has been an exciting journey of self discovery.

headline: Did an Offense Turn Fireable on YouTube?
text: Did Ian Wilkinson, described in news accounts as a respected pilot nearing retirement, get fired for the attention drawn by the following video clip, and not the “Top Gun”-style stunt captured therein?

headline: Harry Dodge and Stanya Kahn
text: An excerpt from "Can't Swallow It, Can't Spit It Out."

headline: Sanchez Returns to the Mound
text: UPDATE: Duaner Sanchez, pitching in his first competitive situation since July 28, 2006, allowed two hits and struck out one while pitching the second inning of the Mets’ intrasquad game Monday. He threw 26 pitches.

headline: Calm Before the Storm
text: John Harwood talks about Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton's strategies for this week.

headline: Reviewing Jon Stewart’s Starring Role
text: “Political satirist Jon Stewart returned as Oscar host on Sunday with a slew of jokes about the bitter Hollywood writers’ strike that had threatened the show and the grim, violent themes of many of the films,” Reuters reports.

headline: Media Blackout Update: Pakistan and Alabama?
text: Governments that try to keep a firm grip on information flow in their countries, like the Kremlin, have used “technical problems” as an excuse to shut out unwelcome content on the Web and television. But could it have happened in the United States?

headline: Oscar Ratings Are Way Down
text: Early ratings for the 80th annual Academy Awards suggest the program may have attracted a significantly smaller audience than in previous years.

headline: For the Moment | Sarah from Colette
text: (Jessica Antola)

headline: The View From Paris, Part Two
text: For many years, the feeling among my friends was that you couldn’t get a bad meal in Paris, or even in France. That’s changed, of course. Chalk it up to globalization or anything else you like. But the feeling remained that the serious restaurants were still serious, and that, music and odd clothing aside, the French, especially Parisians, really understood good taste.

headline: Other Stops
text: More campaign-related opinion for Monday, Feb. 25:

headline: Putting 2-and-20 to the Auction Test
text: “Two and 20″ is a time-honored formula in high finance, and the 20 refers to the percentage of a venture capital or private equity fund’s profit that usually flows to the managers of that fund.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: A Reception in Sounds
text: Related Article: North Korea Welcomes New York Philharmonic

headline: Guzan Disappointed but Not Distraught
text: It was a long, long plane trip back to California from England for Brad Guzan late in January. The Chivas USA goalkeeper was oh-so-close to being up and gone to Aston Villa of the Premier League. Enter the bureaucrats.

headline: Visa: Bailing Out The Banks
text: Visa plans to go publc this spring, and the prospectus filed today indicates that it will get $15.6 billion (after deducting about $481 million in underwriting fees) from the offering if it is sold at $39.50 a share, the mid-point of its offering range.

headline: Analysts See More Pain for Citi
text: Analysts at Goldman Sachs said they expect additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major United States brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup forecast to record the highest write-down of about $12 billion.

headline: Missing ’60 Minutes’ In Alabama
text: “A controversy has been brewing on the Web since a ’60 Minutes’ segment failed to appear on a CBS affiliated TV station in Alabama last night,” sister blog The Lede reports. “The report covered a bitter flashpoint between Democrats and the Bush administration: the case of Don Siegelman, a former Democratic governor of Alabama who was jailed for corruption last June.” Read more…

headline: Waiting for the First Shoes to Drop
text: With the N.H.L. trading deadline lurking Tuesday, it seems odd that some teams would not have gotten started early making some of these moves. I know Trading Day is an unofficial holiday in Canada, but some people do opt to open presents on Christmas Eve too.

headline: The Bunker Goes Paperless
text: My wife is usually right about things. It just takes the bunker a little time to make his way around the block before reaching this conclusion. Mrs. Bunker has often asked me, once she has pushed her way around a stack of newspapers waiting to be read, “Couldn’t you read all this on the Web.”

headline: Net Neutrality Hearing: When Is an Internet Traffic Delay O.K.?
text: UPDATED

headline: You Decode: The 80th Annual Academy Awards
text: The 80th annual Academy Awards were produced under a palpable sense of pressure. The host, Jon Stewart, had little time to prepare material due to the writers’ strike, and the executive producer, Gil Cates, had lengthy clip reels ready in case the actors didn’t show up.

headline: Veterans Group Takes On McCain
text: VoteVets, a group of veterans from the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, plans to broadcast a cable television advertisement attacking Senator John McCain, the only veteran in the presidential race.

headline: Previous Forays Into Paris
text: The numerous comments on my first Paris post made me look back to a couple of my more recent pieces about Paris, both of which appeared in the Travel section of The Times. The first was a little foray into the world of steak frites. And the second, my favorite falafel.

headline: Poll: Obama Rises in Voter Popularity
text: Voters’ opinions of the top three presidential candidates have shifted significantly over the past two months, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: New Jersey’s Dilemma: Raise More Revenue or Cut Spending?
text: Governor Jon Corzine was once chief executive officer of Wall Street uberfirm Goldman, Sachs, but he seems to be having trouble working fiscal magic on New Jersey’s troubled finances. He also seems to be about to change his approach — under pressure from legislators and the public — from raising more revenue to cutting spending.

headline: Bright Lights at Night, Perhaps Not Such a Delight
text: A new study that shows women who live in areas with brighter nighttime illumination have an increased chance of developing breast cancer drew attention from the folks at City Room.

headline: Odd Man Out of Oscar Tribute
text: The Oscar’s ceremony last night included a feature honoring people who died in the past year, but one of the most prominent deaths in the past year was not included. But the Academy told TMZ.com said that the decision had nothing to do with the way Brad Renfro, 25, died (heroin overdose) or the quality of his work (“The Client,” “Apt Pupil”).

headline: Clinton Stresses Foreign Policy Credentials
text: WASHINGTON – Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sought to portray herself as the strongest candidate on foreign policy in a speech Monday afternoon, telling an audience that she was “tested and ready” to be commander in chief.

headline: Wondrous Cesspools
text: If you miss the old Times Square but don’t feel like sitting through “Taxi Driver” again, check out the expanded edition of “Tales of Times Square,” published this month by Feral House.

headline: Girardi Will Be Watching Closely
text: Sometimes, you can learn a lot about a manager or player from what might first seem like a throw-away line. After practice today we were talking with Joe Girardi, and he was asked how much he was looking forward to games.

headline: Cross-Culturalisms
text: The Bagger was very busy stuffing crab claws and shrimp into his baggie-lined pockets at the Governor’s Ball last night, but did actually have a notebook in there as well. He discovered that the growing cosmopolitanism of a traditionally ingrown industry is good for the business, filmgoers and the movies themselves.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Southeast Edition
text: Continuing with our roll call of independent bloggers, here are five representing the hot and humid Southeast Division. The teams appear in the order of their standing at the time we post this.

headline: A Vaccine for Boys to Help Girls?
text: As a parent of a school-age daughter, I haven’t decided what to think about the new cervical cancer vaccine. That’s why I was interested to learn the shot may soon be given to boys primarily to benefit girls.

headline: The Little Things
text: I had the chance to see Villanova’s 67-65 victory over UConn on Saturday. It was everything a Big East conference game should be. It featured two talented squads in a great atmosphere and the refs let the players play. Once a player got inside the paint he had to fend for himself.The refs weren’t bailing anyone out.

headline: An Alternate Theory of Nixzmary Brown’s Death
text: A veteran medical examiner testified in the Nixzmary Brown case today that Nixzmary was killed only by a blow to the head, and not by a combination of a blow, long-term child abuse and malnutrition that prosecutors have cited as the cause of her death.The testimony was elicited by the lawyer for Nixzmary’s stepfather, Cesar Rodriguez, in an effort to persuade the jury to focus only on one blow, rather than on the history of beatings to which Mr. Rodriguez has admitted.

headline: Charges Against TV Anchor Are Reduced
text: Alycia Lane, the former Philadelphia television news anchor who was arrested last December for punching a police officer in Manhattan, walked out of Criminal Court in Manhattan a free woman today. Prosecutors promised to drop the charges, Judge Dena E. Douglas told her, if she stayed out of trouble for six months and performed one day of community service.

headline: Altidore Skips Austria
text: The Red Bulls left Monday for an 11-day training camp in Salzburg, Austria, home of the team’s corporate parent, without one of their rising young stars.

headline: Bruno Says He’s Confident of Union’s Support
text: Brimming with confidence, the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, declared today that he still had the solid backing of one of the state’s most powerful labor unions — no matter what campaign finance reports might show.

headline: To Pave or Not to Pave?
text: John had warned us that the City of Anna Maria would require that our new driveway allow for sufficient rainwater drainage. But until last week, we hadn’t realized that the drainage solution would cost us $3,395 above the cost of building the driveway. That was the estimate from Adkins Contracting, a city-approved firm that installs drainage pipe.

headline: Paul Frère’s death
text: He was 91 years old, he lived an incredibly full life. He drove for Ferrari, raced in 11 Grand Prixs in the 1950s. He won the 24 Hours of Le Mans in 1960. He was cultivated, wrote much (in English and French) and continued testing cars and writing until he was in his 80s – in fact, he was still wickedly fast at 87, setting respectably fast laptimes in an Audi that would later win Le Mans.

headline: Rangers’ Pre-Deadline News on Mara: Ouch
text: The Rangers’ quest for help on defense just got a little more urgent with the news that defenseman Paul Mara will undergo surgery to repair facial fractures sustained in Saturday’s game against Buffalo.

headline: Satellite Shootdown Deemed ‘A Successful Mission’
text: The morning after the Pentagon slammed a missile into a dying satellite — an act deemed unprecedented at the outset — the face of the mission refrained from a full-on celebration, even though all signs pointed to one being in store.

headline: Soft Serve | Bubbly Vodka, Stripping for a New Scent, Dress a Clock in Neon
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.And the Oscar goes to… Soft Serve! We may be jealous of last night’s winners and their golden statuettes, but the Oscar swag is decidedly lackluster since going green: toe pillows, doggie GPS, and mini-kegs… Sparkling Vodka? Now there’s a cutting-edge beverage that should have made the cut… We’d like to be nominated for an opening night drink at The Standard New York. Andre Balazs’ to-be-completed hotel will have a bar on the 18th floor… Speaking of killer views, Agent Provocateur recently staged a scantily clad model in the windows at Selfridges for the launch of its new fragrance, aptly named “Strip”… Looking to draw the blinds? Magnetic curtains will chicly shield you from prying eyes… JFK was not the poster boy for discretion, but his Omega timepiece certainly had an understated elegance. Snatch up a limited edition commemorative replica for $8,250… New York Magazine’s Best Bets has some unconventional options for keeping time. Go for the old-school glam of a wood block LED or turn up the heat on an old clock and “bedeck it with glowing color”… Keep the colder elements and dirt off your car with wiperless windshields… If you’re a fan of getting dirty, Detergent T-shirts will only reveal their true intentions after you’ve thrown them in the wash… Soft Serve is throwing in the towel. Check out our fluffy goodness again tomorrow.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Pacific Edition
text: Next we call on the bloggers of the deserts and the freeways, where, as Easterners drift off to slumber, the third period is just getting under way.

headline: Forsberg Headed Back to Avalanche
text: After his agent threw cold water on the idea of a comeback just last week, Peter Forsberg has decided to return to the Colorado Avalanche for the rest of the season.

headline: Answers About Nature in New York
text: Following is a first set of answers from Leslie Day, the author of “Field Guide to the Natural World of New York City” (Johns Hopkins University Press, 2007), who is taking questions from readers through Feb. 29.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Scenes from Pyongyang
text: Slide Show

headline: 80th Oscars Officially Lowest-Rated Ever
text: Ratings for Sunday night’s Oscar presentations were the lowest ever, according to preliminary Nielsen figures, and down nearly 20 percent from last year’s broadcast of the event.

headline: Is the New York Accent Disappearing?
text: Writing in amNewYork today, Rolando Pujol takes a fascinating look at “the New York accent” and concludes that the accent, while subject to the forces of homogenization, is alive and, if not well, then at least evolving. (And most experts do not think it varies by borough or neighborhood.)

headline: About That Raise You’re Not Getting . . .
text: For most Americans, paychecks are shrinking, as the graph below shows.

headline: Taking Down the Fourth Wall
text: I urge anyone following this discussion to give some close attention to our readers’ comments. We’re incredibly lucky to have attracted an accomplished crew of actors, directors, screenwriters and playwrights — on top of all the other dedicated, careful readers who keep us in business. I’m highlighting some of the comments that struck me below. But all of them are worth reading.

headline: Weiner Expands Middle-Class Themes
text: Representative Anthony D. Weiner continued hammering away today at his theme of making New York City a more hospitable place for the middle class, emphasizing the theme that is likely to guide his run for the Democratic nomination for mayor next year.

headline: Rescuing the Dogs of War
text: Operation Baghdad Pups brought two dogs who were rescued in Baghdad by American soldiers to Kennedy International Airport this past weekend. The two dogs, Liberty and K-Pot, were escorted from Iraq by Terri Crisp, a program manager with Operation Baghdad Pups, who had gone over to retrieve them.

headline: Dior: Can We Tease More?
text: You can’t smoke in the cafes anymore, the French president is married to a former model, and if the models at Dior had worn bigger wigs and hair pieces, they would have tipped over and broken a nail. France–or, anyway, French fashion–seems confused. Coco Rocha motored down the runway at Dior today like a little tractor cutting through a snow drift. Her teased hair and painted eye lids looked that heavy. She had to manage the whole thing, along with her gown. The press notes to John Galliano’s show, taking a line from a Dior press statement in 1961, said, “Never forget the woman.”

headline: Times Election Fight
text: The hedge funds seeking to elect directors at The New York Times Company were buying shares until the last minute, as I speculated a few days ago. They now have 19 percent of the publicly traded Class A shares, according to their latest S.E.C. filing.

headline: Lessig Decides Against Run for Congress at Internet Speed
text: Just like any good Web story, this one took just five days to go from tantalizing to nothing more than that. Silicon Valley will not be represented by an Internet icon in the House of Representatives, not for a couple of years anyway.

headline: Some Big Love
text: I love to see a big man creating shots for his teammates. It’s the ultimate unselfish play. When guards make a fancy pass they get an assist, but if a big man sets a monstrous screen the only satisfaction he gets is the crunch of a guard crumbling to the floor.

headline: New Times/CBS Poll: Obama More Likely to Beat McCain
text: The latest survey of voters nationwide by The Times and CBS News has just been released.

headline: Live From New York, an Endorsement for Clinton
J.C. Penney Launches American Living
text: Scenes from an idealized America in J.C. Penney's new line  of products.

headline: Barack Obama's No J.F.K.
text: David Frum of the American Enterprise Institute and John Judis of The New Republic debate the Obama-Kennedy analogy.

headline: Another Day, Another Ditch
text: Every once in a while, the Democratic primary campaign pitches into the most curious ditches. So much of Monday was spent talking, behind the scenes and through surrogates, about a sort of costume party.

headline: Rocco DiSpirito for Bertolli
text: A TV chef plugs a contest on what it takes to assemble a  romantic night in.

headline: Ford Promotes 'New Beginnings'
text: Ford's videos aim to highlight work opportunities after Ford and dispel workers' potential fears of venturing out again in search of a new career.

headline: Last-Minute Ballot Ruling in Upstate Senate Race
text: The Republican candidate in a closely contested special election for an open State Senate seat will also be listed on the ballot as a candidate for the Independence Party, following a state Court of Appeals ruling on Monday. In such a tight race, having an affiliation with the Independence Party — the state’s third-largest — could be one of several factors that helps tip the balance.

headline: Diane Von Furstenberg on Fashion
text: Von Furstenberg discusses her life and fashion in a spot  for American Express.

headline: Renzi Says He Won’t Resign
text: Representative Rick Renzi, the Arizona Republican who was indicted last week by a federal grand jury on 35 corruption charges, issued a statement on Monday saying that he would not resign despite signals from Republican leaders in Congress that they would welcome his swift departure.

headline: ‘John Kerry Smacking His Forehead’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link bleow):

headline: How to Pick the Ideal Reference
text: A few weeks ago, a friend and colleague whose company is looking for investors e-mailed me to ask if I’d be willing to be a reference for her. I didn’t hesitate to say yes. I have complete respect for the woman and even if we didn’t have any time to chat beforehand, I knew what I would say when the reference checker called. A few days ago, I got another request to be a reference — this one from a professional contact I barely know. I declined, trying to be as polite as possible.

headline: Google and the Undersea Cable
text: Google said Monday that it was part of a six-company consortium that would build a new $300 million high-capacity underwater fiber-optic cable linking the United States and Japan.

headline: Time to Count the Doughnuts
text: If your eyes glazed over at revelations that Hillary Rodham Clinton used $1,200 from her campaign war chest to splurge on Dunkin’ Donuts, that expense turns out to be just the icing on the cake.

headline: The Final Frontier
text: “Normally,” Jon Stewart noted Sunday night at the Oscars, “when you see a black man or a woman president, an asteroid is about to hit the Statue of Liberty.”

headline: Our Exhausted Oceans
text: Heaps of abalone shells in Santa Barbara, Calif., from a 1920 postcard. (Census of Marine Life)

headline: Before They Vanish
text: Population and fishing are taking their toll on coral reefs.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Let Us Now Praise Minders — and Great Men
text: It’s Tuesday morning in the D.P.R.K., and this will be brief, because one of my minders, whom I’ll call Kim 1, is pressing me to leave for the bus. Supposed to be 9:30 a.m. “The program has changed,” he said. So it must be at 9. Things have been highly regimented here, with an emphasis on sticking to the schedule. It may be an effort at maintaining control. A diplomat with long experience in Pyongyang said officialdom here hates surprises, because they can be unpleasant.

headline: Lightning Trades Prospal, Agrees to Deal With Boyle
text: Versus is reporting that the Philadelphia Flyers have acquired forward Vaclav Prospal from the Tampa Bay Lightning for defenseman Alexandre Picard and a conditional pick in the 2009 draft.

headline: Dear Irrational Reader: Close the Door!
text: Dear Reader, don’t take this personally, but the data are in and you’re not looking very rational, at least not when it comes to closing doors.

headline: Spain ‘Must Sell’ Market Booming
text: With the market floundering, the foreclosure rate in Spain has more than doubled in recent years, according to industry estimates.

headline: Security Details
text: On the trail with Barack Obama and the Secret Service.

headline: Poll Shows Obama Is Seen as More Likely to Beat McCain
text: WASHINGTON  In the past two months, Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters, with especially strong support among men, and is now viewed by most Democrats as the candidate best able to defeat Senator John McCain, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Human Shadows on the Seas
text: In 1980, after college, I joined the crew of a sailboat partway through a circumnavigation of the globe. Becalmed and roasting one day during a 21-day crossing of the western Indian Ocean, several of us dived over the side. Within a few swimming strokes, the bobbing hull seemed a toy over my shoulder as I glanced back through my diving mask. Below me, my shadow and the boat’s dwindled to the vanishing point in the two-mile-deep water. Human activity seemed nothing when set against the sea itself.

headline: Patterns: If You Keep Your Cool, You May Heal Faster
text: People who have trouble controlling their temper may take longer to heal from an injury, a new study finds.

headline: Counting the Homeless to Help End Their Plight
text: NEW HAVEN  Looming over a shuttered nightclub by Interstate 91 is a billboard featuring fistfuls of cash and a brassy promise that Connecticut Lottery players could win $100,000 a year in perpetuity and be “Set for Life.”

headline: New York City to Help Doctors Track Patients’ Records Electronically
text: After two years of planning and a public investment of more than $60 million, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Monday that New York City was ready to equip doctors with computer software that can track patients’ medical records in order to provide better preventive care.

headline: Stephen Marlowe, 79, Detective Novelist, Dies
text: Stephen Marlowe, a prolific writer of popular fiction best known for his crime novels featuring the globe-trotting private eye Chester Drum, died on Friday in Williamsburg, Va. He was 79 and lived in Williamsburg.

headline: Where Science and Design Collide, a Few Weird Sights to Behold
text: In the drawing, a nude man and woman stand on either side of a wall. Each wears a plastic breathing mask that covers the nose and mouth; the masks are connected to air hoses that pass through the wall. The hoses attach to pouches at each other’s underarms and crotches.

headline: Dodd Endorses Obama for President
text: CLEVELAND, Ohio  Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a leading Democrat and an early candidate for the party’s presidential nomination, announced Tuesday that he was endorsing Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Lottery Numbers
As Inflation Rises, Home Values Slump, Data Show
text: Two worrisome trends for the economy  falling house prices and the rising cost of everything else  picked up speed in data reported on Tuesday, putting policy makers in an increasingly tough position.

headline: Pfizer to End Lipitor Ads by Jarvik
text: Under criticism that its ads are misleading, Pfizer said Monday that it would cancel a long-running advertising campaign using the artificial heart pioneer Robert Jarvik as a spokesman for its cholesterol drug Lipitor.

headline: Taliban Threatens Afghan Cellphone Companies
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  The Taliban have demanded that all four cellphone companies in Afghanistan cease operating at night or face attacks on their offices and communication towers, according to a statement released to journalists on Monday.

headline: A Twice-Told Tale of Addiction: By Father, by Son
text: David Sheff and his 25-year-old son, Nic, are so close these days, so much on the same wavelength, that they sometimes finish each other’s sentences. There was a time when they weren’t even speaking.

headline: The Advantages of Closing a Few Doors
text: The next time you’re juggling options  which friend to see, which house to buy, which career to pursue  try asking yourself this question: What would Xiang Yu do?

headline: Opening a Hornet’s Nest (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Golf in Retreat: Why the Bunker Mentality?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pieces of Texas Turn Primary Into a Puzzle
text: CRAWFORD, Tex.  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton issued her gunslinger’s invitation to Senator Barack Obama recently, challenging him to “meet me in Texas,” the question many people here asked was, Which one?

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend on Friday about “Cai Guo-Qiang: I Want to Believe,” at the Guggenheim Museum, misidentified the southern Chinese city where Mr. Cai was born and raised. It is Quanzhou, not Guangzhou.

headline: New Grand Jury Is Impaneled in L.I. Murders From 1988
text: RIVERHEAD, N.Y.  Almost 19 years after the murders of Seymour and Arlene Tankleff in their Belle Terre home, a new grand jury has been impaneled to determine who might have killed the Long Island couple, a prosecutor said.

headline: Court Considers Protecting Drug Makers From Lawsuits
text: WASHINGTON  Less than a week after issuing a sweeping ruling that bars most lawsuits against medical device makers, the Supreme Court heard arguments Monday in the first of two cases that could determine whether drug makers receive similar protection.

headline: Attention on Evidence Shifts to Testing for Fingerprints
text: One of the more intriguing elements in the confrontation between Roger Clemens and Brian McNamee has been whether the needles, syringes, gauze pads and vials that McNamee turned over to federal authorities contain Clemens’s DNA or traces of steroids or human growth hormone.

headline: Bush Cool to States’ Call for Public Works Projects
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush rebuffed appeals from the nation’s governors on Monday to increase spending on roads, bridges and other public works as a way to revive the economy.

headline: Yankees Open to Extension for Cashman
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Hank Steinbrenner, the Yankees’ senior vice president, said Monday that he was open to discussing a contract extension for General Manager Brian Cashman.

headline: Police Said to Have Assaulted Rights Lawyer in China
text: SHANGHAI  One of China’s best-known human rights lawyers has been repeatedly beaten by police officers outside his home here in recent days, according to his wife and associates.

headline: Mergers in a Time of Bears
text: Most mergers fail.

headline: Two Men Stabbed at Jewelry Outlet
text: Two men were stabbed on Monday at their Manhattan jewelry business by a business associate who claimed they owed him money, the police said.

headline: Students Return to an Altered Campus After Shootings
text: DeKALB, Ill.  Under a hard, gray sleet, students at Northern Illinois University trudged back to class on Monday for the first time since a gunman burst into a lecture hall on Feb. 14 and killed five students and himself.

headline: It Went By in a Blur: PATH’s 100th
text: You couldn’t miss the 100th anniversary of the New York City subway in 2004. There were speeches, banners, slogans, displays, events and a shelf full of books to mark the milestone for posterity: “Subways,” “A Century of Subways,” “Subwayland,” “Subway Memoirs,” “The Subway Pictures,” “Subway Style,” “The Subway and the City.”

headline: A Driving Force
text: Maybe he can’t help himself. If William Manchester is to be believed, Ralph Nader got a fair amount of his exasperating, nonstop, take-no-prisoners-style of proselytizing from his father, Nathra, who owned a restaurant and bakery in the factory town of Winsted, Conn.

headline: Station Says ‘60 Minutes’ Blackout Was Just Technical
text: A television station in Huntsville, Ala., offered viewers nothing but a black screen for 12 minutes Sunday night  at the exact time that the CBS News program “60 Minutes” was broadcasting a report about potential political skulduggery involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of the state.

headline: Democrats Mount New Attack on War Policies
text: WASHINGTON  Undeterred by President Bush and Senator John McCain’s proud talk of progress in Iraq, Congressional Democrats have begun mounting new lines of attack against the administration’s war policies.

headline: Body Discovered in Queens Blaze
text: A firefighters’ union official accused the Fire Department of a three-minute delay in sending enough trucks to a burning house where a Queens woman was found dead on Monday.

headline: Republican Gets Second Line in a Special Election Upstate
text: ALBANY  The Republican candidate in Tuesday’s hotly contested special election for a vacant State Senate seat will also be listed on the ballot as the candidate of the Independence Party, the state’s highest court ruled on Monday.

headline: A Little Help for His Friends
text: Congress is looking into the decision by the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher Christie, to hand former Attorney General John Ashcroft a hugely lucrative job monitoring a wayward company.

headline: F.C.C. Fines Fox
text: Putting pixels on body parts didn’t save Fox from the wrath of the Federal Communications Commission. The agency has rejected the network’s contention that an episode of the defunct reality program “Married to America” did not violate decency standards because female breasts and buttocks were pixelized during a raunchy bachelor party scene in 2003, Reuters reported. The commission said: “To be sure, the pixelation of the female strippers’ naked breasts and buttocks does render the material less explicit and graphic than it would have been in the absence of pixilation. However, the material is still sufficiently graphic and explicit to support an indecency ruling.” Fox disagreed. The commission, acting against only those stations subjected to complaints, fined 13 stations and affiliates $7,000 each. Last week it fined ABC stations and affiliates a total of $1.2 million for showing a woman’s bare buttock during an episode of “N.Y.P.D. Blue” in 2003. ABC paid but will appeal. The Supreme Court is expected to consider on Friday if it will hear the F.C.C.’s appeal of an appeals court decision that declared its rulings against fleeting profanities to be “arbitrary and capricious.”

headline: Ralph Nader: Going, Going, Not Gone
text: The real question about Ralph Nader’s political nadir is this: are we there yet? Once he was the hero of Americans who wanted safer automobiles, drugs, toys and food. Since then, Mr. Nader has been known for running and running and running  and now running again for president.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A front-page picture caption on Saturday with the “This Weekend” summary carried an erroneous credit in some editions. The photograph of a wounded soldier in Afghanistan was by Lynsey Addario for The New York Times, not by Joshua Lott.

headline: Beginning With the Unfamiliar, Then Concluding With the Ever-Present
text: To conservative ears, recitals like Markus Groh’s at the Frick Collection on Sunday can be said to taketh away, then giveth back. This young German pianist held the attention of the curious and the jaded for the first half of his program with 20th-century music by Erwin Schulhoff, Gyorgy Kurtag, Ligeti and Alberto Ginastera. The ubiquitous B minor Sonata of Liszt arrived after intermission almost as an apology for any inconvenience suffered earlier.

headline: Oscar Hangs His Head as Commercials Disappoint
text: FANS of advertising who watched the Academy Awards could be excused for wishing that Javier Bardem had come onstage to accept his Oscar for best supporting actor toting the stun gun his character wielded in “No Country for Old Men.”

headline: Now Boarding Business Class
text: For a long time, low-cost carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue Airways have had a reputation for catering to leisure travelers  in fact, half of Southwest’s passengers and 75 percent of JetBlue’s customers fit in that category.

headline: Yazoo Pumps, R.I.P.?
text: Stephen Johnson, the embattled career scientist who runs the Environmental Protection Agency, seems ready to defy Congress on an issue that his more politically connected predecessors ducked. Mr. Johnson has all but decided to cancel the Yazoo Pumps, a flood control scheme in the Mississippi Delta that is potentially the most environmentally destructive project undertaken by the Army Corps of Engineers at Congress’s request.

headline: In Boston, Mayor and Librarian Clash Over Control
text: BOSTON  If this city is known for both intellectual heft and political blood sport, the Boston Public Library, one of its proudest institutions, aligns itself strictly with the former. But in recent months, the august library has been at the center of some nasty political tussles.

headline: Justices Send Age Case to Lower Court
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to hand down a definitive ruling in an age-discrimination case from Kansas, declaring instead that the case must go back to federal district court for clarification.

headline: In Visit, Cellist’s Quest for Lost Chord to His Youth
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  For much of his 60 years, Valentin Hirsu has thought of those three Korean boys in his class.

headline: Tracking the Rise and Decline of Dust in the Western U.S.
text: The world is a dusty place. If you don’t believe that, just look under your bed. But it’s dusty on regional and global scales, too, largely because of soil erosion caused by winds.

headline: Nyc Marathon Registration Begins
text: Officials of the New York City Marathon started accepting lottery applications Monday for the Nov. 2 race on their Web site. Applications will be accepted until June 1 for those with a United States address and until May 1 for nonresidents and runners eligible for a guaranteed entry. The applications are being accepted online at ingnycmarathon.org. The entry fee for runners chosen in the lottery and those with guaranteed entries are $125 for New York Road Runners members, $155 for nonmembers and $210 for international entries.

headline: Getty Images Agrees to Be Acquired by a Private Equity Firm
text: Getty Images, the world’s biggest distributor of pictures and video, agreed on Monday to sell itself to the private equity firm Hellman & Friedman for $2.4 billion including debt.

headline: Max Raab, Maker of Fashion and Film, Dies at 81
text: Max L. Raab, whose apparel company helped extend the button-down preppy look of the early 1960s to women’s clothing and who then moved into the film industry as an executive producer of several mind-bending movies, including “A Clockwork Orange,” died Feb. 21 at his home in Philadelphia. He was 81.

headline: Perez Hilton Could Play New Role: A&R Man
text: LOS ANGELES  Mario Lavandeira, known to millions of fans as the gossip blogger Perez Hilton, has a habit of humiliating celebrities he dislikes by doodling explicit images across their photos on his Web site. But he has also long used perezhilton.com to rave about his favorite new music. And now the results of his effusive postings  “you will be foaming at the mouth!”  have attracted the notice of a major record label.

headline: Defense Casts Girl’s Injury as Sole Cause of Her Death
text: A veteran medical examiner testified on Monday that 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown died solely from a blow to the head  not from the blow combined with chronic abuse and malnutrition, as the prosecution contends.

headline: Knicks’ Curry Playing Less, Questioning More
text: Eddy Curry is not obsolete. He is sure of that much. Yes, the N.B.A. has changed in strange and wondrous ways, downsizing its centers and moving them away from the basket. Yes, Curry now looks like a throwback, with his mammoth frame and short-range skills.

headline: In Los Angeles, Oscar Statues Become a Popular Export
text: LOS ANGELES  The morning after the Academy Awards dawned here with a realization: There will be a lot of gold leaving Los Angeles in the next few days.

headline: Airline Says Crew Acted Appropriately Before Death
text: American Airlines officials on Monday disputed accounts by relatives of a woman who died aboard a flight from Haiti to New York on Friday. The airline said that oxygen canisters on the plane were full and that oxygen had been administered in a timely manner to the passenger after she had trouble breathing.

headline: Therapists and Therapy (3 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Tortuous Path That Led to Those Central Park Gates
text: How long did it take Christo and Jeanne-Claude to realize “The Gates”? Here’s a reminder: One of the four directors of “The Gates,” an HBO documentary about that saffron-hued extravaganza in Central Park, has been dead since 1987.

headline: Screening: Dialysis Can Lower Blood Sugar Readings
text: A common test to see how well diabetics control blood-sugar levels tends to give misleadingly good news when the patients are on hemodialysis, researchers say.

headline: Guilty Verdict for 5 in A.I.G. Case
text: Five former insurance executives were found guilty Monday of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.

headline: Is That Your Final Question?
text: Tonight, Hillary Clinton and Barack Obama will debate in Ohio. It will be the 20th debate, and possibly the last, of the Democratic presidential campaign. Is there anything left to ask? The Opinion section asked five experts to pose the questions that they feel have not been answered over the course of more than a year of campaigning. Here’s what they would ask the candidates if they were moderating tonight’s debate.

headline: Goalkeeper Stays in M.L.S., for Now
text: It was a long, long airborne trek back to California for Brad Guzan in late January. Guzan, an up-and-coming goalkeeper for Chivas USA and the United States national team, was oh-so-close to moving to Aston Villa of the English Premier League. Enter the bureaucrats.

headline: Thank You for the Coffee, Ma’am. Your Tip Is at the Stable.
text: WALLER, Tex.  As a widowed waitress struggling to make ends meet, A. D. Carrol has received some good tips over the years. Once in an airport V.I.P. club in San Francisco, stranded businessmen tipped her $600. In a Texas steak house, a happy patron left $500 on the table.

headline: The Right to Counsel, in the Right Situations
text: Zacarias Moussaoui would seem to have little to complain about. He is an admitted member of Al Qaeda. He has pleaded guilty to plotting to commit mass murder. He was tried in a federal court in Virginia before a judge who generally seemed attentive to his constitutional rights. And he was spared the death penalty.

headline: Midwest Hit by Winter Storm
text: A winter storm moved across the upper Midwest early Tuesday dropping snow, sleet and rain on the region and is expected to cause travel delays in the Northeast later in the day, particularly at airports.

headline: New Jersey Schools Told to Discard Suspect Beef
text: Nearly a quarter of New Jersey’s 615 school districts may have received beef unfit for human food from a California slaughterhouse through a federal school lunch assistance program, state agriculture officials said on Monday.

headline: New DVDs: Jean-Luc Godard
text: JEAN-LUC GODARD

headline: Justices Weigh if Cash Hidden Is Cash Laundered
text: WASHINGTON  In colloquial terms, “money laundering” means cleaning “dirty” money  the proceeds of a drug transaction, for example  by using it in a way that hides its origins and gives it the appearance of legitimate wealth.

headline: In Precise Movements, a Russian Sense of Drama
text: The Russian National Orchestra, with its young and energetic players, seemed like an upstart band when Mikhail Pletnev founded it in 1990, but he quickly established it as an important ensemble in the post-Soviet music world. The orchestra has also had a fruitful relationship with Vladimir Jurowski, the 35-year-old Russian firebrand who became its principal guest conductor in 2005.

headline: Mature Artist Celebrates Her Roots (and Flowering)
text: “When you perform music, something gets in your psyche,” the composer and pianist Joan Tower said before a concert at the Chelsea Art Museum on Saturday honoring her 70th birthday. It was the first of three events in the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble’s Second Helpings contemporary-music series exploring the influences of Ms. Tower, who concludes her 10th and last season as St. Luke’s composer in residence this year.

headline: For Crowds at Courthouse, Just Being There Is the Point
text: Monty Street was not a friend or relative of Sean Bell. He never even met Mr. Bell.

headline: Death Risk Found From Anemia Drugs
text: Widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson raise the risk of death among cancer patients by about 10 percent, according to a new analysis of previous clinical trials that was published Wednesday.

headline: Bid for Game Maker Seen as Effort to Buy Innovation
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Creating a video game costs around $20 million. So for $2 billion, Electronic Arts could develop 100 new titles.

headline: Selling Gold at I.M.F. to Rebuild Its Finances
text: WASHINGTON  For decades, the International Monetary Fund has played a pivotal role in rescuing insolvent countries and stabilizing the world economy. But after years of budget problems, the fund received approval on Monday from the Bush administration to sell gold bullion to stabilize its own shaky finances.

headline: Talking With Children About Sex and AIDS: At What Age to Start?
text: What age is the right age to have “the talk,” not just about where babies come from, but also about sex and AIDS?

headline: F.C.C. Weighing Limits on Slowing Web Traffic
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  The head of the Federal Communications Commission and other senior officials said on Monday that they were considering taking steps to discourage cable and telephone companies from delaying the downloads and uploads of heavy Internet users.

headline: Green Fuel (Literally) (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Florida Power Restored After Blackout
text: The power was restored to all but a few areas of South Florida on Tuesday afternoon, the utility company that supplies electricity to the region, Florida Power & Light said.

headline: Azerbaijan’s Progress
text: To the Editor:

headline: Blog Helps a Yankee Connect With Fans
text: TAMPA, Fla.  It was a month or so before the start of spring training, and Phil Hughes had no weekend plans. Hughes is 21 and single, a Californian living in Tampa, and he needed some advice.

headline: Russian Candidate Denounces Kosovo
text: MOSCOW  Dmitri A. Medvedev, Russia’s first deputy prime minister and the presumptive successor to President Vladimir V. Putin, on Monday committed the Kremlin to long-term support for Serbia against an independent Kosovo.

headline: California: No Candidacy for Internet Scholar
text: The Internet scholar Lawrence Lessig decided not to run for a vacant seat in the House of Representatives. Mr. Lessig, the founder of the Center for Internet and Society at Stanford University, had posted a Web video last week hinting of a run for California’s 12th Congressional District, which was held by Representative Tom Lantos, who died on Feb. 11. Mr. Lessig used the same medium to convey a different message Monday, saying that despite seeing an outpouring of support, he had also seen a poll showing him “losing in a big way” to the favored candidate, former State Senator Jackie Speier. Mr. Lessig said he would instead to try to change Congress from the outside. “Losing big in the first important battle is not an effective strategy,” Mr. Lessig said. “My running and losing big would do more harm than good.” The special election to replace Mr. Lantos is scheduled for April 8.

headline: Catching Up on Family Values
text: Members of Congress and state legislatures talk about family values. But unlike those in other developed countries, they have not done much to help workers with new babies or sick family members. The New Jersey Legislature is in position to become just the third state to address this problem.

headline: After Facing Accusations, News Anchor Walks Free
text: Alycia Lane, the former Philadelphia television news anchor who was arrested in December for punching a police officer in Manhattan, walked out of Criminal Court in Manhattan a free woman on Monday. Prosecutors promised to drop the charges, Judge Dena E. Douglas told her, if she stayed out of trouble for six months and performed one day of community service.

headline: Blast Kills Surgeon General of Pakistani Army
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A top Pakistani Army general was killed Monday when a suicide attacker approached his car at a traffic light in Rawalpindi and blew himself up, military officials said.

headline: California Creates Cabinet Post to Manage Volunteers
text: LOS ANGELES  California is a state with frequent natural disasters and vast numbers of people who want to help. But Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger says a recent oil spill in San Francisco Bay helped demonstrate that “volunteerism can be moved a notch.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Monday about Countrywide Financial’s decision to cancel a gathering of bankers at the Ritz-Carlton Bachelor Gulch ski resort in Avon, Colo., referred incorrectly to the resort’s location. It is near Vail, Colo., not Aspen.

headline: Savoring a Moment in the Sun, Despite a Court Date
text: NEWARK  Lil Wayne had three things to explain. No. 1, a religious confession: “I believe in God and his son, Jesus. Do you?” He interpreted the roar as an affirmative response. No. 2, a professional confession: He said he was nothing without the fans, adding, “Make some noise for what you created!” Noise was made. No. 3: Same as No. 2. More noise.

headline: Congress May Single Out Clemens
text: A Congressional committee has taken the first steps toward asking the Department of Justice to start a criminal investigation into whether Roger Clemens committed perjury during testimony about performance-enhancing drugs, according to three lawyers with knowledge of the matter.

headline: Peking Opera Plays China’s Schools
text: China plans to promote its traditional culture by adding Peking Opera to the music curriculum in 200 schools in 10 provinces, Reuters reported. “The aim of this program is to help the children develop an interest in the nation’s unique cultural treasures,” said Wang Jun, a cultural official in the Beijing Education Bureau. But hot on the heels of the announcement, reported on Monday in The Beijing News, came critics who complained on the Internet that untrained teachers and forced instruction might discourage students from this 200-year-old art, characterized by complex gestures and trilling vocals. An Internet user who called himself Little Monkey, said, “If the students are forced to learn, it might backfire and make them totally lose interest.”

headline: Yahoo Plans to Let Users Help Mold New Feature
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even as it struggles to find alternatives to being acquired by Microsoft, Yahoo continues to push elements of a turnaround plan devised by Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder and chief executive.

headline: Union Theological Gets New President
text: Union Theological Seminary in New York City named the Rev. Dr. Serene Jones, 48, as its new president, making her the first woman to hold the post in the institution’s 172-year history. Currently a professor of theology at Yale Divinity School and chairwoman of its department of Women, Gender and Sexuality Studies, Dr. Jones is only the fourth woman to run an independent, mainline school of theology in the country. In the case of Union, Dr. Jones is taking on an institution emerging from serious financial problems.

headline: The Wharton House: A Window Into a Writer’s Life
text: To the Editor:

headline: Robotic Championship Bout Raises Questions for Boxing
text: Boxing will survive Wladimir Klitschko’s spiritless defeat of Sultan Ibragimov on Saturday night. And the heavyweights will stumble on without stardom or charisma.

headline: A Review of Prostate Cancer Leaves Men in a Muddle
text: A diagnosis of prostate cancer is scary enough. But just as scary is that nobody can tell a man the best way to treat it.

headline: I.B.M. to Introduce a Notably Improved Mainframe
text: The mainframe, the aged yet surprisingly resilient survivor of computing, is getting a face-lift. A model called the I.B.M. z10, which is being introduced Tuesday, is far faster and has three times the data-juggling memory of its three-year-old predecessor, the z9.

headline: Researchers Develop a Type of Rubber That Can Repair Itself
text: Flubber was pretty good stuff. The super-rubber of a 1961 Disney film starring Fred MacMurray (and of a 1997 remake starring Robin Williams) could literally make people jump through basketball hoops.

headline: Siemens Plans to Cut Up to 7,000 Jobs
text: Siemens plans on Tuesday to announce that it intends to eliminate up to 7,000 jobs, or 40 percent of the workers in its troubled business telecommunications unit in Germany and Brazil, as it seeks a buyer for the business, a person with direct knowledge of the situation said.

headline: McCain Says Prospects May Hinge on Iraq
text: ROCKY RIVER, Ohio  Senator John McCain said Monday that he needed to convince the American people that the troop escalation in Iraq was working and that American casualties there would continue to decline. If he did not, he said, “I lose” the election.

headline: Other Countries Join Tax Inquiry
text: FRANKFURT  Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes at home.

headline: In Merger Matters, Little Talk About Travelers
text: MARCH MADNESS may soon be upon us. No, you haven’t stumbled by mistake onto the sports pages. When I talk about March Madness and the makeup of the Final Four, I’m talking about the airline industry in the United States and the prospect that it is on the verge of fundamental consolidation.

headline: Tempelsman Sculptures Return to Italy
text: After a long battle two rare sixth-century B.C. marble sculptures that once belonged to the New York businessman Maurice Tempelsman go on view Tuesday at Italy’s presidential palace. For nearly 30 years rumors circulated that tomb robbers had dug up the statues on a hillside in the ancient Greek settlement of Morgantina in Sicily. After amassing evidence that they were looted, Italian investigators began seeking a handover of the acroliths  statues usually made with wooden torsos but with stone heads and extremities  in the late 1980s. Mr. Tempelsman, a diamond importer perhaps best known for having been the companion of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, remained unswayed until the Italian government threatened to sue him, an official said Monday. “He hadn’t wanted to give them up because he’d paid for them; that’s what he told me,” said Mario Bondioli Osio, who formerly headed of an Italian commission that sought to recover the country’s lost cultural patrimony. Mr. Tempelsman, who was said to be traveling and unavailable for comment, bought the acroliths from the London dealer Robin Symes in 1980 for a reported $1 million. In 2002 Mr. Bondioli Osio, Mr. Tempelsman and the University of Virginia worked out a deal under which Mr. Tempelsman would give the university partial ownership of the statues for five years and then cede them entirely. On Jan. 1 the acroliths  their wooden bodies long ago lost, leaving two heads, three hands and three feet  became the property of the university, which promptly returned them to Italy. The statues, one of which is shown above, arrived in Rome on Friday along with nine classical antiquities from the private collection of the New York philanthropist Shelby White that were ceded to Italy in January under a separate pact. Italy says Ms. White’s artifacts were also looted from Italian soil.

headline: North Korea Welcomes New York Philharmonic
