text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Projected on a scrim, the gently falling “snow” speckled the precisely twirling figures at the Mansudae Art Theater in a dance depiction of Korean Communists’ guerrilla action against the Japanese. At the climax, a nighttime scene of downtown Pyongyang materialized, with warm lights glowing in the high-rise buildings.

headline: Tigers’ Off-Season Moves Forge a Lineup Without a Weak Link
text: LAKELAND, Fla.  Iván Rodríguez will be paid $13 million this season to play catcher for the Detroit Tigers and bat eighth. This is not a glamorous lineup spot for a veteran power hitter who could reach the Hall of Fame.

headline: Cochlear Implant Supports an Author’s Active Life
text: Josh Swiller was 22 and profoundly deaf when he applied to the Peace Corps in search of adventure. And indeed, adventure he found. His experiences in Zambia are eloquently recounted in his hard-to-put-down memoir of deafness and Africa, “The Unheard” (Holt, 2007).

headline: Union Spends Heavily for Obama in Primaries
text: The powerful Service Employees International Union  whose local chapters helped John Edwards in the Iowa caucus  is now pouring cash and manpower into helping Senator Barack Obama in the Texas and Ohio primaries.

headline: Sánchez Is Back In the Game
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The fans who packed the stands surrounding Field No. 7 for Monday’s intrasquad game screamed José Reyes’s name and clapped for Jon Niese and roared for David Wright. But they fell silent, eerily so, when Duaner Sánchez jogged toward the mound and picked up a ball.

headline: California: Study of Immigrants and Crime
text: Immigrants in the state, about 35 percent of adults, are far less likely than native-born Americans to commit crimes, according to a study by the Public Policy Institute of California, a nonpartisan research group. Among men ages 18 to 40, the group most likely to commit crimes, native-born Americans were 10 times more likely than immigrants to be incarcerated for crimes in California prisons and jails. The study included both legal and illegal immigrants, without focusing separately on illegal immigrants. But it found that native-born American men ages 18 to 40 were at least eight times more likely to be imprisoned for crimes than Mexican immigrants in that age range who were not naturalized citizens  a group likely to have a high percentage of illegal immigrants.

headline: Is It Time for Clemens to Dial Nanny 911?
text: The nanny, it turns out, speaks English and speaks it well, idioms and all.

headline: Mental Abilities: Dementia Percentages Decline for Elderly
text: We’re not growing older. We’re growing sharper.

headline: Investing in Our Cities
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Encyclopedia of Life, No Bookshelf Required
text: Imagine the Book of All Species: a single volume made up of one-page descriptions of every species known to science. On one page is the blue-footed booby. On another, the Douglas fir. Another, the oyster mushroom. If you owned the Book of All Species, you would need quite a bookshelf to hold it. Just to cover the 1.8 million known species, the book would have to be more than 300 feet long. And you’d have to be ready to expand the bookshelf strikingly, because scientists estimate there are 10 times more species waiting to be discovered.

headline: British Museums Told to Clean House
text: The Museums Association, founded in 1889 to represent Britain’s museums and galleries, reversed a 30-year ban on selling art and urged its 1,500 members on Monday to get rid of objects that are gathering dust, the BBC reported. “Museums typically collect a thousand times as many things as they get rid of,” Mark Taylor, the association’s director, said in a posting on its Web site (museumsassociation.org.). “Wonderful collections can become a burden unless they are cleared of unused objects.” The association told its members to give unused art to other museums or public institutions or, in exceptional circumstances, to sell it. The organization expressed hope that its new policy would encourage museums to put some pieces on display, and said it expected only a few sales each year. Vanessa Trevelyan, convener of the association’s ethics committee and head of Norfolk Museum and Archaeology Service, said, “Although disposal of items is not without risk, it is preferable to transfer items to an alternative home where they will be treasured, rather than retain material that is not supporting a museum’s research, display or interpretation functions.”

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about suggestions that the economy may be entering a period of stagflation misspelled the surname of an investment strategist who commented on moves to bolster the economy. He is David Darst, not Durst.

headline: Belarus: Opposition Prisoner Vows to Starve Himself
text: Aleksandr V. Kazulin, a former presidential candidate who has been serving a five-and-a-half-year prison sentence since leading anti-government demonstrations in 2006, said that he would refuse all food and fluids beginning Tuesday unless the authorities allowed him to attend the funeral of his wife, Iryna, who died of cancer on Feb. 23. He said he would then die swiftly in prison  a person on a “dry” hunger strike can usually live no more than a week  forcing the authorities to bury him and his wife together. The West has been pressing the Belarussian government for his release. Javier Solana, the European Union’s foreign policy chief, urged Belarus to release Mr. Kazulin “immediately and unconditionally, so that he can be reunited with his family and attend his wife’s funeral.”

headline: A Place in the Sun (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Turkey Carries Ireland's Hopes
text: Ireland has chosen Dustin the Turkey, above, a glove puppet known for belching and a thick Dublin accent, to restore the country’s glory at the Eurovision Song Contest in May, Agence France-Presse reported. The bird, a star of television programs for nearly two decades, defeated five finalists late Saturday, when judges chose his song “Irelande Douze Pointe” (“Ireland 12 Points”), a parody of voting procedures at the Europe-wide competition that also pokes fun of “Riverdance,” the international hit Irish dance show. Composed by Darren Smith and Simon Fine, the song includes the lyrics: “Shake your feathers and pop your beak, shake it to the west and to the east, wave Euro-hands and Euro-feet, wave them in the air to the turkey beat,” The Times of London reported. Ireland has won the contest a record seven times, including three straight in the 1990s, but finished last in 2007 in Helsinki. Dustin has previously run (unsuccessfully) for president of Ireland and recorded with the Irish rock star Bob Geldof.

headline: Annan Has Sharp Words for Kenyans as Talks Stall
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kofi Annan has had just about enough  or so it seems.

headline: Multiple Hazards (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Pentagon Says Satellite’s Tank Was Destroyed
text: The Pentagon said the mission to launch a Navy missile-interceptor at a dead spy satellite appears to have succeeded in destroying a tank filled with toxic rocket fuel. The Pentagon said it had reached the conclusion based on studying remnants from the missile strike on Wednesday. The statement said a joint space operations headquarters based at Vandenberg Air Force Base, in California, was tracking less than 3,000 pieces of debris, “all smaller than a football.” Most of the debris, the statement said, had already re-entered the atmosphere or would within coming weeks. There had been no reports of debris hitting Earth, the statement said, adding that “it is unlikely any will remain intact to impact the ground.”

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Feb. 21 about Senator John McCain’s record on lobbying and ethics, including his role in the Keating Five case, described incorrectly the reprimand delivered to three other members of the Senate in 1991 for intervening with government regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. The Senate Ethics Committee rebuked the three senators for improper behavior, but under a parliamentary agreement the full Senate did not censure them or take any other vote on the matter.

headline: Foreclosure Aid Rising Locally, as Is Dissent
text: SEATTLE  As the Bush administration and Congress consider proposals to ease the home foreclosure crisis, local governments across the country have been lending money to imperiled homeowners and confronting some opposition.

headline: A Comedian Goes Green but Won’t Go Off Color
text: BEFORE becoming a comedian, I was a senior engineer with Intel, presenting technical demonstrations at events throughout the world. In six years, I visited every continent but Antarctica.

headline: Iraqi Pilgrims Endure Another Attack
text: BAGHDAD  Another attack on Shiite pilgrims marching to the holy city of Karbala killed at least four people on Monday, just a day after a suicide bombing left 52 dead.

headline: Coral Reefs and What Ruins Them
text: Researchers who studied a string of Pacific Ocean atolls are painting the first detailed picture of pristine coral reefs and how they can be disrupted by people  particularly, they said, by fishing.

headline: Selanne Was Clearly Not Ready to Retire
text: ANAHEIM, Calif.  His Anaheim Ducks were preparing to play Game No. 65 on Friday, but for Teemu Selanne, it was Game No. 9 since his un-retirement.

headline: Midnight Meals
text: Q. Is there any truth to the idea that if you eat heavily late in the evening, you will gain weight?

headline: South Korean President Pledges Pragmatism
text: SEOUL, South Korea  After he was sworn in Monday, President Lee Myung-bak pledged to revive South Korea’s economy, improve relations with the United States and draw North Korea out of its isolation.

headline: History Survey Stumps U.S. Teens
text: Fewer than half of American teenagers who were asked basic questions about history and literature during a recent telephone survey knew when the Civil War was fought, and one-quarter thought that Christopher Columbus sailed to the New World sometime after 1750, not in 1492.

headline: Drug-Resistant TB at Record Levels
text: Multiple-drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in parts of the former Soviet Union have reached the highest rates ever recorded and could soar even higher, spreading the bacterial disease elsewhere, the World Health Organization said on Tuesday in releasing findings from the largest global survey of the problem.

headline: The Real McCain
text: You wouldn’t know it to look at them, but political consultants are as faddish as anyone else. And the current vogueish advice among the backroom set is: Go after your opponent’s strengths. So in the first volley of what feels like the general election campaign, Barack Obama has attacked John McCain for being too close to lobbyists. His assault is part of this week’s Democratic chorus: McCain isn’t really the anti-special interest reformer he pretends to be. He’s more tainted than his reputation suggests.

headline: In Freshman Season, Moore Shows UConn What May Come
text: STORRS, Conn.  Since 1995, the Connecticut women’s basketball team has produced five national championships, five Associated Press national players of the year (Rebecca Lobo, Jen Rizzotti, Kara Wolters, Sue Bird and Diana Taurasi), nine all-Americans and two three-time all-Americans (Svetlana Abrosimova and Taurasi). The talent pool has been so deep that renowned players like Nykesha Sales, Abrosimova and Taurasi did not start until later in their freshman seasons.

headline: Councilwoman’s Strategy for Open Government: Sue and Sue Again
text: HOBOKEN, N.J.

headline: Another Fare Increase
text: ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines have again raised domestic fares, adding $10 to round-trip prices on most routes. The latest fare increase, the third this year, was initiated by United Airlines on Friday and matched the next day by the five other network carriers, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that there would probably be some “competitive price jockeying” as airlines roll back the increase on various highly competitive routes, but that over all the higher fare should stick.

headline: Pakistan Cuts Access to YouTube Worldwide
text: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube was back up two hours after Pakistan, in an act of information provincialism, inadvertently made the video-sharing site inaccessible to users around the world Sunday afternoon.

headline: Gates Promises Help for Indonesian Military
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates pledged arms upgrades and other Pentagon support for Indonesia on Monday, as the Bush administration forged closer ties to the military of a country still viewed skeptically by some in Congress for past human rights abuses.

headline: Hazards: Enlisting Hospitals in Fight Against Carbon Monoxide
text: Carbon monoxide is odorless and colorless. And it can do its work quietly, sickening and even killing people without their knowing they are being poisoned.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,962 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday :

headline: Fighting for Votes in a Blue-Collar Stronghold
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  For as long as anyone here can remember, presidential hopefuls have made this scrappy, blue-collar stronghold an obligatory pit stop on the Democratic stump. Franklin D. Roosevelt and John F. Kennedy breezed through when the steel plants still turned the night sky orange; decades later, after the smelters had gone cold, Bill Clinton and John Kerry came by promising jobs to those left idle by the mill closings.

headline: Body Discovered in Hotel Bathtub
text: The body of a 52-year-old man, his mouth covered by duct tape, was found in a hotel bathtub in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, the police said.

headline: New Outlook on Bond Firms Ignites Rally
text: Signs that two embattled bond insurance companies are getting close to restoring their reputations and credit ratings bolstered stocks on Monday.

headline: Clinton Campaign Starts 5-Point Attack on Obama
text: After struggling for months to dent Senator Barack Obama’s candidacy, the campaign of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is now unleashing what one Clinton aide called a “kitchen sink” fusillade against Mr. Obama, pursuing five lines of attack since Saturday in hopes of stopping his political momentum.

headline: A Bond Born of Grief, and Hope
text: Kadiatou Diallo stayed far from the Queens courthouse where, 15 months after the 50 shots heard round the city, three police detectives went on trial Monday in the killing of Sean Bell. On Wednesday, she plans to be in New York to meet with Valerie Bell, the dead man’s mother. But she has chosen to keep her distance from the courthouse.

headline: Home Resales and Prices Decline
text: The backlog of unsold homes continued to pile up in January, a sign that home prices will continue to drop as would-be buyers hold out for better deals.

headline: Ford Is Pushing Buyouts to Workers
text: WOODHAVEN, Mich.  The Ford Motor Company is applying the hard sell these days  piling on incentives, doling out marketing DVDs and brochures, and making offers it hopes are too good to pass up.

headline: Shifts in Pregnancy and Work
text: As women have children later than ever and more work outside the home, they are also working longer into pregnancy and returning to work faster than they did four decades ago, the Census Bureau said Monday.

headline: Photovoltaic Cells Are Still Very Green, Comparative Test Shows
text: Solar power generated by photovoltaic cells is among the greenest of energy options. The cells just sit there, basking in the sun and emitting nothing but electrons.

headline: Out of Chekhov’s Orchard, Into History’s Frying Pan
text: The title of the new play at La MaMa E.T.C., “The Cherry Orchard Sequel,” may set off the cringe reflex: isn’t that the kind of thing theater types think up during boozy cast parties? But the work, written and directed by Nic Ularu, is a sparkling surprise, helped along by fine performances all around.

headline: Corrections: For the Record
text: A headline in some editions of The Arts on Monday with an article about the Academy Awards ceremony misstated, in some copies, the title of the film that won best picture. It is, of course, “No Country for Old Men,” not “Old Country for Old Men.”

headline: When the Body Decides to Stop Following the Rules
text: Every day over breakfast, I fill three pillboxes. Fifteen pills in the morning, 3 at lunch and 8 before bed, for a total of 26. To my surprise, I find pleasure in the sorting, as it is one of the few moments when I can pretend I have some control over the bizarre war raging in my colon.

headline: The Luckless Office Drone’s Life, and Afterlife, of Benumbed Desperation
text: Do those sunny Broadway songfests make you want to gag? Would you rather go to the dentist than come to the cabaret, old chum? Maybe you secretly think that “Spring Awakening” is too treacly, despite the teenage sex-and-suicide angle?

headline: Oil Hits a High; Some See $4 Gas by Spring
text: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts fearing they could hit $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily and oil closed at an all-time high on Tuesday of $100.88 a barrel.

headline: Trial of Police Begins in 50-Shot Case
text: The three police detectives entered with lawyers at their sides and the stares of a crowded courtroom at their backs. The men, who once worked undercover in the shadows, were now center stage, sitting not among their fellow officers, but at the defense table.

headline: Europe Warns Against Too-Restrictive Laws on Sovereign Investors
text: BRUSSELS  A top official of the European Union has warned the bloc’s member countries not to pass broad laws to restrict investment from sovereign wealth funds, despite fears about state-controlled foreign predators gobbling up major European companies.

headline: Rolling Stone Donates Art for Arts Sake
text: A painting by the Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood will be auctioned this week to raise money for the Royal Academy of Arts, the BBC reported. The sketch of the Royal Ballet stars Carlos Acosta and Darcey Bussell will join works by Tracy Emin, Mary Fedden and Ken Howard that have been donated for the sale. Mr. Wood, who has been exhibiting his art around the world since the 1980s, will be the guest speaker at the auction to “support artists through the Royal Academy Schools so people like me can continue to be inspired by new talent.”

headline: Knee Injuries in Children
text: To the Editor:

headline: However Mean the Streets, Have an Exit Strategy
text: In the South-Central neighborhood of Los Angeles, where Margaret B. Jones grew up in the 1980s, gangs recruited “with the same intensity as the N.F.L. did,” she says, and shootouts and hits were so ubiquitous that “the odds were stacked against a male child living to see 25.” Peddlers went door to door selling life insurance policies, reminding parents of these deadly stats, and even teenage girls and elderly church ladies carried pistols to protect themselves. As the crack epidemic metastasized, and turf wars escalated, the ’hood became a combat zone, with police raids and deadly face-offs between Bloods and Crips becoming routine parts of daily life.

headline: Obama’s Support Grows Broader, New Poll Finds
text: WASHINGTON  In the past two months, Senator Barack Obama has built a commanding coalition among Democratic voters, with especially strong support among men, and is now viewed by most Democrats as the candidate best able to beat Senator John McCain in the general election, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: True North
text: To the Editor:

headline: Transplant Surgeon Charged in Patient’s Death
text: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  On a winter night in 2006, a disabled and brain damaged man named Ruben Navarro was wheeled into an operating room at a hospital here. By most accounts, Mr. Navarro, 25, was very near death, and doctors hoped that he might sustain other lives by donating his kidneys and liver.

headline: Europeans Plan Incentives, as Iran Says Sanctions Won’t Halt Nuclear Program
text: WASHINGTON  European countries are planning to offer new incentives to Iran if it agrees to halt its uranium enrichment program, European diplomats said Monday.

headline: Visa Plans $17 Billion Public Offer
text: Undaunted by recent turbulence in the financial markets, Visa Inc., the nation’s biggest credit card network, said Monday that it would forge ahead with what would be the largest initial public stock offering in United States history.

headline: The Claim: Stretching Can Prevent Soreness and Injury
text: THE FACTS

headline: Mexicans Barely Increased Remittances in ’07
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexicans working in the United States sent back almost $24 billion to their families at home last year, almost the same amount as the year before, the Mexican central bank reported on Monday.

headline: Corrections
text: A front-page article on Feb. 21 about Senator John McCain’s record on lobbying and ethics, including his role in the Keating Five case, described incorrectly the reprimand delivered to three other members of the Senate in 1991 for intervening with government regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr. The Senate Ethics Committee rebuked the three senators for improper behavior, but under a parliamentary agreement the full Senate did not censure them or take any other vote on the matter. (Go to Article)

headline: A Comic Who Acts Like an Ad Man
text: When Tom Brokaw turned up onstage at Radio City Music Hall on Sunday to be interviewed by Ron Burgundy  Will Ferrell, in character from the movie “Anchorman”  he might have been a visitor from another planet, and he knew it. Offering a tidbit of analysis, he said, “By my presence on this stage, the average age of this audience has gone up by 103.” True. Stuffy old Radio City felt like a college gym, which was the point of a show whose goofy, long title explains it all: “Will Ferrell’s Funny or Die Comedy Tour Presented by ‘Semi-Pro.’ ”

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 20 through Feb. 24 with 1,266 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,115 said they were registered to vote, including 427 self-described Democratic primary voters and 327 self-described Republican primary voters.

headline: On Met’s Grand Stage, Opera Singers of Tomorrow
text: The Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions is a cumbersome name for one of the most high-visibility voice competition in America. Every year, typically, 1,500 young singers perform in regional auditions around the country. The field is winnowed in stages until roughly 25 semifinalists are sent to compete in New York. The finalists are then chosen to perform in a special afternoon concert with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

headline: After 3 Die, Questions on Why Erratic Mother Kept Custody
text: They could have been sleeping. The three children, all in pajamas, lay neatly arranged in a bed in their Long Island apartment  Michael Demesyeux, 5, on one side; his half-sister, Jewell Ward, 6, on the other; and Innocent Demesyeux, 18 months old, in the middle.

headline: Gazans Demonstrate at Border Against Israeli Blockade
text: EREZ CROSSING, Israel  Several thousand Palestinians, many of them schoolchildren bused in from their classes, joined peaceful protests in the Gaza Strip along sections of the border with Israel for several hours on Monday, forming human chains in some locations as part of a public campaign against the Israeli blockade.

headline: Two Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Company to 19%
text: Two hedge funds trying to elect a dissident slate to the board of The New York Times Company amassed 19.03 percent of the company’s common stock before last week’s deadline for gaining voting power at the annual meeting, according to a report filed Monday.

headline: Bush Fails to Attend Deposition
text: A lawyer for Reggie Bush has asked a court to prevent a man who is suing Bush from turning over a deposition of Bush to the N.C.A.A.

headline: Poll Finds a Fluid Religious Life in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON  More than a quarter of adult Americans have left the faith of their childhood to join another religion or no religion, according to a survey of religious affiliation by the Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life.

headline: Motion Would Take Aim at Clemens’s Top Lawyer
text: Lawyers for Roger Clemens’s former personal trainer Brian McNamee said Monday that they would file a motion next Tuesday to disqualify Roger Clemens’s lead lawyer.

headline: For the Very Old, a Dose of ‘Slow Medicine’
text: It was two decades ago that a group of culinary mavericks took a giant step backward down the evolutionary trail with the “slow food” movement. Instead of fast food produced by the assembly lines of giant consortiums, they championed products of small-scale agriculture  time-consuming to prepare, beautiful to behold, very good for you.

headline: Been There... Done That... Here’s How
text: Terry Corbell, a management consultant, does not work for start-ups. “People who are starting businesses aren’t good at what they do yet,” he says.

headline: Nielsen Looks Beyond TV, and Hits Roadblocks
text: Being part of a “Nielsen household” has long been a point of pride for people whose television habits are monitored by the Nielsen Company. In exchange for token compensation, these viewers know that their personal taste influences Hollywood and Madison Avenue.

headline: Free Eye Care From Chávez, All the Better to See Him
text: PORLAMAR, Venezuela  Few places capture the disarray of this country’s public health system like the Hospital Luis Ortega. Unconscious patients lie on cots strewn near the reception desk. Paint peels from walls neglected for years. Soldiers stand guard to prevent worried relatives gathered on the curb from bursting inside.

headline: The Clinton-Obama Tug of War
text: To the Editor:

headline: Electric Shadows: Hong Kong’s World Class Film Festival
text: Hong Kong gets a bad rap for not being much of a “culture” city–the old cliche is that we’re all too busy counting our money to think about Art. Meanwhile, the HK government, along with various cultural promoters and poobahs, are tripping over each other trying to promote schemes to Culture-ize the city. For without Art, how can Hong Kong ever hold its head up as a Great World City?

headline: A Parting Shot at the S.E.C.
text: Kayla Gillan, a founding member of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, had to leave the board because her term was up. Now she has sent out a blast at the Securities and Exchange Commission, and the way it handled the efforts to make Section 404 of the Sarbanes Oxley Act more friendly to companies.

headline: Sum Songs
text: Photos from the musical "Adding Machine."

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Northeast Edition
text: Now to the independent bloggers of the Adams Division, which the league has taken to calling the “Northeast Division” so the new fans won’t be confused.

headline: $500,000 Homes
text: Properties on the market in California, Colorado and Massachusetts.

headline: Hockey Night in Blogdom: Northwest Edition
text: The independent bloggers of the mountains, woodlands and tar sands of the Northwest:

headline: The Democrats Battle for Texas
text: The Democratic presidential candidates face the challenges of campaigning in Texas.

headline: The Performance in Pyongyang
text: Images from the New York Philharmonic's performance at East Pyongyang Grand Theater.

headline: ‘Le Paty’
text: A look at a home in a hidden valley of the Luberon Regional Nature Park in France.

headline: Diebold Accidentally Leaks ’08 Election Results Early
text: From The Onion:

headline: Getting Hooked on Fantasy Football
text: Our guest blogger of the week:

headline: ‘The Audacity of Rope’
text: More of your “late night” humor (send via the comment link below):

headline: Paris Fashion Week | Christian Dior
text: (AFP/Getty Images)

headline: Guilty Verdict for 5 in A.I.G. Case
text: Five former insurance executives were found guilty Monday of fraud and conspiracy in a scheme to manipulate the financial statements of the insurance company American International Group.

headline: Virgin to Appeal Ruling on BSkyB’s ITV Stake
text: The British cable operator Virgin Media said Monday that it would appeal the British Competition Commission’s ruling that BSkyB must cut its stake in the rival broadcaster ITV, arguing that the regulator was not requiring a big enough divestment.

headline: India’s HDFC Bank Offers $2.4 Billion for Rival
text: HDFC Bank on Monday offered $2.4 billion in shares for its smaller rival, the Centurion Bank of Punjab, in an attempt to bulk up before the banking sector is opened to foreign competitors.

headline: Radar Networks Reels in $13 Million
text: Radar Networks, which is preparing a public beta launch of Twine, a Web application that organizes and manages information, has raised $13 million in Series B funding from Velocity Interactive, Draper Fisher Jurvetson, and Vulcan Capital.

headline: Novell Buys Virtualization Firm PlateSpin
text: Novell said Monday it plans to acquire PlateSpin, a provider of virtualization services, for $205 million, a move that could bolster Novell’s software for helping customers manage their computing operations.

headline: Live From Colette| Be Scene
text: Come to Colette in Paris where T is putting the store’s hyper-cool clientele (like you) on film all week long. You can take your photo at T Online’s photo-booth computer or, if you’re worthy, our paparazzo will hunt you down. If you’re not in Paris, you can still have fun by telling us which photos you like the most. Just leave us a comment. Don’t forget to smile!

headline: Motorola Picks Up Chinese Set-Top Assets
text: Motorola said Monday it had acquired the assets related to the digital cable set-top products of Zhejiang Dahua Digital Technology and Hangzhou Image Silicon.

headline: Hillary’s ‘Go Negative’ Flow Chart
Ontario Pension Says BCE Buyout Will Meet Ownership Restrictions
text: Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan’s $48.5 billion proposed takeover of the Canadian telephone company BCE, the largest buyout in history, will comply with foreign ownership restrictions and broadcasting rules, the pension plan’s chief executive officer said Monday as the federal communications regulator grilled him about who will control the company.

headline: Brink’s to Spin Off Home Security Business
text: Brink’s has decided to make its home security unit a separate, publicly traded company, following pressure from activist investors to spin off one of its two business segments.

headline: Skilling Prepares for Appeal
text: Lawyers for Jeffrey Skilling, former chief executive of Enron, and the government will soon face off once again as his side argues to erase his convictions while prosecutors seek to maintain them.

headline: Justice Dept. Signs Off on $2.4 Billion UnitedHealth Deal
text: The Justice Department approved UnitedHealth Group‘s $2.4 billion acquisition of Sierra Health Services on Monday, but required UnitedHealth to sell its Medicare Advantage business in Las Vegas to Humana as a condition.

headline: The Balenciaga Line
text: The first three dresses at the Balenciaga show this morning were modern takes on the black cocktail sheath–I should say, extremely modern takes. Nicolas Ghesquiere cut everything close, in fabrics that might typically be stiff–like patent leather and thick wool crepes–but the effect was very light. You could see that his aim was to make everything light: the fabric, the cutting, the mentality. If you think of the couture structure from the 50s and 60s, and from his own recent collections, Ghesquiere still had subtle volumes in his opening dresses but it was as though he had stripped it down.

headline: Lampert Hits Road Blocks in Search for Sears New C.E.O.
text: Edward S. Lampert, the billionaire hedge-fund investor mired in turning around Sears Holdings, has been looking for a chief executive to run the retail giant since last fall, a longer time period than publicly acknowledged, according to The Chicago Tribune.

headline: Two Funds Raise Their Stake in Times Company to 19%
text: Two hedge funds trying to elect a dissident slate to the board of The New York Times Company have raised the ante in their bid to push through changes at the media company.

headline: FriendFeed Hooks Up With V.C.s
text: FriendFeed, the social, shared feed reader similar to Facebook’s news feed, has announced a $5 million round of funding from Benchmark Capital as well as FriendFeed’s co-founders and former employees of Google, Paul Buchheit and Sanjeev Singh.

headline: Sarkozy Lashes Out at SocGen Chairman
text: French President Nicolas Sarkozy stepped up pressure on the head of Société Générale to quit over the bank’s record trading scandal on Tuesday, but France’s top business lobby warned him not to interfere.

headline: Regulator Approves Liberty’s DirecTV Deal
text: The media mogul John C. Malone could soon be back in the business of delivering TV signals to consumers-this time via satellite.

headline: Paris Fashion Week | Undercover
text: (Getty)

headline: Goldman Predicts More Write-Downs for Brokers
text: Goldman Sachs said it expects additional write-downs of about $1 billion to $12 billion each for several major brokers in the first quarter, with Citigroup estimated to record the highest amount of about $12 billion.

headline: Investors Jittery Over Delta-Northwest Talks
text: Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines shares fell on Monday partly on concerns their merger talks may fail on the inability of pilots to agree on how to combine their ranks.

headline: Buried Seed Vault Opens in Arctic
text: [UPDATED, 8:30 a.m.] After several years of planning and digging, the world has its first secure, deep-frozen repository for backup supplies of seeds from hundreds of thousands of plant varieties that underpin agriculture. The Svalbard Global Seed Vault was built into a frigid mountainside in Norway’s northernmost archipelago, deep in the Arctic. It had its ceremonial opening Tuesday morning in the frigid gloom of the Arctic winter. [UPDATE: Many readers wondered about whether it was too close to sea level. But, as I learned in my three Arctic trips, things up there are way more spread out than they appear. The tunnel entrance is 130 meters, or about 400 feet, above sea level. So all can rest easy on that front.]

headline: Bid for Game Maker Seen as Effort to Buy Innovation
text: Creating a video game costs around $20 million. So for $2 billion, Electronic Arts could develop 100 new titles. Instead, it wants to pay $2 billion for Take-Two Interactive, known primarily for one particular game, Grand Theft Auto.

headline: Visa I.P.O. Could Be Boon for Banks
text: Amid the dark days of multibillion dollar write-downs, trading scandals and congressional inquiries, one group of banks have a $17 billion bright spot on their horizon.

headline: Science and Art
text: Images from the exhibition "Design and the Elastic Mind."

headline: Morgan Stanley: Friend to the Bear-Huggers
text: Morgan Stanley, it seems, is the darling of the mulitbillion dollar bear hug these days.

headline: Hedge Funds Still Pose Risk to Financial System, Report Says
text: Despite closer monitoring by regulators, hedge funds still pose significant risks to the financial system, a government report said Monday.

headline: Catching Up With | Michel Gaubert
text: As creator of Colette’s legendary mix CDs, designer of a line of deejay-specific bags for Longchamp and his endless list of fashion clients for whom he creates runway soundtracks, the deejay/sound designer extraordinaire Michel Gaubert is a veritable fashion-music powerhouse. The Moment caught up with him in the midst of fashion weeks.

headline: Live from Germany: Super Return 2008
text: What a difference a year makes.

headline: Wachovia’s Inscrutable Lawsuit
text: The New York Times reported Monday that Wachovia had sued its client, Providence Equity Partners, in a North Carolina court. Wachovia is seeking to have the court declare that it is no longer required to finance Providence’s $1.2 billion acquisition of Clear Channel Communications‘ television unit.

text: (Getty)

headline: Critics Have Their Say

headline: Tips for Weathering the Storm

headline: Potshots at the Zeppelin
text: Over at the Film Experience, it is especially and wonderfully clear that somebody moved blogger Nathaniel’s milkshake. In particular, he’s sick and tired of hearing that the awards honored obscure movies.

headline: The Early Word: Fight Night
text: Oh, Ohio. Tonight’s Democratic debate (9 p.m. E.T., MSNBC) will be the last face off between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama before the state’s bellwether primary one week from today — and with none scheduled for the future, it could be the last one, period.

headline: Och-Ziff Posts Loss on I.P.O. Costs
text: Och-Ziff Capital Management posted a net loss in its first quarterly earnings report as a public company, mostly because of the costs of listing its shares in November. But the hedge-fund group reported higher-than-expected distributable earnings, the number that analysts look at most closely, Reuters said.

headline: Missing Link
text: The Bagger was really busy backstage and his headset was working only intermittently. He heard a number of touching speeches — Diablo Cody fell apart when she thanked her family for loving her as she is — but it all went by too fast.

text: Timing is everything when it comes to mergers.

headline: Sam Zell on Selling Chicago Cubs
text: CNBC interviews Sam Zell, real estate tycoon and Tribune chief executive, about trying to sell the Chicago Cubs and Wrigley Field by opening day.

headline: Oscar Nation Shrinks
text: Throughout his personal and professional life, the Bagger has made a habit of showing up right when a particular cultural phenomenon was about to crash. He went to a Yippie camp-in in 1974. Do the math: the war was over and Nixon was on his way out. And he didn’t get punk until it was more about fashion than music.

headline: In Trial Over Police Killing, Clashing Perspectives
text: The opening of the trial of three New York City police detectives in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell is the top local news story of the day, and every news outlet seemed to have its own take. In a front-page article in The Times, Michael Wilson describes the sharply diverging perspectives of the prosecution and the defense. The lead prosecutor called the detectives as a careless and incompetent group who ran on amok the morning of Nov. 25, 2006, unorganized and desperate for an arrest as their nightclub detail was coming to a close.

headline: Update: Edwards Wins Auto Club 500 on Monday
text: On Sunday, rain stopped the Sprint Cup race on lap 87 with Jimmie Johnson in the lead. The race resumed on Monday.

headline: A Nation Briefly Without Starbucks
text: At 5:30 p.m. Eastern time today, all 7,100 Starbucks locations in the United States will close their doors for three hours.

headline: One Thing Everyone Can Agree On
text: In a panel discussion that pitted industry competitors against each other — it was called “Head-to-Head With the Industry Experts” — there was a hotbed of consensus on at least one issue: the lousy state of the market for private equity deals.

headline: The Democratic Debate in Cleveland
text: The following is a transcript of the Democratic presidential debate on MSNBC in Cleveland, Ohio, as provided by the Federal News Service and CQ Transcriptions via The Associated Press.

headline: Yahoo Reveals (Some) Details About Its Ad Plans
text: The meat of the presentation by Jerry Yang, chief executive, and Sue Decker, president, of Yahoo at the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s convention Monday was a new advertising system called Apex (for Advertiser Publisher Exchange).

headline: A Guarded Tone
text: Jonathan Nelson of Providence Equity Partners is a big-time media investor. But the title of his talk on Tuesday — “Off the Record with Jonathan Nelson” — suggested he might be a bit media-shy himself. As a courtesy, this blogger asked Mr. Nelson afterwards if his speech was on the record. After a bit of confusion, he said, “What if I say no?” Our answer: “I’d say, ‘You’ve got to be kidding with this room full of people.'”

headline: Mets vs. Wolverines
text: It’s T-minus 2.5 hours until the showdown of the spring. Well, at least for the University of Michigan baseball team. Fred Wilpon’s alma mater, ranked No. 8 in the Collegiate Baseball poll, is fresh off a three-game weekend sweep of Villanova.

headline: YouTube Returns to Pakistan: Calm on the Internet, for Now
text: News agencies are reporting that the Pakistani government lifted its restrictions on its citizens’ access to YouTube after a video that it deemed blasphemous was removed. And the nation confirmed that its decision to impose those restrictions accidentally led to a global disruption of YouTube for two hours on Sunday.

text: Rogers Sportsnet is reporting that the Devils have traded Cam Janssen to St. Louis for Bryce Salvador. Sportsnet received confirmation of the deal from the Blues.

text: Rick Peterson, the deep-thinking, ultra-prepared Mets pitching coach, studies every nuance of his pitchers. Peterson is so conditioned to studying habits that he sometimes studies reporters, too.

headline: Sean Bell’s Father Recalls Fatal Night at Club
text: Updated, 5:43 p.m. | William Bell, the father of Sean Bell, testified this morning about the final night he spent with his son. The testimony, on the second day of the trial of three New York City police detectives charged in the killing of Sean Bell, was striking because of the short amount of time that passed — about an hour — between the last time the father saw his son alive and the son’s death.

headline: Belak to Florida
text: The Toronto Maple Leafs have sent defenseman Wade Belak to the Florida Panthers for a fifth-round pick in this summer’s draft.

headline: A Policy Change at Freemans
text: In response to yesterday’s post about restaurants that won’t let you order as you go, I received an e-mail from William Tigertt, one of the owners of Freemans. He wanted it known that the current policy at Freemans — the policy for quite a while now, actually — is to let diners order appetizers or snacks before the rest of their meal if they want to.

text: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

headline: Lightning Trades Richards to Stars
text: The center Brad Richards has reportedly been traded to the Dallas Stars. Rogers Sportsnet says goaltender Johan Holmqvist is a part of the deal.

text: The Montreal Canadiens have traded goaltender Cristobal Huet to the Washington Capitals for a second-round pick in the 2009 draft, according to TSN.ca.

headline: Avalanche Grabs Salei
text: The Florida Panthers have sent defenseman Ruslan Salei to the Colorado Avalanche. In return, defenseman Karlis Skrastins and a third-round pick in this summer’s draft is the package that the Panthers have accepted.

headline: From ABC, a ‘Candid Camera’-Style Twist on Reality
text: When network newsmagazines use hidden cameras, they are usually pursuing child predators, as the “To Catch A Predator” series on “Dateline NBC” has demonstrated. But for the next several weeks, ABC is introducing a new twist on the genre — a social psychology experiment called “What Would You Do?”

headline: ‘Told Him To Shut Up’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: Last night, Javier Bardem won the best supporting actor Oscar for “No Country for Old Men,” and he delivered part of his acceptance speech in Spanish. Afterwards, Bardem said he did this because he wanted everyone who lives in California to understand him.

headline: Leon Black on Doubling Down
text: If you can’t buy ’em, buy their debt.

headline: Chicago Trades Ruutu and Lapointe
text: Tuomo Ruutu is now a Carolina Hurricane. The Blackhawks have traded the young forward to the Hurricanes for left wing Andrew Ladd.

headline: Now Screening | Charlize Theron
text: Last weekend, T rolled out its latest issue with our cover girl Charlize Theron. We’d like to call your attention to the Francesco Carrozzini-directed T: Online video with Ms. Theron — we think it’s pretty cool. Watch the “Monster” talent as she muses about South African drive-ins, homemade outfits, her affection for fried things and falling in love with Tom Hanks. You can see the video and read the accompanying article here.Click the still, below, to view the video.

headline: It’s Off to Ohio for Corzine
text: With New Jersey confronted by staggering debt and shrinking revenue, Gov. Jon S. Corzine unveiled a grim budget today that calls for eliminating thousands of state jobs, $3.2 billion in program cuts, the trimming of every state department and reduced hours at motor vehicle offices and state parks.

headline: Arson Suspected at Fire Chief’s Mansion
text: Somebody trashed a San Francisco landmark that doubled as temporary housing for local officials, resulting in as much as $25,000 in damage, according to The San Francisco Chronicle. The boyfriend of the city’s recently installed planning director is under arrest in connection with the vandalism, which included tossing furniture around and painting the place red with a can of crushed tomatoes. (In San Francisco, even the graffiti is organic.)

headline: Insider | Julia Restoin-Roitfeld
text: The Insider is a recurring profile of emerging tastemakers in the fields of fashion, design, food, travel and the arts. Here Julia Restoin-Roitfeld, the graphic designer, sometime muse, and daughter of Carine, shares with The Moment a few of her stylish essentials. Roitfeld Jr. currently freelances for clients such as Peter Som, V Magazine, and Jean Paul Gaultier. No word yet on if she’ll be hitting up Paris fashion week.Name: Julia Restoin-RoitfeldAge: 27Occupation: Art directorRetail Standbys: Kiki de Montparnasse, Marc By Marc, Fantasy World (for the latex clothes), and Dary’s, a vintage jewelry store in Paris.Book Shop: Le Comptoire de L’image in Paris and Strand Bookstore in New York.Provisions: Sunrise Mart on 3rd Avenue, WholefoodsGifts: Kiki de MontparnasseRestaurant: Omen, Indochine, Caviar KaspiaCocktail: Vodka tonic or a lychie martiniParty Central: Matisse in Paris, The Beatrice Inn in NYMomentary style obsessions: Miu Miu’s Spring ’08 collection, Repetto, and the new turban cashmere hat I got for winter!Reading Material: Paris Vogue!Art Pick: Cocteau drawings; GauguinMuseums: Musée d’Orsay (more for its architecture than its content)Vacation: Anywhere where I can disconnect a bit from NY!Winter Survival Tip: Tons of Moisturizer!

headline: Private Cooking Classes in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Beijing and Kobe, Japan
text: I am going on a cruise to Asia in March and I want to learn how to make local specialties in Hong Kong, Kobe, Shanghai and Beijing. Do you have any information on how to book private cooking classes in these cities?

headline: ‘These People Are Called Republicans’
text: Aired Monday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Ralph Nader announced he is running for president again. His announcement has filled millions of people with excitement and hope. And these people are called Republicans.

headline: Rangers Loose After Practice, Awaiting Trade News
text: The roll call at Rangers practice was complete, save for their two injured players, forward Colton Orr and defenseman Paul Mara. Rangers management was absent, preferring to work the trading deadline business from their Manhattan offices. That left everyone else to pretend it was a normal day.

headline: ‘Raúl Nader Will Then Take Over’
text: Aired Monday night on NBC: How many watched the Academy Awards? You know, the Oscars are broadcast in over 100 different countries, three of which actually like us. Did you know that?

headline: Some Sad News
text: Dennis Letts — who was Tracy Letts’s father, and whom many of us saw on Broadway playing Beverly Weston — died last week. The cause was cancer.

headline: Foote Returning to Colorado
text: The Columbus Blue Jackets have traded defenseman Adam Foote to the Colorado Avalanche, according to Rogers Sportsnet. In return, the Blue Jackets will receive a fourth-round pick this summer and a conditional first-round pick in either this summer’s draft or in 2009, depending on whether the Avalanche re-signs Foote, who is eligible to be an unrestricted free agent after this season. Foote, who began his career in the Nordiques/Avalanche organization, waived his no trade clause to return to Denver.

headline: Fedorov to Washington
text: The Columbus Blue Jackets continue to shed veterans, trading forward Sergei Fedorov to the Washington Capitals. In return, the Blue Jackets will get Ted Ruth, a freshman defenseman at Notre Dame. Ruth, according to TSN and Sportsnet, prefers to be called Theo rather than Ted. But Notre Dame and CollegeHockeyNews.com list him as Ted or Teddy, in case you were wondering.

headline: Dodd Explains Why He Chose Obama
text: CLEVELAND, Ohio — Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut became the first of the vanquished Democratic presidential hopefuls to endorse a rival, putting his hand on Barack Obama’s back and declaring him the best choice for the 21st Century.

headline: Wake Us When It’s Over
text: Twelve to 18 months seems to be the magic range.

headline: City Settles Parks Bias Suit for $21 Million
text: Updated, 4:14 p.m. | After 14 months of negotiation, New York City has agreed to pay more than $21 million to settle a federal class-action discrimination lawsuit filed against the Department of Parks and Recreation and will make “major changes in certain of its personnel practices” as part of the settlement, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund announced today. The settlement, which is expected to be ratified by Judge Denny Chin in United States District Court in Manhattan, includes $11.9 million in back pay and compensatory damages to a group of about 3,500 former and current workers.

headline: Isles Deal for a Defenseman
text: The Islanders have sent a seventh-round draft pick to the San Jose Sharks for defenseman Rob Davison.

text: CINCINNATI, Ohio—A conservative radio talk show host who helped introduce Senator John McCain before a rally here Tuesday used Senator Barack Obama’s middle name, Hussein, three times, while disparaging him, prompting Mr. McCain to apologize and repudiate the comments afterward.

text: Private equity firms are hardly the only ones adjusting to a brave new world these days. Investors in private equity funds are also facing a reality check as it becomes more clear that the days of wine, roses and 30 percent returns may be over, at least for a while.

headline: Sorting It All Out
text: Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin? Pretty good. Add Marian Hossa to the mix and suddenly you have an absurdly nuclear offensive array. Can this put them over the top for the Stanley Cup this year? (Will Ty Conklin turn into a pumpkin at midnight?) Can they re-sign Hossa at the end of the season? Both good questions. But for now, a power play with Gonchar-Whitney-Crosby-Malkin-Hossa will be feared in the East.

headline: A Banner Month for CNN
text: CNN, which normally comes in second to Fox News Channel in cable news ratings, is celebrating its first prime-time victory over its top rival since 2001.

headline: Bruno Gets Makeup Cash From 1199
text: Over the weekend, The Times reported that 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East, the powerful hospital workers union, might be hedging its bets in state political circles by throwing huge amounts of money at the Working Families Party, which is leading the charge for the Democratic candidate in a hotly contested special election for the State Senate being held today.The move was curious because in recent years, 1199 has been the most important financial backer of the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the state’s top Republican. In recent weeks, though, 1199 has donated $257,000 to the Working Families Party. And in the last six months? Nothing to the Senate Republicans.

headline: A Very Popular ‘Raisin’
text: Video

headline: Mr. Nader’s Unforgivable Wrong
text: With Ralph Nader’s announcement of a fourth (or maybe fifth) run for president, it is worth taking a minute to recall his most infamous previous campaign: his 2000 presidential bid. The rosy and imprecise glow of memory might lead one to remember it as a well-intentioned effort to make a point that simply went awry. But such a view is far, far more benign than the reality of the Nader 2000 campaign, and therefore a review of that effort is in order to put his current campaign in context.

headline: Roger Clemens: ‘It’s Baseball Time’
text: Roger Clemens was 50 feet in front of me, walking fast and talking into a cell phone. He was headed to an off-limits area at the Houston Astros’ minor league complex here in Kissimmee, Fla., so I rushed forward and asked him if he had a few minutes. He put the cell phone down and agreed to answer some questions.

headline: Of Superdelegates and the ‘Black-Brown Divide’
text: Democratic House members and university professors of color held two events in Washington within the past 24 hours where they spoke frankly about the issues facing their communities.

headline: Starbucks Retrains, Rivals Discount
text: CNBC reports on how rivals like Dunkin' Donuts are responding to Starbucks closing most of its outlets for three hours to retrain its baristas.

headline: City Raids ‘Counterfeit Triangle,’ Shutting 32 Storefronts
text: City investigators raided dozens of storefronts on a triangular block in Chinatown this morning in what officials described as a major seizing of counterfeit goods — including fake Rolex, Coach, Prada and Gucci products — with an estimated street value of more than $1 million. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who announced the raids, also said that the city had obtained a temporary restraining order to shut the storefronts.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Random Observations
text: North Korea has been trying hard to counter issues often reported about the country: famine, malnourishment, lack of heat, isolation. As mentioned, the heat is blasting in places where the contingent following the New York Philharmonic congregates and in hotel rooms. Photographing has been unfettered. And food at the banquet on Monday night was abundant. The breakfast buffet on Tuesday, too, was vast. A colleague who came late reported a poignant moment: the waiters and waitresses were taking pictures of the food.

headline: Soft Serve | Tunes by Perez Hilton, Coconut Jet Fuel, Doggie Vitamin Water
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.Wanna enjoy the daily dish while listening to iTunes? Gossip gangster Perez Hilton is in talks to get his own music imprint from Warner Brothers… If your house isn’t getting the paparazzi attention it deserves, hire an (expensive) photographer to do it for you… For those with an unfurnished abode, opt for a quick fix with a Room In a Box… Need a houseplant for your pad? Botanicals Twitter will alert you on your Blackberry when your green friend needs some H20… If you’re sick of vacationing on land, soon you’ll be able to check out a number of exotic underwater hotels… Jet fuel may soon be just as tropical as your destination. Virgin Atlantic recently pureed 150,000 coconuts to help fuel a 747… If you are worried that your canine companion is getting parched, there’s now vitamin water for fido… For many, a morning cup of coffee is crucial, but in Texas a man tipped a waitress a thoroughbred racehorse after his cup of joe… Caffeine addicts should be wary of tomorrow’s nationwide Starbucks closure from 5:30-8:30pm. We’ll be on the lookout for rabid Olsens… That’s all for today’s fluffy fix. Come back tomorrow for another dose.

headline: Answers to Reader Questions
text: Thank you for all your responses to my first post and the questions you submitted last week. I’ll do my best to answer a few here.

headline: Unroll Your Own
