headline: Radio silence
text: I haven’t died, or lost my will to be annoying. The shameful truth is that — dare I tell you this? — I’ve been doing algebra. Deadlines to meet (actually to avoid missing by more than I already have), and I’m not even looking at the news until this stuff is out the door.

headline: Writers Ratify New Contract
text: The Associated Press reports:

headline: The Last Waltz? The Democratic Debate in Cleveland
text: Wrapup: This was a debate of several strong, sharp moments that may not have added up to a game-changer for Mrs. Clinton but it gave her a chance to get back to basics — health care, fighter, woman — and to express regret (again) for her vote for the war in Iraq.

headline: What We Learned Today
text: It’s that time of year again: spring training games. The Mets open their season Wednesday against the Tigers in Lakeland, Fla., where Ryan Church will be your only regular position player making the trip. In that spirit, this is as good a point as any to remind you, dear fans, that the outcomes of these games aren’t as important as what transpires in them – there’s a difference.

headline: The Akhdam of Yemen
text: In Yemen, the Akhdam, a word meaning "servants," live in extreme poverty and at the absolute margins of Yemeni society.

headline: Evolving Mistakes
text: Being the second part of an occasional series looking at mutations.

headline: Democrats Debate in Cleveland
text: Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama set aside their cordiality Tuesday evening in their final debate before the pivotal March 4 primaries.

headline: G.M. Voices Confidence in Lending Business
text: DETROIT  Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

headline: Democrats Raise Legal Point Over McCain and Ohio as He Opts Out of Public Money
text: CINCINNATI  Did Senator John McCain of Arizona benefit unfairly from rules that automatically placed him on the ballot in Ohio once he qualified for public campaign financing?

headline: Raymond Smith, Founder and Editor of Literary Journal, Dies at 77
text: Raymond J. Smith, a founder and the longtime editor of The Ontario Review, a noted literary journal, died on Feb. 18 in Princeton, N.J. He was 77 and lived in Princeton.

headline: Ivy League’s Director to Step Down After an Era of Change
text: PRINCETON, N.J.  In the mid-1980s, the Ivy League was going nowhere fast. The days of leather helmets and Rose Bowl glory were long gone, and the league, which began formal play only in 1956, seemed headed for irrelevance.

headline: Pondering Public Uses for a Hall Named Great
text: What if you had a majestic skylighted, columned hall in a Beaux-Arts ferry building at the tip of Manhattan and were required to use it as a public space? What would you do with it?

headline: Huck and Jim Rewrite Story, Sing and Add Their 2 Cents
text: In a “Notice” to his novel “The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,” Mark Twain advised: “Persons attempting to find a motive in this narrative will be prosecuted; persons attempting to find a moral in it will be banished; persons attempting to find a plot in it will be shot.” The author didn’t say what he had in mind for persons wanting to rewrite it, but it couldn’t have been very pleasant.

headline: Now on the Campaign Trail, a Reined-In Bill Clinton
text: LANCASTER, Ohio  The long campaign has taken some of the fight out of the Big Dog.

headline: Child Welfare Supervisor Suspended in L.I. Case of 3 Dead Children
text: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Acknowledging a series of mistakes by child welfare officials, the Nassau County executive announced on Tuesday that he had suspended a supervisor who he said had not adequately followed up a complaint against a Long Island woman who is now accused of drowning her three young children.

headline: New-Home Sales and Prices Continue to Drop
text: Sharply lower prices failed to perk up sales of new homes in January, a government report showed on Wednesday, as a closely watched index fell to its lowest point in 13 years.

headline: Starbucks Takes a 3-Hour Coffee Break
text: At Starbucks stores across the country on Tuesday night, it was time for the corporate version of re-education camp.

headline: A Disaster Relegated to Second Place by the Events of 9/11
text: Had 9/11 not happened, 2/26 would have been the worst day of terrorism in New York’s modern history.

headline: Islanders Trade Simon Before Losing to Penguins
text: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  The Islanders finally gave up on Chris Simon. By late Tuesday afternoon, his blue equipment bag had been packed and it sat in the hallway outside the team’s locker room at Nassau Coliseum, ready to be hauled to Minnesota.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Saturday about the death of an eighth-grade boy in Oxnard, Calif., whose killing is being called a hate crime by prosecutors, misidentified the group that is pushing for a legislative review of anti-bias policies in California schools. It is the Gay-Straight Alliance Network, not the Gay-Straight Alliance. (The network coordinates clubs in California schools that operate under the name Gay-Straight Alliance.)

headline: What You Get for ... $500,000
text: South Egremont, Mass.

headline: The Legions of Frozen Yogurt Push East
text: ACCORDING to Herodotus, even the mighty armies of the Greek and Persian empires took the winter off from warfare.

headline: Racket in the Kitchen, Ruckus in the Crib
text: I AM the silent chef.

headline: Upset Sends Democrat to Albany
text: ALBANY  In a major victory for Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his party, a Democratic assemblyman won a stunning upset in a State Senate election on Tuesday in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century.

headline: F.D.A. and Disk Maker Questioned
text: A ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of an artificial spinal disk about potential financial conflicts of many of the doctors involved in the clinical research that led to F.D.A. approval of the device.

headline: Gazprom Moves Into Coal as a Way to Increase Gas Exports
text: MOSCOW  Gazprom, the world’s largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

headline: Not Everyone Spins Their Wheels
text: Paris

headline: Wildfires Burn in Texas
text: ROBERT LEE, Tex. (AP)  Officials kept watch Tuesday on a wildfire threatening this town of 1,500 people, but evacuated residents were allowed to return.

headline: Binding Emissions Treaty Still a Possibility, U.S. Says
text: PARIS  A senior White House official on Tuesday outlined a new tactic aimed at convincing a skeptical Europe that the Bush administration would support a meaningful agreement to limit global warming.

headline: Surgeon Accused of Speeding a Death to Get Organs
text: SAN LUIS OBISPO, Calif.  On a winter night in 2006, a disabled and brain damaged man named Ruben Navarro was wheeled into an operating room at a hospital here. By most accounts, Mr. Navarro, 25, was near death, and doctors hoped that he might sustain other lives by donating his kidneys and liver.

headline: Witness Gives House Committee More Information About Clemens
text: C. J. Nitkowski, who gave a telephone interview under oath as part of the Congressional investigation into Roger Clemens’s suspected use of performance-enhancing drugs, said Tuesday that he had provided more information to the committee since a public hearing on the matter Feb. 13.

headline: Unfurling a Musical Thank You
text: Among Ralph Shapey’s last pieces were two quintets for the Juilliard String Quartet and specific soloists, the clarinetist Charles Neidich and the pianist Gilbert Kalish. The scores were not commissioned, and the musicians didn’t know about them until after Shapey’s death in 2002. Shapey composed them as gestures of friendship, in gratitude to players who had championed his music over many years.

headline: Lottery Numbers
One Nation, Indivisible
text: Belgrade, Serbia

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Feb. 18 about the cancellation of some campaign events in Wisconsin because of a snowstorm misspelled the name of a town there. It is Menomonee Falls, not Menominee Falls.

headline: City Agrees to Settlement in Parks Dept. Bias Case
text: Moving to close the books on a long and ugly chapter in New York’s employment history, the city has agreed to pay more than $20 million to settle a federal class-action lawsuit charging that the Department of Parks and Recreation systematically discriminated against black and Hispanic employees in awarding jobs and setting salaries, lawyers for the plaintiffs said Tuesday.

headline: Competing on Calls That Aren’t Just Elk to Elk
text: RENO, Nev.  Maddie Smith took a deep breath, the better to get in touch with her inner elk. Nine and nervous, she turned her back on the denim-and-camouflage-clad audience below her. Slowly she bent over, put a piece of soft corrugated plastic pipe to her lips, and began to recreate the soprano bugle of a bull elk.

headline: Study Finds Death Risk From Anemia Drugs
text: Widely used anemia drugs sold by Amgen and Johnson & Johnson raise the risk of death among cancer patients by about 10 percent, according to a new analysis of previous clinical trials that is to be published Wednesday.

headline: Democrats Clash on Trade, Health and Tactics
text: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton confronted Senator Barack Obama on health care, Nafta, Iraq and his political tactics on Tuesday night in one of her most pugnacious debate performances of the campaign, as she fought for fresh momentum before four potentially decisive nominating contests next Tuesday.

headline: Warrantless Searches Removed From Legislation in Mexico
text: MEXICO CITY  Mexican lawmakers on Tuesday stripped a controversial provision from their plan to overhaul the country’s judiciary that would have given police officers, who are widely mistrusted here, the ability to enter homes without obtaining warrants beforehand.

headline: A Watercolorist Who Turned His Hand to Oils of Heroic Vision
text: Search the history of American art, and you will discover few watercolors more beautiful than those of Charles Demuth. Combining exacting botanical observation and loosely Cubist abstraction, his watercolors of flowers, fruit and vegetables have a magical liveliness and an almost shocking sensuousness.

headline: Gas Prices Soar, Posing a Threat to Family Budget
text: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged behind the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts saying they could approach $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily, and crude oil rose above $102 in trading Wednesday after settling at a record high of $100.88 a barrel on Tuesday.

headline: Small and Midsize U.S. Banks Beginning to Struggle in Credit Crisis
text: The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

headline: Dan Shomron, Leader of Entebbe Airport Rescue, Is Dead at 70
text: Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, a former chief of Israel’s general staff and the paratroop commander who planned and led the storied 1976 raid in which Israeli troops freed 103 hijacked hostages at Entebbe Airport in Uganda, died yesterday in Israel. He was 70.

headline: In Wiretap Law’s Stead, Uncertainty
text: WASHINGTON  All last week, intelligence officials fielded calls from nervous lawyers for the country’s phone companies. With a wiretapping law allowed to lapse in Congress, they were no longer certain what they were supposed to do when the government came to them with a wiretapping order, administration officials said.

headline: Magic Proves Too Tough for Nets Late in Game
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Even if the Izod Center had been full Tuesday night, instead of half-empty, the giant Turkish flag would have been easy to spot.

headline: Not Ready to Pay for TV Time, a Mexican Beer Goes Online
text: DECADES ago, brewers determined that television commercials were just about the best way to sell beer, as anyone can attest who has listened to consumers still able to sing jingles like “This Bud’s for you,” “Tonight, let it be Löwenbräu” or “A beer is a beer is a beer is a beer until you’ve tasted Hamm’s.”

headline: A Stew With a Past and a Future
text: IT is hard for me to cook for people I don’t like. I don’t have to do it often, but when I do, I find it a torment because cooking is so personal, so revealing. Even more than sex, I think.

headline: New Twist Keeps Dickey’s Career Afloat
text: PEORIA, Ariz.  By all rights, R. A. Dickey should be working a day job somewhere, cursing twisted fate. Or he should be coaching at some Tennessee high school, telling kids what he once was and lamenting what might have been.

headline: No Laughs, No Thrills, and Villains All Too Real
text: BERLIN  The other morning Jens Augner, slight and owlish, a schoolteacher in his 40s, quizzed his eighth-grade class of 13- and 14-year-olds at the Humboldt Gymnasium, a local school. As part of a trial program, he has just introduced a new history textbook into the curriculum: to be exact, a comic book about the Holocaust, called “The Search.”

headline: Go Back to Black
text: London

headline: Two Siblings Stuck in a Junkyard World, Struggling to Survive and Dream
text: Because the last shot of Ramin Bahrani’s “Chop Shop” is as quiet and matter-of-fact as most of the rest of the film, it takes a moment to register as a metaphor. For nearly an hour and a half we have been immersed in the rhythms of daily life in the battered Willets Point section of Queens, and Mr. Bahrani’s hand-held camera has remained studiously fixed at street level. Now, all of a sudden, it pitches upward to follow a flock of pigeons breaking toward the sky, a shift in perspective that also changes, subtly but unmistakably, our understanding of the movie.

headline: There Will Be Floods
text: LAST month, a 30-foot section of levee ruptured in Fernley, Nev. While the cause of the breach, which swamped 450 homes and forced dozens of people to evacuate, is unknown, anyone familiar with the drowning of New Orleans by Hurricane Katrina will tell you this: Levees fail.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a court ruling allowing Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, to review documents on certain questionable transactions that led to his ouster, misidentified the founder of A.I.G. It was Cornelius Vander Starr, not Mr. Greenberg.

headline: Studies on Depression and Teenagers
text: Depressed teenagers who are not helped by antidepressants like Celexa or Prozac may improve if they switch drugs and receive a certain type of behavioral therapy, a review of studies found. A separate analysis of 35 clinical trials of antidepressants in adults submitted to regulators found that the drugs were no more effective than placebos, other than a small minority with the most severe levels of depression. The study of adolescents, published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, gives mental health professionals guidance about how to treat teenagers who do not improve using antidepressants, said David Brent, a psychiatrist at the Western Psychiatric Institute at the University of Pittsburgh.

headline: Late-Night TV Satires Become Online Hits
text: LOS ANGELES  The worst-kept secret in Hollywood on Oscar night was whom Jimmy Kimmel was sleeping with.

headline: A Loss in Los Angeles
text: An independent Los Angeles bookstore with a national following and local client base of writers and movie stars will close on April 30 after 23 years as a neighborhood meeting spot for dog walkers and a refuge for readers. Dutton’s Brentwood Books, in the Brentwood neighborhood, is known for its thorough stock of classic, new and esoteric literature and a staff of bibliophiles far more familiar with their wares than most employees at corporate chains. More than $500,000 of debt and competition from chain stores and online vendors led Doug Dutton, the owner, to announce his plans to close in a statement on the store’s Web site (duttonsbrentwood.com) on Tuesday. The property owners, Nancy and Charles T. Munger, said in a statement to The Los Angeles Times that they would allow Dutton’s to remain open rent-free through its liquidation.

headline: UConn and Adrien Dominate Rutgers
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  Connecticut does not need Jeff Adrien to dominate a game, but he did so anyway Tuesday night. Adrien, a junior forward, had a career-high 27 points and pulled down 11 rebounds as No. 15 Connecticut defeated slumping Rutgers, 79-61.

headline: North Korea Seeks a Clapton Concert
text: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday, as the New York Philharmonic was on the second day of its visit to North Korea, word emerged that North Korean officials have invited the guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.

headline: One Pot
text: THIS is a soulful dish: handmade meatball sausages subtly seasoned with onion, garlic, cumin, cinnamon, allspice and nutmeg and baked in a bubbling tomato sauce.

headline: Jury Selection Starts in Corruption Trial of Mayor Who Ran Newark for 20 Years
text: NEWARK  Reviewing the questionnaires filled out on Tuesday by 135 potential jurors in the corruption trial of former Mayor Sharpe James, Judge William J. Martini of United States District Court said he was struck by the unusual number who had checked the box for Question 36. Many, it seemed, thought they might be swayed by racial, religious or ethnic bias, or by “personal sympathy” or “personal dislike” for Mr. James, his co-defendant or the lawyers and witnesses in the case.

headline: Writers Ratify Contract
text: Members of two writers’ unions ratified a three-year contract with Hollywood’s movie and television production companies on Monday, ending the entertainment industry’s most difficult labor negotiation in 20 years.

headline: Reborn After 3 Years’ Frantic Effort, Georgia’s Ballet Troupe Tours the U.S.
text: Nina Ananiashvili was having a busy season dancing fragile swans and hot-blooded flirts with American Ballet Theater when she received the phone call in May 2004. Would she meet with Mikheil Saakashvili, the new president of Georgia, in Tbilisi at her first opportunity?

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Books of The Times review on Feb. 15 of “The Middle-Class Millionaire,” about a new demographic group that can afford expensive new personal services, overstated the cost of concierge-type medicine. Patients pay a retainer of as much as $20,000 a year, not a month.

headline: William F. Buckley Jr. Is Dead at 82
text: William F. Buckley Jr., who marshaled polysyllabic exuberance, famously arched eyebrows and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse, died Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

headline: Superdelegates, or Ordinary Voters?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nortel Posts Loss and Plans More Job Cuts
text: OTTAWA  Nortel Networks, the telecommunications company long plagued by bookkeeping troubles, reported a $957 million loss for 2007, largely because of a huge accounting adjustment. The company also said it would cut 2,100 jobs and move 1,000 othersto lower-wage countries.

headline: Lipitor’s Pitchman Gets the Boot
text: Pfizer has been relying on the reputation of Dr. Robert Jarvik, one of the pioneers in designing artificial hearts, to bolster sales of Lipitor, its cholesterol-lowering drug. Now that a Congressional committee is investigating the credibility of those ads, the company has dropped Dr. Jarvik as its pitchman. It was a telling reminder that consumers, besieged by drug promotion ads on television and in print media, need to take what they see, hear and read with a very large grain of skepticism.

headline: Catching a Streamed-In Philharmonic Live From North Korea
text: It would of course have been fascinating to attend the New York Philharmonic’s concert on Tuesday night at the East Pyongyang Grand Theater in North Korea. Daniel J. Wakin, a reporter for The New York Times, was there to cover this breakthrough event, the first performance by an American orchestra in that totalitarian country.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and an article in Business Day on Friday about a recall of 143 million pounds of beef, some of which was used in federal nutrition programs, misstated the reason for the recall. The federal Food Safety and Inspection Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, labeled the beef unfit for human food because of violations of food safety regulations. It did not deem it “tainted” or “contaminated.” (An article on Tuesday about some of the beef that was sent to New Jersey schools repeated the error.) (Go to Article)

headline: WHNT’s Technical Glitches
text: In 1955, when WLBT-TV, the NBC affiliate in Jackson, Miss., did not want to run a network report about racial desegregation, it famously hung up the sign: “Sorry, Cable Trouble.” Audiences in northern Alabama might have suspected the same tactics when WHNT-TV, the CBS affiliate, went dark Sunday evening during a “60 minutes” segment that strongly suggested that Don Siegelman, Alabama’s former Democratic governor, was wrongly convicted of corruption last year.

headline: 9. Tilth
text: 1411 North 45th Street, Seattle; (206) 633-0801; tilthrestaurant.com.

headline: Suitors Are Set to Say to Leno, Long Live King
text: LOS ANGELES  The Jay Leno chase is on.

headline: Britain Convicts 7 of Terrorist Training
text: LONDON  A London court on Tuesday convicted seven men of involvement in a terrorist training plot that included “camping weekends” in remote English parkland. During the sessions, dozens of young Muslims were trained to throw imaginary grenades, to stage mock ambushes with rifles fashioned from branches and to chop watermelons in simulated beheadings.

headline: Struggling to Squelch an Internet Rumor
text: Prof. Jeremy D. Popkin returned to his office at the University of Kentucky on Feb. 19 after teaching a lesson about Vichy France in his course on the Holocaust. During its 30 years on the curriculum, the class has grown perpetually popular, with 60 applicants vying for half as many seats. The university has even created a Judaic Studies program.

headline: South Africa: Power Crisis Puts Jobs at Risk
text: The economic fallout from South Africa’s electricity crisis continued to reverberate as Gold Fields, the second largest gold producer, announced that it might cut up to 6,900 jobs, 13 percent of its work force, because of a 10 percent power reduction by the state utility, Eskom. It said its production would decline by 20 to 25 percent this quarter because of the power cuts. The National Union of Mineworkers, which represents 320,000 workers, said its members would “take to the streets” if there were major job cuts.

headline: For the Press, a Closely Guided Tour of Pyongyang
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  Journalists in town for the New York Philharmonic’s historic concert on Tuesday received a grand tour of this capital’s sites by North Korean officials eager to show off the glories of the revolution.

headline: Regulator to Lift Caps on Fannie and Freddie
text: Federal regulators for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest buyers of American home mortgages, will remove limits on the amount of loans and securities the companies can own, a step that could help bolster the weakening housing market.

headline: Sony Gamesman Quits
text: After 15 years of helping to build Sony’s globe-spanning video game empire, Phil Harrison, below,  is leaving the company. Now president of Sony’s worldwide game development studios, Mr. Harrison announced on Monday that he would resign Friday. Mr. Harrison joined Sony in 1992 and has become perhaps the most public face of the company’s game business. After dominating the last generation of gaming with its PlayStation 2, the company has failed to maintain its leadership more recently with the PlayStation 3 amid new challenges from its rivals Microsoft and Nintendo. The company said that Kazuo Hirai, Mr. Harrison’s boss as chief executive of Sony’s overall game unit, would assume Mr. Harrison’s duties. Mr. Harrison raised eyebrows in the game industry last week when he criticized Sony’s failure to recognize the growth of casual, social gaming. Nintendo has embraced that trend while Sony has largely focused on complicated, sometimes violent fare directed at young men.

headline: When Is a Bar Not a Bar?
text: IN an era of casual dressing, piecemeal supping and food as the adjunct to wine, is a restaurant’s best bet to pretend it’s less than it is? Should it persuade diners that it doesn’t harbor big ambitions or demand close attention, even if the opposite is true?

headline: A Reluctant Partygoer, a Grieving Father, Now a Witness
text: William Bell did not want to go to the party. It felt awkward, going to his son’s bachelor bash at a strip club. It just was not his kind of place. “Be with your friends,” he told his son, Sean.

headline: Ousted Premier Is Set to Return to Thailand, Officials Say
text: BANGKOK  Seventeen months after being ousted in a military coup, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra was set to return to Thailand on Thursday, officials close to him said Tuesday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,963 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: The Scottish Play Steps In
text: Witch: All hail, “Macbeth,” thou shalt be on Broadway hereafter! Macbeth: Tell me more. I know I am a hit at BAM, but to be on Broadway stands not within the prospect of belief. Say from whence you owe this strange intelligence? Well, it just so happens that the Broadway production of Mark Twain’s new-old play, “Is He Dead?,” is closing on March 9, when it will have played 13 previews and 105 regular performances at the Lyceum theater. The show, an adaptation by David Ives of a recently discovered Twain manuscript, was generally well reviewed, and its star, Norbert Leo Butz, drew raves. But the stagehands’ strike, a traffic jam of plays  some of which received stellar reviews  and the traditionally bad winter months helped do it in. “If I thought I could stay open through May, I would, but financially it just doesn’t make sense,” Bob Boyett, the lead producer, said.And it also just so happens that “Macbeth,” like its title character, is duly poised to fill the vacancy. The production, starring Patrick Stewart, is to begin performances at the Lyceum at the end of March for an eight-week run.

headline: A Husband’s Personal Tale of Life on the Home Front
text: Never mind that warning about cellphones; there’s a moment midway through James Braly’s “Life in a Marital Institution” that may prompt you to pull yours out and report Mr. Braly to the child-welfare authorities.

headline: Florida Blackouts Affect One Million Across State
text: MIAMI  A wide-ranging blackout swept across Florida on Tuesday, affecting nearly one million households and businesses, knocking out traffic signals and trapping scores of people in elevators. It also forced two nuclear reactors to shut down.

headline: Russia Quietly Starts to Shift Its Oil Trade Into Rubles
text: MOSCOW  Americans surely found little to celebrate when the price of oil settled above $100 a barrel last week.

headline: City Agents Shut Down 32 Vendors of Fake Items
text: It is a vibrant fixture of Lower Manhattan commerce. Tourists jostle for space at Canal Street’s stores and sidewalk kiosks, bargaining with vendors over sparkly watches, handbags and perfumes with fake designer labels that are sold at a fraction of the cost of the genuine item.

headline: U.S. Among Countries Investigating Tax Evasion
text: FRANKFURT  Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: Argentina: ‘Dirty War’ Suspect Found Dead
text: A military officer linked to crimes during Argentina’s dictatorship was found dead, the second in three months. The body of Lt. Col. Paul Alberto Navone, who was suspected of kidnapping babies during the “dirty war” from 1976 to 1983, was found with a gunshot to the head at a hotel in Asochinga, in Córdoba, according to a lawyer involved in the case. He was to testify next week as part of an investigation into the kidnapping of babies of political prisoners. While the police said that a gun found next to him suggested suicide, rights advocates suggested murder. “They are eliminating the military officers being investigated for the dictatorship’s crimes,” Estela de Carlotto, president of the Mothers of the Plaza de Mayo, said in a radio interview. Marina Barbagelata, a lawyer involved in prosecuting the Navone case, said on television that it was “highly probable that there were people that could have seen themselves threatened by what he would say.” During the dictatorship, about 500 babies were kidnapped from their parents, of whom 88 have been identified through the efforts of rights advocates, Agence France-Presse reported. On Dec. 10, Héctor Febres, a former coast guard officer, was found dead in his prison cell, poisoned by cyanide. The authorities said they believed that he was ready to disclose details about the kidnapped babies.

headline: North Korea Invites Clapton, Too
text: LOS ANGELES  On Tuesday, as the New York Philharmonic was on the second day of its visit to North Korea, North Korean officials invited the superstar rock guitarist Eric Clapton to perform there, according to a representative for the North Korean Embassy in London.

headline: North Koreans Welcome Symphonic Diplomacy
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  As the New York Philharmonic played the opening notes of “Arirang,” a beloved Korean folk song, a murmur rippled through the audience. Many in the audience perched forward in their seats.

headline: A Case-by-Case Ruling on Discrimination
text: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled Tuesday in a closely watched job discrimination case that allegations that a plaintiff’s co-workers had also suffered discrimination, offered as evidence of a biased corporate culture, may be admissible in court  some of the time.

headline: Candles and Bagpipes Honor Officer Killed 20 Years Ago
text: He was a stranger to most of the men and women with whom he worked, and he died a stranger. And early Tuesday, exactly 20 years after he was gunned down in the line of duty, Officer Edward Byrne was honored by strangers.

headline: Finding Their Way Home, or at Least to the Garden

headline: Flooded Village Files Suit, Citing Corporate Link to Climate Change
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Lawyers for the Alaska Native coastal village of Kivalina, which is being forced to relocate because of flooding caused by the changing Arctic climate, filed suit in federal court here Tuesday arguing that 5 oil companies, 14 electric utilities and the country’s largest coal company were responsible for the village’s woes.

headline: 10. Central Michel Richard
text: 1001 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington; (202) 626-0015; centralmichelrichard.com.

headline: Ohioans Hear Populist Pleas by Democrats
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio  For as long as anyone here can remember, presidential hopefuls have made this scrappy, blue-collar stronghold an obligatory pit stop on the Democratic stump.

headline: A Highflier Loses Altitude as Google’s Clicks Go Flat
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Are Internet users clicking on fewer Google ads and putting the company’s growth prospects at risk?

headline: Bush Vows to Veto a Mortgage Relief Bill
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush sided with banks and mortgage lenders on Tuesday, threatening to veto a bill being offered by Senate Democrats that would give more bargaining power to homeowners who face foreclosure.

headline: One of 5 Bidders Backs Off on Building Over Railyards
text: One of the five bidders for the development rights over the West Side railyards failed to submit a revised offer on Tuesday for the tract, the largest development site in Manhattan.

headline: Quill Awards Are Ended
text: Reed Business Information said it had “suspended support” of the Quill Awards program, Publishers Weekly reported. Winners of the 19 awards for books, established in 2005 in an attempt to infuse the publishing industry with some pizazz, were selected by the public in online voting. A spokeswoman for Reed Business Information, a founder of the awards and a parent of Publishers Weekly and Variety, declined to give further details, the Canadian Press news agency reported. The company went up for sale last week. The Reed announcement said that as part of the “dissolution” of Quills, the remaining money of the Quills Literacy Foundation, a philanthropy associated with the awards, would be distributed to First Book and to Literacy Partners, nonprofit organizations. NBC televised the annual black-tie awards ceremony.

headline: Fire Department Defends New Tactic Blamed in Blaze
text: The Fire Department on Tuesday defended an experiment with new dispatching rules in Queens, saying that it had sharply lowered response times.

headline: Humane Society Criticized in Meat Quality Scandal
text: WASHINGTON  As the meat industry scrambles to recover from a public-relations disaster over an undercover video of abused cattle, the secretary of agriculture and at least one congressman have picked an unlikely target to share in the blame: the Humane Society of the United States.

headline: Expressing National Pride, Without a Flag Pin
text: To the Editor:

headline: On the Brink of Destruction, Singing to the Beat of a New Religion
text: Given America’s latest war, it’s not surprising that Kurt Vonnegut’s absurdist satirical takedowns of man’s destructive impulses are showing up in the theater. In January there was Joe Tantalo’s staging Off Broadway of Vonnegut’s masterpiece, “Slaughterhouse-Five,” and now Edward Einhorn and Henry Akona have created a musical adaptation of an earlier, even more apocalyptic novel, the 1963 “Cat’s Cradle,” for the Untitled Theater Company No. 61.

headline: Martínez Would Be Open to Mets Extension
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Pedro Martínez knows he has a lot to prove with the Mets this season, knows that the one solid month he had last September has not answered all the questions about whether he can successfully return from rotator cuff surgery almost 17 months ago.

headline: Senate Democrats Focus on Economic Cost of War
text: WASHINGTON  Undeterred by President Bush and Senator John McCain proudly pointing to progress in Iraq, Congressional Democrats are trying to mount new lines of attack against the administration’s war policies.

headline: U.S. and Czechs Close on Radar Plan
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush and the leader of the Czech Republic said on Wednesday that they are close to agreement on a plan for the United States to install an early warning radar system in the Czech Republic, a key component of a missile defense system that has drawn stiff opposition from Russia.

headline: Gas Prices Soar, Posing a Threat to Family Budget
text: Gasoline prices, which for months lagged behind the big run-up in the price of oil, are suddenly rising quickly, with some experts saying they could approach $4 a gallon by spring. Diesel is hitting new records daily, and oil settled at a record high of $100.88 a barrel on Tuesday.

headline: 'Raisin' Nourishes ABC
text: Averaging 12.7 million viewers, ABC’s Monday broadcast of “A Raisin in the Sun,” with Sean Combs and Phylicia Rashad, lifted the network to No. 1 in that night’s ratings, according to Nielsen’s estimates. A made-for-television movie, it won every hour of prime time except the 8 p.m. slot, when it trailed NBC’s “Deal or No Deal” (15.3 million). After a six-week streak of leading on Monday nights among adults 18 to 49, NBC finished in second place over all as its new game show, “My Dad Is Better Than Your Dad,” at 9 (7.8 million), suffered a decline of 2 million viewers from its debut a week ago. CBS and Fox were third and fourth for the night, with CBS drawing more total viewers and Fox, buoyed by “The Moment of Truth” at 8 (8.6 million), faring better with the 18-to-49 set. Fox’s “Terminator: The Sarah Connor Chronicles” drew lower ratings at 9 (7.1 million). On Friday the cable series “Monk” ended its sixth season on USA Network, delivering the show’s largest audience on record, 6.9 million viewers.

headline: China Says It Will Resume Human Rights Talks
text: BEIJING  China said Tuesday that it would resume a human rights dialogue with the United States, in a move that appeared to be aimed at countering criticism from activists ahead of the Olympic Games here in August.

headline: Anne Frank's True Love
text: Anne Frank called Peter Schiff her “one true love.” Now his photograph, below, is to be displayed in the Anne Frank House museum in Amsterdam, which is dedicated to her memory, Agence France-Presse reported. The photograph was given to the museum by Peter’s childhood friend Ernest Michaelis, now 81, who visited the museum last month with his children and grandchildren. The Observer Magazine reported in London on Sunday that Mr. Michaelis came to realize that the childhood friend in a photograph given him as he left Germany for Britain was the 13-year-old boy that the 11-year-old Anne Frank later wrote about in her diary. “I’m such an idiot,” she wrote on Jan. 7, 1944. “I forgot that I haven’t yet told you the story of my one true love. I can still see us walking hand in hand through our neighborhood.” Anne Frank died in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp the next year. Peter Schiff, whose family, like Frank’s, fled Germany for the Netherlands, died in Auschwitz or Bergen-Belsen.

headline: Corzine Seeks to Cut N.J. Budget and Work Force
text: TRENTON  Declaring that New Jersey had reached an irrevocable “turning point” because of years of bad fiscal habits, Gov. Jon S. Corzine proposed a budget on Tuesday that would reduce the state’s work force by 3,000 people, close three departments and prune expenses for services including colleges and hospitals.

headline: Fed Chief Signals He’s Open to More Rate Cuts
text: WASHINGTON  Having already slashed short-term interest rates by almost half since August, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke, signaled on Wednesday that more rate cuts  which is to say more cheap money  may lie ahead.

headline: Bus Accident Snarls Traffic Near Port Authority
text: The morning commute into midtown Manhattan was snarled for thousands of travelers Wednesday morning when an accident cut off road access to the Port Authority Bus Terminal for about an hour.

headline: Presidents Cup Captains Are Couples and Norman
text: Fred Couples and Greg Norman, two of golf’s most popular figures and dominant players in the 1980s and ’90s, have been named captains for the 2009 Presidents Cup.

headline: A Rule Just Waiting to Be Broken
text: “RED wine with oysters? Are you mad?”

headline: 43 Days Without a Homicide, and Then a Newark Man Is Shot
text: A 43-day stretch without a homicide in Newark  the city’s longest such period in decades  came to an end Tuesday night in front of a bodega in the violence-prone South Ward, where the police said a young man was fatally shot in the head.

headline: 2 Charged With Demanding Payoffs From Contractors
text: Armed with little more than hard hats and a fancy name, two men posing as building inspectors carried out an extortion scheme that gave a sinister new twist to the idea of civic virtue, prosecutors said Tuesday.

headline: Aetna to Still Pay for Colonoscopy Drug
text: Bowing to critics who contended it was putting profits before patients, Aetna said Wednesday that it has suspended  at least temporarily  a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.

headline: Prosecution Plays Defense on How Girl Was Killed
text: Prosecutors in the trial of a man charged in the killing of Nixzmary Brown went on the defensive for the first time on Tuesday, aggressively cross-examining a medical expert called by the defense who had disputed the prosecution’s theory that long-term abuse helped cause the girl’s death.

headline: E.P.A. Staff Lobbied Boss on Decision on Emissions
text: WASHINGTON  Senior nonpolitical staff members at the Environmental Protection Agency wrote an impassioned plea for a former agency chief to deliver to the current E.P.A. administrator about an important decision on greenhouse gas emissions from cars, according to documents released Tuesday by a Senate committee.

headline: Providence Begins to See Its Future Around the Corner
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  This is a city of 25 diverse neighborhoods, many with distinctive New England character, but it is Downcity that is the urban core and the city’s historical heart.

headline: Annan Tries to Spur Kenya Talks
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kofi Annan suspended day-to-day mediation talks in Kenya on Tuesday and said he would now take up the remaining divisive issues with Kenya’s leaders directly.

headline: Judges Uphold Nigeria’s Presidential Election
text: ABUJA, Nigeria  A panel of judges has upheld the election of President Umaru Yar’Adua of Nigeria, ruling that the evidence of ballot-box stuffing and phantom voting booths presented by two challengers in the race was not enough to overturn the outcome.

headline: Suit Against ‘Predator’ Show Advances
text: A federal judge in New York ruled on Tuesday that a lawsuit contending that an NBC television series on pedophiles had played a role in the suicide of a Texas prosecutor two years ago could move forward.

headline: Dutch Bank Restricts Accounts of Americans
text: LONDON  ABN Amro, the Dutch bank bought by three European rivals last year, said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing “strategic reasons.”

headline: Dining Calendar
text: Cook Like a Ligurian

headline: Pilots’ Battles Over Seniority Play Havoc With Airline Mergers
text: Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines have been held up for a couple of weeks while pilots at each carrier discuss how to combine their union seniority lists.

headline: Yanks Aim for Giambi to Return to First
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The winter meetings will be in Las Vegas in December. That is where Jason Giambi lives. So what are the chances Giambi hits the town with a general manager and winds up with a rich new contract?

headline: Belarus Opposition Leader Freed for Wife’s Funeral
text: MOSCOW  Authorities in Belarus temporarily freed Aleksandr V. Kazulin, an imprisoned opposition politician who threatened to starve himself if not permitted to attend his wife’s funeral.

headline: Outrageously Transgressing Boundaries
text: Pick an artist, any artist, and imagine him announcing that he has excised from his production a magical flight of fancy involving Joan Didion, ruby slippers, time travel and Anne Frank. Now exhale: theatrical horror averted.

headline: Getting Real About the Rescue
text: Some big banks are supporting new proposals to rescue homeowners who owe more on their mortgages than their houses are worth, but let’s get one thing straight: the banks haven’t been struck by a sudden urge to help the needy. Rather, by advocating bailouts, the lending industry is trying to head off a possible change in the law that would let troubled borrowers modify their mortgages in bankruptcy court  where lenders, not taxpayers, would be stuck with the losses.

headline: Coast to Coast, Restaurants That Count
text: I HAD called once to make my reservation, and then again to confirm it, but it wasn’t until I telephoned to say I was running late that I really heard the greeting.

headline: Losing Credibility, Piece by Piece
text: Call this the crumbling case of Roger Clemens.

headline: Hoops Hybrid Being Molded Into a League
text: SlamBall redux? The hybrid basketball-gymnastics extreme sport that had a short life on Spike in 2002 and 2003 is being resurrected for a “showcase” season to be taped in June with expectations of selling eight franchises before 2009.

headline: Cubans Wary of Raúl Castro’s Hints at Change
text: HAVANA  In his first state reception as Cuba’s president, Raúl Castro met Tuesday not with leftist Latin American leaders like Hugo Chávez and Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, nor with Chinese officials, but with the secretary of state of the Vatican, a traditional enemy of Communism and a critic of Cuba’s record on human rights.

headline: Bloomberg Ends Presidential Speculation
text: Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy.

headline: $60 Million Gift for Stony Brook
text: James H. Simons, a math professor-turned-hedge fund manager, is giving Stony Brook University $60 million, its largest gift ever and the largest gift to any public university in the state.

headline: Drug-Resistant TB Rates Soar in Former Soviet Regions
text: Drug-resistant tuberculosis cases in parts of the former Soviet Union have reached the highest rates ever recorded globally, the World Health Organization said Tuesday. The rates could soar even higher, spreading the potentially fatal disease elsewhere, a top W.H.O. official said, releasing findings from the largest global survey of the problem.

headline: 20th Debate: Reality Show or a Spinoff?
text: Everybody wanted to know which Hillary Rodham Clinton would show up to the Cleveland debate on Tuesday night. It turned out to be the Amy Poehler version.

headline: Dollar Weakens to $1.51 to the Euro
text: The dollar breached the level of $1.50 to the euro on Wednesday for the first time as fears of weakness in the United States economy mixed with evidence of resilience in Europe.

headline: A Downtown Impresario’s New Uptown Canvas
text: Between sets backstage at Joe’s Pub one evening recently, the crew was busy carrying out a menagerie of African drums for one act and carefully loading in a piano for the comedy-cabaret group coming up next. Inches away, fans crowded the merchandise table while the artists squeezed through to their dressing rooms, and patrons from a play down the hall rushed to the restrooms at intermission.

headline: Filings Show Take-Two Raised Management Payout in Takeover
text: Just days after Take-Two Interactive, the troubled video game maker, received a buyout offer from a rival, Electronic Arts, the board of Take-Two approved a measure that significantly increased the compensation that management would receive in a merger or takeover, according to regulatory filings.

headline: Languishing at the Bottom of Yemen’s Ladder
text: SANA, Yemen  By day, they sweep the streets of the Old City, ragged, dark-skinned men in orange jump suits. By night, they retreat to fetid slums on the edge of town.

headline: Moving On, Clemens Turns to Baseball
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Roger Clemens offered hugs, handshakes and advice to members of the Houston Astros on Tuesday, doing everything he could to become immersed in baseball again. He was under a canopied batting cage, not inside a Congressional hearing room, trying hard to behave like the tough-guy pitcher known as the Rocket.

headline: Footnote
text: It will be father-daughter night in Nashville on April 14 when Billy Ray Cyrus and Miley Cyrus, above, will be the hosts and perform at the seventh annual CMT Music Awards, The Associated Press reported. Other performers on the country music awards show, to be broadcast live on CMT, include Alan Jackson, Brad Paisley, Carrie Underwood, Sugarland, Taylor Swift and Toby Keith.

headline: Iraq Cabinet Demands Turks Leave Kurdish Area in North
text: BAGHDAD  The Iraqi government on Tuesday condemned Turkey’s raids into northern Iraq and demanded that Turkey withdraw its troops, as fighting continued for a sixth day between Turkish forces and Kurdish rebels.

headline: Union Strikes Parts Maker for G.M.
text: DETROIT  The United Automobile Workers union called its third strike in five months Tuesday, sending some 3,650 workers at parts factories in Michigan and New York off the job in opposition to proposed pay and benefits cuts, and to what it called unfair labor practices.

headline: Profit Rises at Macy’s and Falls at Target
text: The department store company Macy’s said Tuesday that lower costs sent fourth-quarter profit up more than analysts had expected, while Target reported that its sales declined.

headline: 2 Teenagers Are Accused of Torturing Ohio Woman
text: CINCINNATI  Two teenagers with long criminal records have been charged with torturing a young woman for at least six hours inside her home in rural southwestern Ohio.

headline: Israel: Court Backs Deal for Ex-President
text: The High Court upheld the plea bargain last year by which possible rape charges against former President Moshe Katsav, left, were dropped in exchange for his stepping down and pleading guilty to lesser charges. There has been fierce public criticism of the deal, and the court’s five-judge panel split 3 to 2 in its opinion. Chief Justice Dorit Beinisch was in the minority. The judges unanimously agreed that there was not sufficient evidence to charge Mr. Katsav with rape. Although Mr. Katsav has protested his innocence, he is to plead guilty to committing indecent acts without consent, sexual harassment of two women and harassing a witness. He faces a suspended sentence and payment of compensation, but no prison time.

headline: Gaza: Israeli Army Clears Itself in 21 Deaths
text: The army said no legal action would be taken against military officials over an artillery strike in Beit Hanun in 2006 in which an errant shell hit residential buildings and killed 21 Palestinian civilians. An army investigation concluded that the shell was fired based on information that militants were intending to fire rockets from the area, an army statement said. The civilian deaths, it said, were “directly due to a rare and severe failure” in the artillery control system. The army’s military advocate general concluded that there was no need for further investigation.

headline: Ashcroft to Testify in Congress on No-Bid Contract for His Firm
text: WASHINGTON  Former Attorney General John Ashcroft has agreed to testify to Congress about a multimillion-dollar no-bid contract steered to his consulting firm by the Justice Department under an out-of-court settlement between federal prosecutors and a medical-supply company, Congressional officials said Tuesday.

headline: Vladimir Putin’s Russia
text: The eight years of Vladimir Putin’s presidency have faithfully reflected his formative years in the Soviet secret police. Mr. Putin’s term ends this spring, but he is nearly certain to become prime minister. That means, we fear, that little will change. The next American president will have to deal with a Russia that is not only nuclear-armed but increasingly wealthy and increasingly authoritarian.

headline: Doctored Up in the Oven
text: MY desperation for good tomato flavor in the winter (documented here a few weeks ago in a column about sun-dried tomatoes) led me a year or two ago to try roasting canned tomatoes.

headline: British Government Ordered to Release Notes on Iraq
text: LONDON  Britain’s information commissioner has ordered the government to release the minutes of two cabinet meetings held in March 2003 under Tony Blair, then the prime minister, to discuss the legality of the allied invasion of Iraq that began later that month.

headline: Near Avignon, a Peaceful Retreat
text: OPPÈDE, France

headline: McCain Criticizes Obama on Al Qaeda
text: Senator John McCain, looking ahead to a possible general-election matchup with Senator Barack Obama, attacked Mr. Obama on Wednesday for what he called a weak and naïve approach to the conflict in Iraq and the effort to combat international terrorism.

headline: Europe Fines Microsoft $1.35 Billion
text: BRUSSELS  The European antitrust regulator levied a record $1.35 billion fine against Microsoft on Wednesday in a ruling designed to send a clear message to the world’s biggest software maker  and to any other company  of the dangers of flouting its competition rulings.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article in Business Day on Friday about Toyota’s global expansion misidentified the location of its European headquarters. It is outside Brussels, not outside Belgium. An accompanying article about Akio Toyoda, the grandson of the company’s founder and its probable next president, also misstated the location of Babson College, where he earned his M.B.A. It is in Wellesley, Mass., a suburb of Boston  not in Boston itself.

headline: The Politics of Trade in Ohio
text: Watching Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton compete with each other to say the nastiest possible thing about the Nafta trade deal has made me think about the politics of abortion.

headline: New Worries on Inflation and Homes
text: Houses are getting cheaper by the month. Everything else is becoming more expensive.

headline: For St. Anthony, a State Title Would Be the Perfect Ending
text: St. Anthony High School of Jersey City has the No. 1-ranked boys basketball team in the country, according to two polls. Six of its nine seniors have already signed to play for Division I teams, and two juniors are likely to follow. Their season is the focus of a documentary.

headline: Corrections
text: A headline and an article in Business Day on Friday about a recall of 143 million pounds of beef, some of which was used in federal nutrition programs, misstated the reason for the recall. The federal Food Safety and Inspection Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, labeled the beef unfit for human food because of violations of food safety regulations. It did not deem it “tainted” or “contaminated.” (An article on Tuesday about some of the beef that was sent to New Jersey schools repeated the error.)

headline: Run Wasn’t Cheap; Heilman Gets Off for a Song
text: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Aaron Heilman is a proud graduate of Notre Dame. Decal-on-the-car, donates-money proud, which made Tuesday’s exhibition against one of his alma mater’s biggest rivals, Michigan, a matter of great personal interest.

headline: A Complicated Challenge on One Side; a Single Task on the Other
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton entered the final debate before Tuesday’s critical primaries with two imperative goals: Challenge Senator Barack Obama’s qualifications to lead the country and raise doubts about his ability to defeat a Republican opponent as experienced as Senator John McCain.

headline: A Host Disparages Obama, and McCain Quickly Apologizes
text: CINCINNATI  Senator John McCain apologized Tuesday after a conservative radio host who helped introduce him before a rally used Senator Barack Obama’s middle name, Hussein, three times, while disparaging him.

headline: Going First Most of the Time
text: WASHINGTON  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton sounded almost put upon.

headline: Dallas and Pittsburgh Trade for Offense
text: On a frenetic day that included 25 trades, the Pittsburgh Penguins snatched the biggest prize, Atlanta forward Marian Hossa, less than two hours before the deadline Tuesday afternoon, adding one of the N.H.L.’s best snipers to a lineup that already features the high-scoring Sidney Crosby and Evgeni Malkin.

headline: Great Lakes Officials Seek Aid From U.S. and Canada
text: CHICAGO  Regional government agencies around the Great Lakes spend some $15 billion a year to protect the lakes from invasive species, contaminated sediment and sewage overflows, a new study shows. But local officials say that still more protection is needed and that the United States and Canadian governments should pay for it.

headline: Corporate Welfare Lives, Especially for Baseball
text: More than four years ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg claimed victory over one of the city’s longest-running three-card-monte operations: big companies demanding, and getting, tax breaks to remain in New York when they really weren’t going anywhere.

headline: Delays at Rijksmuseum
text: Renovation of the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam is unlikely to be finished until late 2012 or 2013, Reuters reported. The Dutch culture ministry said that the renovations were to have been completed this year, but a dispute with the building contractor over costs led to new delays at the museum, a major tourist attraction and home to some of the greatest works of the Dutch masters. In a face-lift reminiscent of the modernization of the Louvre in Paris, the Rijksmuseum, designed by Pierre Cuypers (1827-1921) and opened in 1885, is to have a huge new underground entrance hall. Since the main building closed, in 2003, paintings by Rembrandt, Frans Hals and Vermeer have remained on view in a wing.

headline: Steinbrenner, a Legend, Deserves a Field
text: One of the nicest things I have heard from baseball in a long time is taking place in Florida this spring training: the name of the Yankees’ ballpark in Tampa is being changed from Legends Field to Steinbrenner Field.

headline: Fancy Some Soldiers for Your Eggs, Mate?
text: Wartime rationing in Britain ended in 1954, just in time for the birth of John Haney. A good thing, too, because the boy had an appetite, gluttonously documented in “Fair Shares for All.” The greasy curtain in this food-and-family memoir rises on the 4-year-old John stuffing his face with “soldiers”  toast strips for dipping in soft-boiled egg  as if in training for the strenuous regime of sausages, mince pies, custard, beans on toast and bacon sandwiches to come.

headline: Survey Finds Teenagers Ignorant on Basic History and Literature Questions
text: Fewer than half of American teenagers who were asked basic history and literature questions in a phone survey knew when the Civil War was fought, and one in four said Columbus sailed to the New World some time after 1750, not in 1492.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening This Week

headline: From Witness in Police Killing, Tearful Recall of a Party Gone Bad
text: A riveted courtroom in Queens listened on Tuesday to the first witness testimony describing the 50 police gunshots that killed Sean Bell outside a strip club, delivered by an exotic dancer who saw part of the shooting before running around a corner and hiding in some bushes.

headline: In Las Vegas, Dubai World’s New Investment Sets Sales Record
text: Recent penthouse sales at the massive MGM CityCenter, which is now half-owned by Dubai World, set new records for price-per-square-foot in Las Vegas, according to the agent who made the sales.

headline: Who’s Who in the Baghdad Bureau
text: Update | May 21, 2009

headline: ‘Love and Consequences’
text: Lost

headline: The Sporting Life in Dubai
text: In their quest to bring us the biggest and best of everything, the Emirati billionaires are leaving no game unplayed.

headline: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper?
text: That’s the question we asked each member of our Hockey Night in Blogdom crew in 27 cities across North America in the shell-shocked aftermath of Tuesday’s trade deadline frenzy. Below are their thumbnail analyses for each deal, but there were so many trades that we have to split them into three separate posts. Here’s the first:

headline: Wrinkled but Formidable
text: The amazing career of Gil Miranda, the greatest senior softballer of all time.

headline: How to Get on the Baghdad Bureau Blogroll
text: Send your suggested links to baghdadbureau@nytimes.com and put “Baghdad Bureau blogroll” in the subject line.

headline: Taking Questions: Life Inside the Red Zone
text: It’s been too long since we last answered your questions on life in Iraq. The Baghdad Bureau blog will be answering as many questions as we can on a wide number of issues about the country, its people, the U.S. military, the private contractors and the media attempting to cover it all.

headline: Food Stuff
text: Fruit to Keep, for a Bit of Sweetness Out of Season

headline: Welcome: Dateline Baghdad
text: The Baghdad bureau of The New York Times serves as both home and office for 7 to 10 Western reporters, photographers and videographers, who work with a large Iraqi staff of reporters based in Baghdad and other cities across Iraq.

headline: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper? Part 2
text: Tampa Bay traded C Brad Richards and G Johan Holmqvist to Dallas for G Mike Smith, LW Jussi Jokinen, C Jeff Halpern and a fourth-round pick in the 2009 draft.

headline: How Accurate Were They in 2007?
text: Our guest blogger of the week:

headline: Super Return: The Big Buyout Questions
text: As a founder and managing director of The Carlyle Group, one of the world’s biggest private equity firms, David Rubenstein gets asked a lot of questions these days about the fate of the buyout business.

headline: Revenge, a Comic Dish Served Virally
text: A satiric video in which Jimmy Kimmel touts his sexual relationship with Ben Affleck is a huge hit online, today’s Times reports. It all began when Kimmel’s girlfriend, the comedian Sarah Silverman, revealed in a video that she was hooking up with Matt Damon:

headline: ‘Not Again': Fleeing My Home
text: “Hurry up, Mom, we don’t want to be late,” I called my mother after I heard the sound of an I.E.D., an improvised explosive device, blowing up. They would seal off the area and we would be trapped, that was my concern. My mother was running here and there in the house trying to pack as much stuff as she could. It was our last day. We had decided earlier that we couldn’t stay in our house anymore; the area was getting more and more dangerous and deserted.

headline: A Revamping for the Financial Accounting Standards Board
text: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, which sets American accounting rules, will have two fewer members and the power of its chairman will be increased, the board’s oversight body said on Tuesday.

headline: Gazprom Moves Into Coal
text: Gazprom, the world’s largest natural gas producer, acquired control of a leading Russian coal company in an asset merger announced Tuesday that extends its sprawling business empire into electricity.

headline: I.B.M. Plans $15 Billion Share Buyback
text: I.B.M. said on Tuesday that its board had authorized a $15 billion share buyback program that could increase 2008 earnings by up to 5 cents a share, sending its stock up 4.2 percent.

headline: ABN Amro Restricts Accounts of Americans
text: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank bought by three European rivals last year, said Tuesday that it was closing any portfolio investment accounts held by customers with a United States passport within 30 days, citing “strategic reasons.”

headline: Lucky Pai Rolls the Dice for Second Round
text: Lucky Pai, a Shanghai-based home-shopping network that hawks jewelry and electronics to millions of Chinese households, is showcasing-itself.

headline: FusionOne Picks Up $6 Million from V.C.’s
text: FusionOne, which creates applications and services for mobile devices, has raised $6 million in a Series A-1 preferred stock round for its mobile content backup services.

headline: Podcast: Examining Sadr’s Cease-Fire
text: Listen to the Podcast (mp3)

headline: U.S. Joins Countries Investigating Tax Evasion in Lichtenstein
text: Following the lead of Germany and Britain, at least eight other countries, including the United States, said Tuesday that they were investigating whether some of their citizens were using banks in Liechtenstein to evade taxes.

headline: G.M. Voices Confidence in Lending Business
text: Despite big losses at the auto and mortgage lender GMAC, General Motors is confident that its partner, the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management, can fix the troubled financing business.

headline: China Railway Seeks to Raise $5.4 Billion in I.P.O.
text: China Railway Construction announced a larger-than-expected $5.4 billion initial public offering that would be the world’s biggest so far this year, despite a cut in the number of shares to be listed in Shanghai amid market weakness.

headline: Loss Narrows at Sirius as It Awaits Ruling on Merger
text: Sirius Satellite Radio reported a narrower loss on Tuesday as it awaits regulatory action on its plans to combine with a rival, XM Satellite Radio Holdings.

headline: Chinalco Said to Weigh Options in Rio Tinto Stake
text: The Chinese aluminum giant Chinalco, which led a $14-billion investment in the global miner Rio Tinto, has not increased its Rio Tinto holding, despite an agreement that allows them to buy more, according to Reuters.

headline: Goldman Sachs Names 2 Vice Chairmen
text: Goldman Sachs said on Wednesday that it had appointed J. Michael Evans and Michael S. Sherwood as vice chairmen of the firm effective immediately.

headline: Morgan Stanley, Starwood Sell Tokyo Westin to Singapore Fund
text: The Government of Singapore Investment Corporation bought the Westin Tokyo hotel from Morgan Stanley and the Starwood Capital Group as Morgan Stanley shuffles its Japan portfolio.

headline: Novell’s Big Virtualization Bet
text: Novell‘s $205 million acquisition of PlateSpin, a Canadian provider of virtualization services, represent its biggest bet yet on the server-virtualization business and its largest transaction since 2003.

headline: Sun Sews Up MySQL Deal
text: Sun Microsystems on Tuesday announced that it had completed its $1 billion acquisition of MySQL, the open-source database company, and is now on the prowl for similar prey.

headline: Och-Ziff Dips Toe into Troubled Mortgage Market
text: The Och-Ziff Capital Management Group, a hedge fund, has tentatively begun buying troubled home loans and will likely expand more aggressively in residential mortgage markets this year, its chief executive, Daniel Och, said on Tuesday.

headline: Petroplus Teams Up With Blackstone for Oil Deals
text: Petroplus Holdings has signed a $2 billion deal with private equity firms the Blackstone Group and First Reserve to acquire crude oil refineries in the United States.

headline: Suit Against ‘Predator’ Show Advances
text: Alan Feuer reports:

headline: Genesco Adds Charge Against UBS in Fight With Finish Line
text: The legal battle over the $700 million merger of the shoe retailers Genesco and Finish Line is coming to a head.

headline: Two Years Before Contract Ends, Suitors Circle Jay Leno
text: Four years ago, NBC made Jay Leno the lame-duck host of ‘The Tonight Show,’ announcing with fanfare that he would be succeeded by Conan O’Brien in 2009, Bill Carter reports in today’s New York Times.

headline: Pilots’ Battles Play Havoc With Airline Mergers
text: Merger talks between Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines have been held up for a couple of weeks while pilots at each carrier discuss how to combine their union seniority lists.

headline: ‘Smackdown’ Moving To MyNetworkTV
text: Cherry, Domino, Edge, Hornswoggle, Jimmy Wang Yang and their friends will soon have a new home.

headline: Showdown Expected at UBS Shareholders Meeting
text: Switzerland’s troubled flagship bank, UBS, was expected to face a disturbed bunch of shareholders at its annual meeting on Wednesday.

headline: Activist Investor Raises Stake in Reddy Ice
text: Reddy Ice, the packaged ice maker whose $1.1 billion buyout collapsed in January, may be in for further turmoil as a group of investors, including the Shamrock Activist Value Fund, has increased its stake in the company to 15.6 percent.

headline: Small and Midsize Banks Start Struggling in Credit Crisis
text: The credit crisis is tightening the screws on thousands of small to midsize banks across the United States, squeezing local builders and businesses that depend on those lenders for financing.

headline: Canada: The Country That Couldn’t Say ‘No’
text: Canada’s takeover-friendly securities laws have helped make the country the easiest in the world for foreign acquirers, according to a new study that shows Canadians are the world’s biggest net sellers of corporate assets in terms of the nation’s market size.

headline: Egypt’s Citadel Mulls I.P.O. for Venture Fund
text: Citadel Capital, an Egyptian buyout shop with $7 billion under management, is in talks with four international banks to help it sell shares to the public to raise funds for new energy, food and manufacturing ventures.

headline: Elliott Hits Cedar Hill With Espionage Suit
text: A hedge fund, Elliott Management, accused Cedar Hill Capital Partners in a lawsuit on Tuesday of corporate espionage by misappropriating Elliott Management’s proprietary trading software.

text: Here are some more photos from Colette in Paris. T is there putting the store’s hyper-cool clientele (like you) on film all week long. Stay tuned for shop shots from our paparazzo. Join the fun by telling us which photos you like the most. Just leave us a comment… but be nice!

headline: Posers
text: The Bagger has always felt that the Film Experience is a pretty hip blog and this certainly proves it. Lots of pretty hips, lots of hands on them.

headline: Neck and Neck
text: The Bagger saw Gary Busey on the carpet last Sunday, but did not ask him a question, in part because he could not think of one besides, “What makes your teeth seem so threatening?” Is it their size? Their shape? The Crazy Guggenheim stare that floats over them?

headline: Take-Two Raised Management Pay Amid Takeover Bid
text: Just days after Take-Two Interactive, the troubled video game maker, received a buyout offer from a rival, Electronic Arts, the board of Take-Two approved a measure that significantly increased the compensation that management would receive in a merger or takeover, according to regulatory filings.

headline: Great Taste, Less Coffer-Filling
text: Have the Oscars and the industry it celebrates become a microcosm of the American economy? Think about it. High costs to market something the consumer doesn’t seem to want; a reliance on imports, as well as on selling a traditional product at a time when consumers have all manner of new options. Then there’s the stubborn unwillingness to meet those consumers on the platform and device of their choosing.

headline: L.A. to N.J.
text: The Bagger is outside LAX at Terminal 6, a phrase that pretty much brackets his last six days. Normally, before he hits the red-eye to Newark, he hits the smoking cage to be among his fellow cellmates, they of the off-brand ciggies chain smoked through tattooed fingers. But the smoking cage is closed, with stickers all over it. This was one of the last airports in the country that accommodated smoking – in a town where correctness and prevailing vibe of well-being-whether-you-like-it-or-not persists. It was too good to last.

headline: Ad Agencies Are Starting to Bet for the House
text: Wall Street ideas are creeping into the world of online advertising. One of the most controversial topics at the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s conference in Phoenix has been the rise of advertising exchanges, that are mean to trade impressions on Web sites the way Nasdaq trades stock.

headline: Ranking Corporate America on Identity Theft
text: This is a chart that lots of well-paid corporate executives probably do not want you to see. Based on consumer complaints to the Federal Trade Commission, it purports to rank the overall vulnerability of the world’s largest financial institutions, phone companies and retailers –- and their customers –- to identity theft.

headline: Democrats One Seat Away From Control of State Senate
text: In a major victory for Gov. Eliot Spitzer and his party, a Democratic assemblyman scored an upset victory in a State Senate election on Tuesday in a district that has been in Republican hands for a century, Trymaine Lee reports.

headline: Danger: Curves Ahead
text: What is a private equity professional to do when all the talk about credit crunches and distressed debt becomes too much? Shake it off with a spin in a virtual race car.

headline: The Early Word: Strong, But Strong Enough?
text: The debate between the Democratic presidential candidates Tuesday night in Cleveland — possibly the last time Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama will meet head-to-head in this campaign — brought up the issues that have become standard, health care mandates, foreign policy and trade deals.

headline: The Family Dinner
text: I never thought I’d see the day when The Times could offer a first-rate course in playwriting gratis online, but that’s what Marsha Norman has provided in her last post. So if any of you haven’t read it, take a step back and enjoy.

headline: White House to World: We’ll Sign a Binding Climate Pact (There’s a Catch)
text: James Kanter and I have a story in today’s paper about a new tack by the Bush administration aimed at clarifying, for Europe particularly, that the United States is not opposed to any new climate treaty — just all of the formulations that have bubbled up since 1992, when the first global pact was accepted by nearly all countries (it was signed by the first President Bush).

headline: Auction Set for Michael Jackson’s Neverland
text: Statistics released on Tuesday showed that more than 233,000 properties in the United States were foreclosed in January alone, so the addition of just one more person this year would hardly be cause for news coverage. Except, of course, that the person is Michael Jackson, and the property is his Neverland ranch.

headline: Worried Sick
text: After last night’s debate, the folks at The Corner, National Review’s staff blog, have come down with a case of Obama Fever — meaning, the prospect of Barack Obama as the Democratic presidential nominee is making them feel a little sick to the stomach.

headline: Faith in the Operating Room
text: Patients often rely on religious faith to help them cope with illness. But for Milwaukee surgeon Dr. Bruce H. Campbell, operating on a Jehovah’s Witness rattled his own faith in himself.

headline: An Old Face Rejuvenated
text: New York's General Post Office recently completed an extensive exterior renovation.
