headline: Parents Speak Out on 8th-Grade Promotion
text: Educators typically refer to middle school as the “critical years,” the time when students either hunker down and succeed or get distracted and begin to fail. In January, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his State of the City address to propose ending so-called social promotion for eighth-grade students, just as he has done in earlier grades.

headline: Some Morning Joe Before the Yanks’ Intrasquad Game
text: The Yankees will hold an intrasquad game in about two hours, but the only thing darting around the field now is a cat. Can’t say for sure if it’s black or brown, so I don’t know what kind of omen that is. But I bet the Yankees lose today. (And win. Ha, ha.)

headline: The Kings of Europe
text: As if there were some other way to determine which is the best soccer team, other than playing the game, a German consulting firm reports that, win-or-lose, Spanish clubs are more popular in Europe than English teams.

headline: Good Morning, Pyongyang
text: Musicians from the New York Philharmonic receive a tour of the North Korean capital, including a visit to the Grand People's Study Hall, before performing at the East Grand Theatre.

headline: Selig Back on the Hill to Talk Steroids
text: Congress can’t get enough of sports and performance-enhancing drugs, so the House Subcommittee on Commerce, Trade and Consumer Protection will hold a hearing Wednesday in which the commissioners and union chiefs of Major League Baseball, the N.F.L., N.B.A. and N.H.L. are testifying.

headline: Open Caucus: Ohio Debate Discussion
text: Several of our Open Caucus voters — including one from Ohio — tuned into Tuesday’s debate between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, held in Cleveland. A few also watched last week’s debate between the two Democrats in Texas, as well.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Fast Roast Chicken
text: There are a couple of very real challenges when you roast a chicken: You need high heat to brown the skin, but superhigh heat may burn it. You need to cook the thighs and legs through before the breast dries out. You want to do the whole chicken as quickly as possible. And if you are interested in minimalist cooking, you must accomplish all this without a lot of fuss.

headline: ‘America Closed for Three Hours Today’
text: Aired Tuesday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: Barack Obama said if they make a movie about his life, he would like Will Smith to play him. And Hillary said she would want an older woman who looks good in a pantsuit, so obviously she’s picked John Travolta.

headline: ‘The No-Chance-in-Hell Vote’
text: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Tonight in Cleveland, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton are debating one another for the 20th time. Experts are calling it “redundant,” “unnecessary,” and “the most exciting thing that ever happened inCleveland.”

headline: More on Tomatoes . . .
text: After I made such a fuss about sun-dried tomatoes a few weeks ago, you might have thought I’d let the subject of off-season tomatoes die. But no: I’m back with some comments about the benefits of oven-roasting canned tomatoes. See today’s Minimalist column and accompanying video for more.

headline: Stevens to Face Democratic Challenge in Alaska
text: It looks like Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the most senior Republican in the Senate, may have a serious challenger in November.

headline: Clemens to Reporters: ‘Get a Life’
text: Roger Clemens wheeled his black Hummer into the Houston Astros’ spring training facility in Kissimmee, Fla., at about 10:40 a.m. on Tuesday. There were roughly two dozen reporters, photographers and camera operators waiting for him. The Rocket is expected to throw batting practice to minor leaguers for the next three days.

headline: A Clinton Victory, Certified
text: It’s official. Hillary Rodham Clinton carried New York City in the Feb. 5 presidential primary with about 56 percent of the vote, compared to Barack Obama’s 43 percent, according to the returns certified on Tuesday by the city’s Board of Elections. But Mrs. Clinton won Brooklyn by a mere 1,225 of the more than 273,000 votes cast. The borough has more enrolled Democrats than nearly any other county in the country, and the New York senator had been endorsed by the Democratic county leader and all of Brooklyn’s members of Congress. Mrs. Clinton carried the 15th Congressional District, represented by one of her earliest supporters, Representative Charles B. Rangel, by 60,573 to 53,165. But within that northern Manhattan district, in the 71st Assembly District, where she was endorsed by Herman D. Farrell Jr., the former Democratic county and state chairman, she narrowly won by only 11,843 to 10,178.

headline: Will Publishers Lose Their Bacon if Ads Are Traded Like Pork Bellies?
text: Aside from the Microsoft bid for Yahoo, the biggest topic of conversation at the Interactive Advertising Bureau’s convention this week was pork bellies.

headline: Gary Busey, Philosopher

headline: Obama and Israel
text: I posted recently about the relative lack of courage on the part of both Senator Clinton and Senator Obama to disagree with primary voters, and I asked readers to cite example of political courage on the part of either of them. I’m sure that both senators are far more sympathetic to gay marriage, gun control and free trade, for example, than they let on, and I wish they would show some leadership on issues like those.

headline: Bernanke Speaks to Congress

headline: Spitzer Has Options for Turning Things Around
text: Updated, 7 p.m. | The story of Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s rough-and-tumble first year in office is, by now, well documented: his fight with fellow Democrats over the selection of a state comptroller; his staff members’ handling of the seemingly interminable scandal known as Troopergate; and his abandonment of a plan to issue driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants. Can the governor recover, and if so, how?

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: Maazel Conducts the State Symphony

headline: From Chilly Lakeland, Pelfrey’s Spring Audition
text: Yes, chilly. I know it’s all relative. But 53 degrees with 17 mile an hour winds is more like opening day weather in Detroit. Not here.

headline: YSL Sell
text: YSL has gotten its revolution on. This week, the Rive Gauche women’s boutique reopened to show off its new “design concept” (read: store design) to Fashion Week editors. Dubbed The Opium Experience (very soixante-huitard!), the persimmon lacquer and pale stone space also features a hint of green: namely CO2-emission-busting ductal concrete that will also reduce water waste.

headline: Populist Ads for Democrats
text: Barack Obama, once vocally opposed to outside groups’ involvement in campaigning, quietly has been letting pro-Obama ads from the Service Employees International Union run in Ohio without much comment.

headline: Tributes to William F. Buckley, Conservative Icon
text: Some tributes and other ephemera surfacing across the Web as news spreads of the death of William F. Buckley. The New York Times’s obituary, written by Douglas Martin, is here.

headline: A Tale of Two Hostiles
text: Electronic Arts‘s unsolicited takeover offer for Take-Two Interactive is unfolding fast: Take-Two, which makes the popular Grand Theft Auto video-game series, has responded to Sunday’s public bid by Electronic Arts with the flurry of activity that usually follows these kinds of things: golden parachutes, rapid strategic maneuvers of questionable shareholder value and general hostility.

headline: German Mistaken for Whitey Bulger, F.B.I. Says
text: Whitey Bulger has found himself at the center of another “mandatory kill,” though this one was ordered by a photo agency seeking to delete an image from their archives. The alert was prompted by the F.B.I.’s admission that they misidentified a German couple vacationing in Sicily as the reputed Boston crime boss and his girlfriend, Catherine Greig.

headline: Remembering Buckley’s 1965 Run for Mayor
text: Updated, 3:55 p.m. | William F. Buckley Jr., who died today at 82, ran for mayor of New York City in 1965, in a bizarre but memorable chapter of the city’s political history. Asked what he would do if he won, he famously replied, “Demand a recount.” He injected a rare degree of lofty oratory into city politics — has any other mayoral candidate ever promised “a vision of a new order” and “the beginning of a new dawn”?

headline: Q&A on William F. Buckley
text: Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of The Times Book Review and Week in Review, is writing a biography of William F. Buckley Jr., who died Wednesday. Mr. Buckley was for decades the intellectual standard bearer for American conservatism, and he was also one of the 20th century’s truest men of letters: a magazine editor, newspaper columnist, novelist and essayist — the author of 55 books.

headline: Obama Reaches 1 Million Donor Mark
text: One million and counting. That’s how many people Barack Obama says have invested in him.

headline: Moonves Unfazed by the 100 Days That Shook Hollywood

headline: Soft Serve | Stolen Bling, Neverland Ranch Sale, Canal St. Raids
text: Soft Serve scans newspapers, magazines and Web sites for “soft news” — coverage of products, trends and matters of style. Just the fluff, ma’am.Tilda Swinton may have picked up a red carpet win for Damiani by wearing their diamond cuff, but the jeweler’s Milan showroom wasn’t quite so lucky. Seven men dug a tunnel through a neighboring building and stole $20 million worth of jewels… Next year’s male Oscar nominees wanting to sport a little bling should check out the diamond cufflinks that Thom Browne has designed for Harry Winston… If real estate is your expense of choice, why not throw down for Michael Jackson’s Neverland ranch when it hits the auction block on March 19th… They may not have a theme park, but Curbed’s got a list of the top 10 private pools in the city that may make you spring for a new condo… Having trouble waking up in your new pad? Check out this aromatherapy alarm clock that will wake you to favorite scent…Amy Winehouse may not be the freshest fashion icon in music, but her style is unmistakable. Now you can buy a piece of the action when she launches her new clothing and make-up line… A sad day for fans of felonious fashion. Mayor Bloomberg and the NYPD raided and seized $1 million in goods from Canal St. counterfeiters… In Shanghai, the trend is not towards knock-offs, but “the rebirth of individualism”… You’ll be hardly alone wearing Marc Jacobs re-launched Hillary tee, but as least it one-up’s Senator Clinton’s boxy pantsuits… Soft Serve is sick of today’s politics. Check us out tomorrow for more of the spin.

headline: Did Your Team Get Jobbed, or Did It Prosper? Part 3

headline: No Backing From Bloomberg in ’09 Democratic Primary

At a news conference this morning about the greening of the city’s black car fleet, the billionaire said that he would not be making any endorsements in that 2009 primary.

headline: New York Philharmonic in Asia: After the Big Event, Off to Seoul
text: The Philharmonic left Pyongyang this afternoon for Seoul, where there are no minders, cars fill the roads (boy, do they), shopping is abundant, and a new president was just inaugurated on Monday. The scene at the Pyongyang airport was warm. Many of the musicians and their minders exchanged embraces and warm farewells. There were no exchanges of e-mail addresses, because there is no commonly accessible Internet in North Korea.

headline: Obama and McCain Spar Over Iraq
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio – Senator Barack Obama tangled from afar with Senator John McCain on Wednesday, delivering a spirited retort to Mr. McCain’s mocking suggestion that Mr. Obama was not familiar with the presence of Al Qaeda in Iraq.

headline: Schools Give Out Free Cellphones
text: A Harvard economist’s idea — giving free cellphone air time to high-performing students as an incentive to continue doing well — is now in effect. Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein today started the “Million” Motivation Campaign, an experimental program involving about 2,500 students in seven middle schools. The students will each receive a free cellphone, called the “Million,” with opportunities to earn minutes and other rewards if they achieve academic goals set by their principals.

headline: Mega-Church Pastor in Texas Backs McCain
text: SAN ANTONIO — Senator John McCain got support on Wednesday from an important corner of evangelical Texas when the pastor of a San Antonio mega-church, Rev. John C. Hagee, endorsed Mr. McCain for president. Mr. Hagee, who argues that the United States must join Israel in a preemptive, biblically prophesized military strike against Iran that will lead to the second coming of Christ, praised Mr. McCain for his pro-Israel views.

headline: Save the American Time Use Survey?
text: Should we save the American Time Use Survey? A coalition of social scientists hope the Bureau of Labor Statistics changes plans to ditch the annual report on budgetary grounds, saying that the trove of data is unlikely to be duplicated elsewhere.

headline: Bruno on Election Defeat: ‘The Season Is Not Over’
text: This morning, after a humbling defeat in a heated and expensive State Senate race in a heavily Republican district upstate — a seat that Republicans had held for a century — the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, rallied his troops in Albany on Wednesday in an attempt to bolster spirits.
