Go to Bloggingheads.tv

headline: Boyd Coddington, Hot Rod Hero, Dies at 63
text: Your king is dead, hot-rodders. Long live the king.

headline: The Farmer and the Cranes
text: Endangered whooping cranes have found a haven on George West's Tennessee farm -- itself in danger of being swallowed up by development.

headline: ‘Like Listening to Golf on the Radio in Mandarin’
text: More of your “late night” jokes (send via the comment link below):

headline: Good Country for Old Men (And Women)
text: Oscar is 80 years old this year, Jon Stewart said during the Academy Awards show, “which makes him now automatically the front-runner for the Republican nomination.”

headline: Ask Russians About Their Presidential Election
text: Last week, The New York Times created a Russian-language Live Journal community to give Russian readers a chance to read and discuss articles written by the Moscow bureau. So far, Russian readers have posted more than 4,000 comments.

headline: Bloomberg Writes That He Won’t Run
text: After teasing us for months and months, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York is letting us down easy in an Op-Ed in Thursday’s New York Times.

headline: Your Comments on my Sudan Column
text: My Thursday column is from Juba, Sudan, and argues that the Sudanese government in Khartoum is moving to restart the brutal war between north and south Sudan. I’m afraid that the genocide in Darfur is going to be remembered simply as the prologue to an even more bloodier slaughter that stretches across the entire south of the country as well.

headline: Debate Breaks Record For MSNBC
text: Tuesday’s duel between Democratic candidates Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama earned MSNBC the highest ratings in its 11-year history.

headline: Russia’s Next President
text: Dmitri A. Medvedev is set to become the new president of Russia, having been personally chosen for the job by President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: An ‘Eco Blogs’ List and Thoughts on Blogging
text: The other Times, over in Britain, put out a list of its 50 favorite “eco blogs” on Wednesday and I finally had time to explore it just a bit. There are some fascinating sites that I wasn’t aware of. More on those below. I’d be interested to hear about your favorites, and any criticisms of their list (or my blogroll at right, for that matter).

headline: Respond to Today’s Column: Hillary, Buckeye Girl
text: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, Feb. 28 column.

headline: Google Goes After Another Microsoft Cash Cow
text: Google is adding a new front to its assault on Microsoft’s software applications business.

headline: Neverland Under Siege
text: Michael Jackson could lose his Neverland Valley Ranch in California, above, unless he pays nearly $25 million before March 19. A five-page filing at the Santa Barbara County Recorder’s Office said, “You are in default of a deed of trust,” Reuters reported, citing FoxNews.com. “Unless you take action to protect your property, it may be sold at a public sale.” Mr. Jackson’s representative, Raymone Bain, did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Mr. Jackson has owned the 2,800-acre ranch in the foothills above the California coast since 1988. He has mainly lived abroad since he was acquitted of child molestation charges in 2005.

headline: Jack Abramoff, Jack Abramoff ...
text: Anxiety is palpable in the House as lawmakers try to wriggle out of a vote on whether to create an independent Office of Congressional Ethics. Despite last-minute cries of alarm and resistance from both sides of the aisle, the public is counting on Speaker Nancy Pelosi to stand fast and steer this overdue dose of ethics reform to passage.

headline: A Revision Makes a Photo Management Software Amenable to Amateurs and Pros
text: Aperture, Apple’s photo management and editing software, was originally intended as a professional alternative to iPhoto. But since it was released about 18 months ago, a large number of Aperture buyers have been amateur photographers with digital single-lens reflex cameras who want more sophisticated controls.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A music review on Feb. 18 about two concerts by the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, at Carnegie Hall, misstated the age of the twin children of the orchestra’s music director, David Robertson, who mentioned them in remarks before one concert. They are 5 months old, not 5 years.

headline: A Calm Stretch Ends in Newark, but Officials Claim Progress on Crime
text: NEWARK  The day shift almost always stretches into night for this city’s homicide detectives, but on Tuesday at a little after 5 p.m., Sgt. Miguel Arroyo threw on his coat, picked up his umbrella, bid the boss good night and headed for the door.

headline: Campus Shooting Site to Be Torn Down
text: CHICAGO  The classroom building at Northern Illinois University where a gunman killed five students and himself this month will be demolished and replaced, state officials said Wednesday.

headline: An Office Space of One’s Own for Entrepreneurs
text: WITHIN a few months of starting In Good Company Consulting, a business to advise female entrepreneurs, Amy Abrams and Adelaide Fives discovered that they shared something with many of their clients. They, too, needed office space that was well located and professional with a place for private meetings. And they wanted to be near like-minded entrepreneurs.

headline: With a Tough Win, Stringer Joins Elite Group
text: PISCATAWAY, N.J.  There were just a few minutes left in the game, and a milestone was approaching, but C. Vivian Stringer had not had time to think about the possibility of winning for the 800th time. With DePaul, a team that was supposed to be in over its head, refusing to go away, it was a matter of first things first for No. 4 Rutgers.

headline: New Jersey’s Warning
text: It is hard to remember when any governor used the sort of desperate language that New Jersey Gov. Jon Corzine chose this week to describe his state’s fiscal crisis. His words should be a sober warning to other states to get their fiscal houses in order before they face a crisis of Trenton’s magnitude.

headline: Putin’s Chosen Successor Whatzisname
text: Near the end of Tuesday night’s Democratic debate between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, one of the moderators, Tim Russert of NBC News, tossed up a jump ball. “What can you tell me about the man who’s going to be Mr. Putin’s successor?”

headline: M.T.A. Plan Shows Less Help From Congestion Pricing
text: Supporters of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s plan to charge people who drive into the busiest parts of Manhattan have promoted it as a way to provide a steady flow of money to pay for improvements to public transportation for decades to come.

headline: Microsoft Gets Record Fine and a Rebuke From Europe
text: BRUSSELS  The European antitrust regulator imposed a record $1.35 billion fine against Microsoft on Wednesday in a ruling intended to send a clear message to the world’s largest software maker  and to any other company  of the dangers of flouting Europe’s competition rulings.

headline: Now Windows Users Have Their Own Skinny Contender in the Battle of the Lightweight Laptops
text: It’s hard to be the Lenovo ThinkPad X300. While the rest of the world was fawning over Apple’s ultraslim MacBook Air, Lenovo’s laptop entered the world with little fanfare, even though it is 0.1 of a pound lighter and runs Windows Vista.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Feb. 12 about efforts by hospitals in New York City to expand their emergency rooms misidentified the hospital system with the busiest emergency department, according to the New York State Department of Health, which verifies figures provided by hospitals. It is NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, not Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx.

headline: Hopping Over to Taiwan for Another Title Shot
text: First, look at only the West hand. What would you lead against four spades? You know that South has a minimum opening bid with 6-3-3-1 shape (six spades and a singleton club). North has asked only meaningless questions, then signed off in four spades. Ignore the given auction, which happened at the second table in the match.

headline: A Serious Building, Tailor Made for Fun
text: The butter-hued building with porthole windows rises from the weathered brownstones of Crown Heights like a yellow submarine surfacing from a slate-gray sea. The Brooklyn Children’s Museum, after a six-year, $46 million expansion complicated by financial challenges, is readying itself to open in May.

headline: Republicans in Albany Say, ‘It’s Not Over’
text: ALBANY  In his sprawling suite in the Capitol, a humbled Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, gathered an aging coterie of fellow Senate Republicans on Wednesday morning to commiserate over a fresh defeat and plot a last stand for their beleaguered party.

headline: New Louisiana Governor Pierces Brazen Style of Business as Usual
text: BATON ROUGE, La.  Downstairs, legislators gnashed their teeth, while upstairs at the Capitol here this week, the new governor claimed victory against the old customs down below.

headline: School Board to Pay in Jesus Prayer Suit
text: A Delaware school district has agreed to revise its policies on religion as part of a settlement with two Jewish families who had sued over the pervasiveness of Christian prayer and other religious activities in the schools.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Argentina’s struggle to avoid energy shortages attributed an erroneous distinction to Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the country’s president. She is the first woman to have been elected president  not the first woman to serve in that office. (María Estela Perón, known as Isabelita, became president in July 1974 after her husband, Gen. Juan Domingo Perón, died.)

headline: Sign Augurs Fordham’s 28th Loss
text: Even an electronic sign outside Fordham’s Rose Hill Gym on Wednesday night appeared to be pleading for mercy. It advertised, among other things, an interfaith discussion on the subject of “Why Do Bad Things Happen to Good People?” Inside, for the 28th time in 28 games, in front of another sparse crowd, the university’s women’s basketball team trailed its opponent.

headline: The Moon’s Craggiest Stretch Comes Into Focus
text: In the craggy terrain around the Moon’s south pole, the deepest craters dip 2.5 miles beneath the surface while the peaks reach as high as the highest mountain in North America  a 37,000-foot change of elevation.

headline: Bloomberg Says He Will Not Endorse Anyone for Mayor in the 2009 Democratic Primary
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, in a move that could darken the friendly relations he has enjoyed with the other branches of city government and change the dynamic of the nascent contest for mayor next year, said on Wednesday that he would not make any endorsements in that race’s Democratic primary.

headline: Cash-Rich, Publicity-Shy, Abu Dhabi Fund Draws Scrutiny
text: Abu Dhabi has about 9 percent of the world’s oil and 0.02 percent of its population. The result is a surfeit of petrodollars, much of which is funneled into a secretive, government-controlled investment fund that is helping to shift the balance of power in the financial world.

headline: Dmitri Medvedev, in His Own Words
text: The following are excerpts of speeches by and interviews with Dmitri A. Medvedev, President Vladimir V. Putin’s hand-picked successor, as posted in English on his campaign Web site.

headline: The Long Haul in Afghanistan
text: BRUSSELS

headline: McCain and Obama Trade Jabs on Iraq
text: Senator John McCain opened a new line of attack against Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday, accusing him of being willing to surrender Iraq to Al Qaeda.

headline: A Touch of Blues-Rock From a Son of the South
text: Strange things appear in Jim White’s songs. There are revelations and tall tales, absurdities and tragedies, Southern roots and existential disorientation. A man sits on a railroad track howling at the moon. Jesus returns driving a motor home, alongside Buddha on a motorcycle and Muhammad in a train. The singer finds himself “handcuffed to a fence in Mississippi, where things is always better than they seem.”

headline: Contract Awarded for Newark Heliport
text: A $10 million contract for the construction of a heliport in Newark has been awarded to Air Pegasus Helicopters, a company that operates heliports in Manhattan and Washington.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 3,966 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Softball Is Losing a Chance to Celebrate
text: They are the odd couple of Olympic sports, bonded by three bases and home plate. Women’s softball and men’s baseball have been voted off the Olympic island after this August’s Summer Games in Beijing.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A chart with a sports article on Tuesday about the anticipated strength of the Detroit Tigers’ lineup misstated, in some copies, the year of the statistics for three players who are out of the lineup and for three additions to the team. The totals were from 2007, not 2006.

headline: Hamas and Israelis Trade Attacks, Killing Several
text: JERUSALEM  In a sudden surge of violence, an Israeli civilian was killed Wednesday in a rocket attack by Hamas militants from Gaza, the first such fatality in nine months, and at least eight Palestinians, militants and civilians, were killed in Israeli airstrikes before and after the rocket attack.

headline: I’m Not Running for President, but ...
text: WATCHING the 2008 presidential campaign, you sometimes get the feeling that the candidates  smart, all of them  must know better. They must know we can’t fix our economy and create jobs by isolating America from global trade. They must know that we can’t fix our immigration problems with border security alone. They must know that we can’t fix our schools without holding teachers, principals and parents accountable for results. They must know that fighting global warming is not a costless challenge. And they must know that we can’t keep illegal guns out of the hands of criminals unless we crack down on the black market for them.

headline: Delay in House Vote on New Ethics Panel
text: WASHINGTON  Facing a bipartisan backlash from lawmakers, the House leadership postponed on Wednesday consideration of a plan for an independent ethics panel to review House members’ conduct.

headline: Editors’ Note
text: A front-page article on Saturday described a cocaine epidemic in Argentina fed by the consumption of paco, an addictive smokable cocaine residue. The article included an explanatory paragraph about paco’s addictive power and toxicity that repeated material from a 2006 article published in The Miami Herald, without attributing it to the newspaper. The correspondent, who had done his own research with Argentine and Brazilian officials on the drug and its effects, should have summarized it in his own words, or credited The Herald.

headline: Does Weight Lifting Make a Better Athlete?
text: MIKE PERRY, a 31-year-old rower, trained by himself in Ann Arbor, Mich., for six years while his wife attended medical school. Now he is a member of the United States rowing team and hopes to be selected in a couple of months to compete in the Summer Olympic Games.

headline: American Missing in Afghanistan Is Feared Dead
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  An American woman and her Afghan driver who were abducted at gunpoint on Jan. 26 are feared dead, the administrator of her aid organization said Wednesday.

headline: William F. Buckley Jr.
text: When William F. Buckley Jr.’s “God and Man at Yale” appeared in 1951, the critic and conservative sage Peter Viereck dismissed it as jejune, a word much favored by Mr. Buckley in his later years to describe views he regarded as uninformed by experience. Mr. Buckley’s fierce denunciation of collectivism and atheism on the Yale faculty was all to the good, Mr. Viereck said, but it fell far short of the “profound” conservative manifesto that needed to be written.

headline: Italy: Men Can’t Grope...Themselves
text: Whatever their reason might be, a passing hearse or simple discomfort, Italy’s highest court ruled that men may not touch their genitals in public. The ruling settled an appeal by a 42-year-old worker from Como, north of Milan, who was convicted in May 2006 of “ostentatiously touching his genitals through his clothing,” though his lawyer argued it was a problem with his overalls. But the court struck against a broader practice: a tradition among some Italian men of warding off bad luck by grabbing the crotch. The court ruled that this “has to be regarded as an act contrary to public decency, a concept including that nexus of socio-ethical behavioral rules requiring everyone to abstain from conduct potentially offensive to collectively held feelings of decorum.” The judges suggested that if they need to, men can wait and do it at home.

headline: Home & Garden Calendar
text: Orchid Extravaganza

headline: Outlook Versus Outlook Express?
text: Q. What does Outlook do that Outlook Express doesn’t do? Is there any reason to buy Outlook?

headline: Saluting Ella Fitzgerald With Scatting and Swinging
text: When one singer pays tribute to another, you often learn as much about the object of veneration as about the performer carrying the torch. So it is with Freda Payne’s celebration of Ella Fitzgerald at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency. In the show, which runs through Sunday, Ms. Payne, fondly remembered for her 1970 hit “Band of Gold,” sings Fitzgerald’s signature songs, concentrating on the numbers that lean more toward jazz than toward the standards on her songbook albums.

headline: McCain Steps Up Criticism of Obama
text: Senator John McCain stepped up his critique of Senator Barack Obama on Thursday by accusing him for the second consecutive day of a willingness to hand over Iraq to Al Qaeda, as the Democratic contenders released record-breaking fund-raising figures.

headline: Putting Bad Luck Behind Them, 2 Yankees Focus on Standing Out
text: TAMPA, Fla.  They are right-handers with less than a year of major league service time. Neither has overpowering stuff, and for the Yankees, they are best suited to make occasional starts or pitch in long relief. A rash of injuries to the Yankees’ rotation last spring was supposed to be their big chance.

headline: Aetna Backs Off a Colonoscopy Change
text: Bowing to critics who contended it was putting profits before patients, Aetna said Wednesday that it had suspended  at least temporarily  a plan to stop paying for routine use of a powerful anesthetic in a procedure to screen for colon cancer.

headline: Britain Acquires Major Modern Art Collection
text: A collection of 725 works of modern art valued at $250 million has been bought for Britain for $52 million and will tour the country under the ownership and management of the Tate and the National Galleries of Scotland, the museums said on Wednesday. Described as one of the most important holdings of postwar and contemporary international art in private hands, the collection, featuring names like Diane Arbus, Damien Hirst, Jeff Koons, Sol LeWitt, Robert Mapplethorpe (whose portrait of Patti Smith is shown above), Gerhard Richter and Andy Warhol, was assembled over three decades by the art dealer Anthony d’Offay. Under the name “Artist Rooms,” reflecting the concept of devoting individual rooms to particular artists, the works will be seen at museums and galleries across Britain starting in spring 2009. The cost of acquisition, for a price described as Mr. d’Offay’s original cost, was met by the Scottish and British governments, the National Heritage Memorial Fund and the Art Fund. Prime Minister Gordon Brown reacted to Mr. d’Offay’s contribution by saying, “Individual acts of generosity like this impact on the lives of millions, and reinforce the U.K.’s richly deserved reputation as having a range of world-leading museums and galleries.”

headline: Technique That Glitters, Music That Hurtles Through
text: One of the improvisational trademarks of the guitarist Kurt Rosenwinkel is a high, pinging long tone followed by a briskly descending glissando. It’s a dazzling gesture, the sort of thing that elicits whoops and envious murmurs from the musicians in the room. But he makes it seem no more difficult than trailing a finger across a row of percussive bar chimes. The feeling of effortlessness is a big component of his technique.

headline: Partisan Split Grows Over Housing Crisis
text: WASHINGTON  Just one month after President Bush and Democratic leaders hailed their bipartisan agreement on an economic stimulus plan, the two sides went back to war on Thursday over how to deal with widening damage from the housing and mortgage crises.

headline: Buddy Miles, Hendrix Drummer, Dies
text: Buddy Miles, the drummer in Jimi Hendrix’s Band of Gypsys and a hitmaker under his own name with the song “Them Changes,” died on at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 60.

headline: Colombia: Rebels Free 4 Politicians
text: Latin America’s largest rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, freed three men and a woman, all former members of Congress, held in captivity for more than six years after negotiations led by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela. The release follows Mr. Chávez’s success in January in winning the freedom of two other politicians held by the group, known as the FARC. But hopes that it might imminently free more captives, including three Americans and the former presidential candidate Ingrid Betancourt, were dashed by a statement from the guerrillas requesting that Colombia’s president, Álvaro Uribe, demilitarize two areas in the southwest as a venue for a broader prisoner exchange. The hostages released Wednesday said Ms. Betancourt was seriously ill.

headline: To G.E., a Chinese Olympics Is Just Made for a Global Message
text: SO, how do you say “Imagination at Work” in Chinese?

headline: U.S. Commander Wants Brief Pause in Troop Cuts
text: TAMPA, Fla.  The commander of American forces in the Middle East says he will endorse a brief pause in troop reductions from Iraq this summer, but then will seek a resumption of withdrawals to ease stress on the overall military and allow him to balance deployments across the volatile region.

headline: A Refugee From Gangland
text: Eugene, Ore.

headline: Juilliard and Met Meld Opera Training
text: The Metropolitan Opera and the Juilliard School have agreed to pool their resources in a program for young opera singers, as well as pianists who hope to work as vocal accompanists or opera conductors, the two institutions announced Wednesday.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A film review in Weekend on Friday about the three-part movie “The Signal” reversed the identities of two directors. Part 2 was directed by Jacob Gentry and Part 3 was directed by Dan Bush. The review also misidentified a character at one point. It is Lewis who is “now raging” in Part 2, not Ben.

headline: An Intriguing Adventure, Too Bad About the Dull Heroine and the Misspellings
text: There is an inherent artificiality in video games. You pretend to be wielding a sword or building a skyscraper when in fact you are just playing with a mouse or controller.

headline: Border Patrol Agent’s Trial in Killing of Illegal Immigrant Starts in Arizona
text: TUCSON  In a patch of desert just north of Mexico, what began as a relatively routine interception a year ago ended when a Border Patrol agent shot and killed an illegal immigrant at close range.

headline: William F. Buckley Jr., 82, Dies; Sesquipedalian Spark of Right
text: William F. Buckley Jr., who marshaled polysyllabic exuberance, arched eyebrows and a refined, perspicacious mind to elevate conservatism to the center of American political discourse, died on Wednesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

headline: A Lender Halts U.S.-Backed Student Loans
text: The Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency, one of the nation’s largest student loan operations, announced Wednesday that it would suspend making federal-guaranteed loans starting early next month.

headline: Boulez Visits With Selections That Sound Like Tomorrow
text: The Chicago Symphony came to Carnegie Hall on Monday and Tuesday. Pierre Boulez, who happily leaves the three B’s and most of the M’s and S’s of the standard repertory to other conductors, offered pieces from the 20th and 21st centuries. On Tuesday there was also music by Berlioz, a 19th-century composer whose beautiful strangeness will assuredly make him sound original in the 22nd.

headline: Gannett Picks Head for Newspaper Unit
text: The Gannett Company, owner of USA Today, named Robert J. Dickey president of its newspaper division on Wednesday, succeeding Susan Clark-Johnson, who is retiring in May.

headline: 1890s Outside, Loftlike Inside
text: WHEN Ellen Weiman and Dubi Silverstein began dating, they often went for rambles through Lower Manhattan, killing time before a movie or just meandering for the fun of it.

headline: House Passes Renewable Energy Credits
text: WASHINGTON  The House on Wednesday approved a bill to extend more than $17 billion in tax credits and other incentives to encourage the production of energy from solar, wind and other renewable sources, and to promote energy conservation. The bill would be financed by ending tax incentives for oil and natural gas producers.

headline: When Training Becomes Overtraining
text: "Though it seems innocuous, overtraining isn't just a matter of having overdone things in a workout or two," Gretchen Reynolds writes in her column, "Crash and Burnout." Overtraining is a recognized illness, she writes, one that's similar in some respects to chronic-fatigue syndrome and major depression, with symptoms that might include mood changes, insomnia and fatigue. The conundrum for elite athletes, then, is maximizing training without crossing the line into overtraining. While science doesn't agree on how best to avoid crossing that line, there is consensus on how to treat it: "Rest, rest and more rest," says Robert Schoene, a professor of medicine at the University of California, San Diego.

headline: Senator Queries F.D.A. and Spinal Disk Maker
text: A ranking member of the Senate Finance Committee has asked the Food and Drug Administration and the maker of an artificial spinal disk about potential financial conflicts of many doctors involved in the clinical research that led to F.D.A. approval of the device.

headline: France: Holocaust Study Plan Tweaked
text: President Nicolas Sarkozy’s intensely criticized plan for each fifth grader to study the life of one of the 11,000 French children killed in the Holocaust was abandoned at the first meeting of the education minister’s advisory group, officials said. Instead, they said, an entire classroom might be paired with a young victim, a proposal the advisers said would be less traumatizing for students and more acceptable to their parents.

headline: King and Mellencamp Team Up for Musical
text: “Ghost Brothers of Darkland County,” a new Southern Gothic musical by Stephen King, the horror writer, and John Mellencamp, the musician, is to open in April 2009 at the Alliance Theater in Atlanta. In a recent interview in Rolling Stone Mr. Mellencamp said that if the musical, about the reverberations of a tragedy in small-town Mississippi, did well in Atlanta, it would head to Broadway.

headline: Mendelssohn for Two Parts (of the World)
text: PYONGYANG, North Korea  With international attention focused on the New York Philharmonic’s music making here, it was time on Wednesday for the North Koreans to show what they could do with Mendelssohn, Wagner and Tchaikovsky.

headline: Senate Panel Seeks to Alter Whistle-Blower Law
text: WASHINGTON  Complaining that recent court rulings were thwarting efforts by citizens to report fraud against the government, members of a Senate committee said on Wednesday that they wanted to work with the Justice Department to undo some of the harm they thought the courts had caused.

headline: W. C. Heinz, 93, Writing Craftsman, Dies
text: W. C. Heinz, the sports columnist, war correspondent, magazine writer and novelist who was considered one of the finest journalistic stylists of his era, died Wednesday in Bennington, Vt. He was 93.

headline: Flu Shots Recommended for Children Through 18
text: All children aged six months to 18 years in this country should receive an influenza shot every year, a federal advisory panel said on Wednesday.

headline: Ralph Nader: A Spoiler, or a Welcome Voice?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush Calls Surveillance Bill an ‘Urgent Priority’
text: WASHINGTON  Using some of his toughest language in weeks, President Bush prodded Congress on Thursday to pass his preferred version of surveillance legislation, asserting that every day of delay could put the country in danger.

headline: New Pitch for Mickelson, Just for Laughs
text: SAN DIEGO  The commercial shoot seemed to be going along just fine Tuesday. The star was delivering his ad-libbed lines with aplomb, nicely timed one-liners, and his arch eyebrows were raised just so, displaying facial expressions that stretched into a winsome, nonplussed look. But there was a slight problem.

headline: Never Too Young for That First Pedicure
text: ONE recent rainy afternoon, Eleanor LaFauci, 7, sat with her feet in open-toed foam slippers, admiring her toenails, freshly painted watermelon pink.

headline: Congress Requests Clemens Inquiry
text: WASHINGTON  A Congressional committee asked the Justice Department on Wednesday to investigate whether Roger Clemens made false statements under oath about his suspected use of steroids and human growth hormone, strengthening the possibility that he could be charged with perjury.

headline: A Genocide Foretold
text: JUBA, Sudan

headline: Reporters Seeking Reaction From Clemens Receive Brushback
text: KISSIMMEE, Fla.  Roger Clemens did a lot of throwing, but very little talking, in his first day as an intensely scrutinized batting-practice pitcher for the Houston Astros. Clemens essentially ignored questions from reporters during his three-and-a-half-hour visit to the team’s spring training complex Wednesday.

headline: Also in this Issue ...
text: -- In "Daddy's Little Phenoms," Pat Jordan writes about Ginger and Robbi Howard, two junior golfers in Florida whose father has an ambitious master plan -- to create the Williams sisters of golf.

headline: Pelfrey Hopes First Outing Becomes a Lasting Impression
text: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Mets’ ride here was timed at a cool 2 hours 30 minutes. And when they shook the sleep out of their eyes and tottered off the bus, they encountered a frightening possibility: Were they still in Florida, or had the driver misread the directions and zoomed past Tigertown, all the way to Detroit?

headline: Undercurrents of Hope in a Region of Turbulence
text: Few American journalists are as familiar with the Middle East as Robin Wright. Having first visited Iran in 1973, lived in Beirut in the 1980s and chronicled the region on repeated trips since then, she has a deep mix of on-the-ground knowledge, awareness of the historical background and step-back policy perspective. She wrote one of the first books on militant Islam (“Sacred Rage”) and two others on Iran.

headline: Winehouse Seeks Delay in Drug Case
text: A lawyer for Amy Winehouse has asked a court in Norway to postpone a hearing on Friday related to her arrest in October on a charge of drug possession in Bergen, The Associated Press reported. She and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were held overnight at the time and released after paying fines of $715 each. She later appealed, contending that the police made mistakes in handling the case, involving a quarter-ounce of marijuana. ... A lawyer for the singer Bobby Brown said a Brockton County District Court clerk magistrate in Massachusetts had found no probable cause to issue a criminal complaint against Mr. Brown, whom the police found in possession of a small amount of cocaine in December. Mr. Brown, formerly married to Whitney Houston, agreed to a year’s community service, and the lawyer said the matter would be struck from the docket if no problems involving Mr. Brown arise in the next year.

headline: Where to Find Help (and Self-Help)
text: FOR those paralyzed by the fear of galleries and large expenditures, below are a few tips from art consultants and other experts.

headline: Twists in Chain of Supplies for Blood Drug
text: RUGAO, China  With reports of more than 400 patients in the United States suffering serious complications after receiving the blood-thinner heparin, American investigators are trying to determine whether the raw material for the drug, made from pig intestines, became contaminated on the journey that begins in the slaughterhouses of China.

headline: Hot, Hotter, Hottiest
text: PUNXSUTAWNEY PHIL knows nothing. If there was any sign earlier this month that spring was around the corner, it was the sight of the stylist Tina Chai standing at the summit of the Bryant Park steps in shoes the color of daffodils. She had purloined the lace-up stilettos from Thakoon’s fall 2008 collection (as the show stylist, Ms. Chai is allowed such indiscretions) and paired them with dark tights and a leopard print coat. Amid the sea of fashion-editor black, she looked like a ray of sunshine.

headline: Guggenheim’s Provocative Director Steps Down
text: After nearly 20 years, Thomas Krens, the provocative director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, is stepping down, its board announced on Wednesday.

headline: Chief Is Leaving the About.com Unit of The Times
text: The chief executive of About.com, The New York Times Company’s lucrative information and advice site, said Wednesday that he would leave the company next week.

headline: Clocking Your Internet Speed
text: Q. My broadband Internet connection seems to be slower than advertised and is noticeably pokey at certain times. What might be causing this slowness, and how I can find out how fast my connection really is?

headline: Humane Society Sues U.S. in Cattle Case
text: WASHINGTON  The Humane Society of the United States sued the Agriculture Department on Wednesday for creating a “loophole” that it said is permitting potentially sick cows into the food supply.

headline: Iraq’s Legal System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Trying Times for the Remaining Nader Faithful
text: Glen Cove, N.Y.

headline: Orchids Without Tears
text: Orchids Without Tears

headline: Qaeda Suspect Escapes
text: A Singaporean man who was once one of the most hunted terrorist suspects in Southeast Asia escaped from a detention center in Singapore on Wednesday, the government announced.

headline: Footnotes
text: Jim Shepard has won the $20,000 Story Prize. This four-year-old award for short-story collections honors his 2007 volume, “Like You’d Understand Anyway” (Alfred A. Knopf). ... A federal judge in Los Angeles has postponed the wiretapping trial of the Hollywood private investigator Anthony Pellicano and co-defendants until March 5 to give lawyers more time to prepare. ... The modest East Hollywood bungalow that was once the rented residence of the hard-drinking poet and novelist Charles Bukowski (1920-1994) has been designated a civic landmark by the Los Angeles City Council, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Early Obama Promise on Money Becomes Target
text: Just 12 months ago, Senator Barack Obama presented himself as an idealistic upstart taking on the Democratic fund-raising juggernaut behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Pictures From a Democratic Debate
text: To the Editor:

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about commercials that ran during the Academy Awards show on Sunday, referred incorrectly to “Killing the Blues,” a song featured in a commercial for J. C. Penney. Although the recording heard is from a new album by Alison Krauss and Robert Plant, the song itself is not new. (It is by John Prine and has been recorded by many artists.)

headline: The Terrible Toll of Art Anxiety
text: TEDDY GREENSPAN is a longtime art collector who does not suffer doubt. He is a bond salesman at Libertas Partners, in Greenwich, Conn., and he and his wife, Emily, recently created an art consulting company in Bedford, N.Y., called tag-arts. The pieces he sells average about $20,000, with a few selling for as much as $90,000; his clients, many of whom work in the financial fields, can well afford them. So you can imagine his frustration when dealing recently with a friend and potential client he calls “Mr. No-Name Hedge Fund Manager.”

headline: Former Prosecutor to Testify for Detainee
text: Until four months ago, Col. Morris D. Davis was the chief prosecutor at Guantánamo Bay and the most colorful champion of the Bush administration’s military commission system. He once said sympathy for detainees was nauseating and compared putting them on trial to dragging “Dracula out into the sunlight.”

headline: Tyree Talks the Talk, and Also Wears the Helmet
text: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  The helmet that Giants wide receiver David Tyree wore and used to help secure Eli Manning’s pass in the waning minutes of the Super Bowl glistened under the lights at the Yogi Berra Museum on Wednesday, proving that it was not covered in bubble gum or Velcro.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday by The Associated Press about the crash of a B-2 stealth bomber misspelled the name of the Air Force base in Guam from which the plane took off. It is Andersen Air Force Base, not Anderson.

headline: He Listens. He Cares. He Isn’t Real.
text: COMPASSION is an aphrodisiac. It is a potent elixir for sure to those who tune in to HBO five nights a week to watch Gabriel Byrne play Dr. Paul Weston, the rumpled, world-weary shrink of “In Treatment.”

headline: Rice Offers Regret After Marine Is Accused of Rape on Okinawa
text: TOKYO  Hoping to prevent outrage here from harming ties between the United States and Japan, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice expressed deep regret on Wednesday over a case in which an American marine is accused of raping a 14-year-old Japanese girl on Okinawa.

headline: A Plan to Keep the C.W.S. in Omaha
text: In an effort to keep the College World Series in Omaha, city officials on Wednesday announced plans to replace Rosenblatt Stadium with a $140 million downtown ballpark that would open in 2011.

headline: Celtics' Bench Mantra: 'Pinch Me'
text: Fortunes have changed dramatically for the Boston Celtics this season. But as Chuck Klosterman writes in "What a Difference a Man Makes," a number of players from the luckless 2007 team still play for the successful 2008 version, including several bench players. "These are the same people, living in the same city, holding the exact same jobs - yet so much about their lives has changed," he writes. Credit Kevin Garnett, the superstar acquired in the offseason. Brian Scalabrine, a seven-year veteran in the league and one of team's returning role players, tells Klosterman: "Look, I can keep saying a million clichés, but those clichés are going to be true... He demands a different level of focus from everybody." Still, the question remains: Can the Celtics, built around aging veterans with little playoff success, have more than a good regular season?

headline: BMW Plans to Eliminate 8,100 Jobs
text: FRANKFURT  BMW announced Wednesday that it was eliminating 8,100 jobs, as the rising euro pushed the company into the kind of tough cost-cutting it had resisted.

headline: At Fiery Meeting, UBS Shareholders Back Bid to Raise Cash
text: BASEL, Switzerland  Managers of the troubled Swiss bank UBS won shareholder backing Wednesday for a plan to raise capital, but only after facing fierce criticism over the huge write-downs on subprime investments that led to the bank’s first annual loss.

headline: Moving Forward Quickly After the Unification of Open-Wheel Racing
text: Tony George described the merger of his Indy Racing League and the Champ Car World Series as a unification at a news conference Wednesday in Homestead, Fla., but it sounded as if George’s open-wheel series would be virtually swallowing up its rival.

headline: $60 Million Gift Is a Record, for Stony Brook
text: James H. Simons, a mathematician turned investor, may be one of the world’s most successful  and wealthy  hedge fund managers, but he can remember how Stony Brook University gave him a berth after he lost his job as a Defense Department code-breaker for protesting the Vietnam War.

headline: The Modern Nursery, Batteries Required
text: MODERN technology aids in many of life’s experiences, with one noticeable oversight: raising infants.

headline: McCain’s Canal Zone Birth Prompts Queries About Whether That Rules Him Out
text: WASHINGTON  The question has nagged at the parents of Americans born outside the continental United States for generations: Dare their children aspire to grow up and become president? In the case of Senator John McCain of Arizona, the issue is becoming more than a matter of parental daydreaming.

headline: Justices Take Up Battle Over Exxon Valdez
text: WASHINGTON  The Exxon Valdez oil spill, which caused a 3,000-square-mile oil slick and still affects Alaska’s fisheries after nearly 19 years, was a “tragedy,” Exxon’s lawyer told the Supreme Court on Wednesday.

headline: U.S. and India to Strengthen Security Ties
text: NEW DELHI  With a landmark nuclear energy pact between the United States and India stalled, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that the nations would nonetheless strengthen their security ties as India looked to embark on a closer  and still contentious  level of military cooperation with the United States.

headline: Council Vote for Good Health May Weaken Business at Groceries in Poor Neighborhoods
text: They are fixtures of New York City life: sidewalk peddlers and the grocers who try to shoo them away from their storefronts. The City Council grudgingly added to that time-honored clash on Wednesday, approving a bill that will increase the number of fruit and vegetable carts in the city’s poor neighborhoods.

headline: Sprint Nextel Posts $29.5 Billion Loss
text: Daniel R. Hesse, Sprint Nextel’s new chief executive, tells it like it is  but on Thursday, investors didn’t like what they heard.

headline: Europe to Review Rules After Bailouts of 2 Banks
text: FRANKFURT  European Union regulators on Wednesday said they would investigate whether bailouts of two German banks hit by the subprime lending crisis had violated rules on state aid for ailing enterprises.

headline: Dell Misses Forecast as Profit Falls
text: SAN FRANCISCO  A year after it began a fundamental transformation of its basic formula, Dell missed analysts’ forecasts on Thursday for quarterly net income and revenue.

headline: Tip of the Week: Adding Songs to an iTunes Playlist
text: Want to quickly add a song in iTunes to a playlist without dragging it? Right-click (or control-click) on the song’s title in the iTunes window. Choose the “Add to Playlist” option from the menu and select a playlist; you can also select multiple songs and add them this way. And if you want to see how many playlists contain a certain song, click the song title and choose the “Show in Playlist” option to see a list.

headline: Catholic Principal Was Fired Over Photos, Official Says
text: The principal at a prominent Catholic boys’ high school in the Bronx was ousted late last week after photos of nude men were discovered on his computer, a law enforcement official confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Ranking Officer Expected to Testify About Sean Bell’s Killing
text: Prosecutors in the trial of three detectives accused in the shooting death of Sean Bell plan to call the detectives’ commanding officer to testify on Thursday about the club enforcement detail that he supervised, and to be questioned about supposed blunders it made, according to people who have been briefed on the case.

headline: Paparazzo Loses Case
text: A celebrity photographer who sued an Australian newspaper for defamation after it accused him of hounding Nicole Kidman has lost his case, The Associated Press reported. Not only did Justice Carolyn Simpson of the New South Wales Supreme Court find against the photographer, Jamie Fawcett, below, she also called his conduct “intrusive” and “threatening” and ordered him to pay the legal costs of Fairfax Media, the publisher of the newspaper he sued, The Sun-Herald. Ms. Kidman was a star witness in the case. Mr. Fawcett, who, the judge found, tried to bug the Kidman house in Sydney and engaged in a dangerous car chase, said he would probably appeal the court’s decision.

headline: Black Leader Changes Endorsement to Obama
text: DALLAS  Senator Barack Obama on Wednesday accepted the endorsement of Representative John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat and longtime African-American political leader, who switched his support from the presidential candidacy of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Private Medicare Plans’ Cost Questioned
text: WASHINGTON  Private Medicare plans often cost beneficiaries more than the traditional government-run Medicare program, Congressional investigators say.

headline: Beanie Babies Updated With a Web Connection
text: Toy collectors and cultural anthropologists, take note. The Beanie Babies 2.0 Collection has arrived in stores, with a Web-ready scratch-off code on every heart-shaped tag.

headline: The Boss's Legacy
text: Jonathan Mahler writes in this weekend's PLAY about the succession strategy within the Yankees, with George Steinbrenner firmly in the background and his two sons taking over control of the team. Though the original Boss hasn't left the scene entirely, this seems like a good time to take stock of his 24-year stewardship: When all is accounted for -- his six championships, his free spending, his blunders, his bluster, his impact on baseball overall -- how do you think we should view the elder Steinbrenner?

headline: Personality Plus: A Twin Takes Over
text: IT was hard to tell just who was talking over a plate of scrambled eggs at a cafe in the West Village on Tuesday: was it Elisa DeCarlo, a playwright and part-time vintage dealer, or her online alter ego, the Mad Fashionista? But neither one of her personalities was very pleased with the red carpet parade at Sunday night’s Oscars.

headline: Panel Advises Flu Shots for Children Up to Age 18
text: All children ages 6 months to 18 years in this country should receive an influenza shot every year, a federal advisory panel said on Wednesday.

headline: Federal Regulators to Ease Rules on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
text: Federal regulators for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the biggest buyers of American home mortgages, will remove limits on the amount of loans and securities the companies can own, a step that could help bolster the weakening housing market.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Heralded New Law Is Vetoed by Iraq’s Presidency Council
text: BAGHDAD  Political momentum in Iraq hit a sudden roadblock on Wednesday when a feud between the largest Shiite factions led to the veto of a law that had been passed with great fanfare two weeks ago. The law had been heralded by the Bush administration as a breakthrough for national reconciliation.

headline: David Watkin, 82, Cinematographer, Dies
text: David Watkin, a British cinematographer best known for the scenic splendor he framed for “Out of Africa” and for capturing the loping strides of runners on the beach in “Chariots of Fire,” set to the symphonic score by Vangelis, died on Feb. 19 at his home in Brighton, England. He was 82.

headline: Family Saga, Steinbrenner Style
text: From the moment Hank Steinbrenner commandeered Jonathan Mahler's rental car, navigated it through Tampa then swerved onto a walkway at Legends Field and pulled to stop a few feet from his offices, Mahler could sense something "very Steinbrennarian" about the older son who was taking command of the New York Yankees, along with his brother Hal. "Hank was in exile for so many years," Mahler said the other day, "but he's clearly quite comfortable stepping into this role."

headline: 1 in 100 U.S. Adults Behind Bars, New Study Says
text: For the first time in the nation’s history, more than one in 100 American adults is behind bars, according to a new report.

headline: Ousted Thai Premier Returns to Face Charges
text: BANGKOK  Saying “I miss my motherland,” former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra returned to Thailand on Thursday, 17 months after being ousted in a coup, and said he was ready to face corruption charges that have been brought against him.

headline: I’ll Have What She’s Having
text: COMPARED with an array of beverages, sports drinks are “wildly skewed to men,” said David Lockwood, a director of research at Mintel International, a market research group. Part of the reason, he said, is that women tend to avoid the high calories and salty taste. Manufacturers are coming out now with lower-calorie, lighter-flavored drinks aimed at fit women.

headline: Cheruiyot Seeks 4th Boston Title
text: No Kenyan man has won four Boston Marathons, but three Kenyans have won three each. One of them is Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot, and race officials announced that he would return April 21 for the 112th running of the race. His main challengers will include Patrick Ivuti and James Kwambai, also from Kenya. In the Chicago Marathon last October, Ivuti outleaned Jaouad Gharib of Morocco, the world champion. Kwambai finished second in Boston last year.

headline: Clinton’s Efforts on Ethanol Overlap Her Husband’s Interests
text: To big rounds of applause, three of the world’s richest men  Richard Branson, Ronald W. Burkle and Vinod Khosla  trooped onto a New York ballroom stage with former President Bill Clinton to pledge support for renewable energy projects to combat global warming and create jobs.

headline: New Jersey Braces for Cuts Sought by the Governor
text: TRENTON  From the emergency rooms of city hospitals to hayfields in horse country, from motor vehicle offices to small towns and state parks, New Jersey residents began bracing on Wednesday for the upheaval that Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s plan to reduce the state work force by 3,000 people and eliminate three government departments is expected to cause.

headline: Correction
text: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about homeowners who hire professional photographers to take pictures of their houses misidentified Juergen Nogai, who was shown with two such homeowners. He is a photographer and the business partner of another photographer, Julius Shulman, who was also pictured. Mr. Nogai is not Mr. Shulman’s assistant.

headline: For ‘A’ Students in Some Brooklyn Schools, a Cellphone and 130 Free Minutes
text: What’s the cheapest way to text message your friends? For thousands of the city’s middle school students, the answer now is to earn an “A.”

headline: They Come Bearing Mystique
text: Paris

headline: Winning Parties, Urging Unity, Press Pakistan’s Leader to Convene Parliament
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Nawaz Sharif, a former prime minister and an opposition leader, on Wednesday increased the pressure on President Pervez Musharraf by urging him to call a session of Parliament and contending that the three opposition parties discussing a coalition had won two-thirds of the seats.

headline: Europe Fines Microsoft $1.3 Billion
text: BRUSSELS European antitrust regulators on Wednesday fined Microsoft $1.3 billion for failing to comply with a 2004 judgment that the company had abused its market dominance. The new fine by the European Commission was the largest it has ever imposed on an individual company, and brings the total in fines imposed on Microsoft to about $2.5 billion, in current exchange rates.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A listing of American military deaths on Tuesday misstated the number of confirmed dead in the Iraq war as of then. It was 3,962, not 3,961. An updated Names of the Dead appears on Page A10 today.

headline: Think of Adidas, by Way of Porsche
text: AT least twice a year, a fashion reporter will write an article about “The New Modesty,” declaring that clothes are finally returning to well-constructed tailoring of subtlety and restraint. Then, in the same publication, you will see a fashion spread of an impossibly chiseled man in a python codpiece straddling a Russian supermodel wearing a bikini made of pink dental floss, and you wonder (1) what that writer was on; and (2) if humanity will ever be sophisticated again.

headline: Supreme Court Alters Tone in Discrimination Case
text: WASHINGTON  The failure to file the proper form to complain about job-related age discrimination does not deprive an employee of the ability to go into court later with a discrimination lawsuit, the Supreme Court ruled Wednesday.

headline: Robust Moves, Exuberant Yet Distinguished
text: Ballet de Monterrey traveled many miles from its home in northeastern Mexico to land at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. For the occasion the company laid out quite a spread: eight short dances featuring pageboy wigs, broken hearts, tango encounters, a stage that resembled a scene out of the 1982 film “Tron,” spooky masks, a Day of the Dead celebration and star-crossed lovers. But what really stood out in every work, no matter the tone, was exuberant dancing, occasionally blurred by exhaustion yet distinguished by willful, effervescent classicism.

headline: Mine Water Poses Danger of a Toxic Gusher
text: LEADVILLE, Colo.  In a snowswept trailer park, Emily Medina wakes each morning wondering whether she will be washed away by toxic water that local officials fear could burst from a decaying mine tunnel near her home.

headline: Freedom for Cubans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Thousands Are Warned of Clinic’s Dirty Syringes
text: LAS VEGAS  Thousands of patients may have been exposed to the hepatitis C virus because of an inappropriate medical practice at an outpatient clinic here over the past four years, state health officials said Wednesday.

headline: If You Build It ...
text: The goal of Dubai Sports City is both grand and simple: to be the ultimate destination for athletes and fans. And no expense is spared in the process.

headline: Pop Sales Resume Slide
text: Last week’s Billboard chart had some rare good news for the music industry, with sales bumps for Amy Winehouse and Herbie Hancock in the wake of their Grammy victories. But now it’s mostly back to the doldrums. Jack Johnson’s “Sleep Through the Static” (Brushfire/Universal) is No. 1 for a third week with a respectable 105,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. From there the numbers plunge. Alicia Keys’s “As I Am” (J) is No. 2 with 53,000, and Ms. Winehouse’s “Back to Black” (Universal Republic) is right behind it with 52,000; the new “Kidz Bop 13” (Razor & Tie) sold 49,000 copies to reach No. 4, and the soundtrack for “Step Up 2 the Streets” (Atlantic) rose five spots to No. 5, though its 43,000 sales were slightly less than the week before. Chris Cagle’s “My Life’s Been a Country Song” (Capitol Nashville) opened at No. 9 with 37,000.

headline: Businesses, Worried About Economy, Invest Less
text: Hesitant about the shaky economy, American businesses are cutting back on investments and equipment. And the housing industry, in its worst crisis since the early 1990s, is poised for several months of anemic sales.

headline: Poor Start for Quarterlife
text: NBC’s new drama “Quarterlife,” which made its debut on the Internet, got off to a sluggish start in the network television ratings on Tuesday, drawing just 3.9 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The new series, from the creators of “My So-Called Life” and “Thirtysomething,” Marshall Herskovitz and Edward Zwick, finished third in the 10 p.m. time slot behind CBS’s “Jericho” (6.9 million) and ABC’s “Primetime” (7.6 million). NBC ranked third for the night over all in total viewers but second among adults 18 to 49, thanks to a solid showing for “The Biggest Loser” from 8 to 10 (8.1 million). Fox dominated the night’s ratings with “American Idol” at 8 (28.5 million), followed by “Back to You,” which earned a series-high 12.3 million viewers at 9:30. CBS was runner-up in total viewers for the night but third in the 18-to-49 set. ABC finished fourth.

headline: Black Ohioans Backing Clinton Feel the Pressure to Switch
text: CLEVELAND  The way Eugene R. Miller was hemming and hawing about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, you would have thought he was trying to sell igloos in the Sahara.

headline: Despite Nafta Attacks, Clinton and Obama Haven’t Been Free Trade Foes
text: As they have tussled for votes in economically beleaguered Ohio, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton have both excoriated the North American Free Trade Agreement while lobbing accusations against their opponent on the issue.

headline: Some Fear the Scope of Nortel Is a Liability
text: OTTAWA  For investors in Nortel Networks, Wednesday’s news release fit a familiar pattern.

headline: Bloomberg Says He Won’t Run but Will Be Active
text: Bringing an end to a long flirtation with a bid for the White House, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has officially closed the door on a presidential candidacy this year.

headline: Gates Urges Limits on Turkish Raids
text: BAGHDAD  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates urged Turkish leaders on Wednesday to abandon their invasion of guerrilla-controlled lands in the northernmost reaches of Iraq by mid-March.

headline: A PC That Imagines Itself on the Move Between Home Office and Living Room
text: If desktop computers are ever going to get out of the home office, they need to be smaller, prettier and quieter. The Asus Nova P22, priced at $749 to $899 depending on options, is a step forward in all three directions, weighing just under 4 pounds and measuring 9 by 7.2 by 2 inches.

headline: It’s Not a Cellphone, but It’ll Get Your Words Across
text: The Sony Mylo Personal Communicator COM-2, or Mylo 2, is a device situated firmly in the netherworld between laptops and cellphones. It has Wi-Fi and a touch screen, but it can make only Skype phone calls. It has a keyboard, but you wouldn’t want to type your novel into it. It’s not a media player, but it can handle audio, photos and video.

headline: ‘Black Cars’ Are Destined to Turn Green
text: Those long lines of sleek black cars that idle outside corporate headquarters, belching exhaust as they wait to shuttle executives from meeting to meeting, will become more environmentally friendly under a plan announced on Wednesday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: Wine’s Global Reach Brings New Buyers to Bordeaux
text: ST.-MARTIN-DU-PUY, France  The chateau’s walled courtyard under the gracefully decaying 15th-century tower and the irregular pond, stone-lined and shaped roughly like a kidney, caught Haiyan Cheng’s eye.

headline: 18 Finalists for Hall Announced
text: Brian Boitano, Joan Benoit Samuelson, Oscar De La Hoya and David Robinson head a list of 18 finalists announced Wednesday for the United States Olympic Hall of Fame. The public will select six inductees.Boitano won the gold medal in men’s figure skating in 1988. In 1984, Samuelson won the first Olympic marathon for women. De La Hoya won boxing’s lightweight gold medal in 1992 and Robinson basketball gold medals in 1992 and 1996.The other individual finalists are Greg Barton (kayak), Bruce Baumgartner (wrestling), Jeff Blatnick (wrestling), Valerie Brisco (track and field), Teresa Edwards (basketball), Karch Kiraly (volleyball), Mary T. Meagher (swimming), Sheila Young Ochowicz (speed skating), Darrell Pace (archery), Michael Plumb (equestrian), John Smith (wrestling), Amy Van Dyken (swimming), Peter Westbrook (fencing) and Lones Wigger (shooting).

headline: Corrections
text: Editors' Note

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A picture caption with an article in some editions last Thursday about concerns that New York City’s plans to rezone 125th Street in Harlem would force out many black residents and small businesses referred incompletely to a street scene along East 125th Street, shown in the picture at left. It was taken in 1975. (The picture at right showed a current scene of nighttime commerce between Fifth Avenue and Malcolm X Boulevard.)

headline: Room to Improve
text: Q. How can I create a faux brick wall in my home?

headline: Chile: 11 Die as Plane Crashes Into Ball Field
text: A small police plane crashed into a soccer field in Santiago, the capital, where dozens of women and children were enjoying their first day of aerobics classes, and burst into flames. The plane’s six occupants and three women and a child on the field were killed immediately. Another woman, seriously burned, died later. Seven other women were said to have suffered critical burns. The cause of the crash was unknown. The plane, a Cessna, crashed minutes after taking off from the nearby Tobalaba airport, which residents have been demanding be relocated from the populous residential area.

headline: George Mason Calmer 2 Years After Final Four Run
text: FAIRFAX, Va.  After George Mason’s unimaginable Final Four run in 2006, Patriots forward Will Thomas found that visits to the dining hall inevitably regressed into eat-and-greets.

headline: Bush and Czech Leader Close to Deal on Radar
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush and the Czech leader said Wednesday that they were close to an agreement on a plan for the United States to install an early warning radar system in the Czech Republic, a key component of a missile defense system that has drawn stiff opposition from Russia.

headline: Hillary, Buckeye Girl
text: ZANESVILLE, Ohio

headline: A Little Nuke Music
text: The New York Philharmonic’s concert in Pyongyang was a tantalizing taste of what might be in America’s relationship with North Korea. It was also a reminder of the missteps and dangerously wrongheaded judgments that have kept the two countries apart and at saber-point for more than a half century.

headline: In a Season of Lows, a High Point Is Reached
text: When Jamal Crawford inexplicably threw himself an alley-oop off the backboard and missed the dunk attempt, and when Coach Isiah Thomas did not budge from his seat on the bench, the Madison Square Garden crowd knew it was the Knicks’ night.

headline: China Says Poisoning Was Isolated
text: BEIJING (Bloomberg News)  The Chinese government reported Thursday that the pesticide-laced dumplings that sickened at least 10 people in Japan might have been deliberately poisoned, but that its investigators found no evidence that the contamination had occurred in China.

headline: A Surrealistic Journey to Mexico With Paul Taylor
text: The rehearsal studio is narrow and a little battered, with uncompromising sunlight pouring in from windows overlooking Broadway. Paul Taylor watches his dancers, his big, lean, denim-clad body hunching into his chair, a cigarette constantly in hand and a cup of coffee never far. An invisible curtain rises on a flesh-and-blood dancer, a smiling Mexican flower seller who seems to have stepped out of a travel poster just as the music begins for “De Sueños” (“Of Dreams”) and “De Sueños Que Se Repiten” (“Of Recurring Dreams”), new works that are centerpieces of the Paul Taylor Dance Company’s City Center season, which opens on Thursday.

headline: Top F.T.C. Official Expected to Resign
text: The chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission is expected to resign her post next month to take a senior position at Procter & Gamble, according to people briefed on her plans.

headline: Easing the Pain of Collecting
text: JEN BEKMAN’S apartment is hardly what you would expect from a woman who has made herself a force in the art world in the last five years, building a photography and fine arts Web site that draws international collectors and earning an innovator-of-the-year title from American Photo magazine.

headline: Detroit Mayor Loses Fight Over Secret Papers
text: DETROIT  The Michigan Supreme Court on Wednesday ordered the release of a trove of documents that revealed how Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit and city lawyers tried to cover up Mr. Kilpatrick’s extramarital affair with his chief of staff, as well as text messages that could expose the mayor to perjury charges.

headline: Building a Web of Influence
text: I’VE always thought I’d make a great chief executive of a Fortune 500 company. I have strong organizational skills, for instance, and I would be happy to slash redundant divisions to raise the stock price.

headline: Bernanke Says Sagging Growth Is Chief Concern
text: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, signaled his readiness on Wednesday to bolster the economy with cheaper money even though inflation is picking up speed.

headline: As Gaming Turns Social, Industry Shifts Strategies
text: SAN FRANCISCO  Even before Electronic Arts roiled the video game world on Sunday with its $2 billion hostile takeover bid for Take-Two Interactive, even before Phil Harrison, president of Sony’s worldwide game studios, announced his resignation on Monday, one could plainly see the creative and financial disruptions underlying the industry’s explosive growth.

headline: Longtime Clinton Aide Returns to the Fray
text: ARLINGTON, Va.  Harold M. Ickes may be Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s last hope for winning the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Nonprofit Diabetes Group Is Subject of Investigation
text: The Manhattan district attorney is investigating the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International after an internal audit showed that hundreds of thousands of dollars was missing. The audit led to the dismissal of two foundation employees.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a lawsuit filed against energy companies by an Alaska Native coastal village that is being forced to relocate because of flooding caused by the changing Arctic climate misstated the estimated cost of moving the village. It could cost up to $400 million, not up to $400,000.

headline: Putin’s Anointed Heir Shows Hints of Less Icy Style
text: ALABINO, Russia  Dmitri A. Medvedev, the man chosen to be the next Russian president, sat surrounded by soldiers. It was Feb. 23, Defenders of the Motherland Day, and Mr. Medvedev had traveled to the parade grounds of the Tamanskaya Motorized Rifle Division outside Moscow.

headline: Bill Gates and Other Happenings at LinkedIn
text: Bill Gates has changed his social networking allegiance.

headline: More Dubai: Fund makes bid for troubled Spanish property firm
text: Not to get off on a Dubai tangent here, but a Dubai-based investment fund made a €3 billion ($4.5 billion) bid Wednesday for a majority stake in Colonial, the struggling Spanish property giant.

headline: Paris: Just Clothes
text: I’m sitting in my hotel room, it’s 7 in the morning, and Carlos, the waiter in my hotel, has gratefully arrived with the black coffee and the boiled egg. A light rain is falling; my kind of day in Paris. Yesterday was a barn-burner: long, with deadlines and many shows, and not very good shows at that. Givenchy was the march of the toothpicks. Super-skinny pants with feminine blouses and jackets with Spanish or Sud de France embroidery. Either way, you felt the influence, from way, way back, of Ghesquiere (the Jules Verne collection, among others) and, much closer, Christian Lacroix, especially in the last black and white coat.

headline: Even Solo Workers Want Company
text: There is a lot of buzz these days about coworking (without the hyphen), a new movement — well chronicled in this recent New York Times article — in which people share a workspace to combat loneliness, forge a community and enjoy the creative sparks generated by like-minded people. But coworking is about much more than sharing a workspace. It is a global movement whose adherents follow certain principles (check out the terrific video at the bottom of this page), including environmental responsibility and a free exchange of ideas. Interestingly, these spaces are not usually run for a profit; they tend to be more mission-focused.

headline: Revisiting the Other Half of Jacob Riis
text: Mention Jacob A. Riis, and what usually comes to mind are spectral black-and-white images of New Yorkers in the squalor of tenements on the Lower East Side. The commonly held view of Riis is that of the muckraking police reporter, whose seminal 1890 work, “How the Other Half Lives,” prompted legislative reforms, focused attention on the desperate lives of poor urban immigrants and left an enduring mark on the history of documentary photography.

headline: Scent Notes | Angel Men Pure Coffee by Thierry Mugler
text: In the only conversation I’ve ever had with the movie critic David Denby, in a kitchen on New Year’s Day, I mentioned some terribly obvious movie that had done extremely well despite Denby’s (and everyone else’s) having ripped it apart. He shrugged. “It’s critic-proof,” he said, and made a round motion with his hands. No point of critical entry. I think the most interesting thing about Thierry Mugler’s Angel Men Pure Coffee, a limited edition scent landing this April and hanging around for a scant four months or so, is that it feels critic-proof as well. It is jarringly direct, like the person blithely unflustered by your eye contact. It is, in its friendly self-assurance, impossible to approach with any kind of critical knife; irritatingly disarming, it is as effortlessly pleasing as it is exasperatingly obvious. The one difference between Pure Coffee and the movie is that this scent is excellent.

Instead, state officials will establish a task force made up of city officials, the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, state legislative leaders, hotel and tourism executives to address the future of the convention and trade show industry in New York.

headline: Saturn Imitates Louis XIV
text: Sometimes science imitates art. The Greeks myths told how Enceladus, a Giant who was buried beneath Mount Etna, caused earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. At Versailles, Louis XIV built a fountain in his honor. When the Giant’s name was given to one of Saturn’s moons in the 19th century, no one had any idea what was on that faint dot in the sky, but it turns that Enceladus really does have underground rumblings and a mysterious fountain.

headline: Pettitte Weary of Clemens Story

People might think that Andy Pettitte gets no peace with reporters after him 24/7 asking about the Roger Clemens mess. Not so. Pettitte usually floats in and out of the clubhouse just like the rest of his teammates. He is not a pressing topic every moment.

headline: $6.50 to Enter a Taxi?

Bloomberg’s congestion pricing proposal held a 2 p.m. news conference to propose an alternative plan that would aim to reduce traffic by charging a $4 surcharge on all taxi and limousine rides. The “drop charge” — the flat fee imposed once a passenger enters a cab — would rise to $6.50 from $2.50, but the subsequent charge would be reduced to 35 cents per one-fifth of a mile, down from the current charge of 40 cents per one-fifth of a mile.

headline: And for Our Next Act

And it’s an incredibly entertaining read. We’re putting together a great panel, which we will announce soon. Until then, start reading: the book is a page-turner, but it’s long!

headline: Podcast: The State of Conservatism

headline: The Relevance of Ralph
text: Eight years ago, I traveled the country with Ralph Nader. He was sardonic and surprisingly funny. As we drove through post-industrial landscapes of depressing sameness, Mr. Nader kept up a constant monologue about the spiritual costs of box stores and fast food. I recall standing at an airport counter — it was Sioux Falls, or maybe Fargo — where the agent cheerfully informed Mr. Nader that he had been upgraded to first class; he protested vigorously and smoldered the entire flight home. After Mr. Nader was tossed out of the presidential debate site in Boston, he and I watched the next debate in front of the TV at the brownstone that was his Washington headquarters. I ate pizza as Mr. Nader paced the room trying out phantom debate lines and railing against the two “corporate supremacists” on stage, who, he pointed out, refused to mention the plight of the working poor, the tilt of the political system toward special interests, the human toll of free trade.Mr. Nader’s candidacy took a dark turn in the closing weeks of the 2000 campaign. Until then, he had been running primarily to get the 5 percent of the vote he needed to qualify the Green Party for matching funds. But then Mr. Nader’s consuming resentment — at the way leading Democrats pressured his friends to denounce him, at the way Al Gore refused to speak his name — seemed to possess him, and at some point he seemed to make it his mission to deny Mr. Gore the presidency, attacking his Democratic rival in swing states over the protests of his own aides. I’ve always thought that Mr. Gore probably could have avoided what came next simply by picking up the phone in those final weeks and making some small gesture of respect toward the man. But he didn’t, and Mr. Nader got his wish.

headline: Wild Wheat
text: There was a time when commodities markets were viewed with deep suspicion by farmers, who saw speculators and gamblers manipulating the prices of crops to benefit themselves and steal from farmers. In 1874, one house of the Illinois legislature approved a bill to make it a crime to trade a futures contract unless the seller actually had possession of the crop. The Chicago Board of Trade managed to water down the law to bar the trading of options, but not futures, and thus stayed in business.

text: With the Democratic nomination still not decided, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton have understandably pulled out all the stops to woo Democratic superdelegates, the party grandees who might ultimately determine the nominee.

headline: A Lifetime of Pain, and She Still Will Not Complain
text: Hazel Reese didn’t realize she was suicidal until the day she was filling out the intake form at her first appointment at Chicago’s Diamond Headache Clinic in 1982. That was when she read the question asking if she had ever tried to take her own life.

headline: Why I’m Afraid of the Clintons
text: If it’s not the first rule of Republican politics, it should be: never, ever, ever underestimate anybody whose last name is Clinton. Not Bill, not Hillary. Not Chelsea, not even George. They’re very good at what they do, and when they’re about to be written off for dead, that’s when they’re at their very best.

headline: An End to One-Child Families in China?
text: Jim Yardley in our Beijing bureau reports, along with others, on hints that after 30 years, China appears poised to relax its one-child policies. Demographers I consulted today said this could overturn predictions of an imminent end to global population growth. [UPDATE, 3/6: I added a followup post with China’s denial, sort of.]

headline: YSL: The Chic is Real
text: Nicolas Ghesquiere finally has someone to set his shoulder against. Tonight, Stefano Pilati hammered out his best Saint Laurent collection since he became creative director. This is the first group of clothes that has captured the energy of the Rive Gauche era and at the same time feels contemporary. You are no longer looking at any trace of the old Saint Laurent, except perhaps a jewel color, and yet it is Saint Laurent. Pilati carries forward the simplified lines of the spring collection and now adds more sex appeal, more flare to the geometry. The collection has a lot of versaility, but your eye goes immediately to the straight shoulders of unlined, cutaway coats in Donegal tweeds and then to the succinct volumes at the hem. Sharpness at the top, movement and freedom at the bottom, an effect repeated in wool felt coats and skirts.

headline: Data Points on Google’s Growth
text: On Tuesday, a report by comScore said that Internet users in the United States were clicking on Google ads far less frequently than expected. The news spooked investors, fanning worries that Google’s growth might be stalling, and that the company would not be immune to the broader economic slowdown. The company’s shares, which have been falling since their early November peak, dropped 4.6 percent on Tuesday. They regained some ground in the last two days.

headline: The Greatest Living Yankee, Right Across the Hall
text: So I was coming back to my hotel room early this evening, and who’s in the lobby but the great Yogi Berra? He said he was just coming in from a round of golf. Turns out he’s in the room right across the hall. There’s just something neat about that. The greatest living Yankee is sleeping just a few feet away. Sounds like the start of a novel.

headline: Russia Is Luring Back N.H.L. Stars
text: YAROSLAVL, Russia  When Alexei Yashin moved to this worn-out, provincial city 4,500 miles and seemingly centuries away from his former home in New York, he left behind his plush Western lifestyle, multimillion-dollar salary and the home base of his supermodel wife. He also ended a career in the National Hockey League, turning his back on a dream shared by nearly every young Russian with a stick and skates for the last 15 years.

headline: Top Officer at Queens Club Testifies in Sean Bell Case
text: The group of police officers and detectives involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell outside a strip club in Queens had first planned to work elsewhere that night, but changed their plan when they could not find the drug dealer they wanted to arrest, the group’s commanding officer testified on Thursday.
