text: When Raymond Zulueta went into default on his mortgage last year, he did what a lot of people do. He worried.

headline: 'Idol' Still Glitters
text: Fox dominated Wednesday night’s ratings with a 90-minute edition of “American Idol,” which drew 27.4 million viewers, according to Nielsen’s estimates. The network’s wide lead over its competitors eroded considerably at 9:30 p.m., as Fox’s “Back to You” earned a more modest 12.3 million viewers during the half-hour following the singing competition. NBC ranked a distant second over all, getting a boost at 10 p.m. from “Law & Order,” which led its time slot with 11.4 million viewers, outpacing both CBS’s “CSI: NY” repeat (8 million) and the return of ABC’s “Men in Trees” (5.7 million). CBS and ABC ranked third and fourth respectively. On Tuesday MSNBC’s broadcast of the Democratic presidential primary debate in Ohio delivered 7.8 million viewers, making it the third-highest-rated debate of this season and the most-watched program in MSNBC’s 11-year history.

headline: China to Reconsider One-Child Limit
text: BEIJING  China is studying how to move away from the country’s one-child-per-couple restriction, but any changes would come gradually and would not mean an elimination of family planning policies, a senior official said Thursday.

headline: Senate Kin and the Campaign Kitty
text: A worthy House measure to clamp down on members of Congress who employ relatives using campaign donations has disappeared into the maw of the Senate. A nonprofit watchdog group, Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, may have come up with a reason why. It has uncovered at least 20 senators who have paid out more than $500,000 in campaign funds to family members since 2000.

headline: Fathers and Sons in Gloom Above Rio’s Sunny Beaches
text: The most disquieting moment in “City of Men,” a rootin’-tootin’ gangster movie shot in the notoriously lawless shantytowns overlooking the beaches of Rio de Janeiro, is also the most subdued. Acerola, a k a Ace (Douglas Silva), an 18-year-old still carrying baby fat, admits that he is frightened and unprepared to care for his infant son as his wife, Cris (Camila Monteiro), leaves to find work in São Paulo. Although Ace loves his little boy, he is only a child in a man’s body himself, and he begs her not to go. For him to assume full parental responsibility is almost unimaginable.

headline: On a Treasure Hunt, Uncovering Modern Wonders
text: “Works on Paper,” a gathering of 78 purveyors of drawings, prints, posters and photographs at the Park Avenue Armory, is not one of those jaw-dropping fairs that confront you at every turn with shockingly expensive brand-name wonders. And though it features mostly modern and contemporary material, there is little in it to challenge conservative tastes. Yet once you adjust to its low-key visual register, perusing the exhibition becomes enthralling and often revelatory.

headline: Obama Cutting Into Clinton’s Edge Among Superdelegates
text: Senator Barack Obama has made significant inroads over the last month among the Democratic elected officials and party leaders known as superdelegates who will cast a fifth of the votes at the party’s convention, cutting into Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s long-held advantage with the group.

headline: Bipartisan Spirit Falters in Fights on Debt Relief

headline: A Haunting Enigma of Violence and Chaos
text: The picture of Iceland that emerges in Baltasar Kormákur’s “Jar City” is vivid and powerful but not something the country’s tourist board would be likely to endorse. The landscape has its austere poetry to be sure  mountains framing the apartment blocks of Reykjavik, spits of volcanic rock jutting into a churning sea  but a fog of damp unhappiness seems to pervade every face and conversation.

text: “Cinderella” meets “The Ugly Duckling” in “Penelope,” a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character, played by Christina Ricci, is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.

It will be a welcome strengthening of a foreign aid program that was already one of the shining accomplishments of the Bush administration.

headline: Latest Legal News for Two Pop Singers
text: Amy Winehouse, above left, doesn’t have to worry about a hearing on drug-possession charges in Norway as long as her husband stays in a British jail. That was the essence of a court ruling on Thursday in Bergen, Norway, where the Grammy-winning Ms. Winehouse was scheduled to appear on Friday, Agence France-Presse reported. “One of the people involved in the case, Blake Fielder-Civil, Amy Winehouse’s husband, is currently in jail in Britain and can’t make the trip,” said Anne Vedvik of the Bergen court. “The hearing has therefore been postponed to an undetermined date.” Ms. Winehouse, 24, her husband and her hairdresser were arrested in Bergen in October and charged with possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana. Ms. Winehouse was released after paying a $756 fine, which she later contested. Agreeing to a fine in Norway is equivalent to admitting the charges, which could make it difficult for Ms. Winehouse to obtain visas. Mr. Fielder-Civil has been in custody since November, awaiting trial on charges of assault and conspiracy to pervert the cause of justice. He is accused of trying to bribe a barman not to testify against him in an assault case. ... Boy George, above right, denied on Thursday that he imprisoned a 28-year-old Norwegian man at his London home last year, The Associated Press reported. Appearing in a London court under his real name, George O’Dowd, he pleaded not guilty to a charge of false imprisonment lodged by Audun Carlsen, who claimed that he was handcuffed to a wall after he went to Boy George’s apartment in April as a photo model. Boy George, 46, is free on bail and is to stand trial in November.

headline: The People’s Artist, Herself a Work of Art
text: PHILADELPHIA  You really should come down, a friend e-mailed me this summer from Mexico City. She meant, come down for the Frida Kahlo centennial, with a retrospective at the Palacio de Bellas Artes and displays of memorabilia at Casa Azul, the Blue House, Kahlo’s home. You should come, she wrote, not just for the art, which looks fabulous, but for the place, the people.

headline: Festival Highlights

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Feb. 13 about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, misstated the circumstances of his office’s prosecution in 2002 of James Treffinger, then the Essex County executive. Mr. Treffinger was seized by armed F.B.I. agents, but not at gunpoint. The article also misspelled the surname of a former prosecutor in Mr. Christie’s office who said partisan politics did not play a role in whom the office investigated. He is Scott Resnik, not Resnick.

headline: Councilman Is Said to Be Considering a Plea Deal
text: A city councilman accused of rape has entered into negotiations with the Queens district attorney’s office that could keep him out of jail if he pleads guilty to a misdemeanor and agrees to resign, among other conditions, according to people familiar with the discussions.

text: GOSHEN, Ohio  The scream that Dustin Carter let loose in a gym here last weekend conveyed equal parts pain and elation. It was the sound of glory for a high school senior who wrestles unlike any of his opponents.

headline: Prosecutors Build Case Against Pellicano

headline: Israel Sees Escalation in Gazans’ Longer-Range Strikes

headline: A Glide Along Minnesota’s Gunflint Trail
text: IN Minnesota, a state known for its relentless winters, there’s a spot in the pointy northeastern corner known as the Arrowhead, where snow falls earlier, drifts deeper and hangs on longer. That spot is centered on a 57-mile-long road called the Gunflint Trail.

headline: Mets Unveil Their Own Health Plan: Keep Alou on the Field
text: JUPITER, Fla.  The oldest position player in baseball enters the clubhouse with only a few minutes to spare, removes his sunglasses and puts on his favorite blue Smarty Jones T-shirt. He makes a brief call on his cellphone, gets his ankles taped and wolfs down a quick breakfast.

headline: Report to Senators Says Many States Are Lax in Funding Their Pension Plans
text: Congressional auditors said Thursday that many states have been failing to set aside enough money for the pensions they owe public workers, and are likely to face fiscal distress, particularly those states that have also promised to help cover retiree health costs.

headline: Stocks Dive on New Signs of Economic Chill

headline: Semi-Animated History of an Animated Time
text: The 1968 Democratic National Convention in Chicago  to say nothing of the violent confrontations between police and antiwar protesters that simultaneously seethed in the city’s parks and streets  can hardly be called an obscure historical event. Demonstrators chanted, “The whole world is watching,” and so it was. Images of blue-helmeted officers and their long-haired antagonists have been part of the collective memory ever since.

headline: A Relaxed Mountain Retreat That Offers More Than Snow
text: ONE HUNDRED miles east of the smog, gridlock and vanity of Los Angeles, cupped high in the pine forests of the San Bernardino Mountains, sits Big Bear Lake, a glistening splash of fresh alpine water ringed by 22 miles of shoreline. A resort town of the same name hugs the lake’s south shore and offers a multiseason retreat.

headline: Modern Pool for Public Is Opening in Flushing
text: In an era of private grandeur, New York City has built a temple for the public in Queens: the Flushing Meadows-Corona Park Natatorium and Ice Rink  it does not even have a corporate name  which is to open on Friday.

headline: Asian Tour Ends on a High Note
text: After two encores at the Seoul Arts Center, the New York Philharmonic gave the audience of 2,500 what it had been waiting for, The Associated Press reported: “Arirang,” the wistful folk song that is an unofficial anthem for reunification of the two Koreas. Thunderous applause and cries of “Bravo!” erupted from audience members, who rose from their seats after the music ended on Thursday. “There’s no sides; there’s no North and South in ‘Arirang,’ ” Lorin Maazel, the orchestra’s music director, said afterward. “It’s a melody for everybody. All these artificially created barriers fade away.” Backstage, Park Sam-koo, chairman of the Kumho-Asiana Culture Foundation, referred to the combined population of the Koreas when he told Mr. Maazel, “Seventy million Koreans love you.” Besides “Arirang,” which the orchestra also played in Pyongyang, the Seoul program included Beethoven’s Piano Concerto No. 2, featuring the South Korean pianist Son Yeol-eum, and Beethoven’s Symphony No. 5.

headline: U.S. Imprisons One in 100 Adults, Report Finds
text: For the first time in the nation’s history, more than one in 100 American adults are behind bars, according to a new report.

headline: A Goofball’s Quest: Slam Dunk for Survival
text: A throwaway scene in “Semi-Pro,” a comedy starring Will Ferrell as Jackie Moon, the owner, coach, promoter and star of a struggling 1970s-era basketball team, boils Mr. Ferrell’s macho man-child persona down to a sentence.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in some editions last Friday about a proposal for a waterfront park near the United Nations building in Manhattan referred incorrectly to the status of a request to Sheldon Solow, the owner of an adjacent site, for an easement allowing access to the park property. Although a member of a local community board said Mr. Solow “hadn’t said anything yet” about granting the easement, Mr. Solow’s company, East River Realty, said it had in fact responded to the request. In an e-mail statement issued the day that officials announced the proposal at a news conference, the company said, “We will certainly consider creating an easement.”

headline: NBC Pulls the Plug on 'Quarterlife'
text: NBC pulled “Quarterlife,” the made-for-Internet series, on Thursday, after broadcasting only one low-rated episode. The network had intended to run the series on the next five Sunday nights; “Dateline NBC” and reruns of “Law & Order” will replace it. On Wednesday Marshall Herskovitz, a co-creator of the series, said it did not belong on broadcast television because its subject matter, the lives of blog-savvy men and women in their 20s, was too narrow for a network audience. “If it was going to go on TV, it probably should have been on a cable network, and that’s probably where it’s going to end up,” Mr. Herskovitz said at a conference at Harvard. An NBC spokeswoman confirmed that the show would run its course on the Bravo cable channel. “Quarterlife” stirred considerable interest as the first network show born on the Internet. It originally consisted of eight-minute Web episodes, which were then strung together into one-hour episodes for television.

headline: Texas on Pace for Record Voter Turnout
text: SPRING, Tex.  Anita Dawkins has never voted early. But there she was Wednesday, a 48-year old homemaker, or “domestic engineer,” as Ms. Dawkins called herself, lining up outside the Barbara Bush Branch Library in this fast-growing northern Houston suburb “to beat the crowds” and cast her primary ballot for Senator Barack Obama.

headline: Yes, There’s the Trial, but There Are Also Broader Statistics
text: Inevitably, emotions ran high this week with the start of the trial in the 50-shot police killing of Sean Bell. That much was obvious in protests outside the courthouse in Queens. It was obvious in angry comments posted on blogs.

headline: Buddy Miles, 60, Hendrix Drummer, Dies
text: Buddy Miles, the drummer in Jimi Hendrix’s Band of Gypsys and a hitmaker under his own name with the song “Them Changes,” died on Tuesday at his home in Austin, Tex. He was 60.

headline: Goyas Get a New Look
text: Two celebrated Goya paintings damaged during the Spanish Civil War are being restored by the Prado in Madrid for “Goya and the War Years,” an exhibition scheduled to run at the museum from April 14 through July 13, Agence France-Presse reported. Though the paintings, “Charge of the Mamelukes” and “The Shootings of May 3rd,” have been on view at the Prado, Manuela Mena, who is in charge of conserving Goya’s works, said this was the first restoration to repair damage to parts of the paintings that show buildings and heads. Both works depict a popular uprising in Madrid that led to Spain’s war against France from 1808 to 1814. They were damaged when transported to the Mediterranean port of Valencia to safeguard them from bombings in Madrid.

headline: Reduce the Risk
text: Here are recommendations to minimize your risk if your vacation home is in a region with wild animals:

headline: Strike at Auto Parts Supplier Stops Work at a G.M. Plant
text: DETROIT  General Motors halted production at one of its pickup truck plants Thursday afternoon when it ran out of some parts because the workers who make them are on strike.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Sharp Rebuke for Developer in Big Project at Landfills
text: The inspector general of New Jersey sharply criticized a developer and a politically powerful law firm, accusing them of bungling a billion-dollar project to clean up landfills in the Meadowlands and replace them with golf courses and houses. The official asked the state attorney general to determine whether a criminal investigation was warranted.

headline: Judith Jamison to Retire in 2011
text: Judith Jamison, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, announced on Thursday that she would retire in 2011. She plans to maintain her connection to the company, which she joined as a dancer in 1965, as artistic director emerita.

headline: Spare Times: For Children
text: FOR CHILDREN

headline: A Series and Its Sponsor Capture a Shared Link With History
text: ALTHOUGH television is a visual medium, sound is also important. And there are few sweeter sounds for viewers than the words “brought to you with limited commercial interruption by. ... ”

headline: Prince Harry Withdrawn From Afghanistan
text: LONDON  The Defense Ministry announced Friday that Prince Harry, the third in line to the British throne, would have to come home from Afghanistan because it was too risky for him to stay there.

headline: More Radio for Seacrest
text: Ryan Seacrest, a familiar face on “American Idol,” also wants to be a familiar voice on pop radio. This spring Mr. Seacrest, who is already the host of “American Top 40,” a four-hour national weekend radio show, will also become the host of a nationally syndicated three-hour show, Premiere Radio Networks announced on Thursday. The show, to run Monday through Friday, will borrow from Mr. Seacrest’s successful morning program on KIIS-FM in Los Angeles, with custom insertions for local stations. Mr. Seacrest, 33, will control some of the advertising time on the new show.

headline: Open Country for Women of a Certain Age
text: The synopsis of “Bonneville” makes it sound like “Thelma and Louise” in first gear: A recent widow named Arvilla Holden (Jessica Lange) and her two best friends, Carol and Margene (Joan Allen and Kathy Bates), hit the road in Idaho in a 1966 Pontiac convertible to deliver an urn full of ashes to a funeral in Santa Barbara, Calif., bickering, bonding and facing hard truths along the way.

headline: The Week in Twang, Day by Day
text: Acoustic music, especially bluegrass, has found new momentum and a new generation of pickers, and can be found every night of the week these days in clubs around New York. (The number preceding each item corresponds to a location on the map at right.)

headline: Movie Guide and Film Series
text: MOVIES

headline: Stringer’s Crowded Résumé Has a Spot Left
text: C. Vivian Stringer has to win the national championship. That’s all there is to it. No coming close, no near miss, no rainbow at the end of a tunnel.

headline: California: Bringing Home Babies
text: Two American families have been notified that they can bring home their adopted Vietnamese babies, who initially had been denied United States entry visas over concerns they were not actually orphaned. One of the mothers, Julie Carroll, who adopted an 11-month-old girl in September, said by phone from Camarillo, Calif., that she was “overjoyed” and that her husband, Steve Carroll, was flying to Hanoi. Mr. Carroll and another adoptive father, Claude McRoberts, of Seaside, Calif., planned to retrieve their girls from foster care. The State Department, which has urged families to beware of possible baby buying and other irregularities in Vietnamese adoptions, confirmed that the families had been given visa notifications.

headline: Retooled State Ballet of Georgia Shows Its Wares
text: I wonder what the State Ballet of Georgia looked like in 2004. According to a program note for its current engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the dancer and choreographer Vakhtang Chabukiani had transformed it “into one of the leading dance ensembles of the former Soviet Union” and “choreographed ballets which became Soviet classics” during his 30-year tenure as artistic director starting in 1941; then, from 1973 on, George Aleksidze “brought the SBG to another level.”

headline: New York City Education Department Proposes Changes in School Grades
text: The New York City school system has released a list of proposed changes to its system of grading schools, intended to soften some of the sting of the blunt A through F grades, as well as to measure school quality more accurately.

headline: William Buckley’s Legacy
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Backcountry Trip Across British Columbia’s Glaciers
text: THE Spearhead Traverse is a two- to four-day backcountry ski trip into the unpopulated alpine realm that awaits just beyond the boundary ropes of Whistler Blackcomb, in British Columbia. The epitome of high (and cold) lonesome, it’s a journey of glacier crossings, impossibly fresh snow and winter camping in tents and huts.

headline: Spare Times
text: AROUND TOWN

headline: Man Abandons Infant Girl in a Car for Hire in Queens
text: A man carrying a 6-month-old girl flagged down a black car for hire in Queens on Thursday and left the baby behind after asking the driver to stop, the police said.

headline: In His Nets Debut, Harris Leads the Way
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  As far as stopgap solutions go, Marcus Williams had been doing his part. Starting each of the four games since the Nets traded Jason Kidd to the Dallas Mavericks, he had averaged 12 points, 6.2 rebounds, and 7.3 assists.

headline: World Group Tells Banks to Beware Deals With Iran
text: WASHINGTON  In a move that strengthens the American-backed effort to isolate Iran, a leading international organization responsible for combating financial crimes called Thursday for all countries to be wary of Iran’s banking system because of concerns over money-laundering and aid to terrorists.

headline: Letting His Racing Colors Show
text: CONSIDERING that C. Steven Duncker is a master-of-the-universe type who is arguably addicted to action  be it at the track, on the trading floor, or across a poker table like the 2004 Main Event of the World Series of Poker  a monumental stillness emanates from his Upper East Side apartment. There is no sound of pounding hooves, though he has an oft-enjoyed home library of audio replays of his racehorses’ finer finishes.

headline: Art in Review
text: BARBARA T. SMITH

headline: The Word Is Out: Harry Is in Afghanistan
text: LONDON  For 10 weeks he has been in Afghanistan, deployed with the British Army in Helmand Province with the full knowledge of the rapacious British news media, and no one said a word.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the growing use of wind power in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount of money that Louis Brooks is paid for allowing 78 wind turbines on his ranch on the outskirts of Sweetwater, Tex. It is $500 a month for each, not $500 for all of them. The article also misstated the length of blades for new wind turbines that stand as high as 20-story buildings. The blades span about 200 feet; they are not “longer than a football field,” which is 300 feet. (Go to Article)

headline: Seductive Rebel Who Kept It Real
text: At the moment the Metropolitan Museum of Art, always a paradise of painting, is more edenic than ever. In less than four weeks it has opened three large exhibitions, each devoted to a master of sublime strangeness. First Jasper Johns, then Nicolas Poussin and now Gustave Courbet.

headline: Myron Cope, 79, Writer and Steelers Broadcaster, Is Dead
text: Myron Cope, the longtime broadcaster for the N.F.L’s Steelers who became a sports treasure in Pittsburgh with his distinctive vocabulary and his creation of the fans’ Terrible Towel, died Wednesday in Mount Lebanon, Pa. He was 79.

headline: Turkey Resists Gates’s Call to End Its Iraq Offensive
text: ANKARA, Turkey  Turkish leaders on Thursday resisted calls by Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates for a swift end to Turkey’s offensive against Kurdish guerrillas, offering no timetable for withdrawing their troops from northern Iraq.

headline: For Young Filmgoers, a Chance to Venture Far Beyond the Multiplex
text: On any recent weekend adult filmgoers could see big, commercial movies like “Vantage Point” and “Fool’s Gold,” or art-house foreign works like “The Band’s Visit” and “4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days.” Children could choose big, commercial movies like “The Spiderwick Chronicles” and the Miley Cyrus 3-D extravaganza, or art-house foreign works like ... like ...

headline: Groups Urge a Moratorium on City Use of Artificial Turf
text: Several environmental and civic groups are calling for a moratorium on the use of artificial turf in new sports fields in the city, and question the seriousness with which the Bloomberg administration is investigating the turf’s potential hazards.

headline: Romanticism, Aborning and in Full Flower
text: Romanticism was the engine that drove the recital by David Finckel and Wu Han at the Morgan Library & Museum on Tuesday evening, and if there was a message to be found in their program, it was that Romanticism covers a vast range of musical styles.

headline: The Sound Is Rural, the Setting Urban
text: “HOWDY, folks,” Chris Thile said one recent Tuesday night, as he twisted a peg on his mandolin. His audience, packed into the cozy Rockwood Music Hall on the Lower East Side, seemed to appreciate the salutation. Somebody voiced a request: “Over the Waterfall,” a bluegrass standard. “Second tune I ever learned,” he shot back, “after ‘Woody’s Rag.’ ”

headline: Energy Loss
text: David Novack’s documentary “Burning the Future: Coal in America” is as upsetting as it is informative. The movie concentrates on the Appalachian states  particularly West Virginia, the epicenter of an industry that mines enough coal to provide electricity for half the nation. In recent years increasing amounts of coal have been obtained through mountaintop mining, in which mountain ridges are scraped away by heavy machinery to get at the coal seams below.

headline: Nader’s No. 2
text: The 2008 campaign has its first official vice-presidential candidate, and it is not Mike Huckabee.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An article on Monday about Ralph Nader’s announcement that he is again running for president misstated the percentage of votes Mr. Nader received nationwide in the 2004 presidential election. He won 0.38 percent of the vote, not 0.3 percent. The article also misstated the reason that Mr. Nader was not on the ballot in California in 2004. It was because he did not gather enough signatures, not because of lawsuits and challenges filed by the Democratic Party.

headline: Jazz Listings
text: JAZZ

headline: Wiretapping Law
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bush May Take Foreign Money for Presidential Library
text: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Thursday that he would probably accept foreign donations to build his presidential library in Dallas and would consider keeping the donors’ names confidential if they do not want to be identified.

headline: Corrections
text: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a television station in Huntsville, Ala., that showed a black screen for 12 minutes on Sunday night during a “60 Minutes” report about possible political deception involving the former Bush administration official Karl Rove in the conviction of a former Democratic governor of Alabama referred incorrectly to one of the owners of the station. Robert M. Bass, manager of an investment company that bought the station, WHNT, last year, has been a contributor to Democratic Party candidates, but unlike his brothers in Texas, he has not been a contributor to President Bush. An editorial on Wednesday about WHNT going dark repeated the error. An article about an internal review of the incident by the Huntsville station is on Page C4 today.

headline: Rethinking Help for Children
text: The federal nutrition program known as WIC  for Women, Infants and Children  has enormous reach. It helps feed about 8 million people every day and, at one time or another during the course of a year, it helps provide nourishing meals for half of all America’s infants and one-quarter of its children.

headline: An Iconic Look in High Demand
text: “Often, people refuse to look at anything else,” said Terry Horrocks, owner of Prudential Terry Horrocks Real Estate in Lake Placid, N.Y., referring to Adirondack-style homes. Whether on a historic home or on new construction, the style’s twig-filigree detailing, stone appointments and bark-sheathed surfaces appeal to buyers who want to own a part of, or pay tribute to, the region’s rustic history.

headline: Exploring Small Stories of the Great War
text: With her new novel, “Life Class,” Pat Barker returns to the subject of World War I  a subject that earned her immense acclaim in the 1990s with her “Regeneration” trilogy (“Regeneration,” “The Eye in the Door” and “The Ghost Road”), an artful improvisation on the lives of the poets Siegfried Sassoon, Wilfred Owen, Robert Graves and their compatriots, which unfurled into a fierce meditation on the horrors of war and its psychological aftermath.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Sports Briefing column on Thursday about the announcement that Robert Kipkoech Cheruiyot will race in the Boston Marathon in April misstated the number of times the event has been held. This will be the 112th running, not the 111th.

headline: Yankee Joba Chamberlain, a ‘Big Kid’ at Heart
text: TAMPA, Fla.  If everything works out for Joba Chamberlain  and life has been a dream lately  he will start and finish this season with a trip to Disney World. That is where athletes go after winning a championship, and it is where Chamberlain is going this weekend, with a family from Nebraska in tow.

headline: Creature Discomforts
text: EVERYONE knows that unpleasant neighbors can take some of the fun out of a vacation house. They might be noisy. They might have junked cars in their front yards. They might bite.

headline: Wyeth Antidepressant Is Approved
text: Faced with the looming loss of patent protection for its top-selling drug, the antidepressant Effexor XR, Wyeth on Friday received federal approval for a follow-on drug, Pristiq, that the company hopes will also become a blockbuster.

headline: Minnesota Transportation Chief Is Out
text: Minnesota’s transportation commissioner was removed from her post on Thursday by the State Senate after several years of concern about the department’s performance, the low point of which was last summer’s deadly collapse of a highway bridge over the Mississippi River in Minneapolis and its aftermath.

headline: Theater Listings
text: WINTER REP 2008 While a season of plays presented in rotating repertory is common practice in summer stock, it is not the norm in the Off Off Broadway world. But the Oberon Theater Ensemble, now in its 11th season, has been presenting shows this way for a few years, and its current offerings include “Macbeth,” with James Holloway, above left, and William Laney, and Michael Weller’s “Ghost on Fire.”

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings
text: ART

headline: A Sign That Has Served Its Time
text: On one street corner in Lower Manhattan, the World Trade Center is still spoken of in the present tense, confusing some passers-by, enlightening many others.

headline: Correction
text: An editorial on Wednesday erred in saying that the medication Lipitor was losing market share to Zocor. It is losing market share to the generic version of Zocor.

headline: Revlon Swings to Quarterly Profit
text: Revlon, the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, posted its first quarterly profit in two years, bolstered by sales outside the United States and by savings from ending its Vital Radiance line.

headline: Rival Sisters Duke It Out for the Passion of a King
text: More slog than romp, “The Other Boleyn Girl” tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII. Best known for losing her head to the king, first metaphorically, then literally, Anne Boleyn (Natalie Portman, saucy), along with her sister, Mary (Scarlett Johansson, sedate), entered the court of the king (Eric Bana, brooding and glowering) when he was still wed to Catherine of Aragon (Ana Torrent). A man of considerable and changeable appetites, the king yearned for a male heir and anything in a frock who wasn’t the queen. His sexual wish was their command.

headline: U.S. Embrace of Musharraf Irks Pakistanis
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The Bush administration’s continued backing of President Pervez Musharraf, despite the overwhelming rejection of his party by voters this month, is fueling a new level of frustration in Pakistan with the United States.

headline: Remembering the Mentor
text: When I was in college, William F. Buckley Jr. wrote a book called “Overdrive” in which he described his glamorous lifestyle. Since I was young and a smart-aleck, I wrote a parody of it for the school paper.

headline: Supplier Strikes Idle 16,000 Auto Workers
text: DETROIT  More than 16,000 workers at General Motors and Chrysler have been temporarily laid off because strikes at two suppliers have created a shortage of parts at some of the carmakers’ factories.

headline: Bill Would Remove Doubt on Presidential Eligibility
text: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCain said Thursday that he had no concerns about his meeting the constitutional qualifications for the presidency because of his birth in the Panama Canal Zone. A Democratic colleague said she wanted to remove even a trace of doubt.

headline: Brooding on the Bayou
text: Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in “Little Chenier,” a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land  the kind of place where strangers are greeted with “Who your daddy?,” and the sheriff is up in everybody’s business.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Tuesday about Brad Guzan, a promising goalkeeper for the United States national team who was close to joining an English Premier League club, referred imprecisely to a requirement for a British work permit that Guzan failed to meet. He needed to have played in at least 75 percent of his national team’s official matches in the previous two years, not one year.

headline: Trader Accused of Betting Money He Didn’t Have
text: For nearly two decades Evan Dooley quietly made a living trading commodities like wheat in his home state, Tennessee, far from the hurly-burly of Wall Street.

headline: Sprint Nextel Posts $29.5 Billion Loss
text: Daniel R. Hesse, Sprint Nextel’s new chief executive, tells it like it is  but on Thursday, investors did not like what they heard.

headline: Declining to Enter Field, Mayor Eyes Sideline Role
text: For more than two years, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had the ultimate presidential campaign that wasn’t. Aides spent hundreds of hours and untold dollars plotting out a route to the White House. But the prospects for his maybe-I-will, maybe-I-won’t campaign were never tested in the quiet of a voting booth.

headline: Mike Smith, Lead Singer of Dave Clark 5, Is Dead
text: Mike Smith, the lead singer of The Dave Clark Five, died Thursday outside London, less than two weeks before the band is to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. He was 64.

headline: N.F.L. Free Agency Begins With Lack of Big Names
text: Maybe the surest sign of how quiet free agency is expected to be for anyone not named Asante Samuel comes from the flight plans for the plane owned by the Washington Redskins’ owner, Daniel Snyder.

headline: Boutique Bank That’s Riding Out the Storm
text: It was over sushi in Midtown Manhattan that Blair W. Effron and Robert A. Pruzan, two longtime Wall Street deal makers, began devising plans for a new investment bank.

headline: It’s a Hard Rock Life
text: “At this point in the play, we were planning a show tune,” says the roly-poly guy with the guitar and the funny eyeglasses. “An upbeat gotta-leave-this-town kinda show tune.”

headline: Germany: Gallery Shut After Muslim Threats
text: The authorities in Berlin closed a gallery whose exhibition included satirical works by Danish artists that caricatured the Kaaba shrine in Mecca after Muslims protested, the German news agency Deutsche Presse Agentur reported, citing the local arts council. The protesters had threatened to use violence if the posters of the Danish art group Surrend were not removed from the gallery, Galerie Nord, the report said.

headline: Hoping to Become the Next Hot Baseball Export From Japan
text: NAGO, Japan  No. 81 is the eighth uniform number of Masato Yoshii’s professional career.

headline: Families Help Care for Half of U.S. Preschoolers, Census Says
text: Grandparents serve as the primary caregivers for about 20 percent of the 11.3 million preschool children with employed mothers, according to data released Thursday by the Census Bureau.

headline: Knight Joins ESPN as a Commentator
text: Bob Knight, who recently resigned as the basketball coach at Texas Tech, will join ESPN next month as a television, radio and online commentator for the network’s championship week and the N.C.A.A. men’s tournament.

headline: Northrop and EADS Win Refueling Tanker Deal
text: In a surprising reversal for the Boeing Company, the Pentagon on Friday awarded a multibillion-dollar contract for refueling tankers to a partnership between Northrop Grumman and EADS, the European parent of Airbus.

headline: Painting Nature’s Grandeur With Music
text: The second week of December 1908 was a happy time for modern music. On Dec. 10 Olivier Messiaen was born in Paris. The next day Elliott Carter was born in New York. Miraculously, Mr. Carter remains alive and active. And though Messiaen died in 1992, his visionary work is being commemorated in concerts around the world.

headline: Corrections
text: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Saturday about the growing use of wind power in Texas referred imprecisely to the amount of money that Louis Brooks is paid for allowing 78 wind turbines on his ranch on the outskirts of Sweetwater, Tex. It is $500 a month for each, not $500 for all of them. The article also misstated the length of blades for new wind turbines that stand as high as 20-story buildings. The blades span about 200 feet; they are not “longer than a football field,” which is 300 feet.

headline: New Heathrow Runway Would Erase a Village
text: SIPSON, England  The fortunes of this little village have long depended on the fortunes of Heathrow Airport, just a couple of miles away. But just as it has lived for Heathrow, Sipson might have to die for Heathrow.

headline: Union Grows, but Leader Faces Criticism
text: Andy Stern has been hailed in some quarters as the nation’s top labor leader largely because his union, the Service Employees International Union, has added members faster than any other, 800,000 over the last decade.

headline: Panel Is Set to Examine Security at U.N. Sites
text: UNITED NATIONS  The director of a new panel that will look into attacks on United Nations offices said Thursday that the organization had to accept the fact that in many parts of the world it was no longer viewed as impartial and was therefore increasingly vulnerable.

headline: Missile Attack, Possibly by NATO, Kills 8 in Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Eight suspected Islamic militants, including four men of Middle Eastern origin and two from Central Asia, were killed early Thursday in a triple missile attack on a house used as a training facility in Pakistan’s tribal areas, a security official and residents said.

headline: Kenya Rivals Reach Peace Agreement
text: NAIROBI, Kenya  Kenya’s rival leaders broke their tense standoff on Thursday, agreeing to share power in a deal that may end the violence that has engulfed this nation but could be the beginning of a long and difficult political relationship.

headline: A Vermeer Painting Is Heading West
text: West Coast art lovers will be offered a rare opportunity to see a Vermeer when the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif., exhibits “A Lady Writing,” above, from Nov. 7 through Feb. 2, 2009. On loan from the National Gallery of Art in Washington, the painting, one of about 35 known works by Vermeer, will come to Pasadena as part of a series of exchanges between the Norton Simon foundations and the National Gallery. The program began last summer when the Norton Simon lent Rembrandt’s “Portrait of a Boy, Presumed to Be the Artist’s Son, Titus” to the National Gallery. “A Lady Writing” depicts a young woman poised to write with a quill pen as she sits at a desk, wearing an ermine-trimmed yellow morning jacket, pearl earrings and golden ribbons in her hair, with a strand of pearls and a ribbon on the desk. It is the first loan from the National Gallery to the Norton Simon.

headline: Pettitte Says He Hates Having a Role in a Legal Drama
text: TAMPA, Fla.  Andy Pettitte was not surprised to learn that his friend and former teammate Roger Clemens was being investigated by the Department of Justice for possibly making false statements to Congress earlier this month.

headline: Latest Troubles Put Detroit Mayor’s Job at Risk
text: DETROIT  This city has forgiven Kwame M. Kilpatrick, its towering, charismatic, next-generation mayor, before.

headline: Blood Thinner Might Be Tied to More Deaths
text: Amid indications that more people may have died or been harmed after being given a brand of the blood thinner heparin, federal drug regulators said Thursday that they had found “potential deficiencies” at a Chinese plant that supplied much of the active ingredient for the drug.

headline: A Life Spent Between Colored Strands and Colorful Strays
text: Mitzi’s future in West New York, N.J., where she lived in a down-and-out pocket of town, didn’t look particularly bright. She might have ended up on the street, like so many of her peers, if she hadn’t caught the eye of a beloved New York hair colorist named Grato Longoria. Within a year of that chance encounter, she was living on upper Madison Avenue, rolling around in 330-thread-count Matouk sheets and maintaining a meticulous grooming regimen.

headline: Leaving Las Vegas, for the Suburbs
text: WHEN Bob Carson set out last year to find a second home in the Las Vegas area, his list of must-haves was short but sweet.

headline: Logging in Congo River Basin Imperils Sea Turtles Very Far Downstream
text: The growth of logging in the rain forests of central Africa appears to be posing a long-distance threat to one of the world’s most important nesting grounds for several species of rare sea turtles  the coast of Gabon.

headline: A Hardy Cowgirl Endures the Pain and Longing on the Trail to Love
text: A prairie wind swept through the Allen Room on Wednesday night as the singer K. D. Lang and a five-member band conjured big-sky country where romantic dreamers infused the wide-open spaces with swooning desire. Listening to Ms. Lang’s languid interpretations of songs from her new album, “Watershed” (Nonesuch), as well as selections from her older records, an image surfaced of the singer as a hardy cowgirl, lost in reflection as she leans on a fence post and gazes toward the horizon.

headline: Profit Falls as Dell Tries to Grow and Limit Costs
text: SAN FRANCISCO  The midterm grades are in, and Dell says it has a lot more work to do.

headline: Rikers Island Counselor Is Charged With Selling Cocaine to an Officer
text: A substance abuse counselor assigned to a drug treatment unit at Rikers Island has been charged with selling $100 worth of cocaine to an undercover police officer.

headline: Exploitation’s Wheel Spins in London
text: It’s a free world, Ken Loach asserts in his latest film with well-practiced disgust and unfortunately little hope. This being a Loach film, it’s also a cruel world, populated by capitalist tools and fools, schemers and dreamers of every stripe, accent and ethnicity. In “It’s a Free World ...” it’s the war of all against all yet again, this time with fistfuls of filthy pound notes and mouths crammed with speeches and broken promises.

headline: 2 Are Seeking to Buy Into Concert Promoter
text: In a move that could alter the hierarchy of the live-music industry, the entertainment giant Cablevision and the ticketing powerhouse Ticketmaster are negotiating to acquire significant stakes in the nation’s No. 2 concert promoter, AEG Live, people briefed on the talks said Thursday.

headline: Russia’s Last Hope
text: Moscow

headline: A Biennial Bustin’ Out of the Whitney
text: Old mattresses springs

headline: Spending Flat as Inflation Persists
text: Rising prices are forcing Americans to spend more and save less, even as the growth of income slows.

headline: Near Arctic, Seed Vault Is a Fort Knox of Food
text: LONGYEARBYEN, Norway  With plant species disappearing at an alarming rate, scientists and governments are creating a global network of plant banks to store seeds and sprouts, precious genetic resources that may be needed for man to adapt the world’s food supply to climate change.

headline: Three Kinds of Emotional Baggage
text: Three women converge on the road to self-awareness in “Vivere,” a moody drama from the German director Angelina Maccarone.

headline: Officials Split on Viability of Border-Fence Project
text: A top Homeland Security Department official said Thursday that a pilot project to create a virtual fence along parts of the Mexican border had been a success, but he said the technology was never intended to be used  and would not be used  across the entire length of the border.

headline: Ousted Premier Returns to Thailand
text: BANGKOK  Back home in Thailand from a 17-month voluntary exile after his ouster in a military coup, former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra was released on bail on corruption charges Thursday and began his new life as a criminal defendant.

headline: New Clinton Ad Prompts Reply From Obama
text: WACO, Tex.  Playing on anxieties about national security, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has produced a “red phone moment” advertisement that suggests she would be better able to respond to a crisis than Senator Barack Obama.

headline: The Eiffel Tower Is Always Ready for Its Close-Up
text: Paris in the springtime, Paris in the fall. Paris when it drizzles and when it sizzles, and of course Paris in April. In the words of Cole Porter, “Until you’ve lived a lot, and loved a lot, and lost a lot, you don’t know Paree.”

headline: One Is Killed and Three Are Injured in Crash Involving Stolen Car Fleeing the Police
text: A man was killed and three people were injured in Brooklyn early Thursday when their car was hit by a stolen vehicle whose driver had been fleeing the police at speeds of up to 100 miles an hour, the authorities said.

headline: Correction: For the Record
text: An art review in Weekend last Friday about “Parmigianino’s ‘Antea’: A Beautiful Artifice,” at the Frick Collection, misidentified the arm of the painting’s subject that “looks illogically long” and has a gloved hand. It is her right arm, not the left.

headline: PATH’s Anniversary
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time and Time Again
text: The Bush administration has tried repeatedly to kill or shortchange government surveys. Motivated in part by pound foolishness, but also by a disdain for information that might upset partisan or ideological agendas, the attempts have had mixed results. Taken together, however, they amount to an assault on reliable data that’s necessary to judge the effectiveness of existing government programs and the need for new ones.

text: Two of the biggest trade deadline pickups played their first games with their new teams Thursday.

text: DIYALA PROVINCE, Iraq – “Tell them we are staying,” ordered Lt. Col. Rod Coffey, nodding toward the Iraqis clustered nervously in the driveway beside his armored Stryker vehicle.

headline: ‘America Hadn’t Been Discovered Yet’
text: Aired Thursday night on “The Late Late Show With Craig Ferguson” on CBS: John McCain might not be eligible to run for the presidency because he was born outside of America. Now, I actually think this is unfair, because when McCain was born, technically, America hadn’t been discovered yet.

headline: Write-Down Sends A.I.G. to $5 Billion Loss
text: American International Group on Thursday posted its biggest quarterly loss ever, missing Wall Street expectations after being hurt by a write-down of derivatives exposed to bad mortgage investments.

headline: XM Satellite Radio Posts Narrower Loss
text: XM Satellite Radio Holdings, awaiting regulatory approval for its merger with Sirius Satellite Radio, said on Thursday that it narrowed its fourth-quarter loss, helped by a 20 percent increase in revenue and a favorable comparison to last year, when the company took a significant write-down.

headline: U.S. Investigates 2 Wachovia Employees
text: Wachovia, the bank based in Charlotte, N.C., said Thursday that two employees in its main banking unit are targets of a Department of Justice inquiry of municipal bid rigging.

headline: Clean-Tech Reaps More Green from V.C.’s
text: Global venture-capital investment in clean technologies rose 43 percent last year to a record $3 billion, overwhelmingly in the United States, according to an annual survey of the industry.

headline: Covad Pays $7 Milion to Settle Suit by Former General Counsel
text: Covad Communications and its ex-general counsel have finally laid to rest a sordid, six-year saga of allegations of self-dealing directors, sexual harassment and retaliatory firing.

headline: Onex Sees Challenges Ahead
text: The Canadian private-equity group Onex said Thursday its pace of investment will slow this year as the “upheaval” in credit markets makes financing large deals more difficult.

headline: Bally Fitness Settles S.E.C. Fraud Charges
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil lawsuit against Bally Total Fitness Holding, alleging the Chicago health-club chain violated securities law — and misled investors — by issuing financial reports that fraudulently misrepresented Bally’s financial condition during the years from 1997 to 2003.

headline: Digg’s Rose Tamps Down Deal Speculation
text: If you believe the blog rumors, Kevin rose, the founder of Digg, a news site where readers rank stories, is constantly dealing with perpetual acquisition offers from companies such as Google and News Corporation.

headline: British American Tobacco Signs $4.14 Billion Deal for Danish Rival
text: British American Tobacco, the world’s second-biggest cigarette maker, has agreed a 20.3 billion Danish kroner ($4.14 billion) deal to buy Scandinavia’s leading tobacco group in its second major acquisition in seven days.

headline: Struggling Fremont May Go on the Block
text: A struggling California bank, Fremont General on late Thursday said it might sell itself as it faces a serious liquidity crunch.

headline: C.I.B.C. Takes $1.49 Billion Write-Down
text: Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce reported a first-quarter loss of 1.46 billion Canadian dollars ($1.49 billion) on Thursday, compared to a profit of 770 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, as the bank took a slew of charges related to its subprime mortgage exposure.

headline: Peloton Partners Said to Put Flagship Assets on the Block
text: One of London’s most successful hedge funds imploded Thursday when Peloton Partners put the assets of its $2 billion flagship fund up for sale and froze its remaining fund after mortgage trades left it unable to meet lenders’ demands, according to The Financial Times.

headline: Ross to Inject Up to $1 Billion Into Assured Guaranty
text: Wilbur L. Ross will acquire up to a $1 billion stake in bond insurer Assured Guaranty in a private placement, the company said Friday morning. He will also join Assured’s board of directors.

headline: Alcoa Accused of Fraud by Firm in Bahrain
text: A smelting firm in Bahrain is seeking more than $1 billion in a lawsuit against the aluminum manufacturer Alcoa, accusing it of a 15-year conspiracy involving overcharging, fraud and bribery.

headline: Conrad Black Loses Bond Appeal
text: Conrad Black, the former media mogul, cannot remain free on bond pending the outcome of his appeal and must report to prison Monday, the Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals ruled Thursday.

headline: 2 Are Seeking to Buy Into Concert Promoter
text: In a move that could alter the hierarchy of the live-music industry, the entertainment giant Cablevision and the ticketing powerhouse Ticketmaster are negotiating to acquire significant stakes in the nation’s No. 2 concert promoter, AEG Live, The New York Times reported.

headline: CardioNet Pushing Ahead With I.P.O.
text: The initial public offering of CardioNet, a wireless heart monitoring company, is showing a pulse.

headline: Univision’s Music Assets Are Sold
text: The Universal Music Group, the world’s biggest music conglomerate, reached a deal to acquire the recorded music and music publishing assets of Univision, the Spanish-language media giant, the companies said on Thursday.

headline: Cazenove Boss Resigns Amid Reported Tensions With JPMorgan
text: Robert Pickering has resigned from his post as chief executive of Cazenove, the British bank, in a surprise move that has triggered speculation about its future.

headline: Mascoma Bulks Up With $50 Million Round
text: Mascoma, an East Coast biofuel startup with a multi-pronged approach to commercializing cellulosic ethanol, has just become one of the most heavily funded companies of its kind with a $50 million funding round first reported by peHUB.

headline: China Construction May Raise $5.4 Billion in Dual I.P.O.
text: China Railway Construction, a major contractor in China, began subscriptions Friday for an initial public offering in Hong Kong that, along with a Shanghai share offering, is expected to raise up to $5.4 billion.

headline: TidalTV Gest $15 Million Wave of Funding
text: A Web TV start-up, TidalTV, has closed a $15 million first round of funding led by New Enterprise Associates and Valhalla Partners.

headline: Merrill Lynch to Close Subprime Lending Unit, Report Says
text: Merrill Lynch plans to wind down most of its First Franklin subprime mortgage lending unit, responding to continued deterioration in United States mortgage markets, CNBC reported.

headline: Regulator Fines Brokerages Over Mutual Fund Sales
text: Brokerages, including units of Merrill Lynch and UBS, have agreed to pay $2.4 million in fines and reimburse more than $20 million to customers to settle investigations of improper mutual fund sales and transfers, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday.

headline: Germany’s DZ Bank Reports 1.36 Billion Euro Writedown
text: One of the biggest financial groups in Germany, the DZ Bank, joined the country’s growing list of casualties from the subprime mortgage crisis on Thursday by posting 1.36 billion euros in write-downs.

headline: Syms Shares Soar in Re-Listing
text: Shares of the off-price clothing retailer Syms, which delisted its shares from the New York Stock Exchange last month, soared 11 percent after they began trading on the Nasdaq.

headline: China Wealth Fund to Hire Foreign Money Managers
text: The China Investment Corporation, the $200 billion Chinese sovereign wealth fund, is hiring foreign fund managers to invest in hedge funds and private equity, as well as in traditional assets like bonds and shares.

headline: Investors Move Against Bear Stearns in Hedge Fund Fight
text: Rebel investors have seized two failed Bear Stearns hedge funds in a move their lawyers hope will give them a platform to sue the bank for compensation, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Are Today’s ‘Rogues’ Yesterday’s ‘Superstars’?
text: What’s with the flurry of rogue trading? In the last six months, there have been at least three big losses tied to unauthorized trades, with the latest coming from a wheat trader at MF Gloabl.

headline: Take-Two Says Other Bidders Have Come Knocking
text: Take-Two Interactive Software said late Thursday that it haD received expressions of interest from other potential bidders since Electronic Arts unveiled a $2 billion takeover offer for the company earlier this week.

headline: Would Yahoo Investors Shudder at Bigger Microsoft Bid?
text: Yahoo‘s biggest shareholders who also hold stock in Microsoft might not demand that Microsoft raise its $44.6 billion takeover offer because there is more to lose from a decline in their holdings of the buyer, analysts at Friedman Billings Ramsey Group said.

headline: Recipe of the Day: Spanish Tortilla
text: The Spanish tortilla has nothing in common with the Mexican tortilla except its shape and its name. One is just a bread. The other can be an appetizer, a snack, or even a light meal. In its most basic form, it’s a potato and egg open-faced omelet that derives most of its flavor from olive oil.

headline: Top Officer at Bell Shooting Testifies
text: Lt. Gary Napoli, the commanding officer who was supervising several New York City police detectives when they fatally shot Sean Bell in November 2006, gave a first-hand account today of the shooting — the most detailed account so far in the trial of three of the detectives.Lieutenant Napoli, who took the stand on Thursday afternoon in State Supreme Court in Queens, continued his testimony today. He recalled being in a car with two colleagues — Detectives Paul Headley and Marc Cooper — not far from Club Kalua, early on the morning of Nov. 25, 2006, when he got a frantic call on his cellphone from one of his detectives, Gescard F. Isnora.

Two years ago he collaborated, with the city’s Parks Department and Economic Development Corporation, and the lighting designer Leni Schwendinger, to re-light the dormant Boardwalk ride, promoting it as a beacon to draw eyes toward Coney Island.

headline: Some Still Dream of a Third-Party Run
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg may have finally put the kibosh on running for president this year, but that does not mean the independent stalwarts are giving up their dreams of electing a third-party president. Frank MacKay of the Independence Party of New York said on Thursday that Mr. Bloomberg’s decision not to run for president was “certainly disappointing” but not so much that anyone had been told “to keep me away from sharp objects or anything like that.”Indeed, he is already moving on, talking with other potential candidates to carry the torch now that Mr. Bloomberg won’t.

headline: The Cure for Exhaustion? More Exercise

headline: All About the M.T.A. Fare Increase
text: Updated, 9:40 p.m. | Even the most seasoned subway and bus riders might be a bit confused by some aspects of the fare increases that take effect at 12:01 a.m. Sunday. Passengers who buy regular pay-per-ride MetroCards will start to see odd amounts left over on their cards. Those who buy MetroCards at supermarkets and newsstands will find themselves paying amounts like $17.39 and $52.17. And New Yorkers who want to hoard unlimited-ride MetroCards at the present cost should beware: the M.T.A. won’t say how long the cards will be honored.

headline: Fatal Stabbing at Key Food on Lower East Side
text: Updated, March 1 | Two female workers, ages 24 and 27, were stabbed — one fatally — inside a Key Food grocery store on the Lower East Side this afternoon, by a man who then fled and is still at large, the police said. The suspect, later identified as James Gonzalez, 42, ran from the store after the attack and apparently dropped the knife outside, near Avenue A and East Fourth Street, the police said. The 24-year-old, later identified as Tina Negron, was stabbed in the torso. At 5:45 p.m. she was confirmed to have died from her injuries at Beth Israel Hospital, where both women were taken for treatment.

headline: American to its Core
text: I love to think of this play as super-American, and that “American” is, as Jeff put it, “a big stew of meat and potatoes confrontations,” and a brainy one at that. But “August” is not brainy to the degree of preachiness or wrought with heavy literary earnestness. It is not at all condescending, and — though I know America is so often perceived as haughty and arrogant — it is this America, this mix of high and low, as Frank points out, and this humor that’s loaded with so much humanity, that I like to think of as ours. That the play is breaking rules that I haven’t even considered, as Marsha so fascinatingly explained, is all the more reason to call it American to its core.

Eliot Spitzer told a story Thursday morning about the role of President Martin Van Buren — one of his predecessors as governors of New York — in the origins of the phrase “O.K.” But in venturing into the world of etymology, Mr. Spitzer offered an account that is a matter of some dispute.

headline: Nader’s Running Mate Was Not Such a Fan in ’04
text: Back in June 2004, Matt Gonzalez, the young president of the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, spoke candidly to a group of the nation’s top college journalists as part of a prestigious writing competition.

headline: Settling Very Old Scores in South Korea
text: To what extent should people be made to pay today for what their parents or grandparents did more than 60 years ago?

headline: Remembering That There’s a War Going On
text: Whether it’s due to election year politics, conviction, or a combination of the two, we’re encouraged to see Senate Democrats planning an energetic re-examination of America’s Iraq policy over the next couple of months.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 29
text: Here is a slide show of photographs that tell the story of the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the 15th anniversary of the first World Trade Center bombing, a new swimming pool in Flushing and a mural by Tattfoo Tan in Dumbo.

headline: Graffiti in Berlin
text: Graffiti artists show off what may be the world's most colorful city.

headline: In This Week’s Magazine: Speak, ‘Tootsie’
text: “Tootsie” came out in 1982, when most Americans assumed that if you didn’t catch a movie while it was playing in theaters, you might never see it. Moviegoers were largely ignoring the climactic developments in home-entertainment technology — including the so-called format war between Betamax and VHS — that would, in the coming decades, transform not just movie watching but also home design and romantic relationships. The best format for audiovisual data storage was still considered to be the human memory.

headline: CNBC Video: Bayh on Sovereign Wealth Funds
text: Sovereign wealth funds have gained a harsh spotlight from Washington over the past year, as one American firm after another has taken billions of dollars from these overseas investors. Politicians in Congress have bemoaned the coming of another selling of America to foreigners, this time wealthy funds run by governments in the Middle East and eastern Asia.

headline: Graffiti in Berlin
text: Graffiti artists show off what may be the world's most colorful city.

headline: Kenya's Tourism Industry in Shambles
text: Months of violence have taken their toll on Kenya's tourism industry. Jeffrey Gettleman reports from the Masai Mara game reserve.

headline: An Italian Designer’s Sleek Interpretation of Green
text: The Geneva auto show is right around the corner (press days start on Monday). Over the past couple of weeks, Italdesign Giugiaro, the Italian design firm founded by Giorgetto Giugiaro (of DeLorean fame) has been leaking sneak peeks of its latest show car. On Friday, Italdesign released final images ahead of its press conference at the show next week.

headline: Getting to Know Them
text: If they turn out to be their party’s nominees, both Barack Obama and John McCain need to educate voters about themselves in some pretty basic, and challenging, ways. The Democratic candidate has to give voters a better sense of what he stands for, and the Republican candidate has to assure members of his own party that he is conservative enough.

headline: UrbanEye: 'Passing Strange'
text: The new musical (or perhaps opera, or perhaps rock show) 'Passing Strange' opens at the Belasco Theater on Broadway.  Melena Ryzik reports.
